0.53923285.15604432.html.plaintext.txt	211	Received 26 July 2004; accepted 1 October 2004.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	0	DNA-containing and empty hepatitis B virus core particles bind similarly to envelope protein domains Christophe Hourioux1, Antoine Touze2, Pierre Coursaget2 and Philippe Roingeard1.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	1	Laboratoires de Biologie Cellulaire et Virologie, EA 2639 Analyse Structurale des Antigenes, Faculte de Medecine, Institut Federatif de Recherche Transposons et Virus, Universite Francois Rabelais, 2 bis Boulevard Tonnelle, F-37032 Tours Cedex, France1 Laboratoire de Virologie Moleculaire, EA 2637 Processus Infectieux et Tumoraux, Faculte des Sciences Pharmaceutiques  Philippe Maupas , Institut Federatif de Recherche Transposons et Virus, Universite Francois Rabelais, Tours, France2.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	2	Author for correspondence: Philippe Roingeard.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	3	   Abstract Top Abstract Main text References   DNA synthesis within the hepatitis B virus (HBV) nucleocapsid appears to be coupled to nucleocapsid envelopment.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The nature of the envelopment signal is unknown, but is thought to involve a conformational change at the surface of the capsid that facilitates interaction with HBV envelope proteins.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In binding assays in vitro, it was found that empty HBV core particles bound synthetic peptides corresponding to HBV envelope protein domains with the same affinity as did HBV DNA-containing core particles.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This suggests that the selection of replication-competent nucleocapsids for envelopment is not related to the capacity of DNA-containing core particles to bind specifically to HBV envelope proteins, and that there must be an alternative mechanism.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	7	   Main text Top Abstract Main text References   Human hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a member of the hepadnaviruses, a family of small, enveloped viruses with partially double-stranded, circular DNA genomes that replicate by reverse transcription (Ganem  and  Varmus, 1987 ).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	8	 During initiation of infection, virus particles deliver their DNA to the nucleus, where it is converted to a covalently closed, circular DNA molecule that acts as a transcriptional template for the production of an RNA genome (the pregenome) (Tuttleman et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The RNA pregenome and the viral polymerase are encapsidated in the cytoplasm by viral capsid proteins to form immature nucleocapsid particles within which viral DNA synthesis occurs.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Initially, a minus-strand DNA is synthesized by reverse transcription of the pregenome.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	11	 This minus-strand DNA is then used as a template for plus-strand synthesis (reviewed by Nassal, 1996 ).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Thereafter, nucleocapsids interact with surface proteins embedded in a lipid bilayer of a post-endoplasmic reticulum, pre-Golgi compartment and bud into the lumen of this compartment to form mature virions (Roingeard et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1990 ; Bruss  and  Ganem, 1991 ; Huovila et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	14	Previous studies have shown that immature nucleocapsids containing pregenomic RNA are incompetent for envelopment and that minus-strand DNA synthesis must be completed for core particle envelopment to occur (Wei et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This suggests that DNA synthesis within the capsid is coupled to the appearance of a signal on the exterior of the nucleocapsid that is essential for nucleocapsid envelopment.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The molecular nature of this envelopment signal is unknown, but it is thought to involve the specific binding of DNA-containing core particles, but not of RNA-containing core particles, to HBV envelope proteins (Hui et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	17	 We have recently investigated the core to envelope interactions involved in the maturation of HBV, using in vitro assays to determine the capacity of HBV core particles to bind a panel of synthetic peptides that map to HBV envelope proteins (Poisson et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	18	 A short domain of the large (L) envelope protein (aa 96 to 116 in the ayw subtype) and a short domain in the cytosolic loop of the small (S) envelope protein (aa 56 to 80) were found to bind HBV core particles efficiently.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The L envelope domain found to interact with HBV core particles was subsequently shown to be essential for virion morphogenesis in two independent studies with envelope mutants, in which this domain was substituted by random sequence (Bruss, 1997 ) or deleted (Le Seyec et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	20	 A recent study with the S domain confirmed that deletions and/or amino acid substitutions within this domain hinder subviral particle morphogenesis and therefore provide no information about the role of this domain in virion packaging (Jenna  and  Sureau, 1998 ).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	21	Our previous assays of the binding of HBV core particles to HBV envelope peptides were performed with purified, liver-derived core particles containing HBV DNA (Poisson et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In this study, we used similar assays to compare the binding of these DNA-containing core particles with that of empty HBV core particles, obtained by using the baculovirus expression system.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These particles, called HBV core particles, were obtained by expression of the sequence encoding the first 144 amino acids of the HBV core gene (excluding the arginine-rich C-terminal stretch of 39 amino acids responsible for pregenome binding) and have been described elsewhere (Touze et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	24	 1) and binding assays were described previously (Poisson et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	25	 We used two 25-residue peptides, S1 and S2, that together covered the cytosolic loop of the HBV S protein.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	26	 To cover the cytosolic domain of the HBV L protein, we used five peptides of 28, 28, 29, 23 and 55 residues named L1, L2, L3, L4 and L5, respectively (L1 to L4 corresponded to the pre-S1 domain and L5 corresponded to the pre-S2 domain).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Two additional peptides overlapping peptide L4 were used: peptide L4a (the last 10 residues of peptide L3 plus the first eight residues of peptide L4) and peptide L4b (the last 13 residues of peptide L4 plus the first eight residues of peptide L5).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	28	View larger version (11K):    Fig.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Synthetic peptides that map the cytoplasmic domains of the HBV S and L envelope proteins.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The S protein (226 residues) spans the membrane at its N-terminal type I and central type II signals (open boxes) and probably twice at its hydrophobic C-terminal region.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The S protein exposes a loop of 50 residues covered by peptides S1 and S2.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The L protein contains S plus the 55 residues of the pre-S2 domain, covered by peptide L5, and the 108 residues (ayw subtype) of the pre-S1 domain, covered by peptides L1, L2, L3 and L4.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Two overlapping peptides, L4a and L4b, complete this mapping.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	34	  Dynatech ELISA plates were coated with the various peptides coupled to BSA (or with BSA alone) at a concentration of 20  microg/ml in 0 05 M bicarbonate buffer (pH 9 6) for 24 h at 4  degrees C (200  microl per well).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Plates were washed three times with 0 01 M PBS containing 0 15 M NaCl, pH 7 4, and 0 5% Tween 20 and were blocked by adding 300  microl PBS containing 2% newborn calf serum (NBCS) and incubating for 45 min at 37  degrees C.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The plates were washed once and the HBV core preparations were adjusted to the same concentration (estimated by immunocapture ELISA and electron microscopy to be around 105 core particles/ml) in 1 mM PBS plus 15 mM NaCl, pH 7 4, and were incubated for 24 h at 4  degrees C with the peptides.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The plates were washed three times and 100  microl of anti-HBc monoclonal antibody 6C6A1, diluted 1:10000 in 0 05 M PBS, 0 75 M NaCl, pH 7 4, containing 5% NBCS, 5% BSA and 0 5% Tween 20, was added.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The plates were incubated for 1 h at room temperature and then washed three times and 100  microl horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-mouse F(ab')2 (Tago), diluted 1:10000 in the same buffer, was added.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Plates were incubated for 30 min at 37  degrees C and washed three times.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	40	 A mixture of hydrogen peroxide and o-phenylenediamine was added and the plates were left for 30 min in the dark at room temperature.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Colour development was stopped with 1 M H2SO4 and absorbance was read at 492 nm.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The cut-off value chosen was twice the mean value obtained from eight control wells containing BSA alone (2x0 035 in a representative experiment).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Binding activity for a given peptide was expressed as the absorbance/cut-off value.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	44	We found that HBV core particles bound the L and S HBV envelope peptide domains with the same affinity as liver-derived, HBV DNA-containing capsids (Table 1).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	45	 We cannot rule out the hypothesis that, in the absence of their C-terminal part, our truncated capsids could adopt a structure that resembles that of DNA-containing capsids, thus explaining their binding to envelope peptides.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	46	 This is unlikely, however, because others have demonstrated the ability of full-length, E.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	47	 coli-derived HBV capsids to bind to HBV L envelope protein expressed in rabbit reticulocyte lysates (Tan et al.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Therefore, our results suggest that the selection of replication-competent nucleocapsids for envelopment is not related to a particular capacity of DNA-containing nucleocapsids to bind HBV envelope proteins.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Binding of BSA-coupled HBV envelope peptides to HBV DNA-containing, liver-derived HBV core particles and to empty, baculovirus-derived HBV core particles.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	50	  Alternatively, HBV DNA-containing capsids may interact with a cellular factor, such as a molecular chaperone or an element of the cytoskeleton involved in cell trafficking.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	51	 We recently analysed HBV morphogenesis in HepG2 cells transfected with HBV DNA and showed that nucleocapsids seems to regroup and bud into specific areas of dilated host cell compartments (Roingeard  and  Sureau, 1998 ).
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	52	 This suggests that there may be a specific transport of DNA-containing core particles towards these cellular compartments.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Such a mechanism may depend on host cell factors binding specifically to DNA-containing core particles, resulting in the selection of these core particles for envelopment.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	54	 In vitro binding assays will be of value for identifying these host factors that potentially bind HBV core particles.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Such studies may reveal novel targets for specific antiviral strategies.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	56	 was supported by a fellowship from the Association pour la Recherche contre le Cancer (ARC), France.
0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	57	   References Top Abstract Main text References   Bruss, V.
