0.2416355.10725437.html.plaintext.txt	92	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS INT J SYST EVOL MICROBIOL MICROBIOLOGY J GEN VIROL J MED MICROBIOL ALL SGM JOURNALS.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	0	Modes of intercellular transcription factor movement in the Arabidopsis apex Xuelin Wu1, Jose R.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Crawford3, Yoon Rhee4, Vitaly Citovsky4, Patricia C.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Zambryski3 and Detlef Weigel1,5,*.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	3	1 Plant Biology Laboratory, The Salk Institute for Biological Studies, La Jolla, CA 92037, USA 2 Department of Biology, University of California San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, USA 3 Department of Plant and Microbial Biology, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA 4 Department of Biochemistry and Cell Biology, State University of New York, Stony Brook, NY 11794-5215, USA 5 Department of Molecular Biology, Max Planck Institute for Developmental Biology, D-72076 Tubingen, Germany.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	4	* Author for correspondence (e-mail: weigel{at}weigelworld.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	5	   SUMMARY TOP SUMMARY INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   A recent and intriguing discovery in plant biology has been that some transcription factors can move between cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In Arabidopsis thaliana, the floral identity protein LEAFY has strong non-autonomous effects when expressed in the epidermis, mediated by its movement into underlying tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	7	 By contrast, a structurally unrelated floral identity protein, APETALA1, has only limited non-autonomous effects.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Using GFP fusions to monitor protein movement in the shoot apical meristem and in floral primordia of Arabidopsis, we found a strong correlation between cytoplasmic localization of proteins and their ability to move to adjacent cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The graded distribution of several GFP fusions with their highest levels in the cells where they are produced is compatible with the notion that this movement is driven by diffusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We also present evidence that protein movement is more restricted laterally within layers than it is from L1 into underlying layers of the Arabidopsis apex.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Based on these observations, we propose that intercellular movement of transcription factors can occur in a non-targeted fashion as a result of simple diffusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This hypothesis raises the possibility that diffusion is the default state for many macromolecules in the Arabidopsis apex, unless they are specifically retained.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	13	Key words: Arabidopsis, Protein trafficking, Movement protein, LEAFY, APETALA1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	14	   INTRODUCTION TOP SUMMARY INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Intercellular communication is essential in determining and enforcing developmental fates in all multicellular organisms.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In animals, this process relies mainly on secreted signaling peptides, which interact with the extracellular matrix, and specific cell surface receptors.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The interaction first triggers a signal transduction response in the cytoplasm of the target cells, and eventually leads to changes in gene expression.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Complex protein-protein interactions and multiple protein phosphorylation steps are involved in many of these pathways, such as the EGF, TGFss, Notch, Hedgehog and WNT family signaling pathways.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	18	 An alternative form of communication is achieved by the diffusion of transcription factors from their sources to the target nuclei through a continuous cytoplasm, such as the syncytium of Drosophila blastoderm embryos, one of the best understood model systems for transcriptional regulation (Rivera-Pomar and Jackle, 1996).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	19	 However, syncytial organization is restricted to only a few tissues in metazoans.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	20	Although plants lack homologs of the well-known metazoan peptide ligands, such as EGF, TGFss or Hedgehog, plant cells can also communicate via secreted molecules (Fletcher et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	21	, 2001; McCarty and Chory, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	22	 However, in contrast to animals, cytoplasmic continuity between plant cells is the rule, not the exception.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Most plant cells are connected by plasmodesmata, plasma membrane-lined channels that provide cytoplasmic continuity between adjacent cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Plasmodesmata, which are used in the transport of nutrients and signaling molecules including RNAs and proteins, can be divided into two major groups (Crawford and Zambryski, 1999; Haywood et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The primary plasmodesmata form during cytokinesis, whereas the secondary plasmodesmata develop between cells that are not necessarily clonally related.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The size exclusion limit (SEL) of the different types of plasmodesmata can be measured using fluorescent tracer molecules.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In most cases, plasmodesmata in younger tissues have larger SEL and are morphologically simpler than those in older tissue (Crawford and Zambryski, 2001).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	28	Two modes of movement through plasmodesmata have been proposed.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Targeted movement involves specific interactions between the transported macromolecules and plasmodesmata components.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	30	 This leads to an increase in the SEL and is therefore not limited by the endogenous SEL of a given cell.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	31	 By contrast, non-targeted movement resembles passive diffusion and is governed by the endogenous SEL of the plasmodesmata involved (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000; Imlau et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The best understood case of targeted movement is probably the trafficking of plant viral movement proteins (MPs), which can move over long distances in plants and are key to the spreading of plant viral infections.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	33	 A good example of non-targeted movement is provided by green fluorescent protein (GFP).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Using transient transfection by bombardment, it has been shown that native GFP can move several cells away from its source.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In addition to the SEL, multimerization and the addition of nuclear or ER localization signals can hinder, or even prevent, GFP from leaving the source cell (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000; Crawford and Zambryski, 2001).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	36	Apart from viral proteins, studies of macromolecule movement in plants have focused traditionally on long-distance transport of photosynthates and larger molecules or complexes through the phloem (Lucas, 1995; Zambryski and Crawford, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	37	 A good example is the sucrose transporter SUT1, whose mRNA is transported into the phloem before it is translated (Kuhn et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Moreover, grafting experiments have demonstrated the existence of long-distance mRNA movement in plants (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	39	 More recently, studies conducted in several plant species have demonstrated that non-cell-autonomous effects of transcription factors involved in plant development can be mediated by protein movement (reviewed by Haywood et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	40	The first example of transcription factor movement was discovered through studies of the homeodomain protein KNOTTED1 (KN1) in maize.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Most plant organs originate post-embryonically from meristems, which include stem cells set aside during embryogenesis.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	42	 In the aerial part of the plant, new organs emerge from the shoot apical meristem (SAM), which consists of three tissue layers, L1-L3.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	43	 KN1 protein is found throughout the maize SAM but kn1 mRNA is absent from the L1 layer (Jackson et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	44	 In leaf injection experiments, not only was KN1 transported to the surrounding tissue through plasmodesmata, but KN1 also increased the SEL of plasmodesmata, enabling the transport of kn1 sense RNA and protein complexes (Kragler et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	45	 KN1 can also move away from its source of expression when expressed from heterologous promoters in Arabidopsis (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	46	 There is similar evidence that the Antirrhinum MADS-box transcription factor DEFICIENS (DEF) moves from inner to outer tissue layers in developing flowers, although the extent of movement is stage- and organ-dependent (Perbal et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	47	In Arabidopsis, two endogenous transcription factors move into neighboring cells: SHORTROOT (SHR) (Nakajima et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	48	, 2001) and LEAFY (LFY) (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	49	 RNA of the GRAS-family transcription factor SHR is expressed in the stele of the root (Helariutta et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	50	, 2000), but SHR protein is found in both the stele and the surrounding endodermis, which is missing in shr mutants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Further studies using transgenic misexpression confirmed that movement of SHR from the root stele to endodermis is required for endodermis development (Nakajima et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	52	 RNA of the plant-specific transcription factor LFY is expressed in all three layers of young floral primordia, which are mis-specified as shoots in strong lfy mutants (Weigel et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Surprisingly, LFY RNA expression in the L1 of developing flowers is sufficient to fully rescue the lfy-mutant phenotype.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	54	 In such transgenic plants, LFY protein, but not LFY RNA, is detected in all layers of the rescued flowers, indicating that LFY protein moves from the L1 into inner layers (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	55	 By contrast, the transcription factor APETALA1 (AP1), which has similar in vivo functions as LFY but is structurally unrelated, behaves largely cell-autonomously (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	56	Although movement of transcription factors in Arabidopsis and other plants is by now well-established, there are still major gaps in understanding the underlying mechanisms.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Here, we characterize the mode of LFY movement in Arabidopsis SAMs and floral primordia.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Using functional LFY-GFP fusion proteins, we show that LFY moves more readily from the L1 into deeper cell layers than laterally into adjacent, clonally related cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	59	 By contrast, a functional AP1-GFP fusion is unable to move from its source cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Comparison of the dynamics of LFY-GFP fusion proteins with other GFP fusions suggests that this movement is driven by diffusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Deletion experiments failed to identify a specific movement signal in LFY, which is compatible with the conclusion that LFY movement is non-targeted.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The hypothesis of non-targeted movement is also supported by the finding of a correlation between cytoplasmic localization and the ability of these proteins to move to adjacent cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	63	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP SUMMARY INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Transgenes See Table 1 for a list of transgenes used in this study.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	64	  LFY-GFP fusions PstI sites were added to both ends of the mGFP5 coding sequence (Haseloff et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	65	, 1997) using oligonucleotide primers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The GFP PstI fragment was inserted into the internal PstI site of a LFY cDNA in pAS116 (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	67	, 2000), which contains a LFY cDNA with 300 bp of LFY 3'UTR and a nos terminator, creating pBS-GLFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The GLFY/nos fragment was then ligated into the binary vector pMX202, which includes the RBCS terminator sequence (M.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Busch, personal communication), along with the ML1 promoter fragment from pAS98 (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	70	ML1::GFP:LFY was created by ligating the ML1 promoter from pAS99 (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	71	, 1999) to the 5' portion of GFP:LFY 5' (up to the XbaI site in LFY) from pRTL2-sGFP:LFY, and the 3' portion of LFY from pAS116 into binary vector pMX202.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	72	 In this fusion, there is an additional serine inserted between GFP and LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	73	 35S::GFP:LFY was created by ligating the same GFP:LFY 5' and LFY 3' fragments into binary vector pCHF3, which contains a CaMV 35S promoter (Fankhauser et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	74	ML1::LFY:GFP was created by ligating the 5' portion of ML1::LFY 5' up to the HindIII site from pAS104 (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	75	, 2000) and the 3' portion of LFY:GFP from pBS-ML1::LFY-link-sGFP into the binary vector pJIHOON212 (J.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	76	 35S::LFY:GFP was created by ligating the 5' portion of LFY cDNA from pAS107 (up to the HindIII site) with the 3' portion of LFY:GFP into pCHF3.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	77	lfy mutant alleles Four lfy alleles were included in this study: lfy-2, lfy-3, lfy-9 and lfy-20 (Weigel et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	78	 GFP fusions of these mutant versions were generated in the same way as the ML1::GLFY fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	79	LFY truncations Truncations of the LFY coding sequence were created in the context of pBS-LFY, which includes both the full-length cDNA and 300 bp of the LFY 3'UTR.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	80	 LFY1 was generated by opening, filling-in and religating the BamHI site overlapping the start codon and the XbaI site at position 379, which results in an in-frame deletion of amino acids 4 to 127.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	81	 LFY2 was created by opening, filling-in and religating the XbaI site at position 379 and the StyI site at position 860, which results in an in-frame deletion of amino acids 128 to 287.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	82	 LFY3 was created by opening, filling-in and religating the StyI site at position 860 and the HindIII site at position 974, which leads to a frame shift such that amino acids 289 to 424 are replaced with the sequence SFKCSQKSV.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Fusions of the GFP:LFY truncations to the ML1 promoter were created by combining the promoter fragment from pAS99, the 5' fragment of GFP:LFY from pRTL2-sGFP:LFY and the respective LFY truncations in pMX202.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	84	AP1-GFP fusions For AP1:GFP, restriction sites were added to the AP1 cDNA sequence by PCR amplification, using pAM571 as a template (M.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Yanofsky, personal communication), which resulted in an EcoRI and a BamHI site in front of the 5' UTR, and a PstI site at the 3' end, replacing the stop codon.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	86	 GFP coding sequence was amplified from pCAMBIA1302, replacing the start codon with a PstI site and adding an XbaI site to the 3'UTR.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	87	 For GFP:AP1, the start codon of AP1 was replaced with a PstI site, and an XbaI site was added to the 3'UTR.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	88	 An EcoRI site was added to the 5' end of the GFP coding region and a PstI site replaced the stop codon.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In both fusions, the PstI site also created an alanine linker of 2-3 amino acids.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	90	 ML1::AP1:GFP and ML1::GFP:AP1 were created by ligating the ML1 promoter from pAS99 to the AP1 and GFP fragments in the background of pMX202.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	91	 AP1::AP1:GFP and AP1::GFP:AP1 were created in the same way as the ML1 versions, but using the AP1 promoter from pAM571.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	92	Other ML1 constructs ML1::2xGFP was created by ligating the ML1 promoter to TEV5':2xsGFP from pRTL2-2xsGFP (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000) and inserting into pMX202.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The NLS-2xsGFP fragment from pRTL2-NLS:2xsGFP (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000) was used to generate ML1::NLS:2xGFP.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	94	 ML1::TVCVMP:GFP was generated by ligating the ML1 promoter to coding sequences for a Turnip Vein Clearing Virus Movement Protein (TVCVMP):GFP fusion into pMX202.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	95	Ectopic expression in the center of shoot and flower meristems A 833 bp BamHI/HindIII fragment from the 3' end of the second AG intron (Busch et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	96	, 1999) was used to drive expression in the AG domain.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	97	 This enhancer fragment, from pMX141, carries a point mutation (from CCTTATTTGG to AATTATTTGG) that results in ectopic activity in the inflorescence meristem in a lfy-independent manner (Hong et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The enhancer was placed upstream of a -46 bp cauliflower mosaic virus 35S minimal promoter in pMX202.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	99	 AG intron*::2xGFP, AG intron*::NLS:2xGFP, AG intron*::LFY and AG intron*::GLFY were created by inserting the respective coding sequence fragments into this cassette.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	100	LFY rescue constructs The LFY and GLFY rescue constructs were generated by expressing the LFY cDNA and GLFY under the control of the 2.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	101	3 kb LFY promoter (Blazquez et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	102	Plant material Plants were grown in long days (16 hour light / 8 hour darkness) under 120  microE m-2 seconds-1 light provided by a 3:1 mixture of cool-white and GroLux (Osram Sylvania) fluorescent bulbs, at 21 degrees C.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	103	 lfy-12 and ap1-15 are strong alleles in the Columbia background (Huala and Sussex, 1992; Ng and Yanofsky, 2001).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Plant transformations were carried out using the floral dip method (Weigel and Glazebrook, 2002).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	105	 For each transgene, 40-70 T1 lines were initially analyzed, and at least three plants each from three independent lines were used in further characterization and imaging.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Transgenic seedlings were selected on MS agar plates containing 50  microg/ml kanamycin, then transplanted to soil.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	107	 For all transgenes presented in this work, multiple samples from both agar- and soil-grown plants of at least three generations were examined, always with very similar results.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	108	 In all cases where a mutant allele was involved, transgenic lines with both wild-type and mutant backgrounds have been examined.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	109	 We never observed an effect of the endogenous allele on the GFP signal.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	110	In situ hybridization In situ hybridization was performed as described (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	111	, 2000; Weigel and Glazebrook, 2002).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Digoxigenin-labeled antisense RNA probe for TVCVMP:GFP was generated by digesting pBSTVCVMP:GFP with XhoI, then transcribing it using T3 polymerase,.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	113	Immunoblot analysis Crude protein extract was obtained from 2-week-old seedlings and separated on 4-12% gradient gels (NuPAGE, Invitrogen) with Benchmark Protein Marker (Invitrogen).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Samples were transferred to a PVDF membrane by electroblotting, and incubated with rabbit anti-GFP primary antibody (1:1000 dilution, Molecular Probes).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	115	 An HRP-conjugated goat anti-rabbit secondary antibody (1:5000 dilution, BioRad) was used for signal detection with SuperSignal Chemiluminescent Substrate (Pierce).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	116	Microscopy GFP fluorescence images For ML1 transgenic plants, emerging leaves and apices were dissected from 10- to 12-day-old seedlings grown on MS agar plates.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	117	 For AG intron* transgenic plants, primary inflorescence apices were dissected from 4-week-old plants for image analysis.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Confocal images were collected using a 40x or 63x oil-immersion lens on a Leica SPII spectral confocal laser scanning microscope.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	119	 GFP fluorescence was excited with a 488 nm Argon laser, and images were collected in the 500-550 nm range.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	120	 In some cases, images from the transmissible light channel were collected simultaneously.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	121	 For ML1 transgenic plants, both vegetative and inflorescence apices were examined.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	122	 In each figure, all panels were collected during the same microscopy session from plants grown under exactly the same conditions.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	123	Light microscopic images Pictures of flowers were taken with a Polaroid DMC digital camera mounted on an Olympus SZH10 stereomicroscope.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Images of in situ hybridization were taken with a SPOT digital camera mounted on a Nikon compound microscope.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	125	Quantification of the subcellular distribution of GFP-LFY fusions Confocal image series of epidermal cells in emerging leaves were collected from transgenic plants carrying ML1::GLFY, ML1::GFP:LFY, and ML1::LFY:GFP using a 63x objective, with 1  microm steps.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Separate masks were generated for the nuclei and the cytoplasm using the image processing software Khoros (www.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Total signal intensity in each part was calculated for every section and summed within the same image series.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Data from approximately thirty cells were averaged for each transgene.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	129	   RESULTS TOP SUMMARY INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Movement of viral MP and GFP from the L1 layer Plant viral movement proteins (MPs) and the green fluorescence protein (GFP) have been widely used in studies of intercellular protein movement in plants, and represent examples of targeted and non-targeted movement, respectively.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	130	 To provide data relevant to transcription factor movement in Arabidopsis meristems, we first set out to examine the movement of these two types of proteins from the L1 layer when expressed in intact plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	131	 When we expressed the Turnip Vein Clearing Virus Movement Protein fused to GFP (TVCVMP:GFP) in the L1, using the L1-specific ML1 promoter (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	132	, 1999), GFP fluorescence was detected in all cells of vegetative and inflorescence apices, although the signal was slightly higher in the L1 layer (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	133	 1A, inset) demonstrated that TVCVMP:GFP RNA was restricted to the L1 in these plants, not only confirming the specificity of the ML1 promoter, but also confirming that TVCVMP does not transport its own RNA.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In the maturing leaf epidermis, which is part of the L1 layer and where cellular boundaries are clearly visible, TVCVMP:GFP was found specifically associated with the cell wall in a punctate pattern (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	135	 1D), which may coincide with the location of plasmodesmata pit fields (Crawford and Zambryski, 2001; Heinlein et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Deeper optical sections also revealed that a substantial fraction of TVCVMP:GFP can enter the mesophyll cells from the leaf epidermis (data not shown).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	137	 These data confirm that plant viral movement proteins are able to move over many cell diameters (Citovsky, 1999; Haywood et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	138	View larger version (111K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Movement of TVCVMP:GFP, 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Confocal images of GFP fluorescence in inflorescence apices (A-C) and leaf epidermis (D-F) of 2-week-old ML1::TVCVMP:GFP (A,D), ML1::2xGFP (B,E) and ML1::NLS:2xGFP (C,F) transgenic plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Inset in A shows that TVCVMP:GFP RNA is restricted to the L1, as detected by in situ hybridization.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In D-F, the GFP fluorescence channel is overlaid with the transmissible light channel.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	143	 TVCVMP:GFP is found in all cells in the inflorescence apex (A), and it is associated with the cell wall in a punctate pattern (D).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	144	 2xGFP forms a gradient of six to ten cells in the apex, with the highest concentration in L1 (B).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	145	 It is located in both the nucleus and the cytoplasm (E).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	146	 NLS:2xGFP can move efficiently only one cell layer from the L1 in the apex (C), and it appears mostly nuclear (F).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	147	  We then examined the behavior of GFP, which does not display targeted movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	148	 We chose a dimerized version of GFP (2xGFP) because it has a molecular weight of approximately 54 kDa, which is similar to LFY, which is 47 kDa in size.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In previous leaf bombardment studies, it has been demonstrated that 2xGFP can move at least occasionally into neighboring cells, whereas adding a nuclear localization signal (NLS) nearly fully blocks this movement (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Here, 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP, when expressed stably in the L1, behaved similarly.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In vegetative and inflorescence apices, 2xGFP could move at least six cells into the L2 and L3 layers, forming a gradient with the highest levels in the L1 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	152	 It appeared both cytoplasmic and nuclear in the leaf epidermis (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	153	 In agreement with bombardment studies, only a small amount of NLS:2xGFP was able to enter the L2 layer in apices, with no GFP signal detected in the L3 layer (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Its subcellular localization was assayed in the leaf epidermis, where most of the GFP signal came from the nuclei (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	155	To confirm that the GFP signal was indeed from dimerized GFP instead of a breakdown product resulting in monomeric GFP, whole-cell protein extracts were prepared from transgenic seedlings after imaging and analyzed by western blot with an anti-GFP antibody.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	156	 For NLS:2xGFP, a major band at about 57 kDa was observed (predicted size 58 kDa), indicating that it was stable (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Similarly, 2xGFP migrated at about 50 kDa (predicted size 54 kDa), and only a small amount of degradation product was observed for 2xGFP.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	158	View larger version (58K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Western blots of whole-cell extracts from 2-week-old transgenic seedlings of ML1::2xGFP and ML1::NLS:2xGFP (A), ML1::AP1:GFP and ML1::GFP:AP1 (B), and ML1::GLFY, ML1:LFY:GFP and ML1::GFP:LFY (C) probed with anti-GFP antibody.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Extract of wild-type Col-0 seedlings was used as a negative control in A.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Blots were deliberately overexposed to reveal the presence of any minor bands.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	162	 No major degradation products in the form of single GFP were found.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Bands detected at higher molecular weight in the 2xGFP and GLFY lanes probably represent dimers formed during the extraction procedure.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	164	 In B, GFP:AP1 bands are marked with an arrow and the minor single GFP band in GFP:AP1 is marked with an arrowhead.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	165	  Absence of movement of a functional AP1-GFP fusion To exclude the possibility that all GFP fusion proteins can move, we examined N- and C-terminal fusions of GFP to the transcription factor AP1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	166	 We have previously reported that AP1 has largely cell-autonomous effects when expressed in the L1 layer, indicating that AP1 does not move into internal layers, although protein localization was not directly examined (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	167	 In strong ap1 mutants, sepals and petals fail to develop, and secondary flowers develop in the axil of sepals that have been converted into bracts.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	168	7 kb promoter fragment drives expression of a reporter gene in a pattern similar to that of endogenous AP1 (Hempel et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	169	, 1997), and when fused to an AP1 cDNA can largely rescue the phenotype of the strong ap1-15 allele (M.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Yanofsky, personal communication).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Expression of the C-terminal AP1:GFP fusion from the AP1 promoter rescued most aspects of the ap1-15 mutant phenotype, although rescue was variable in different lines (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	172	 In contrast, the N-terminal GFP:AP1 fusion was unable to rescue the ap1-15 phenotype (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	173	View larger version (75K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Absence of movement of a functional AP1:GFP fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The C-terminal AP1:GFP fusion can rescue ap1-15 mutant flowers to near wild type when expressed from the AP1 promoter (A), and leads to the development of bracts subtending flowers when expressed in the L1 of wild type (C).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The N-terminal fusion GFP:AP1 does not rescue ap1-15 mutant flowers when expressed from the AP1 promoter (B).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Confocal images of GFP fluorescence in inflorescence apices of 2-week-old ML1::AP1:GFP (D,E) and ML1::GFP:AP1 (F) plants are shown.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	178	 AP1:GFP does not move from the L1 (D; optical section through the shoot apex), and is tightly associated with nuclei (E; tangential section through the L1 of a floral primordium).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	179	 By contrast, GFP:AP1 is largely cytoplasmic and moves into deeper tissues layers from the L1 (F).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	180	  We subsequently expressed both fusions under the control of the ML1 promoter to test for their movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	181	 When AP1:GFP (55 kDa) was expressed under the ML1 promoter, we observed some gain-of-function phenotypes associated with the overexpression of AP1 in the L1 (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	182	, 2000), such as the development of bracts subtending the flowers (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The GFP signal in apices from these plants was restricted to the L1 layer (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	184	 2D), and was very tightly associated with the cell nuclei (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	185	 This observation supports the previous conclusion that AP1 does not move from the L1 layer into the inner tissue, and that only some transcription factors can move between tissue layers in the Arabidopsis apex.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	186	 GFP:AP1, which appeared non-functional when expressed from the AP1 promoter, moved into all tissue layers from the L1 in ML1::GFP:AP1 apices (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The subcellular localization of GFP:AP1 was also abnormal; instead of being exclusively nuclear like the functional AP1:GFP fusion, it produced a mostly cytoplasmic signal.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The cytoplasmic localization may well be causally related to the ability of this fusion to move and to the inability to rescue the mutant phenotype; however, it is unlikely that movement itself interferes with AP1 function.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Western blots probed with an anti-GFP antibody showed that both fusions migrated at approximately 52 kDa (expected size 55 kDa; arrow, Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	190	 There was only a small amount of free GFP (27 kDa; arrowhead, Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	191	 4B), confirming that the observed fluorescence signal reflected the behavior of the fusion protein.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	192	Movement of LFY-GFP fusions from the L1 layer To avoid artifacts caused by the addition of GFP to a specific domain of the LFY protein, we generated three different LFYGFP fusions: GFP:LFY, an N-terminal fusion; GLFY, with an insertion of GFP at amino acid 31; and LFY:GFP, a C-terminal fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	193	 We used these fusions, which increase the size of LFY by about half, from 47 to 74 kDa, to further characterize the movement of LFY, which has been previously detected using anti-LFY antibodies (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The fusions were introduced into lfy-12/+ plants under the control of the ML1 promoter.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	195	 To test independently for functionality, the N- and C-terminally tagged versions were also expressed under the control of the constitutive CaMV 35S promoter.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	196	 All five transgenes were able to rescue the lfy-12 mutant phenotype, and to cause the typical gain-of-function phenotypes associated with overexpression of LFY (Weigel and Nilsson, 1995), which indicates that the three GFP fusions were fully functional.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	197	Using the ML1 promoter lines, we examined the subcellular localization of the LFY-GFP fusions, as well as their movement from the L1 layer (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	198	 All three fusions were detected in both the nucleus and cytoplasm, which was best seen in leaf epidermal cells (GLFY shown in Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	199	 3C), and all produced more cytoplasmic signal than NLS:2xGFP (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	200	 In leaf epidermal cells, a punctate signal that appeared along the cell wall was observed with all three fusions (GLFY shown in Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	201	 3C), which suggests a possible association with plasmodesmata pit fields.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	202	 GLFY and GFP:LFY moved three to four cell layers into the L2 and L3 in both the vegetative and inflorescence apices, forming a gradient with the highest concentration in the L1 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Both GLFY and GFP:LFY were restricted to the epidermal layer in maturing leaves (data not shown).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	204	 LFY:GFP moved further, approximately 10 cell layers in apices (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	205	 In leaves, its distribution in the epidermis was similar to that of GLFY and GFP:LFY, but it could also be detected in the underlying mesophyll cells (data not shown).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Overall, LFY:GFP appeared more cytoplasmic than GLFY and GFP:LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	207	 This observation was confirmed by quantifying the total signal intensity in the nucleus and cytoplasm of the epidermal cells of emerging leaves from all three fusions (see Materials and Methods).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	208	 For GLFY and GFP:LFY, the nuclear to cytoplasmic signal ratios were very similar, 1:2.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	209	 By contrast, the nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio of LFY:GFP was 1:5.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	210	4, a twofold increase compared with GLFY and GFP:LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Western blots probed with an anti-GFP antibody demonstrated that there was little degradation of the fusion proteins, indicating that the in vivo fluorescence signal came from the intact fusion proteins (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Taken together, the behavior of LFY-GFP fusions is intermediate between that of 2xGFP and NLS:2xGPF, both with respect to their cytoplasmic localization and their ability to move from the L1 layer.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	213	View larger version (153K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Confocal images of GFP fluorescence in inflorescence apices (A,B,D) and leaf epidermis (C) of 2-week-old ML1::GLFY (A,C), ML1::GFP:LFY (B) and ML1::LFY:GFP (D) transgenic plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	215	 GLFY moves several cell layers into the underlying tissue from the L1 in the apex (A).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	216	 GFP:LFY shows a similar gradient from the L1 as GLFY (B).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The signal from LFY:GFP, which has the longest moving range, appears `fuzzy' because of its higher cytoplasmic localization (D).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	218	 All three fusions are localized to both the nucleus and cytoplasm in leaf epidermal cells, and bright spots are sometimes found along the cell wall with GLFY (shown in C).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	219	  Lateral movement of GLFY within tissue layers Movement of LFY-GFP fusions from the L1 to deeper layers indicated that they can pass through the secondary plasmodesmata, which connect cells that are not clonally related.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	220	 To study the lateral movement of LFY within each tissue layer, we took advantage of a mutated enhancer from the AGAMOUS (AG) gene, which drives reporter gene expression in the inflorescence meristem in addition to the normal AG domain in the center of floral meristems (Hong et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	221	We expressed 2xGFP, NLS:2xGFP and GLFY under the control of the CaMV 35S minimal promoter fused to the mutated AG enhancer (AG intron*).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Except for the subcellular localization, the expression patterns of NLS:2xGFP (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	223	 5B) were indistinguishable, with fluorescent signal in the inflorescence meristem and central domain of young floral primordia.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The signal in both the shoot and floral meristems had discrete boundaries, indicating that GFP neither moved from the inflorescence meristem into emerging floral primordia, nor moved from the center of stage 3 flowers to the periphery (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	225	 However, a gradient of 2xGFP could be seen extending into deeper cell layers in L3 in stage 3 flowers (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	226	 5E), which is consistent with our earlier observation.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Thus, compared with movement from the L1 to internal layers, lateral movement of 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP within tissue layers is much more limited, or possibly even absent.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The much reduced movement of 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP within L1 and L2, compared with movement between layers, suggests that the plasmodesmata SEL within these two layers is lower than that between layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	229	View larger version (118K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Restricted lateral protein movement in the Arabidopsis shoot apex.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Confocal images of GFP fluorescence for inflorescence meristems with surrounding young floral primordia from AG intron*::NLS:2xGFP (A,D), AG intron*::2xGFP (B,E) and AG intron*::GLFY (C,F) plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The confocal images have been overlaid with images from the transmitted-light channel for orientation only.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Note that the confocal images are optical sections, which is not true for the transmitted-light images.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The mutated AG sequences in the reporters activate expression in the shoot apical meristem and the center of young flowers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Close-up views of stage 3 flowers reveal discrete lateral boundaries of the GFP signal (D-F).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	236	 No lateral movement is obvious in any of the three cases.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	237	  Similarly, GLFY could not move laterally within the same tissue layer (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	238	 We have previously found that periclinal, as well as anticlinal, sectors of LFY can rescue mutant parts of flowers, indicating that LFY moves in both directions (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	239	 One possibility for the apparently different behavior of LFY and GLFY is that the greater size of GLFY, compared with endogenous LFY, reduces its ability to move laterally within tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	240	We used a functional assay to test this assumption.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	241	 For this, we took advantage of the fact that the mutated AG enhancer is active in lfy mutants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	242	 When we expressed LFY and GLFY under the control of this enhancer in lfy-12 plants, the same fraction of transgenic lines showed rescue in flowers (4 out of 12 lines for LFY and 4 out of 11 lines for GLFY; no significant difference using Fisher's exact test), suggesting that GLFY has similar activity to LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	243	 However, the rescued flowers differed in phenotype.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Both GLFY and LFY rescued the development of the two inner whorls, which contain stamens and carpels, and in which the AG enhancer is active (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	245	 6), but only LFY was able to rescue petal development.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	246	 All four of the lfy-12; AG intron*::LFY lines that showed phenotypic rescue produced at least some flowers with petals, and many flowers had the normal complement of four petals.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	247	 By contrast, none of the four lfy-12; AG intron*::GLFY lines produced flowers with petals.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	248	 As GLFY appears to be as active as LFY in the inner two whorls where it is produced, the difference in their activity in the outer two whorls is consistent with the conclusion that LFY can move more extensively than GLFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	249	View larger version (75K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Rescue of lfy-12 mutant flowers by LFY and GLFY expression in the center of the floral primordia.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	251	 A wild-type Arabidopsis flower (A) and a shoot-like structure that replaces a flower in lfy-12 mutants (B) are shown.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Both AG intron*::LFY and AG intron*::GLFY can rescue the stamens and carpels of lfy-12 mutant flowers (C,D), but only LFY rescues petals completely (arrow in C).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	253	  Requirement of LFY movement for normal flower development Although it has been established that LFY can move within flowers (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	254	, 2000) (this work), it is unclear whether LFY movement is required for normal flower development, because LFY protein and RNA are expressed throughout young flowers (Parcy et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The difference between LFY and GLFY in their apparent ability to move within layers allowed us to address this question by expressing LFY and GLFY under the control of the LFY promoter and comparing their ability to rescue lfy-12 mutants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Of ten LFY::LFY transgenic lines in the lfy-12 background, three showed complete rescue, and the remaining seven showed nearly complete rescue, with only a few flowers having reduced petal or stamen number.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	257	 By contrast, only six out of fourteen LFY::GLFY lines in the lfy-12 background showed a similar degree of rescue; the remaining eight lines resembled weak or intermediate lfy mutants and were sterile.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	258	 This difference between their ability to rescue is statistically significant based on Fisher's exact test.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Although only the opposite result  to  full ability of movement-compromised LFY to rescue lfy mutants  to  would have been entirely conclusive, our finding is consistent with the notion that LFY movement may be required for normal flower development.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	260	 However, we cannot exclude the possibility that GLFY is somewhat less active as a transcription factor than native LFY, although no difference in activity could be observed when tested from the 35S and AtML1 promoters.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	261	Movement of mutant LFY proteins To further test whether LFY movement is regulated, we investigated whether deleting parts of the LFY protein abolishes intercellular movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Three large, non-overlapping deletions were made in the LFY coding sequence, each removing approximately one third of the protein (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	263	 All three were linked to GFP at the N terminus and expressed under the ML1 promoter.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Although they differed in the extent with which they moved from L1 to inner layers, all three deletion variants were still able to move from L1 into the inner layers in both vegetative and inflorescence apices.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	265	 GFP:LFY1, with an N-terminal deletion, behaved very similar to GFP:LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	266	 It was mostly located in the nucleus, and formed a gradient of four to five cell layers into the L2 and L3 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	267	 GFP:LFY2, with a central deletion, was expressed at lower levels and was largely cytoplasmic, presumably because of the deletion of the NLS.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	268	 GFP signal could be clearly detected for at least three cell layers into the L2 and L3 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	269	 7C), but its low expression levels may have been limiting our ability to determine its actual range of movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	270	 GFP:LFY3, with a C-terminal deletion, showed the least degree of movement, moving only one to two cell layers from the L1 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	271	 However, most of the GFP signal was found in large aggregates, sometimes associated with the cell membrane when imaged in the leaf epidermis (data not shown), suggesting that GFP:LFY3 is improperly folded and localizes to a specific subcellular compartment, which may affect its movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Furthermore, all three truncated versions were able to enter mesophyll cells from the epidermis in maturing leaves (data not shown).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	273	View larger version (70K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Movement of truncated LFY from the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	275	 (A) Diagram of GFP:LFY and the three truncated forms of the GFP:LFY fusion protein.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	276	 GFP-coding sequence is shown in green and LFY-coding sequence in light blue, along with restriction sites used to make the deletions: B, BamHI; P, PstI; X, XbaI; S, StyI; H, HindIII.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	277	 (B-D) Confocal images of GFP fluorescence in inflorescence apices of 2-week-old plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	278	 All three forms of truncated GFP:LFY move from the L1 to the inner tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	279	 GFP:LFY1 is mostly located in the nucleus (B), whereas GFP:LFY2 appears to be largely cytoplasmic (C).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Both can move several cell layers from the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	281	 GFP:LFY3 is mainly found in the form of large aggregates, but can still move one to two cell layers from the L1 (D).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	282	  As large deletions may cause mis-folding of a protein, we also generated GFP fusions of four weak and intermediate lfy alleles mutating specific residues in GLFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	283	 All four fusions were functional, as they rescued lfy-12 plants to the phenotype corresponding to the lfy allele used for the fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	284	 When expressed in the L1 layer, all of them could move into the underlying tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Products of the fusions of the two weak lfy alleles, glfy-2 and glfy-20, showed near wild-type movement (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	286	 3A), whereas the products of the two intermediate alleles, glfy-3 and glfy-9, moved somewhat less well into the L2 and L3, about two to three cell layers (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Taken together, these data suggest either the presence of redundant movement signals, or the absence of a specific movement signal.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	288	View larger version (104K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Movement of mutant GLFY fusions from the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	290	 (A) Diagram of fusions of GFP to weak alleles lfy-2 (P240L) and lfy-20 (N306D), and intermediate alleles lfy-3 (T244M) and lfy-9 (R331K) in the GLFY background.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	291	 (B-E) Confocal images of GFP fluorescence in inflorescence apices of 2-week-old plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	292	 All fusion proteins can move from the L1 into interior layers, although to different degrees.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	293	     DISCUSSION TOP SUMMARY INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Since the discovery of transcription factor movement in plants almost a decade ago, questions have arisen regarding how they move and whether movement is regulated.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	294	 There are at least two scenarios for how transcription factors reach neighboring cells: targeted movement guided by a specific movement or export signal, or non-targeted movement by diffusion (Crawford and Zambryski, 1999).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	295	 We have performed several tests to determine whether there is evidence for targeted movement of LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	296	 None of our results point to specific regulation of LFY movement, which suggests that LFY movement is non-targeted.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Furthermore, we have found important differences in the dynamics of apical-basal and lateral movement in the apex.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	298	Mode of LFY movement Several lines of evidence are compatible with the view that LFY movement is non-targeted.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	299	 First, GFP-LFY fusions produced in the L1 formed limited gradients extending into deeper layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Their movement range was between that of 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP, which move in a non-targeted fashion (Crawford and Zambryski, 1999; Crawford and Zambryski, 2000; Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	301	 This is in contrast to the nearly uniform distribution in the shoot apex (reflecting an active mechanism of cell-to-cell transport) that is observed when a viral movement protein fusion is expressed in the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Second, size affects LFY movement, as native LFY was more effective in rescuing lfy defects in adjacent cells in the same tissue layer than the larger GLFY fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The effect of size is one of the prominent characteristics of non-targeted movement (Zambryski and Crawford, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Third, although differing in stability and sub-cellular localization, all three GFP-LFY truncations and fusions of four mutant lfy alleles were able to move from the L1 into interior cell layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Although one cannot exclude the possibility that LFY has several redundant movement signals, the simpler explanation is that the LFY protein sequence does not contain a specific movement or export signal.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	306	It has been suggested that non-targeted movement, like targeted movement, occurs through plasmodesmata.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The potential localization of foci of GFP-LFY fusion proteins along the cell wall in the leaf epidermis supports this hypothesis.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	308	 This also suggests that the size exclusion limit of the secondary plasmodesmata connecting tissue layers in the Arabidopsis apex is greater than 74 kDa (the size of the LFY-GFP fusions), which is consistent with previous estimates for nascent leaves (Zambryski and Crawford, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	309	Movement within and between tissue layers An important new finding is that GFP variants, as well as GLFY, move more easily in the apical-basal direction than laterally.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Using in vivo function as a criterion, we found that the GLFY fusion was less efficient than the native LFY in moving from the center of floral primordia to the periphery.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	311	 This functional difference is most likely a result of their size difference, because both proteins are fully functional in the cells where they are produced.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	312	 Similar to previous studies that have demonstrated that the inner central zone (L3) does not allow fluorescent tracer uploading from the vascular tissue (Gisel et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	313	, 2002), we observed much more limited lateral movement within the L3.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Thus, intercellular movement needs to be considered in the context of the specific location and developmental stage within the plant.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	315	That lateral movement is less easily achieved than apical-basal movement may also explain the fact that LFY does not move out of floral primordia into the inflorescence meristem in wild type (Parcy et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	316	, 2000), as lateral movement would be required for efficient protein exchange between the two tissues.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	317	 The inflorescence meristem may even form a symplasmic domain that is insulated from emerging floral primordia (Rinne and van der Schoot, 1998), thus restricting movement of all macromolecules.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Alternatively, there may be selective gating, such that movement of only certain macromolecules from floral primordia into the inflorescence meristem (and vice versa) is permitted.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	319	 A similar mechanism may also be responsible for maintaining discrete whorl boundaries within the flower.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	320	 In this context, it is noteworthy that floral homeotic proteins that are expressed in distinct whorls of the developing Arabidopsis flower, such as AP1 and AP3, do not move, whereas LFY, which is expressed throughout the flower, does (Jenik and Irish, 2001; Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	321	Movement and subcellular localization LFY and LFY-GFP fusions can move into the inner tissue layers from the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	322	 By contrast, AP1:GFP does not move between tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	323	 This cannot be simply due to size, because an N-terminal fusion, GFP:AP1, could move well.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Furthermore, GFP:AP1 (55 kDa) is smaller than either NLS:2xGFP (57 kDa) or LFY-GFP fusions (74 kDa).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Therefore, if LFY is moving by diffusion, AP1 and AP1:GFP must be actively retained in the cells where they are expressed.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	326	 One way to achieve the retention may be by subcellular localization, such as nuclear or ER localization.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	327	 From this study, we have found that there is a good correlation between nuclear localization and movement: 2xGFP, which is highly cytoplasmic, can move a considerable distance from the L1, and the same is true for the predominantly cytoplasmic GFP:AP1 fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	328	 AP1:GFP, which appeared to be exclusively nuclear, did not move.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Between these two extremes, NLS:2xGFP showed little cytoplasmic localization and moved only one cell layer.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	330	 The GFP-LFY fusions all showed more cytoplasmic localization than NLS:2xGFP, and all moved farther than NLS:2xGFP but less than 2xGFP.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Among the three GFP-LFY fusions, LFY:GFP had the most cytoplasmic localization and moved the farthest.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	332	Another possible mechanism for retaining a protein could be through the formation of large protein complexes with more exclusive subcellular localization, or simply with sizes above the SEL of plasmodesmata.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	333	 This may contribute to the retention of MADS domain proteins such as AP1, as several of them, including AP1, are known to form heteromultimers in the absence of DNA (Egea-Cortines et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	334	 In addition, it has been shown that AP3, a MADS-domain transcription factor that does not move between tissue layers, needs to heterodimerize with another MADS-domain protein, PISTILLATA (PI), in order to localize to the nucleus (McGonigle et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	335	 It is possible that the GFP:AP1 fusion disrupts such interactions, thereby interfering with biological activity and nuclear localization, as well as with retention in the cells where it is produced.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	336	In this context, it is noteworthy that SHR is found in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of the stele, where it is produced.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	337	 From there, SHR moves exactly one cell diameter, into the adjacent endodermis, where it is located entirely in the nucleus (Nakajima et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	338	 This observation is consistent with a model in which SHR gets trapped in the nuclei of the endodermis through interaction with a partner that causes translocation to the nucleus, similar to the AP3/PI interaction (McGonigle et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	339	Mechanisms of movement Our results are compatible with the view that LFY movement is driven by diffusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	340	 However, it remains unclear whether the same conclusion can be drawn regarding the intercellular movement of other transcription factors.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Another well-studied example of a trafficking transcription factor is KN1 of maize (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	342	 As with LFY, KN1-GFP fusions are detected in the nucleus and cytoplasm, and in a punctate pattern associated with the cell wall (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	343	 In contrast to LFY, for which various deletions did not prevent movement, a simple mutation in the homeodomain and the potential NLS of KN1 abolished its movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	344	 Furthermore, experiments with tobacco have indicated the presence of a cellular component that is limiting for KN1 movement, and have suggested that the mode of KN1 trafficking may be related to the targeted movement of viral movement proteins (Kragler et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	345	 However, other results are consistent with KN1 moving in a non-targeted fashion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	346	 In bombardment assays, KN1-GFP moved considerably less well than a fusion of GFP to the movement protein of TVCV (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Furthermore, movement of KN1 expressed from the SCR promoter in the shoot apex of transgenic Arabidopsis plants was rather limited (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	348	, 2002), similar to that of NLS:2xGFP or GFP:LFY expressed from the ML1 promoter (this work).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	349	 Further studies in a nonheterologous system will be required to clarify the mechanisms behind KN1 movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	350	 A complex relationship between targeted and non-targeted movement is also indicated by a recent study, in which a dominant-negative form of the tobacco NON-CELL-AUTONOMOUS PATHWAY PROTEIN 1 (NtNCAPP1) was overexpressed.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	351	 In such transgenic plants, trafficking of viral movement protein, but not of KN1, was affected (Lee et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Interestingly, tobacco LFY protein appears more uniform in such transgenic plants, which also have phenotypes reminiscent of LFY overexpressing plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	353	 The causal relationship between these observations needs further investigation, but it will be interesting to combine the dominant-negative NtCAPP1 overexpressing plants with the tools presented here.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	354	It is also worth noting that the determinants underlying transcription factor movement may be species-dependent.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Like LFY, its Antirrhinum ortholog FLORICAULA (FLO) has non-cell-autonomous effects in mosaic studies (Carpenter and Coen, 1995).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	356	 In contrast to LFY, the extent to which FLO can rescue mutant flowers varies depending on the layer in which FLO is expressed (Hantke et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	357	 As FLO protein has not been examined in these mosaics, it is unknown whether the differential rescue ability is caused by differences in FLO movement, or is only a result of downstream effects, such as the documented abnormalities in target gene expression in the mosaics (Hantke et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	358	 Another example of interspecific differences is provided by DEF of Antirrhinum, which was found to move from the L2 to the L1 in a stage- and organ-dependent manner (Perbal et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	359	 However, the DEF ortholog AP3 of Arabidopsis does not move between layers (Jenik and Irish, 2001), which indicates that subtle differences in sequence, or interspecific differences in the translocation machinery, affect transcription factor movement, the latter being consistent with the interspecific differences that have been reported for GFP movement (Crawford and Zambryski, 2001).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	360	 These observations highlight that care must be taken when extrapolating from one transcription factor assayed in a single species or single tissue.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	361	In conclusion, we have presented evidence that the transcription factor LFY moves in a non-targeted fashion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	362	 We are proposing the testable hypothesis that movement is a default mechanism for many proteins in the Arabidopsis shoot apex, unless they are either efficiently targeted to specific subcellular locations or retained through formation of protein complexes.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	363	 More case studies are needed to determine whether our results can indeed be generalized to include other proteins, other tissues and other species.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	364	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank: Steve Barlow for help with confocal microscopy; Virginia Butel for generating GLFY; Ji Hoon Ahn and Marty Yanofsky for gifts of material; and Ray Hong, Jan Lohmann, Alexis Maizel, Javier Palatnik, Markus Schmid, Jon Werner and Philip Wigge for discussions and critical reading of the manuscript.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	365	 We especially acknowledge our comrade in plasmodesmatis, Bill Lucas, for spirited discussions and exchange of ideas on intercellular protein movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	366	 This work was supported by: fellowships from the Life Sciences Research Foundation/US Department of Energy (X.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	367	) and the Howard Hughes Medical Institute (J.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	368	); a grant from the NIH (GM45244) to P.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	369	; grants from the NIH (GM50224), NSF (9975717 and 0210992), USDA (00-35304-9333), BSF (0100476) and BARD (334702) to V.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	370	; and a grant from the NIH (GM62932) and funding by the Max Planck Society to D.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	371	, who is a Director of the Max Planck Institute.
