0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	0	Positively charged sequences of human papillomavirus type 16 capsid proteins are sufficient to mediate gene transfer into target cells via the heparan sulfate receptor Latifa Bousarghin, Antoine Touze, Alba-Lucia Combita-Rojas and Pierre Coursaget.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	1	Laboratoire de Virologie Moleculaire, INSERM EMIU 00-10 and USC INRA, Faculte des Sciences Pharmaceutiques  Philippe Maupas , 31 avenue Monge, 37200 Tours, France.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	2	Correspondence Pierre Coursaget coursaget{at}univ-tours.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT Top ABSTRACT Introduction Methods Results and discussion REFERENCES   Using synthetic peptides we have shown that positively charged sequences present at the C terminus of the L1 protein and the N and C termini of the L2 protein of human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV-16) bind to both DNA and heparan sulfate receptors.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Moreover, these short amino acid sequences are sufficient to mediate gene transfer in COS-7 cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The L1 proteins of other HPVs were shown to contain one or two DNA- and heparin-binding sequences that have the capacity to transfer genes.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	6	 These DNA-binding sequences also recognized the enhancing packaging sequence of bovine papillomavirus type 1.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The results suggest that the L2 protein could participate in DNA packaging during maturation of virions.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	8	   Introduction Top ABSTRACT Introduction Methods Results and discussion REFERENCES   Papillomaviruses are non-enveloped DNA tumour viruses that persistently infect squamous epithelia.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Their viral capsids are 50 to 55 nm in diameter and contain 72 pentamers of the major structural L1 protein (capsomers) centred on the vertices of a T=7 icosahedral lattice (Baker et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The minor structural protein L2 is present at a ratio of about 1/30 of L1 (Kirnbauer et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The L1 protein can self-assemble into virus-like particles (VLPs) in the presence or absence of the L2 protein (for a review see Schiller  and  Roden, 1995).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	12	The use of artificial virus vectors consisting of DNA packaged in vitro into or associated with recombinant papillomavirus VLPs was recently described (Kawana et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1998; Touze  and  Coursaget, 1998; Rossi et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Papillomaviruses are difficult to propagate in vitro, and thus the production of these pseudovirions offers a model to study human papillomavirus (HPV) cell entry.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The pseudovirions obtained have the ability to transfer the plasmid DNA into cells where the reporter gene is then expressed.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Entry of these artificial gene delivery vehicles into cells is dependent on the interaction between VLPs and the cell surface.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Two putative cell receptors have been identified for HPVs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The first is -6 integrin (Evander et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 1999) and the second comprises the cell-surface glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	20	, 2001), which interact with the C-terminal portion of HPV L1 (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	21	Translocation of L1 and L2 proteins to the nucleus is mediated by nuclear localization signals (NLS) containing, as do the majority of NLS, a high proportion of positively charged residues (K and R).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The prototype NLS is the SV40 large T antigen NLS (KKKRK).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	23	 One has six basic amino acids (aa 499 to 504).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The other is a bipartite NLS (aa 484 to 486, 499 to 500) (Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The L2 protein contains two NLS corresponding to the arginine- and lysine-rich sequences located at the N and C termini of the protein (Sun et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Two DNA-binding sequences have been identified in the L1 and L2 proteins of HPV-16.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The first DNA-binding sequence was identified at the N-terminal end of L2 (Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The second was identified at the C terminus of the L1 protein of HPV-11 and HPV-16 (Li et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In addition, the nine C-terminal amino acids of the L2 protein have been shown to be necessary for infection of bovine papillomavirus type 1 (BPV-1) pseudovirions (Roden et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The DNA-binding activity of these two domains is sequence-independent.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	31	 However, it has recently been shown that DNA binding to BPV-1, HPV-6 and HPV-16 VLPs is enhanced by the presence of a 120 bp DNA sequence located in the BPV-1 E1 gene (Zhao et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	32	We have previously demonstrated that HPV L1 VLPs obtained by self-assembly of L1 protein lacking the last nine C-terminal amino acids had lost their capacity to bind DNA and transfer genes into target cells (Touze et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Moreover, addition of this sequence at the N terminus of the major capsid protein of an RNA virus, the rabbit haemorrhagic disease virus (RHDV), allowed the production of chimeric VLPs that could encapsidate DNA and transfer reporter genes into cells (El Mehdaoui et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	34	 These experiments suggest a central role for this short sequence in DNA binding, interacting with the cell surface of target cells and facilitating the nuclear import of complexes owing to the presence of an NLS.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In order to verify the role of this positively charged sequence, we investigated the possibility of using a synthetic peptide corresponding to the 14 C-terminal amino acids of the HPV-16 L1 protein in DNA transfection experiments.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The study was then extended to positively charged sequences of the HPV-16 L2 protein and the L1 protein of four other HPVs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	37	   Methods Top ABSTRACT Introduction Methods Results and discussion REFERENCES   Plasmids, peptides and VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Three different plasmids were used: a 7 2 kbp plasmid encoding -galactosidase (pCMV-; Ozyme), a 7 3 kbp plasmid (pCMV-PES-) (El Medhaoui et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	39	, 2000) obtained by insertion of the 120 bp BPV-1 packaging enhancing sequence (PES) described by Zhao et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	40	 (1999), and a 7 1 kbp plasmid encoding luciferase (pCMV-Luc; Ozyme).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The peptides were synthesized by Sigma Genosys or Neosystem.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	42	HPV-16 and -31 VLPs were expressed in Sf21 cells infected with recombinant baculoviruses encoding the HPV-16 and -31 L1 open reading frames, respectively, and purified according to previously described procedures (El Medhaoui et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In addition, HPV-16 L19 VLPs composed of the L1 protein lacking the nine C-terminal amino acids were used (Touze et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	44	VLP/DNA and peptide/DNA complex formation.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	45	 VLP/DNA complexes were obtained according to a previously described method (Combita et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Ten  microg VLPs and 1  microg DNA were mixed in 40  microl 50 mM NaCl, pH 5, and incubated for 30 min at room temperature before transfection.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Peptide/DNA complexes were obtained according to the same method.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	48	 One  microg plasmid DNA and an amount of peptide corresponding to a DNA to peptide charge ratio (-/+) of 1/10 were mixed in 40  microl 50 mM NaCl, pH 5, and incubated for 30 min at room temperature.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	49	 This charge ratio corresponded to peptide/DNA mass ratios ranging from 8 6 to 15 6 for L1 peptides, except for peptide HPV-16 L1 Cta (peptide/DNA mass ratio of 20), 6 2 to 6 4 for L2 peptides and SV40 large T NLS and 17 4 to 100 for other peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Charge ratios take into account histidines, since DNA/peptide complexes were obtained at pH 5.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	51	DNA retardation assay and protection of DNA from DNase.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	52	 DNA binding was investigated by agarose gel retardation assays.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	53	 One  microg plasmid was incubated for 30 min at 25  degrees C in 50 mM NaCl, pH 5, with an amount of peptide corresponding to DNA/peptide charge ratios ranging from 1/1 to 1/10.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Complexes were electrophoresed through a 1 % agarose gel in 1xTAE buffer.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	55	To evaluate the amount of protected plasmid DNA, the complexes were treated with Benzonase (Merck) as previously described (Touze  and  Coursaget, 1998; El Mehdaoui et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The amount of DNA was quantified using Molecular Analyst Software (Bio-Rad) and results expressed as the percentage of Benzonase-protected DNA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	57	Detection of DNA binding by ELISA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The DNA-binding activity of the peptides was detected by ELISA as previously described (Touze et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	59	, 2000), with some modifications.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The digoxigenin-labelled PES probe (120 bp) was obtained by PCR amplification of the PES sequence from the plasmid pBPV-CMV- (El Mehdaoui et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	61	, 2000) in the presence of digoxigenin-labelled dUTP (Roche Diagnostics).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	62	 PCR was performed using the following oligonucleotide primers: upper, 5'-CCGGAATTCAAGCTTATGCAAAAAAGATCTCATGAAGGAGGA-3', and lower, 5'-CCGGAATTCCTCTTCTCTTACATTTAGCGTGTTTGC-3'.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	63	 A PES-negative DNA probe was obtained by PCR amplification of a 290 bp fragment corresponding to the cDNA of E1^E4 HPV-16 mRNA in the presence of digoxigenin-dUTP, using the following primers: upper, 5'-CTTAAGATGGCTGATCCTGCATATTATGTCCTACATCTGTG-3', and lower, 5'- CTTAAGTGGGTGTAGTGTTACTATTACAGTTAATCC-3'.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	64	 A 96-well plate (Maxisorp, Nunc) was seeded with 1  microg peptide per well diluted in PBS, pH 7 6, and incubated overnight at 4  degrees C.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	65	 BSA was used as negative control.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After a blocking step with 5 % BSA in PBS for 1 5 h at 37  degrees C, equimolar amounts of digoxigenin-labelled DNA probes (0 5 ng PES-probe, 0 2 ng PES+probe) diluted in PBS were added.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	67	 After 1 h incubation at room temperature and four washes, bound DNA was revealed by anti-digoxigenin antibodies covalently linked to horseradish peroxidase (Roche Diagnostics) diluted 1 : 1000 in PBS.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	68	 After 1 h at 37  degrees C and four washes, bound antibodies were revealed using 2,2'-azino-bis(3-ethylbenzthiazoline-sulfonic acid) and H2O2.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Absorbance was read at 405 nm and the results shown are the means of four determinations.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	70	 COS-7 cells grown in monolayers in Dulbecco's Minimal Essential Medium (D-MEM)/Glutamax (Invitrogen) supplemented with 10 % foetal calf serum (FCS), 100 IU penicillin ml-1 and 100  microg streptomycin ml-1 were seeded in 96-well plates (Nunc).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	71	 After washing with serum-free medium, pCMV-Luc/peptides or pCMV-Luc/VLP complexes diluted in 50  microl culture medium were added to each well.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	72	 After 1 h incubation at 37  degrees C, the complexes were removed and 50  microl D-MEM/Glutamax supplemented with 10 % FCS was added.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Cells were then incubated for 48 h at 37  degrees C.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Luciferase gene expression was measured by luminescence assay (luciferase reporter gene assay with constant light signal; Roche Molecular Biochemical).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The luminescence was integrated over 10 s (Victor2, Wallac, Perkin Elmer) and results were expressed as counts per second (c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	76	 At that time, each well contained approximately 6x104 cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	77	 For experiments using pCMV-/peptide complexes, in situ -galactosidase activity was determined according to a previously described procedure (Muller et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	78	To evaluate the effects of GAGs on transfection by L1 and L2 peptides, peptide/DNA complexes and 5  microg heparin ml-1 were added simultaneously to the cells according to the protocol described by Mislick  and  Baldeschweiler (1996).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	79	 After 48 h incubation at 37  degrees C, luciferase gene expression was measured and results were expressed as percentages of inhibition of gene transfer compared with the gene transfer with peptide/DNA complexes alone.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	80	The role of GAGs was also investigated by desulfation of cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	81	 COS-7 cells were seeded into 96-well plates and the medium was supplemented with 50 mM sodium chlorate after 12 h incubation at 37  degrees C.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	82	 After an additional 48 h incubation period, cells were washed twice with 200  microl PBS, and 200  microl D-MEM/Glutamax medium was added.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Peptide/DNA complexes were then added to the cells and luciferase gene expression was measured after 48 h incubation at 37  degrees C.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Results were expressed as percentage inhibition of gene transfer compared with gene transfer obtained with untreated cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The interaction between peptides and heparin was tested by using a competition assay derived from the heparin-binding assays described by Giroglou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Microtitre plates (Maxisorp, Nunc) were coated with 20 ng per well of either heparin to BSA (Sigma) or BSA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The plates were incubated at 4  degrees C overnight.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	88	 After four washings with PBS containing 0 1 % Tween 20, non-specific binding sites were blocked by incubation for 1 h at 37  degrees C with PBS plus 1 % FCS.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	89	After washing, 200 ng of peptides or BSA diluted in PBS per well was added.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Following incubation at 37  degrees C for 60 min and four washes, HPV-31 VLPs (200 ng per well) in PBS were added and incubated at 37  degrees C for 60 min.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	91	 After washing, mouse anti-HPV-31 VLP antibodies diluted 1 : 1000 in PBS, 0 1 % Tween 20 and 10 % FCS were added and incubated at 45  degrees C for 60 min.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Bound antibodies were detected with mouse anti-IgG antibodies covalently linked to horseradish peroxidase.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	93	 After 1 h incubation at 45  degrees C and four washings, 100  microl of substrate solution containing o-phenylene diamine and H2O2 were added.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The reaction was stopped after 30 min by addition of 100  microl 2 M H2SO4 and the absorbance was read at 492 nm with an automated plate reader.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The absorbance of the control well was subtracted from values for test wells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Results are expressed as the percentage reduction of HPV-31 VLP binding to heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	97	   Results and discussion Top ABSTRACT Introduction Methods Results and discussion REFERENCES   DNA binding and gene transfer with HPV-16 C-terminal synthetic peptide HPV-16 L1 Ctb synthetic peptide (SSTSTTAKRKKRKL, nt 492 to 505) was mixed with pCMV- DNA (7 2 kbp) and the DNA/peptide interaction was measured by determining the amount of peptide required to retard the migration of the plasmid DNA during agarose gel electrophoresis.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	98	 1(A), the electrophoretic mobility of DNA was reduced for charge ratios (-/+) of 1/3 to 1/5 and was completely abolished for a charge ratio of 1/10.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Retardation was not observed when using the positively charged SV40 large T NLS peptide (PPKKKRKVA) at the same charge ratios.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	100	 We further hypothesized that the formation of such complexes might prevent DNA degradation by nuclease.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	101	 L1 peptide/pCMV- DNA complexes were therefore treated for 1 h at 37  degrees C with Benzonase.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Two antigenic peptides, HPV-16 E4 Ag (KPSPWAPKKHRRLS) and HPV-16 L1 Ag (cVGENVPDDLYIKGSG), with a charge ratio of 1/10 corresponding to a mass ratio of DNA/peptide of 1/100, and SV40 large T NLS peptide were used as control peptides with varying proportions of positively charged amino acids.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Seventy-two per cent DNA protection was observed with HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	104	 2) compared with 55 % with HPV-16 VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	105	 No protection was observed with HPV-16 E4 Ag peptide (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	106	 2, lane 6) and only 23 % with the SV40 large T NLS peptide (not shown).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The ability of the HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide to deliver DNA into cells was then investigated with a -galactosidase reporter plasmid in COS-7 cells (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Transfections were performed with 1  microg DNA per well.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The highest level of -galactosidase expression was observed for a DNA/peptide charge ratio of 1/10.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	110	 This peptide is one of the few examples of a natural peptide capable of interacting with plasmid DNA and carrying it across cellular barriers, as observed with the HIV-1 VpR C-terminal sequence (Kichler et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Moreover, pre-incubation of COS-7 cells with HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide induced 60 % inhibition of the gene transfer obtained with HPV-31 pseudovirions, compared with an absence of inhibition (0 %) observed after pre-incubation with the SV40 large T NLS peptide.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This result suggests that the peptide binds to the HPV-31 cell-surface receptor.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	113	 An alternative explanation could be that the excess of peptide binds to the DNA associated with the VLPs, resulting in a decrease in gene transfer due to the lower capacity of the peptide to transfer the gene compared with that obtained with the VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In order to rule out this hypothesis, COS-7 cells were pre-incubated with HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide followed by the addition of plasmid DNA to the cell culture medium.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The absence of gene transfer (not shown) thus supports the hypothesis that the peptide binds to the cell receptor of HPV-31.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	116	View larger version (38K):    Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Formation of peptide/DNA complexes.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The charge ratios of pCMV- and HPV-16 L1 peptide were 1/1, 1/2, 1/3, 1/5, 1/10 and 1/20.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	119	 BSA was used as a negative control.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	120	  View larger version (39K):    Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Benzonase protection of plasmid DNA complexed to positively charged synthetic peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Lane 1, DNA with Benzonase (positive control); lane 2, DNA alone (negative control); lane 3, HPV-16 L2 Nt; lane 4, HPV-16 L2 Ct; lane 5, HPV-16 L1 Ctb; lane 6, HPV-16 E4 Ag.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	123	  Gene transfer to COS-7 cells using pCMV-Luc DNA was also investigated under varying conditions of pH and molarity used for the binding of the DNA to the peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	124	 A gene transfer of 500 plus or minus 52 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	125	 was observed when DNA/peptide complexes were prepared at pH 5 in presence of 50 mM NaCl.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Gene transfer decreased to 235 plus or minus 63 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	127	 at pH 7 5, 50 mM NaCl, and to 225 plus or minus 49 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	128	 At pH 7 2, with 50 mM Tris/HCl, 100 mM NaCl, gene transfer of 210 plus or minus 35 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The results obtained indicate that HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide binds to DNA under conditions resembling the inside of the cell.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	130	DNA binding and gene transfer with positively charged peptides derived from the L1 or L2 proteins of HPVs There are two positively charged sequences at the C terminus of HPV L1 proteins and one such sequence at the N- and C-terminal ends of HPV L2 proteins.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	131	 In order to investigate whether the gene transfer properties observed for the HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide are features shared by similar sequences observed in HPV L1 and L2, various synthetic peptides corresponding to positively charged sequences derived from the L1 protein of HPV-16, -31, -33, -45 and -58 and from HPV-16 L2 protein were investigated (Table 1).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	132	 DNA and heparin binding of HPV L1 or L2 positively charge peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	133	  These peptides were tested for DNA binding by gel retardation assay and for gene delivery to COS-7 cells using pCMV-Luc DNA as reporter plasmid (7 1 kbp).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The results indicated that all the peptides bound to DNA at a 1/10 charge ratio (Table 1), with the exception of the control peptides HPV-16 E4 Ag, SV40 large T NLS, HPV-16 L1 Cta, HPV-31 L1 Ctb and HPV-58 L1 Ctb peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	135	 A mobility shift was only observed at a 1/40 ratio for these five peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	136	The complexes formed between DNA-binding peptides and pCMV-Luc plasmid DNA were used to transfect COS-7 cells, and gene transfer was measured by the luciferase activity determined 2 days after transfection (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The cut-off value for gene transfer positivity was set up at 25 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	138	 (mean value observed with DNA alone plus or minus 3 SD).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	139	 No gene transfer was observed with the two control peptides (HPV-16 L1 Ag, HPV-16 E4 Ag), nor with the positively charged peptide corresponding to the SV40 large T NLS.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Using an HPV-16 L1 Ctb scramble peptide (HPV-16 L1 CtbSc), a gene transfer of 118 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	141	 was observed, compared with 413 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The reduction in gene transfer with the scramble peptide suggested that gene transfer is a sequence-specific-dependent phenomenon.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The residual capacity of this scramble peptide to transfer the gene could be attributed to a generic charge effect.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This is in agreement with the fact that similarly charged peptides such as HPV-31 Ctb and HPV-58 Ctb peptides have no or low capacity to transfer genes.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	145	View larger version (12K):    Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Gene transfer with HPV L1- or L2-derived synthetic peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	147	 HPV-16 VLPs were used as positive controls and data are the mean of three experiments.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Error bars represent the mean plus or minus SD.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	149	  Using the L1 positively charged peptides, the highest level of gene transfer was observed with the sequence located at the C-terminal end of the L1 protein (L1 Ctb peptides) compared with the level observed with the sequence located upstream (L1 Cta) for types 16 and 45.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Among the efficient peptides, the highest level of transfer was observed with the upstream sequence for types 31, 33 and 58.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	151	 It should be noted that no gene transfer was observed with HPV-16 L1 Cta peptide (22 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	152	) and very low levels with HPV-31 L1 Ctb and HPV-58 L1 Ctb peptides (89 and 27 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	153	These results indicate the presence of two L1 sequences that bind DNA and play a role in gene transfer for HPV-33 and -45 L1 VLPs, and show that these properties are linked to the last amino acids of the L1 protein for HPV-16, and the first C-terminal sequence of HPV-31 and -58.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Gene transfer with the HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide was 574 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	155	 3), and gene transfer with the HPV-31 L1 Cta peptide was 1048 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Thus, the level of gene transfer obtained with L1 peptides was 24 to 26 % of that observed with the corresponding VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	157	L2-derived peptides were also tested to verify the role of L2 in DNA binding and gene transfer.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The results showed that the N- and C-terminal L2 peptides bound to and protected DNA from Benzonase degradation (65 % and 88 %, respectively) (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	159	 COS-7 transfection was observed with both peptides with luciferase activity of 860 and 1115 c.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	160	, respectively (Table 1 and Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	161	 These findings indicate the presence of two DNA binding sequences on HPV-16 L2 protein, contrary to the findings of Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	162	 (2001) recently observed that the nine C-terminal amino acids of L2 are necessary for BPV infection.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Our findings suggest that this could be due to the presence of a strong DNA-binding sequence at the C terminus of the protein.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	164	 This raises the question of which DNA-binding sequence detected within the L1 and L2 proteins interacts with the PES identified on the BPV-1 genome between nucleotides 1506 and 1625 (Zhao et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	165	 This PES was also recognized by HPV-6b VLPs despite the phylogenic distance between these two papillomavirus types.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	166	 (1999) have therefore suggested that other papillomaviruses may use the same packaging sequence that we confirmed using HPV-16 VLPs (El Mehdaoui et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	167	 It has been shown that the presence of L2 in HPV VLPs dramatically increase their gene transfer efficiency (Roden et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	168	, 1998) and that packaging with BPV-1 L1+L2 VLPs is increased in the presence of a papillomavirus DNA sequence (Zhao et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	169	, 1999), suggesting that specific DNA binding to L2 is necessary to obtain efficient packaging.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	170	 We therefore investigated gene transfer into COS-7 cells, using L1 and L2 synthetic peptides complexed with a pCMV- plasmid and a pPES-CMV- plasmid (El Mehdaoui et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	171	No transfection was observed with HPV-16 L1 Cta and HPV-31 L1 Ctb peptides, whichever plasmid was used.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	172	 However, when using the two HPV-16 L2 peptides or the HPV-16 L1 Ctb, HPV-31 L1 Cta and HPV-45 L1 Cta peptides, a two- to threefold significant increase in the level of gene transfer was observed (Table 2) when the plasmid contained the BPV PES, in comparison with the levels obtained with the pCMV- plasmid (P=10-5, 10-2,  < 10-5, 7x10-5and 2x10-4, respectively).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	173	 No increase in gene transfer was observed when using Lipofectamine and pCMV-PES- (438 plus or minus 3 cells per well) compared with the use of pCMV- (470 plus or minus 2 cells per well).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	174	 This suggested that the increase observed in gene transfer with L1 or L2 peptides is not due to differences in gene transfer efficiency of the two plasmids used, nor to a post-entry effect of PES on luciferase expression.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Gene transfer with L1 or L2 peptides in the presence or absence of the BPV-1 packaging enhancing sequence (PES).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	176	Data are the means of three experiments.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	177	  To confirm the higher binding of positively charged sequences of L1 and L2 proteins with PES sequences compared with random DNA as suggested by transfection experiments, binding of the HPV-16 L1 Ctb, HPV-16 L2 Ct and SV40 large T peptides to probes containing PES or not was also investigated by ELISA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Absence of DNA binding with PES-positive and PES-negative DNA sequences was observed for the SV40 Large T peptide (A=0 007 plus or minus 0 001 and 0 014 plus or minus 0 007, respectively).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Increased DNA-binding activity to DNA sequences containing the PES sequence of BPV1 was observed for both the HPV 16 L1 Ctb peptide (0 390 plus or minus 0 040 versus 0 030 plus or minus 0 020) and the HPV 16 L2 Ct peptide (0 440 plus or minus 0 040 versus 0 030 plus or minus 0 020).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	180	These findings indicated that gene transfer was enhanced in the presence of the BPV PES with all peptides that had the capacity to bind to DNA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	181	 This confirmed that the PES is not papillomavirus type-specific and suggested that both L1 and L2 proteins recognized BPV PES.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	182	 In addition, the results suggested that the very low level of gene transfer observed with HPV-16 L1 Cta and HPV-31 L1 Ctb peptides in the presence of pCMV-Luc plasmid was not a consequence of the fact that these peptides have a higher affinity for papillomavirus DNA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	183	Binding of positively charged peptides derived from HPV L1 or L2 proteins to heparin and cell GAGs As L1 and L2 positively charged sequences are able to transfer genes, it could be hypothesized that such peptides bind to DNA and to cells and that the NLS activity of such peptides sends the plasmid DNA to the nucleus where the reporter gene is expressed.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	184	 GAGs have been proposed as cell receptors for HPVs (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	185	, 2001) and a sequence has been identified at the C terminus of the HPV-11 L1 protein that interacts with this cell receptor (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	186	 This sequence was included in the HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	187	The interaction between peptides and heparin was tested using a competition assay measuring the binding of HPV-31 VLPs to heparin-coated plates.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The results were expressed as percentage inhibition of HPV-31 VLP binding to heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Inhibition greater than 50 % was considered to indicate binding of the peptide to heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	190	 To rule out the hypothesis that these findings were due to binding between peptides and VLPs, the interaction between HPV-31 VLPs and HPV-16 L1 Ctb, HPV-31 L1 Cta, HPV-45 L1 Ctb and HPV16 E4 Ag peptides was investigated by ELISA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	191	 No binding (A < 0 050) of HPV-31 VLPs to any of the peptides investigated was observed.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	192	 These results indicated that all peptides inhibited binding of VLPs to heparin with the exception of HPV-16 E4 Ag, HPV-16 L1 Cta, HPV-31 L1 Ctb and HPV-58 L1 Ctb (Table 1).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	193	 It should be noted that peptides that did not deliver genes into cells did not bind to heparin, nor did they bind efficiently to DNA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	194	 In addition, the absence of binding of HPV-16 L19 VLPs to heparin (data not shown) confirmed and extended the results of Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	195	 (1999) with HPV-11, suggesting that binding to heparin is mediated by the L1 protein 15 C-terminal amino acids.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	196	To test whether GAGs could competitively inhibit gene delivery, COS-7 cells were transfected with all the DNA/peptide complexes that transferred genes in the presence of heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Following exposure to DNA/peptide complexes and heparin, cells were washed, incubated in fresh culture medium and assayed for luciferase expression 48 h later.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Gene transfer was inhibited by 67 to 90 % when heparin was added to the DNA/peptide complexes, depending on the peptide used (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Inhibition of gene transfer was not observed after pre-incubation of the complexes with BSA in place of heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The role of proteoglycans in binding of HPV to cells was also assessed by inhibition of their sulfation with sodium chlorate.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	201	 For this purpose, COS-7 cells were grown in the presence of sodium chlorate for 12 h and then transfected with HPV-16 L1 Ctb, HPV-33 L1 Ctb, HPV-45 L1 Ctb and L2 N- and C-terminal peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Luciferase gene expression was inhibited by pretreatment with sodium chlorate in a dose-dependent manner (data not shown).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Gene transfer was dramatically decreased compared with untreated cells, with a decrease of 69 % for HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide and 70 % for HPV-45 L1 Ctb (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	204	 These findings suggested that L1-derived peptides use heparan sulfate to enter cells and deliver genes into cells, as do VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	205	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Inhibition of luciferase gene transfer by heparin (black bars) or after pretreatment of cells with sodium chlorate (grey bars).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Data are the mean of three experiments.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Error bars represent the mean plus or minus SD.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	209	  The results obtained are in agreement with those of gene transfer using HPV-16 L19 VLPs made of L1 protein lacking the last nine amino acids (Touze et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	210	, 2000), indicating that these amino acids are essential for DNA binding and gene transfer.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	211	 These findings are in agreement with those of Giroglou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	212	 (2001) indicating that HPV-33 VLPs made of L1 protein lacking the last seven amino acids still bind to target cells since we identified a second positively charged sequence able to bind heparan sulfate at positions 472 to 481 of the C terminus of HPV-33 L1 protein.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	213	 However, they are not in agreement with the fact that HPV-33 VLPs made of L1 protein lacking the 22 last amino acids still bind to target cells, since this deletion partially deletes the second DNA- and heparin-binding sequence.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	214	 However, it should be noted that the VLPs used by Giroglou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	215	 (2001) were composed of L1 and L2 proteins and that binding to heparin could be due to the presence of the two DNA- and heparin-binding sequences identified at the N and C termini of L2.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	216	Structural data available concerning L1 protein (Chen et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	217	, 2000) and immunological and DNA-binding data concerning L2 protein (Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	218	, 2002) suggest that the peptides tested in this study are inside the virions, where they would be expected to be unavailable for heparin and cell GAG binding.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	219	 However, gene transfer experiments using VLPs have indicated that VLP binding to DNA, to cells and to heparin is linked to the last C-terminal amino acids of the L1 protein (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	220	, 2000), suggesting its presence at the surface of the VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The absence of heparin binding observed for HPV-16 L19 VLPs clearly suggests the involvement of this sequence in cell binding through its binding to GAGs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	222	The role of the positively charged termini of the L2 protein in viral encapsidation has been fully established (Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The results of heparin binding obtained with L2 positively charged peptides raise the possibility that these sequences could also be involved in VLP and virion binding to the cell GAGs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	224	 L1+L2 VLPs lacking either the N or C terminus of the L2 protein have been shown by immunoflurescence studies to bind to cells in the same way as wild-type VLPs (Roden et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	225	, 2001), suggesting that these sequences do not play a central role in binding to cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	226	 However, in the absence of data obtained with pseudovirions composed of L1 C-terminal mutants and L2 proteins (both wild-type and N-terminal mutants), it is difficult to conclude whether N-terminal positively charged sequences of the L2 protein are present on the virion surface and play a role in its binding to the cell or not.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	227	In conclusion, using synthetic peptides we have confirmed that the DNA binding of the HPV-16 L1 protein is due to the last C-terminal amino acids.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	228	 We also confirmed the binding properties of N- and C-terminal amino acids of the HPV-16 L2 protein.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	229	 In addition, we determined that a second positively charged sequence located upstream from the previous L1 sequence is able to bind DNA for some HPV types (HPV-33 and -45), but not, or not significantly, for other types (HPV-16, -31 and -58).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The interaction between these DNA-binding peptides and DNA induced protection from DNase degradation and was sufficient to obtain gene transfer in COS-7 cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	231	 However, the level of gene transfer with a peptide was around 150 times less efficient than that observed with the corresponding sequence within the VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	232	 It was also shown that gene transfer is mediated by binding of DNA/peptide complexes to heparan sulfate receptors, as for VLPs, confirming that positively charged DNA complexes can enter cells after binding to membrane-associated sulfated proteoglycans (Mislick  and  Baldeschweiler, 1996; Mounkes et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	233	 In addition, our findings are in agreement with reports that the inclusion of L2 protein in the constitution of HPV VLPs increases their gene transfer capacity (Roden et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	234	, 2001) and thus suggests that L2 participates in DNA encapsidation and could play a role in binding to cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	235	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   This study was supported by grants from the Association pour la Recherche sur le Cancer (grant No.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	236	 5836), the Association Vaincre la Mucoviscidose and Biotechnocentre.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	237	 was the recipient of a fellowship from the Region Centre and A.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	238	   REFERENCES Top ABSTRACT Introduction Methods Results and discussion REFERENCES   Baker, T.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Structures of bovine and human papillomaviruses.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Analysis by cryoelectron microscopy and three-dimensional image reconstruction.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Detection of neutralizing antibodies against human papillomaviruses (HPV) by inhibition of gene transfer mediated by HPV pseudovirions.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	242	 J Clin Microbiol 40, 926 to 932.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Structure of the small virus-like particles assembled from the L1 protein of human papillomavirus 16.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Gene transfer using human papillomavirus pseudovirions varies according to virus genotype and requires cell surface heparan sulfate.
