0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	179	  An even more soluble version of the HPV11 TAD containing 4 lysines at its C terminus was also purified and was also found to be monomeric by size-exclusion chromatography and analytical ultracentrifugation (data not shown).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	180	 3) to this Lys-tailed TAD was analyzed by isothermal titration calorimetry.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Formation of a 1:1 complex was observed with a Kd value of 40 nM (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	182	View larger version (14K):    FIG.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Inhibitor 1 (BILH 434), used in calorimetry and crystallization studies, has an IC50 of 180 nM in the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Inhibitor 2 was used to obtain the results in Table IV.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Inhibitor 3, carrying a tritiated methyl group (*), was used to obtain the results in Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The unlabeled analogue of this compound has an IC50 of 100 nM in the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay and a Kd for TAD binding of 40 nM, as determined by isothermal titration calorimetry.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	187	 All three inhibitors are single enantiomers with the absolute configuration as shown.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	188	  Crystal Structure of the Apo-HPV11 E2 TAD The structure of the HPV11 TAD was determined from Multiwavelength Anomalous Dispersion diffraction data obtained using crystals of the protein labeled with Se-Met (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Overall the structure of the HPV11 TAD shown in Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	190	 4 is very similar to that previously reported for the analogous domain of HPV16.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The all-C superposition of the HPV11 and -16 structures (187 residues) yielded an r.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	192	54 A, and all secondary structural elements are conserved.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The major differences are a slight twist ( < 1 degrees ) in the relative orientation of the -helical and -sheet subdomains and to variations in the position of loops, in particular those comprised of residues 140-143 and 160-165, which are involved in crystal packing in the HPV16 and HPV11 structures, respectively.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The N-terminal (amino acids 3-94) and C-terminal (amino acids 95-195) subdomains can be individually superimposed with r.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Interestingly, the HPV11 protein crystal lattice was distinct from that reported for HPV16, such that a different monomer-monomer interface was observed in the HPV11 crystal structure.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	196	View larger version (51K):    FIG.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Comparison of HPV11 and HPV16 TAD structures.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	198	 All C superposition of the HPV11 His-TAD (1R6K) and HPV16 His-TAD (Protein Data Bank code 1DTO [PDB] (20)) proteins.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The HPV11 structure is shown in red and for HPV16 is shown in blue.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The location of loops at amino acids 122-127 (not modeled in the HPV11 structure) and at 140-143 and 160-165 (not well superimposed because of crystal packing differences) are also indicated.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	201	  Crystal Structure of an HPV11 E2 TAD-Inhibitor Complex We obtained crystals of the more soluble Lys-tailed TAD in complex with compound 1, albeit using different conditions than those used to crystallize the apo-His-TAD.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The space group of these crystals was also different from any of the previous TAD structures (Table I).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The conformation of the HPV11 TAD within the complex (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	204	 5A) is very similar to that observed for the apoprotein; all backbone C could be superimposed with an r.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The two inhibitor 1 molecules are both in the free carboxylate form (as drawn in Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	206	 3), one of two distinct forms that this class of inhibitors adopts in solution (43).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The presence in the crystal structure of the free carboxylate form confirms a prediction that this form is the one with inhibitory activity (43).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	208	View larger version (61K):    FIG.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Structure of the HPV11 TAD-inhibitor 1 complex.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	210	 A, stereo view of the complex of two inhibitor molecules bound to the HPV11 TAD (1R6N).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Inhibitor molecule B is above molecule A.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	212	 B, stereo view of the molecular surface of HPV11 TAD with inhibitor molecules A (bottom) and B (top).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Spheres corresponding to locations within the binding site where ligand atoms are predicted to make particularly favorable interactions with the protein are shown in yellow and amino acids that comprise this small molecule binding pocket are shown in magenta.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The indandione moiety of inhibitor B (left-most portion in the view shown) is well above the protein surface, 7 A from the nearest residue in the binding pocket.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	215	 C, stereo view of selected amino acids within 4 A of inhibitor A are shown as they appear in the apo structure (magenta) and in the inhibitor-TAD complex (green).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Inhibitor A is shown in orange.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The relative positions of residues are based on an all C- superposition of the two structures.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Thin green lines indicate hydrogen bonds between the inhibitor carboxylate and main chain amide nitrogens of residues 99 and 100.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	219	  Because we had demonstrated that the TAD and inhibitor 1 form a 1:1 complex in solution, we were surprised to find two molecules of inhibitor bound per protein monomer (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	220	 We believe that the molecule referred to below as inhibitor A is the one that binds tightly in biological assays (see below).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	221	 In contrast, inhibitor B appears to interact only weakly with a secondary binding pocket, formed not only by the TAD protein alone, but also in part by one surface of inhibitor A, as well as by residues from an adjacent protein monomer in the crystal lattice.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	222	 In fact, inhibitor B has approximately equal surface area in contact with each of the two TAD molecules, as well as with inhibitor A (data not shown).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The close contact between the two inhibitor molecules may distort the observed interaction between the TAD and the dichlorophenyl ring of inhibitor A (see below).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The TAD-TAD interface that incorporates inhibitor B is distinct from that in the apo structure, and in fact does not result in formation of a dimer, but rather an infinite array (along the 41 screw axis of the crystal), which is unlikely to exist in solution except at very high protein and inhibitor concentrations.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	225	To further demonstrate that the region of the TAD near inhibitor A constitutes a better binding pocket than does the one near B, a computational analysis of the protein surface was performed using the Site Finder application within the MOE software package (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	226	 This program uses an shape-based algorithm (44) to identify concave regions on the protein surface.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Furthermore, it evaluates whether these cavities have an appropriate composition of hydrophobic and hydrophilic atoms, as hydrophilic cavities are likely to be highly solvated and thus interact only weakly with organic molecules in aqueous solution.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The TAD surface was evaluated after removal of the two inhibitors, and residues that comprised the best small molecule-binding pocket are highlighted in Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Inhibitor A makes a number of close contacts with these highlighted residues, as described below.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Inhibitor B is located on the periphery of this pocket and does not make any well defined hydrogen bonding or Van der Waals interactions.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The dichlorophenyl ring of inhibitor B is 4 A from the nearest pocket atoms; other portions of the molecule are further from the protein surface (indandione moiety) or make closest contact with non-pocket atoms (thiadiazoylphenyl moiety).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	232	In a separate computational study, binding energies for each inhibitor molecule to the TAD (in the absence of the other) were predicted using three different empirical protein-binding scoring functions (Table III).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	233	 As expected, results significantly favored binding of inhibitor A relative to B, with predicted binding energies 2-fold higher for inhibitor A.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Taken together, these different methods suggest that inhibitor A is solely responsible for inhibition at the low concentrations used in biological assays and that the presence of inhibitor B might be an artifact of crystallization.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	235	 This suggestion is further supported by the mutational analysis of the inhibitor binding pocket, presented below.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Although an artifact, it is possible that the fortuitous presence of this second molecule aided in crystallization of the complex.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	237	View this table:    TABLE III Estimated binding affinities for inhibitors A and B.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	238	Three empirical scoring functions were applied to compound 1 bound in the location of either inhibitor A or B.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	239	 For PMF (35) and PLP (36), a lower (more negative) score indicates better affinity, whereas for LUDI (37) a higher score predicts better affinity.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	240	 For each program, scores are proportional to predicted binding energies.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	241	5 A of 12 residues (marked by asterisks in Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	242	 1), and the backbone superposition for these in the apo and complex structures gives an r.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	243	 However, binding of this inhibitor induces significant movement of several amino acid side chains.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The indandione moiety of the inhibitor is buried in a pocket that is not present in the apo structure, but results from rotations of the side chains of Tyr-19 (1, 85 degrees ; 2, 40 degrees ) and His-32 (2, 90 degrees ) (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In the apo structure, the aromatic rings of His-32 and Trp-33 form a T-shaped edge-to-face structure, with the hydroxyl group of Tyr-19 close enough to form a hydrogen bond with the -nitrogen of His-32.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	246	 In the complex structure, this interaction is lost and the rings of His-32 and Trp-33 become parallel to each other.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Two other side chains, Leu-94 and Glu-100, also adjust their conformations to accommodate the inhibitor (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Together, these changes in side chain conformation result in the formation of the observed binding pocket (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	249	View larger version (121K):    FIG.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Amino acids that form the inhibitor binding pocket.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Residues discussed in the text are colored as follows: Tyr-19 and His-32 in magenta; Leu-94 and Glu-100 in yellow (left and right, respectively); Trp-33 in blue; Met-101 in cyan.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Residues surrounding the shallow end of the binding pocket are colored red.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	253	  The new positions of Tyr-19 and His-32 not only open up the pocket, but also allow the indandione moiety of the inhibitor to become a middle layer of a three-tier -stacking interaction between His-32 and Trp-33.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Additional Van der Waals contacts from the Leu-94 side chain result in a highly complementary shape to the deepest part of the pocket.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Two other important interactions are made with the backbone nitrogen atoms of Tyr-99 and Glu-100; the distance (2.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	256	77 A) and angle between these atoms and the inhibitor carboxylate oxygens suggests the formation of strong hydrogen bonds (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	257	Remaining contacts of inhibitor A with the pocket are less well defined hydrophobic interactions.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The dichlorophenyl ring lies in a wider but shallower portion of the pocket without making obvious specific interactions.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Although it has been found in previous studies (22) that both chlorine atoms contribute significantly to binding, neither atom is very close to the protein; the closest one being 4 A from the Tyr-19 side chain.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	260	 The observed position of the dichlorophenyl ring may be due in part to distortions induced by crystal packing or the presence of the second inhibitor molecule, as discussed above.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The thiadiazolylphenyl group lies along the protein surface outside of the pocket.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Notably, the phenyl-thiadiazole bond is close to the side chain of Met-101.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This finding is consistent with recent photoaffinity labeling experiments2 in which the carbon atom para to the amide bond of an analogue was found to be covalently linked to the terminal carbon of Met-101 (see Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	264	Mutational Analysis of the Inhibitor Binding Pocket Several residues in or near the inhibitor binding pocket were mutated to examine the roles of specific side chains in binding the indandione, as well as gain insight into the possible overlap between the E1- and inhibitor-binding sites.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Most residues were mutated to Ala, but a few residues were replaced by amino acids found in other HPV types: His-32 was changed to Tyr as found in HPV16 E2, whereas Ile-30, Met-31, and Ile-36 were changed to Val, Leu, and Met, respectively, as found in HPV6 E2.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	266	 These last three residues are the only ones in the vicinity of inhibitor A that are different between HPV11 and -6 E2.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Also included in this study was the amino acid substitution I73A that is located on the opposite face of the protein and was previously shown to specifically affect the transactivation activity of E2 rather than its replication or E1 binding activity (25).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Each mutant protein was produced by in vitro translation and tested in our previously described E1-E2-ori complex formation assay using radiolabeled origin DNA (Table IV).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	269	 The ability of each protein to interact with E1 was scored qualitatively, because we did not control for variations in the level of protein produced in the in vitro transcription-translation reaction and, in any case, could not assess the proper folding or stability of the proteins.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Most mutant proteins retained at least some ability to productively interact with E1 at the origin.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	271	View this table:    TABLE IV Effect of amino acid substitutions in the E2 TAD on E1-E2-ori complex formation.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	272	E1-E2-ori complex assembly reactions were carried out using in vitro translated HPV11 E2, E1-containing extract, and 33P-labeled origin DNA (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	273	 A signal of 3100 cpm and signal: background (S:B) ratio = 21 was observed in assays performed with wild type E2.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	274	 For mutant E2 proteins, E1-E2-ori complex formation was scored qualitatively as follows: + +  >  1000 cpm and S:B  >  8; + = 500-1000 cpm and S:B = 3-8; +/- = 150-500 cpm and S:B = 2-3.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	275	 IC50 values for compound 2 (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	276	 3) were determined by measuring complex assembly in the presence of compound concentrations ranging from 2 nM to 40  microM.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Values shown are the average from duplicate determinations which in most cases differed by 30% or less.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	278	  We also determined the sensitivity of these mutant proteins to inhibitor 2 (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	279	 3), an analogue of compound 1 that we have described previously (23).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	280	 A number of substitutions had little if any effect on interaction with E1 or on inhibitor binding.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	281	 These included V64A and K68A, which interact with inhibitor molecule B in the inhibitor-TAD complex, thereby providing further evidence that binding of this second molecule is not relevant to inhibition.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	282	Substitutions I30V/M31L and I36M, which make the HPV11 TAD more similar to that of HPV6 E2, also had little effect on inhibition.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	283	 These results suggest that none of these three residues are responsible for the 30-fold weaker affinity of HPV6 E2 for compound 2 (23).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	284	 In further support that these residues do not play a major role in the type selectivity of the indandione inhibitors, we found that the corresponding mutations (V30I/L31M and M36I) in HPV6 E2 also had little effect on inhibition (data not shown).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	285	Other substitutions (L15A, Y19A, E39A, and S98A) produced inactive or weakly active proteins.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	286	 In principle this could indicate either that these side chains are directly involved in interaction with E1, or that the mutant proteins are not properly folded.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The low signals obtained with the Y19A and E39A E2 proteins in the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay were insufficient to assess inhibition.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	288	Substitution of Gln-12, His-32, Leu-43, Ser-65, and Ile-73 had a more deleterious effect on compound binding (IC50 values) than on interaction with E1, suggesting that these residues may have a specific role in binding the inhibitor.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	289	 However, three of these substitutions are at the periphery of the inhibitor-binding site (Gln-12, Leu-43, and Ser-65), and Ile-73 is on the opposite face of the protein.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	290	 A possible rationale for these observations is discussed below.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	291	 In contrast, His-32 is in direct contact with the biologically relevant inhibitor A.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	292	 The presence of a tyrosine instead of a histidine at position 32 of the E2 proteins of HPV16, -18, and -31, (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	293	 1) may contribute to the insensitivity of these proteins to the indandione class of inhibitors.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Consistent with this proposal, we found in other studies3 that an HPV31 E2 carrying the double amino acid substitution D31M/Y32H was significantly more sensitive to compound 2 (IC50 = 6  microM) than its WT counterpart (IC50 = 70  microM), when tested in an assay format similar to that used to generate the results reported in Table IV.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Finally, a particularly interesting result, which we have noted previously (23), was the improved affinity of E100A E2 for this class of inhibitors.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	296	Biophysical and Functional Characterization of Purified Mutant E2 TADs Because the roles of Tyr-19 and Glu-39 in the binding of E1 or inhibitors could not be assessed using the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay, we produced the corresponding mutant TAD proteins in E.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	297	 coli to carry out additional assays and biophysical studies.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	298	 We also expressed the L15A TAD, for which a moderately reduced affinity for E1 and inhibitor 2 were observed, as well as the I73A and E100A proteins, to better understand the significant effects of these two mutations on inhibitor binding.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Analysis of all these proteins by circular dichroism indicated no significant change in secondary structure compared with the WT (data not shown).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	300	 The thermal stability of each mutant protein was determined by differential scanning calorimetry and found to be comparable with that of the WT TAD, with the L15A protein being reproducibly the least stable (Table V).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	301	View this table:    TABLE V Effect of selected amino acid substitutions on properties of E2 TAD proteins.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	302	Melting temperatures were determined by differential scanning calorimetry.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Values shown are averages of two determinations that differed by less than 0.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Dissociation constants for compound 3 were determined using a tight-binding equation (see data in Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Parameters for inhibition of E1 ATPase activity were determined using a three-parameter logistic (WT, L15A, I73A, and E100A) or, when not possible, by estimation (Y19A and E39A), see data in Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	306	 For these experiments, values shown are the averages of triplicate or quadruplicate experiments  plus or minus  SD.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	307	  Next, we measured the affinity of each TAD protein for compound 3 (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	308	 3) using an equilibrium binding assay.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	309	 The Kd values for binding of 3 to WT and Y19A TADs were similar (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Because the side chain of Tyr-19 undergoes a substantial change in position upon inhibitor binding, the lack of effect of the Y19A mutation on the affinity for inhibitor 3 may actually be due to a combination of two offsetting effects: a loss of Tyr-19-inhibitor interactions partially compensated for by a reduction in the conformational change (entropic cost) necessary to form the inhibitor binding pocket.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Further mutagenesis of this residue would be necessary to address this possibility.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The Kd value for 3 binding to E100A was roughly 10-fold lower, but could not be precisely determined in part because the value of Kd is well below the protein concentration used in the experiment (5 versus 50 nM).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	313	 I73A, L15A, and especially E39A had significantly reduced affinities for the compound.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Where a direct comparison can be made, results in Table V are in qualitative agreement with those from the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay shown in Table IV.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	315	View larger version (21K):    FIG.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Interaction of mutant TAD proteins with inhibitor 3 or E1.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	317	 For both panels, data points shown are for WT TAD (solid circles), or derivatives carrying the substitutions L15A (open squares), Y19A (black triangles), E39A (open triangles), I73A (open circles), and E100A (solid squares).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	318	 A, dissociation constants for inhibitor 3 were determined by titrating the inhibitor (4-500 nM) into 96-well Ni-chelate Flashplates containing 50 nM TAD.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Lines were determined by non-linear regression using a tight-binding equation and are based on triplicate measurements.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	320	 B, E1 binding was evaluated by the ability of the different proteins to inhibit HPV11 E1 ATPase activity.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	321	 ATPase activity was measured by a scintillation proximity assay as described previously (40, 41) using 3 nM E1 and 20  microM ATP.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Inhibition was measured for each TAD protein at concentrations from 2 to 1000 nM and points are based on averages of three separate experiments.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Lines connecting the points are for ease of visualization only.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	324	  We assessed the relative affinity of each of these TAD proteins for E1 by taking advantage of our earlier finding that the ATPase activity of E1 is inhibited by addition of the transactivation domain.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	325	 TAD binding significantly increases the apparent Km of E1 for ATP.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	326	 However, we observed that TAD-saturated E1 retained some ATPase activity.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	327	 We also reported a corresponding weakening of E2 binding in the presence of high ATP concentrations, which might play a role in the dissociation of E2 and assembly of E1 hexamers at the origin (40).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	328	Although not a direct binding assay, monitoring ATPase activity in the presence of E2 (or the TAD) provides a DNA-independent, solution-phase method of assessing the E1-E2 interaction.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Titration of WT TAD into E1 ATPase assays inhibited activity to a maximum of 86% (Imax = 86%), with an IC50 of 4 nM (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Similar results were obtained for I73A and E100A confirming that these mutations do not affect E1 binding substantially.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	331	 It should be noted, however, that the IC50 values reported for I73A, E100A, and WT TAD are close to the E1 concentration used in these assays (3 nM), and hence that these IC50 values are likely to be an underestimate of the affinity of these proteins for E1.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	332	The remaining three mutant E2 proteins (L15A, Y19A, and E39A) differed from their WT counterpart in two ways.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	333	 First, the maximal degree of E1-ATPase inhibition obtained at saturating concentrations of TAD was lower for these mutants than for WT E2.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	334	 This was more prominent for Y19A and E39A E2, which achieved a maximum inhibition of only 32 and 38%, respectively.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Although we do not completely understand why these mutant E2 TADs achieve a lower maximum level of inhibition it suggests that the geometry of the TAD-E1 complexes that do form for these two proteins is such that the complexes retain greater residual ATPase activity.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	336	 The second way in which these three mutant proteins differed from WT E2 is in their lower affinity for E1, as measured by the IC50 values required to reach their respective maximal level of ATPase inhibition.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	337	 By this measure, L15A was found to reduce only slightly, if at all, the affinity of E2 for E1, whereas Y19A and E39A had a larger effect.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Qualitatively, these results are in good agreement with those obtained in the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay (Table IV) in that the E1-E2 interaction is little affected by I73A and E100A, moderately affected by L15A, but more significantly reduced by Y19A and, as anticipated, by E39A.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Notably, all mutant proteins retained some ability to interact with E1.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	340	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Structure of HPV11 E2 TAD The tertiary structure of the HPV11 E2 TAD is nearly identical to that of the analogous domain from HPV16 (20).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	341	 In particular, the orientations of the two subdomains are similar for both TADs, suggesting that the relative position of these subdomains is a fundamental characteristic of this -fold, and that the overall structure is fairly rigid even though it is far from globular.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	342	 This idea is further supported by the fact that neither the binding of the indandione inhibitor nor the differing crystal packing arrangements of the three structures significantly altered the observed tertiary structure.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	343	Based on the structure of the HPV16 E2 TAD, Antson et al.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	344	 (20) proposed the existence of an additional E2 dimerization interface within the TAD, comprised of the second and third -helices, and notably involving a cluster of conserved residues (Arg-37, Ala-69, Ile-73, Gln-76, Leu-77, Glu-80, and Thr-81).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Although the area of this interface is relatively large (2000 A2), it contains a number of water-mediated interactions and relatively few hydrophobic residue contacts, in contrast to most protein interfaces that are typically less hydrophilic than solvent-exposed surfaces (45, 46).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Our observation that quite distinct monomer-monomer interactions are found in both of our HPV11 TAD structures, together with the results from chromatography and ultracentrifugation experiments that the HPV11 TAD is fully monomeric at concentrations up to 20  microM calls into question the generality of the TAD dimerization interface and thus the likelihood that it plays a fundamental role in the function of E2, at least in the case of HPV11.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	347	Nature of the Inhibitor Binding Site The inhibitor binding pocket (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	348	 7) is not present in the E2 apo structure but rather appears to be induced upon inhibitor binding.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	349	 This pocket is comprised of a large "shallow end" approximately defined by residues Gln-12, Glu-39, Lys-68, and Gln-71 and a smaller "deep end" defined by His-32, Trp-33, and Leu-94.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	350	 The indandione moiety of inhibitor A is complementary to the deep end, and the resulting Van der Waals interactions, together with the hydrogen bonds between the carboxylate and backbone amides, account for the strongly exothermic binding of compounds in this series (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Additional interactions are made by the thiadiazoylphenyl moiety that extends out of the pocket, near Met-101.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	352	Conclusions Based on Studies with Mutant E2 Proteins The Side Chain of Glu-100 May Impede Inhibitor Binding Mutation of Glu-100 to Ala did not affect substantially the interaction of E2 with E1, but specifically enhanced inhibitor binding as we reported previously (23).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	353	 The structure of the inhibitor-TAD complex provides an explanation for this gain in affinity, namely that the entropic cost associated with the conformational change in the Glu-100 side chain necessary for compound binding (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	354	 5C) is likely reduced in the case of Ala-100.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	355	Amino Acids Outside the Pocket Can Reduce Inhibitor Binding A number of substitutions (Q12A, L15A, L43A, S65A, and I73A) clearly affected binding of the inhibitor, although they changed residues that do not directly contact the inhibitor in the structure.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Further structural information would be required to fully understand the effects of these five substitutions, but all of these residues are located on helices in the three-helix bundle that defines the N-terminal subdomain of the TAD.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	357	 The residues that form the deep pocket that binds tightly to the indandione moiety are also located within this three-helix bundle, and given the close fit between the inhibitor and this pocket it is possible that these substitutions subtly affect the packing of the three helices in a way that slightly alters the binding pocket.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	358	 Perhaps similar subtle conformational changes explain why the indandione class of inhibitors binds to HPV6 E2 10-30-fold less tightly than to HPV11 E2, because the few amino acid differences in or near the binding pocket did not account for this type of differential activity.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	359	 The effects of these non-binding site residue differences are conceptually similar to some HIV protease resistance mutations that occur well outside of the active site (47).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	360	Importance of His-32 for Inhibitor Binding We found that the specificity for inhibitor binding to low-risk rather than high-risk HPV types is in part because of a residue forming the pocket, His-32, which is a tyrosine in high risk types (Fig.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	361	 Substitution of His-32 for tyrosine in HPV11 E2 abrogated inhibitor binding, although it did not significantly affect interaction with E1.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Based on our structure of the inhibitor-TAD complex, this substitution is predicted to prevent formation of the deep end of the inhibitor binding pocket.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	363	 Furthermore, the converse experiment of inserting His-32 into HPV31 E2 generated a mutant protein that could interact with compound 2, albeit not to the same extent as HPV11 or HPV6 E2.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	364	A Role for Tyrosine 19 in Binding to E1 Tyr-19 is highly conserved among HPV types although it is an Ile in bovine papillomaviruses.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Substitution of this residue by Ala resulted in an HPV11 E2 protein that was still capable of binding the inhibitor and whose melting temperature and CD spectrum were very similar to that of wild type E2, indicating that this mutation does not affect the overall structure of the TAD.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	366	 However, the Y19A mutant protein was defective in binding to E1 both in an E1-E2-ori complex formation assay and in an E1-ATPase inhibition assay.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Thus, this mutation appears to specifically affect E1 binding.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	368	 The proximity on the TAD surface of Tyr-19 to Glu-39, the only other residue specifically implicated in binding to E1, suggests that this surface of E2 might form part of the E1-E2 protein-protein interface.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	369	 If so, our results would imply that the interaction of Tyr-19 with E1 is energetically important for formation of this interface and that the indandione class of inhibitors antagonizes E1 binding by competing directly for the same or an overlapping binding surface on E2.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	370	 In fact, the structure of an HPV18 E1-E2 TAD complex has recently been determined, and Tyr-19 does appear to make an important interaction with E1.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	371	Analysis of the two crystal structures presented here has provided a detailed understanding of the mechanism by which the indandione inhibitors bind to E2, to disrupt the E1-E2 protein-protein interaction.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Comparison of these two structures revealed the induced fit mechanism by which the inhibitor binding pocket is formed and further illustrates that it is very difficult to accurately identify binding pockets or model protein-ligand interactions using only the structure of an unliganded protein (48).
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	373	 The binding pocket includes both a deep, narrow cavity filled by the indandione moiety, as well as a wider shallow region that makes only a few contacts with the inhibitor.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	374	 The finding that a second inhibitor molecule can bind to this shallow region of the pocket raises the possibility that molecules could be found that would retain specific interactions with the deep cavity but gain additional binding energy by interaction with the larger shallow region.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	375	 The characterization of a well defined small molecule binding pocket on the E2 TAD represents an important step toward the design of HPV antivirals.
0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	376	   FOOTNOTES   The atomic coordinates and structure factors (code 1R6K and 1R6N) have been deposited in the Protein Data Bank, Research Collaboratory for Structural Bioinformatics, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ (http://www.

0.33389336.14634007.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	4	, Laval, Quebec H7S 2G5, Canada.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	5	Received for publication, March 2, 2001, and in revised form, April 12, 2001.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	6	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	7	To better characterize the enzymatic activities required for human papillomavirus (HPV) DNA replication, the E1 helicases of HPV types 6 and 11 were produced using a baculovirus expression system.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The purified wild type proteins and a version of HPV11 E1 lacking the N-terminal 71 amino acids, which was better expressed, were found to be hexameric over a wide range of concentrations and to have helicase and ATPase activities with relatively low values for Km(ATP) of 12  microM for HPV6 E1 and 6  microM for HPV11 E1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Interestingly, the value of Km(ATP) was increased 7-fold in the presence of the E2 transactivation domain.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In turn, ATP was found to perturb the co-operative binding of E1 and E2 to DNA.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Mutant and truncated versions of in vitro translated E1 were used to identify a minimal ATPase domain composed of the C-terminal 297 amino acids.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This fragment was expressed, purified, and found to be fully active in ATP hydrolysis, single-stranded DNA binding, and unwinding assays, despite lacking the minimal origin-binding domain.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	13	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	14	The papillomaviruses (PVs)1 are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that infect and replicate in the cutaneous or mucosal epithelia of humans and other mammals.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	15	 There are over 100 types of human papillomavirus (HPV), which cause conditions ranging from plantar warts (HPV1) and genital warts (HPV6 and -11) to cervical cancer (HPV16, -18, and -31).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	16	 HPV6 and -11 are also responsible for laryngeal papillomatosis, a rare but very serious infection of the respiratory tract (1).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Antiviral agents capable of specifically inhibiting PV replication could play an important role in the treatment of these diseases, but none exist at this time.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	18	Despite their host and tissue specificity, all of the PV types share a common genomic organization.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The closed, circular genome of ~8000 base pairs codes for only 10 proteins: eight early proteins termed E1-E8 and two late proteins, L1 and L2, that make up the viral coat (2).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	20	 E1 and E2 are the only viral proteins required for HPV DNA replication (3, 4).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	21	 E2 is a sequence-specific DNA-binding protein that serves to regulate both transcription and DNA replication.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	22	 E1, a DNA helicase, is the only PV protein that possesses enzymatic activity (5) and is also the most highly conserved of the PV proteins.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	23	 For these reasons, E1 has been considered as the most attractive molecular target for the development of antiviral agents (6).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	24	During the initiation of PV DNA replication, E2 serves as a specificity factor to enhance binding of E1 monomers to the origin, which by themselves bind to double-stranded DNA with little sequence specificity (4, 7-11).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	25	 E2 dimers bind with high specificity to DNA sequences within the origin and recruit to it E1 monomers, through direct protein-protein interactions (12, 13).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Upon binding to DNA, E1 monomers assemble into hexamers (14, 15), but the E1-E2 interaction is not maintained (16, 17).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Thus, the role of E2 is to catalyze the assembly of hexameric E1 complexes specifically at the origin.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	28	 ATP hydrolysis is also required for E1 hexamers to distort the origin and encircle single strands of DNA (18).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Using in vitro translated HPV11 proteins, we have previously shown that ATP binding stimulates the E2-dependent association of E1 with the origin (19).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	30	 ATP binding does not affect the E2 binding step or the E1-E2 interaction but rather a subsequent process, either oligomerization and binding of E1 to DNA or the stability of the assembled E1-origin DNA complex (19, 20).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	31	 ATP hydrolysis is not required in this case, since the nonhydrolyzable analog ATPS and ADP have similar effects.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	32	 For BPV, it has been demonstrated that ATP hydrolysis is required for displacement of E2 from the origin during assembly of E1 multimeric complexes (17).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Either concurrent with or after formation of E1 oligomers, the host polymerase  primase (21-25) and possibly also replication protein A (22, 26) bind to E1, and a replication complex is formed together with additional host factors.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	34	We and others have identified subdomains of E1 as well as conserved amino acids that are required for a number of its DNA replication activities.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	35	 We have recently shown that amino acids 166-649 of E1 efficiently support DNA replication in a cell-free system and thus must encode for all necessary binding and enzymatic activities required in vitro (25).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	36	 In vivo, additional sequences spanning amino acids 82-128 (HPV11 E1) are required; these contain an extended nuclear localization sequence (27, 28) as well as a cyclin-binding motif and cyclin-dependent kinase phosphorylation sites (29-31).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	37	 A minimal DNA binding/origin recognition sequence was mapped to approximately amino acids 140-300 for BPV E1 (32-35) (amino acids 185-345 for HPV11 E1), although the entire C terminus of the protein (amino acids 186-649) is required to observe stable binding of HPV11 E1 to the origin (20, 36).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	38	 An HPV11 E1 truncation consisting of the C-terminal amino acids 353-649 retains the ability to bind to E2 or the p70 subunit of polymerase  primase and to oligomerize into hexamers (19, 20, 25).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Within this C-terminal fragment of E1 are four conserved regions termed A, B, C, and D (see Fig.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	40	 1), which are highly similar to the functionally related T antigens of SV40 and polyomaviruses (37).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The conserved region A lies in a minimal E1 oligomerization sequence located within amino acids 353-416 (see Fig.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Three motifs characteristic of superfamily 3 of NTP-binding proteins are located between amino acids 478 and 525 of HPV11 E1 (see Fig.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Two of these motifs (motifs a and b) correspond to the Walker A and B boxes involved in binding the substrate nucleotide triphosphate-magnesium complex (39), while the exact function of the third motif (motif c) remains unclear.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Mutations of conserved residues in all three motifs have been shown to significantly decrease the ATPase activity of the superfamily 3 helicase Rep68, encoded by the adeno-associated virus (40).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Mutation of a highly conserved lysine in motif a (Lys484 in HPV11 E1) has been shown to abrogate the ATPase activity of BPV E1 (41) and HPV11 E1 (42), as also observed for many other ATPases (43).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	46	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	47	   Domain structure of the HPV11 E1 helicase.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The 649-amino acid-long HPV11 E1 helicase is diagrammed as a rectangle with black boxes labeled A, B, C, and D indicating regions of E1 that are conserved in the large T antigens of SV40 and polyomaviruses (37).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The region of HPV11 E1 that corresponds to the minimal DNA-binding domain mapped in BPV E1-(32-35) is also indicated as a black box.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The locations of conserved motifs a, b, and c that are common to members of superfamily 3 NTP-binding proteins (38) are indicated by arrows.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Indicated below E1 are truncated constructs of the protein that we have found in previous studies to be sufficient for catalyzing DNA replication in a cell-free system, for stable binding to the origin, for interaction with the transactivation domain of E2 (19) or the p70 subunit of polymerase  primase (25), or for oligomerization of the protein (20).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The position of a minimal E1-E1 interaction domain mapped between amino acids 353 and 416 using the yeast two-hybrid system (20) is indicated by a hatched box.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	53	Most studies on the enzymatic activities of purified E1 have been carried out using the BPV enzyme, purified from baculovirus-infected insect cells (5, 41, 44, 45) or Escherichia coli (15, 46).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Although the HPV E1 proteins are 40-50% identical in primary sequence to BPV E1 and presumably have very similar structures and mechanisms of action, it has proven very difficult to isolate sufficient quantities of purified HPV enzymes to characterize their enzymatic activities.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Very low levels of expression, compounded by proteolysis and contamination with other proteins, have commonly been observed.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Of the few reports on the isolation of HPV E1 (42, 47-49), in only one case was sufficient material obtained for a basic characterization of helicase activity and biophysical properties (42).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	57	 (50) have reported the isolation of epitope-tagged HPV11 E1 that is functional for in vitro DNA replication assays, but the enzymatic activities of their E1 preparations have not been described.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	58	In this report, we present our characterization of the enzymatic activities of HPV11 and -6 E1 helicases.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	59	 We have made extensive use of an N-terminal truncated form of E1, composed of amino acids 72-649, which we have shown previously is as active as wild type E1 in supporting HPV DNA replication in vitro.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	60	 We report here that this truncated E1 is expressed in significantly greater yield than full-length E1 and has improved biophysical properties.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	61	 We show that, in contrast to previous reports (41, 42, 45, 49), our purified E1 preparations have a relatively low value of Km(ATP), well below the physiological concentration of ATP.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	62	 We show that high concentrations of the E2 transactivation domain raise the apparent value of Km(ATP) and also demonstrate that the binding of ATP-Mg to E1 weakens its interaction with E2.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The perturbation of E1-E2 binding by physiological concentrations of ATP suggests a mechanism by which some of the energy gained by tight binding of ATP is used to destabilize the E1-E2 complex, which forms transiently during the initiation of viral DNA replication.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	64	 We also show that E1-(353-649), which encodes motifs for enzymatic activity but lacks the previously identified minimal origin-DNA binding region, is fully active in ATPase, helicase, and ssDNA binding assays.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Thus, while the N-terminal half of E1 is necessary for replication from the HPV origin, all sequences necessary for proper folding, oligomerization, and enzymatic catalysis are within the C terminus.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	66	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	67	Construction of Recombinant Baculoviruses-- The complete E1 open reading frame from HPV11 was amplified from plasmid pCR3-E1 (19).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The forward primer was 5'-CGC GGA TCC AGG ATG CAT CAC CAT CAC CAT CAC GCG GAC GAT TCA CGT ACA GAA AAT GAG-3', and the reverse was GG CTG AAT TCA TAA AGT TCT AAC AAC T-3', inserting 6 histidines immediately after the initial methionine.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Similarly, E1-(72-649) and E1-(353-649) were amplified from plasmid pTM1-E1 (19) with the same reverse primer but with the following forward primers, respectively: 5'-CGC GGA TCC AGG ATG CAT CAC CAT CAC CAT CAC GCG GAT GCT CAT TAT GCG ACT GTG CAG GAC-3' and 5'-CGC GGA TCC AGG ATG CAT CAC CAT CAC CAT CAC GAC AGT CAA TTT AAA TTA ACT GAA ATG GTG C-3'.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	70	 To express the corresponding catalytically inactive mutant E1 proteins, similar PCR amplifications were performed on the appropriate mutant E1 template (19).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The PCR products were then cut with BamHI and EcoRI, subcloned between the BamHI and EcoRI sites of pFASTBAC1 (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	72	), and transposed into the baculovirus genome according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	73	 E1-containing recombinant baculovirus genomes were transfected into SF9 insect cells, and baculovirus-containing supernatants were amplified for large scale protein production.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The gene for HPV6 E1 was amplified by PCR from a clinical condyloma sample and subcloned into pCR3.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	75	 PCR primers used were 5'-CAA CGA TGG CGG ACG ATT CAG GTA CAG-3' (forward, nt 827-853) and 5'-TGC TTC GGA CAC CT-3' (reverse, nt 2923-2910).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The baculovirus expression construct was made by the same procedure as for HPV11 E1, using the same forward and reverse primers for PCR.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The DNA sequence matched that reported for HPV6a E1 (GenBankTM accession number L41216) except for eight silent mutations (nt 1297 C to A, nt 1495 T to A, nt 1540 C to T, nt 2170 C to T, nt 2363 T to C, nt 2396 T to C, nt 2530 G to A, and nt 2548 T to C) and two mutations encoding conservative changes (nt 1670 G to T, changing Val280 to Leu, and nt 1741 C to A, changing Asp303 to Glu).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	78	2 The amino acid sequence for HPV6a E1 is 88% identical to that for HPV11 E1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	79	E1 Expression-- SF21 cells were maintained in SFM-900 medium (Life Technologies) at cell densities between 1 and 2  x  106/ml.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Infections were carried out for 48-72 h using a multiplicity of infection of 5.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Cells were harvested and frozen rapidly in liquid nitrogen before being stored at 80  degrees C.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	82	 All subsequent steps were performed at 0-4  degrees C.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	83	 For nuclear extraction, frozen cell pellets were thawed and resuspended in one volume of cell lysis buffer (20 mM Tris, pH 8, 5 mM -mercaptoethanol, 5 mM KCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM Pefabloc (Pentapharm Ltd.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	84	), 1  microg/ml pepstatin, 1  microg/ml leupeptin, and 1  microg/ml antipain) for 15 min and then broken with a Dounce homogenizer (20 strokes for 40 ml, pestle B) followed by centrifugation at 2500  x  g for 20 min.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Supernatant (cytosol) was discarded, and nuclei were resuspended to 1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	86	4 volumes with extraction buffer A (20 mM Tris, pH 8, 5 mM -mercaptoethanol, 2 mM Pefabloc, 2  microg/ml pepstatin, 2  microg/ml leupeptin, and 2  microg/ml antipain), followed by the addition of an equal volume of extraction buffer B (20 mM Tris, pH 8, 5 mM -mercaptoethanol, and 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	87	02% Triton X-100 for full-length E1 or the same buffer supplemented with NaCl to a final concentration of 450 mM for truncated proteins).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The nuclei were incubated with rocking for 30 min before ultracentrifugation at 148,000  x  g for 45 min.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Glycerol was added to the supernatant to a final concentration of 10%, and the extract was frozen rapidly on dry ice and stored at 80  degrees C.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	90	His-E1 Purification-- All steps were performed at 4  degrees C.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	91	 A 5-ml Hi-Trap chelating column was charged with NiSO4 according to the manufacturer's instructions (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) and then washed with equilibration buffer (20 mM Tris, pH 8, 5 mM -mercaptoethanol, 500 mM NaCl, 10 mM imidazole, and 10% glycerol).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Nuclear extracts from 5 liters of culture were thawed rapidly, the NaCl concentration was adjusted to 500 mM for full-length E1 that was initially extracted in low salt, and the material was loaded onto the Hi-Trap column.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The column was washed with 50 ml of equilibration buffer followed by 10 volumes of washing buffer (equilibration buffer with 50 mM imidazole).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	94	 His-tagged E1 was eluted in 1-ml fractions with equilibration buffer containing 180 mM imidazole and dialyzed in 20 mM MES, pH 7.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	95	05 mM EDTA, and 10% glycerol before being frozen on dry ice and stored at 80  degrees C.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	96	 E1 truncations were eluted with 250 mM (E1-(72-649)) or 350 mM (E1-(353-649)) imidazole and were not dialyzed prior to freezing, since dilution of the protein into assay buffers was found to give insignificant residual imidazole concentrations.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	97	 E1 preparations were tested for the presence of DNA using the fluorescent dye PicoGreen (Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	98	, Eugene, OR), according to published procedures (51).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The concentrations of purified proteins were determined using the Coomassie Plus reagent (Pierce), with bovine serum albumin serving as a standard.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	100	Cross-linking-- Bismaleimidohexane cross-linking of purified HPV11 E1-(72-649) and subsequent analysis on Weber-Osborn polyacrylamide gels (52) were performed as described previously for in vitro translated protein (20).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	101	Analytical Ultracentrifugation-- A velocity run for HPV11 E1-(72-649) was carried out using the XL-A analytical ultracentrifuge (Beckman Coulter), in an An-60 Ti rotor at 40,000 rpm and 11  degrees C.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	102	 E1-(72-649) was exchanged into a buffer composed of 20 mM Tris, 500 mM NaCl, 10% glycerol, 1 mM DTT, and 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	103	0, using a NAP-5 column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The protein was diluted to ~40  microg/ml (600 nM) and analyzed using a 1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	105	2-cm double sector charcoal-filled Epon centerpiece and quartz windows pretreated with Sigmacoat silconizing agent (Sigma).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Data were acquired at 230 nm and at 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	107	005-cm intervals, with five replicate readings taken at each point.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Scans were spaced as closely as the absorbance optics would allow, approximately every 2 min.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	109	 E1-(72-649) was found to be stable over the time required to acquire velocity data, although it began to lose activity after several hours at 4-11  degrees C.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Buffer density was determined to be 1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	111	00007 g/ml at 22  degrees C using a pyknometer and corrected to a value of 1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	112	05851 g/ml at 11  degrees C (53).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The partial specific volume for E1-(72-649) (0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	114	7285 cm3/g) and the solvent viscosity (1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	115	810 centipoise) at 11  degrees C were calculated using the program Sednterp (53).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Data were analyzed with the programs DCDT+ 1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	117	38 (56), which gave similar results.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	118	E2-dependent E1-DNA Binding-- E2-dependent binding of E1 to the HPV11 origin was measured using a modification of the procedure previously used for in vitro translated proteins (19).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Binding reactions (80  microl) contained ~0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	120	4 ng of probe DNA, 2  microg of salmon sperm DNA, and the indicated amounts of E1 and E2.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Radiolabeled probe DNA was obtained by PCR amplification of the HPV11 origin from plasmid pN9.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	122	 HPV11 E2 was expressed in SF21 insect cells infected with baculovirus Ac11E2 (obtained from R.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Rose, University of Rochester) and purified by DNA affinity chromatography in a procedure similar to that of Seo et al.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	124	 After 1-h binding reactions, detection was performed by a modification of the previously described procedure in which protein A scintillation proximity assay beads (SPA beads) were used in place of protein A-Sepharose.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Anti-E1-coated SPA beads were added to binding reactions, and after an additional 1 h, plates were spun briefly to pellet beads and counted using a TopCount NXT microplate scintillation counter (Packard Instruments).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Blanks were subtracted before calculating relative activities.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	127	Synthesis of Helicase Substrates-- M13mp18 ssDNA was obtained by infection of E.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	128	 coli according to standard procedures (58).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Substrate oligonucleotides were synthesized (trityl-off) on an Applied Biosystems 394 DNA/RNA synthesizer and purified by gel electrophoresis (58).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	130	 To synthesize the substrate used for most of the work in this report, 125 pmol of the purified oligonucleotide 5'-TTC CCA GTC ACG TTG T-3' was mixed with an equimolar amount of M13mp18 in 500  microl of TEN buffer (10 mM Tris, 80 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA), heated in a water bath to 95  degrees C, and then allowed to cool slowly overnight.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	131	 dCTP was then added (to give 230  microM), together with [-33P]dATP (125 pmol or 250  microCi) and unlabeled dATP (400 pmol), to give a final volume of 700  microl, and the oligonucleotide sequence was extended with the Klenow fragment at 30  degrees C to give the final sequence 5'-TTC CCA GTC ACG ACG TTG TAA AAC-3' (radiolabeled residues in boldface).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The labeled partial duplex was purified using a freshly packed 50-ml column of Sepharose 4B equilibrated in TEN buffer.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Pooled partial duplex fractions (~10 ml) were concentrated to ~2 ml using Centriprep 50 filters (Millipore Corp.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The typical yield was 80 pmol of purified product at a specific activity of 107 cpm/pmol.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	135	To synthesize substrates for testing the effect of 3'- or 5'-unannealed tails, 125 pmol of each oligonucleotide were 5'-labeled using 30 units of polynucleotide kinase and 125 pmol of [-33P]ATP.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The reaction was stopped by the addition of EDTA to 70 mM, and labeled oligonucleotide was separated from remaining [-33P]ATP using a Chromaspin 10 column (CLONTECH).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Radiolabeled oligonucleotides were then annealed to M13mp18 and purified by Sepharose 4B chromatography as above.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Oligonucleotides used were as follows: GTA AAA CGA CGG CCA GTG CCA AGC (nontailed), GTA AAA CGA CGG CCA GTG CCA AGC AAT GTA AGA TAG CAT CTC CGT (3'-tailed substrate), and AAG AAG AAG AAG AAG AAG GTA AAA CGA CGG CCA GTG CCA AGC (5'-tailed substrate).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The sequence complementary to M13 is underlined.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	140	Helicase Assays-- Unless stated otherwise, reactions were run for 90 min in an incubator maintained at 37  degrees C and 70% humidity in Microfluor 2 96-well plates (Dynex) and in a buffer consisting of 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	141	01% IGEPAL-CA630 (Sigma; equivalent to Nonidet-P40).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	142	 M13 partial duplex substrates were used at 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Reaction products were analyzed using either gel electrophoresis or streptavidin-coated SPA beads; the two methods gave equivalent results.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	144	 For detection by gel electrophoresis, an aliquot of the reaction was mixed with one-half volume gel-loading buffer (60 mM EDTA, pH 8, 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	145	09% of the nonintercalating dye Orange G (Sigma)).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Samples (10  microl) were loaded onto 20% acrylamide gels and electrophoresed at 100 V until the orange band had migrated two-thirds of the way down the gel.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Gels were then dried onto DE-81 paper (Whatman) and exposed to a storage phosphor screen.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Unwinding was quantified using a STORM 860 imaging system (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Results were calculated as the percentage of substrate unwound, where this value was measured relative to the intensity of the oligonucleotide band from a reaction blank sample boiled for 15 min prior to electrophoresis.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Blank reactions, containing no enzyme, were run in parallel with all helicase reactions, and the resulting blank value, typically 2-3% of the boiled sample, was subtracted from enzyme reactions.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	151	 For detection by SPA beads (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), 45  microl of helicase reaction was mixed with 20  microl of stop solution (100 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	152	5, 300 mM NaCl, 20 mM EDTA, 1% SDS) containing a biotinylated oligonucleotide complementary to the substrate oligonucleotide at 20 nM.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	153	 After 30 min, 20  microl of streptavidin SPA beads suspended at 3.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	154	 After brief mixing and a further 30-min incubation, plates were centrifuged at 1300  x  g for 5 min and counted using a TopCount NXT (Packard Instruments).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	155	 SPA-detected reactions were quantified in the same way as above, using a boiled reaction mixture as a 100% reference and subtracting the value for reaction blanks.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	156	ATPase Assays with Purified Proteins-- Reactions were performed using the same buffer as used for helicase reactions in either Dynex Microfluor 2 plates or Packard Optiplates.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Unless stated otherwise, reactions were typically performed using 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	158	0 mM MgOAc or 1  microM ATP and 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Reactions at higher ATP concentrations were carried out at 37  degrees C, and phosphate product was quantified using an ammonium molybdate/malachite green colorimetric assay (59).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The same procedure was used for assays with the seven other nucleotide triphosphates and with manganese and magnesium chloride.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	161	 We found the practical limit of sensitivity for this method to be ~25  microM phosphate product.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Reactions at low ATP concentrations were supplemented with [-33P]ATP (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech or PerkinElmer Life Sciences) to at least 1 nCi/45- microl reaction, and unless stated otherwise they were carried out at room temperature.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	163	 For reactions run to determine the value of Km(ATP), ATP and radiolabeled ATP were maintained at a constant ratio, and the magnesium concentration was adjusted to give a constant excess, usually 500  microM, since the ATP-magnesium complex is the true substrate for the reaction, and the Kd for ATP chelation of magnesium is ~50  microM (60).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Radiolabeled phosphate product was detected either by thin layer chromatography or by binding a phosphate-molybdate complex to streptavidin SPA beads.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	165	 For TLC detection, reactions were stopped by the addition of one-half volume of cold EDTA (500 mM), and 1- microl aliquots were spotted onto polyethyleneimine-cellulose TLC plates (Sigma).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Spots were allowed to dry and samples were eluted in a running buffer of 1 M formic acid plus 1 M LiCl.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Plates were then dried and exposed on a storage phosphor screen, and the resulting signal was quantified using a STORM 860 imaging system (Molecular Dynamics).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Blank reactions containing no E1 were run in parallel, and this background signal, typically 3-5%, was subtracted.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The same TLC procedure was used for reactions using [-33P]GTP, UTP, or dATP, since the nucleoside diphosphates were found to have Rf values similar to that for orthophosphate.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The SPA-based detection procedure will be described in detail elsewhere,3 but briefly this involves quenching reactions with a mixture of polyvinyl toluene SPA beads and ammonium molybdate in HCl.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The resulting phosphomolybdate complex binds to SPA beads by hydrophobic forces, and binding is enhanced by the subsequent addition of cesium chloride and citric acid.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Signals were detected by scintillation counting using a TopCount NXT (Packard Instruments), and values for no-enzyme blank reactions run in parallel, typically 2-4%, were subtracted.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	173	 To correlate the detected signal with the absolute amount of phosphate product produced at each time point, in each assay, some reactions were detected with both the TLC and SPA procedures.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Plots of cpm (SPA) versus nM phosphate (TLC) were linear up to at least 100  microM phosphate, and the slope of this line was used as a conversion factor for all reactions in the assay.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	175	Data Analysis-- IC50 inhibition curves were fit to a logistic using SAS, and kinetic data were analyzed using the appropriate equations in the program GraFit 3.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	176	 For kinetic experiments, reaction aliquots were taken (in triplicate) at multiple time points between 20 and 120 min.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Observed rates were calculated using data at 20% conversion or lower, to maintain initial rate conditions.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	178	ATPase Assay Using in Vitro Translated E1-- Truncated E1 proteins were synthesized and labeled in vitro with [35S]methionine by coupled transcription/translation using the TNT reticulocyte lysate system (Promega), as described previously (19).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	179	 150- microl transcription/translation reactions were programmed with deletion constructs of the E1 open reading frame cloned into plasmid pTM1, which have been described previously (19, 20).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	180	 In vitro synthesized E1 proteins were then immunoprecipitated using either the K72 polyclonal antibody or, when indicated, an anti-FLAG M2 monoclonal antibody (Sigma) coupled to protein A- or protein G-Sepharose beads (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), respectively.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Immunoprecipitations were carried out for 90 min in binding buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	182	6, 100 mM NaCl, 3 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The immunoprecipitated proteins bound to beads were washed three times with 1 ml of ATPase wash buffer (50 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	184	1% Triton X-100, 1 mM DTT) followed by two times with 1 ml of ATPase buffer (50 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	185	 ATPase reactions were performed by resuspending the bead-bound E1 immunocomplexes in 30  microl of ATPase buffer supplemented with 1 mM ATP followed by incubation at 37  degrees C for 2 h.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Inorganic phosphate generated during the reaction was quantified using an ammonium molybdate/malachite green colorimetric microassay (59).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	187	 ATPase activities above background levels were normalized to the amount of 35S-labeled E1 protein present in each immunoprecipitate, as determined by SDS-PAGE analysis and autoradiography.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Quantification of 35S-labeled E1 was performed with a STORM 860 imaging system (Molecular Dynamics) with a correction for the number of methionine residues present in each E1 truncation.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	189	DNA-binding Assay-- 75- microl binding reactions were performed in triplicate in 96-well plates (Dynex), with the indicated concentrations of purified HPV11 E1 protein, either E1-(353-649) or E1-(72-649), in binding buffer (20 mM Tris pH 7.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	190	6, 100 mM NaCl, 5 mM ATP, 3 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Binding reactions were started by adding a mixture of probe and competitor DNA.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The probe consisted either of 1.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	193	25 ng of a 63-mer oligonucleotide, end-labeled by phosphorylation with [-33P]ATP (ssDNA probe), or of a 370-base pair 33P-labeled PCR fragment (dsDNA probe) identical to the probe used in the E2-dependent E1-DNA-binding assay described above.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Binding reactions were performed at 23  degrees C for 1 h.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	195	 E1-DNA complexes were immunoprecipitated using the anti-E1 K72 polyclonal antibody coupled to protein A-Sepharose beads, washed three times with 200  microl of binding buffer, and then filtered on a 96-well 0.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	196	45- microm Durapore membrane filter plate (Millipore).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The amount of radiolabeled DNA probe present in the retained E1-DNA complexes was quantified with a TopCount NXT (Packard Instruments).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	198	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	199	Expression and Purification of HPV11 and HPV6 E1-- We initially attempted to purify E1 after overexpression in E.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	200	 However, we consistently found HPV E1 expressed in bacteria to be largely insoluble and the soluble protein to be partially degraded.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Preparations of E1 proteins with amino acid substitutions of the essential Lys484 in the Walker A phosphate-binding motif retained helicase and ATPase activities, demonstrating that bacterially produced E1 copurified with contaminating helicases and ATPases (data not shown).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	202	 As a result of these experiences, we decided to express HPV E1 in insect cells using a baculovirus expression system.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Recombinant baculoviruses were constructed to express full-length HPV11 and HPV6 E1 as well as a slightly shorter version of HPV11 E1, encompassing amino acids 72-649.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	204	 A similar truncation of HPV33 E1 was reported to be expressed at higher levels than the full-length protein in E.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Furthermore, we have shown previously that this truncated E1, when made by in vitro translation, retains the ability to support cell-free DNA replication (25).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	206	 These three E1 proteins were expressed as fusions with an N-terminal 6-histidine tag to facilitate their rapid purification by metal affinity chromatography and hence minimize losses of activity over the course of the procedure.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Finally, in order to rule out the possibility that the enzymatic activities associated with our E1 preparations were due to contaminating proteins, we also expressed several catalytically inactive HPV11 E1 proteins containing single amino acid substitutions at lysine 484.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	208	 We showed previously, using in vitro translated proteins, that HPV11 E1 in which Lys484 is substituted by alanine, histidine, isoleucine, or arginine retains the ability to form a specific complex with E2 at the HPV origin (19).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	209	 These substitutions were made in the context of the full-length HPV11 E1 protein, and the alanine and arginine changes were also made in E1-(72-649).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	210	In agreement with previous work, we found that during expression in baculovirus-infected SF21 cells E1 accumulated in the nuclei, with only a small proportion in the cytosolic fraction.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	211	 E1 was extracted from nuclei with a buffer containing 500 mM NaCl, but in further experiments, we found that full-length HPV6 and HPV11 E1 could be extracted from nuclei using a buffer with no added salt.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	212	 This unusual low salt extraction was as efficient as a more standard high salt procedure at extracting soluble wild type E1, with the advantage that significantly fewer contaminating proteins were present in the low salt extracts, so that the final product obtained after chromatography was more pure (data not shown).
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Due to the higher expression level obtained for E1-(72-649), very pure E1 could be isolated in relatively good yield after high salt extraction.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Following extraction, all three E1 proteins were purified in a single nickel affinity chromatography step.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The E1 isolated by this procedure was  > 80% pure as estimated by SDS-PAGE (Fig.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	216	 We routinely obtained ~200  microg of full-length E1 or 800  microg of E1-(72-649) per liter of insect cell culture.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	217	View larger version (51K):    Fig.
0.41806388.11304544.html.plaintext.txt	218	   Elution profiles of HPV11 E1 proteins from nickel-chelating columns and activity of purified WT and mutant proteins.
