0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	0	An NF-Y Binding Site Is Important for Basal, but Not Gonadotropin-releasing Hormone-stimulated, Expression of the Luteinizing Hormone  Subunit Gene* Ruth A.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Bachmann, Alireza Behrooz, Brian D.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Department of Pharmacology, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio 44106.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	4	Regulated synthesis of luteinizing hormone (LH) requires coordinated transcriptional control of the  and LH subunits in pituitary gonadotropes.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Several cis-acting elements and trans-acting factors have been defined for control of the LH promoter through heterologous cell culture models.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In this report, we describe the identification of bipartite NF-Y (CBF/CP1) binding sites within the proximal bovine LH promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	7	 When multimerized, one of these sites activates the heterologous, minimal HSV thymidine kinase promoter in the gonadotrope-derived cell line T3-1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The functional role of the promoter-distal site in regulating the full-length bovine LH promoter was assessed in vivo using transgenic mice harboring a mutant promoter linked to the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase reporter gene.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	9	 While this element is important for conferring high level activity of the LH promoter in pituitary, it does not appear to be essential for mediating gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) regulation.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	10	 This is the first characterization of a cis-acting element within this GnRH-dependent promoter that is restricted to regulating basal expression and not GnRH-induced activity.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	11	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	12	Stimulation of gametogenesis and synthesis of sex steroids by luteinizing hormone (LH)1 is essential for reproduction in all mammalian species.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Thus, understanding the regulated synthesis and secretion of this hormone from the gonadotropes in the pituitary is paramount to understanding the reproductive process.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	14	LH is a member of the glycoprotein hormone family whose members are composed of a shared  subunit that combines with unique, hormone-defining  subunits.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Synthesis and secretion of LH requires coordinated, gonadotrope-specific expression of the genes encoding both the  and LH subunits (1).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Gonadotrope-specific expression of the  subunit gene requires a number of cis-acting elements located within the promoter-proximal 400 bp of the 5'-flanking region of the gene (2-7).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Discernment of the essential cis-acting elements involved in expression of the LH subunit has lagged behind that made for the  subunit due to the lack of readily accessible, appropriate model systems.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	18	Five models have been used to uncover regulatory elements within the LH promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	19	 These include cell lines corresponding to kidney fibroblasts (CV-1) (8, 9), modified somatotropes (GGH3-1') (10, 11), primordial gonadotropes (T3-1) (12-14), and differentiated gonadotropes (LT2) (15, 16) as well as transgenic mice (17-21).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Using these approaches, four transcription factors have been identified that regulate expression of the LH subunit gene through direct binding to its promoter (see Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These include the orphan nuclear receptor, SF-1 (8, 15, 21), an early growth response protein, Egr-1 (22, 23), a bicoid-related homeodomain protein, Pitx1 (9), and the ubiquitous transcription factor, Sp1 (11).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	22	 There are two Egr-1 and SF-1 binding sites that exist in a pairwise conformation interrupted by a Pitx1 binding site within the promoter-proximal 150 bp (24).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	23	 This configuration is conserved across many, if not all, mammalian LH promoters.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Numerous recent studies have shown that SF-1 and Egr-1 functionally cooperate to activate transcription (16, 24, 25) of the LH subunit gene.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In addition, Pitx1 further potentiates the activation mediated by these two proteins; however, this does not appear to require direct binding of Pitx1 to DNA (25).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Rather, Pitx1 can interact directly with SF-1 and Egr-1 to induce expression (25).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Sp1 regulates the rat LH promoter by binding two elements that reside further upstream in the promoter at (451/428) and (411/386) (11).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This region is less conserved across species than the promoter-proximal sequences, and its importance in other species remains to be determined.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	29	The relative importance of Egr-1, SF-1, and Pitx1 in regulating LH gene expression has been confirmed with targeted disruption of each gene in mice.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Mice deficient in Egr-1 exhibit a specific loss of LH gene expression, while the  and follicle-stimulating hormone  genes remain functional (22, 23).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	31	 This suggests that Egr-1 is a selective transcriptional regulator of the LH gene and may mediate differential regulation of LH and follicle-stimulating hormone within the same cell.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In contrast, mice deficient in SF-1 have a reduced gonadotrope population accompanied by attenuated expression of all three gonadotropin genes (26).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Whether this is due solely to a defect within the gonadotrope (21) or to an additional impact in the hypothalamus (27) remains to be determined.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Targeted disruption of the Pitx1 gene leads to gross defects in limb development (28, 29) as well as multiple pituitary effects (28).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Although gonadotrope number and expression of the gonadotropin genes is significantly reduced in these animals, there is not an ablation of either (28).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Thus, while Pitx1 is important for LH gene expression and gonadotrope development, it does not appear to be essential.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	37	While earlier work focused on evaluating basal expression of the LH subunit gene, this rapidly evolved into analyses of the effects of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	38	 This reflects the exquisite dependence of transcriptional activity of the LH gene on pulsatile release of GnRH from the hypothalamus, exemplified by the hpg/hpg mouse (30) that harbors a spontaneous deletion of this gene (31).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Mice harboring this mutation express the LH subunit gene at only 5-10% of normal levels (32), suggesting that "basal" activity of this gene requires activation of GnRH-induced signaling cascades.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Indeed, all of the factors described to date as being important for LH gene expression also contribute to GnRH induction (11, 13, 14, 16, 21, 24, 25).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	41	 In the current manuscript, we report the identification of an additional pairwise cis-acting element that binds NF-Y (CBF/CP1).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	42	 In contrast to the previously described cis-acting elements and their cognate factors characterized for this gene, these sites are the first to be described that solely affect basal expression of this gene.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	43	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	44	Materials-- Radiolabeled nucleotides and chloramphenicol were obtained from NEN Life Science Products.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Acetyl coenzyme A and the GnRH antagonist, antide, were from Sigma.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	46	 DNA-modifying enzymes were from either Roche Molecular Biochemicals or Life Technologies, Inc.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	47	0 was from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Poly(dI-dC) was purchased from Roche Molecular Biochemicals.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Sp1 antibody was obtained from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	50	, and NF-Y (A subunit-specific) antibody was from Rockland Immunochemicals.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	51	Plasmid Constructs-- The HSVtk-luc vector was constructed by inserting an XhoI/SalI fragment containing the HSVtk minimal promoter (105/+5) from BLCAT2 (33) into the XhoI site of pGL2-Basic (Promega).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Kinased, double-stranded oligodeoxynucleotides corresponding to L1 or L2 (see below) were ligated into the SacI site 5' to the thymidine kinase promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The number and orientation of elements was then determined by dideoxynucleotide sequencing.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	54	A transversion mutation of the L1 site within the context of the full-length (776/+10)bLH promoter was accomplished using an oligodeoxynucleotide replacement approach in the previously described (776/+10)bLHCAT vector (18).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Oligodeoxynucleotides corresponding to the region to be mutated were 5'-CCGGGAACCGACAACGATTCCCCGGTTCAGAGGGGCGGTGCTGCA-3' and 5'-GCACCGCCCCTCTGAACCGGGGAATCGTTGTCGGTTCCCGG-3', with the mutant sequence indicated with boldface letters.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The annealed oligodeoxynucleotide has a 5' blunt end and a 3' PstI overhang.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The annealed, double-stranded oligodeoxynucleotide was inserted into the PstI sites at 397 and 355, relative to the start site of transcription, that flank the L1 consensus site.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	58	 This required conversion of the 5' PstI site into a blunt end prior to ligation with the mutant oligonucleotide.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The composition of the resultant clone was confirmed by sequencing the region containing the mutation and restriction digests confirming the remainder of the expression cassette.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Isolation of the transgene was accomplished by restriction digestion with SalI and BamHI.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	61	Cell Culture/Transient Transfections-- Transient transfection assays of T3-1 and MCF-7 cells were performed essentially as described (7) using 1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	62	42  microg of RSV-gal per 35-mm2 well containing 110,000-170,000 cells.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Cells were harvested 48 h post-transfection in 150  microl of reporter lysis buffer (Promega).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Luciferase and -galactosidase assays were performed as previously reported (7).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	65	Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assays (EMSAs)-- Nuclear extracts from T3-1, MCF-7, and BeWo cells were prepared as described previously (7).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	66	 EMSAs were performed essentially as described (21) except with 5-10  microg of nuclear protein.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The following oligodeoxynucleotides were used (lowercase type indicates SacI sites added for cloning purposes): L1(+), 5'-cTGCAGCCAATCACCATCGGAAAATTGagct-3'; L1(), 5'-CAATTTTCCGATGGTGATTGGCTGCAgagct-3'; L1  micro610(+), 5'-cTGCAGTCAACACCATCGGAAAATTGagct-3'; L1  micro610(), 5'-CAATTTTCCGATGGTGTTGACTGCAgagct-3'; L110  micro18(+), 5'-cTGCAGCCAACACCATCTGAAAATTGagct-3'; L110  micro18(), 5'-CAATTTTCAGATGGTGTTGGCTGCAgagct-3'; L1  micro18/25(+), 5'-cTGCAGCCAATCACCATCTGAAAATGGagct-3'; L1  micro18/25(), 5'-CCATTTTCAGATGGTGATTGGCTGCAgagct-3'; L1  micro6(+), 5'-cTGCAGTCAATCACCATCGGAAAATTGagct-3'; L1  micro6(), 5'-CAATTTTCGATGGTGATTGACTGCAgagct-3'; L2(+), 5'-cTGTGAAGTCACCTTCTCCTGGGTGagct-3'; L2(), 5'-CACCCAAGGAGAAGGTGACTTCACAgagct-3'; B1(+), 5'-CTGCAGTCAACACCATCTGAAAATGGA-3'; B1(), 5'-CCATTTTCAGATGGTGTTGACTGCAGA-3' and an Sp1 consensus oligodeoxynucleotide obtained from Promega Corp.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Double-stranded oligodeoxynucleotides were end-labeled with [-32P]ATP using polynucleotide kinase.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	69	 For the antibody supershift experiments, binding reactions were performed with 5-10  microg of T3-1 nuclear extract and 1  microg of poly(dI-dC) in 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	70	5 mM dithiothreitol, and 4% glycerol in a total volume of 15  microl.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	71	 After a 30-min incubation on ice, 5  x  104 cpm of labeled probe was added with an additional 30-min incubation on ice.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	72	 For reactions containing antibody, 1  microl of anti-Sp1 or anti-NF-Y was added during the initial 30-min incubation.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	73	Transgenic Mice-- All mice were housed in microisolator-plus units under pathogen-free conditions.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Food and water were given ad libitum, and animals were subjected to a 12-h light/dark cycle.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Mice harboring the (776/+10)bLHCAT construct have been previously described (18).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	76	 For this work, we regenerated this transgenic strain to utilize mice that were as few generations from the founder animals as possible for direct comparison with mice harboring the  microL1 construct.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	77	To generate mice with the (776/+10) microL1bLHCAT construct, the 2.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	78	4-kilobase pair expression cassette was liberated with SalI plus BamHI.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Transgenic mouse production, identification, and characterization of tissue-specific expression were done as reported (18).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) assays were performed as described (18) with 10-25  microg of cellular lysate for 1 or 4 h.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Each assay contained control tissues from mice containing the wild type promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The amount of lysate used in each CAT assay was identical for each sample within that assay.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	83	The ovariectomy/antide treatment paradigm was performed as follows.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Female mice harboring either the wild type or mutant promoter were ovariectomized under avertin anesthesia.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Following surgery, randomized mice were separated into two groups: those receiving vehicle (20% propylene glycol in saline) injections and those receiving antide injections.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	86	 60  microg of antide was given as a subcutaneous injection every 48 h for 10 days.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	87	 On day 10, mice were killed by asphyxiation in a CO2 chamber, and cardiac blood, pituitaries, and livers were collected.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	88	 All animals used were adults and age-matched (within 1 month) within individual experiments.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	89	 All animal studies were approved by the Case Western Reserve University Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	90	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	91	Alignment of the Bovine  and LH Promoters Reveals Three Conserved Regions-- Production of LH requires coordinated expression of both the  and LH genes.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	92	 These genes must be expressed concurrently in a temporal and spatial pattern to form an intact heterodimer.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	93	 In addition, regulation of their expression by GnRH and gonadal steroids may involve similar mechanisms for the two genes.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Thus, we speculated that specific cis-acting elements may be shared between the two gonadotropin subunit genes as a means to confer similar signals for regulated expression.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	95	 To begin to identify targets for functional analysis of the LH promoter in transgenic animals, we examined the bovine gonadotropin promoters for regions of apparent conservation.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Three regions with greater than 80% homology were identified (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	97	 One of these, the GSE, was previously shown to be important for activity of both the  (5) and LH (8, 21) genes.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The other two elements located at positions 399/372 (element L1) and 228/204 (element L2) relative to the start site of transcription of the bovine LH gene, were subject to further analyses to determine their role, if any, in activating the LH promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	99	 A diagrammatic sketch of the positions of these elements as well as others identified for the bovine or rat genes is shown in Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	100	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	101	   Alignment of the bovine  and LH promoters reveals three conserved regions.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	102	 A, a schematic diagram of the bovine LH promoter with the position of L1 and L2 is shown.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Binding sites for SF-1 (GSE), Egr-1, and Pitx1 are indicated.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The positions of Sp1 binding sites that are present within the rat LH promoter are also shown.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	105	 L4 harbors a sequence that binds the same protein as L1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The Sp1 site that is 5' to the L1 site is outlined in gray to reflect the lack of an Sp1 consensus at this site in the bovine promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	107	 B, the bovine  and LH subunits were scanned for any regions of conservation between the two promoters.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The sequences of three conserved elements are indicated.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The GSE has previously been described (5, 8, 21).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Element 1 and element 2 are designated L1 and L2 when referring to the elements within the LH promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	111	L1, but Not L2, Stimulates Transcriptional Activity of a Minimal Thymidine Kinase Promoter-- In the absence of GnRH, the bovine LH promoter has low activity in transiently transfected cells (18) that precludes functional analyses of the L1 and L2 elements in the context of the full-length promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Therefore, functional activity was initially assessed by determining whether multimerized L1 or L2 elements could stimulate expression of the HSVtk minimal promoter when linked to luciferase.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The resulting constructs were transiently transfected into T3-1 cells.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	114	 2, the L1 element was capable of activating the HSVtk promoter 2-3-fold with inverted repeats of this sequence resulting in the greatest induction.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	115	 In contrast, L2 was incapable of activating the heterologous promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Similar results were obtained in the breast cancer cell line, MCF-7 (data not shown).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The ability of L1 to function independently of cell lineage suggested that it might bind a factor that is not gonadotrope-specific.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	118	View larger version (42K):    Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	119	   L1, but not L2, stimulates transcriptional activity of a minimal thymidine kinase promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Oligodeoxynucleotides corresponding to L1 or L2 were multimerized and ligated upstream of the HSVtk minimal promoter linked to luciferase.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	121	 A shaded (L1) or black (L2) box indicates the presence and orientation (arrowheads) of each element.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	122	 T3-1 cells were transiently transfected with each construct.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Values are expressed relative to HSVtk-luc activity and represent the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	124	 of three independent experiments each with three replicates.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	125	L1, but Not L2, Binds a Nuclear Factor That Is Common to a Variety of Cell Lines-- To determine if L1 and L2 elements bind nuclear proteins, EMSAs were performed with T3-1 nuclear extracts.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	126	 This assay revealed that L1 could bind a single complex with high specificity and affinity (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	127	 While only a 50-100-fold molar excess of homologous competitor was necessary to eliminate binding of the factor to the probe, a 100-fold molar excess of heterologous competitor (LH GSE (21)) had no impact on protein binding.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	128	 A monophasic Scatchard analysis revealed a high affinity interaction between the nuclear protein and the L1 site (KD = 1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	129	2  x  1010 M, data not shown) that was well within the known range for eukaryotic transcription factors that bind to DNA (34).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	130	 In contrast to L1, incubation of the L2 probe with T3-1 nuclear extract failed to reveal any high affinity complexes (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	131	 This supports data obtained from the transient transfection studies and suggests that L2 is nonfunctional in these cells.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Given the transcriptional activity and protein binding function of L1, we chose to focus on further characterization of this element.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Whether L2 has a transcriptional function in mature gonadotropes remains to be determined.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Studies aimed at addressing this issue will probably involve complex experimental paradigms such as transgenic mice and preparation of nuclear extracts from mature gonadotrope cells.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	135	View larger version (57K):    Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	136	   L1 binds a nuclear factor that is common to a variety of cell lines.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	137	 A, EMSA were performed with either the L1 or L2 probes and T3-1 nuclear extracts.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	138	 A single complex was observed with the L1 probe.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	139	 To assess binding specificity, competition analyses were performed by adding 10-, 50-, or 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled, homologous L1 or L2 (as indicated) or heterologous GSE (21).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Increasing concentrations of added oligodeoxynucleotides are indicated by triangles.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	141	 B, EMSA were accomplished with nuclear extracts obtained from cell lines derived from gonadotrope (T3-1), choriocarcinoma (BeWo), or mammary epithelium (MCF-7).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The L1 band is indicated by an arrow.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Competition analyses were performed with unlabeled homologous L1 or an L1 mutant harboring a C/T transition at position 6 (see Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	144	 4A for the L1 and mutant sequence).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	145	To address whether the L1 protein-binding complex was unique to gonadotrope origin cell lines, we performed additional EMSA studies using nuclear extracts from MCF-7 and BeWo cells.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Both extracts exhibited a complex with the same mobility and competition profile as that observed with T3-1 nuclear extracts (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	147	 An additional complex displaying a faster migration pattern was also observed in both heterologous extracts.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	148	 This interaction was considered nonspecific due to the increase in intensity that corresponded with increasing concentrations of unlabeled competitors.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	149	 From these results, we conclude that the protein(s) that bind to LB1 are not cell-specific and are likely to be ubiquitous given their distribution in gonadotrope-, mammary-, and choriocarcinoma-derived cell lines.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	150	The L1 Element Contains a CCAAT Motif That Is Essential for Protein Binding-- To begin to discern whether the L1 element was functionally conserved in the bovine  subunit promoter, we performed EMSA with its L1 homolog, designated B1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Interestingly, although homology analysis was utilized to originally identify L1, the B1 element did not bind any proteins with high affinity in EMSA with T3-1 nuclear extracts (data not shown).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	152	 While function of the B1 element within the context of the full-length  subunit promoter was not addressed, lack of protein binding in gonadotrope-derived cells suggests that this region was not important for transcriptional function of the bovine  subunit gene promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	153	Only four nucleotide differences exist between the L1 and B1 elements.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Thus, the lack of high affinity binding of a nuclear protein to B1 could be used to rapidly discern the specific nucleotides required for protein binding to L1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Mutations in the L1 element were made to mimic those nucleotide differences observed in B1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	156	 4A outlines the mutant oligodeoxynucleotides utilized in EMSA.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Two nucleotide changes were within a CCAAT motif, while two additional differences were external to this motif.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The importance of these particular nucleotides in protein binding was addressed using pairwise mutations and competition analysis in EMSA utilizing the wild type L1 probe.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	159	 4B, mutation of nucleotides at positions 6 and 10 within L1 eliminated the ability of this oligonucleotide to compete for binding to the wild type L1 probe.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Similar to the 6/10 mutation, mutation of nucleotides 10 and 18 also resulted in loss of L1 protein binding.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	161	 In contrast, pairwise mutation of the two nucleotides outside the CCAAT motif at positions 18 and 24 resulted in no change in affinity.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	162	 These results implicate the position 10 nucleotide (the T of CCAAT) in protein binding and minimized the likelihood that binding involved specific sequences eight nucleotides downstream of the CCAAT motif.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	163	 To directly assess the importance of the C at position 6 of L1, an additional point mutant was used in EMSA.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	164	 This mutant was incapable of competing with protein binding to the wild type L1 probe (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Thus, both the initial C and the T of the CCAAT motif are essential for protein binding to L1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	166	View larger version (83K):    Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	167	   The L1 element contains a CCAAT motif that is essential for protein binding.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	168	 A, alignment of the element 1 sequences from the bovine  (B1) and LH (L1) promoters reveals only four nucleotide differences between the two that must dictate binding activity.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	169	 These differences are indicated by boldface letters, and the position of each is denoted.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	170	 B, EMSA with T3-1 nuclear extracts and L1 probe.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	171	 wild type) was added at 10- and 50-fold molar excess.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Unlabeled mutant L1 oligonucleotide competitors were added at 50-, 100-, and 300-fold molar excess.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The mutations within the L1 oligodeoxynucleotides are indicated by the position of the mutation.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	174	 At each of these positions, the sequence was converted from the LH promoter sequence to that present within the  promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	175	NF-Y Is the L1-binding Protein-- The requirement for sequences corresponding to a CCAAT motif suggested that the L1 element might bind to a known CCAAT box-binding factor.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	176	 To begin to determine the nature of the CCAAT-binding protein that interacts with L1, we performed a variety of competition EMSA studies with consensus oligodeoxynucleotides and antisera to known CCAAT box-binding factors.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Antiserum directed against NF-Y was capable of "supershifting" the L1 protein band (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	178	 NF-Y is a ubiquitous transcription factor that binds to CCAAT motifs.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Thus, the protein that interacts with L1 is either NF-Y or a highly related protein.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Within the rat LH promoter, an Sp1 site that resides just 5' to the NF-Y binding site was shown to be important for mediating GnRH regulation.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	181	 No Sp1 consensus binding sequence exists in the bovine promoter at this site; however, to determine if Sp1 could also bind to the L1 element, we performed additional EMSA.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Antiserum to the transcription factor Sp1 did not affect binding of nuclear factors to the L1 element but did retard the mobility of a complex formed with an oligodeoxynucleotide corresponding to a consensus Sp1 element (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Thus, we conclude that NF-Y, but not Sp1, binds to this site in the bovine LH promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	184	View larger version (63K):    Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	185	   NF-Y is the L1- and L4-binding protein.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	186	 A, EMSA were performed with T3-1 nuclear extracts and either L1-, L4-, or Sp1-labeled probes.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Supershift assays were performed with antisera directed against NF-Y or Sp1 to assess the nature of the protein complexes associated with these oligodeoxynucleotide probes.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Supershifted complexes containing either NF-Y or Sp1 are indicated with arrows.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	189	 B, the L1 and L2 core CCAAT elements are aligned with the NF-Y consensus sequence (36).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The L1 site harbors an exact consensus sequence for NF-Y.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Lowercase letters indicates mismatches from the consensus.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The full sequences of the probes used in the EMSA are delineated under "Experimental Procedures.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	193	The L1 Element Exists as an Inverted Repeat in the Bovine LH Promoter-- Subsequent analysis of the bovine LH promoter for additional CCAAT motifs surprisingly indicated that no motif was present in the region surrounding 80 bp relative to the start site of transcription.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	194	 5B, an additional imperfect motif (CCTAT) was observed in the opposing orientation of the LH promoter at positions 332 to 328.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	195	 This sequence, within the context of a larger oligodeoxynucleotide (designated L4), was analyzed for its ability to bind a nuclear protein in EMSA (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Interestingly, L4 bound the same protein as L1 as shown by complete cross-competition and antibody supershift experiments.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	197	 However, L4 bound this protein with significantly lower affinity.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	198	 While only a 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled L1 is required to compete for binding to the L1 probe, over 500-fold molar excess of unlabeled L4 is required for a similar level of competition (data not shown).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	199	 It is intriguing that the inverted orientation of the L4 and L1 elements within the LH promoter is identical to the most active multimerized L1 elements in transient transfection (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Inverted repeats of NF-Y sites have been identified in multiple genes, suggesting that these sequences may cooperate to lead to full expression of the LH promoter (35).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	201	The L1 Element Regulates Pituitary-specific Expression of the Bovine LH Promoter-- To determine the functional importance of the L1 element in the context of a full-length promoter in an appropriate physiological context, transgenic mice were made.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	202	 These mice harbored the 776-bp bovine LH promoter containing a transversion mutation throughout the entire 26-bp region of the L1 element linked to CAT.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Pituitary CAT activity in these mice was compared with that observed in mice harboring the wild type promoter linked to CAT.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Previous studies have shown that the full-length, wild type promoter is highly active only in gonadotropes of transgenic mice (18).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	205	 In addition, the promoter responds appropriately to GnRH and gonadal steroids (18).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Pituitary CAT activity from six independent lines of mice harboring the mutant LH promoter was compared with activity observed in three independent lines of mice harboring the wild type promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Mutation of the L1 element reduced activity of the LH promoter to approximately 14% of the wild type promoter's activity (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	208	 While this reduction was substantial, it is important to note that the L1 mutant promoter had detectable activity in a number of mice.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	209	 In particular, mutant lines 1, 3, and 4 displayed higher activity than the other lines of mice harboring the mutation.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	210	 This suggests that while L1 is important for high level expression of the LH promoter, some integration sites permit low level expression from this attenuated promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Thus, the remaining cis-acting elements must compensate to some degree for the loss of the distal NF-Y binding site.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	212	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	213	   The L1 element regulates pituitary-specific expression of the bovine LH promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Transgenic mice harboring either the wild type (wt, gray bars) or an L1 mutant ( micro, black bars) LH promoter linked to CAT were made.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Pituitary CAT activity was measured in three lines of mice with the wild type promoter and six lines of mice harboring the mutant promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Values are the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The following numbers of animals were used: 29 (wt1), 44 (wt2), 11 (wt3), 12 ( micro1), 5 ( micro2), 8 ( micro3), 6 ( micro4), 1 ( micro5), and 1 ( micro6).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The  micro5 and  micro6 animals were founder transgenics.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	219	 In all animals in which liver activity was examined, it was below detection and similar to the levels of activity observed in  micro3,  micro5, and  micro6 animals.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Expression of the wild type transgene versus the mutant transgene was significantly different (p  0.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	221	0001, two-tailed Student's t test assuming unequal variances).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	222	L1 Is Unnecessary for GnRH Regulation of the LH Promoter-- Numerous cis-acting elements have been described for the LH promoter, and most, if not all, mediate GnRH stimulation (11, 14, 16, 21, 24, 25).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	223	 To determine the role of the L1 element in conveying GnRH regulation, female transgenic mice harboring either the wild type promoter or the L1 mutant promoter were subjected to an ovariectomy/antide treatment paradigm.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Ovariectomy removes negative feedback from ovarian steroids and causes an increase in GnRH synthesis and secretion from the hypothalamus that further results in increased LH gene expression (1).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Treatment with the GnRH-specific antagonist, antide, can block this increase (18).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Thus, the degree of repression of transgene activity following antide administration is an indicator of the degree of promoter responsiveness to GnRH.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	227	 To assess the impact of the L1 mutation, mice were ovariectomized and treated with either vehicle or antide for 10 days.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	228	 As previously shown (18, 21), antide treatment lead to a 38-63% reduction in wild type promoter activity in two independent lines of mice (Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Similarly, antide treatment of ovariectomized mice harboring the L1 mutation resulted in 50% reduction in promoter function.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	230	 This indicates that while the basal function of the LH promoter is significantly attenuated by mutation of the L1 element, this element is not necessary for mediating GnRH-regulated expression.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Whether NF-Y can mediate GnRH regulation through the intact L4 site or additional, uncharacterized, binding sites is unknown and warrants further study.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	232	View larger version (33K):    Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	233	   L1 is unnecessary for GnRH regulation of the LH promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Transgenic mice harboring either the wild type (wt) or mutant ( microL1) (776/+10) LH promoter were subjected to a GnRH regulation assay.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The mutant line used in this study corresponds to  micro1 in Fig.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Mice were ovariectomized and treated with either vehicle (OVX, gray bars) or 60  microg antide (OVX + antide, black bars) every 48 h.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Pituitaries were collected, and CAT enzymatic activity was measured.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Values are expressed relative to the OVX control for each line of mice and represent the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	239	 In each case, antide treatment resulted in CAT activity that was significantly different from OVX animals (p  0.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	240	05, one-tailed Student's t test assuming unequal variances).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	241	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	242	Expression of luteinizing hormone in the gonadotrope of the pituitary requires the coordinated expression of the  and LH subunits.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Both subunit genes respond to GnRH and sex steroids to promote synthesis and secretion of appropriate levels of the intact heterodimer (1).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Several elements have been defined for transcriptional control of both the  and LH subunit genes.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	245	 However, a complete picture of LH gene regulation has not been resolved.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	246	 This has largely been due to the lack of appropriate cell culture models to study expression of this gene.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	247	Using transgenic mice, we and others have shown that the LH promoter-proximal region confers high level expression that is confined to gonadotropes and responds appropriately to GnRH and gonadal steroids (17-20).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	248	 In this report, we describe an inverted repeat element that binds to NF-Y and is important for full activity of the LH promoter in transgenic mice.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In contrast to the other elements that have been described thus far for this promoter, the distal NF-Y binding site is not required for mediating GnRH responsiveness.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Thus, two different classes of cis-active elements exist for the LH promoter.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	251	 These include basal and GnRH-responsive sites, both of which contribute to transcriptional tone.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Since expression of the LH gene is very low in the absence of GnRH (32), the so-called basal elements may play a role in amplifying a signal that must be initiated by GnRH acting through the promoter-proximal SF-1, Pitx1, and Egr-1 binding sites, as well as potential Sp1 sites.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	253	NF-Y is a ubiquitous CCAAT box-binding factor that is composed of three subunits (36).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	254	 It regulates both TATA-containing and TATA-less promoters (35).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Functional NF-Y sites within promoters are usually closely associated with the start site of transcription, occurring within the promoter-proximal 100 bp (36).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	256	 However, there are several genes that contain NF-Y binding sites that are over 1 kilobase pairs 5' to the promoter (35).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Both the L1 and L4 sites are located more distally than the typical NF-Y site.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	258	 In addition, this factor displays an almost strict requirement for the pentanucleotide CCAAT motif that can occur on either the coding or noncoding strand (35, 36).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	259	 While L1 harbors an exact consensus for NF-Y, the L4 site has a CCTAT motif on the opposite strand from L1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Although the L4 site also binds NF-Y, it does so with lower affinity than L1 (data not shown).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The L4 motif has been observed in the cdc25 gene (37) as well as the MHC Class II DPA gene (38).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Interestingly, these sequences, like L4, all occurred in the reverse orientation on the coding strand.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Unlike the LH subunit gene, however, both of these genes are TATA-less.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	264	There are numerous examples of NF-Y cooperativity with other transcription factors (39-41).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	265	 It is particularly interesting to note that NF-Y can synergize with the transcription factor Sp1 (39, 41).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	266	 An Sp1 site has been characterized within the rat LH promoter that is immediately adjacent to a conserved NF-Y sequence (11).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Whether these two proteins synergize to activate the rat promoter remains to be determined.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	268	 With regard to LH promoters from other species, the Sp1 sequence is not conserved at this site, although the adjacent NF-Y sequence is.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Within the bovine LH promoter, we have shown that an oligodeoxynucleotide that encompasses the NF-Y site fails to bind Sp1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Thus, the transcriptional regulation that occurs through this cis-acting element cannot be attributed to Sp1.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	271	 It will be important to determine if Sp1 consensus sequences located within other regions of this promoter can bind to Sp1 and potentially synergize with the NF-Y binding sites to activate transcription.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	272	Sp1 and the other factors that define transcriptional activity of the LH promoter have largely been characterized using heterologous cell culture systems.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	273	 These include the use of kidney fibroblasts (CV-1) (8, 9, 22), somatotropes (GH3 and GGH3-1') (10, 11, 24), and immature gonadotropes (T3-1) (13-15).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	274	 None of these cell lines express the endogenous LH subunit gene, and they are probably devoid of essential factors for activating its transcription.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	275	 While these models have allowed ascertainment of the ability of specific transcription factors to induce the LH promoter, most depended upon overexpression of those factors.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Thus, the relative importance of these factors in defining the transcriptional tone of the LH promoter within the mature gonadotrope is unknown.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	277	 The recently derived LT2 cell line, which does express the endogenous LH subunit gene (42), will probably present an ideal avenue to confirm studies previously performed in these alternative models.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Prior to development of this cell line, however, the only mature gonadotrope model effectively used for analyses of the LH promoter was the pituitary of transgenic mice.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Even with this cell line, the transgenic mouse presents the most physiologically relevant system to assess important factors in regulating expression of the LH gene.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	280	 In this regard, we have characterized a new site that is important for basal expression of this gene but not GnRH induction.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The function of this element contrasts with the previously defined GSE that was shown to be essential for pituitary activity as well as GnRH activation of this promoter in transgenic mice (21).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	282	 While previous in vivo and in vitro studies have focused specifically on the promoter-proximal 150 bp, the studies presented herein indicate that additional sequences involved in regulation of promoter activity reside upstream of this region.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Thus, any attempts to study the proximal promoter in isolation will probably result in a limited picture of the transcription control of this gene.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	284	We acknowledge the Pharmacological Sciences Consortium Core Transgenic Facility at Case Western Reserve University for production of transgenic mice.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	285	 We also thank David Peck for excellent technical assistance and Paul MacDonald for helpful discussions during the preparation of this manuscript.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	286	* This work was supported by National Institutes of Health Grants DK28559 (to J.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	287	) and an Endocrine Society fellowship (to B.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	288	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	291	To whom correspondence should be addressed: Dept.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	292	 of Pharmacology, Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine, 2109 Adelbert Rd.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	293	: 216-368-4497; Fax: 216-368-3395; E-mail: jhn@po.
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	294	The abbreviations used are: LH, luteinizing hormone; SF-1, steroidogenic factor-1: GnRH, gonadotropin-releasing hormone; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; HSVtk, herpes simplex virus thymidine kinase; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay; GSE, gonadotrope-specific element; bp, base pair(s).
0.19470528.10777613.html.plaintext.txt	295	    REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES 1.
