0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	292	Received 13 January 2003; accepted 13 May 2003.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	0	Safety and Immunogenicity Trial in Adult Volunteers of a Human Papillomavirus 16 L1 Virus-Like Particle Vaccine.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Harro, Yuk-Ying Susana Pang, Richard B.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Roden, Allan Hildesheim, Zhaohui Wang, Mary Jane Reynolds, T.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Christopher Mast, Robin Robinson, Brian R.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Karron, Joakim Dillner, John T.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Karron (Center for Immunization Research, Department of International Medicine, School of Hygiene and Public Health), R.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Roden (Department of Pathology, School of Medicine), The Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD; Y.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Lowy (Laboratory of Cellular Oncology, Division of Basic Sciences), A.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Hildesheim (Environmental Epidemiology Branch, Division of Cancer Epidemiology and Genetics), National Cancer Institute, Bethesda, MD; Z.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Dillner, Microbiology and Tumor Biology Centre, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden; R.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Murphy, Laboratory of Infectious Diseases, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Bethesda.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	11	, National Institutes of Health, Bldg.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	12	 1D-32, Bethesda, MD 20892 (e-mail: drl{at}helix.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	13	   ABSTRACT Top Notes Abstract Introduction Subjects and Methods Results Discussion References   Background: Studies in animal models have shown that systemic immunization with a papillomavirus virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine composed of L1, a major structural viral protein, can confer protection against subsequent experimental challenge with the homologous virus.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Here we report results of a double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-escalation trial to evaluate the safety and immunogenicity of a human papillomavirus (HPV) type 16 (HPV16) L1 VLP vaccine in healthy adults.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Methods: Volunteers were given intramuscular injections with placebo or with 10- or 50- microg doses of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine given without adjuvant or with alum or MF59 as adjuvants at 0, 1, and 4 months.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	16	 All vaccine recipients were monitored for clinical signs and symptoms for 7 days after each inoculation.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Immune responses were measured by an HPV16 L1 VLP-based enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and by an HPV16 pseudovirion neutralization assay.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The antibody titers were given as the reciprocals of the highest dilution showing positive reactivity in each assay.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	19	 All statistical tests were two-sided.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Results: The prevaccination geometric mean ELISA titer for six seropositive individuals was 202 (range, 40 to 640).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	21	 All vaccine formulations were well tolerated, and all subjects receiving vaccine seroconverted.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Serum antibody responses at 1 month after the third injection were dose dependent in recipients of vaccine without adjuvant or with MF59 but were similar at both doses when alum was the adjuvant.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	23	 With the higher dose, the geometric means of serum ELISA antibody titers (95% confidence intervals) to purified VLP 1 month after the third injection were as follows: 10 240 (1499 to 69 938) without adjuvant, 10 240 (1114 to 94 145) with MF59, and 2190 (838 to 5723) with alum.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Responses of subjects within each group were similar.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Neutralizing and ELISA antibody titers were highly correlated (Spearman correlation = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	26	85), confirming that ELISA titers are valid proxies for neutralizing antibodies.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Conclusions: The HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine is well tolerated and is highly immunogenic even without adjuvant, with the majority of the recipients achieving serum antibody titers that were approximately 40-fold higher than what is observed in natural infection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	28	   INTRODUCTION Top Notes Abstract Introduction Subjects and Methods Results Discussion References   Invasive cervical cancer develops in approximately 400 000 women per year worldwide and results in approximately 200 000 deaths per year (1,2).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The greatest burden of disease is in developing countries, where cervical cancer is often the most frequent female malignancy, and may constitute up to one quarter of all female cancers.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Early detection of premalignant cervical neoplasia is possible with Pap smears, but it has been difficult to establish screening programs in developing countries.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In the United States, Pap smear screening and follow-up have been estimated to cost more than 5 billion dollars annually, but the widespread availability of such screening has been associated with a 75% reduction in the incidence of cervical cancer (3).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	32	 However, in the United States, this cancer still accounts for about 7% of all female malignancies and about 5000 deaths per year (4).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	33	Clinical and molecular epidemiologic investigations have identified human papillomavirus (HPV) as the major cause of cervical cancer and cervical dysplasia (5,6).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Virtually all cervical cancers contain the genes of high-risk HPVs (most commonly, types 16, 18, 31, and 45), and the relative frequency with which these types are found is remarkably similar in most regions of the world (6,7).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	35	 HPV16 is found in approximately 50% of cervical cancers, and types 18, 31, and 45 account for an additional 25% to 30% of HPV-positive tumors.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	36	Identification of HPV as a causal factor in virtually all cervical cancers implies that development of an effective vaccine against high-risk HPV could prevent the premalignant and malignant disease associated with HPV infection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Since prophylactic viral vaccines have a long record as a cost-effective approach to prevent infection or modify disease, such a vaccine might also lower the cost of screening and treating premalignant cervical disease.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	38	 HPVs are DNA tumor viruses that contain oncogenes.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	39	 There might be theoretic arguments against the presence of such genes, which can disrupt normal growth controls, in a vaccine destined for normal individuals.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	40	 To develop a prophylactic vaccine against HPV infection, we and others (8) have, therefore, taken a subunit vaccine approach, analogous to that used successfully against hepatitis B-induced disease, including hepatocarcinoma (9).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	41	Papillomaviruses encode a major capsid protein, L1, that has the intrinsic capacity to self-assemble into virus-like particles (VLPs) in the absence of other viral gene products (10 to 13).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Recombinant L1 VLPs are morphologically indistinguishable from authentic virions, contain the immunodominant conformationally dependent neutralization epitopes present in authentic virions, and have the ability to generate high titers of type-specific neutralizing antibodies (8).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	43	Several trials of preventive papillomavirus vaccine candidates using L1 VLPs purified from insect cells have been conducted by use of the cutaneous cottontail rabbit papillomavirus (CRPV), the oral mucosal bovine papillomavirus 4 (BPV4), or the canine oral papillomavirus (COPV) disease model in its natural host.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Three subcutaneous injections of CRPV L1 VLPs given without adjuvant, or combined with alum or Freund's adjuvant, protected rabbits against persistent infection and subsequent carcinoma after high-dose CRPV challenge (14,15).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Protection lasted at least 1 year (15).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Similarly, dogs or calves given two intramuscular injections of COPV L1 VLPs (without adjuvant) or BPV4 L1 VLPs (with alum), respectively, were protected from subsequent oral mucosal challenge (16,17).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	47	 In the CRPV and COPV models, passive transfer of serum or immunoglobulin (Ig) G from animals immunized with the L1 VLPs protected naive animals challenged with the homologous virus, indicating that neutralizing antibodies were sufficient to confer protection (14,16).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	48	Since papillomaviruses are species specific and HPVs do not induce disease in animals (4), further HPV vaccine development and evaluation require studies in humans.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Therefore, as an initial step in demonstrating proof-of-principle, we developed a prophylactic recombinant HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine candidate, produced in insect cells with recombinant baculovirus, for testing in humans.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	50	 This study was designed to evaluate the safety and immunogenicity in healthy young adults of two dose levels (10 and 50  microg) of the HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine given in aqueous solution without adjuvant or mixed with alum or MF59 adjuvant.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	51	   SUBJECTS AND METHODS Top Notes Abstract Introduction Subjects and Methods Results Discussion References   Vaccine.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	52	Recombinant baculovirus expressing the full-length L1 capsid gene of HPV16 strain 114K (11) as VLPs was constructed by use of the bacmid system (18).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	53	5-kilobase BglII DNA fragment from pEVnod-KL1 (11) containing the HPV16 L1 gene was cloned in the BamHI site downstream of the polyhedrin promoter within the polh locus in the baculovirus donor plasmid pFASTBAC-1 (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	54	 [GIBCO BRL], Rockville, MD) by site-specific recombination in Escherichia coli DH10Bac1.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Recombinant baculovirus containing the HPV16 L1 DNA was isolated from Sf-9 insect cells transfected with the recombinant bacmid DNA by use of the cationic lipid Cellfectin (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Recombinant baculovirus was plaque purified three times and screened for insert integrity by DNA sequencing and L1 capsid antigen expression in insect cells by sodium dodecyl sulfate to polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and western blot analyses.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	57	 One recombinant baculovirus isolate that expressed high levels of L1 protein intracellularly and extracellularly was amplified in Sf-9 cells, tested for microbial contaminants and adventitious agents, and designated the master virus seed stock (bHPV16 L1 R-212).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Working virus seed stocks of bHPV16 L1 virus were produced in Sf-9 cells infected for 3 days at a multiplicity of infection (moi) of 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	59	01 plaque-forming unit (pfu)/cell.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	60	Production of clinical lots of recombinant HPV16 L1 VLP vaccines was performed in accordance to good manufacturing practice guidelines for well-characterized biologicals at the Vaccine Production Facility of Novavax, Inc.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	61	 (formerly DynCorp) in Columbia, MD.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Production lots of recombinant HPV16 L1 VLPs were manufactured in Sf-9 cells (2 to 3 x 106 cells/mL in 16.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	63	8-L-size batches) infected with bHPV-16 L1 virus at an moi of 3 to 5 pfu's/cell for 4 to 5 days at 28  degrees C as described previously (19).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Sf-9 cells were cultivated as suspension cultures by use of Sf-900 II serum-free medium (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Extracellular HPV16 L1 VLPs were recovered from infected cell suspension by low-speed centrifugation (1000g for 10 minutes at 4  degrees C), and supernatants were clarified by centrifugation (10 000g for 30 minutes at 4  degrees C).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Clarified supernatants were concentrated 15-fold by ultrafiltration with the use of hollow fiber membranes (UFP-5-C-6A, MWCO 500 000) (A/G Technologies) and diafiltered against 20 volumes of phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (pH 7.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The dialysate was clarified by centrifugation as described above, the clarified supernatant was loaded onto 30% sucrose cushions in PBS, and the recombinant VLPs and baculovirus were pelleted through the sucrose cushions by ultracentrifugation (26 000g for 3 hours at 4  degrees C) by use of swinging bucket rotors.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Pellets were solubilized in PBS and loaded onto 25% to 65% sucrose step gradients.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	69	 VLPs were resolved as bluish bands on gradients by ultracentrifugation (25 000g for 1 hour at 4  degrees C) by use of swinging bucket rotors.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Successive rounds of ultracentrifugation on sucrose gradients were used to obtain VLPs with a purity of more than 95%.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	71	 VLPs were recovered from banded VLPs by ultracentrifugation (26 000g for 3 hours at 4  degrees C).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Sucrose was removed from pelleted VLPs by dialysis against PBS.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The VLPs were then diluted to 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	74	3 mg/mL and filtered aseptically through 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The filtered VLPs were designated the final bulk product and stored at -20  degrees C.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The final bulk product underwent both safety and analytic testing, and the batch records were audited by quality assurance before release of the final bulk product for formulation of final container vaccine product.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The integrity of the VLPs was monitored by their morphology in the electron microscope, their ability to hemagglutinate mouse red blood cells efficiently (20), and their strong reactivity to HPV16 conformational and neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (H16.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	78	U4) (21,22) and nonreactivity to an HPV11 neutralizing monoclonal antibody (H11.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	79	The final bulk product of recombinant HPV16 L1 VLPs was formulated in a final volume of 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	80	5 mL as a nonadjuvanted vaccine at a 10- and 50- microg dose or in a final volume of 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	81	25 mL to be mixed with MF-59 adjuvant (Chiron Corporation, Emeryville, CA), which is a microfluidized oil-in-water emulsion consisting of 1.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	82	25 mg of sorbitan amonoleate (Tween 80 ), 1.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	83	25 mg of sorbitan trioleate (Span 85 ), and 10.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	84	 At the time of vaccine administration, 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	85	25 mL of MF59 emulsion was combined with 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	86	25 mL of vaccine to yield a vaccine dose of 10 and 50  microg.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Alternatively, the final bulk product was formulated with alum (aluminum potassium sulfate, 10%; EM Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) at 120 mg of alum per mg of VLP antigen.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The final volume of the VLP to alum vaccine was 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	89	5 mL for 10- and 50- microg doses.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Sterile saline served as the placebo vaccine.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Formulated VLPs were dispensed aseptically into sterile vials (3.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	92	0-mL size, type 1 borosilicate glass, silanized, depyrogenated; Wheaton Glass, Wheaton, MD) as a single-unit dose and were designated final container vials.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Vials containing only VLP antigen were stored at -20  degrees C before administration, whereas vials containing VLP antigen adsorbed to alum were stored at 4  degrees C because of stability concerns.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	94	This double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, phase I safety and immunogenicity trial was conducted at The Johns Hopkins University Center for Immunization Research (Baltimore, MD).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Guidelines for human experimentation of the Joint Committee for Clinical Investigation of The Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and its institutional review board were followed in the conduct of this study.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Seventy-two healthy, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-1-seronegative, 18- to 29-year-old volunteers (58 females and 14 males) were recruited for this study.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Subjects were determined by history to be at low risk for HPV16 exposure.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Individuals were not eligible to participate if they had a history of more than four lifetime sexual partners or more than two sexual partners within the preceding 6 months.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Additional exclusion criteria included history of abnormal cervical cytology, immunodeficiency, anaphylaxis to medicines or vaccines, receipt of blood products within 3 months of enrollment, current pregnancy or lactation, and any other condition that might interfere with the study objectives.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	100	 All aspects of the protocol were explained to the subjects who met the eligibility criteria, and informed, witnessed, written consent was obtained.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Preimmune HPV16 serostatus was not a criterion for eligibility, since it was expected that only about 10% of the volunteers would be seropositve (in this study, only six of 72 volunteers were found to be seropositive at study entry), its omission simplified recruitment, enrollment, and initiation of vaccination, and the presence of a few seropositive vaccine recipients would enable us to monitor the response of such individuals.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	102	Before enrollment, a medical history was obtained from each subject, a physical examination was performed, and the following laboratory tests were done (Quest Diagnostics; Baltimore, MD): complete blood cell count (CBC), platelet count, alanine aminotransferase (ALT), serum creatinine, hepatitis B surface antigen, HIV antibody test, and urine dipstick for hemoglobin and protein.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Volunteers were eligible to enroll if their medical history, physical examination, and laboratory tests were without clinically significant abnormalities.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Individuals with clinically significant abnormalities were not enrolled but were counseled and referred for medical consultation as appropriate.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	105	 To qualify for enrollment and subsequent vaccination, female subjects were required to have a negative urine pregnancy test on the day of each vaccination and to use an acceptable method of birth control until completion of the study.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	106	To determine whether the dose of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine and/or the addition of alum or MF59 adjuvant would influence the reactogenicity or immune response, the trial was conducted in a dose-escalation manner, starting with 10  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine given alone, with alum, or with MF59 adjuvants.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	107	 When this dose was determined to be safe, we then evaluated a 50- microg dose of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine given alone, with alum, or with MF59 adjuvant (Table 1).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	108	 For each dose/adjuvant group, 10 subjects were randomly assigned to receive investigational vaccine, and two were randomly assigned to receive placebo (sterile physiologic saline).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Subjects received vaccine or placebo as an intramuscular injection (0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	110	5 mL) in the deltoid region at months 0, 1, and 4.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	111	 To maintain blinding, the individual who prepared and administered the vaccine was not involved in data collection or clinical evaluation of volunteers.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Immunization scheme for safety and immunogenicity trial of human papillomavirus 16 L1 virus-like particle vaccine with or without alum or MF59 adjuvant*   Subjects were evaluated clinically, and blood was collected for clinical and immunologic tests before each injection (months 0, 1, and 4) and 1 month after each injection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Clinical laboratory tests done at each of these visits included the following: CBC, platelet count, serum ALT, serum creatinine, urine protein, and urine hemoglobin measurements.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	114	 After each injection, oral temperatures were recorded after 30 minutes, 6 hours, and daily for 6 days.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Adverse reactions were monitored by study staff in the clinic at 30 minutes and 2 days after each injection and by telephone for the following 6 days.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Clinical signs and symptoms were scored as follows: none = no reaction; mild = transient or mild discomfort; moderate = mild to moderate limitation in activity; and severe = marked limitation in activity.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	117	IgG-specific HPV16 L1 VLP-based enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) were performed in a 96-well plate format as described previously (24), except that 200 ng of VLPs was used per well and end point dilution titers were determined.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	118	 VLPs for the ELISAs were purified from the nuclei of HPV16 L1 recombinant baculovirus-infected Sf-9 cells as described previously (11).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Fourfold dilutions of each serum were assayed, starting at a dilution of 10.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Sera were designated ELISA positive at a given dilution if the absolute optical density (OD) was greater than or equal to 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	121	2 and was at least double the reactivity of the same serum dilution in a well containing blocking buffer but no VLPs.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Seroconversion was defined as a fourfold or greater rise in titer.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Vaccine recipients were considered to be HPV16 seropositive at enrollment if their prevaccination serum demonstrated an ELISA antibody titer that was greater than or equal to the reactivity of a standard pooled serum, which was assayed on the same plate (generally OD of 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Reactivity to the standard serum had been validated as a cut point for seropositivity in a previous seroepidemiologic study (24).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	125	The detailed procedure for IgM, IgA, and IgG isotyping and for determining IgG subclass with subclass-specific second antibodies is reported elsewhere (25).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Sera from the individuals receiving vaccine without adjuvant or with alum were tested in triplicate at a dilution of 1 : 50 for IgG and IgG1 or at a dilution of 1 : 20 for IgG2, IgG3, and IgG4 by use of the corresponding isotype- or subclass-specific second antibody.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	127	 A sample was considered to be positive if, after subtraction of the reactivity to denatured BPV1 VLPs, the OD was greater than the mean OD plus three standard deviations from the mean for a panel of sera from virgin women and was at least 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	128	In vitro HPV16 pseudovirion neutralization assays were performed as described previously (26).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Briefly, infectious virions composed of the HPV16 L1 and L2 capsid proteins and the BPV1 genome were generated by infection of BPHE-1 hamster cells (which contain autonomously replicating BPV genomes) with replication-defective Semliki Forest Virus vectors expressing HPV16 L1 and L2 genes.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Individual infections by the pseudotype virions were detected as transformed foci in a monolayer of mouse C127 cells.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Fourfold dilutions of the sera, starting with a dilution of 1 : 10, were mixed with approximately 50 to 100 focus-forming units of pseudotype virions and assayed for inhibition of focal transformation.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Neutralization was defined as at least a 50% reduction in the number of foci compared with the number obtained in the absence of human serum.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The ELISA and neutralizing antibody titers are given as the reciprocal of the highest positive dilution for each assay.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	134	The data for local and systemic reactions were grouped by vaccine dose and adjuvant.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Data from placebo recipients were pooled for analysis.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	136	 We compared proportions of reactions among different categories of volunteers by use of a continuity corrected test for proportions between two independent groups (27).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Nonparametric statistics (Kruskal to Wallis test) were used to make comparisons across groups at a given time.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The Kruskal to Wallis test was also used to compare the distribution of antibody titers in different groups over time (28).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The Spearman correlation coefficient was used when comparing ELISA results against those obtained by using the neutralization test (28).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Categorized ELISA and neutralization results were compared with the use of the Kappa statistic, and overall agreement percentages were also computed (29).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	141	 All statistical tests were two-sided.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	142	   RESULTS Top Notes Abstract Introduction Subjects and Methods Results Discussion References   This was a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled safety and immunogenicity dose escalation trial of HPV16 L1 VLPs that were made in insect cells with a recombinant baculovirus.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	143	 An electron micrograph of the VLP preparation is given in Fig.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	144	 When the VLP preparation was denatured and subjected to gel electrophoresis, L1 was the only band seen in the gel (Fig.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The trial tested two vaccine doses, 10 and 50  microg, without adjuvant or with alum or MF59 adjuvant (Table 1).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Each vaccine preparation was given at 0, 1, and 4 months.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The demographic characteristics of the study population are shown in Table 2.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In the first part of the study, 35 of the 36 subjects were randomly assigned and received three injections of either 10  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine (with or without adjuvant) or placebo.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	149	 One placebo recipient moved away before receiving the third injection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In the second part of the study, 33 of the 36 subjects were randomly assigned and received three injections of either 50  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine (with or without adjuvant) or placebo.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Two subjects who did not complete the scheduled series of injections were in the group that received 50  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP with alum.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	152	 One of these subjects received two immunizations but did not return for follow-up visits thereafter.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The other subject received the first two immunizations, but the third was not given because of 1+ hemoglobin in the urine (as determined by standard dipstick measurement, calibrated as 0 [neg] to 4+) noted on the day the third vaccination was scheduled.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Subsequent urologic evaluation of this volunteer revealed no abnormality.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The third subject who did not complete the full series of injections was a placebo recipient who was lost to follow-up after the second injection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	156	View larger version (67K):    Fig.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Human papillomavirus type 16 L1 virus-like particles (HPV16 L1 VLPs) used as vaccine in the trial.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	158	 A) transmission electron micrograph showing the morphology of the HPV16 L1 VLPs in the vaccine preparation (original magnification x36 000).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	159	 B) Coomassie Blue-stained gradient polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis of the vaccine preparation showing L1 as the only detectable band.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Demographics of study population by human papillomavirus type 16 L1 virus-like particle (HPV16 L1 VLP) vaccine dose group*   Clinical Responses.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	161	Administration of three injections of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine, given alone or with alum or MF59 adjuvant, was well tolerated at both dose levels (Table 3).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	162	 For each group, the frequency and severity of reactions following each of the three doses were similar, and reactions for all three vaccinations have, therefore, been grouped together.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Most of the local and systemic reactions were classified as mild.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Clinical responses of the subjects who received 10  microg of vaccine without adjuvant were almost identical to those of the placebo group.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Subjects who received 50  microg of vaccine without adjuvant reported local side effects about twice as frequently as the placebo recipients.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Recipients of either 10 or 50  microg of vaccine with MF59 reported pain at the injection site more frequently than recipients of vaccine with alum or without adjuvant (10  microg 24 (80%) of 30 versus 11 (36.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	167	0001, respectively; 50  microg 28 (93.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	168	 However, pain was mild to moderate in intensity and resolved spontaneously within 48 to 72 hours in all subjects.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Similarly, recipients of 50  microg of vaccine with MF59 reported local induration and/or erythema more frequently than recipients of 50  microg of vaccine with alum or without adjuvant.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Of note, one recipient of 50  microg of vaccine with MF59 reported erythema that peaked at 60 mm in diameter on the day of the third vaccination and resolved on day 2 after vaccination.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	171	 A second recipient of 50  microg of vaccine with MF59 reported 45 mm of erythema and induration that began on the day of the second vaccination and resolved on day 4 after vaccination.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Neither of these subjects required medication or other clinical intervention.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	173	 There was no notable difference in the clinical responses of the five vaccine recipients who were seropositive at entry compared with the seronegative vaccine recipients in the same group nor was the frequency or severity of reactions greater after the third vaccination than after the initial vaccinations.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Cumulative percent reactions in subjects within 1 week of vaccination*   Two subjects had clinically significant laboratory abnormalities.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	175	 As described above, one subject in the group that received 50  microg of vaccine with alum had transient idiopathic microscopic hematuria.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	176	 A second subject was noted to have asymptomatic ALT elevation 1 month after receiving the second vaccine dose (ALT = 356 U; normal range, 0 to 48 U), which resolved during the subsequent month.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Clinical evaluation, including laboratory studies for hepatitis, was unrevealing, except that the subject recalled a similar asymptomatic episode (not reported before enrollment in the vaccine study) of ALT elevation that was discovered 2 years earlier after donating blood.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The clinical evaluation at that time was also negative.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	179	 After resolution of the ALT abnormality, the subject received the third vaccine dose and had no further elevation in the ALT level.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Clinical laboratory results for all other subjects were unremarkable.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	181	HPV16-Specific Antibody Responses.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	182	The volunteers were evaluated for serum IgG responses to the vaccine by use of an HPV16 VLP ELISA (24) (Table 4).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Overall, the sexual-history screening tool used in this study was an effective predictor of baseline HPV16 seronegativity by ELISA.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	184	 A total of six of 72 subjects were IgG seropositive by ELISA at study entry.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The geometric mean ELISA titer (GMT) of the prevaccination sera from these six individuals was 202 (range, 40 to 640).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Four of these subjects received 10  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine (one without adjuvant, two with alum, and one with MF59), one received 50  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine without adjuvant, and one received placebo.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The final serum ELISA titers for each of the five vaccine recipients who were seropositive before vaccination were no more than one fourfold dilution above the final serum GMT of the prevaccination seronegative vaccinees in the same group.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Geometric mean titers for human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16)-specific antibodies by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and neutralization assay   Excluding the initial seropositive subjects, GMT ELISA titers at entry were less than or equal to 20 for each group, and there was no statistically significant difference in baseline antibody titers between groups (P = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	189	 None of the placebo recipients seroconverted.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	190	 By contrast, all vaccine recipients seroconverted within 1 month after the second vaccination (data shown only as group mean).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	191	 In all groups receiving investigational vaccine, the titers 3 months after the second injection (month 4) waned compared with those achieved 1 month after this injection (month 2) (P values for all comparisons =  > .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	192	1, with the exception of the comparison for the group that received 10  microg of vaccine with MF59, where P = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Conversely, a clear boost in the titers was seen 1 month after the third injection (month 5) (P values ranging from .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	194	04), except for the group that received 50  microg of VLP in alum, whose titers showed a small increase (P = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	195	In each group that received vaccine (alone or with adjuvant), peak titers were observed at month 5 (1 month after the third injection).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	196	 The month-5 antibody titers for the groups that received 10  microg of vaccine with alum and 10  microg of vaccine with MF59 were similar (P = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	197	76) and were significantly higher (P =.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	198	01, respectively) than the month 5 antibody titers of the group that received 10  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP alone.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Thus, within the low-dose group, the addition of alum or MF59 adjuvant enhanced the immune response.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	200	Compared with the month-5 titers at the 10- microg dose, titers for the 50- microg groups were markedly higher in recipients of vaccine without adjuvant, modestly higher in recipients of vaccine with MF59, and slightly lower in recipients of vaccine with alum.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In contrast to the results obtained with the 10- microg vaccine dose, the ELISA antibody titers achieved in the group that received 50  microg of vaccine without adjuvant were equivalent to those in the group that received 50  microg of vaccine with MF59 (P = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Month-5 antibody titers in these two groups were significantly higher (P = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	203	001, respectively) than the antibody titers in the group that received vaccine with alum.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	204	The sera from subjects vaccinated without adjuvant or with alum were also analyzed in HPV16 VLP ELISAs specific for IgM and IgA and for IgG subclasses (Table 5).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The majority of the antibody response to VLP vaccination was of the IgG1 subclass.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	206	 As expected, most vaccine recipients became transiently seropositive for HPV16 IgM antibodies, which were usually detected in the sample taken 1 month after the initial vaccination.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Most vaccine recipients also became seropositive for serum IgA; however, relative to IgG responses, the responses varied considerably and were generally weaker.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	208	 All vaccine recipients became strongly seropositive for IgG1, and the responses closely paralleled the response to total IgG.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	209	 In contrast, only one subject became weakly, although consistently, seropositive in the IgG2 assay.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Responses to IgG3 and IgG4 were weak and variable.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Number of vaccine recipients who became ELISA seropositive for human papillomavirus type 16 virus-like particle-specific immunoglobulin (Ig) isotype or subclass*   The VLP ELISAs may measure a combination of neutralizing and non-neutralizing HPV virion antibodies, as well as antibodies to immunogenic insect cell or baculovirus proteins common to the vaccine and ELISA antigen.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Therefore, it was important to determine directly whether the HPV L1 VLP vaccine was able to induce virion neutralizing antibodies, which are expected to correlate most closely with the potential for protection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	213	 For this analysis, we employed an HPV16 pseudovirion neutralization assay developed previously (26).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	214	 On the basis of studies with animals, this assay is approximately 20- to 30-fold less sensitive than the HPV16 ELISA (30).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	215	 For analysis of the current trial, month 5 sera from recipients of the 50- microg dose (with or without adjuvant) were studied with the neutralization assay (Table 4; Fig.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	216	View larger version (66K):    Fig.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Month-5 serum enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) titers and neutralization antibody titers for individuals vaccinated with three doses of 50  microg of human papillomavirus type 16 L1 virus-like particles (HPV16 L1 VLPs).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	218	 HPV16 L1 VLP ELISA titers are indicated by the hatched bars, and HPV16 pseudovirion neutralizing titers are indicated by the black bars.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The individuals vaccinated without adjuvant, with alum, and with MF59 are grouped from left to right.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	220	 * indicates an individual whose preinoculation serum was ELISA positive.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	221	 # indicates an individual who received only the first two immunizations.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	222	  As expected, the neutralization titers were much lower than those obtained with the ELISA (Fig.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	223	 However, sera from all vaccine recipients had detectable neutralizing antibodies.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	224	 In contrast, none of the placebo recipients developed a detectable neutralizing antibody response (data not shown).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	225	 There was a remarkable consistency of neutralizing titer within each vaccine/adjuvant group.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	226	 With the exception of one individual in the MF59 group with an unusually strong response, neutralizing titers varied by no more than one fourfold dilution from the median (Fig.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	227	 In addition, the neutralizing antibody titers were highly correlated with ELISA antibody titers (Spearman correlation = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Similarly, when neutralization assay and ELISA results were categorized as low, medium, or high titers (ELISA low = 160, medium = 640 to 2450, and high =  > 2450; neutralization assay low = 10, medium = 40 to 160, and high =  > 160) and compared, the kappa coefficient was .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	229	80 (95% confidence interval = 0.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	230	99) and the percent agreement was 87.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	231	 These data suggest that ELISA titers were effective surrogates for neutralizing antibody titers.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	232	The GMT neutralizing antibody titers in the group that received 50  microg of vaccine with MF59 were greater than the titers in recipients of 50  microg of vaccine without adjuvant, but this difference was not statistically significant (P = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	233	 However, the neutralizing antibody titers achieved in groups receiving VLPs with MF59 or with no adjuvant were significantly higher than the titers in the group receiving VLPs in alum (P = .
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Thus, the relative hierarchy of the GMT neutralization resembled the GMT ELISA titers.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	235	   DISCUSSION Top Notes Abstract Introduction Subjects and Methods Results Discussion References   The results presented here indicate that three intramuscular doses of 10 or 50  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine with no adjuvant, with alum, or with MF59 were well tolerated and highly immunogenic in normal human volunteers.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Regardless of dose and whether or not adjuvant was present in the vaccine, each of the volunteers who received the vaccine demonstrated a serum immune response by 1 month after the second immunization (i.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The third immunization induced a further elevation in end point serum antibody titers in most instances.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	238	 These results complement, for a high-risk HPV type, a recent report of HPV VLP vaccination in a therapeutic setting (31).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	239	 In that study, multiple injections of 1, 5, or 10  microg of HPV6 VLPs, without adjuvant, were well tolerated in genital wart patients with HPV6 infections, and vaccination induced an increase in VLP ELISA titers in most patients.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	240	The most commonly reported side effect in our study was pain at the site of injection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Most of the pain was mild and short-lived, consistent with other intramuscularly administered recombinant subunit vaccines, such as licensed hepatitis B vaccines (32,33).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Side effects were similar in recipients of placebo and recipients of 10  microg of vaccine without adjuvant.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	243	 However, recipients of the higher vaccine dose (50  microg) without adjuvant did report more side effects than the placebo recipients.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	244	 As expected, a greater proportion of recipients of HPV16 L1 VLP with MF59 reported moderate pain at the injection site than recipients of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine given alone or with alum.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The proportion of subjects experiencing injection site reactogenicity after injection of HPV16 L1 VLP with MF59 was comparable to that reported with other investigational vaccine antigens given with MF59, such as hepatitis B surface antigen and herpes simplex type II gD glycoprotein (34,35).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	246	In this study, the adjuvant effects of alum and MF59 were evident in recipients of the lower vaccine dose (10  microg).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	247	 In addition, there was a dose-dependent response in the groups receiving vaccine without adjuvant or with MF59, although not in the groups receiving vaccine with alum.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Specifically, as determined by GMT ELISA titers, there was a marked increase in the immune response to 50  microg without adjuvant compared with 10  microg without adjuvant (10 240 versus 640), a modest increase with MF59 (10 240 versus 3480), and no increase in the ELISA titers seen with alum (3040 versus 2190).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Since at the 50- microg dose the ELISA titers in recipients of vaccine without adjuvant were comparable to the titers in the group that received vaccine with MF59, and even higher than the group that received vaccine with alum, there was no apparent benefit to using adjuvant at this dose when serum antibody titers were measured shortly after immunizations.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	250	 It is unknown whether these properties would continue to be true following a longer interval after the third vaccine dose.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Since the addition of MF59 adjuvant was associated with increased pain and induration at the injection site, the optimal immunogenicity and reactogenicity profile in the current study was obtained with 50  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP vaccine without adjuvant.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	252	 It is encouraging to note that, with the higher dose without adjuvant or with MF59, the final serum titers were about 40 times higher than those detected systemically after natural infection in the subjects who were seropositive before vaccination.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	253	The similar titers seen at the 50- microg dose with no adjuvant or with MF59, combined with the modest increase seen with MF59 at the higher dose, suggest that even higher doses of vaccine would probably not induce substantially higher antibody titers.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	254	 For alum, the 10- microg vaccine dose induced maximum ELISA titers.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	255	 A similar plateau effect was reported when alum was used for HPV11 L1 VLP vaccination of macaques (36).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Although we do not understand the basis for this phenomenon, two factors that can have a substantial impact on the immune response of antigens delivered with alum are the degree of antigen adsorption onto alum and the dose of alum used (37).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	257	 It is unlikely that the degree of antigen adsorption adversely affected immunogenicity because, in the formulation containing 50  microg of HPV16 L1 VLP with alum, more than 95% of the VLPs was complexed with the aluminum hydroxide.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	258	 However, even with high levels of antigen adsorption, it is possible that the concentration of alum was insufficient to induce a maximal adjuvant effect.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	259	 It is also possible that the VLPs in alum, which were stored at 4  degrees C, might have been less stable.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Such instability would presumably have affected only the 50- microg dose, which was given after the 10- microg dose.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	261	A predominantly IgG1 response was also not unexpected.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	262	 We have found recently that IgG1 is also the IgG isotype that predominates after seroconversion to natural infection (25).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Predominantly IgG1 responses are also commonly seen after other microbial infections (38).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	264	 In C57BL/6 mice, HPV16 L1 VLPs induce a more varied IgG response, with substantial amounts of specific IgG1, IgG2b, and IgG3 detected (Heather Greenstone, Ph.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Thesis, The Johns Hopkins University).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Whether this reflects a stronger Th1 type response to HPV VLPs in humans than in mice remains to be determined.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The inability to detect an IgG2 response in most vaccine recipients is unlikely to be due to poor sensitivity or specificity of the IgG2 assay.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	268	 In fact, the sensitivity/specificity of the IgG2 assay was superior to that of the IgG1 assay for isotype-specific human Ig control subjects (25).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	269	Neutralization assays are often considered to be the "gold standard" in assessing the immunogenicity of a prophylactic vaccine such as the one tested here.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	270	 When the month-5 sera from the groups that received the 50- microg dose of vaccine were analyzed for HPV16 peudovirion neutralizing activity, there was an excellent quantitative correlation with the ELISA titers.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	271	 This correlation held for individuals as well as for groups, further implying that the ELISA appears to represent an appropriate surrogate assay for the more cumbersome and expensive neutralization assay.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	272	For both assays, there was a remarkable consistency of response within each vaccine group.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The immunogenicity results seen here with the human volunteers parallel those obtained in animals, where consistently statistically significant immunogenicity and protection against experimental disease have been observed, even when adjuvant was not given.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	274	 It is likely that the particulate nature and regular array of L1 in the VLPs contribute to their high immunogenicity.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Perhaps efficient immune recognition is promoted by an interaction between the VLPs and cell surface pattern recognition receptors that bind the ordered external structure of icosahedral virions (39).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	276	It is not possible to know from these studies whether systemic administration of vaccine will protect against cervical infection under natural conditions.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	277	 However, the magnitude of the antibody responses in the human volunteers compares favorably with that seen in animal studies in which VLP vaccination, with alum or without adjuvant, induced protection from high-dose virus challenge (Table 6).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Although some caution must be taken in comparing studies in which different vaccination protocols and ELISAs were used, our overall impression is that humans and experimental animals respond similarly to VLP vaccination.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Animal studies demonstrating the ability of virus-like particles to protect against experimental papillomavirus challenge*   The animal models used experimental inoculation of abraded epithelium and tested cutaneous and oral mucosal infection, rather than genital infection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	280	 However, there are reasons to suspect that anticapsid antibodies generated systemically could at least partially neutralize natural HPV16 infection, even though HPV infection and replication occur in the epidermis of the genital tract.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	281	 First, it is likely that HPV infection of the basal cell layer requires microtrauma or abrasion of the epidermis (4).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Such disruption of the epidermis could expose the virus to serous exudate containing neutralizing IgG antibodies.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Second, in immune-mediated dermatologic diseases, such as pemphigus vulgaris, circulating antiepidermal antibody traverses the dermal to  epidermal junction, suggesting that the basement membrane is not an impermeable barrier to immunoglobulins (40).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Third, statistically significant levels of IgG have been reported in cervicovaginal secretions.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Much of this IgG is likely the result of transudation from the circulation (41).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	286	 (36) demonstrated in African green monkeys that parenteral immunization with as little as 10  microg of HPV11 L1 VLPs induced detectable IgG antibody titers in cervicovaginal secretions.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Although lower in magnitude, these titers closely paralleled the serum responses.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	288	 In addition, the IgG present in the cervicovaginal secretions was sufficient to neutralize HPV11 virus.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	289	 It is, therefore, plausible that parenteral immunization with HPV16 L1 VLPs could result in the appearance of HPV16-specific IgG in cervicovaginal secretions in humans.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Even if VLP vaccination did not achieve sterilizing immunity, it might, nevertheless, substantially modify the incidence and duration of HPV16-induced genital neoplasia by restricting virus replication and the extent of primary infection.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	291	 It is likely that a reduction in viral load would also diminish transmission to sex partners.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	292	The safety and immunogenicity profile obtained in this study encourages further clinical investigation of HPV VLP-based immunoprophylactic vaccines.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	293	 On the basis of these results, we have initiated a phase II trial of 50  microg of L1 VLP without adjuvant.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The key question of whether systemic administration with a VLP vaccine can confer protection under natural conditions must await the outcome of controlled efficacy trials.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	295	 If the vaccine were eventually shown to be effective, the type specificity of the neutralizing activity induced by the VLPs implies that protection would be type specific.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Since multiple HPV types are implicated in cervical cancer, a multivalent vaccine would be needed.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	297	 A vaccine composed of the four HPV types seen most frequently in cervical cancer (types 16, 18, 31, and 45) would theoretically be able to protect against approximately 80% of cervical cancers (6).
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	298	   NOTES   Supported by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Office of Women's Health, the NIH Office of Research on Minority Health, and the intramural research programs of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the National Cancer Institute, Bethesda, MD.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	299	We thank Catherine Greer and Lori Hansen (Chiron, Emeryville, CA) for providing the MF59, Dr.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Robert Chanock (National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD) for a critical reading of the manuscript, and Dr.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Richard Leapman and his colleagues (Division of Bioengineering and Physical Science, National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases, National Institutes of Health) for providing electron microscopic facilities and assistance.
0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	302	 We also acknowledge the expert assistance of Gwen Hammer, Sabrina Drayton, Arlene Bloom, Nancy Frazier, Martin Blair, and Denos Harris, The Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD.

0.25418594.11181775.html.plaintext.txt	499	 J Natl Cancer Inst 93: 252-253 [Full Text]                 Copyright   2001 Oxford University Press (unless otherwise stated) Oxford University Press Privacy Policy and Legal Statement Search All Search JNCI Search Journals Search Cancer Statistics Search PDQ Search PDR Search Calendar.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Multistep, ATP-dependent Pathway for Assembly of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Capsids in a Cell-free System.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Hill,* Mei Lie Wong,  and Ramanujan S.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	2	* Department of Physiology,  Department of Medicine, and   Department of Biochemistry and HHMI, University of California, San Francisco, California 94143-0444 Abstract Materials and Methods Results Discussion Footnotes Acknowledgements Abbreviations used in this paper References.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	3	To understand the mechanism by which human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV) capsids are formed, we have reconstituted the assembly of immature HIV capsids de novo in a cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Capsid authenticity is established by multiple biochemical and morphologic criteria.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Known features of the assembly process are closely reproduced, indicating the fidelity of the cell-free reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Assembly is separated into co- and posttranslational phases, and three independent posttranslational requirements are demonstrated: (a) ATP, (b) a detergent-sensitive host factor, and (c) a detergent-insensitive host subcellular fraction that can be depleted and reconstituted.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Assembly appears to proceed by way of multiple intermediates whose conversion to completed capsids can be blocked by either ATP depletion or treatment with nondenaturing detergent.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Specific subsets of these intermediates accumulate upon expression of various assembly-defective Gag mutants in the cell-free system, suggesting that each mutant is blocked at a particular step in assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Furthermore, the accumulation of complexes of similar sizes in cells expressing the corresponding mutants suggests that comparable intermediates may exist in vivo.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	10	 From these data, we propose a multi-step pathway for the biogenesis of HIV capsids, in which the assembly process can be disrupted at a number of discrete points.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	11	The protein shell of the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV)1 virion, termed the HIV capsid or core, is composed of ~1,500 copies of the Pr55 Gag structural protein precursor (for review see Gelderblom, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	12	 For proper assembly of the capsid to occur, Pr55 chains must undergo myristoylation (Gheysen et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1989), an NH2-terminal modification thought to occur co-translationally (Towler et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The myristoylated chains are targeted to the host plasma membrane where assembly takes place concomitant with RNA encapsidation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	15	 As capsids are formed, they bud into the plasma membrane, which results in envelopment and subsequent release of viral particles from the cell.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Coincident with these events, the immature viral particles undergo a maturation process, involving proteolytic processing of the precursor structural proteins and condensation of the capsids into collapsed, electron-dense cores (for review see Gelderblom, 1991; Wills and Craven, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	17	Much of our knowledge of HIV capsid assembly comes from studies of viral particle formation in cultured cells transfected with viral genes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	18	 EM studies of these cells have indicated that the plasma membrane is the site of capsid assembly (Gelderblom, 1991; Wills and Craven, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Analysis of various mutants of Pr55 have revealed key domains required for efficient capsid assembly and targeting to the plasma membrane (Gheysen et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	20	, 1993; Wang and Barklis, 1993; Hockley et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	21	 However, the actual mechanisms involved in coordinating the formation of an HIV capsid from 1,500 Gag monomers have not been elucidated.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Many important questions about HIV capsid assembly remain unanswered, including whether assembly is an energy-dependent process, whether host proteins are required for assembly to take place, and whether assembly proceeds by way of discrete intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	23	A major obstacle to addressing these questions experimentally has been the inherent difficulty of studying capsid assembly in cellular systems.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In cells, many of the events in question proceed extremely rapidly and are not readily amenable to manipulation, making it difficult to identify trans-acting factors and energy substrates that may be required for assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Development of a cell-free system that recreates capsid biogenesis would greatly facilitate a biochemical dissection and mechanistic understanding of capsid formation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	26	In this study, we report the development of a cell-free system for the assembly of immature HIV capsids that appears to reproduce known features of capsid structure and biogenesis, including the phenotypes of a variety of assembly-competent and assembly-defective Gag mutants.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	27	 We use this system to demonstrate that capsid formation can be dissociated into co- and posttranslational phases, each of which has distinct requirements.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The reactions that occur during the posttranslational phase are dependent on ATP and at least two independent host factors, distinguished by their sensitivity to detergent.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In addition, the posttranslational phase appears to proceed by way of previously unrecognized assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Expression of Gag mutants that are defective for assembly results in accumulation of these assembly intermediates in the cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Similar findings are obtained in cellular systems.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Together, these data indicate that HIV capsid formation is a regulated, energy-dependent, multi-step process involving trans-acting host factors.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	33	Materials and Methods Plasmid Constructions.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	34	All plasmid constructions for cell-free transcription were made using PCR and other standard nucleic acid techniques (Sambrook et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Plasmid vectors were derived from SP64 (Promega, Heidelberg, Germany) into which the 5 untranslated region of Xenopus laevis globin had been inserted at the HindIII site (Melton et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The gag ORF from HIV genomic DNA (a kind gift of Jay Levy, University of California, San Francisco, CA) was introduced downstream from the SP6 promoter and the globin untranslated region.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The GA mutation was made by changing glycine at position 2 of Gag to alanine using PCR.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The Pr46 mutant was made by introducing a stop codon after gly 435 which removes p6; Pr41 has a stop codon after arg 363 (in the COOH-terminal region of p24).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	39	 These truncation mutants are comparable to those described by Jowett et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	40	 To make the D2 mutant, amino acids from gly 250 through val 260 were deleted (Hockley et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	41	 All changes engineered by PCR were verified by DNA sequencing.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	42	Transcription with SP6 polymerase and translation of the transcription products in wheat germ extract containing [35S]methionine (ICN Biochemicals, Irvine, CA) were performed as previously described (Lingappa et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	43	, 1994), except for modifications noted below.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Improved assembly was obtained when wheat germ extract, prepared as described before (Erickson and Blobel, 1983; Lingappa et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	45	, 1994), was subjected to ultracentrifugation at 50,000 rpm (TLA 100 rotor; Beckman Instruments, Palo Alto, CA) for 15 min at 4 degrees C and the supernatant used for in vitro translation (Lingappa, J.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	46	 10  microM myristol CoA (MCoA; Sigma Chemical Co.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Louis, MO) was added at the start of translation when indicated.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Translation reactions ranged in volume from 20 to 100  microl and were incubated at 25 degrees C for 150 min.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Some reactions were adjusted to a final concentration of the following agents at times indicated in figure legends: 0.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	50	2  microM emetine (Sigma Chemical Co); 1.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Results of some cell-free translation and assembly reactions were repeated using rabbit reticulocyte lysate that was prepared as described previously (Merrick, 1983).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	52	 In pulse-chase experiments, translation reactions contained [35S]cysteine (Amersham Corp.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	53	, Arlington Heights, IL) for radiolabeling.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	54	 4 min into translation, 3 mM unlabeled cysteine was added, and the reaction was continued at 25 degrees C for variable chase times, as indicated.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	55	A standard curve for quantity of translation product was established by immunoblotting a cell-free translation product and standards of known concentration (Lingappa, J.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The amount of Pr55 was determined by interpolation on this curve.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	57	Cell-free reactions were diluted into ice cold NP40 buffer (containing 10 mM TrisAc, pH 7.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	58	4, 100 mM NaCl, 4 mM MgAc, 50 mM KAc, and 1% NP-40) and layered onto the following gradients.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	59	 All sucrose solutions were made using the same buffer.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	60	 After centrifugation (TLS55 rotor; Beckman Instruments), 200  microl fractions were collected serially from the top.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Sucrose step gradients for batch separation of soluble and particulate material (used in Figs.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	62	 1, 2, and 4) contained 600  microl of 66% sucrose, 900  microl of 40% sucrose, and 500  microl of 20% sucrose, and were centrifuged at 30,000 rpm for 35 min at 4 degrees C.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Particles of 500-750-S partition into fractions 4-6, which were collected for further analysis.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Linear 10-50% sucrose gradients (used in Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	65	 1) were centrifuged at 30,000 rpm for 35 min at 4 degrees C.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Immature HIV capsids synthesized in the cell-free system resemble authentic capsids by biochemical and morphologic criteria.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	67	 (A and B) Migration of capsids on velocity sedimentation gradients.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	68	 (A) Cell-free translation and assembly reactions containing 10  microM MCoA and 35S methionine were programmed with HIV Gag transcript and performed as described in Materials and Methods.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	69	 At the end of the reaction, samples were diluted into buffer containing 1% NP-40 and separated into soluble and particulate fractions on sucrose step gradients.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Material in the particulate fraction ( > 500-S) was further analyzed by a variety of methods.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Shown here is an analysis of the particulate fraction by velocity sedimentation on a linear sucrose gradient.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Radiolabeled Pr55 protein in the gradient fractions was visualized by SDSPAGE and autoradiography.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The autoradiograph shows 10 consecutive fractions of a gradient with the top of the gradient at the left side.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	74	 (B) Cell culture medium was collected from transfected Cos cells that were releasing immature HIV particles.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Virus particles were harvested by ultracentrifugation through a 20% sucrose cushion, as described in Materials and Methods.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Authentic immature capsids were generated by treating these harvested particles with detergent to remove their envelopes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	77	 These authentic capsids were sedimented on a velocity sedimentation gradient, in parallel with the particulate fraction of the cell-free reaction shown in A.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Pr55 present in these fractions was visualized by immunoblotting.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Fractions are displayed in the same order described for A.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	80	 (C and D) Examination of buoyant density.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The particulate fraction of the cell-free reaction (C) and of authentic immature capsids (D) was analyzed in parallel by equilibrium centrifugation on CsCl.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Particle density was obtained by measuring the refractive index of each fraction and plotted on the right ordinate (open circles).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Gag polypeptide in the fractions was visualized, and the amount of protein was determined by densitometry of bands and plotted on the left ordinate (closed circles).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	84	 (E) Examination of electron microscopic appearance.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The particulate fraction of the cell-free reaction (1-4) and authentic capsids (5 and 6) were incubated on EM grids that were coated with antibody to HIV Gag.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	86	 100-nm particles were visualized by negative staining.

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Characteristics of HIV capsid assembly are reproduced in the cell-free system.

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The amount of radiolabeled Pr55 in the particulate fraction (which contains assembled capsids) was determined by densitometry of bands and is expressed as a percentage of total Gag protein synthesized.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The presence of MCoA had no effect on the total amount of Pr55 synthesized.

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Immediately after emetine treatment, apyrase, an enzyme that hydrolyzes ATP, was added at a concentration of 1 U/ microl to one of the emetine-treated reactions.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	107	 At the end of the incubation (150 min), 1  microl of each reaction was analyzed directly by SDS-PAGE (autoradiographs are shown below bar graph).

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	111	 (B) Effect on assembly of depletion and reconstitution of a subcellular fraction.

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	140	 At 4 min into translation, an excess of unlabeled cysteine was added to the reaction so that no further radiolabeling would occur.

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	144	 [View Larger Versions of these Images (24 + 15 + 15 + 15K GIF file)].
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Phenotypes of known mutations in Gag appear to be reproduced in the cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	146	 (A) Diagram of mutations within Gag.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Gag is a polyprotein precursor that consists of four domains, referred to as p17, p24, p7, and p6.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The Pr46 and Pr41 mutants were constructed by introducing a stop codon truncation at amino acid 435 or at amino acid 363, respectively.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In the D2 mutation, amino acids 250 to 260 are deleted.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In the GA mutation, the glycine at amino acid 2 is substituted with an alanine, thereby blocking myristoylation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The known phenotypes with respect to particle release from cells expressing each of these mutants is indicated to the right.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	152	 (B) Capsid assembly in cell-free reactions programmed with Gag mutants.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Cell-free translation and assembly reactions were programmed with transcript coding for each of the Gag mutants described above, as well as transcript coding for wild-type Gag in the presence or absence of MCoA (labeled WT and MCoA, respectively).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	154	 At the end of the reaction period, each sample was detergent treated, fractionated by velocity sedimentation on 13 ml sucrose gradients, and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The amount of radiolabeled translation product in the position of completed 750-S capsids was quantitated by densitometry and expressed for each reaction as a percentage of total synthesis.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The total amount of translation was approximately equal in all reactions.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	157	 [View Larger Version of this Image (22K GIF file)].
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	158	Estimates of S-values of Gag-containing complexes seen on 13 ml sucrose gradients were determined by the method of McEwen (1967) using the following formula: S = I / 2t where S is the sedimentation coefficient of the particle in Svedberg units, I is the time integral for sucrose at the separated zone minus the time integral for sucrose at the meniscus of the gradient,  is rotor speed in radians/sec, and t is time in sec.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	159	Values for I were determined for particles of a density of 1.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	160	3 g/cm3 and for a temperature of 5 degrees C, according to tables published by McEwen (1967).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Calculated S-values for different fractions in the gradients are labeled as markers above each gradient tracing (Figs.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Markers such as BSA (5-S), macroglobulin (20-S), Hepatitis B Virus capsids (100-S), ribosomal subunits (40-S and 60-S), and polysomes ( > 100-S) were used to calibrate the gradients and to confirm the calculated S-values.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	163	 However, it should be noted that the S-value assignments for each Gag-containing complex are meant to be very approximate estimates that allow a general description of the complex and should not be interpreted as constituting a detailed biophysical analysis.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Different assembly-defective mutants in Gag accumulate different assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Cell-free translation and assembly reactions were programmed with wild-type Gag (A), the assembly-competent Pr46 truncation mutant (B), the assembly-defective Pr41 truncation mutant (C), the assembly-defective GA mutant (D), or the assemblydefective D2 mutant (E).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	166	 At the end of the incubation, reaction products were detergent treated and analyzed by velocity sedimentation on 13 ml sucrose gradients as in Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The amount of radiolabeled translation product in each fraction was determined and expressed as a percentage of total synthesis for each reaction.
