0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	0	Human papillomavirus type 6 virus-like particles present overlapping yet distinct conformational epitopes Xin-Min Wang1, James C.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Merck Research Laboratories, PO Box 4, West Point, PA 19486, USA 2 The Jake Gittlen Cancer Research Institute, Department of Pathology, Penn State University, Milton S.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Hershey Medical Center, 500 University Drive, Hershey, PA 17033, USA.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	3	Correspondence William McClements william_mcclements{at}merck.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT Top ABSTRACT MAIN TEXT REFERENCES   The epitope for a human papillomavirus (HPV) type 6 conformation-dependent, neutralizing monoclonal antibody (mAb) was partially mapped using HPV L1 recombinant virus-like particles (VLPs).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	5	J54 is cross-reactive with the closely related HPV types 6 and 11.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	6	 By making HPV-6-like amino acid substitutions in the cottontail rabbit papillomavirus (CRPV) major capsid protein L1, we were able to transfer H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	7	J54 binding activity into a CRPV/HPV-6 hybrid L1 protein.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Full binding activity was achieved with only nine amino acid changes and identified a region centred on the HPV-6 residues 49 to 54.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	9	 This region has previously been shown to be a critical part of HPV-6 type-specific epitopes.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Fine mapping of the region by scanning a series of alanine substitution mutations showed that in HPV-6 VLPs this type-common epitope overlaps HPV-6 type-specific epitopes.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	11	   MAIN TEXT Top ABSTRACT MAIN TEXT REFERENCES   Human papillomavirus (HPV) infections are among the most common sexually transmitted diseases (Bauer et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	12	, 2001) and are implicated in both benign and malignant disease of the genital epithelia (Bosch et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1995; Galloway, 1994; Gissmann et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	14	, 1983; Munoz, 2000; Pisani et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	15	 To meet medical needs imposed by HPV infection, several experimental vaccines have been developed and are currently in human clinical trials (Brown et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	16	, 2001), and one has been shown to be effective in preventing persistent viral infection (Koutsky et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	17	 These vaccines are based on virus-like particles (VLPs), which assemble spontaneously when the papillomavirus major capsid protein, L1, is recombinantly expressed either alone or together with L2, the minor capsid protein (Hofmann et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	18	 VLPs are morphologically and immunologically similar to native virions (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 1993), can induce neutralizing antibody responses (Bryan et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	20	, 2000) and in animal models, can protect against viral disease (Breitburd et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	21	The amino acid sequences of L1 proteins are similar among papillomaviruses of all species and are well conserved among HPV genotypes.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Alignment of HPV L1 proteins reveals that within these well-conserved proteins there are localized regions of amino acid sequence divergence.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These regions contain determinants of type-specificity (Ludmerer  and  McClements, 1999).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	24	 We and others have shown that the epitopes recognized by HPV neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), which are generally type-specific and conformation-dependent, map to these regions (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	25	, 1996, 1997, 2000; McClements et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Furthermore, structural studies of HPV capsomers and VLPs have shown that these divergent sequence regions are surface-exposed (Chen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	27	, 2000), and other studies have shown that substitution of these regions with non-L1 sequences results in the presentation of foreign epitopes on VLPs (Chackerian et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	28	Previously, we mapped type-specific neutralizing epitopes for the closely related HPV types 6 and 11 by demonstrating that HPV-11-like amino acid substitutions in HPV-6 L1 transferred type 11-specific epitopes to VLPs assembled from mutant type 6 L1 proteins and that reciprocal experiments transferred HPV-6-specific epitopes to type 11 VLPs (Ludmerer et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	29	, 1996, 1997, 2000; McClements et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	30	 These studies mapped the HPV-11 immunodominant neutralizing epitope to a sequence of approximately 20 amino acids centred on residue Y132 and found that a second subdominant neutralizing epitope comprised residues 270 to 290 and 340 to 345.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	31	 For HPV-6, neutralizing epitopes are bipartite and comprise two regions of sequence divergence, both of which are distinct from the regions identified in HPV-11.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The principal region is centred on residues 49 to 54 (region I, Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	33	 1a) and contains determinants for H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	34	M48, the three HPV-6-specific conformation-dependent mAbs (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	35	, 1996b) that are neutralizing in an HPV-6 pseudovirion assay (Yeager et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The second region is centred on residues 169 to 178 (region II, Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	37	 1a) and modulates binding to region I.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	38	5 require region II as well as region I to achieve full binding to VLPs (McClements et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The physical association of regions I and II is consistent with the crystal structure of HPV-16 VLPs (Chen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	40	, 2000) where HPV-16 L1 sequences analogous to regions I and II map to loop B to C and segment G1, respectively, and are predicted to be in close proximity in capsomers and VLPs.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Type-specific bipartite epitopes have also been described for HPV types 11 and 16 (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	42	, 1996b), a conformation-dependent mAb that is cross-reactive with HPV types 6 and 11, suggested that it also recognizes a bipartite epitope, with one part mapping in the N-terminal region of L1 (N.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Christensen, unpublished observations).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	44	 This raised the possibility that, in HPV-6, type-common and type-specific epitopes may overlap and could interfere with precise serological characterization.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	45	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Amino acid sequence alignments of HPV-6, HPV-11 and CRPV L1 proteins.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Alignment of the three (complete) amino acid sequences was carried out using Vector NTI software.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	48	 (a) Aligned N termini of HPV-6 and CRPV.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Regions I and II of HPV-6 are indicated.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Arrowheads indicate residues in CRPV replaced with HPV-6-like residues in the CR/H6 hybrids; shaded areas denote the extent of amino acid identity with HPV-6 in hybrid L1 molecules.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	51	 (b) Alignment of HPV-11 region I with HPV-6 region I.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Residues in HPV-11 identical to those in HPV-6 are indicated by dots; the three differences (at residues 49, 53 and 54) that confer type 6 specificity are shown.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Residues of HPV-6 replaced with alanine in the scanning study are underlined.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	54	  To extend our mapping studies to address the question of epitope interference and to generate novel reagents for monitoring immune responses to HPV infection or immunization with experimental HPV vaccines, we attempted to transfer the HPV-6-specific epitopes to a less closely related papillomavirus VLP, i.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	55	 one that should have fewer epitopes in common with HPV-6 (Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	56	 We chose cottontail rabbit papillomavirus (CRPV) for the L1 scaffold.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The CRPV and HPV-6 L1 molecules are nearly identical in length and CRPV VLPs are structurally similar to HPV VLPs, but the CRPV L1 amino acid sequence (SWISS-PROT accession no.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	58	 P03102) is only about 50 % identical with that of HPV-6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Using PCR mutagenesis, we transferred the HPV-6-specific residues of regions I and II into the CRPV L1.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The CRPV/HPV-6 hybrid L1, CR/H6:I, had nine HPV-6-like substitutions in region I making that sequence identical to HPV-6 over a 20-residue sequence (CRPV L1 aa 45 to 64).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	61	 In addition to the region I changes, CR/H6:I-II was generated, which also had nine HPV-6-like substitutions in region II making that sequence identical to HPV-6 for the 22 residues (aa 166 to 187).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The alignment of HPV-6 and CRPV L1 sequences in Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	63	 1(a) highlights these changes and also shows the extended similarity between the two sequences.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	64	 All constructions were confirmed by complete sequencing of the L1 genes.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	65	 These hybrid proteins, as well as those from wild-type CPRV, HPV-6 and HPV-11, were expressed using the baculovirus vector pVL1393 (Stratagene).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Extracts were prepared from transfected Spodoptera frugiperda cells (Sf9; Invitrogen) and assayed by ELISA for binding activity to conformation-dependent mAbs as described previously (Benincasa et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	67	 2 shows the results of the binding activity assay.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	68	 With wild-type L1 proteins, type specificity of mAbs H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Also evident was the failure to transfer quantitatively HPV-6-specific binding activity to the CRPV backbone.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Lack of binding was not due to the failure of the hybrid L1 proteins to form high-order structures including capsomers and VLPs; CRPV-5A, a conformation-dependent CRPV-specific mAb (Christensen  and  Kreider, 1991) bound both hybrid proteins well.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Of the three type 6-specific mAbs, only H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	72	N8 showed any binding to a hybrid L1, and while the signal was well above background, binding was clearly impaired.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The surprising result was that H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	74	J54, a neutralizing conformation-dependent HPV-6 and -11 cross-reactive mAb (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	75	, 1996b), bound CR/H6:I as well as it bound wild-type HPV-6 or -11 VLPs.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	76	 This indicated that at least part of the J54 epitope was located in region I.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	77	 However, when the second HPV-6-like substitution at region II was made, the resultant hybrid L1 protein was not recognized by H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	78	 This result was in contrast to earlier data from HPV-6/11 hybrid VLPs where we found that sequences in region II could stabilize binding of the HPV-6 type-specific mAb interactions at region I (McClements et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	79	 However, it was consistent with H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	80	J54 binding studies on HPV-11/16 chimeric VLPs, which suggested that part of the J54 epitope maps to HPV-11 residues 45 to 60 (N.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Christensen, unpublished observations).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	82	J54 binding is most likely independent of region II, and because regions that are well separated in the linear L1 sequence can affect the secondary and tertiary structure of assembled VLPs, introduction of HPV-6-like amino acids at this site may distort one or more components of the J54 epitope.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	83	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Binding of HPV-6 mAbs to CRPV VLPs bearing HPV-6-like amino acid substitutions.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Baculovirus-expressed VLPs and control extracts (Sf9) were assayed by ELISA as previously described.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Assays were carried out in duplicate and the results are the average of assays of two independently derived clones for each mutant.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Error bars denote standard deviation.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	88	 H6 wt, wild-type HPV-6; H11 wt, wild-type HPV-11; CRPV wt, wild-type CRPV; CR/H6:I, CRPV with HPV-6-like substitutions in region I; CR/H6:I to II, CRPV with HPV-6-like substitutions in regions I and II.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	89	  These results suggested that the J54 type-common epitope overlapped the HPV-6-specific epitope and might share determinants.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	90	 To map the region I portion of J54 more precisely, we next made a series of alanine substitution mutants that scanned a 22-residue stretch centred on the critical binding region I (Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	91	J54 is cross-reactive with HPV-11, we selected charged or hydrophilic residues that were common to both HPV types and likely to contribute to antibody binding.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The mutant L1 proteins  to  R40A, S50A, K52A, N55A, T57A, P60A and K61A  to  were expressed and assayed for binding to H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	93	C6, which recognizes a distal linear epitope common to both type 6 and 11 (Ludmerer et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Binding results are shown in Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The signals with the conformation-dependent mAbs indicated that all mutants formed ordered structures and that region I was intact, although reduced binding of mAb H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	96	5 to the R40A, K52A and K61A mutants was observed.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	97	 While the relative binding of the four antibodies varied across the mutant set, the results from one mutation  to  N55A  to  stood out.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	98	J54 was completely lost but with little impairment of H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	99	 To assess the assembly state of this critical mutant, partially purified material from the N55A extract was characterized by transmission electron microscopy and was found to be indistinguishable from preparations of either wild-type or the T57A mutant; each showed the presence of 55 nm particles with the characteristic appearance of VLPs (data not shown).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	100	 We consider it likely that the N55A mutation has a direct effect and that residue 55 asparagine is critical for H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	101	N8 recognized this mutant VLP well, indicating that region I was not grossly distorted.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	102	5 seen with the R40A, K52A and K61A mutants suggests that these residues contribute to the region I type-specific epitope.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Taken together with the J54 epitope transfer to CRPV described above, these data confirm the overlap of the type-specific and type-common conformation-dependent epitopes.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	104	View larger version (25K):    Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Binding of HPV-6 mAbs to mutant HPV-6 VLPs.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	106	 VLPs from alanine scanning mutants of HPV-6 region I and control extracts (Sf9) were assayed by ELISA for binding to HPV-6-specific mAbs.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	107	 For the S50A, K52A, N55A and K61A mutants, the results are averages obtained from assays of two independently derived clones.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Error bars denote standard deviation.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	109	 H6 wt, wild-type HPV-6; alanine mutants as indicated.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	110	  These observations extend an earlier study describing the theoretical overlap of a linear epitope with a conformation-dependent one (Ludmerer et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The linear epitope, mapped to residues 108 to 127 of HPV-16 (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	112	, 1995), was transferred into HPV-11 VLPs by making HPV-16-like substitutions (V123L, V126T) at the two residues in that region where the HPV-16 and -11 L1 proteins differed.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	113	 In this hybrid VLP context, the linear HPV-16 epitope overlapped the HPV-11 major neutralizing epitope, which mapped to an approximately 20 amino acid sequence centred on residue 132.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Residue 123 was critical for each epitope but because it differed between the two types (L in HPV-16, Y in HPV-11) simultaneous presentation of both epitopes could not occur.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The present results are of greater significance because the epitopes exist simultaneously on the VLP and both are conformation-dependent, yet have distinguishable binding properties.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	116	J54 binding can be eliminated from HPV-6 without affecting the binding of the type-specific mAbs and it can be transferred into CRPV VLPs without reconstituting the epitopes for the other antibodies.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	117	 This suggests that alteration of epitope structure can be significant in impact, yet highly localized in effect.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	118	 This has important implications for HPV serology.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	119	 If cross-reactive responses between two closely related HPV types, for example types 16 and 31 or 18 and 45, hinder precise serological evaluation, hybrid VLPs can be made in which the cross-reactive responses are reduced or eliminated, thus creating serological typing reagents with improved sensitivity and selectivity.
