0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	451	 Plasmodesmata: gatekeepers for cell-to-cell transport of developmental signals in plants.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	0	Interaction of L2 with -Actin Directs Intracellular Transport of Papillomavirus and Infection* Rongcun Yang, William H.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Departments of  Pathology,   Pediatrics, and   Gynecology and Obstetrics, The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland 21205.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, August 23, 2002, and in revised form, January 23, 2003.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	4	Viruses that replicate in the nucleus, including the primary causative agent of cervical cancer, human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16), must first cross the cytoplasm.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We compared the uptake of HPV16 virus-like particles (VLPs) either with or without the minor capsid protein L2.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Whereas VLPs containing only the major capsid protein L1 were diffusely distributed within the cytoplasm even 6 h post-infection, VLPs comprising both L1 and L2 exhibited a radial distribution in the cytoplasm and accumulated in the perinuclear region of BPHE-1 cells within 2 h.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	7	 L2 of HPV16 or bovine papillomavirus was shown to bind to a 43-kDa cellular protein that was subsequently identified as -actin by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight analysis.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	8	 A conserved domain comprising residues 25-45 of HPV16 L2 was sufficient for interaction with -actin.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	9	 HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 fused to green fluorescent protein, but not green fluorescent protein alone, colocalized with actin and caused cell retraction and disruption of the microfilament network.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Finally, wild-type L2, but not L2 with residues 25-45 deleted, facilitated HPV16 pseudovirion infection.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Thus, binding of -actin by L2 residues 25-45 facilitates transport of HPV16 across the cytoplasm during infection, and blockade of this novel interaction may be useful for prophylaxis.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	12	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	13	Passive diffusion of molecules within the cytoplasm is limited by molecular crowding and does not provide targeting to a particular subcellular domain (1).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Thus, many intracellular pathogens subvert existing transport mechanisms and cytoskeletal components, both to efficiently reach their site of replication and also for the exit of their progeny (2).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The cytoskeleton is highly dynamic, and its role in locomotion is regulated by a plethora of actin- and tubulin-binding proteins, kinases, and phosphatases of multiple signaling cascades.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Changes in tyrosine phosphorylation of actin regulatory proteins induce the condensation of actin "comet" tails behind endosomes (3), as well as the bacteria Listeria, Shigella, and Rickettsia (4) and viruses including vaccinia, baculovirus, and SV40, for propulsion through the cytoplasm (5, 6).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Other viruses employ cellular motors such as dyneins and kinesins for transport along microtubules.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	18	 A single virus type can employ several intracellular transport mechanisms.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Indeed, vaccinia particles are driven along microtubules by kinesin, whereupon actin tails take over propulsion (7, 8).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	20	Compelling epidemiologic and molecular virologic studies demonstrate that infection with an oncogenic type human papillomavirus (HPV),1 typified by HPV16, is a necessary cause of cervical cancer (9).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In the absence of effective screening programs, cervical cancer is a leading cause of cancer death in women (10).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Furthermore, oncogenic HPV infection is also strongly associated with vulval, anal, and penile cancers, some non-melanoma skin cancers, and esophageal and salivary cancers (11).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	23	 An understanding of the infectious process is critical to rational development of approaches for prevention of HPV-related cancers.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Although several cellular molecules, including heparan sulfate glycosaminoglycans (12), 6 integrin (13), and CD16 (14), have been implicated as cell-surface receptors for papillomavirus, little else is known about cellular proteins that mediate cytoplasmic transport of papillomavirus and delivery of the viral genome to the nucleus.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	25	The papillomavirus capsid comprises the major capsid protein L1 arranged as 72 pentamers, or capsomers, in a T=7d icosahedral surface lattice (15, 16) and a minor capsid protein, L2 (17), one molecule of which may be located at each vertex (18).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Overexpression of L1 alone is sufficient to form empty capsids, termed virus-like particles (VLPs) (19).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	27	 L1 VLPs bind to cell surfaces and compete with bovine papillomavirus type 1 (BPV1) infection in vitro (20).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	28	 However, both L1 and L2 are necessary for efficient production of papillomavirus and infection (21-23).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Recent studies by Kawana et al.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	30	 (24, 25) suggest that residues 108-120 of L2 are displayed upon the virion exterior and bind to the cell surface, resulting in internalization.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Furthermore, anti-L2 antiserum neutralizes papillomavirus without preventing virion binding to the cell surface (26).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	32	 We recently demonstrated that L2 plays a critical role in infection, but is not required for interaction of papillomavirus particles with the cell surface (23).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Taken together, the data suggest that L1 mediates the initial binding of virions to the cell surface, whereas L2 provides later functions critical for infection.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	34	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	35	Preparation of Papillomavirus VLPs and L2-- VLPs containing L1 and L2, only L1, or L1 and L2 lacking residues 25-45 were generated by infection of Sf9 with recombinant baculoviruses and purified as previously reported (27).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The HPV16 L225-45 deletion mutant was prepared by two rounds of PCR using oligonucleotides CGCGGATCCATGCGACACAAACGTTCTGC and CCCATACTTCCATATTGTAACTGTTTGCATGTTTTATAAAG or TCCCCCCGGGCTAGGCAGCCAAAGAGAC and CTTTATAAAAACATGCAAACAGTTACAATATGGAAGTATGGG, followed by just the outside primers.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The quantity and quality of VLP preparations were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and electron microscopy, respectively.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	38	 His6-tagged BPV1 L2 fusion proteins were prepared as previously described (26).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	39	 For generation of glutathione S-transferase (GST)-tagged L2-green fluorescent protein (GFP) fusion proteins, L2 oligonucleotides with EcoRI and SalI overhangs were directly synthesized (HPV16 L2-(13-31), AATTCGCATCGGCTACCCAACTTTATAAAACATGCAAACAGGCAGGTACATGTCCACCTGACGG and TCGACCGTCAGGTGGACATGTACCTGCCTGTTTGCATGTTTTATAAAGTTGGGTAGCCGATGCG; HPV16 L2-(25-45), AATTCGCAGGTACATGTCCACCTGACATTATACCTAAGGTTGAAGGCAAAACTATTGCTGAT CAAATAGG and TCGACCTATTTGATCAGCAATAGTTTTGCCTTCAACCTTAGGTATAATGTCAGGTGGACATGTACCTGCG; HPV16 L2-(61-81), AATTCGGAACAGGGTCGGGTACAGGCGGACGCACTGGGTATATTCCATTGGGAACAAGGCCTCCCACAGG and TCGACCTGTGGGAGGCCTTGTTCCCAATGGAATATACCCAGTGCGTCCGCCTGTACCCGACCCTGTTCCG; and HPV16 L2-(108-126), AATTCTTAGTGGAAGAAACTAGTTTTATTGATGCTGGTGCACCAACATCTGTACCTTCCATCGG and TCGACCGATGGAAGGTACAGATGTTGGTGCACCAGCATCAATAAAACTAGTTTCTTCCACTAAG) or amplified by PCR using HPV16 L2-(1-128) (primers GCAGAATTCATGCGACACAAACGTTCTGCA and GCAGGTCGACTGGGGGAATGGAAGGTAC) and HPV16 L2-(299-333) (primers GCAGAATTCACTGGCATTAGGTACAGT and GCAGGTCGACTTCTTCTGCAGGATCAATAGT).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Expression of the recombinant GST-tagged proteins in Escherichia coli BL21 and their purification on a GSTrapTM FF column (Amersham Biosciences) were performed according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	41	Metabolic Labeling and Immunoprecipitation-- Cells were grown overnight in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium and 10% fetal calf serum containing 35S-radiolabeled methionine and cysteine (0.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	42	2 mCi/ml) and harvested in ice-cold buffer A (10 mM HEPES (pH 7), 1 mM EDTA, 0.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	43	1 mM EGTA, 10 mM KCl, 1 mM dithiothreitol, and 20 mM n-octyl -D-glucopyranoside with Complete  protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Molecular Biochemicals)).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The nuclei were removed by centrifugation at 12,000  x  g for 15 min at 4  degrees C, and the lysate was precleared with 100  microl of protein G-Sepharose and 20  microg/ml isotypic control antibody for 2 h at 4  degrees C.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	45	 After addition of His6- or GFP-tagged fusion protein, immunoprecipitation was performed with anti-His5 or anti-GFP monoclonal antibody, respectively, and protein G-Sepharose for 16 h at 4  degrees C with slow agitation.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The immunoprecipitates were washed six times with ice-cold lysis buffer and resolved by 10% SDS-PAGE.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	47	 After treating with 50% (v/v) methanol and 10% (v/v) acetic acid and then AmplifyTM (Amersham Biosciences) for 30 min, the gel was dried under vacuum at 60-80  degrees C, and the incorporated 35S was visualized by autoradiography.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	48	43-kDa Protein Purification and Identification-- GST-HPV16 L2-(1-128)-GFP was bound to a GSTrap FF column, and detergent extracts of 109 SiHa cells in buffer A were passed over the column.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	49	 After extensive washing, the column was eluted with 50 mM Tris-HCl and 10 mM reduced glutathione at pH 8.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Eluates were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and silver staining.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The 43-kDa protein band was excised and digested with TPCK-treated sequencing grade trypsin (Worthington) as previously described (28).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The masses of the resulting peptides were measured by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) analysis on a Voyager DE STR apparatus (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Positive ion mass spectra were analyzed using Data Explorer (Version 3.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Mass accuracy was better than 100 ppm.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	55	 -Actin was identified by using the monoisotopic masses acquired from the 43-kDa protein to search the NCBI Non-redundant Database using the MS-Fit search engine on the Protein Prospector Web site.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	56	Flow Cytometric Analysis of L2-GFP Binding-- After fixation for 5 min in 3.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	57	7% paraformaldehyde and phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), cells were permeabilized with 1% (v/v) Triton X-100 for 20 min.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The cells were incubated with the L2-GFP fusion protein for 1 h at room temperature, washed, and then analyzed by flow cytometry (FACScan, BD Biosciences).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	59	Transfection-- The HPV16 L2-(25-45) fragment was subcloned between the EcoRI and SalI restriction sites of pEGFP-C2 (Clontech).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The constructs were then transfected into COS-7 cells using LipofectAMINE 2000 (Invitrogen) according to the recommended protocol.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Three days after transfection, the cells were stained with rhodamine-phalloidin (Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	62	) and examined by confocal fluorescence microscopy (UltraView confocal imaging system, PerkinElmer Life Sciences).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	63	Indirect Immunofluorescence, Rhodamine-Phalloidin Staining, and Confocal Microscopy-- BPHE-1 cells were incubated with VLPs for 1 h at 4  degrees C in Dulbecco's PBS and then washed with medium at 37  degrees C.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	64	 At the time points indicated, the cells were washed with PBS, fixed with 3.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	65	7% formaldehyde solution for 10 min, permeabilized with 0.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	66	1% (v/v) Triton X-100 in PBS for 5 min, and blocked with PBS containing 1% bovine serum albumin for 30 min.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	67	V5 was used at 1:100 dilution for detection of HPV16 L1, and fluorescein isothiocyanate-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG (Sigma) was added at 5  microg/ml for 20 min at 4  degrees C.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Actin was stained with rhodamine-phalloidin.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Samples were examined by confocal fluorescence microscopy using a Nikon Eclipse TE 200 inverted microscope equipped with a  x 40 plan fluor or  x 60 or  x 100 plan apochromatic objective lens with a corresponding 1-, 0.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Twelve bit images were merged and analyzed with the UltraView acquisition software, RGB mode.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	71	Electron Microscopy-- HPV16 VLPs were bound to BPHE-1 cells for 1 h at 4  degrees C.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The cells were washed; shifted to 37  degrees C for 15 min; and then fixed in 2% glutaraldehyde, 0.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	73	05 M sodium cacodylate, and 3 mM CaCl2 (pH 7.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	74	4) for 30 min at room temperature with gentle rocking.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	75	8% potassium ferrocyanide in buffer for 15 min on ice, the cells were dehydrated with a graded series of ethanol and embedded in Eponate 12 (Ted Pella, Inc.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	76	15% tannic acid for 1 min, rinsed, and then stained en bloc in uranyl acetate for 2 h in the dark.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The sections were cut and examined with a Phillips CM120 transmission electron microscope operating at 80 kV.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	78	Generation and Infectivity of HPV16 Pseudovirions-- HPV16 pseudovirions were generated, and their infectivity was assayed as described previously (22).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The HPV16 L225-45 deletion mutant was prepared as described for the generation of HPV16 particles.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The resulting DNA was inserted into the BamHI and XmaI restriction sites of pSFV4.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	81	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	82	L2 Facilitates Perinuclear Trafficking-- To further define the role of L2 in the infectious process, we compared the binding, uptake, and intracellular transport of HPV16 VLPs containing both L1 and L2 (L1/L2 VLPs) with VLPs comprising only L1 (L1 VLPs) (27) in the permissive cell line BPHE-1 (29).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	83	 HPV16 VLPs were incubated with BPHE-1 cells for 1 h at 4  degrees C and visualized by indirect immunofluorescence.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	84	 As we previously demonstrated (20), VLPs comprising L1 and L2 or only L1 bound to cell surfaces with a similar pattern and degree (data not shown).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Upon shifting to 37  degrees C for 15 min to initiate synchronized uptake, the cells were fixed, sectioned, and examined by transmission electron microscopy.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	86	 No differences were noted in the cellular ultrastructure of plasma membrane-associated L1 VLPs (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	87	 1, A1 and A2) or L1/L2 VLPs (B1 and B2) or their engulfment by invagination of the plasma membrane (A2 and B2).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	88	 At 30 min and 1, 2, and 6 h after shifting the BPHE-1 cells to 37  degrees C, the VLPs were localized (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	89	 2) by indirect immunofluorescence using the HPV16 L1-specific, conformationally dependent, neutralizing monoclonal antibody H16.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Interestingly, L1/L2 VLPs aligned along distinct radial tracks across the cytoplasm and within ~2 h at 37  degrees C arrived in the perinuclear region (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	91	 However, L1 VLPs were not aligned along such radial tracks.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Rather, L1 VLPs remained widely distributed throughout the whole cell and showed a less clear-cut tropism toward the nucleus during this 6-h time course (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	93	 These differences in the uptake of L1/L2 and L1 VLPs suggest that L2 contributes to the transport of virions across the cytoplasm.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (123K):    Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	95	   Ultrastructural analysis of L1/L2 and L1 VLP uptake into BPHE-1 cells.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	96	 HPV16 VLPs were bound to BPHE-1 cells for 1 h at 4  degrees C.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The cells were washed; shifted to 37  degrees C for 15 min (A1, A2, B1, and B2) or 30 min (B3-B5); and then fixed in 2% glutaraldehyde, 0.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	98	05 M sodium cacodylate, and 3 mM CaCl2 (pH 7.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	99	4) for 30 min at room temperature with gentle rocking.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	100	8% potassium ferrocyanide in buffer for 15 min on ice, the cells were dehydrated with a graded series of ethanol and embedded in Eponate 12 overnight.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	101	15% tannic acid for 1 min, rinsed, and then stained en bloc in uranyl acetate for 2 h in the dark.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The sections were cut and examined with a Phillips CM120 transmission electron microscope operating at 80 kV.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	103	 A1 and A2, binding and engulfment of L1 VLPs; B1 and B2, binding and engulfment of L1/L2 VLPs; B3, L1/L2 VLPs bound to the surface of BPHE-1 cells (arrow 1), particles within a vesicle that exhibits pinching (arrow 2), and particles free in the cytoplasm (arrow 3); B4, fine filaments radiating from L1/L2 VLPs in the cytoplasm; B5, a fine filament emanating from L1/L2 VLPs toward a microtubule (arrow 1) and a microtubule (arrow 2).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	104	View larger version (67K):    Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	105	   L2 promotes rapid transport across the cytoplasm and radial distribution of VLPs.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Subconfluent BPHE-1 cells were incubated with 10  microg of HPV16 VLPs comprising L1/L2 (A panels), L1 alone (B panels), or L1 and L2 lacking residues 25-45 (C panels) for 1 h at 4  degrees C and then shifted to 37  degrees C for various times.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The cells were fixed at 30 min (A1-C1), 1 h (A2-C2), and 2 h (A3-C3), respectively, with 3.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	108	7% formaldehyde solution for 10 min, permeabilized with 0.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	109	1% (v/v) Triton X-100 in PBS for 5 min, and blocked with PBS containing 1% bovine serum albumin for 30 min.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Murine monoclonal antibody H16.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	111	V5 was used at 1:100 dilution for detection of HPV16 L1, and fluorescein isothiocyanate-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG (green) was added at 5  microg/ml for 20 min at 4  degrees C.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Actin was stained with rhodamine-phalloidin (red).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Samples were examined by confocal fluorescence microscopy (UltraView confocal imaging system).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	114	 D, cytochalasin B at 10  microM depolymerizes actin and prevents the uptake of L1/L2 VLPs into cells; E, actins in a normal BPHE-1 cell; F, localization of -tubulin (red) and L1 VLPs (green) at 2 h after shifting to physiologic temperature.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	115	Because the cytoskeleton provides a framework for intracellular transport and L1/L2 VLPs exhibited a radial distribution (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	116	 2, A1 and A2) during transit to the perinuclear region, we determined the subcellular localization of cytoskeletal components during VLP uptake.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	117	 (32) observed an interaction between L1 and tubulin, as well as blockade of particle uptake by the microtubule-depolymerizing agent nocodazole.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Thus, we examined the relative localization of HPV16 L1 VLPs and tubulin by immunofluorescent staining.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	119	 However, limited overlap of L1 VLP and tubulin signals was noted 2 h after uptake (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Cytochalasin B both disrupted the microfilament network by depolymerizing actin (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	121	 2, compare D and E) and inhibited uptake of HPV16 L1 (data not shown) and L1/L2 (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	122	 2D) VLPs, consistent with previous studies (33).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Therefore, we compared the localization of actin (using rhodamine-phalloidin) and VLPs during their uptake.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Upon their initial uptake, the VLPs colocalized with cortical actin at the periphery of the cell.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	125	 At later time points, the radially distributed L1/L2 VLPs colocalized with actin filaments (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	126	 2A2), whereas little overlap was observed for L1 VLPs and actin (compare A and B panels).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Thus, actin polymerization is critical early in VLP uptake, and the particles colocalize with actin microfilaments while traversing the cytoplasm.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Although other viruses, including the structurally related SV40, induce the formation of actin comet tails (34), this phenomenon was not observed during HPV16 VLP uptake, suggesting a different mode of transport.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	129	Residues 25-45 of L2 Bind -Actin-- BPV1 is frequently exploited in virologic studies because, unlike HPVs (35), BPV can be readily prepared in milligram quantities, and its infectivity can be readily assayed in vitro (36).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	130	 To identify cellular "targeting molecule(s)" recognized by L2, we generated in E.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	131	 coli six His6-tagged polypeptides spanning residues 1-88, 45-173, 130-257, 216-340, 300-425, and 384-469 that together encompass the entire open reading frame of BPV1 L2 (26).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	132	 These polypeptides were each incubated with [35S]methionine/cysteine-radiolabeled SiHa cell lysates (data not shown) or HeLa cell lysates and immunoprecipitated with a monoclonal antibody specific for their tag.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	133	 BPV1 L2 residues 1-88 co-immunoprecipitated with a cellular protein of ~43 kDa, whereas the other fragments, including the overlapping BPV1 L2 peptide comprising amino acids 45-173, did not (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	134	 This implies that residues 1-45 of L2 mediate binding to a 43-kDa cellular protein.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	135	View larger version (37K):    Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	136	   The conserved N terminus of BPV1 and HPV16 L2 binds to the 43-kDa cellular protein.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	137	 A, detergent lysates of 35S-radiolabeled HeLa cells were subjected to centrifugation at 12,000  x  g for 15 min at 4  degrees C and precleared with 100  microl of protein G-Sepharose and 20  microg/ml isotypic control (contr.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	138	) antibody for 2 h at 4  degrees C.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	139	 After addition of His6-tagged BPV1 L2 fragments comprising the residues indicated, immunoprecipitation was performed with His5-specific monoclonal antibody and protein G-Sepharose for 16 h at 4  degrees C with slow agitation.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The immunoprecipitates were washed six times with ice-cold lysis buffer and resolved by 10% SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	141	 B, purified GST-GFP alone (GFP) or fused to HPV16 L2 residues 1-128 (1-128) was incubated with 35S-radiolabeled and precleared SiHa cell lysates and immunoprecipitated using monoclonal antibody to GFP or isotype-matched control antibody.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	142	 C, coprecipitation was performed as described for B, but using GST-GFP fused to different regions of HPV16 L2.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	143	 D, HeLa cell lysate in ice-cold buffer A was clarified by centrifugation at 16,000  x  g for 30 min and passed over glutathione-Sepharose precoated with GST-GFP either alone or fused to HPV16 L2 residues 25-45, 1-128, or 299-333 or with GST fused to full-length HPV16 L2.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	144	 After extensive washing, the bound proteins were eluted with 50 mM Tris-HCl and 10 mM reduced glutathione (pH 8.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	145	0) and analyzed by Western blotting with mouse anti--actin monoclonal antibody (AC-15, Sigma).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	146	 E, purified GST-GFP alone or fused to HPV16 L2 fragment 25-45 or control fragment 299-333 was incubated with purified rabbit muscle actin in PBS for 1 h and then passed through a GSTrap FF column.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	147	 After extensive washing, the bound proteins were eluted and visualized by SDS-PAGE and Coomassie staining.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	148	Unlike the C-terminal sequence, the first ~120 amino acids of L2 are well conserved among the  > 70 known papillomavirus genotypes.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	149	 To examine whether the N-terminal domain of L2 derived from other papillomavirus genotypes is also able bind to this 43-kDa cellular protein, we next generated in E.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	150	 coli a chimera comprising GST fused in-frame to amino acids 1-128 of HPV16 L2 and GFP to form GST-HPV16 L2-(1-128)-GFP.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The purified fusion protein was incubated with [35S]methionine/cysteine-radiolabeled SiHa cell lysates and immunoprecipitated using a monoclonal antibody to GFP.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The GST-HPV16 L2-(1-128)-GFP (but not GST-GFP) fusion protein also bound to the 43-kDa cellular protein (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	153	 3B), showing that this interaction is conserved in two evolutionarily distant papillomavirus types, BPV1 and HPV16.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	154	 When testing smaller N-terminal subfragments of HPV16 L2, only residues 25-45 co-immunoprecipitated with the 43-kDa cellular protein from detergent lysates of radiolabeled SiHa cells (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	155	 3C), suggesting that this motif is sufficient for interaction.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	156	To determine the distribution of the cellular protein that interacts with the HPV16 L2-GFP fusion protein, we examined, by confocal fluorescence microscopy (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	157	4), the binding to detergent-permeabilized human cervical carcinoma-derived cell lines of GST-GFP chimeric proteins either with or without HPV16 L2 residues 1-128.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Whereas the GST-GFP fusion protein failed to bind to SiHa cells, GFP fusion proteins containing either residues 1-128 or 25-45 of HPV16 L2 bound to a similar extent within the cytoplasm of the detergent-permeabilized SiHa cells (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	159	 To eliminate the possible effects of GST in the binding of the fusion protein to cells, the GST-HPV16 L2-GFP fusion proteins were digested with PreScission protease (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Thus, the binding to SiHa cells of PreScission protease-digested (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	161	4) GST-HPV16 L2-(25-45)-GFP fusion protein was compared.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	162	 L2-GFP (but not GFP alone) bound to SiHa cells to a similar extent either with or without GST, indicating that neither GST nor GFP mediates binding.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Flow cytometric analysis showed that HPV16 L2 residues 1-128 bound to both HPV-positive cervical carcinoma-derived cell lines HeLa (data not shown) and SiHa (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	164	2) to a similar extent as the HPV-negative human cervical carcinoma-derived cell line C33A (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	165	4), indicating that HPV16 L2 binds to a cytoplasmic component that is not derived from papillomavirus.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	166	View larger version (43K):    Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	167	   Residues 25-45 of HPV16 L2 bind to a non-viral component of the cytoplasm.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	168	4) cervical carcinoma-derived cell lines were washed with PBS, fixed with 3.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	169	7% paraformaldehyde, and then permeabilized with 1% (v/v) Triton X-100 for 20 min.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The cells were incubated for 1 h at room temperature with purified fusion protein comprising GST-GFP alone (A1.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	171	3) or fused to residues 1-128 of HPV16 L2 (A1.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	172	4), washed, and examined by confocal fluorescence microscopy (A1 panels; scale bars = 10  microm) or flow cytometry (A2 panels).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	173	 B1, GST-GFP fusion proteins containing various HPV16 L2 fragments (shown for residues 25-45) were affinity-purified, digested with PreScission protease (PreS.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	174	P), and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Coomassie staining.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	175	2, the binding of GFP alone and the HPV16 L2-(25-45)-GFP fragment, respectively, to SiHa cells was detected by laser scanning confocal microscopy.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	176	4, the binding of the HPV16 L2-(25-45)-GFP fragment to SiHa cells is independent of the GST tag.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Shown are the results from flow cytometric analysis of the binding to SiHa cells of PreScission protease-digested (B3.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	178	4) GFP-GST fusion protein either lacking (B3.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	179	To identity the 43-kDa cellular protein, a detergent lysate of SiHa cells was passed over a GST-HPV16 L2-(1-128)-GFP-coated column.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	180	 After extensive washing, the proteins bound were eluted and visualized by SDS-PAGE and silver staining (data not shown).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The 43-kDa protein band recovered was excised and subjected to in-gel trypsin digestion and MALDI-TOF analysis.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	182	 This analysis resulted in the identification of 13 peptides whose protein sequences were all consistent with -actin (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	183	View larger version (35K):    Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	184	   Tryptic mass fingerprint identifies the 43-kDa band as -actin.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	185	 A, the 43-kDa protein band that bound to residues 1-128 of HPV16 L2 was excised and digested with TPCK-treated sequencing grade trypsin as previously described (28).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Masses of the resulting peptides were measured by MALDI-TOF analysis on a Voyager DE STR apparatus.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Positive ion mass spectra were analyzed using Data Explorer (Version 3.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Mass accuracy was better than 100 ppm.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	189	 B, the predicted and measured peptide masses are listed.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	190	 -Actin was identified by using the acquired monoisotopic masses to search the NCBI Non-redundant Database using the MS-Fit search engine on the Protein Prospector Web site (see Footnote 2).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	191	Because peptides of L2 were used for the actin binding experiments, it is possible that the truncations resulted in exposure on a nonphysiologic cryptic epitope.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	192	 To demonstrate interaction between full-length L2 and actin, a detergent lysate of HeLa cells was passed over glutathione-Sepharose beads precoated with GST fused to full-length HPV16 L2.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The bound proteins were separated by electrophoresis and subjected to Western blot analysis using a mouse monoclonal antibody to -actin (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Full-length HPV16 L2 and its fragments 1-128 and 25-45 bound to actin, whereas fragment 299-333 and the GFP control did not (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Thus, binding to actin is a property of full-length L2.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	196	It is unclear whether L2 binds directly to actin.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Therefore, to address this question, purified GST-GFP fusion proteins containing HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 or, as a negative control, residues 299-333 were incubated for 1 h at ambient temperature with actin purified from rabbit muscle (A-2522, Sigma).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Upon pull-down with glutathione-Sepharose, actin copurified with the GST-GFP fusion protein containing residues 25-45 (but not residues 299-333) of HPV16 L2 (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	199	 This observation strongly supports the existence of a direct interaction between HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 and actin.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	200	L2 Residues 25-45 Are Necessary for Efficient Transport to the Perinuclear Region and HPV16 Infection-- Studies in other viral systems suggest that interaction with actin can facilitate the intracellular transport of viral particles and infection.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Therefore, to address the biologic significance of the putative actin-binding domain in HPV16 L2, we compared the uptake of HPV16 VLPs comprising wild-type L1 alone, L1 and L2, and L1 and L2 with residues 25-45 deleted (L1/L225-45).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Whereas wild-type HPV16 L1/L2 VLPs were rapidly transported to the perinuclear region along radial tracts (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	203	 2A1), L1/L2 VLPs lacking residues 25-45 failed to align along radial tracts in the cytoplasm and did not reach the perinuclear region during a 6-h time course (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Rather, L1/L225-45 VLPs remained widely distributed throughout the cell as described for L1 VLPs (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	205	Because papillomavirus exhibits a high particle to infectivity ratio in vitro (22), it is possible that the uptake of HPV16 VLPs shown in Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	206	 1 does not represent the true infectious pathway.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Therefore, to examine the significance of this interaction between L2 and -actin to the infectious process, we generated HPV16 pseudovirions lacking the conserved -actin-binding domain, viz.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	208	 6A), and tested their infectivity using a previously described system.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Briefly, the hamster fibroblast cell line BPHE-1 harbors 50-200 episomal copies of the bovine papillomavirus genome/cell (29), but it produces no virus because the L1 and L2 genes are not expressed.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	210	 However, ectopic expression of HPV16 L1 and L2 in BPHE-1 cells via infection with recombinant defective Semliki Forest viruses results in the generation of infectious HPV16 pseudovirions containing the BPV genome within capsids formed of HPV16 L1 and L2 (22).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Like native BPV1 virions, the infectivity of HPV16 {BPV1} pseudovirions can readily be quantified using the in vitro focal transformation of mouse C127 cells (36).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	212	 HPV16 pseudovirions lacking residues 25-45 of L2 showed dramatically reduced infectivity (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	213	 6), suggesting that interaction between L2 and -actin indeed plays a critical role in the infectious process of papillomavirus.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	214	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	215	   L2 residues 25-45 are required for efficient HPV16 pseudovirion infection.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	216	 A, the putative actin-binding motif (residues 25-45 of HPV16 L2) is highly conserved among the different papillomavirus types.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	217	 EEPV, European Elk Papillomavirus; RhPV, Rhesus papillomavirus.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	218	 B, shown is the effect of the L225-45 deletion mutation on infection of C127 cells by HPV16 pseudovirions.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	219	 HPV16 pseudovirions were generated in BPHE-1 cells, and their infectivity was assayed as described previously (22).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The presence of infectious HPV16 pseudovirions in extracts of BPHE-1 cells expressing wild-type HPV16 L1 and L2 (L1+L2), L1 and L2 lacking residues 25-45 (L1+L2(25+45)), or L1 alone was assessed using the focus forming assay in monolayers of C127 cells and compared with untreated control (Contr.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Mouse C127 cells were maintained for 3 weeks in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal calf serum.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The plates were stained with 0.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	223	25% (w/v) carbol fuchsin in methanol to highlight transformed foci for counting.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	224	 C, foci counted in four experiments are plotted.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	225	Cytoplasmic Overexpression of HPV16 L2 Residues 25-45 Disrupts the Actin Architecture-- Actin is one of most abundant proteins in eukaryotic cells, and its role as a primary determinant of cell shape, cytoplasmic structure, and locomotion is highly regulated by a plethora of binding proteins.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Given the ability of L2 to bind to actin and the karyophilic nature of full-length L2, we hypothesized that an overabundance of L2 within the cytoplasm might induce changes in the cytoskeleton and cell morphology.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	227	 To test this hypothesis, the fragment of HPV16 L2 encoding residues 25-45 was inserted 3' of the GFP gene in the mammalian expression vector pEGFP-C2 to form pEGFP-L2-(25-45).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	228	 COS-7 cells were transfected with either pEGFP-C2 or pEGFP-L2-(25-45).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Three days after transfection, equivalent expression of GFP alone and fused to HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 was confirmed by Western blot analysis with a monoclonal antibody to GFP (data not shown).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The subcellular localization of actin (upon staining with rhodamine-phalloidin) and either GFP alone or fused to HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 was examined by confocal fluorescence microscopy.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Transient expression of GFP fused to HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 within the cytoplasm of COS-7 cells induced a dramatic retraction of transfected cells from the culture surface (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	232	 In contrast, expression of GFP alone in the transfected cells did not noticeably influence cell morphology (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	233	 7A1) compared with the parental untransfected cells (data not shown).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Interestingly, staining revealed apparent reorganization of filamentous actin into cytoplasmic bundles, which colocalized with the GFP fusion proteins containing HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	235	 GFP did not significantly colocalize with actin staining even in dividing cells that had retracted from the culture dish (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Thus, cytoplasmic overexpression of the actin-binding domain of HPV16 L2 is sufficient to induce retraction of COS-7 cells and actin reorganization.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	237	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	238	   Expression of HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 in COS-7 cells alters cell morphology and actin structure.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	239	 COS-7 cells in two-well chamber slides were transfected using LipofectAMINE 2000 with 1  microg of plasmid vector pEGFP encoding GFP (A panels) or pEGFP-L2-(25-45) encoding GFP fused to HPV16 L2 residues 25-45 (B panels).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	240	 After 3 days, the cells were stained with rhodamine-phalloidin and analyzed by confocal microscopy.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	241	 A1 and B1, phase-contrast light microscopy; A2 and B2, GFP fluorescence; A3 and B3, actin stained with rhodamine-phalloidin; A4 and B4, overlays of fluorescence channels.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	242	Furthermore, we examined, by transmission electron microscopy, sections of BPHE-1 cells 30 min after addition of HPV16 VLPs for the association of intracellular L1/L2 or L1 particles with actin microfilament-like structures.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	243	 1B3 shows surface-bound HPV16 L1/L2 VLPs, large groups of particles within vesicles, and individual particles free in the cytoplasm.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The majority of 50 HPV16 L1/L2 VLPs present in the cytoplasm were associated with fine filamentous structures whose width is consistent with that of actin microfilaments.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	245	 HPV16 L1/L2 VLPs occasionally formed "star-like" structures (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	246	 1B4) with fine filaments radiating from the capsid surface or a halo around the particle in the dense cortical actin (data not shown), suggestive of actin rearrangement.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	247	 1B5, arrow 1) that seemed to link HPV16 L1/L2 particles to microtubules (arrow 2) were also found.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	248	 However, we did not observe such structures in association with 50 L1 VLPs free in the cytoplasm of BPHE-1 cells (data not shown).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	249	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	250	During the infectious process, an intracellular pathogen hijacks the normal cellular function of its receptor molecules for transportation to its site of replication.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Thus, study of such infectious pathways can both enhance our understanding of normal cellular transport as well as identify targets for intervention.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Although intracellular pathogens use diverse primary and secondary receptors to gain entry to the cell, the mechanisms employed for intracellular transport are more restricted.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	253	 For example, microorganisms as diverse as Listeria, Shigella, Rickettsia, vaccinia, and SV40 employ different receptors to gain entry to a cell, but a similar mode of intracellular transport (6, 34).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	254	 However, despite their structural similarity to SV40 (18), the papillomaviruses use a distinct cell-surface receptor and entry pathway, about which little is known.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Indeed, three different surface molecules (12-14) have been proposed to bind to the major capsid protein L1 and to function as the primary receptor for papillomavirus.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Papillomavirus L1 pseudovirions prepared in vitro are infectious, although significantly less so than those containing L2 (38-40).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	257	 We have provided genetic evidence that L2 also plays a critical role during papillomavirus infection, but after the initial binding of the particle to the cell surface (23).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	258	 By virtue of its ability to bind to and enter cells, L2 was recently proposed to bind to a secondary viral receptor and to facilitate uptake (24).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The inability of L1 VLPs to enter the nucleus (41) and the importance of the DNA-binding and karyophilic domains of L2 to the infectious process suggest that interaction of L2 with the viral genome may play a key role in its delivery to the nucleus (23, 42).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	260	The high local protein concentration (as high as 300 mg/ml), organelles, and the cytoskeleton contribute to the molecular crowding within a cell that restricts the free diffusion of molecules of  > 500 kDa (1).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Because the papillomavirus capsid is 55 nm in diameter and  > 2000 kDa, its free diffusion within the cell will be extremely slow (15).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	262	 During infection, the virus needs to rapidly traffic to the nucleus, the site of viral replication, rather than to other organelles such as lysosomes.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	263	 To efficiently transport particles across the cytoplasm during infection, residues 25-45 of HPV16 L2 bind to -actin, and this interaction influences microfilament structure.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	264	 However, understanding the mechanism of locomotion requires further investigation.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	265	The high degree of sequence conservation of the L2 motif (Fig.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	266	 6A) and the ability of both BPV1 and HPV16 L2 to bind actin suggest that this interaction is common to other papillomavirus genotypes and therefore may represent a useful target for the development of pan-papillomavirus-preventative treatments.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Indeed, antibody to L2 (but not L1) neutralizes diverse papillomavirus genotypes, suggesting that a conserved functional domain of L2 is displayed on the capsid surface (25, 43).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Furthermore, L2-specific neutralizing antibodies predominantly recognize its N terminus and do not prevent virions from binding to the cell surface (26), suggesting that neutralization may occur by a blockade of virion uptake or intracellular transport.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	269	Several pathogens have independently evolved mechanisms to harness the power of actin polymerization to get into and out of cells (34).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Indeed, the entry of a wide variety of viruses, including papillomavirus, human immunodeficiency virus, vaccinia, Autographa californica M nucleopolyhedrovirus, adenovirus type 2, and echoviruses, is dependent upon actin polymerization as demonstrated by blockade with the inhibitor cytochalasin D (44).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	271	 However, this does not necessarily reflect a direct interaction between the virus and actin because actin function is necessary for receptor-mediated endocytosis and many other cellular processes.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	272	 californica M nucleopolyhedrovirus induces the formation of thick actin cables that frequently project toward the nucleus.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	273	 These actin cables are transiently formed in association with the viral nucleocapsids prior to viral gene expression and concomitantly with nucleocapsid transport to the nucleus (45).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Two virus-encoded capsid proteins, p39 and p78/83, in A.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	275	 californica M nucleopolyhedrovirus were found to bind to actin directly and therefore could be involved in the observed acceleration of actin polymerization by viral actin-binding proteins (46).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	276	 It is unclear how this effect relates to the changes in actin structure produced by overexpression of L2 residues 25-45 within the cytoplasm because neither papillomavirus L1/L2 VLPs nor L2 induces such actin cables.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	277	Both endosomes and diverse pathogens are able to recruit host cytoskeletal factors to induce the polymerization of actin filaments from their surface into a structure known as a comet tail for intracellular propulsion (34).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	278	 However, the presence of L2 or L1/L2 VLPs during infection did not promote the formation of such actin comet tails, suggesting that interaction of L2 with -actin facilitates particle transport by another mechanism.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	279	Actin is an ATPase, and ATP hydrolysis affects the kinetics of polymerization (47).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	280	 In vivo, actin polymerization is a highly regulated process controlled both by ATP binding and hydrolysis and by the action of a number of actin-binding proteins that initiate, cleave, cross-link, stabilize, or destabilize the filaments (48).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Actin comet tails result from a depolymerization of filamentous actin and re-polymerization behind the particle (34).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Interestingly, overexpression of the -actin-binding motif comprising residues 25-45 of HPV16 L2 in the cytoplasm was associated with the redistribution of actin in COS-7 cells and altered cell morphology.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	283	 This is consistent with a functional interaction between L2 and actin in vivo that orchestrates the intracellular motility of papillomavirus during infection.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	284	In addition to promoting uptake, the actin cytoskeleton facilitates egress of vaccinia from infected cells (8, 34).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The spread of vaccinia is enhanced by actin tail formation that is triggered via tyrosine phosphorylation of A36R.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Herpesvirus type 1 VP22 exploits microfilaments to promote intercellular spreading (49).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Furthermore, interaction of the Black Creek Canal virus N protein with actin microfilaments is required for virion morphogenesis and release, but not infection (50).
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	288	 However, papillomavirus accumulates in microcrystalline arrays within the nucleus of productively infected cells, and there is currently no evidence for such an egress pathway mediated by L2-actin interaction.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Wu (The Johns Hopkins University) and Andrew Lewis (Food and Drug Administration) for donating cell lines; Neil D.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Christensen (Pennsylvania State University) for antibody H16.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Cole for assistance in protein identification; the Mass Spectrometry Facility of The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine; Mike Delannoy (Microscopy Facility, The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine) for expert confocal and electron microscopy; Hung Chien-Fu and Lin Ken-Yu for discussion on molecular biotechnology; Liang-Mei He for technical assistance; and Drs.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Wu and Douglas Robinson (The Johns Hopkins University) and John T.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Lowy (National Cancer Institute) for providing critiques during the preparation of this manuscript.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	294	* This work was supported by Grants AI48203 and CA83706 from the National Institutes of Health the Cancer Research Institute, and by American Cancer Society Grant RSG MBC-103111 (to R.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	295	 The work performed at the Mass Spectrometry Facility of The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine was supported by National Center for Research Resources Shared Instrumentation Grant 1S10-RR14702 and the Johns Hopkins Fund for Medical Discovery.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	296	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	297	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	299	To whom correspondence should be addressed: Dept.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	300	 of Pathology, The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Ross 512B, 720 Rutland Ave.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	301	: 410-502-5161; Fax: 443-287-4295; E-mail: roden@jhmi.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	302	Published, JBC Papers in Press, January 30, 2003, DOI 10.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	303	The abbreviations used are: HPV, human papillomavirus; VLP, virus-like particle; BPV, bovine papillomavirus; GST, glutathione S-transferase; GFP, green fluorescent protein; TPCK, L-1-tosylamido-2-phenylethyl chloromethyl ketone; MALDI-TOF, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline.
0.37472588.12560332.html.plaintext.txt	304	    REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES 1.
