0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	0	  The Rockefeller University Press, 0021-9525/2002/6/1223 $5.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 The Journal of Cell Biology, Volume 157, Number 7, June 24, 2002 1223-1232 Article.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	2	L1 endocytosis is controlled by a phosphorylation-dephosphorylation cycle stimulated by outside-in signaling by L1 Andrew W.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Schaefer1, Yoshimasa Kamei1, Hiroyuki Kamiguchi1, Eric V.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Wong1, Iris Rapoport6,7, Tomas Kirchhausen6,7, Carol M.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Beach5, Gary Landreth1, Sandra K.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	6	1 Department of Neurosciences, School of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106 2 Department of Molecular Biology and Microbiology, School of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106 3 Department of Ophthalmology, School of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106 4 Cancer Center, School of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106 5 Macromolecular Structural Analysis Facility, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY 40536 6 Department of Cell Biology, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA 02115 7 The Center for Blood Research, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA 02115.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	7	Address correspondence to Vance Lemmon, Department of Neurosciences, Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine, Rm.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	8	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Dynamic regulation of the cell surface expression of adhesion molecules is an important mechanism for controlling neuronal growth cone motility and guidance.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Clathrin-mediated vesicular internalization of L1 via the tyrosine-based endocytosis motif YRSL regulates adhesion and signaling by this Ig superfamily molecule.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Here, we present evidence that tyrosine-1176 (Y1176) of the YRSL motif is phosphorylated in vivo.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The nonreceptor tyrosine kinase (p60src) is implicated in L1-mediated neurite outgrowth, and we find that p60src phosphorylates Y1176 in vitro.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Phosphorylation of Y1176 prevents L1 binding to AP-2, an adaptor required for clathrin-mediated internalization of L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	13	 mAb 74-5H7 recognizes the sequence immediately NH2-terminal to the tyrosine-based motif and binds L1 only when Y1176 is dephosphorylated.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	14	 74-5H7 identifies a subset of L1 present at points of cell to cell contact and in vesicle-like structures that colocalize with an endocytosis marker.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	15	 L1 to L1 binding or L1 cross-linking induces a rapid increase in 74-5H7 immunoreactivity.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Our data suggest a model in which homophilic binding or L1 cross-linking triggers transient dephosphorylation of the YRSL motif that makes L1 available for endocytosis.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Thus, the regulation of L1 endocytosis through dephosphorylation of Y1176 is a critical regulatory point of L1-mediated adhesion and signaling.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	18	Key Words: IGSF protein; cell adhesion; growth cones; endocytosis; tyrosine-based sorting motifs.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	19	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   The immunoglobulin superfamily cell adhesion molecule (IgSF CAM) L1 participates in several processes that are essential for the normal development of the nervous system.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Processes such as neurite extension and neuronal migration require dynamic regulation of the cell adhesion mediated by L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	21	 This is controlled in part by internalization of L1 to regulate the availability of L1 on the cell surface.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	22	 L1 internalization is controlled by interactions of its cytoplasmic domain with signaling, cytoskeletal, and internalization machinery (Long and Lemmon, 2000).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	23	The L1 cytoplasmic domain (L1CD)* is not required for adhesion, but it is needed for regulation of adhesion by signal transduction and internalization.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Interestingly, mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the human L1 gene impair the formation of major axon tracts in neural development (for review see Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	25	 One important function of the L1CD that has been analyzed in detail is the regulation of endocytosis, intracellular trafficking, and cell surface distribution of L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Neuronal L1 differs from L1 found in nonneuronal cells such as Schwann cells and neuroblastoma cell lines in that it contains four amino acids (RSLE) in the cytoplasmic domain encoded by the alternatively spliced exon 28 (Miura et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The RSLE stretch immediately follows tyrosine 1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The composite sequence (YRSLE) forms a tyrosine-based sorting motif that is required for endocytosis of L1 via clathrin-coated pits (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Like tyrosine-based sorting signals characterized in other proteins (Ohno et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	30	, 1996), the YRSLE sequence found in L1 serves as a binding site for the  micro2 chain of the clathrin-associated AP-2 complex in vitro, and a number of endocytic machinery components can be coimmunoprecipitated with L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Furthermore, mutating tyrosine 1176 (Y1176) or removing the RSLE exon also prevents L1 from interacting with AP-2, and consequently prevents clathrin-mediated endocytosis of L1 (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons growing on an L1-Fc substrate, clathrin-mediated endocytosis of L1 occurs preferentially at the rear of growth cones, suggesting local regulation of L1 endocytosis and that its recycling may be important in growth cone motility (Kamiguchi and Lemmon, 2000).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Indeed, blocking AP-2 to mediated internalization of L1 inhibits L1-based neurite growth in part by disrupting a gradient of L1 adhesivity from the growth cone periphery to the central domain (Kamiguchi and Yoshihara, 2001).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Finally, the neuronal form of L1 (with YRSLE) is significantly less adhesive than the nonneuronal form due to its more rapid internalization and shorter dwell time on the cell surface (Long et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	35	Phosphorylation is likely to play a critical role in regulating L1-mediated processes such as neurite outgrowth (Atashi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	36	 L1 is phosphorylated on both serine and tyrosine residues in cultured neurons, and clustering of L1 on cultured cells with cross-linking antibodies can trigger changes in both kinase and phosphatase activity (Klinz et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	37	, 1999), as well as in the phosphorylation state of L1 (Zisch et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Several kinase activities coimmunoprecipitate with L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	39	 We have identified three L1-associated kinases, CKII, p90rsk, and ERK2, that can phosphorylate certain serine residues in the L1CD in vitro (Wong et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Inhibition of p90rsk phosphorylation of L1 impairs DRG neurite outgrowth on L1 but not on laminin substrates.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Furthermore, activation of the MAP kinase cascade, which includes p90rsk and ERK2, requires L1 endocytosis.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Tyrosine kinases, such as p60src and FGF receptor, have also been implicated in L1 signaling (Ignelzi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	43	, 1994; Doherty and Walsh, 1996), and the receptor tyrosine kinase, EphB2, is capable of phosphorylating L1 (Zisch et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Tyrosine phosphorylation may regulate associations between L1 and the cytoskeleton.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	45	 For example, both L1 and the L1 family members neurofascin and NrCAM associate with the membrane cytoskeleton protein ankyrin, and phosphorylation of a tyrosine within the ankyrin binding site of neurofascin, which is conserved in L1, disrupts this association (Tuvia et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	46	Here, we present evidence that outside-in signaling dynamically regulates the functional state of the L1CD via dephosphorylation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	47	 We have characterized the mAb 74-5H7 that recognizes a subset of L1 at points of cell to cell contact and in vesicular structures.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The 74-5H7 epitope is regulated by phosphorylation of L1 and maps to the region immediately preceding the tyrosine-based sorting motif.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	49	 In vitro studies show that phosphorylation within the epitope prevents recognition by 74-5H7 and also binding of AP-2 to L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	50	 We have identified the nonreceptor tyrosine kinase p60src as an L1-phosphorylating kinase that preferentially phosphorylates Y1176 of the tyrosine-based sorting motif in vitro.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Cell to cell contact is able to induce changes in the phosphorylation state of L1 that is recognized by 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	52	 These data demonstrate that L1 to L1 binding induces a functional change in the L1CD mediated by a phosphorylation-dephosphorylation cycle.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	53	   Results Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   mAb 74-5H7 recognizes a special fraction of L1 in neurons Chick DRG neurons growing in culture have L1 distributed over their entire surfaces (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	54	 When mAb 74-5H7 was used for immunocytochemistry, however, we were surprised to find that immunoreactivity (IR) was concentrated at points of contact between DRG neuron cell bodies in culture (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Previous characterization of 74-5H7 indicated that it recognizes L1 exclusively on Western blots of whole brain extracts and can immunoprecipitate mammalian and chick L1 (Lemmon et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	56	 It does not bind to Western blots of membranes of L1 knockout mice, demonstrating that it does not cross react with other L1 subfamily members (unpublished data).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The 74-5H7 recognizes the 200 to 220-kD full-length L1, as well as the 85-kD carboxy-terminal portion including the cytoplasmic tail, and it does not bind to live neurons.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Therefore, the mAb epitope is likely to reside near or within the L1 cytoplasmic domain.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The immunolabeling pattern in cultured neurons suggests the mAb epitope is not present or not accessible in the majority of cell surface L1, but is exposed or induced in L1 when clustered and engaged with its binding partners at points of cell to cell contact.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	60	 This implies that cell to cell contact induces changes in the cytoplasmic domain of L1 that can be visualized with this mAb.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	61	View larger version (40K):    Figure 1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	62	 74-5H7 recognizes a subpopulation of L1 localized to cell to cell contact sites and in growth cones.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Immunocytochemistry of two DRG neuron cell bodies plated on an L1-Fc substrate and double labeled with (A) 74-5H7 and (B) rabbit polyclonal anti-L1 antibody (8D9).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	64	 (C) Superimposition of the images with 74-5H7 in red and polyclonal anti-L1 antibody (8D9) in green.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Immunocytochemistry of DRG growth cones extended on an L1-Fc substrate and double labeled with (D) 74-5H7 and (E) rabbit polyclonal anti-L1 antibody (8D9).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	66	 (F) Superimposition of the images with 74-5H7 in red and polyclonal anti-L1 antibody (8D9) in green.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	67	 74-5H7-IR is brightest in association with vesicle-like structures in the growth cone.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	68	 L1-IR is brightest in association with L1 on the surface.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Consequently, the two channels have been set up quite differently, with one emphasizing L1 at the surface and the other, L1 inside the growth cone.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	70	 This leads to situations where 74-5H7 to positive structures inside the growth cone are comparatively weakly stained by the pan-L1 antibody, leading to a misimpression that 74-5H7-IR is present where there is no L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Bar, 10  microm; circle radius, 0.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	72	  In addition to points of cell to cell contact, a striking punctate/vesicular pattern of 74-5H7 immunoreactivity (74-5H7-IR) was evident in growth cones visualized by confocal microscopy.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	73	 In growth cones of DRG neurons extending on an L1-Fc substrate, 74-5H7-IR revealed a vesicle-like distribution that was predominately restricted to lamellipodial and central domains of the growth cones rather than filopodia (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	74	 In contrast, immunolabeling with a rabbit anti-L1 antibody (8D9) showed that total L1 was distributed along the entire surface of the growth cone and axon shaft with strong labeling extending into the filopodia tips (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Measurement of the size of the 74-5H7-IR vesicle-like structures using the image analysis software of the confocal microscope revealed that they were  < 0.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	76	3  microm in radius, which is consistent with the size of clathrin coated vesicles.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Our detailed analysis of the pattern of 74-5H7-IR, in conjunction with our earlier report showing that 74-5H7-IR can colocalize at the rear of growth cones with the endocytosis marker protein Eps15 (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	78	, 1998b), indicates that 74-5H7 recognizes a subset of L1 that is in vesicle-like structures and on the cell surface at points of cell to cell contact.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Therefore, expression of the 74-5H7 epitope correlates with a functional state of L1 that occurs when L1 is engaged in adhesion at the cell surface and during trafficking.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	80	Characterization of the 74-5H7 epitope In principle, there are several possible explanations for the unique distribution of 74-5H7-IR, including a change in posttranslational modification such as phosphorylation, blocking of the epitope by protein to protein interactions, or conformational change.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Two lines of evidence suggest that phosphorylation is the most likely explanation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	82	 First, 74-5H7 recognizes L1 by Western blot after fractionation by SDS-PAGE (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Under these conditions, posttranslational modifications to the L1CD would be preserved, whereas global conformational changes or protein associations would be lost.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Second, bacterially produced, purified recombinant L1CD is recognized by 74-5H7 on Western blots (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	85	 2 B), indicating that the 74-5H7 epitope is part of the primary structure of the L1CD, suggesting that the epitope is masked by posttranslational modifications of L1 in vivo.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	86	View larger version (14K):    Figure 2.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	87	 (A) Western blot of myeloma cell extracts expressing different L1 constructs: (1) full-length L1; (2) L1CD truncated after lysine 1147, leaving only the first four amino acids of the cytoplasmic domain; and (3) L1CD truncated after Y1176, leaving the first 33 amino acids of the cytoplasmic domain.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The blot was probed with the 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The 220-kD molecular mass marker is indicated on the left.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	90	 (B) Dot blot showing that 74-5H7 binds to bacterially expressed L1CD (rL1CD), a 14 to amino acid L1CD sequence, SEARPMKDETFGEY, immediately preceding the alternatively spliced (RSLE) region, but not to a peptide corresponding to the juxtamembrane region (KRSK.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	91	 (C) A series of peptides was synthesized with alanine substituting for individual amino acids to determine which amino acid residues are critical for 74-5H7 binding to the SEARPMKDETFGEY sequence.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Dot blot analysis shows that substituting alanine for lysine 1169, glutamine 1171, threonine 1172, phenylalanine 1173, or glycine 1174 inhibits 74-5H7 binding to the peptides.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Additional peptides were synthesized containing phosphoserine 1163, phosphothreonine 1172, and phospho-Y1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The dot blot shows that phosphorylation of threonine 1172 or Y1176 inhibits 74-5H7 recognition of the peptide, whereas phosphorylation of serine 1163 has no effect.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	95	 (D) Western blot showing (lane 1) 74-5H7 binding to purified rat L1, and (lane 2) that preincubation of the monoclonal antibody with the SEARPMKDETFGEY peptide competes for binding to purified rat L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The 220- and 85-kD molecular masses are shown on the left.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	97	  To determine which region of the cytoplasmic domain contained the 74-5H7 epitope, we prepared a series of plasmid constructs containing sequences coding for L1 with various cytoplasmic domain truncations, expressed them in myeloma cells, and examined which ones preserved the 74-5H7 epitope.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Western blot analysis of extracts from myeloma cells expressing different L1 truncations shows that 74-5H7 recognizes full-length L1 and L1 truncated after Y1176, which leaves the first 33 amino acids of the L1CD intact (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The mAb also recognizes the nonneuronal form of L1 that lacks the alternatively spliced exon 28 (amino acids 1177 to 1181; unpublished data).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	100	 In contrast, the 74-5H7 does not recognize L1 truncated after lysine 1147 that removes all but the first four amino acids of the cytoplasmic domain (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	101	 These results suggest that the 74-5H7 epitope resides in the first 33 amino acids of the L1 cytoplasmic domain.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	102	A series of peptides was made to map the precise epitope recognized by 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	103	 First, we synthesized two peptides spanning the first 33 amino acids of the cytoplasmic domain and asked whether 74-5H7 recognized either on dot blots.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Our analysis indicates that 74-5H7 recognizes a 14 amino acid peptide, SEARPMKDETFGEY (residues 1163 to 1176; Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	105	 2 B), but not the peptide, KRSKGGKYSVKDKEDTQVDS (residues 1144 to 1163), consisting of the first 20 amino acids of the L1CD.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	106	 We then used synthetic peptides with alanine scanning substitutions through the 14 amino acid peptide to determine which residues are essential for recognition by 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	107	 This analysis identified five amino acids, SEARPMKDETFGEY (underlined) that when individually changed to alanine, abolish 74-5H7 binding (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Although only these five amino acids were identified as critical for 74-5H7 binding, we were unable to detect binding to peptides shorter than the SEARPMKDETFGEY sequence, suggesting there may be structural contributions to the epitope from other residues (unpublished data).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The SEARPMKDETFGEY peptide also competed with purified L1 for 74-5H7 binding, confirming the importance of this sequence for mAb recognition of L1 (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Thus the 74-5H7 epitope, which is present in L1 at points of cell to cell contact and in small vesicle-like structures, is positioned immediately NH2-terminal to the tyrosine-based sorting motif.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	111	 This motif (YRSL) is present in the neuronal form of L1 and is critical for regulation of L1 endocytosis (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	112	Phosphorylation of L1 peptides inhibits 74-5H7 binding The 14 amino acid peptide contains three potential phosphorylation sites, SEARPMKDETFGEY (underlined).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	113	 We synthesized peptides in which one of these residues was phosphorylated, and found that the peptide containing phosphorylated threonine 1172 was no longer recognized by 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In addition, 74-5H7 recognition of phosphorylated Y1176 peptide was reduced over 80%, although the peptide containing phosphoserine 1163 was strongly reactive (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	115	 These results suggest that phosphorylation of one or both of these sites, threonine 1172 and Y1176, in L1 could be responsible for its inability to react with 74-5H7, and that the epitope may be transiently unmasked by dephosphorylation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	116	 However, phosphothreonine has never been reported in L1 (for review see Schaefer et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	117	p60src phosphorylates the L1CD Although phosphorylation of both threonine 1172 and Y1176 disrupt the 74-5H7 epitope, phosphorylation of threonine residues in L1 has not been reported either in vitro or in vivo (Salton et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	118	 In contrast, at least two reports indicate that L1 is tyrosine phosphorylated in vivo (Heiland et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Therefore, we were interested in determining which kinase(s) can phosphorylate L1 on Y1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The nonreceptor tyrosine kinase p60src has been implicated in L1 function (Ignelzi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Tyrosine phosphorylation of the CTLA-4 T-lymphocyte receptor endocytosis motif by src family kinases is implicated in regulation of its cell surface expression (Bradshaw et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	122	 To determine if L1 could be a substrate for p60src, we tested the ability of purified p60src to phosphorylate recombinant L1CD in vitro, and found that L1 is phosphorylated by this kinase (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The phosphorylated L1CD was digested with endoproteinase Asp-N, and the resulting fragments were separated by reverse phase HPLC.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	124	 One major peptide, DETFGEYRSLES, was identified associated with radioactivity.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The site of phosphorylation of this peptide was determined to be the seventh residue by assessing the elution of radioactivity using covalent sequencing supports to allow tracking of the radiolabeled residue(s); this corresponds to Y1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Phosphorylated peptide fragments containing the other three tyrosines present within the L1CD did not coelute with radioactivity, indicating that p60src preferentially phosphorylates Y1176, an amino acid residue that plays a critical role in regulating L1 trafficking and endocytosis.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	127	View larger version (18K):    Figure 3.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	128	 (A) Ra-pYRSLE binds to L1CD phosphorylated by p60src and L1 in brain.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	129	 L1CD was phosphorylated with p60src (lanes 1 and 3) or mock phosphorylated (lanes 2 and 4).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Both an anti-phosphotyrosine monoclonal antibody (4G10, lanes 1 and 2) and Ra-pYRSLE (lanes 3 and 4) reacted with the phosphorylated peptide but not the unphosphorylated peptide.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	131	 (B and C) Homogenates from human (H), rat (R), mouse (M), and chick (C) brain were analyzed by Western blots.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	132	 (B) Rabbit anti to rat L1 (aRat L1) recognized a band at 85 kD that corresponded to the major proteolytic cleavage fragment of L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	133	 (C) Rabbit anti-pYRSLE (pYRSLE) recognized the same 85-kD band.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	134	  L1 Y1176 is phosphorylated in vivo The finding that 74-5H7 recognizes dephosphorylated L1, and the restricted distribution of 74-5H7-IR relative to total L1 IR, predicts that some neuronal L1 is phosphorylated on Y1176 in vivo.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	135	 To demonstrate that Y1176 was, indeed, phosphorylated in vivo, we produced a new Ra-pYRSLE antibody.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	136	 This affinity-purified antibody showed strong binding to KDETFGEpYRSLESDN and virtually no immunoreactivity for KDETFGEYRSLESDN in ELISA assays (unpublished data).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The Ra-pYRSLE also bound to rL1CD, phosphorylated using src, as did an anti-pY antibody (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Neither Ra-pYRSLE nor anti-pY antibody bound to unphosphorylated rL1CD.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Finally, Ra-pYRSLE did bind to a band corresponding in molecular weight to L1 in human, rat, mouse, and chick brain homogenates prepared in the presence of tyrosine phosphatase inhibitors (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	140	 3, B and C), demonstrating that y1176 is, indeed, phosphorylated in vivo.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	141	 L1, affinity purified from mouse brain using 74-5H7, did not bind the Ra-pYRSLE as one would expect (unpublished data).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	142	To support the idea that phosphorylation of the Y1176 was responsible for regulating the 74-5H7 epitope in vivo, fresh chick brains were homogenized in the presence and absence of a cocktail of tyrosine phosphatase inhibitors (0.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	143	2 mM phenyl arsine oxide, 5 nM microcystin, and 100 pM cypermethrin, 10 mM pervanadate; Tonks et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The anti-pY antibody recognized two very prominent bands in the brain extract that were not L1 but served as indicators for the effectiveness of the phosphatase inhibitors.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	145	 When the inhibitors were absent, a strong signal for the 74-5H7 epitope was seen, whereas the anti-pY antibody gave a relatively weak signal (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Alternatively, when the inhibitors were present, the 74-5H7-IR was relatively weak but the pY-IR was strong (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The simplest interpretation of this data is that the phosphatase inhibitors prevent dephosphorylation of Y1176 on L1 and thereby block 74-5H7 binding.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	148	View larger version (54K):    Figure 4.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Effect of tyrosine phosphatase inhibitors on 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Fresh chick brains were homogenized in the absence (A) or presence (B) of a cocktail of phosphatase inhibitors.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	151	 As expected, a monoclonal anti-pY antibody (4G10) showed stronger binding to different proteins in the extract including the phosphatase inhibitors (B).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	152	 74-5H7 binds much more strongly to L1 in the extract lacking the inhibitors.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	153	 A rabbit antibody to L1 (85 kD) shows there were approximately equal amounts of L1 in the two preparations.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	154	  Phosphorylation of L1 Y1176 inhibits L1 binding to AP-2 We have shown previously, using an in vitro peptide competition assay, that the peptide FGEYRSLESDNEE blocks binding of a biotin-labeled TGN38 peptide to AP-2 purified from rat brain (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	155	 This, and other data, showed that the YRSLE sequence mediates L1 binding to AP-2 (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	156	 It is known that phosphorylation of a tyrosine in the tyrosine-based sorting motif of CTLA-4 can inhibit binding to AP-2 and, as a result, can inhibit clathrin-mediated endocytosis of the CTLA-4 (Shiratori et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	157	 To test this for L1, we compared the ability of phosphorylated and unphosphorylated L1 peptides to compete with a peptide spanning the TGN38 tyrosine-based sorting motif for binding to AP-2 (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The FGEpYRSLESDNEE peptide phosphorylated on Y1176 failed to block the interaction between TGN38 peptide and AP-2, indicating that L1 phosphorylated at Y1176 cannot bind to AP-2.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	159	 In contrast, phosphorylation of S1181, which we have shown is the residue phosphorylated by CKII (Wong et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	160	, 1996b), gave a peptide that retained its ability to block TGN38 binding to AP-2, demonstrating that CKII phosphorylation of L1 would not inhibit binding to AP-2.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (13K):    Figure 5.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	162	 L1 peptide phosphorylated at Y1176 cannot bind to AP-2.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The  micro2 chain of AP-2 was incubated with the YQRL peptide (see Materials and methods) in the absence (right-most band) or presence of competitor peptides (EpYRSLES, EYRSLEpS, and EYRSLE).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The concentrations of each competitor peptide are indicated in the figures.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The EYRSLEpS and EYRSLE peptides were strong competitors of the YQRL peptide, showing that they bound to the  micro2 chain of AP-2, even at concentrations as low as 10  microM.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	166	 In contrast, the EpYRSLES peptide did not act as a competitor, even at 1,000  microM.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	167	  74-5H7 binding to L1 is dynamically regulated by cell to cell contact, L1 to L1 homophilic interactions, and L1 cross-linking The results of immunocytochemical studies reported in Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	168	 1 suggested that 74-5H7-IR might be induced by cell to cell contact.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	169	 To directly test this idea, we used a cell-pelleting paradigm to rapidly induce cell to cell contact and asked whether a change in 74-5H7-IR could be detected on Western blots.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Mechanically dissociated chick brain cells were induced to reform cell to cell contacts by low speed centrifugation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	171	 When cells were lysed at various times after cell pelleting and the lysates were analyzed by Western blot, a clear increase in 74-5H7-IR was observed beginning as early as 5 min and continuing for up to 60 min.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The increase was followed by a decrease toward basal levels by 3 h after the cells were pelleted (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The presence of intact L1 throughout the time course was confirmed by reprobing the blots with a polyclonal anti-L1 antibody (8D9).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	174	 These results indicate the change in 74-5H7-IR is rapidly and transiently induced by cell to cell contact.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	175	View larger version (33K):    Figure 6.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Cell to cell contact induces a transient increase in 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Mechanically dissociated chick brain cells were forced to reform contacts by low speed centrifugation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	178	 After various periods of time, cell pellets were extracted and analyzed by Western blot for 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The blots were then stripped and reprobed for total L1 labeling with a polyclonal anti-L1 antibody (8D9).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The graph shows the relative 74-5H7-IR for L1 compared with the polyclonal anti-L1 (8D9) labeling at various times after pelleting.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	181	  Although the cell pelleting experiments described above indicate that cell to cell contact dramatically increases 74-5H7-IR, the cell pelleting paradigm involves inducing contact among many types of cell surface receptors present on brain cells in addition to L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Therefore, to ask whether the increase in 74-5H7-IR can be induced specifically by L1 to L1 interactions, we used stable lines of myeloma cells transfected to express L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	183	 These cells are normally nonadhesive, but form L1-dependent aggregates when they express L1 (Wong et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Immunocytochemistry of myeloma cells expressing full-length L1 shows 74-5H7-IR localized to regions of cell to cell contact (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	185	 7 A), whereas labeling L1 with a polyclonal antibody raised against recombinant L1CD shows a more uniform cell surface distribution for L1 (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Colocalization of the two antibodies is shown in yellow at the cell to cell contact site (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	187	 This result is consistent with L1 to L1 homophilic binding being sufficient to mediate changes in 74-5H7-IR at cell to cell contact sites.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	188	View larger version (15K):    Figure 7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	189	 L1 to L1-mediated cell adhesion induces 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Immunocytochemistry of myeloma cells expressing full-length L1 and double labeled with (A) 74-5H7 and (B) polyclonal anti-L1CD.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The confocal images show 74-5H7-IR concentrated at points of cell to cell contact, whereas polyclonal anti-L1CD-IR is present around the entire cell surface.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	192	 (C) Superimposition of images with 74-5H7 (green) and polyclonal anti-L1CD (red).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	193	  The cell pelleting data indicate that the 74-5H7 epitope is rapidly and transiently induced.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Previous work from our lab has shown that L1 can be phosphorylated at multiple sites (Wong et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Regulation of the epitope was preserved in myeloma cells expressing L1 with only the first 33 amino acids of the cytoplasmic domain, indicating that the potential posttranslational modification was restricted to this region of the L1CD (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Similar results were obtained with myeloma cells expressing full-length L1 but not L1 expressing 3T3 cells or Cos-7 cells.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	197	View larger version (43K):    Figure 8.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Myeloma cells expressing L1 (1 to 1176, i.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	199	, truncation after Y1176) were centrifuged at low speed to induce cell to cell contact.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	200	 After various periods of time, the cell pellets were extracted and analyzed by Western blot for 74-5H7-IR and polyclonal anti to human L1-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The graph shows the relative change in 74-5H7-IR compared with the polyclonal anti to human L1 immunostaining.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	202	  To determine whether the change in 74-5H7-IR can be induced by L1 binding in neurons, we used L1 cross-linking polyclonal antibodies to mimic L1 binding.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Cross-linking L1 with antibodies has been shown to induce changes in a number of intracellular second messengers including Ca2+, IP2, and IP3 (von Bohlen und Halbach et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	204	, 1992), as well as to activate the MAPK signaling cascade (Schaefer et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	205	, 1999) and phosphatase(s) (Klinz et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	206	 In addition, cross-linking L1 or the L1 heterophilic binding partners, axonin-1 and F3/F11, can also regulate the phosphorylation state of L1 (Zisch et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	207	 74-5H7-IR was observed at points of cell to cell contact in cultured neurons without L1 antibody cross-linking (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	208	 74-5H7-IR was dramatically up-regulated by cross-linking L1 on DRG neurons in culture with polyclonal anti-L1 antibodies (8D9) (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	209	 9 C) as compared with isolated neurons without L1 antibody cross-linking (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In a variation of the L1 cross-linking experiment, we took mechanically dissociated chick brain cells, preincubated them at 4 degrees C with cross-linking polyclonal L1 antibodies (8D9), and then brought the cells to 37 degrees C to induce cross-linking of L1 on the cell surface.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The cells were lysed after various times and the L1 was immunoprecipitated.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The immunoprecipitates were analyzed by Western blot and a clear time course for 74-5H7-IR was observed.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	213	 74-5H7-IR for L1 peaked at 5 min and returned to baseline levels by 30 min (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Together, these results indicate that the 74-5H7 epitope is dynamically regulated on cell surface L1, and that it can be induced by L1 to L1 homophilic binding and L1 cross-linking.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	215	View larger version (39K):    Figure 9.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	216	 L1 cross-linking induces 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Immunocytochemistry of DRG neurons plated on a laminin substrate and labeled with 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	218	 (A) An isolated cell showing typically low 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	219	 (B) A group of cells showing 74-5H7-IR at cell to cell contact sites.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	220	 (C) A cell preincubated while alive with L1 cross-linking polyclonal antibodies (8D9) for 60 min shows increased levels of 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	221	 (D) Mechanically dissociated chick brain cells in suspension were incubated with L1 polyclonal antibodies (8D9) for 30 min at 4 degrees C.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The cells were then incubated at 37 degrees C for various periods of time to induce L1 cross-linking.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The cells were extracted and L1-immunoprecipitated with protein A beads and the immunoprecipitates were analyzed by Western blot for 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	224	     Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   We have presented evidence that L1 homophilic binding and L1 cross-linking at the cell surface induce a transient change in the phosphorylation state of the L1CD that can regulate its association with the endocytic machinery.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	225	 This regulation of L1 internalization provides a means to control adhesion and facilitate growth cone movement.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Our present studies depend in large measure on mAb 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Several lines of evidence showed that this antibody binds to a subset of L1 and binding to L1 is negatively regulated by phosphorylation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	228	 First, several epitope mapping experiments demonstrate that 74-5H7 recognizes the sequence SEARPMKDETFGEY, and that phosphorylation of Y1176 inhibits recognition.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Second, L1 purified from brain extract in the presence of phosphatase inhibitors has weak 74-5H7-IR, whereas L1 purified in the absence of inhibitors shows stronger 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	230	 We showed that the L1CD could be phosphorylated by src on Y1176 and that an antibody specific for pYRSLE showed that the corresponding epitope on L1 was present in brain.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Immunohistochemical studies of growth cones with 74-5H7 revealed that this form of L1 is restricted, being absent from filopodia and concentrated in vesicle-like structures.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Finally, experiments using neurons and L1 expressing myelomas showed that cell contact or antibody cross-linking of L1 caused significant but transient changes in the phosphorylation state of L1 on Y1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Together, these data show that L1 mediated contact causes an outside-in signal that alters the phosphorylation state of L1 and this, in turn, alters L1 internalization and adhesion, a form of inside-out signaling.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	234	The SEARPMKDETFGEY sequence, where 74-5H7 binds, is perfectly conserved in human, mouse, rat, chicken, and fugu fish L1 homologues.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Although the complete SEARPMKDETFGEY sequence is not conserved in other vertebrate L1 homologues, acidic residues NH2-terminal to Y1176 and a hydrophobic residue at the Y-3 position are conserved not just in direct L1 homologues, but also in the L1 family members Nr-CAM and neurofascin (Hortsch, 1996).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Previous data implicate p60 src in L1 function, because src-/- neurons extend poorly on L1 substrates, suggesting their response to L1 is impaired (Ignelzi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Our finding that p60src can phosphorylate Y1176 provides potential mechanistic insight into this phenotype.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	238	 We suggest that L1 in src-/- neurons grown on L1 may be relatively hypophosphorylated at Y1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	239	 This could alter the regulation of L1 endocytosis; disruption of L1 trafficking could in turn impair neurite outgrowth on L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Suter and Forscher (2001) recently showed that p60src activity could be involved in a positive feedback loop strengthening CAM interactions with their cytoskeletal linkages.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Our data support a similar role for p60src in which it could phosphorylate L1 under certain conditions, thereby inhibiting internalization and increasing adhesion.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	242	The 74-5H7 epitope is adjacent to the tyrosine-based motif, Yxx ( is a bulky hydrophobic amino acid) in the L1CD that mediates L1 endocytosis (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Studies of tyrosine-based sorting motifs in other proteins indicate that the tyrosine has to be in a nonphosphorylated state for the signals to be active in sorting and endocytosis; i.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	244	, phosphorylation of the tyrosine prevents binding of adaptin proteins to the motif (Boll et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Indeed, our in vitro peptide competition experiments using peptides derived from L1 show that a Y1176-phosphorylated peptide corresponding to the potential p60src phosphorylation site, FGEpYRSLESDNEE, is no longer able to bind the  micro2 chain of AP-2, whereas a serine 1181-phosphorylated peptide corresponding to the CKII phosphorylation site, FGEYRSLEpSDNEE, retains its capacity to associate with  micro2.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	246	 It is highly unlikely that T1172 influences L1 to AP-2 interactions because there is no evidence suggesting it is phosphorylated, and extensive studies show that the fourth residue in the amino-terminal direction does not influence  micro2 binding to tyrosine-based sorting motifs (Boll et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Our results show that the 74-5H7-IR is inhibited by phosphorylation of Y1176 and that src family kinases may mediate this.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Similarly, clathrin-mediated endocytosis of the T lymphocyte receptor, CTLA-4, has been shown to be negatively regulated by phosphorylation of the critical tyrosine in the endocytosis motif (Bradshaw et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	249	, 1997) and this is likely by src family kinases (Miyatake et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Overall, our results imply that only L1 that can bind 74-5H7 is capable of interacting with the clathrin-mediated endocytic machinery.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	251	 This is consistent with the finding that in growth cones growing on L1 substrates, 74-5H7-IR is at the rear of growth cones, where L1 is internalized and colocalizes with Eps15, a marker for clathrin-coated pits (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	252	 We have shown previously that inhibition of L1 endocytosis dramatically increases L1-mediated adhesion (Long et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	253	 L1 at the rear of growth cones growing on L1 is less adhesive than L1 at the front of the growth cones, but this differential is not observed on growth cones growing on N-cadherin (Kamiguchi and Yoshihara, 2001).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Therefore, phosphorylation of Y1176 provides a rapid but reversible means of increasing L1-mediated adhesion.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	255	The hypothesis that the 74-5H7 epitope is regulated by phosphorylation/dephosphorylation implies the involvement of L1 phosphatases in its regulation and is consistent with early results that show that cross-linking L1 activates tyrosine and serine phosphatases (Klinz et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	256	 A number of potential candidate phosphatases exist.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	257	 These include phosphotyrosine phosphatases (PTPases) that prefer substrates containing acidic residues NH2-terminal to the phosphotyrosine such as PTP1B, and rat brain PTP1 (for review see Zhou and Cantley, 1995).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Another candidate is the receptor protein tyrosine phosphatase ss because of its ability to bind heterophilically with L1 family CAMs.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The phosphatase may also be coexpressed in some of the same cell types as L1 (Peles et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	260	 It has been suggested that acidic residues NH2-terminal to the phosphotyrosine residue are a hallmark for targeted dephosphorylation (Pinna and Ruzzene, 1996) and that the number, nature, and position of the acidic residues may create consensus sequences that are recognized selectively by individual PTPases (Pinna and Donella-Deana, 1994).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	261	The simplest interpretation of our biochemical analysis of the 74-5H7 epitope is that unengaged L1 is phosphorylated on Y1176, and that Y1176 becomes dephosphorylated subsequent to L1 ligand binding.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Dephosphorylation allows interaction with AP-2 and clathrin-mediated endocytosis.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	263	 In this paradigm, the time course of 74-5H7-IR observed in the cell pelleting experiments could reflect internalization and subsequent recycling (and rephosphorylation) of L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Our immunohistochemical observations of the distribution of 74-5H7-IR suggest the situation is more complex, however, and that L1 to L1 binding does not always induce L1 endocytosis.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	265	 First, L1 can mediate stable axon fasciculation, suggesting it is not invariably endocytosed at points of L1 to L1 binding.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Second, although growing DRG neurons on L1 increases L1 internalization and subsequent recycling (Kamiguchi and Lemmon, 2000; Kamiguchi and Yoshihara, 2001), endocytosis of L1 occurs preferentially at the rear of the growth cone.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	267	 74-5H7-IR is colocalized with vesicle-like structures in these neurons, rather than just at points of contact between the growth cone and the L1-Fc substrate (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	268	 These observations suggest that dephosphorylation of Y1176 and L1 endocytosis in growth cones are not regulated solely by L1 to L1 binding, but also by restricted localization of the dephosphorylation machinery.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	269	 We cannot rule out the possibility that, in vivo, the 74-5H7 epitope in some L1 is masked by interactions with other proteins, such as cytoskeletal components (Brophy, 2001).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Thus, although 74-5H7 clearly identifies a subset of L1 in cells that are dephosphorylated at Y1176, there may be other populations of L1 that are dephosphorylated at Y1176, but not accessible to the antibody and thus not visualized in immunocytochemical experiments.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	271	In summary, we have used 74-5H7 to show that L1 is dephosphorylated at Y1176 where L1 is internalized and trafficking in growth cones.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	272	 We have also shown that the phosphorylation state of Y1176 determines whether L1 can interact with the clathrin internalization machinery.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	273	 A variety of experiments showed that the phosphorylation/dephosphorylation state of L1 is regulated by cell contact and restricted to specific sites in neurons.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The phosphorylation of the L1CD on Y1176 by p60src that is important for L1-mediated neurite outgrowth raises the possibility that the regulation of L1 internalization by phosphorylation and dephosphorylation represents a critical regulatory point for L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The ability of L1 to L1 adhesion to influence its endocytosis is reminiscent of how other surfaces can influence integrin expression on neurites (Condic and Letourneau, 1997).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	276	 In Aplysia, the distribution of apCAM, an IgSF CAM member, is acutely regulated by endocytosis during learning-induced synaptic remodeling (Bailey et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	277	, 1992), whereas in Drosophila, changing the distribution of another IgSF member, fasciclin II, alters synapse size (Schuster et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	278	 It appears that regulated endocytosis may be a general mechanism underlying CAM functions in dynamic processes such as cell migration, neurite outgrowth, and synaptic plasticity.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	279	   Materials and methods Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Materials Protease inhibitors, Pefabloc SC, leupeptin, and aprotinin, as well as HRP-conjugated goat anti to rabbit antibodies were from Boehringer.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Texas red to  and Oregon green to conjugated anti to rabbit IgGs were from Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Anti to phosphotyrosine antibody (4G10) and recombinant human p60src were from Upstate Biotechnology.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The anti-L1 antibodies were produced in the laboratory and include polyclonal anti to chicken L1 antibody (8D9) (Lemmon and McLoon, 1986), polyclonal anti to human L1 antibody (Hlavin and Lemmon, 1991), polyclonal anti-recombinant L1 cytoplasmic domain, and 74-5H7 mouse monoclonal anti-L1 (Lemmon et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The new rabbit anti-pYRSLE antibody was made in conjunction with Eurogentec [32P]H3PO4 was purchased from ICN Biomedicals.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Genosys synthesized the L1 cytoplasmic domain synthetic peptides used to characterize mAb 74-5H7 and the custom alanine substitution peptides as well as the phosphopeptides directly onto a solid cellulose-based support using SPOTsTM technology.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The Immobilon-P polyvinyldifluoridene (PVDF) membrane was from Millipore.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	286	 RenaissanceTM enhanced chemiluminescent detection reagents were from NEN Life Science Products.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Tissue culture reagents were from GIBCO BRL.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The following tyrosine phosphatase inhibitors were used: microcystin and cypermethrin (Calbiochem), molybdate, phenylarsine oxide, and orthovanadate (Sigma-Aldrich).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	289	 All other chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	290	DRG cell culture DRG were dissected from embryonic day 10 chicks and dissociated with 0.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	291	1% DNase in Ca2+/Mg2+ free HBSS and grown on glass coverslips sequentially coated with poly-L-lysine, 10  microg/ml goat anti to human IgG (Fc specific), and L1-Fc chimera (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Some DRG neurons were grown on glass coverslips coated with poly-L-lysine and 10  microg/ml laminin.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	293	L1-expressing myeloma cell lines L1-expressing myeloma cells were described previously (Wong et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Cell surface expression of L1 by transfected myelomas was evaluated by live cell staining immunofluorescence, and stable cell lines were cloned using FACS  and subsequently sorted by FACS  to produce lines with identical expression levels.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	295	Chick brain cell suspension Whole brains were dissected from E10 chick embryos and the meninges were carefully removed.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	296	 The brains were then broken up into small fragments by passing them through a 300- microm nylon mesh.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	297	 The fragments were incubated on ice in DME supplemented with 1 mM EDTA for 5 min, and then run through 50- microm nylon mesh.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	298	 The fragments were then pelleted by centrifugation, washed with DME/10% FCS, and pelleted again to remove the EDTA.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	299	 A single cell suspension was obtained by trituration with flame-polished Pasteur pipettes.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	300	 The cells were centrifuged through a DME/50% FCS cushion to remove cell fragments and vesicles.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Finally, the cells were resuspended in DME/10% FCS, counted, and plated in 15-cm tissue culture dishes in a tissue culture incubator (37 degrees C, 5% CO2) for 1 h.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	302	Cell pelleting and L1 cross-linking time course experiments The chick brain cells in suspension were transferred to 15 ml-conical tubes (5 x 106 cells in 5 ml), centrifuged in a clinical centrifuge for 30 s, and then replaced into the tissue culture incubator.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	303	 At each time point (0, 5, 15, 30, 45, 60, 120, and 180 min), pelleted cells were removed from the incubator.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	304	 The cells were extracted in 20 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	305	4, 1 mM EGTA, 2 mM sodium orthovanadate, and 10 mM p-nitrophenyl phosphate (TEV-PNP) containing 0.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	306	25% SDS, 1% NP-40, 40 mM sodium fluoride, and protease inhibitors (200  microM Pefabloc SC, 1  microg/ml leupeptin, 100  microg/ml aprotinin, and 5  microg/ml turkey trypsin inhibitor).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The cell extracts were incubated for 30 min on ice and then centrifuged in a microfuge at maximum speed for 10 min at 4 degrees C.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	308	 SDS-PAGE sample buffer was then added to the supernatants, and the samples were boiled for 5 min.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	309	 The samples were separated by SDS-PAGE (5 to 15% gradient gel), transferred to a PVDF membrane, and the membrane was blocked with 5% evaporated nonfat milk, 0.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	310	 The membrane was incubated with 74-5H7, washed, probed with HRP-goat anti to mouse antibodies, and reactive proteins were visualized by chemiluminescence.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Blots were stripped and reprobed with polyclonal anti-L1 antibodies to assess protein loading.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The relative intensity of the bands was quantified using transmittance densitometry and NIH Image analysis software.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	313	 In some experiments, samples were divided in half and immunostained with 74-5H7 and polyclonal anti-L1 antibodies separately.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	314	 The same 74-5H7-IR time course was observed as with the stripping and reprobing procedure.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	315	In L1 cross-linking experiments, chick brain cells in suspension (106/ml) were preincubated on ice with polyclonal anti-L1 (8D9) cross-linking antibodies for 30 min.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	316	 The cells were brought to 37 degrees C for various periods of time to induce L1 clustering by the antibodies, spun down in a microfuge for 30 s, extracted, and the L1 was immunoprecipitated with protein A beads for 1 h.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	317	Immunocytochemistry of DRG neurons and L1-expressing myeloma cells Cells were fixed with a modified Bouin's solution containing 75 ml saturated picric acid, 5 ml formalin, 5 ml glacial acidic acid, and 20 ml distilled water for 5 min.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	318	 The cells were washed with PBS and permeabilized and blocked in a solution of 10% horse serum/0.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	319	02% Triton X-100 in PBS for 1 h.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Cells were incubated in primary antibodies overnight at 4 degrees C.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Polyclonal anti-L1 antibodies were added to undiluted 74-5H7 hybridoma culture supernatant.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	322	 In some experiments, live cells were incubated for 1 h with polyclonal anti-L1 antibodies (1:250) to cross-link L1 on the cell surface.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	323	 The cells were then rinsed with prewarmed tissue culture medium, fixed, and stained with 74-5H7, followed by fluorescent secondary antibodies (Schaefer et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	324	Confocal microscopy Images of DRG neurons and L1-expressing myeloma cells were taken with a confocal laser microscope (model LSM 410; ZEISS), using an argon/krypton laser (excitation lines, 488 and 568 nm) and a 100x Plan-Neofluor, NA 1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	325	Peptide sequencing 20  microg recombinant L1CD, prepared as described previously (Wong et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	326	, 1996b), was phosphorylated with recombinant human p60src in TEV-PNP containing 10 mM MgCl2, 2 mM MnCl2, 5 mM ATP, and 20  microCi -[32P]ATP.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The L1CD was isolated by running the sample on SDS-PAGE (5 to 15% gradient gel), transferring the proteins to PVDF membrane and cutting out the radiolabeled L1CD band.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	328	 The sample was then digested with endoproteinase Asp-N for 18 h at 37 degrees C, and the resulting peptides were separated by HPLC on a C-18 reverse phase column.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	329	 The fractions containing significant protein and radioactivity were then sequenced on an ABI protein sequencer (University of Kentucky, Macromolecular Structural Analysis Facility).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	330	Rabbit anti-phosphoYRSLE (pYRSLE) production and characterization A new affinity-purified rabbit antibody to pYRSLE was made by immunizing a rabbit with the peptide KDETFGEpYRSLESDN and then purifying the antibody over a column with the same peptide.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	331	 The bound antibodies were eluted and run over a peptide column with KDETFGEYRSLESDN to remove antibodies that recognize unphosphorylated L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	332	To demonstrate that the Ra-pYRSLE antibody recognized the appropriate epitope, recombinant L1CD was phosphorylated with src and ATP as above, run on an SDS gel, transferred to PVDF membrane, and Western blots were done.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	333	Studies on the effect of phosphorylation of the L1CD on interactions with AP-2 The photoactivation cross-linking reaction was performed as described previously (Rapoport et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	334	 In brief, AP-2 complexes were purified from calf brain and then incubated with a peptide including the tyrosine-based sorting motif from TGN38, biotin, and a photo-activatible cross-linking reagent.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Competitor peptides (Research Genetics) were simultaneously added at varying concentrations.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	336	 The peptides included FGEYRSLESDNEE, which corresponds to amino acids 1173 to 1185 of the L1CD, and two phosphopeptides, FGEpYRSLESDNEE and FGEYRSLEpSDNEE.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	337	 After allowing the mixtures to incubate in the dark, they were cross-linked with UV.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	338	 The samples were then run on SDS-PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose, and incubated with streptavidin-conjugated HRP (Boehringer).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	339	 The labeled bands were detected via chemiluminescence.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	340	 ECL films for densitometry were scanned with an imaging densitometer (model GS-710; Bio-Rad Laboratories) using Quantity One V4.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	341	 All images were prepared with Adobe  Photoshop 5.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	342	 Wong's present address is Department of Biology, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY 40292.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	343	 Schaefer's present address is Department of Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	344	 Kamiguchi's present address is Developmental Brain Science Group, RIKEN Brain Science Institute, 2-1 Hirosawa, Wako, Saitama 351-0198, Japan.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	345	* Abbreviations used in this paper: 74-5H7-IR, 74-5H7 immunoreactivity; DRG, dorsal root ganglion; IR, immunoreactivity; L1CD, L1 cytoplasmic domain; PVDF, polyvinyldifluoridene; Y1176, tyrosine 1176.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Activation of the MAPK signal cascade by the neural cell adhesion molecule L1 requires L1 internalization.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Tyrosine phosphorylation controls internalization of CTLA-4 by regulating its interaction with clathrin-associated adaptor complex AP-2.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	374	 Transmission of growth cone traction force through apCAM-cytoskeletal linkages is regulated by Src family tyrosine kinase activity.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Purification of the major protein-tyrosine-phosphatases of human placenta.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	376	 The phosphorylation state of the FIGQY tyrosine of neurofascin determines ankyrin-binding activity and patterns of cell segregation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	377	 The cytoplasmic domain of the cell adhesion molecule L1 is not required for homophilic adhesion.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Involvement of p90rsk in neurite outgrowth mediated by the cell adhesion molecule L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Recognition and specificity in protein tyrosine kinase-mediated signaling.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	380	 Tyrosine phosphorylation of L1 family adhesion molecules: implication of the Eph kinase Cek5.
