0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	108	Mapping of kni and ri breakpoints Restriction fragments isolated from a lambda phage walk (Nauber et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	109	, 1988) covering over 50 kb of the kni upstream region, delimited by the Df(3L)kniri[XT2] deletion, were used as probes to determine the locations of potential chromosomal abnormalities such as deletions or rearrangements in ri mutants on Southern blots (Southern, 1975).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Several different restriction enzymes were used to scan each region to distinguish single nucleotide polymorphisms from larger scale abnormalities such as those present in the kniri[1] and kniri[M3] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	111	Isolation of kniri genomic fragments and construction of the E[ri]-lacZ vectors Primers AA and RK were used to amplify a region surrounding the proximal EcoRI-BglII (1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	112	197 kb) fragment of E from kniri[1], kniri[92f], kniri[M*], and kniri[53j] genomic DNA (AA=GACACAATGCTCCGAATTCC, the 5' end is in F, the 3' end contains the EcoRI site; RK=CCCAATGGACCCCAATCTGGTTGGGG, the 5' end is at 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Note that TGGGG was added to produce a KpnI site at the distal end of the resulting fragment).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	114	 PCR fragments were purified for sequencing using the QIAquick PCR Purification kit.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The blunt ended kniri[1] fragment was cloned into pCR-BluntII-TOPO (TOPO) and oriented so that the NotI site within TOPO and the BglII site within the fragment (N, B) are on opposite sides.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The resulting TOPO-N,B construct and pBS-E were digested with NotI and BglII, fragments isolated and ligated to form pBS-Eri[1].
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The Eri[1] insert was sequenced to confirm that it differed from the wild-type sequence by only the 252 bp deletion.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	118	 KpnI and NotI were used to remove Eri[1], and it was cloned into the corresponding sites of C4PLZ to form Eri[1]-lacZ.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Similarly, primers ECO-ri and XBA-ri were used to PCR amplify the EcoRI-XhoI fragment of E (termed EX) from kniri[53j] genomic DNA (ECO-ri=GAATTCCAACGCGAAGCGTC; XBA-ri=TCTAGATGGGGCTGCTGCCA).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	120	4 kb product was cloned into the TOPO vector.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The EX(ri53j) fragment was digested with EcoRI and XbaI and subcloned into the corresponding sites of pC4PLZ to form EX(ri53j)-lacZ.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	122	 A single subclone was sequenced to verify that only the single nucleotide change (C596A) had been incorporated.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	123	Generation and analysis of sd- clones Generation of reduction-of-function sd58 clones and immunohistochemical analysis were performed as described previously (Guss et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	124	Analysis of Sd binding sites in the L2 enhancer Identification and analysis of Sd binding sites was performed as described by Guss et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Sequences of the upper strand of oligonucleotides used as probes for gel mobility shift assays and as PCR primers to introduce mutations into the Sd binding sites of the kni 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	126	69 kb element (fragment EC in Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	127	 1F) are listed below in the 5' to 3' orientation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Altered bases are shown in lowercase in the mutant version, and the corresponding bases are underlined in the native sequence as follows:.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	129	kni 271 wild type: TTCCCCTCTTACATTTGTCGCATAGTTCCCATCTTGGCCA kni 271 mutant: TTCCCCTCTTtCATTaGgCtCATAaggCCCATCTTGGCCA kni 570 wild type: TTGCGGACACAGGACACGAAATGCGTTTTGTGCCTTAATT kni 570 mutant: TTGCGGACACAGGACACctAATGaGgTTTGTGCCTTAATT kni 640 wild type: TTGCTGGTGCACTGAAAGAAATAGTTGAAGGGATTATTG kni 640 mutant: TTGCTGGTGCACTGAAcctAATAGgTGAAGGGATTATTG.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	130	Reporter constructs with three mutated Sd binding sites were made by cloning PCR-generated fragments of fragment EC into the Hsp lacZ-CaSpeR plasmid (Nelson and Laughton, 1993).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Four independent EC-3Sdmut-lacZ transformants were recovered and tested for lacZ expression.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	132	Mounting fly wings Wings from adult flies were dissected in isopropanol and mounted in 100% Canada Balsam mounting medium (Aldrich #28,292-8) as described previously (Roberts, 1986).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	133	In situ hybridization to whole-mount larval wing discs In situ hybridization using digoxigenin-labeled antisense RNA probes (O'Neill and Bier, 1994) was performed alone or in combination with anti-ss galactosidase (Promega) labeling as described previously (Sturtevant et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	134	   RESULTS TOP SUMMARY INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   An L2 enhancer element lies upstream of the knirps coding region In a previous study, we presented genetic evidence that the kniri[1] mutation, as well as an approximately 50 kb deletion of kni upstream sequences (Df(3L)kniri[XT2]), disrupt the function of a wing-specific regulatory element in the kni locus that is responsible for driving expression of the kni and knrl genes in the L2 primordium (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	135	 As a consequence of the loss of kni/knrl expression, kniri[1] (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	136	 1C) flies have severely truncated L2 veins (compare with the wild-type vein pattern in Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	137	 As a first step in extending these studies, we gathered and characterized four other putative independently generated viable ri alleles of the kni locus, which lack portions of the L2 vein, including kniri[53j] (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	138	 1D), kniri[M3], kniri[92f], and kniri[M*] (not shown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	139	 As in kniri[1] wing discs, we found that kni expression is eliminated in the L2 primordium of each of these kniri alleles (data not shown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	140	The studies mentioned above suggested that there might be an L2-specific wing vein enhancer that controls expression of kni and knrl in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	141	 We searched for such an enhancer element in two ways.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	142	 First, we screened for the ability of genomic fragments upstream of the kni coding region to drive lacZ expression in the L2 primordium (summarized in Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Second, we used Southern blot analysis to identify deletions or rearrangement breakpoints in the genomic DNA of ri mutants in the kni upstream region uncovered by Df(3L)kniri[XT2] (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	144	 As a result of the former effort, we identified a single 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	145	8 kb EcoRI fragment (fragment E in Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	146	 1E-G) that drives lacZ reporter gene expression in a sharp stripe (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	147	 2B) similar to that of endogenous kni expression in the L2 primordium (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Double label experiments confirm that lacZ expression driven by the E-lacZ construct coincides with that of endogenous kni expression (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Additionally, the E-lacZ expression pattern includes a weaker stripe in the posterior region of the wing (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	150	 A faint endogenous kni stripe can also be observed in this location in overstained preparations of wildtype discs (data not shown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Consistent with previous studies (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	152	, 1998), the E-lacZ L2 stripe is located just anterior to the broad domain of strong salm expression (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Notably, the weaker posterior E-lacZ stripe forms immediately adjacent to the posterior border of the salm domain (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	154	View larger version (63K):    Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Expression of wild-type and mutant L2 enhancer constructs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	156	 (A) kni expression in a wild-type mid-third instar larval wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The L2 primordium (L2) and margin (M) are indicated.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	158	 (B) lacZ expression driven by the E-lacZ construct in a mid-third instar larval wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Note the lower levels of lacZ expression in a diffuse stripe in the posterior region of the wing pouch (arrow).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	160	 (C) E-lacZ expression relative to endogenous kni expression in a mid-third instar larval wing disc double-stained for kni mRNA expression (blue) and anti-ss-galactosidase protein (brown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Note the high degree of coincidence of these two expression patterns.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	162	 (D) E-lacZ expression relative to salm expression in a mid-third instar larval wing disc double-stained for anti-ss-galactosidase protein (brown) and salm expression (blue).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Note the abutting and mutually exclusive expression of these two genes.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	164	 (E) EX-lacZ expression driven by fragment EX (1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	165	4 kb 3' subfragment of E; see Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	166	 1G) in a mid-third instar larval wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	167	 (F) EC-lacZ expression driven by fragment EC (0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	168	69 kb 3' subfragment of E; see Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	169	 1G) in a mid-third instar larval wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Note the broad anterior and posterior domains of ectopic lacZ expression relative to that driven by the E-lacZ and EX-lacZ constructs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	171	 (G) E-ri[1]-lacZ expression driven by the fragment E-ri[1], which is deleted for the same 252 bp segment that is missing in the ri[1] allele, in a mid-third instar larval wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Note the entire absence of patterned staining, including that observed in the posterior region of the wings discs (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	173	 compare with staining in panel D).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	174	 (H) EX(ri53j)-lacZ expression driven by the fragment EX(ri53j), which contains the same single base pair alteration present in the kniri[53j] allele, in a mid-third instar larval wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Note that L2 staining is selectively lost while expression in extreme anterior and posterior domains of the wing pouch is retained (arrowheads: compare with staining in G).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	176	In order to delimit a minimal L2 enhancer element, we tested the ability of 5' truncated derivatives of the 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	177	 1G) to drive reporter gene expression in larval wing imaginal discs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	178	 We observed that subfragments of 2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	179	0 kb (EcoRI-SalI, data not shown) and 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	180	4 kb (the EcoRI-XhoI fragment EX, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	181	 1G) drive expression of lacZ (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	182	 2E) in patterns nearly indistinguishable from that of the 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Further truncation generating a 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	184	69 kb EcoRI-HincII fragment (EC, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	185	 1G), however, results in high levels of ectopic lacZ expression in broad anterior and posterior domains (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	186	 This observation indicates that regulatory element(s) required to repress gene expression in the extreme anterior and posterior domains of the wing primordium reside between the distal 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	187	4 kb of fragment EX (repression domain, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	188	 3B), and that sequences sufficient for activation are contained within the proximal 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	189	69 kb fragment EC (activation domain, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	190	 As discussed below, we have identified sequences necessary for L2 activity in the activation domain as well as potential repressor binding sites in the proposed repression domain (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	191	View larger version (71K):    Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The L2-enhancer element is activated by Sd.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	193	 (A) Sequence of the EcoRI-HincII fragment (EC) of E, which contains sites necessary for activation of the minimal L2 enhancer (0 to 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	194	 (B) Sequence of the HincII-XhoI fragment, which contains sequences required to repress ectopic activity of the L2 enhancer element (0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Key: The deletion in the kniri[1] mutant is indicated by blue text and the nucleotide mutated in the kniri[53j] mutant (C to A at 596) highlighted in turquoise.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Sd binding sites in fragment EC (underlined in brown) were determined empirically by footprinting and gel shifts.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	197	 A tandem doublet of binding sites begins at 271 [TACATTTGTCGCATAGTT], while the sites beginning at 463 [TGTATGTAT] (opposite strand), 523 [AAAATGTCG], 570 [GAAATGCGT], and 640 [ACTATTTCT] (opposite strand) are single sites.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	198	 These experimentally determined sites define a consensus [(A/T)(A/G)NAT(G/T)TNT], which matches well with the consensus [WRVWATKYR] derived for Sd binding to other wing enhancers that require vestigial and sd function such as bs=DSRF (Halder et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	199	, 1998), cut, sal and the vg quadrant element (Guss et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Other predicted DNA binding sites are indicated based on matches to known consensus sequences.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Engrailed (En) [TAATTA   yellow type]: (Ades and Sauer, 1994); Spalt-related (Salr) [TTATGa/tAa/cT   pink type]: (Barrio et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	202	, 1996); Brinker (Brk) [c/tGCCAg/c   green type]: (Rushlow et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	203	 No predicted DNA binding sites were identified in fragment EX for Mad (Kim et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	204	, 1997), Ci (Kinzler and Vogelstein, 1990), or Kni (Small et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	205	 (C-F) Reporter gene expression driven by the 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	206	8 kb element E is dependent upon sd function.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	207	 (C) A mitotic clone homozygous for the hypomorphic sd58 allele located in the wing pouch is marked by the absence of the MYC epitope tag and is outlined in red.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	208	 (D) Expression of the E-lacZ reporter gene is eliminated or reduced by the reduction of sd function, except in clones along the wing margin, where it is unaffected (data not shown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The yellow arrowhead indicates the position of the sd- clone.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	210	 (E) The position of cells is marked by the nuclear dye TOPRO.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	211	 (F) Merged image of panels A-C.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	212	 (G) Gel mobility shift assays of oligonucleotide probes spanning the tandem binding sites at 271, and the single sites at 570 and 640, with the Sd TEA domain (left panels of each pair).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Mutations introduced at these sites (right panels of each pair), reduce Sd binding.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	214	 F, free probe; 1, probe with one Sd TEA domain bound; 2, probe with two Sd TEA domains bound.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	215	 (H) A wing disc from one of the transformant lines in which the 271 doublet, and 570, 640 single Sd sites were mutated in the context of fragment EC.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	216	  View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	217	 A model for L2 initiation: global activation, regional repression and local induction.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	218	 (A) Activation of kni expression in the L2 primordium as a consequence of the action of patterning genes initiates morphogenesis of the L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Analysis of the kni/knrl locus L2 enhancer element reveals that this element is activated in a narrow stripe by a combination of global wing specific activation, regional repression, and localized signal mediated activation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Global wing-specific activation is provided at least in part by Sd/Vg (this study).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Regional repression is mediated either directly or indirectly by Salm/Salr (Sal) in central wing cells (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	222	, 1998), and by a repressor(s) acting in peripheral wing cells (green domain)   possibly Brk (this study).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	223	 In addition, a short range signal X (blue), which is produced by Sal-expressing cells (pink domain) is required to induce kni/knrl expression (blue line) in cells just anterior to sal-expressing cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Since kni/knrl expression is activated in cells just anterior to the sal expression domain, but not in posterior cells adjacent to the sal domain (dashed blue line), there must be either a repressor (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	225	 En?) acting in the posterior compartment (hatched) or an activator acting in the anterior compartment together with X' which provides this AP specificity in kni/knrl activation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	226	 The AP compartment border is indicated (solid black line).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	227	 (B) The kni/knrl L2 enhancer can be subdivided into separate domains mediating at least certain components of activation (black region) and repression (red region).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Global wing-specific activation, which requires Sd/Vg function (this study), is mediated by some combination of the empirically determined Sd binding sites (brown ovals) of which there are four single sites and one double site in the activation region.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The action of the hypothetical signal X is presumably mediated by a transcription factor X', which binds to sequences in the activation domain.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The binding site for factor X' (blue circle) may include sequences containing the single nucleotide mutated in the kniri[53j] mutant (C596A) since L2 enhancer activity is selectively lost in the L2 primordium of these flies.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	231	 This site is also eliminated in the 252 bp deletion in the kniri[1] mutant (dark blue region), as are additional sequences required for activity of the enhancer throughout the wing (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The repression domain contains five predicted binding sites for the repressor Brk (green diamonds), two sites for En (hatched yellow triangles), and one site for Salr (pink diamond).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Since the reporter gene expression driven by the activation region alone is repressed in central cells, this fragment must also contain some yet unidentified binding sites for Salm, Salr, or some other factor mediating the repressive effect of Salm/Salr.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	234	ri mutants have lesions in the L2 enhancer that disrupt its function As a complement to screening genomic fragments upstream of the kni locus for the ability to drive gene expression in the L2 primordium using lacZ promoter fusion constructs, we scanned the approximately 50 kb region deleted in the Df(3L)kniri[XT2] allele for detectable aberrations in five putative independently isolated ri alleles.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Using a series of probes spanning that complete genomic region (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	236	 1E), we found that a single EcoRI fragment (the same fragment E that drives expression in the L2 primordium) contains aberrations in the kniri[1], kniri[92f], kniri[M*] and kniri[M3] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	237	 For each of these alleles, mutations map within the minimal 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	238	4 kb L2 enhancer element (see Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Although no large-scale lesions were detected by Southern blot analysis within fragment E of the kniri[53j] mutant, subsequent sequence analysis identified a single base pair alteration within the minimal L2 enhancer element EX (see below).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The kniri[53j] allele is also associated with a small deletion (approx.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	241	Further molecular analysis of the various ri alleles revealed that the putative independently derived kniri[1], kniri[92f], and kniri[M*] alleles all contain the same 252 bp deletion.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	242	 As this deletion is not flanked by duplicated sequences that could promote frequent identical recombination events, it may be that the kniri[92f] and kniri[M*] alleles are actually re-isolates of the original kniri[1] mutation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Consistent with these three alleles having a common origin, they also share a restriction enzyme polymorphism (i.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	244	 loss of a HindIII site) in fragment Q (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	245	 1E) that is not shared by the other ri mutants or our white- control stock.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	246	 To test whether the 252 bp deletion within the minimal L2 enhancer element is responsible for the loss of kni and knrl gene expression in kniri[1] mutants, we made a kniri[1]- mutated E-lacZ construct.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	247	 We amplified genomic DNA containing the kniri[1] mutation and substituted it for the corresponding part of the original E-lacZ construct to generate Eri1-lacZ (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	248	 1G) and transformed this construct into flies.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	249	 We examined lacZ expression in third instar larval wing discs of Eri1-lacZ flies and found that they failed to express lacZ in the L2 primordium or anywhere else in the wing pouch (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	250	 2G), indicating that the 252 bp deletion in kniri[1] mutants eliminates the activity of the L2 enhancer element.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	251	Since Southern blot analysis did not reveal any obvious lesions in fragment E of the kniri[53j] allele, we considered the possibility that this allele might have a subtler lesion in the L2 enhancer region.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Accordingly, we PCR amplified and sequenced the 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	253	 1G) corresponding to the minimal L2 enhancer from kniri[53j].
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	254	 We found only a single nucleotide difference between the sequence of this mutant allele and the wild-type fragment EX (C596A, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	255	 3A), which lies within the same 252 bp region deleted in kniri[1].
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Although it has been observed that single nucleotide mutations can eliminate endogenous enhancer function (Shimell et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	257	, 1994), such cases are sufficiently rare that it was important, as in the case of kniri[1], to demonstrate whether this point mutation was responsible for the loss of enhancer function.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	258	 We used the EX kniri[53j] PCR fragment to make a lacZ construct, confirmed the sequence of the mutant construct, generated four independent transformants, and tested these flies for lacZ expression in third instar wing discs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	259	 We found that EX(ri53j)-lacZ mutant wing discs fail to express lacZ in the L2 primordium (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	260	 2H), strongly suggesting that this single base pair mutation is responsible for the observed L2 vein loss phenotype observed in kniri[53j] flies.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	261	 One notable difference between the EX(ri53j)-lacZ and Eri1-lacZ mutant wing discs is that in the point mutant construct (ri53j), lacZ expression is lost selectively in the L2 primordium and in the weaker posterior stripe (note the normal levels and pattern of expression in extreme anterior and posterior regions of the disc, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	262	 2H), while in the deletion mutant construct (Eri1), reporter gene expression is eliminated throughout the wing disc (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	263	As noted above, the kniri[53j] mutant is also associated with a deletion of 50 bp in fragment R, which lies approximately 15 kb 5' to fragment E within predicted intron sequences of a putative transcription unit (see kni locus map, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	264	 As the ubiquitous expression of this transcription unit is not affected in kniri[53j] mutants (K.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	265	, unpublished observations) and fusion of fragment R with lacZ does not result in gene expression in the L2 primordium, we have no evidence to suggest that this aberration has any relevance to the L2 vein loss phenotype of kniri[53j] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	266	Analysis of the kniri[M3] allele indicates that this mutation involves an insertion and possibly rearrangements within fragment E.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	267	 One breakpoint of the kniri[M3] allele falls within the 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	268	4 kb EX minimal L2 enhancer element (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Because this is a relatively weak ri allele and is associated with a complex lesion, we did not characterize the nature of this rearrangement further.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	270	The wing selector protein Scalloped binds to the L2 enhancer and is required for its activity The 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	271	8 kb L2 enhancer fragment E and truncated derivatives (fragments EX and EC) drive reporter gene expression specifically in the wing pouch.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Recent work has shown that gene expression in the wing primordium is controlled by Sd, which functions with Vestigial (Vg) to define wing identity (Kim et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	273	, 2001; Halder and Carroll, 2001).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	274	 We tested whether Sd might similarly be required to activate endogenous kni expression by generating clones of cells homozygous for a strong hypomorphic allele of sd using FLP-FRT mediated mitotic recombination (Golic, 1991).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	275	 In sd clones, ss-galactosidase expression driven by the E-lacZ element is reduced (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	276	 In clones falling along the future wing margin, however, reporter gene expression is unaffected (not shown; see Discussion).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	277	 These results indicate that Sd plays an in vivo role in activating kni expression within the wing blade.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	278	Because Sd, a TEA-domain protein, functions as a direct transcriptional regulator of several key developmental genes expressed in the wing disc (Halder et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	279	, 2001), we tested whether Sd binds to the kni L2 enhancer.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	280	 We searched for specific Sd DNA binding sites in the 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	281	69 kb EC activation domain using DNAse I footprinting and gel shift analysis (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	282	 3G and data not shown) and identified five sites bound by the Sd TEA domain, which conform well to the known Sd consensus binding site and consist of a tandem doublet of Sd binding sites and four single binding sites (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The four single Sd sites are removed by the 252 bp deletion in the kniri[1] allele, however, none of them covers the kniri[53j] point mutation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	284	 To determine whether Sd plays a direct role in activating the L2 enhancer, we mutated a subset of these Sd binding sites in the context of the EC-lacZ construct, transformed these mutated constructs into flies and stained for lacZ expression in third instar wing discs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	285	 We found that mutation of the doublet at 271 in combination with the two single sites at 570 and 640 resulted in a complete loss of lacZ expression in the wing disc (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	286	 These results indicate that Sd is required for activation of kni expression in the wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	287	kniri[1] mutants can be rescued by kni, knrl or the downstream target gene rho Having shown that the minimal L2 enhancer is mutated in several independently derived ri alleles (kniri[1], kniri[M3], and kniri[53j]), we wished to know whether driving expression of either the kni or knrl genes with this element could rescue the ri vein-loss phenotype.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	288	 We addressed this question using the conditional GAL4/UAS expression system of Brand and Perrimon (Brand and Perrimon, 1993).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	289	 We created transgenic flies that carry fragment E driving GAL4 expression (L2-GAL4) and used this driver to activate expression of UAS-kni or UAS-knrl transgenes in the L2 primordium of kniri[1] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	290	 As expected, GAL4 RNA is expressed in the L2 primordium of L2-GAL4 wing discs (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	291	 We placed this L2-GAL4 driver and the UAS-kni and UAS-knrl transgenes into the kniri[1] mutant background and generated flies of the genotype L2-GAL4 > UAS-kni; kniri[1]/kniri[1] (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	292	 4B) and L2-GAL4 > UAS-knrl; kniri[1]/kniri[1] (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	293	 These flies have fully restored L2 veins that resemble wild-type L2 veins in that the bulk of the vein is formed on the ventral surface of the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	294	View larger version (64K):    Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Rescue of L2 in kniri[1] by targeted gene expression in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	296	 (A) GAL4 expression in an L2-GAL4 mid-third instar larval wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	297	 (B) Rescue of the L2 vein (arrow) in an L2-GAL4 > UAS-kni; kniri[1] male adult wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	298	 (C) Rescue of the L2 vein in an L2-GAL4 > UAS-knrl; kniri[1] male adult wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	299	 (D) Rescue of the L2 vein in an L2-GAL4 > UAS-rho; kniri[1] male adult wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	300	Since rho is known to play a critical role in activating Egfr signaling in all vein primordia, we also determined whether expression of this downstream effector of the kni locus could bypass the requirement for kni in kniri[1] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	301	 We found that L2 formation is indeed rescued in L2-GAL4 > UAS-rho; kniri[1]/kniri[1] flies (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	302	 As in the case of rescue by kni or knrl, the rescued L2 vein forms primarily on the ventral surface of the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	303	Misexpression of genes expressed in veins other than L2 alters L2 development As mentioned above (see Introduction), several genes that are important for vein development are expressed in veins other than L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	304	 For example, the vein- and sensory organ-promoting gene ara is expressed in the odd numbered veins (L1, L3, and L5), the proneural genes ac and sc are expressed in L1 and L3, and the Notch ligand Delta is expressed in L1 and L3-L5, but not in L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	305	 We were interested to know whether it is necessary to exclude expression of these genes from the L2 primordium for normal L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	306	 To address this question, we misexpressed UAS-transgene copies of these genes in the L2 primordium with the L2-GAL4 driver and examined the L2 vein in adult wings.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	307	 In each case, we observed defects in L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Misexpression of the lateral inhibitory signal Delta in L2-GAL4 > UAS-Dl flies results in modest truncation of the L2 vein in females (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	309	 5A) and almost entirely eliminates the L2 vein in sibling males (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	310	 5B), which are the consistently more severely affected sex.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	311	 The near elimination of L2 development in severely affected Dl-misexpressing males is accompanied by a loss of rho expression in the L2 primordium of third instar larval wing discs (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	312	 5D), compare with wild-type rho expression in Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Misexpression of the proneural gene sc in the L2 primordium of L2-GAL4 > UAS-sc flies results in L2 veins covered with ectopic bristles (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	314	 The great majority of these ectopic bristles are strictly confined to the L2 primordium, consistent with the double label experiments (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	315	 2C) indicating that the L2-enhancer element drives gene expression precisely in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	316	 In addition, ectopic bristles form sporadically in a broad posterior domain of the wing, which derives from a region of the wing disc in which the L2 enhancer element is also expressed in a weak diffuse pattern (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Finally, misexpression of the ara gene in L2-GAL4 > UAS-ara flies causes a reproducible thinning of the L2 vein (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Cumulatively, these results underscore the importance of excluding expression of non-L2 vein genes from the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	319	View larger version (93K):    Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Misexpression of non-L2 vein genes in the L2 primordium alters L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	321	 (A) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-Dl adult female wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	322	 The distal tip of the L2 vein is typically missing (arrow).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	323	 (B) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-Dl adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	324	 The L2 vein is consistently truncated to this severe extent.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	325	 (C) rho expression in a wild type mid third larval instar disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Vein primordia L2-L5 and the margin are indicated.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	327	 (D) rho expression in a 2X L2-GAL4 > UAS-Dl mid-third instar larval wing disc is lost selectively in the L2 primordium (arrow).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	328	 (E) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-sc adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Ectopic bristles are largely confined to the L2 vein as well as to a broad posterior domain, which presumably corresponds to cells in L2-GAL4 wing discs expressing high (L2) or moderate (posterior domain) levels of GAL4 (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	330	 (F) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-ara adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Note that the width of the L2 vein is reduced in the middle (arrowhead).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	332	 This thinning of L2 by misexpression of ara is a consistent phenotype that we have not observed when we misexpress the related gene caup in the same pattern (not shown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	333	The L2-GAL4 driver can be used as a tool to dissect gene function and range of action As discussed above, the L2-GAL4 driver activates UAS transgene expression precisely in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	334	 The ability to drive highly localized expression of genes in a non-essential tissue with L2-GAL4 suggests that this driver could be used as an effective tool to dissect the function and range of action of various genes.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	335	 For example, since the eagle (eg) gene encodes a steroid hormone receptor closely related to Kni and Knrl (Rothe et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	336	, 1989) we wondered whether this gene could substitute for kni or knrl in rescuing kniri[1] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	337	 eg is involved in neuroblast specification during embryogenesis (Higashijima et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	338	, 1997; Lundell and Hirsh, 1998), but is not expressed in the wing pouch (data not shown) and is not known to play a role in development of the wing proper.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	339	 We found that, as in L2-GAL4 > UAS-kni; kniri[1]/kniri[1] individuals, L2 formation is rescued in L2-GAL4 > UAS-eg; kniri[1]/kniri[XT2] flies, however, this restored `L2' vein is decorated with a line of ectopic sensory bristles (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	340	 As the same ectopic bristles are observed in L2-GAL4 > UAS-eg individuals (data not shown), this phenotype can be attributed to misexpressing eg in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	341	 By employing the L2 expression system it should now be possible to map the domain in Eg that is responsible for inducing ectopic bristles using chimeric Eg/Kni receptors.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	342	View larger version (106K):    Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	343	 Use of the L2-GAL4 expression system to assay gene function in the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	344	 (A) Rescue of the L2 vein in an L2-GAL4 > UAS-eg; kniri[1]/kniri[XT2] male adult wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Note the ectopic sensory bristles along the reinstated L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	346	 (B) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-top adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	347	 (C) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-vein adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Note the minor degree of ectopic venation (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	349	 anterior to L2 and at the junction of L2 with the margin).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	350	 (D) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-secreted-spitz adult female wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Note the ectopic vein running parallel and anterior to L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	352	 (E) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-rho+UAS-Star wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Note patches of ectopic vein material anterior to L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	354	 (F) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-wingless adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Note change in shape of the margin, ectopic vein material both anterior and posterior to L2 and ectopic bristles near the junction of L2 with the margin (magnified in insert).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	356	The L2 expression system should also be useful in distinguishing cell-autonomous from non cell-autonomous gene activity.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	357	 As a test of this idea we compared the phenotypes resulting from driving expression of an activated form of the Egfr (top) in the L2 primordium versus expression of the secreted Egf-like ligands Vein (Schnepp et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	358	, 1996) and sSpitz (Schweitzer et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Consistent with top acting in a cell autonomous fashion to promote vein versus intervein development, expression of this gene in the L2 primordium of L2-GAL4 > UAS-top wings (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	360	 6B) had no effect on the development of the L2 vein or neighboring intervein cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	361	 In contrast, when secreted Egf ligands were expressed in a similar fashion in L2-GAL4 > UAS-vn wings (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	362	 6C) or in L2-GAL4 > UAS-sspi wings (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	363	 6D), we observed ectopic veins that formed 2-3 cell diameters away from the L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Similarly, when we co-expressed rho and Star in the L2 primordium (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	365	 in L2-GAL4 > UAS-rho; UAS-Star wings; Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	366	 6E), which also generates a potent secreted Egfr promoting activity (Guichard et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	367	, 1999), we observed ectopic veins that were displaced from the endogenous L2 vein by a few cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	368	 The ability of secreted ligands, but not the top construct, to induce ectopic vein formation at a distance cannot be attributed simply to the latter being a weaker activator of Egfr signaling since UAS-top is considerably more effective at generating ectopic veins than UAS-vn when other wing-GAL4 drivers are used (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	369	 MS1096-GAL4 or CY2-GAL4, data not shown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	370	We also observed a non cell-autonomous activity of the Wingless (Wg) ligand in L2-GAL4 > UAS-wg wings (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	371	 6F), which had ectopic veins displaced from the endogenous L2 as well as ectopic marginal bristles near the intersection of L2 with the margin.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	372	 These ectopic marginal bristles always formed on the appropriate surface of the wing (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	373	 6F, insert), suggesting that this phenotype may result from the inappropriate activation of the wing margin genetic program.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	374	   DISCUSSION TOP SUMMARY INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   An important step in understanding the link between patterning and morphogenesis is to identify key cis-regulatory elements that lie at the interface of these sequential processes.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Formation of the L2 vein provides a potential paradigm for connecting patterning initiated by a morphogen (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	376	 a centrally positioned BMP activity gradient) to the activation of a vein differentiation program in a narrow stripe of cells in the wing imaginal disc (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	377	 In this study we have identified a cis-acting regulatory element that drives expression of the kni locus in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	378	 We found that three distinct mutations causing L2 vein truncations alter this regulatory element and that in at least two of these cases the mutations disrupt the function of the enhancer.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Dissection of this enhancer element indicates that a locally provided activating signal acts in conjunction with broadly distributed activating (sd dependent) and repressive systems to limit activation of the L2 enhancer to a sharp stripe of cells in the wing imaginal disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	380	 We also found that excluding expression of non L2 vein genes from the L2 primordium is essential for normal L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	381	ri mutants are L2-enhancer specific regulatory alleles of the kni locus The results described in this study demonstrate definitively that ri mutations are regulatory alleles of the kni locus disrupting the function of a cis-regulatory enhancer element that drives gene expression in the L2 primordium of wing imaginal discs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	382	 A crucial line of evidence supporting this conclusion is that mutant versions of the L2 enhancer incorporating either the 252 bp deletion present in kniri[1] or the single base pair substitution present in kniri[53j] eliminate the ability of this element to direct gene expression in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	383	 In addition, it is possible to completely rescue the vein-loss phenotype of kniri[1] by expressing either the UAS-kni or UAS-knrl transgenes with an L2-GAL4 driver.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	384	 Consistent with activation of rho being one of the key effectors of kni/knrl function, it is also possible to rescue the L2 vein-loss phenotype of kniri[1] by expressing a UAS-rho transgene in L2, although rescue is less complete and penetrant than that observed with UAS-kni or UAS-knrl.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	385	The isolation of the L2 enhancer also addresses an unresolved question regarding the basis for the failure of Df(3L)kniri[XT2] and Df(3L)kniFC82 to complement (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	386	 As these two deletions have endpoints that break within the same 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	387	7 kb EcoRI fragment (indicated by the dashed vertical lines in Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	388	 1E), one explanation for the failure of complementation could be that this 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	389	7 kb fragment contains the L2 enhancer.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	390	 The alternative explanation for the ri phenotype of Df(3L)kniri[XT2]/Df(3L)kniFC82 is that transvection (Lewis, 1954; Geyer et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	391	, 1990; Pirrotta, 1999), which normally occurs between regulatory and coding region alleles of the kni locus (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	392	, 1998), is interrupted by the large divergent deletions that have little if any overlap.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	393	8 EcoRI fragment containing the L2 enhancer maps nearly 10 kb upstream of the 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	394	7 kb EcoRI fragment, and a lacZ fusion construct (abd-lacZ, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	395	7 kb EcoRI fragment does not drive any gene expression in the wing disc (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	396	, 1998), the latter hypothesis that Df(3L)kniri[XT2] and Df(3L)kniFC82 are unable to engage in effective transvection is the most likely explanation for the failure of these two mutations to complement.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	397	Global activation, regional repression and localized induction restrict L2-enhancer activity to a narrow stripe of cells The results of these and previous studies of L2 vein initiation lead to a model in which localized vein inductive signaling acts against a background of regional repression and global wing-specific activation (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Previous genetic experiments have suggested a model in which sal-expressing cells produce a short-range L2 inducing signal (X) to which sal-expressing cells themselves cannot respond (Sturtevant et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	399	 According to this `for export only' signaling model, the signal X diffuses into adjacent anterior cells and activates expression of the kni/knrl genes in the L2 primordium, in much the same fashion as Hh, expressed from the refractory posterior compartment, activates expression of target genes such as dpp or ptc in the anterior compartment (reviewed by Bier, 2000).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	400	 Based on the analysis of the L2 enhancer element described in this study, the 252 bp region deleted in kniri[1] mutants may contain response element(s) to this putative factor X.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	401	 It is worth noting, however, that lacZ expression is lost in all cells of the wing disc (posterior and circumferential cells as well as the L2 primordium) when these sequences are deleted from the 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	402	 This observation suggests that sequences mediating more general activation (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Sd binding sites, see below) may also be contained within this 252 bp region.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	404	 The sequence surrounding the single nucleotide alteration in kniri[53j] mutants (C596A), however, is a particularly intriguing candidate for mediating the L2-specific activation of kni since introducing this mutation in the context of the minimal 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	405	4 kb enhancer leads to selective loss of lacZ expression only in the stripe of cells adjacent to the sal domain.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	406	The hypothetical transcription factor X' (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	407	 7B) that binds to the region surrounding the kniri[53j] point mutation and mediates the inductive signal X presumably collaborates with the more generally required wing selector Sd (Halder et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	408	, 2001), since mutation of four of the Sd binding sites (the doublet and two single sites) in the L2 activation domain completely eliminates enhancer activity in the wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	409	 Clonal analysis with a hypomorphic sd allele also indicates that sd is required for high-level expression of the full 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	410	8 kb L2 enhancer element in the wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	411	 It is notable that the reduction in lacZ expression in these clones is not as dramatic as the complete loss of L2 activity observed when Sd binding sites in the activation domain are mutated.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	412	 There are several possible explanations for this discrepancy.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	413	 Firstly, the sd mutation used in these experiments is a hypomorphic allele and therefore has residual activity.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	414	 Unfortunately, stronger sd alleles produce even smaller viable clones in the wing disc and thus were not used.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	415	 Secondly, as only small clones can be generated, they must typically have been produced with only two or three intervening cycles of cell division.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	416	 Consequently, the sd  cells may still contain functional levels of wild type Sd (protein perdurance).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	417	 Another possibility is that other activators can partially substitute for Sd, at least in certain regions of the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	418	 Based on the absence of L2 activity when Sd binding sites are mutated and the reduction in L2 activity in sd  hypomorphic clones, we conclude that Sd plays an important role as an activator of the L2 enhancer.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	419	 These results support the view that Sd functions as a general transcriptional activator of genes expressed in the wing field.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	420	Repression also plays a key role in restricting L2 enhancer expression to a narrow stripe of wing disc cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	421	 It has been shown previously that salm and salr, which are expressed strongly in the central region of the wing, repress expression of kni and knrl (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	422	, 1998), although low levels of sal may also be required to activate kni expression (de Celis and Barrio, 2000).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	423	 In the current study we also find evidence for repression of L2-enhancer activity in peripheral wing disc cells abutting those expressing high levels of sal.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	424	4 kb (fragment EX) L2 enhancer element results in reporter gene expression expanding to fill the anterior and posterior regions of the wing pouch in a pattern complementary to that of sal.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	425	 The region deleted from the EX fragment contains several consensus binding sites for Brinker (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	426	, 2001), which may mediate this repression since the pattern of brinker (brk) expression in the wing pouch (Campbell and Tomlinson, 1999; Jazwinska et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	427	, 1999) is very similar to that of lacZ expression driven by the 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	428	 One way to integrate the action of the localized inductive signal XX' pathway with that of abutting central and peripheral repressive factors is to propose that the signal-dependent activator X' can overcome the repressive action of the peripheral inhibitor but not repression by Salm/Salr (see legend to Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	429	 One feature common to several prominent signaling pathways is that activation of the pathway converts a resting repressor into a transcriptional activator (Barolo and Posakony, 2002).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	430	 In the kni L2 enhancer, activation of the hypothetical signal X pathway may relieve repression by a heterologous repressor since the putative activator (i.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	431	 Brk?) sequences in the L2 enhancer are separable.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	432	 One example of a signaling pathway that functions by relieving inhibition by a heterologous repressor is the recent report of Egfr signaling inactivating repression by Suppressor of Hairless (Su(H)) (Tsuda et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	433	 In addition to central and peripheral repression in the wing disc, there may also be a repressor in posterior compartment cells (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	434	 7A,B) to prevent activation of the L2 enhancer in cells posterior to the sal expression domain.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	435	8 kb L2 enhancer element lacks some sites for this putative repressor since E-lacZ drives significantly higher levels of gene expression in the posterior stripe than that observed for endogenous kni or knrl expression.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	436	Expression of non-L2 vein genes must be excluded from the L2 primordium All longitudinal veins share several morphological characteristics such as being composed of densely packed cells on both the dorsal and ventral surfaces of the wing that secrete a thickened cuticle.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	437	 The primordia of all longitudinal veins also express the rhomboid gene, which is required for activating the Egfr pathway in vein but not in intervein cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	438	 In addition to these shared properties, each vein can be distinguished by expression of other vein genes (Biehs et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	439	 For example, vein L2-specific characteristics include: expression of kni and knrl, lack of Delta expression, lack of cauplara expression, and lack of ac/sc expression.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	440	 Given that all veins are ultimately quite similar morphologically, it is relevant to ask whether the differences in gene expression patterns observed in different veins are important.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	441	In this study, we examined the necessity of excluding expression of non-L2 vein genes in the L2 primordium by forcing expression of genes such as Dl, ara, ac and sc in L2 and asking whether this manipulation had any impact on L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	442	 These experiments strongly suggest that exclusion of non-L2 vein genes from the L2 primordium is indeed important since misexpression of each of these genes resulted in abnormal L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	443	 The phenotypes resulting from misexpressing non-L2 vein genes in the L2 primordium can largely be reconciled with the normal functions of these genes.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	444	 For example, forced expression of Dl leads to loss of L2, consistent with suppression of vein formation by Notch signaling.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	445	 The ectopic bristles that form strictly along the L2 vein in wings misexpressing ac or sc are also consistent with the neural promoting function of proneural genes.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	446	 It is less clear why misexpression of the ara gene causes thinning of the L2 primordium, since this gene normally activates expression of the vein-promoting gene rho in odd numbered veins and ac and sc in the L3 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	447	 Perhaps expression of a gene normally involved in development of the odd numbered dorsal veins is somehow incompatible with development of the ventral L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	448	The L2 expression system provides a localized assay for gene function in the wing The sharp stripe of gene expression driven by L2-GAL4 can also be used as a rapid assay to test the function or range of action of various genes in the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	449	 For example, in the case of the Egfr pathway, it is possible to distinguish components exerting cell-autonomous versus non cell-autonomous functions.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	450	 In line with the fact that activation of the Egfr pathway in the wing leads to the formation of veins, L2-GAL4-driven expression of the secreted ligand sSpi generates ectopic veins in the neighborhood of L2 while expression of the equally potent constitutively active top form of the EGF receptor does not result in a non-autonomous phenotype.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	451	 The L2 expression system may also be used to compare the functions of related genes such as the nuclear receptors Kni, Knrl, and Eg.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	452	 Although these three transcription factors share nearly identical DNA binding domains and can all rescue the vein-loss phenotype of ri mutants, they differ in that misexpression of eg in the L2 primordium induces the formation of ectopic bristles along L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	453	 This distinct activity of eg may relate to its normal embryonic function in directing cell fate choices in the CNS.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	454	 Using the L2 expression system as an assay, it should be straightforward to map the domain in eg that is responsible for its neural inducing capacity by constructing chimeric molecules composed of different domains of Eg and Kni.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	455	 Finally, the observation that L2-driven expression of Dl leads to a highly penetrant loss of L2 in males and a consistently weaker phenotype in females provides the basis for a modifier screen to identify mutations that either suppress the phenotype in males or enhance the phenotype in females.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	456	 Some of the modifier loci identified in such a screen, which are not specifically involved in Notch signaling, may encode components of the hypothesized factor XX' pathway.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	457	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Orna Cook and Margaret Roark for critical comments on the manuscript, and Dan Ang for help with preparing figures.
