0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	367	 73, 4110-4119[Abstract/Free Full Text] Zhou, Z.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	368	 73, 3210-3218[Abstract/Free Full Text] Zhou, Z.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	369	 2, 1026-1030[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Chen, D.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	370	 75, 11863-11867[Abstract/Free Full Text] Bowman, B.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	371	 22, 757-765[Abstract/Free Full Text] Desai, P.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	372	 (1998) Virology 247, 115-124[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Farnsworth, A.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	373	 77, 481-8494[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Kramer, M.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	374	 72, 1177-1185[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	0	Microtubule-mediated Transport of Incoming Herpes Simplex Virus 1 Capsids to the Nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	1	Yale University School of Medicine, Department of Cell Biology, New Haven, Connecticut 06520-8002 Abstract Materials and Methods Results Discussion Footnotes Abbreviations used in this paper References.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	2	Herpes simplex virus 1 fuses with the plasma membrane of a host cell, and the incoming capsids are efficiently and rapidly transported across the cytosol to the nuclear pore complexes, where the viral DNA genomes are released into the nucleoplasm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Using biochemical assays, immunofluorescence, and immunoelectron microscopy in the presence and absence of microtubule depolymerizing agents, it was shown that the cytosolic capsid transport in Vero cells was mediated by microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Antibody labeling revealed the attachment of dynein, a minus end-directed, microtubule-dependent motor, to the viral capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We propose that the incoming capsids bind to microtubules and use dynein to propel them from the cell periphery to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	6	The entry of animal viruses into their host cells involves adsorption to cell surface receptors, penetration into the cytosol, and uncoating of the viral genome.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	7	 For viruses that replicate in the nucleus, entry also entails extensive movement of viruses and viral capsids through the cytoplasm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Transport over long distances is particularly critical for viruses that infect neurons in which the site of entry can be located far from the cell body and the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	9	Since movement of virus-sized particles through the cytosol is not likely to occur by free diffusion due to high viscosity and steric obstacles (Bray, 1992; Luby-Phelps, 1994), viruses most likely exploit the cell's motile functions for transport.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The limited information available suggests that viruses can make use of both microtubules (MT)1 and actin filaments.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	11	 EM analysis has shown MT binding of certain viral capsids, such as adenovirus and reovirus in vivo and in vitro (for review see Luftig, 1982) as well as herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) in neurons (Lycke et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Way and co-workers have described actin filament-dependent intra- and intercellular transport of vaccinia virus during egress from cells (Cudmore et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Moreover, many viruses take advantage of the retrograde movement of endocytic organelles during entry.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	14	 They are internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis and carried within coated vesicles and endosomes from the cell periphery toward the perinuclear area of the cell (see Greber et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	15	, 1994; Marsh and Helenius, 1989).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	16	In this study we have focused on the intracytosolic transport of incoming HSV-1 capsids in Vero cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	17	 HSV-1 has three structural components: capsid, tegument, and envelope.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The capsid consists of the viral DNA of 152 kbp and a proteinaceous shell comprising six different proteins; it has a diameter of 125 nm, and the proteins are arranged in an icosahedron formed by 12 pentons and 150 hexons (Booy et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 1974; Spear and Roizman, 1972).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	20	 VP5 constitutes the major protein component of both hexons and pentons (Newcomb et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The tegument is a protein layer between the envelope and the capsid and contains ~12 different viral polypeptides (Roizman and Furlong, 1974; Roizman and Sears, 1996).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	22	 While the functions of most of these remain to be identified, one is a protein kinase (LeMaster and Roizman, 1980), one induces shut off of host cell protein synthesis (Read and Frenkel, 1983), and some are known to be activators and modulators of viral gene expression (Batterson and Roizman, 1983; Campbell et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The viral envelope contains at least 12 different membrane proteins, some of which are involved in receptor binding and fusion.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	24	The infectious cycle begins with virus binding to heparan sulfate receptors on the cell surface followed by glycoprotein-mediated fusion of the envelope with the plasma membrane (for review see Spear, 1993).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	25	 After release into the cytosol and dissociation from some of the tegument components, the capsids move through the cytosol to the nucleus and bind to nuclear pores (Batterson et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	26	, 1988), whereafter the genome is released into the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Transcription, replication of viral DNA, and assembly of progeny capsids take place within the host nucleus (for review see Roizman and Sears, 1996; Steven and Spear, 1996).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The synthesis of early viral proteins peaks after 4-6 h of virus entry, and the first progeny viruses are produced after 8 h (Honess and Roizman, 1973).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	29	We analyzed the transport of incoming HSV-1 capsids to the nucleus in fibroblasts and found that it occurs rapidly and efficiently by an MT-mediated mechanism.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The incoming capsids shed most of the associated tegument proteins and bind dynein, an MT-dependent, minus end- directed motor in the peripheral cytosol, whereafter they are transported along MT toward the cell center.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The viral capsids thus make use of the machinery responsible for retrograde organelle transport in animal cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	32	Materials and Methods Cells and Antibodies.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	33	BHK-21 cells were grown in Glasgow's MEM with 5% FCS and 10% tryptose phosphate broth, and Vero cells were grown in MEM with 7.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	34	5% FCS and nonessential amino acids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Both media contained 100 U/ml penicillin, 100  microg/ml streptomycin, and 2 mM glutamine.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	36	 All tissue-culture reagents were obtained from GIBCO BRL (Gaithersburg, MD).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Both cell lines were maintained as adherent cultures in a 5% CO2 humid incubator at 37 degrees C and passaged twice a week.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	38	 We used rabbit polyclonal antibodies against VP-5 (NC-1), VP-19c (NC-2), DNA-containing capsids (anti-HC), empty capsids (anti-LC; all provided by Roselyn Eisenberg and Gary Cohen, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia), and a mouse mAb 8F5 against VP5 (provided by William Newcomb and Jay Brown, University of Virginia, Charlottesville).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	39	 All rabbit polyclonal antibodies to viral proteins were preadsorbed against paraformaldehyde (PFA)-fixed, Triton X-100 (TX-100)-permeabilized Vero cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	40	 They were used at the highest possible concentration, giving no signal in noninfected cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	41	 An mAb against ICP4, an early herpes protein, was obtained from Advanced Biotechnologies, Inc.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	42	 We used a mouse monoclonal anti-tubulin (1A2; provided by Dr.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Thomas Kreis, University of Geneva, Switzerland; Kreis, 1987), a rabbit antipeptide anti-calnexin (Hammond and Helenius, 1994), and a rabbit polyclonal, affinity-purified antibody directed against a bacterially expressed fragment of dynein heavy chain (provided by Dr.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Eugeni Vaisberg, University of Colorado at Boulder; Vaisberg et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Fluorescently labeled secondary antibodies (Texas red- or fluorescein-conjugated goat anti-rabbit or goat anti-mouse) were obtained from Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories (West Grove, PA), and rabbit anti-mouse was obtained from Organon Teknika-Cappel (Durham, NC).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	46	 HSV-1, (strain F), designated passage 1, was obtained from American Type Culture Collection (Rockville, MD).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	47	 BHK-21 cells grown to confluency at 37 degrees C for 3 d were infected with an 8 ml/175 cm2 flask of MEM containing 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	48	01 plaque-forming units (PFU) per cell.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	49	 After 2 h, 25 ml per flask of normal medium was added to the cells, and after 3 d, the medium containing secreted extracellular virus was collected.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	50	 All the following steps were performed at 4 degrees C.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Cells and debris were removed by spinning at 2,000 rpm for 10 min, and the virus was collected by centrifugation from the medium using a JA-14 rotor (Beckman Instruments, Inc.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Palo Alto, CA) at 12,000 rpm for 90 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The resulting pellets were resuspended by gentle shaking overnight in MNT buffer (30 mM MES, 100 mM NaCl, 20 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	54	 After waterbath sonification (4 degrees C; three times for 30 s each), the suspension derived from 30 flasks was layered on top of one linear 10-40% (wt/vol) sucrose gradient in MNT buffer and centrifuged in a Beckman SW28 at 15,000 rpm for 45 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The virus-containing band in the middle of the gradient was detected by light scattering, collected (~3 ml per gradient), aliquoted, snap frozen in liquid nitrogen, and stored at 80 degrees C.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	56	 All experiments described here were carried out with gradient-purified virus from passage three.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Virus was diluted in 10-fold steps into MEM with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	58	2% BSA and incubated in 24-well dishes with just confluent Vero cells for 1-2 h at 37 degrees C in a humidified 5% CO2 incubator.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Unbound virus was removed by three washes in MEM-BSA, and the cells were further incubated in normal medium for 30 h.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Plaques were counted using a dissecting microscope after fixation in absolute methanol (20 degrees C) and Giemsa staining.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Titers of 109-1010 PFU/ml and protein concentrations of 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	62	5-2 mg/ml were obtained using this protocol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	63	Preparation of [3H]Thymidine-labeled virus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	64	 BHK cells grown in an 850cm2 roller bottle to ~70% confluency were infected with a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	65	2% wt/vol) containing 20 mM Hepes, pH 7.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	66	 At 2 h postinfection (PI), the inoculum was removed and normal growth medium containing 5 mCi [methyl-3H]thymidine (Amersham Lifescience, Amersham, UK) was added.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	67	 After 2 d, the cells and the medium were collected and transferred to 4 degrees C, the cells were pelleted by a low speed spin, and the resulting supernatant was spun in a Beckman SW40Ti at 13,700 rpm for 2 h.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The pellet was resuspended by gentle shaking overnight in MNT buffer, layered onto a linear 10-40% (wt/vol) sucrose gradient in MNT buffer, and spun in a Beckman SW40Ti at 15,800 rpm for 1 h.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The gradient was fractionated into 1-ml fractions, and the radioactivity in each fraction was determined by scintillation counting.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The peak fractions were pooled, aliquoted, snap frozen, and stored at 80 degrees C.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	71	 This preparation had a titer of 1  x  107 PFU/ml and contained 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Cells were inoculated with virus for 2 h at 4 degrees C with constant rocking in RPMI medium containing 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	73	2% (wt/vol) BSA, 20 mM Hepes, pH 6.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Viral infection was initiated by shifting the cells to growth medium and 37 degrees C in a humidified 5% CO2 incubator.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	75	 In those experiments analyzing incoming viral particles, 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	76	5 mM cycloheximide was added to the medium to prevent synthesis of new viral proteins and progeny virus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In some experiments, the cells were incubated for 1 h before infection in normal medium containing 2  microM nocodazole, 10  microM vinblastine, 2  microM colchicine, 20  microM taxol, or 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	78	5  microM cytochalasin D and were maintained in these drugs during the infection.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Nocodazole was stored as a stock at 20 mM, vinblastine at 10 mM, colchicine at 20 mM, taxol at 20 mM, and cytochalasin D at 10 mM, all in DMSO and at 20 degrees C.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	80	Vero cells grown on culture dishes or glass coverslips (for flat embedding) for 1 d to just confluency were infected with HSV-1 at an MOI of 500 PFU per cell (or 150 PFU/cell for the nocodazole experiment) in the presence of cycloheximide.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The virus was dialyzed before infection against RPMI containing 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	82	2% BSA for 2 h (75 kD cut off) to remove sucrose.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The infected cells were analyzed by three different protocols.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The cells were fixed with 1% glutaraldehyde (GA) in 200 mM cacodylate, pH 7.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	85	4, or with 2% GA in PBS containing 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	86	5 mM CaCl2 and 1 mM MgCl2 for 30 min at room temperature (for MT analysis), treated with 1% OsO4 for 1 h (or 30 min for MT), treated with 2% uranyl acetate in 50 mM maleate buffer, pH 5.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	87	2, for 1 h, dehydrated using a graded ethanol series and propylenoxid, and pelleted before embedding in Epon and cutting, or flat-embedded in Epon and cut parallel to the substrate (for MT).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	88	Flat Embedding of Extracted, Immunolabeled Cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	89	5% Triton X-100 in MT stabilizing buffer (MT buffer: 80 mM Pipes-KOH, pH 6.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	90	8, 5 mM EDTA, 1 mM MgSO4, 10  microM taxol) for 2 min at 37 degrees C (or 4 degrees C for the 0-min time point) before the addition of twofold fixative (2% GA in MT buffer; Baas and Ahmad, 1992).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The cells were fixed for 20 min at room temperature and rinsed with PBS, and remaining fixative was inactivated by three rounds of freshly prepared 2 mg/ml sodium borohydride in PBS, pH 7.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	92	 After blocking with 10% FCS in PBS, the cells were incubated with primary antibody, with secondary rabbit anti-mouse antibody (if the primary was not a rabbit antibody), and with 9 nm protein A-gold (University of Utrecht, The Netherlands), each in 10% FCS in PBS for 30 min at room temperature with extensive washings with PBS in between.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	93	 After a second fixation in 1% GA with 2 mg/ml tannic acid in 100 mM cacodylate buffer, pH 7.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	94	4, for 10 min, the cells were contrasted using 2% OsO4 for 10 min and 2% uranyl acetate in 50 mM maleate buffer, pH 5.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	95	 They were embedded in Epon and ultrathin sections parallel to the substrate were prepared.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	96	 All Epon sections (first and second protocols) were further contrasted using lead citrate and uranyl acetate.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The cells were transferred to 4 degrees C and removed from the culture dish either by proteinase K treatment (25  microg/ml for 2-3 min on ice) and fixed (4% paraformaldehyde and 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	98	4), or fixed first for 20 min and then collected by scraping.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	99	 After pelleting, the cells were fixed further overnight.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The pellets were infiltrated with 20% (wt/vol) polyvinyl pyrolidone and 2.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	101	0 M sucrose in PBS and frozen in liquid nitrogen, and ultrathin sections were cut at 100 degrees  to 120 degrees C and immunolabeled as previously described (Griffiths, 1993a; Sodeik et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	102	 To analyze the efficiency of capsid transport to the nucleus (see Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	103	 5), 25 EM negatives of infected, flat-embedded cells were taken at a magnification of 5,800 in a systematic random fashion for each time point (Griffiths, 1993b).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The negatives were analyzed under a dissecting microscope, and the number and localization of cytosolic capsids was determined.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Capsids within 100 nm of the plasma membrane were scored as being at the plasma membrane, and within 50 nm as being on MT and at the nuclear pore complex.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The remaining capsids were scored as being apparently free in the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Virions present in endosomes were also counted.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	108	 To quantify the effect of nocodazole (see Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	109	 7), 50 negatives of conventionally embedded cells infected in the presence or absence of nocodazole (10  microM) were taken in a systematic random fashion.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Cytosolic capsids were scored as being at the plasma membrane, in the cytosol, or at the nuclear pore complex.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	111	 To quantify the dynein labeling, 25 micrographs of cryosections were taken at a magnification of 16,900.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Since incoming herpes capsids were rare structures, the specimen was systematically translated in a defined direction, and a micrograph was taken every time a cytosolic capsid came into view.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	113	7) and the area of each structure was outlined (virions, capsids, mitochondria, nuclei, and cytoplasm).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	114	 A lattice grid was placed over the prints, and the number of points and gold particles falling into each structure was counted.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The formula G/P*d2 gives the labeling density (gold particles per  microm2), where G is the number of gold particles, P is the number of points of the lattice grid over the structure, and d is the distance between points (Griffiths, 1993b).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Vero cells infected at an MOI of 500 in the presence of CH were fixed at various times postinfection with 2% glutaraldehyde in PBS and embedded in Epon for EM analysis.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	117	 (a) Schematic cross-section perpendicular to the substrate through an adherent Vero cell.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	118	 For quantitation, 25 random electron micrographs obtained from sections cut parallel to the substrate through the basal part of the cells were taken in a systematic fashion for each time point.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	119	 "Basal" is defined as being within 2  microm distance from the substrate (30 sections of ~50-70 nm).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	120	 (b) The total numbers of cytosolic capsids (full and empty), cytosolic empty capsids, and virions in endosomes were determined for each time point.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The number of cytosolic capsids increased rapidly until 1 h postinfection.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	122	 At later time points, less cytosolic capsids were detected, suggesting that they were ultimately disassembled.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	123	 In addition, the subcellular localization of each capsid was determined and the numbers were expressed as a percentage of the total (c-g).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (c) At the earliest time point of 15 min, the majority of cytosolic capsids was localized close to the plasma membrane, from where they disappeared rapidly later.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	125	 (d) Several capsids could not be localized to a particular organelle.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	126	 At 1 h postinfection, there was the highest amount of those capsids, which were apparently free in the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	127	 (e) A significant portion of all cytosolic capsids, namely 10% at 1 h postinfection, colocalized transiently with microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	128	 (f) Capsids began to appear at the nuclear pores at 2 h postinfection, and at 4 h, 60% of all cytosolic capsid had reached the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	129	 (g) The appearance of empty cytosolic capsids coincided with the arrival at the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Only at 4 h postinfection, there was a very small portion of empty, cytosolic capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	131	 N, nucleus; PM, plasma membrane.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	132	 [View Larger Version of this Image (21K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Quantitation of capsid transport and viral protein synthesis in the absence of MTs.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Vero cells were infected at an MOI of 170 in the presence of CH and in the absence or presence of nocodazole to depolymerize microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	135	 They were fixed at 2 (a) or 4 (b) h postinfection with 1% GA and collected by scraping and pelleting, and Epon sections were prepared.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	136	 For quantitation, 50 random electron micrographs were obtained in a systematic fashion for each time point and both treatments.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The subcellular localization of each cytosolic capsid was determined.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	138	 (a) At 2 h postinfection in the presence of microtubules, the majority of cytosolic capsids was localized in the cytosol, and a significant fraction had reached the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	139	 In the absence of microtubules, the majority of capsids remained at the plasma membrane (PM), some were in the cytosol, and none had reached the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	140	 (b) At 4 h,  > 70% of the capsids had reached the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In the presence of nocodazole, a much smaller fraction was transported to the nucleus, and more capsids remained at the plasma membrane and in the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Vero cells were infected at an MOI of 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	143	5 (without CH!) in the absence or presence of 5  microM nocodazole for various times.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The cells were harvested and lysed in 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	145	5% TX-100 in buffer, the nuclei were pelleted, and the supernatants were analyzed by immunoblotting.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	146	 To monitor viral protein synthesis, antibodies to ICP4, an early viral protein, and to VP5, a late viral protein, were used.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Calnexin, a membrane-bound ER protein, was used as a cellular marker protein.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Equal amounts of protein were loaded per lane, and the amount of ICP4 or VP5 was normalized with the amount of calnexin.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	149	 ICP4 synthesis commences at 2 h PI, whereas VP5 is first detectable at 5 h PI.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The amount of ICP4 is maximal after 6 h PI.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In contrast, VP5 synthesis increases during the whole time course of the experiment.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	152	 At all time points, lower amounts of both, ICP4 and VP5, are synthesized in the absence of microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	153	 [View Larger Version of this Image (12K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	154	Quantitation of Virus Binding and Internalization.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	155	We assayed for virus binding and internalization as described previously (Helenius et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	156	 To quantify binding, 6-well dishes containing Vero cells grown for 2 d to just confluency were set on a metal plate on an ice box and washed three times with ice cold RPMI-BSA, and [3H]thymidinelabeled virus was added (1 ml per dish).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	157	 After incubation on ice for various amounts of time and intensive washings, the cells were scraped into 1 ml RPMI-BSA and pelleted, and cell-associated radioactivity was determined by scintillation counting.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The data are expressed as mean values from duplicates.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	159	 To assay for virus internalization, [3H]thymidine-labeled virus was bound to cells at 4 degrees C for 2 h.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The cells were washed to remove unbound virus, and then shifted to normal medium at 37 degrees C and 5% CO2 for various lengths of time.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The cells were transferred back to ice, washed, and stored at 4 degrees C until the last time point.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	162	 All the following treatments were performed at 4 degrees C.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The cells were washed with cold, protein-free PBS and incubated with 1 ml per well proteinase K (2 mg/ml in PBS; Boehringer Mannheim GmbH, Mannheim, Germany).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	164	 After 1 h, 1 ml of PBS containing 1.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	165	25 mM PMSF and 3% (wt/vol) BSA was added to stop further proteolysis.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The cells were collected, the wells were rinsed with wash buffer (PBS containing 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	167	2% BSA), and the cells along with the wash buffer were spun at 1,500 rpm for 10 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The pellet was resuspended and pelleted again; scintillation liquid was added to the resuspended pellet (0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	169	5 ml) and counted in a liquid scintillation counter.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The amount of internalized virus was expressed as cell-associated [3H]thymidine counts (mean value from triplicates).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Control cells, which were not warmed up after virus binding, showed that the proteinase K treatment removed 90-95% of cell-bound virus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	172	Vero cells grown on coverslips for 1-2 d to ~70% confluency were infected with HSV-1 at an MOI of 50 PFU per cell in the presence of cycloheximide.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	173	 In one protocol, cells were fixed with 3% (wt/vol) paraformaldehyde for 20 min followed by quenching remaining fixative using 50 mM NH4Cl for 10 min and permeabilization with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Here, all incubations were carried out in PBS, pH 7.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	175	 In an alternative protocol, the cells were preextracted with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	176	5% TX100 for 10 s at 37 degrees C in an MT stabilizing buffer (80 mM Pipes, 2 mM MgSO4, pH 6.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	177	8, 10  microM taxol), and then fixed in 100% methanol at 20 degrees C for 4 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Before immunolabeling at room temperature, the cells from both protocols were washed again in PBS, transferred to 10% normal goat serum for 30 min, and then labeled with the primary antibody in 10% goat serum for 20 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The coverslips were rinsed three times for 5 min and incubated with fluorescently labeled secondary antibodies in 10% goat serum for 20 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	180	 For double-labeling experiments, the two primary and the two secondary antibodies were applied simultaneously.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	181	 After extensive washing and one short wash in water, the coverslips were mounted in Mowiol containing 2.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	182	5% (wt/vol) 1,4-diazabicyclo-[2.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	183	2]octane on glass slides and examined with an Axiophot fluorescence microscope (Carl Zeiss, Inc.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	184	, Thornwood, NY) or a confocal fluorescence microscope (Bio Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Image processing was performed using Adobe Photoshop (Adobe Systems, Inc.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	186	Assay for Viral Protein Synthesis.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	187	Confluent Vero cells grown in 6-cm tissue-culture dishes were infected with HSV-1 at an MOI of 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	188	5 PFU per cell for 30 min at 37 degrees C and 5% CO2 in MEM containing 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	189	2% (wt/vol) BSA, and then incubated further in normal growth medium.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	190	 At various time points, they were transferred to 4 degrees C, washed three times with ice cold PBS, scraped, pelleted, and resuspended in 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	191	3 ml per dish lysis buffer (MNT with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	192	5% TX-100, 2 mM DTT, 2 mM EDTA, and 10  microg/ml each of chymostatin, leupeptin, antipain, and pepstatin).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The nuclei were removed by centrifugation at 5,000 rpm for 5 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	194	 A 50- microl aliquot of the resulting supernatant was used for protein assays (bicinchoninic assay; Pierce Chemical Co.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	195	2 ml were solubilized in 5  x  Laemmli sample buffer.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Equal amounts of protein were loaded onto a 7.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	197	5% SDS polyacrylamide gel for electrophoresis, and the separated proteins were blotted onto nitrocellulose membranes using a semidry blotter.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	198	 After blocking in 5% lowfat milk in PBS with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	199	1% Tween-20, the membranes were incubated with either anti-NC-1 and calnexin or anti-ICP4 and calnexin, followed by HRP-conjugated anti-rabbit or anti-mouse secondary antibody (Pierce Chemical Co.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The secondary antibodies were visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence detection (Amersham Corp.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	201	) and Kodak film (Eastman Kodak Co.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The bands were quantified by densitometry using a Visage 200 digital gel scanner (Bioimage, Ann Arbor, MI).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The amount of viral protein (ICP4 or VP5) was normalized for the amount of cellular protein (calnexin).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	204	Results Early Events during HSV-1 Entry.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	205	Due to the large size of HSV-1 virions and capsids, early virus cell interactions can be readily visualized by EM (Campadelli-Fiume et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	206	 We followed the incoming capsids at different stages of entry in Vero cells (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The extracellular, surface-bound virus particles had the familiar features of a herpes virus: a membrane envelope with spikes, a capsid with an electron-dense DNA core, and a tegument layer between the capsid and the envelope (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Images of fusion between the viral envelope and the plasma membrane were readily obtained (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	209	 After fusion, the capsids appeared to separate from the bulk of the tegument since an electron-dense mass remained associated with the cytoplasmic surface of the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	210	 1, e and f, arrowheads; see also CampadelliFiume et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Ultrathin Epon sections of Vero cells infected with HSV-1 at an MOI of 500 in the presence of cycloheximide (CH).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	212	 After 2 h of virus binding at 4 degrees C, the cells were either fixed immediately (a and b), or warmed up for 30 (c-f) or 60 min (g and h).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	213	 The main morphological features of the intact virus bound to the plasma membrane (PM) are the viral envelope (b, arrowhead) with the viral spikes (a, arrowhead), the viral capsid (arrow), and the electron-dense viral DNA genome within the capsid.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Upon warming up, the viral envelope fuses with the plasma membrane, and the capsid (arrow) and the tegument proteins are released into the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	215	 (e and f) Release of the capsid.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Preparations, which display a prominent contrast of the tegument, show that the tegument (arrowheads) stays behind at the PM.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	217	 (g and h) Binding to the nuclear pore.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	218	 At later time points, the capsids (arrows) have arrived at the nuclear envelope (NE), where they are exclusively located in close apposition to the nuclear pore complexes.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Occasionally, fibers emanating from the pores (arrowheads) are visible, to which the capsids seem to bind.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Almost all of the capsids at the nuclear pores appear empty and have lost the electron-dense DNA core.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	221	 [View Larger Version of this Image (91K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	222	After 1 h, the first capsids had reached the nucleus and attached themselves to the nuclear pore complexes (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	223	 1, g and h; see also Batterson et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	224	 They seemed to bind to cytsosolic fibers emerging from the pores (see arrowheads in Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Since most of the capsids on the nuclear envelope lacked the electron-dense central mass, DNA release had apparently occurred.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	226	 At later time points, some empty capsids were also seen free in the cytosol without connection to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Occasionally, 1 h postinfection and later, intact and partially degraded virions were also seen in endosomes and lysosomes, indicating that a fraction of the inoculum was taken up by endocytosis.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	228	The rate and efficiency of cell surface binding and subsequent internalization was assayed quantitatively using [3H]thymidine-labeled HSV-1.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	229	 To monitor binding, cells were incubated with labeled virus at an MOI of 10, 50, or 100 at 4 degrees C, and the cell-associated radioactivity was measured at different times.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	230	 As previously reported, a continuous increase in virus binding was observed up to 4 h with no signs of saturation (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	231	 2 a; McClain and Fuller, 1994; Shieh et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	232	 At 2 hthe adsorption period used in all subsequent experiments ~40% of the added virus was bound.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Efficiency and kinetics of HSV-1 binding and internalization.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	234	 (a) Using [3H]thymidine-labeled virus at different multiplicities of infection (MOI), the amount of virus bound to cells at 4 degrees C was quantified after various time points.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	235	 There is no apparent saturation of virus binding to Vero cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	236	 After 2 h, ~40% of the virus added bound.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	237	 (b) Using [3H]thymidine-labeled virus at different MOIs, the amount of virus internalized into cells was quantified after various time points.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	238	 At time 0 min (equals 2 h of virus binding at 4 degrees C), proteinase K treatment removes  > 95% of the virus bound to the plasma membrane.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Upon warming up to 37 degrees C and viral fusion, the virus is protected within the cells from the protease treatment.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	240	 After 30 min, the maximal amount of virus, ~70% of the bound virus, is internalized.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The half-time (t1/2) of internalization is 8 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Depolymerization of microtubules by nocodazole (ND) has no effect on the kinetics and the amount of internalization.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	243	 [View Larger Version of this Image (17K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	244	To follow internalization biochemically, a protease protection assay was used (Helenius et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	245	 After a 2-h binding period in the cold, the cells were warmed up to 37 degrees C for different periods of time to initiate penetration.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Thereafter, they were chilled to 4 degrees C and treated with proteinase K to detach remaining cell surface viruses.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The fraction of virus protected from the protease increased rapidly after warming (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	248	 2 b) with a half-time of internalization of 8 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The overall protease resistance reached a level of 70% within 30 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The efficiency and rate of internalization was identical over a multiplicity range from 3  x  104-10 MOI.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Treatment of the cells with nocodazole, a drug that depolymerizes MT (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	252	 2 b, ND), or with cytochalasin D, which depolymerizes actin filaments (not shown), had no effect, either on the efficiency of binding and internalization or on the kinetics of internalization.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Consistent with previous reports using acid inactivation and plaque assays to assess virus internalization (Huang and Wagner, 1964), these results showed that HSV-1 penetration occurs rapidly and efficiently.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	254	Transport of Capsids from the Plasma Membrane to the Nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	255	Indirect immunofluorescence microscopy was next used to analyze the transport of individual capsids from the cell periphery to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	256	 The antibodies used were either against VP-5 (anti-NC-1) or VP19c (anti-NC-2), the two major capsid proteins, or against purified whole capsids (anti-HC and anti-LC).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	257	 All the antibodies gave similar results and had in common that they stained capsids that were in the cytosol (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	258	 3, 1 h) but not capsids present in surface-bound intact viruses (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Presumably, this useful selectivity was caused by antigen accessibility; the relevant capsid epitopes in the intact virus particles were probably obscured by envelope and/or tegument components.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	260	 In contrast, anti-capsid antibodies labeled viral capsids on thawed cryosections (Sodeik, B.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Helenius, unpublished observations).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Subcellular distribution of incoming HSV-1 capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Conventional immunofluorescence microscopy of Vero cells infected with HSV-1 at an MOI of 50 in the presence of CH.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The cells were fixed in 3% PFA, permeabilized with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	265	1% TX-100, and labeled with anti-HC, an antibody generated against purified capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	266	 After 2 h of virus binding at 4 degrees C (0 h), there is no signal.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	267	 At 1 h PI, numerous cytoplasmic capsids (arrows) distributed within the entire cytoplasm are detectable.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	268	 At 2 h PI, the capsids begin to accumulate at the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	269	 At 4 h PI, most of the capsids decorate the nuclei.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Note that at 1 h, the focus was close to the coverslip, whereas at 2 and 4 h, it was at the nuclear membrane.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	271	 [View Larger Version of this Image (74K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	272	The capsids in the cytoplasm appeared as small, intensely labeled spots (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Using immunoelectron microscopy on thawed ultrathin cryosections, we confirmed that these spots represented single capsids (not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	274	 All the structures labeled in the cytosol or at the nuclear membrane by antibodies directed against the capsid or against VP5 represented single viral capsids (not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The number of fluorescently labeled spots increased continuously during the first hour of warming.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	276	 In addition, their distribution within the cell changed with increasing time: from the cell periphery toward the nucleus where they accumulated at the nuclear rim (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	277	 After 4 h, virtually all the spots were localized at the nuclear membrane (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	278	 3, 4 h) where several hundred capsids could be seen.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Thus, incoming cytosolic capsids were transported efficiently from the periphery to the host nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	280	Double immunofluorescence microscopy using anti-capsid and anti-tubulin antibodies showed that most of the capsids that were not bound to the nucleus were associated with MT (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Moreover, in many cells, capsids were seen to concentrate around the MT organizing center (MTOC) (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The close association of capsids with MT was confirmed by EM (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Numerous cytoplasmic capsids were seen in close proximity to cytoplasmic filaments with the expected 24-nm width and MT-like morphology.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Typically, the distance between the capsid surface and the tubules was ~50 nm, suggesting the presence of additional tethering components.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The viral DNA inside the MT-associated capsids could be seen as a darkly stained material.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Incoming HSV-1 capsids colocalize with MTs.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	287	 (a) Conventional immunofluorescence microscopy.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Vero cells infected at an MOI of 50 in the presence of CH were fixed in methanol at 2 h PI, and double labeled with anti-VP5 (NC-1; FITC anti-rabbit) and antitubulin antibodies (IA2; rhodamine anti-mouse).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The FITC and the rhodamine signals were documented simultaneously using the FITC filter set.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Almost all capsids (arrows) not localized to the nucleus (N) colocalize with microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	291	 (b) Confocal immunofluorescence microscopy.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Vero cells infected at an MOI of 50 in the presence of CH were fixed in methanol 2 h PI, and double labeled with anti-capsid (HC, white) and anti-tubulin antibodies (IA2, gray).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Almost all capsids not localized to the nucleus (N) colocalize with microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Note that in some cells, the viral capsids accumulate at the microtubule-organizing center (MTOC).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	295	 At 1 h postinfection, Vero cells infected at an MOI of 500 in the presence of CH were fixed with 2% glutaraldehyde in PBS.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Epon sections were cut parallel to the substrate.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Numerous incoming viral capsids are localized to microtubules (MT) as identified by their typical morphology, localization, and their 24-nm diameter.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	298	 (f-h) Immunoelectron microscopy.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Vero cells infected at an MOI of 500 in the presence of CH were extracted at 1 h (f) or 4 h PI (g and h) with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	300	5% TX-100 in MT buffer before fixation.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	301	 They were labeled with rabbit anti- tubulin followed by protein A-9 nm gold, and Epon sections were cut parallel to the substrate.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	302	 The cytoskeleton, nucleus, and nuclear pore complexes (NPC), as well as cytoplasmic capsids, were preserved excellently, whereas all membranous organelles were extracted.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The microtubules (MT) are easily identified, since they are heavily decorated with antibody and protein A-gold.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	304	 In rather thick sections (f), the microtubules can be traced over long distances, and many capsids (filled arrows) are localized on them.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	305	 These capsids still contain their electron-dense DNA core.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	306	 At later time points (g and h), most of the capsids have lost their electron-dense core (h, open arrow) and are mostly located in close proximity to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Very often the capsids are bound directly to the outer ring of the nuclear pore complex (g, NPC).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Virions bound to the plasma membrane (h, curved arrowhead) have lost the trilaminar appearance of their membrane, but apparently a lot of glycoprotein and tegument remains attached to them, causing a distinct morphology easily distinguished from cytoplasmic capsids (g).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	309	 [View Larger Version of this Image (135K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	310	The tubules were unambiguously identified as MT by antitubulin labeling of specimen that had been preextracted with TX-100 before fixation.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	311	 After such extraction, thicker sections could be viewed, allowing the analysis of MT over longer distances.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The MT-associated capsids generally contained the viral DNA (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	313	 At later time points, most of the capsids were empty and typically located at the nuclear pores and not at the nuclear envelope membrane (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Most of these capsids did not contain DNA (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	315	 At 4 h postinfection, there were occasionally empty capsids localized on MT in close proximity to the nucleus (not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Whenever extracellular viruses were observed in these TX-100 extracted samples, they were surrounded by very-electron dense material, which probably represented the viral glycoproteins and tegument proteins that were apparently not removed during extraction (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	317	Quantitation of HSV-1 Entry and Capsid Transport.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	318	To quantify the kinetics of the cytosolic capsid transport, we determined the subcellular localization of the incoming virus by EM at various time points postinfection at an MOI of 500 (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	319	 To compare this experiment with the immunofluorescence microscopy, ultrathin sections were cut parallel to the substrate through the basal region of the cells (see Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	320	 For each time point, 25 electron micrographs were taken in a systematic random fashion, and the number and localization of cytosolic capsids was determined.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	321	 5 b) were localized at the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	322	 5 c), in the cytosol without obvious connection to any organelle (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	323	After warming, the total number of cytosolic capsids increased rapidly, reaching a peak after 60 min (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	324	 At later times the number of cytosolic capsids declined, suggesting that the capsids were ultimately disassembled.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	325	 We also scored whether the cytosolic capsids contained the electron-dense viral DNA core or whether they appeared empty (see Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Up to 60 min after internalization, no empty capsids were detected, whereas after 2 h 20% and after 4 h 64% had lost their electron-dense DNA core (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Virions in endosomes peaked at 1 h and sharply declined thereafter.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	328	 They may have been degraded or recycled back to the cell surface, or capsids could have been released by fusion into the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	329	At 15 min postinfection, almost 70% of all cytosolic capsids were localized within 100 nm of the plasma membrane (see Figs.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	330	 All of the capsids close to the plasma membrane contained the viral DNA core.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	331	 At 1 h postinfection, most of the cytosolic capsids (almost 80%) had an intermediate location; they were neither close to the plasma membrane or to the nucleus (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	332	 A significant fraction (10% of all cytosolic capsids) colocalized with MT (see Figs.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Since the capsids (125 nm) are considerably larger than the section thickness (60-70 nm), the figure for colocalization with the MT was most likely an underestimation.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Of the cytosolic capsids, only one capsid (0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	335	9% of all capsids at 4 h postinfection) was seen to colocalize with intermediate filaments (not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	336	Cytosolic capsids arrived at the nucleus at 2 h postinfection, and at 4 h, the majority of cytosolic capsids ( > 60%) was localized to the nucleus (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	337	 At the ealier time points (up to 1 h),  < 4% of the cytosolic capsids were located at the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Of the nuclear capsids, 68% at 2 h and 87% at 4 h were empty, suggesting that DNA release occurred after arrival at the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	339	 The vast majority of empty capsids were localized to the nucleus (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	340	 All capsids at the nucleus were localized to the nuclear pore complexes (see Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	341	In summary, the electron microscopic experiment confirmed the immunofluorescence microscopy data.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	342	 Cytosolic capsids were efficiently transported from the plasma membrane via the cytosol to the nuclear pore complexes.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	343	 During transit, a significant fraction attached to MT.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	344	 Empty capsids appeared soon after their arrival at the nucleus, and some of these were released into the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Ultimately, the capsids seemed to disassemble and disappear because the overall number of cytosolic capsids decreased late in infection.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Interestingly, the appearance of cytosolic capsids under the plasma membrane peaked before the transport of virions into endosomes, strongly suggesting that the early cytosolic capsids were indeed derived from fusion of the virus at the plasma membrane rather than by fusion from endosomes.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	347	Reduced Capsid Transport to the Nucleus without Microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	348	To determine whether efficient capsid transport via the cytosol depended on an intact cytoskeleton, cells were infected at an MOI of 50 for 2 h in the presence of drugs that affect MT or actin filaments.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	349	 Immunofluorescence microscopy showed that neither taxol, a drug that prevents the disassembly of MT (Wilson and Jordan, 1994), nor cytochalasin D, a drug that causes depolymerization of actin filaments (Cooper, 1987), affected capsid transport to the nucleus (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	350	 In contrast, capsid accumulation at the nuclear membrane was significantly reduced by colchicine, vinblastine, and nocodazole (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	351	 These drugs interact with tubulin by different molecular mechanisms (Wilson and Jordan, 1994).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Labeling with anti-tubulin confirmed that colchicine and nocodazole depolymerized MT, whereas vinblastine caused tubulin paracrystal formation (not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	353	 In the presence of these drugs, the majority of capsids remained scattered throughout the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	354	 To test whether the effect of nocodazole was reversible, the cells were analyzed 2 h after drug removal.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	355	 At this time, the MT had repolymerized, and the previously dispersed capsids were concentrated on the nuclear rim (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Reduced transport of capsids to the nucleus in the absence of MTs.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Immunofluorescence microscopy of Vero cells infected with HSV-1 for 2 h at an MOI of 50 in the presence of CH and drugs affecting the cytoskeleton.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	358	 Under control conditions, almost all capsids accumulate around the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	359	 If the cells were infected in the presence of nocodazole, colchicine, or vinblastine, respectively (lower panel), there is no accumulation of viral capsids at the nucleus; instead, the capsids are scattered throughout the entire cytoplasm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	360	 In cells infected in the presence of taxol or cytochalasin D, the capsids accumulate at the nucleus (upper panel).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	361	 The cells were fixed in 3% PFA, permeabilized with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	362	1% TX-100, and labeled with an antibody directed against purified capsids (HC).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	363	 In the presence of nocodazole, the amount of viral capsids localized to the nucleus is drastically reduced, whereas, after a 2-h chase in nocodazole-free medium, the capsids accumulate around the cell nuclei.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Cells were infected in the presence of nocodazole for 2 h, fixed immediately (left panels), or washed and further incubated in normal medium for an additional 2 h before fixation (right panels).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	365	5% TX-100 in MT buffer and fixation in methanol, the cells were double labeled with anti-tubulin (left panels) and anti-capsid (HC, right panels).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	366	 [View Larger Versions of these Images (76 + 86K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	367	Since we were unable to quantify the localization of the fluorescent spots representing cytosolic capsids reliably, we infected Vero cells at an MOI of 150 in the presence or absence of nocodazole and analyzed the embedded cell pellets by quantitative EM.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	368	 For each experimental condition, 50 electron negatives were taken in a systematic, random fashion and the localization of cytosolic capsids was determined (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	369	 After 2 h of infection, 31% of the cytosolic capsids had reached the nucleus, and only 25% were still in close proximity to the plasma membrane.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	370	 In contrast in the absence of MT, none had reached the nucleus, and 58% were still in the region close to the plasma membrane.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	371	 After 4 h postinfection, 75% of all cytosolic capsids had reached the nucleus, 14% were at the plasma membrane, and the remaining 11% were present in the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	372	 In the presence of nocodazole, only 47% of the cytosolic capsids had reached the nucleus, 18% were still at the plasma membrane, and 36% were in the cytosol distant from both the plasma membrane and the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	373	As nocodazole, vinblastine, and colchicine all affect the network of MT (Wilson and Jordan, 1994), we concluded that MT are directly or indirectly involved in the rapid transport of capsids from the cell periphery to the nucleus in Vero cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	374	 In cells devoid of functional MT, the arrival of capsids at the nucleus was significantly delayed.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	375	Viral Infection in the Absence of Microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	376	Whether nocodazole would have an effect on productive infection was determined by monitoring the onset of viral protein synthesis in the presence or absence of the drug.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Cell extracts prepared after different periods of infection were subjected to immunoblotting using antibodies against an early HSV-1 protein, ICP4, and a late structural protein, VP5.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	378	 7 c show that the synthesis of both viral proteins was delayed and reduced in the absence of MT.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Calnexin, an integral membrane protein of the ER (Hammond and Helenius, 1994), was used as a control and remained constant.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	380	 Labeling with [35S]methionine demonstrated that nocodazole had no overall effect on protein synthesis in uninfected or HSV-1-infected Vero cells (not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	381	When immunofluorescence microscopy using ICP4 was performed, we found that, under control conditions, viral protein synthesis commenced in many cells already at 2 h postinfection.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	382	 In contrast, in the presence of nocodazole, only very few cells showed ICP4 labeling.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	383	 At 4 h postinfection, all control cells were strongly labeled for ICP4, whereas in the absence of MT, significantly less cells show strong labeling for ICP4 (data not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	384	 However, at later time points, all cells synthezised ICP4, in the presence and absence of MT.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	385	Thus, depolymerization of MT delayed the onset of viral protein synthesis in cultured fibroblasts, but did not prevent viral infection per se.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	386	Dynein Colocalizes with Incoming Capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	387	Our results strongly suggested that incoming herpes capsids move along MT toward the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	388	 Therefore, we ask whether they would use host MT-dependent motors for their transport.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	389	 Since the antibody against tubulin often obscured the morphology of putative tethering factors located between the viral capsids and the MT (see Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	390	 4), we repeated these experiments without immunolabeling.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Electron-dense material was usually attached to the vertices of the capsids that were associated with MT (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	392	 The morphology of the appendages was variable, but, in some cases (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	393	 8 d, arrow), they had the dimensions and the shape of cytoplasmic dynein, a minus end-directed MT-dependent motor.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	394	 Dynein is a Y-shaped protein complex with a length of ~50 nm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	395	 It is connected to its cargo via the stalk and to MT through two 14-nm globular domains (Gilbert and Sloboda, 1989; Vale, 1990; Vallee et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	396	 Incoming HSV-1 capsids display appendices at their vertices.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	397	 At 1 h PI, Vero cells infected at an MOI of 500 in the presence of CH were extracted with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	398	5% TX-100 in MT buffer for 2 min at 37 degrees C and fixed in 1% GA in MT buffer.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	399	 They were labeled with anti-tubulin followed by protein A-9 nm gold (a) or embedded directly (b-d), and Epon sections were cut parallel to the substrate.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	400	 All viral capsids display some appendages on their outside (arrowheads).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	401	 The appendages are visible at three, four, five, or all six corners visible in a section, which represent the pentons of a viral capsid.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	402	 Some of the appendices have a morphology very similar to purified cytoplasmic dynein (large arrow in d): a large globular stalk with two smaller globular head domains.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	403	 The capsid size is ~100-110 nm; the dynein-like appendices are ~50 nm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	404	 In thick sections of golden color, the appendices are often buried in cytoskeletal material (b and d), whereas in very thin sections of grey color (a and c), they are very prominent.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	405	 The appendices have all kinds of different morphology with varying sizes and electron density, but they are always located at the pentons.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	406	 [View Larger Version of this Image (172K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	407	To test whether cytoplasmic dynein was, indeed, associated with the capsids, we used an affinity-purified antibody directed against the heavy chain of cytoplasmic dynein (Vaisberg et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	408	 Immunoelectron microscopy with the anti-dynein antibody was performed on ultrathin cryosections of in situ fixed cells 1 or 2 h after initiation of virus entry.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	409	 In addition to a low level of labeling of the cytoplasm, dynein was found to be localized on the surface of endosomes (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	410	 9 a), and the Golgi apparatus (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	411	 Very few gold particles were seen over the nucleus and the mitochondrial matrix (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	412	 The mitochondria, which do not contain dynein, served as a background control.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	413	 Compared with the mitochondrial matrix, there was a slightly higher labeling in the nuclei, and the cytoplasm was labeled 2.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	414	3-fold higher than background (Table I).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	415	 Anti-dynein antibodies label incoming viral HSV-1 capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	416	 Thawed cryosections of Vero cells infected for 1 (c) or 2 h (a, b, and d-h) in the presence of CH at an MOI of 500 were labeled with rabbit antibodies followed by protein A-5 nm (a-d, and g) or 10 nm gold (e, g, and h).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	417	 About 5% of the incoming viral capsids (a-f, and h) are labeled by anti-dynein (arrows), an affinity-purified antibody made against a recombinant fragment of dynein heavy.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	418	 Labeled capsids are localized close to the plasma membrane (g, PM), at the nuclear envelope (c and d), or within the cytoplasm without obvious connection to either one (b).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	419	 Note that the capsids within the extracellular virions (f) or within the endosomes (g and h, E) are not labeled.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	420	 Anti-dynein also labels the membranes of mitochondria (a, M), endosomes (h, E), and the Golgi complex (a, G) and diffusely the entire cytoplasm, whereas the mitochondrial matrix (a, b, and d) or the nucleus (d, N) show no labeling for dynein.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	421	 [View Larger Version of this Image (168K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	422	 Quantitation of Dynein Immunolabeling.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	423	In cells containing incoming HSV-1 capsids, dynein was, in addition, found associated with many of the capsids (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	424	 Capsids directly underneath the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	425	 9 g) and within the cytoplasm (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	426	 9 b), as well as capsids in close proximity to the nucleus (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	427	 9, a, c, and d), were labeled with anti-dynein.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	428	 On average, 13% of the cytoplasmic capsids were labeled (Table I).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	429	 Capsids of intact virions, either extracellular (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	430	5% of all capsids present in virions had colloidal gold particles in close proximity (Table I).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	431	 Thus, the labeling density was eightfold higher on cytosolic capsids compared with capsids within virions, ruling out the possibility that the antidynein antibody showed cross-reactivity to capsid proteins.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	432	 Given that the labeling efficiency using this technique does not exceed 10%, e.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	433	, only 10% of the primary antibody present on the sections is detected by protein A-gold (Griffiths, 1993a), these results showed that incoming cytosolic viral capsids associated with cytoplasmic dynein.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	434	HSV-1 causes a range of diseases from benign common cold sores to life-threatening encephalitis.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	435	 It infects epithelial cells of mucocutaneous membranes, and, as other  herpesviridae, it establishes latent infections in sensory ganglia (Whitley and Gnann, 1993).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	436	 It is thought to enter neurons by fusion at the presynaptic membrane, after which the capsid is transported along the axon to the nucleus (Hill et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	437	, 1988; Roizman and Sears, 1989; Topp et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	438	 The efficient infection of neurons and other terminally differentiated cells has made HSV-1 a useful vehicle for gene delivery with potential for gene therapy in the human brain (Glorioso et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	439	The biochemical and morphological assays used in our study showed that HSV-1 entry into Vero cells is both rapid and efficient.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	440	 Over a broad range of multiplicities, we found that ~70% of bound virus penetrated with a half-time of ~8 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	441	 More than 60% of the capsids delivered to the cytosol were transported to the nucleus within 4 h of uptake, and binding to fibers extending from the nuclear pore complexes seemed to occur.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	442	 The ratio of particles to plaque-forming units for HSV-1 is between 10 and 50 (Frenkel et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	443	, 1992; Smith, 1964; Watson et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	444	 Thus, if cells were infected at an MOI of 50, and 40% of these bound, the number of particles entering the cells was 140-700 according to the proteinase K assay.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	445	 We determined that 60% of the internalized virus, namely 80-420 particles, uncoat their viral genome within 4 h postinfection as measured by a DNase protection assay (Ojala, P.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	446	 Helenius, manuscript in preparation).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	447	A majority of the capsids remained associated with nuclear pores after releasing their DNA (see also Batterson et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	448	 The apparent transient stability of the empty capsids contrasts with adenovirus, another virus that delivers its DNA to the nucleus through the nuclear pore complexes, for which no empty capsids could be detected at the nuclear pore complexes (Greber et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	449	 We cannot formally rule out that, even though the herpes capsids appeared empty at the nuclear membrane, viral DNA release had not been completed yet.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	450	Our results demonstrate that MT are involved in capsid transport from the cell surface to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	451	 Since the distance from the plasma membrane to the nucleus in Vero cells is not as large as in neurons, MT-assisted transport was not essential for infection, but it accelerated both the transfer of the capsids to the nucleus and the onset of viral protein synthesis.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	452	 Having first detached from most of the tegument proteins at the plasma membrane, the capsids moved in minus end direction along MT to the MTOC.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	453	 From there, they were transferred to the nuclear pores by unknown mechanisms.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	454	 At early times (1-2 h PI), the majority of the capsids associated with the nuclear membrane proximal to the MTOC, but later the distribution became more homogenous around the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	455	Nocodazole and colchicine, which both depolymerize MT, and vinblastine, which causes MT paracrystal formation, reduced capsid accumulation at the nuclear envelope.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	456	 These drugs were also reported to reduce the amount of infectious HSV-1 recovered from rat dorsal root ganglia infected in vitro (Kristensson et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	457	, 1986) and from the trigeminal ganglia after inoculation of the murine cornea (Topp et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	458	 We think that it is very likely that capsids derived from virions bound to the "apical" plasma membrane in our system (see Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	459	 5 a) reached the nucleus independent of MT, since the distance between the apical plasma membrane and the nuclear membrane is only ~200-300 nm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	460	 Thus, the larger the distance between the plasma membrane where the virion had bound and the nucleus, the more the transport to the nucleus depended on MT.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	461	 In contrast with the results obtained in neurons (Kristensson et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	462	, 1986), taxol, which stabilizes MT, did not reduce the efficiency of capsid transport, suggesting that the dynamic turnover or "treadmilling" of MT was not required for capsid transport in Vero cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	463	 Depolymerization of actin filaments by cytochalasin D had no effect either on HSV-1 internalization or transport to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	464	The presence of dynein heavy chains in the material attached to the cytosolic capsids indicated that the MT-mediated transport was powered by cytoplasmic dynein.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	465	 Cytoplasmic dynein is a multisubunit protein complex of 1,270 kD consisting of two heavy chains, two to three intermediate chains, and a variable number of small subunits (Holzbaur and Vallee, 1994; Schroer, 1994).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	466	 It has a length of ~40-50 nm and a shape reminiscent of the letter Y.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	467	 The two head domains contain the MT binding and ATPase sites, while the base interacts with the cargo (Gilbert and Sloboda, 1989; Vale, 1990; Vallee et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	468	 Dynein is responsible for minus end-directed movement of chromosomes and membrane organelles along MT (Cole and LippincottSchwartz, 1995; Mitchison, 1988).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	469	 Since the plus ends of MT are localized in the periphery of Vero cells close to the plasma membrane and the minus ends are anchored at the perinuclear MTOC, dynein seems a logical choice as a motor for the transport of incoming viral capsids to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	470	 The same applies to the axons of neurons, where the MT have their plus ends toward the synapse, and the minus end anchored at the MTOC in the cell body (Black and Baas, 1989).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	471	 Although some kinesin-like MT minus end-directed motors have been implicated to play a role in mitosis and meiosis, none of them has been demonstrated to be involved in interphase transport processes (Barton and Goldstein, 1996; Hirokawa, 1996).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	472	 Since the MT-mediated transport that is crucial for infection of neurons also operates in cultured fibroblasts, its analysis will be greatly facilitated.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	473	It is believed that dynein attachment to vesicles and kinetochores requires another large multimeric complex, called dynactin, which contains 10 different proteins (Holzbaur and Vallee, 1994; Schroer, 1994; Vallee and Sheetz, 1996).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	474	 So far, receptor molecules for dynein and dynactin have not been identified on any cargo structures, but several studies indicate that the activity of dynein and its binding to cargo may be regulated by phosphorylation (Allen, 1995; Dillman and Pfister, 1994; Lin et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	475	 Whether the binding of dynein to HSV-1 capsids involves dynactin or other cellular components and whether it is regulated by phosphorylation remains unclear at this point.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	476	 The viral protein(s) that serve as dynein receptors also remain to be identified.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	477	 Since the polypeptide composition of the capsids and tegument is known, some potential candidates can, however, be singled out.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	478	 The capsid itself contains six different proteins.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	479	 Of these, only VP5 is known to be located at the pentons (Trus et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	480	, 1992), which were the sites of preferential attachment of proteinaceous material onto cytosolic capsids shown here.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	481	 In addition to the bona fide capsid polypeptides, components derived from the tegument are also likely to be present.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	482	 For example, VP1-2, a 270-kD protein, is particularly tightly associated with the capsids (Roizman and Furlong, 1974) and may constitute part of the material seen attached to the pentons in our electron micrographs.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	483	 Taking advantage of the relative simplicity of the capsids, of existing virus mutants, and of the complete genomic sequence of the virus, work is in progress to identify and to characterize the dynein receptor in HSV-1 capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	484	Received for publication 4 October 1996 and in revised form 13 December 1996.

0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	486	 Victor Stolc is acknowledged for his contribution to the immunofluorescence studies.

0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	488	 Gary Whittaker, Jani Simons, Paivi Ojala, Philippe Pierre, and Urs Greber for many stimulating discussions and critical reading of the manuscript.
