0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	0	 1996 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Lipoyl Domain-based Mechanism for the Integrated Feedback Control of the Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex by Enhancement of Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Kinase Activity (*).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	2	(Received for publication, April 10, 1995; and in revised form, August 18, 1995).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	3	From the  (1)Department of Biochemistry, Kansas State University, Manhattan, Kansas 66506 and the (2)Department of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, University of Sheffield, Sheffield S102UH, United Kingdom ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION FOOTNOTES ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS REFERENCES.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	4	To conserve carbohydrate reserves, the reaction of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) must be down-regulated when the citric acid cycle is provided sufficient acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	5	 PDC activity is reduced primarily through increased phosphorylation of its pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) component due to E1 kinase activity being markedly enhanced by elevated intramitochondrial NADH:NAD and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	6	 A mechanism is evaluated in which enhanced kinase activity is facilitated by the build-up of the reduced and acetylated forms of the lipoyl moieties of the dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2) component through using NADH and acetyl-CoA in the reverse of the downstream reactions of the complex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Using a peptide substrate, kinase activity was stimulated by these products, ruling out the possibility kinase activity is increased due to changes in the reaction state of its substrate, E1 (thiamin pyrophosphate).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Each E2 subunit contains two lipoyl domains, an NH-terminal (L1) and the inward lipoyl domain (L2), which were individually produced in fully lipoylated forms by recombinant techniques.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Although reduction and acetylation of the L1 domain or free lipoamide increased kinase activity, those modifications of the lipoate of the kinase-binding L2 domain gave much greater enhancements of kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The large stimulation of the kinase generated by acetyl-CoA only occurred upon addition of the transacetylase-catalyzing (lipoyl domain-free) inner core portion of E2 plus a reduced lipoate source, affirming that acetylation of this prosthetic group is an essential mechanistic step for acetyl-CoA enhancing kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Similarly, the lesser stimulation of kinase activity by just NADH required a lipoate source, supporting the need for lipoate reduction by E3 catalysis.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	12	Complete enzymatic delipoylation of PDC, the E2-kinase subcomplex, or recombinant L2 abolished the stimulatory effects of NADH and acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Retention of a small portion of PDC lipoates lowered kinase activity but allowed stimulation of this residual kinase activity by these products.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Reintroduction of lipoyl moieties, using lipoyl protein ligase, restored the capacity of the E2 core to support high kinase activity along with stimulation of that activity up to 3-fold by NADH and acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	15	 As suggested by those results, the enhancement of kinase activity is very responsive to reductive acetylation with a half-maximal stimulation achieved with 20% of free L2 acetylated and, from an analysis of previous results, with acetylation of only 3-6 of the 60 L2 domains in intact PDC.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Based on these findings, we suggest that kinase stimulation results from modification of the lipoate of an L2 domain that becomes specifically engaged in binding the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In conclusion, kinase activity is attenuated through a substantial range in response to modest changes in the proportion of oxidized, reduced, and acetylated lipoyl moieties of the L2 domain of E2 produced by fluctuations in the NADH:NAD and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios as translated by the rapid and reversible E3 and E2 reactions.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	18	In mammalian cells, the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) ()controls the oxidative utilization of glucose(1) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Flux through this reaction results in a net depletion of body carbohydrate reserves.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The activity of PDC must be reduced when fatty acids or ketone bodies are being preferentially used to provide 2-carbon units for oxidative energy production by citric acid cycle/oxidative phosphorylation systems, a routine situation in many organs.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Furthermore, under conditions of starvation or diabetes, the activity of PDC is reduced to a minimal level to conserve carbohydrates essential for the brain and other specialized tissues/organs.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	22	 To achieve its critical role in cellular fuel conservation, the PDC reaction is controlled primarily by a highly regulated phosphorylation/dephosphorylation cycle which is carried out by dedicated kinase and phosphatase components.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Phosphorylation of the pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) component inactivates the complex and dephosphorylation reactivates the complex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	24	Shortly after PDC was shown to be regulated by this interconversion (2) , the capacity of fatty acids and ketone bodies to promote inactivation of PDC was demonstrated in intact tissues (3, 4) and in studies with intact mitochondria(5, 6) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Studies with purified complex (7, 8, 9) and isolated mitochondria (10, 11, 12) found that increases of the PDC reaction products promote an increase in the proportion of PDC in the phosphorylated (inactive) state.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	26	 With purified complex, the activity of the kinase is greatly enhanced upon elevation of the NADH:NAD ratio and the acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio along with a reciprocal reduction in phosphatase activity as the NADH:NAD ratio is elevated(7) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	27	Accordingly, the E1a kinase has a crucial role wherein it throttles down PDC activity in response to increases in the mitochondrial acetylation and reduction potentials.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Not only are NADH and acetyl-CoA produced during mitochondrial oxidation of all fuels, they are direct products of the PDC reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	29	 This laboratory presented evidence that this control of kinase activity initially involves these product to substrate ratios being translated by competitive utilization in the downstream reactions of the complex which, in turn, adjusts the fraction of the complex's lipoyl prosthetic groups in the oxidized versus reduced versus acetylated forms(13, 14, 15, 16, 17) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Specifically, our mechanism proposes that kinase down-regulates PDC activity due to NADH reacting in the reverse of the dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3) reaction and acetyl-CoA reacting in the reverse of the dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2) reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Typically a 60-80% enhancement in kinase activity occurs upon lipoate reduction and up to a 3-fold enhancement following lipoate acetylation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The potential for understanding the molecular basis of this control has greatly improved with new insights into the structure of E2 subunits and the unusual nature of the association of the kinase with E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	33	The E2 subunits of mammalian PDC have four domains connected by relatively large (2-3 kDa) and highly mobile linker regions Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Sixty COOH-terminal inner domains (E2) associate to form a dodecahedral inner core which catalyzes the transacetylation reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Each inner domain is connected to 3 globular domains by linker or hinge regions.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The globular domains consist of two 10-kDa lipoyl domains (E2 and E2, or L1 and L2) and an E1-binding domain (E2) located between the inner core and the lipoyl domain region.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	37	Figure 1: Domain structure of the dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2) component and interactions with the kinase and E1 components.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	38	 E2 has four globular domains consisting of an NH-terminal lipoyl domain, L1, an inner lipoyl domain, L2, an E1 binding domain, and a core-forming, transacetylase-catalyzing inner domain at the COOH-terminal end(18, 19, 20) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The kinase binds to the L2 domain by a domain-specific and lipoyl prosthetic group-requiring interaction(26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	40	 E1, an tetramer, binds to the B domain of E2 via its -subunit (18) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	41	The subunits of E1a kinases of PDC and the branched-chain -keto acid dehydrogenase complex are related to procaryotic histidine kinases but not to the extramitochondrial serine and tyrosine kinases of eukaryotes(21, 22, 23) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	42	 PDC kinase binds to the lipoyl domain region of E2 through an association that requires the lipoyl prosthetic group(24, 25, 26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Using lipoylated and delipoylated forms of recombinant L1 and L2 of human PDC-E2(27) , the kinase was shown to bind preferentially to the lipoylated L2 (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The E1a kinase was also shown to interchange rapidly between L2 structures(26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	45	 To account for tight binding and rapid interchange, a dynamic ``hand over hand'' mechanism is proposed in which a dimeric kinase alternates between being bound to one and two L2 domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	46	 This interchange and catalytic function of the kinase exert their combined effects in the limited space at the surface of the complex where the a kinase molecule and many E1 components are tightly bound to the mobile outer domains of E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The capacity of continuously bound kinase to phosphorylate bound E1 components more rapidly than free kinase can phosphorylate free E1 is termed E2-activated kinase function.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	48	The aim of this work is to determine the compulsory components, domains, and catalytic processes involved in kinase stimulation by NADH and acetyl-CoA, and to evaluate the relative capacities of the recombinant L1 and L2 in mediating the stimulation of kinase in the presence or absence of E2-activated kinase function.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	49	 We have found that stimulation occurs with a peptide substrate of the kinase; that a lipoyl source must be available for catalytic reduction by E3 or acetylation by E2; that the L2 lipoyl domain is much more effective in mediating kinase stimulation than the L1 domain; and that the kinase is remarkably sensitive to the level of acetylation of L2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The ``Discussion'' integrates these observations and draws new mechanistic conclusions based on these and previous results.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	51	MaterialsStandard procedures were used to prepare: bovine kidney pyruvate dehydrogenase complex(28) , the E2XK1K2 subcomplex(29) , E1 component, the bilipoyl domain region (E2 fragment) of bovine E2(30) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The inner core of bovine E2, E2, was prepared using trypsin treatment followed by pelleting through a sucrose layer in the presence of 5  microg/ml soybean trypsin inhibitor(31) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The individual lipoyl domains, L1(1-98) and L2(120-233) of human E2 were expressed in Escherichia coli as fully lipoylated structures fused to glutathione S-transferase and purified to homogeneity as fusion protein free domains as described by Liu et al.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Lipoamidase from Enterococcus faecalis was prepared by modification of the procedure of Suzuki and Reed(32) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	55	 coli strain TM202 which contains the expression plasmid pTM70, and purified as described(33) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The E3 component from porcine heart was from Sigma.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Kinase pentadecapeptide substrate, YHGHSMSDPGVSYRT with the sequential sites of phosphorylation designated by S and S, was prepared in the Biotechnology core facility at Kansas State University and shown to give a single symmetric peak in reverse phase HPLC, to have the correct sequence by automated Edman degradation, and correct mass by FAB mass spectrometry.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	58	 [-P]ATP, [1-C]acetyl-CoA, and [2-C]pyruvate were obtained from DuPont NEN.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	59	Kinase ActivityE1a kinase activity was measured in duplicate or triplicate as the initial rate of [P]phosphate incorporation from [-P]ATP (250 to 500 cpm/pmol) into E1a tetramers in PDC or as the resolved E2-free component.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Most assays were conducted in a final volume of 50  microl of buffer A: 50 mM MOPS-K, 20 mM potassium phosphate, 60 mM KCl, 2 mM MgCl, 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Unless otherwise indicated, assays used 25-30  microg of PDC or 25  microg of E1 and 1  microg of E3.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Some resolved E1 preparations have more E1a kinase; here such a preparation was a source of stable, E2-free kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	63	 ()The specific activity of E1-kinase was 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	64	44 nmol/min/mg when assayed in 20 mM potassium phosphate in the absence of E2; this indicates kinase represents about 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	65	4% of the protein in this E1 fraction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Unless otherwise indicated, the levels for the following reactants were: NADH and NAD at 3:1 ratio with final concentrations of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	67	2 mM NAD and acetyl-CoA or pyruvate at 50  microM, L1 or L2 at 16  microM, dihydrolipoamide at 20 to 200  microM, and E2 at 2  microg.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Dihydrolipoamide was dissolved in HO containing 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	69	2 mM EDTA by warming the solution to 60  degrees C; it was critical that the stock solutions (0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	70	0 mM) be maintained at room temperature (i.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	71	 not placed on ice) to retain this ligand in solution.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The latter was monitored with the E3 cycling reaction below.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	73	 ATP was added last except in one experiment in which a concentrated fraction of delipoylated E2XK1K2 subcomplex was treated with ATP and lipoyl protein ligase and the subsequent kinase assays were performed without removal of residual ATP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	74	 In the latter series of assays, including those with parallel samples of untreated and delipoylated subcomplex, E1-kinase was added last to initiate kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	75	 For effective reductive acetylation of E2 lipoyl domains by E1, E1 was preincubated with 50  microM TPP and diluted 10 or 20-fold into kinase assays lacking additional TPP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Kinase (and acetylation) assays conducted with CoA removal were performed using the conditions described under acetylation studies.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	77	 All control assays were conducted in triplicate or quadruplicate and other assays at least in duplicate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	78	 In these and other assays the absolute deviations are shown.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Reactions were terminated by spotting samples to dry trichloroacetic acid-containing Whatmann No.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	80	 3MM with E1 as the substrate or to Whatmann P81 phosphocellulose paper disks with the peptide substrate, followed by steps previously described(16, 25) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	81	Extent of AcetylationThe degree of acetylation of the lipoyl prosthetic groups from various sources of E2 lipoyl domains were measured using either the E1 reaction with [2-C]pyruvate as substrate (15, 17) or E3/NADH reduction followed by acetylation with [1-C]acetyl-CoA(15, 16, 17) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	82	 For acetylation with pyruvate, a concentrate of E1 + 50  microM TPP was prepared and used as described above.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	83	 In some experiments, the acetylation of E2 or lipoyl domains using acetyl-CoA was driven to completion by converting the CoA product to succinyl-CoA with the -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex in reaction mixtures containing 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	84	4 mM -ketoglutarate and 50  microM Ca(16) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	85	 This gave a maximal acetylation of 16  microM L1 or L2 with high acetyl-CoA (e.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	86	 24  microM), whereas at lower levels of acetyl-CoA (e.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	87	5-16  microM), acetyl-CoA was completely used, producing an extent of acetylation of lipoyl domains equivalent to added acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The acetylation of intact E2 subunits was measured by spotting samples on dry trichloroacetic acid-containing paper disks or on P81 phosphocellulose disks (as with the kinase assays); P81 disks were always used to measure acetylation of the L1 or L2 domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The washing and counting procedures were as described previously(16, 27) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	90	E3 Cyclic AssayLipoyl domain levels were routinely assessed by an assay coupling conversion of E3/NADH-dependent reduction of lipoates to their reoxidation by reaction with 5,5`-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoate) to produce two 5-thio(2-nitro)benzoates(27) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Reactions were conducted in mixtures containing 50 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 7.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	92	1 mM 5,5`-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoate).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Reactions were started by adding 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	94	5  microg of E3 to a final volume of 200  microl.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The change in absorbance ( = 27.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	96	2 ODmMcm at 405 nm) was measured with time using a UV Max microplate reader.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	97	Lipoamidase TreatmentLipoyl groups were released from PDC, E2XK1K2, and isolated lipoyl domains by incubation with E.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	98	 faecalis lipoamidase for 90-210 min at 30  degrees C or overnight at room temperature(24, 25, 26, 27) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The incubation mixture contained 50 mM potassium phosphate (pH 7.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	100	5) and 1 mM EGTA and ratios of lipoyl-bearing structure to lipoamidase (w/w) 345:1 for PDC; of 180:1 for E2XK1K2; and of 100:1 for the human L2 domain.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The extent of delipoylation was monitored by measuring either residual PDC activity or reconstituted PDC activity (below).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	102	 A steep decline occurred only as the final 40% of lipoyl groups were removed from E2 and protein X.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Final products were evaluated for their content of lipoyl groups by measuring the extents of acetylation by the CoA removal approach (described above).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Delipoylation of isolated lipoyl domains was estimated from the loss of activity in the E3 cyclic assay.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Free lipoate caused only a minor interference with the latter assay since lipoyl domains are much more efficient substrates; ()full delipoylation was judged to have occurred when the rate had dropped to that produced by an equivalent concentration of free lipoate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Delipoylation of L1 and L2 was also evaluated by the characteristic shift (mobility decrease) observed for these delipoylated domains in native gel electrophoresis(27) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	107	 All delipoylated preparations were examined by SDS-PAGE to ensure that no subunit degradation had occurred.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	108	 In experiments in which delipoylation was followed by ligase treatment (below), the delipoylated preparations were treated with 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	109	4 mM PMSF for 15 min at 30  degrees C to terminate lipoamidase activity, and residual PMSF quenched with 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	110	Ligase ProcedureRelipoylation was conducted by incubating delipoylated samples in a 25 mM potassium phosphate buffer, pH 7.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	111	5 containing lipoyl protein ligase, 50  microM lipoic acid, 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The acetylation and E3 assays (described above) were used to show that lipoyl moieties had been incorporated.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Usually, excess ATP was removed by dialysis versus 20 mM potassium phosphate buffer, pH 7.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	114	PDC Activity StudiesThe effects of delipoylation or relipoylation of PDC and E2XK1K2 samples were deduced from their PDC activities(34) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	115	 For E2XK1K2 subcomplex, 4  microg subcomplex was combined with 8  microg of E1 and 4  microg of E3 in 10  microl and incubated for 60 s at 30  degrees C, and a 6- microl sample was added to a standard PDC assay.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Since removal of lipoyl groups has a disproportionately low effect on PDC activity at early stages, delipoylation is analyzed more accurately by determining changes in acetylation capacity (above).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	117	The fractional binding of TPP to E1 can be evaluated in PDC activity assays because bound TPP is continuously converted to the more tightly bound hydroxyethylidene-thiamin pyrophosphate intermediate, the substrate of the rate-limiting reductive acetylation step(35, 36) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The levels of TPP bound to E1 were evaluated by comparing the rates of PDC reaction obtained by diluting enzyme 200-fold as the last addition into assay mixtures lacking or containing TPP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Reconstituted PDC activity was measured with resolved E1 and excess E2XK1K2 subcomplex (10  microg) and E3 (4  microg) and limiting E1 (4  microg).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The fractional E1-TPP is defined as the ratio of the highest activity observed in the absence of TPP to that observed in the presence of TPP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	121	The effects of changes in NADH:NAD and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios on PDC activity were analyzed in the absence of ATP in the same high K buffer (buffer A) used to evaluate the regulation of kinase activities rather than the standard 40 mM potassium phosphate buffer used in routine PDC activity assays.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Pyruvate and TPP were introduced at saturating levels of 1.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	123	 When the relative amount NADH + NAD were varied while retaining a total concentration of constant 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	124	5 mM, PDC activity was measured at 365 nm ( = 4.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Other conditions were as described in the legend to Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	126	Figure 8: Effects of changes in product to substrate ratios on PDC reaction measured in buffer A.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Reaction mixtures were modified as follows.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio was varied at a constant total pool of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	129	1 mM total pyridine nucleotides (); the NADH:NAD ratio was varied with a constant total pool of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	130	2 mM CoA () or at an acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio of 1 () using 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	131	 In each case 100% rates were the rate observed at a product to substrate ratio of zero for the varied ratio.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Other conditions and assay procedures are described under ``Experimental Procedures.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	133	E1, E1-TPP, and Peptide SubstratesThe requirements for NADH and acetyl-CoA stimulation of E1 kinase activity were evaluated via phosphorylating various substrates using the E2XK1K2 subcomplex as a source of kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	134	 As in assays below, NAD and NADH were used at a 1:3 ratio to prevent inhibition of E3 by its conversion to the 4 e-reduced state.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	135	 At this ratio, kinase activity is near maximally stimulated by NADH and maximally stimulated by the combination of NADH and acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	136	 We used an E1 preparation that gave  < 1% activity in a PDC reaction mixture lacking TPP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	137	 As shown in Table 1, kinase activity was stimulated 50% by NADH and nearly 2-fold by the combination of NADH and acetyl-CoA in the phosphorylation of E1 whether or not E1 contained TPP cofactor.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	138	 As expected(37) , kinase activity was reduced by TPP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	139	 However, the stimulation has been due to reversing the inhibitory effect of TPP or activation via the formation of a reaction intermediate on E1 (e.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	140	 hydroxyethylidenethiamin pyrophosphate formed from acetyl-lipoate by E2).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	141	Table 1also shows that E1 can be replaced by peptide substrate so the stimulations are not dependent on changes in E1(38) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	142	 ()This is consistent with the observation of Reed et al.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	143	(40) that kinase stimulation occurs with tryptic digestion of PDC.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Such PDC digestion produces a complex mixture of lipoyl domains, the catalytic inner core of E2 and the trypsin-resistant E3, all of which are required for kinase stimulation (see below).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	145	Because some stimulation by acetyl-CoA is detected in the absence of NADH, the level of incorporation of covalently attached acetyl groups from [1-C]acetyl-CoA was determined in the presence or absence of unlabeled ATP under the conditions of kinase assays (Table 1).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Without NADH, exposure to submillimolar levels of dithiothreitol allows acetylation of a small portion of the lipoyl groups by acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The low stimulation of kinase that occurs in conjunction with the low level of acetylation in the absence of NADH agrees with previous studies (15, 16, 17) (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Thus, our results eliminate the possibility that kinase stimulation is due to changes in the form of TPP interacting with the E1 substrate but they are consistent with the participation of lipoyl prosthetic groups.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	149	Pyruvate StimulationStimulation by pyruvate was first reported by Cooper et al.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Support for this stimulation occurring via reductive-acetylation of lipoyl moieties stems from the findings that adding low levels of pyruvate to TPP-containing PDC generates an increased kinase activity equivalent to that with NADH plus acetyl-CoA and that pyruvate is principally used in the reductive acetylation of oxidized lipoyl groups(13, 14, 15) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	151	 This mechanism for kinase stimulation predicts some TPP bound to E1 and a lipoyl domain source are required.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Using a resolved TPP-dependent E1 preparation, containing low levels of kinase activity but completely free of E2, the kinase activity was not significantly enhanced by pyruvate and/or lipoyl domain in the absence of TPP (Table 2).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Even in the presence of TPP, pyruvate failed to stimulate kinase activity with E1 unless lipoyl domains were added.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Furthermore, a fragment of bovine E2 that contains both lipoyl domains (designated E2) was effective.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The results are thus consistent with the view that the enhancement of kinase activity is mediated by the E1(TPP)-catalyzed acetylation of the E2 fragment.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Furthermore, a very low level of E2 fragment (1  microM) was effective.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	157	 This is below the level that gave a small enhancement of the kinase (up to 40%)(25) , suggesting a specific and possibly a stronger interaction of the kinase with acetylated-E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	158	Lipoamidase Treatment of PDCThe proposed mechanism of lipoyl-mediated enhancement of kinase activity predicts that complete removal of lipoyl groups would abolish kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Lipoyl groups were removed by treatment of PDC, E2XK1K2 subcomplex, or isolated lipoyl domains with E.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The enhancement in kinase activity by the E2 component (in the absence of effectors) declines rapidly as the last portion of lipoyl groups is removed and the kinase tends to dissociate from E2(24) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Treating PDC for 150 min with lipoamidase (1  microg/345  microg of complex) produced a preparation of complex, PDCD, lacking  > 96% of the lipoyl groups, based on the maximal acetylation assay (see ``Experimental Procedures'').
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Delipoylation reduced kinase activity from 6.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	163	 it removed most of E2 enhancement of kinase function (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Surprisingly, PDCD could still be stimulated nearly 2-fold by NADH plus acetyl-CoA but the activity remained well below the fully lipoylated PDC control (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The delipoylated PDCD incorporated  < 5 acetyl groups per molecule of complex (M 7.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	166	5 10) under the same conditions.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The retention of only a few lipoyl groups allowing effector stimulation can be explained by the lipoyl prosthetic group being a critical part of the high affinity binding site of the kinase and the kinase moving between lipoyl domains(25, 26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	168	 This would allow the kinase to relocate to E2 subunits retaining lipoyl groups with the residual activity of this localized kinase still being enhanced by reductive acetylation of the remaining lipoyl groups (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	169	Figure 2: Effect of lipoamidase treatment on the activity and effector stimulation of E1a kinase associated with intact PDC.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Lipoamidase treatments of PDC were for 150 min for second series of bar graphs (PDC-D) and for 210 min in the fourth set of bar graphs (PDC-D).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The interested preparations (PDC and PDC) were incubated for the same times with lipoamidase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	172	 No changes in the SDS-PAGE profiles were detected with any of the incubated samples.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Kinase assays were conducted as described under ``Experimental Procedures'' with the addition, as indicated by the bar graph key legend, of NADH and NAD in a mixture to a final concentration of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	174	2 mM, respectively, and of acetyl-CoA to 50  microM.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Pyridine nucleotides were added 60 s and acetyl-CoA 20 s prior to [-P]ATP, and the reactions were terminated after 60 s.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	176	Using a 210-min lipoamidase treatment of PDC lowered the level of acetylation 1.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	177	8 ()for the untreated PDC control, and abolished the stimulations of kinase activity by NADH and/or acetyl-CoA relative to the control (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The low stimulation of control kinase of PDC or PDC by acetyl-CoA in the absence of NADH was associated with a low level of acetylation of lipoates reduced during storage of the complex in 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	179	 SDS-PAGE analysis of the lipoamidase treated PDC or PDC showed no changes in the protein pattern indicating that there was no proteolysis during the lipoamidase treatments.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	180	Lipoamidase and Lipoyl Protein Ligase Treatment of EXK1K2The requirement for lipoate could be confirmed by reattaching the cofactor but E1 must be absent to avoid its phosphorylation in the ATP-dependent lipoyl-protein ligase reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	181	 E2XK1K2 was incubated with or without lipoamidase for 210 min and then lipoamidase-inactivated with PMSF as described under ``Experimental Procedures'' and the legend to Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Acetylation per subcomplex was reduced from 165.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	183	89 per subcomplex using acetyl-CoA with CoA removal approach and reconstituted pyruvate dehydrogenase complex activity was decreased by  > 99%.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Portions of the delipoylated and control subcomplexes were treated with lipoate, ATP, and lipoate protein ligase (as described under ``Experimental Procedures'') and dialyzed to remove ATP and lipoate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The acetylation capacity increased to 117.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	186	3 per subcomplex by 60 min, declined slightly thereafter, and remained below untreated subcomplex ( > 160 acetyl incorporated/subcomplex).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In a parallel study, after lipoamidase and then lipoate protein ligase treatments, the E2XK1K2 subcomplex gave a reconstituted PDC activity of 30.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	188	6  micromol/min/mg which was nearly as high as the untreated control (31.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	189	 SDS-PAGE analysis did not detect any change in the profile for the subunits of the subcomplex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Delipoylation of the subcomplex reduced kinase activity and abolished the rate enhancing effects of NADH and acetyl-CoA (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	191	 3), but these were to a large extent restored following ligase treatment.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	192	Figure 3: Effects on kinase activity and regulation of enzymatic removal and restoration of lipoyl groups of the E2Xkinase subcomplex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The E2Xkinase subcomplex was treated with lipoamidase for 210 min, and the lipoamidase was inactivated with PMSF as described under ``Experimental Procedures.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	194	'' Lipoyl groups were then restored to a portion of this preparation using E.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	195	 coli lipoyl protein ligase and then substrates removed as described under ``Experimental Procedures.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	196	'' The control sample of subcomplex was given parallel incubations.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Kinase assays included 25  microg of E1; pyridine nucleotides were added 60 s and acetyl-CoA 20 s prior to [-P]ATP, and the reactions were terminated after 60 s.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	198	Lipoyl Domain Role and Requirement for Acetyltransferase ReactionTo investigate the relative effectiveness of E2's lipoyl domains, the capacity of recombinant human lipoyl domains (L1 and L2) in mediating kinase stimulation was evaluated with resolved E1 in the presence of E3 and in the presence or absence of lipoyl domain-free E2 (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Kinase activity was increased slightly by NADH with the L1 domain but to a much larger extent by the L2 domain.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	200	 In the absence of E2, acetyl-CoA had no effect, alone, nor did it enhance the effect of NADH alone.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In the presence of acetyltransferase-catalyzing E2, kinase activity was stimulated by the combination of NADH and acetyl-CoA with the L1 domain, but not to the extent achieved with just NADH with the L2 domain (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	202	 An even larger (nearly 3-fold) enhancement of kinase activity was observed when a combination of effectors was added with L2 in the presence of E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Since there seems to be no possible role of E2 other than catalyzing the transacetylation reaction, the results provide definitive support for the view that the stimulating effects of acetyl-CoA are mediated by lipoate acetylation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	204	 4), the enhancement by acetyl-CoA, alone, occurred with acetylation of L2 (below).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The results establish a preferential role for L2 in mediating kinase stimulation in keeping with the preferential binding of the kinase to the L2 domain (26) (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	206	Figure 4: Capacity of the L1 and L2 domains of E2 to support effector stimulation of kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Kinase assays were conducted with 25  microg of E1 containing low kinase, and, as indicated, human recombinant L1 or L2 domains were included at 16  microM.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Effectors were added at the levels and times given in Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The solid bar shows kinase activity in the absence of L1 or L2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Other conditions were as described under ``Experimental Procedures.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	211	In parallel experiments, the levels of acetylation of lipoyl domains under the conditions used for studying kinase stimulation were evaluated.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	212	 With the L2 domain at 20 s (time of ATP addition after acetyl-CoA addition) and at 80 s (the time the kinase reactions were terminated) 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	213	25 acetyl groups were incorporated per L2 in the presence of E2 but in the absence of NADH.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Whereas in the presence of NADH/NAD, slightly more than one acetyl group per L2 was incorporated at 20 and 80 s.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Similar levels of acetylation occurred with L1.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	216	 This indicates that there is a low level of biacetylation (i.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	217	 at the 6- and 8-positions of a lipoate) as previously observed with the recombinant L1 and L2 constructs(27) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	218	Degree of Acetylation of L2 Versus the Extent of Stimulation of the KinaseThe above results suggest a progression in kinase stimulation with L2 acetylation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	219	 This relationship was evaluated studying kinase activity and acetylation, in parallel, under conditions of controlled acetylation by the acetyl-CoA being completely consumed (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Low concentrations of acetyl-CoA were incubated with the L2 domain in the presence of E2, E3, and a 1:1 ratio of NADH:NAD along with the -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex plus -ketoglutarate to convert CoA produced into succinyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The measured extents of acetylation confirmed that, at all but the highest level (24  microM), all the [1-C]acetyl-CoA was consumed in acetylating the L2 domain (16  microM).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The enhancement of kinase activity increased with the level of acetylation with a half-maximal stimulation observed when 20% of the L2 were acetylated (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Though a low proportion of free L2, this is higher proportion of L2 acetylated than is required in the intact complex as explained under ``Discussion.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	224	'' The decline in stimulation at high levels of acetylation is also consistent with the latter studies with intact complex(15, 16, 17) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	225	Figure 5: Relationship between the degree of acetylation of the L2 domain and stimulation of kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	226	 In kinase and acetylation assays, the acetylation of 16  microM L2 catalyzed by the E2 oligomer was carried out with removal of CoA formed by the -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex reaction under the conditions described under ``Experimental Procedures.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	227	'' Acetyl-CoA was included at levels from 1.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	228	5 to 30  microM and was completely consumed in acetylating L2 at all but the two highest concentrations (based on the measured extents of acetylation).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	229	 NADH and NAD were present at 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Other conditions were as described under ``Experimental Procedures.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	231	Effects of Dihydrolipoamide and Acetyl-dihydrolipoamide and Requirement for a Lipoyl Source for NADH Stimulation of Kinase ActivityPreviously reported stimulation of PDC-kinase by dihydrolipoamide (13, 14) could involve reduction of lipoyl moieties in the complex through E3 catalysis or disulfide exchange.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	232	 We were unable to do experiments in the absence of E3 because of trace E3 in our E1 and resolved kinase preparations.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (E3 is very active enzyme and only one round of turnover is needed to reduce the lipoate of L1 or L2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	234	) With no lipoyl domain source present, E1-kinase was increased by dihydrolipoamide with a maximal stimulation at 50  microM of 40-55%.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	235	(26) found L1 and L2 inhibited kinase activity at levels greater than 20  microM.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	236	 For direct comparison, effects of lipoate sources (dihydrolipoamide, L1, and L2) at 20  microM, alone and in combination, were determined to evaluate the direct and supportive roles of dihydrolipoamide.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Addition of 20  microM dihydrolipoamide to E1-kinase without a lipoyl domain source or with L1 or L2 gave small but reproducible enhancements (15-40%  plus or minus L1; 30-60% +L2) of kinase activity (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	238	 NADH did not stimulate in the absence of a lipoate source (first series, solid bar); indeed, the mixture of NADH + NAD at 3:1 ratio seemed to inhibit kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	239	 This strongly supports the conclusion that E3 catalyzed reduction of a lipoate source is required.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Only with L2 did NADH increase kinase activity beyond that with just dihydrolipoamide.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	241	 6, third series), larger effects were observed with NADH than with dihydrolipoamide and the combination had no effect beyond NADH alone.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	242	 These results indicate that the higher stimulation by dihydrolipoamide in the presence of L2 results from reduction of the lipoyl group of L2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	243	Figure 6: Relative effects of dihydrolipoamide and acetylated-dihydrolipoamide to L1 and L2 on kinase activity and capacity of dihydrolipoamide to support lipoyl domain effects.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Where indicated by key bar legends, dihydrolipoamide, L1, and L2 were added to assays at 20  microM.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	245	 E1-kinase was added to reaction mixtures containing 1  microg of E3 and all reactants except dihydrolipoamide, acetyl-CoA, and ATP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Dihydrolipoamide was added 40 s and acetyl-CoA 20 s before ATP, and other additions were made as described in the legend to Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	247	 4and under ``Experimental Procedures.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	248	Dihydrolipoamide alone was effective in supporting acetyl-CoA stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	249	 It was important that acetylation of dihydrolipoamide immediately precede the kinase assay since stimulation was not detected with stored preparations in which acetyl groups transfer from L-isomer to incorrect D-isomer and from 8-position to 6-position of the dihydrolipoamide.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Dihydrolipoamide replaced NADH in supporting the higher acetyl-CoA stimulation with L1 and particularly with L2 (diagonally cross-hatched bars).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Acetyl-CoA stimulation again required E2 (minus E2 results not shown).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	252	 For the marked stimulation by acetyl-CoA plus L2, dihydrolipoamide likely reduced enough L2 lipoates in the presence of E3 to allow L2-acetylation to an extent giving near maximal stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	253	7-fold enhancement was greater than with NADH probably due to the extent of acetylation being somewhat lower, resulting in less diacetyl-L2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Although reduction and acetylation of the lipoate of L2 is clearly most effective, a direct stimulation of kinase activity is observable with dihydrolipoamide and acetyl-dihydrolipoamide and this limits mechanistic possibilities (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	255	Effect of Delipoylation and Relipoylation of L2 DomainTo test the importance of L2's lipoate while not exposing the kinase to lipoamidase and lipoate protein ligase, delipoylated and relipoylated preparations of L2 were made.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Delipoylation of the L2 domain abolished its capacity to potentiate acetyl-CoA stimulation of the kinase and ligase treatment restored the full capacity for stimulation (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The previous lack of full recovery in the ligase treatment of delipoylated E2XK1K2 (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	258	 3) was probably due to loss or modification of some of the kinase during these treatments.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The requirement for L2's lipoyl group and for E2 catalysis seem to constitute incontrovertible evidence that kinase stimulation is mediated by acetylation most effectively via the L2 domain of E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	260	Figure 7: Effects of removal and restoration of the lipoyl groups of L2 on kinase stimulation by NADH and acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The L2 domain was delipoylated with lipoamidase and relipoylated with lipoyl protein ligase using the conditions described under ``Experimental Procedures.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	262	'' Kinase assays were conducted as described in the legend to Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	263	 4and under ``Experimental Procedures,'' except that L2 was unchanged, delipoylated, or relipoylated, as indicated.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	264	Direct Product Inhibition of the PDC ReactionThe mechanism of product inhibition of PDC under low salt conditions (43) and the effects of higher ionic strengths on the PDC reaction have been characterized(44) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	265	 However, at physiological K levels, the effects of varying NADH:NAD and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios have been characterized for the kinase reaction (27) but not the PDC reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	266	 8show that half-maximal inhibition of PDC is observed at an NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	267	42 () in the absence of acetyl-CoA; and at an acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio of 11.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	268	2 () in the absence of NADH and at 3.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	269	55 in combination with a fixed NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	270	 The strongest direct product inhibition of PDC was found with a half-maximal effect at a low NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	271	125 when the acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio was held at 1 (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	272	 However, near-maximal stimulation of the kinase to switch off bovine kidney PDC occurs with an NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	273	1 at a 10-fold lower acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	274	 We conclude that much higher ratios of products to substrates are required for direct product inhibition of bovine kidney PDC than for speeding PDC inactivation by enhancing kinase activity (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	275	Randle and co-workers (45, 46) pointed out the importance of feedback control of PDC in satisfying metabolic needs and presented evidence for direct product inhibition of the PDC reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	276	 After regulatory interconversion of PDC between active and inactive forms (2) became known, Randle's laboratory contributed to evidence (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Introduction) that the products of PDC reaction influence the proportion of PDC in the active form, through diverse studies with purified complex isolated mitochondria, and intact tissues (1, 8, 9, 47) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	278	 In their studies with purified porcine heart PDC, no stimulation by acetyl-CoA beyond that of NADH was detected, and they speculated that enhanced kinase activity might be due to the removal of an inhibition of kinase activity caused by the absence of an interaction between oxidized lipoate and the E1 substrate (8, 9) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Although not the correct mechanism and detection of an effect of acetyl-CoA required use of higher K concentration (see below), the suggestion of a role for changes in the intermediate status of lipoyl groups was insightful as was their linking of the stimulatory effect of pyruvate (41) to the effect of products(9) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	280	 This laboratory presented the initial and much subsequent evidence that reduction and acetylation of lipoyl prosthetic groups of PDC constituted essential steps in the operation of a sensitive signal translation process whereby increases in the NADH:NAD and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios markedly enhance kinase activity(13, 14, 15, 16, 17) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	281	 However, elucidation of the minimal requirements for the operation of this control could be accomplished only following a greatly enhanced understanding of the organization of the complex, the preparation of individual lipoyl domains of PDC-E2, and the availability of lipoamidase and lipoyl protein ligase, combined with the selective use of peptide substrate and free forms of lipoamide.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	282	Using these tools, we have found that the marked enhancement of kinase activity by acetyl-CoA requires a lipoate source and its reduction, the catalytic domain of E2, and a peptide substrate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	283	 These requirements conclusively support a change in the kinase mediated by catalytically forming acetyl-dihydrolipoate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Accumulation of this intermediate explains the similarly strong stimulation of kinase activity by low pyruvate via E1(TPP) catalysis.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The direct stimulation by dihydrolipoamide, its capacity to replace NADH in potentiating acetyl-CoA stimulation, and the complete lack of an effect of NADH on kinase activity in the absence of a lipoate source strongly favor NADH boosting kinase activity through its use in the E3 reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	286	 We have established that this intervention is abolished by complete removal of lipoates from intact E2 subunits or lipoyl domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Of particular importance for understanding the operation and regulation of the kinase is our finding that the kinase-binding L2 domain is much more effective than E2's L1 domain or lipoamide in mediating kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The 3-fold increase in kinase activity generated by reductive acetylation of recombinant L2 is comparable to the change in kinase activity produced by acetylation of lipoyl moieties in the intact complex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Reduced L1 was only slightly more effective than free dihydrolipoamide when compared at 20  microM, and 50  microM dihydrolipoamide gave at least an equivalent stimulation, suggesting the structure of L1 does not contribute significantly to these effects.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	290	 At higher levels L1 inhibits kinase activity(26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Thus, the L2 domain must have structural features that facilitate its dedicated roles in binding the kinase, producing enhanced E1 phosphorylation within the confines of the complex, and further increasing kinase activity upon reduction and acetylation of its lipoyl group.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	292	 This raises the question of the linkage between these L2-supported actions of the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	293	Detaching lipoates of the E2 core removes the capacity of the E2 core to give a severalfold increase in E1 phosphorylation(24) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Via lipoyl-dependent binding to the L2 domain, rapid ``hand over hand'' interchange of a kinase dimer between lipoyl domains apparently eliminates constraints normally associated with binding that is as tight as exists between E2 and the kinase(25, 26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	295	 It is significant that a lipoamidase treatment of PDC, which left only a few lipoates and caused close to full loss of this E2-enhanced kinase function, still allowed marked stimulation of the residual kinase activity upon acetylation of those few domains retaining lipoyl groups (PDC series in Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	296	 This result forcefully suggests that the kinase has moved to the limited number of lipoylated L2 domains and, furthermore, that their acetylation (during a short-lived dissociation and reassociation of the kinase) facilitated kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Based on this continued stimulation when very few E2 subunits retain lipoate, we hypothesize that maximal effector stimulation is mediated by an allosteric effect induced by a reductively acetylated L2 domain that becomes engaged in binding of the kinase (i.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	298	 not by interaction of an acetylated prosthetic group on a neighboring lipoyl domain that is not engaged in binding the kinase).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Such a highly specific interaction is further supported below.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	300	Beside E1 catalyzed reductive-acetylation giving a nearly equivalent stimulation to acetyl-CoA(13, 14, 15) , -ketobutyrate (38) gives a lesser stimulation similar to that of propionyl-CoA at low levels of propionylation(16) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	301	 In the absence of a lipoyl domain source, kinase phosphorylation of E1 is not stimulated at low pyruvate ((17) , miniprint section); and here we show that TPP and a lipoyl domain source are needed to achieve pyruvate stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	302	 These findings raise the question as to whether the E1 reaction or the downstream (E2,E3) reactions determine the relative proportion of lipoates in the oxidized, reduced and acetylated forms in the complex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Since E1 catalyzes the rate-limiting step(35, 36) , under most metabolic conditions, this distribution should be determined by the NADH:NAD and the acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios and kinase activity should primarily respond to their fluctuation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	304	With purified porcine liver and bovine kidney PDC, half-maximal stimulations of kinase activities occur at ratios of NADH:NAD of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	305	05, respectively, and, with 2 mM dithiothreitol as a reducing agent, at ratios of acetyl-CoA:CoA of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Even lower acetyl-CoA:CoA ( < 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	307	1) give half-maximal stimulation when a NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	308	1 is provided to reduce lipoates (data not shown).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	309	 At these low ratios, there is minimal product inhibition of the PDC reaction by NADH plus acetyl-CoA (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Significant direct product inhibition occurs with low NADH:NAD ratio when the acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio was held at a relatively high level of 1 (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios have been generated at and above this range with isolated mitochondria and are proposed to contribute to direct PDC inhibition (48) ; depletion of CoA may also inhibit PDC due to buildup of fatty acyl-CoAs(49) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	312	 While these probably contribute to a fine tuning role on a small portion of active PDC, enhanced phosphorylation should effectively throttle down PDC activity before onset of these extremes.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	313	A priori, the lesser enhancement of kinase activity by just the conversion of lipoates from the oxidized to the reduced form could involve either removal of an inhibitory interaction of oxidized lipoates, an enhancement of kinase activity by gain of a positive allosteric interaction of the reduced form, or a change in the thiol disulfide state of a kinase subunit.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Studies with E2-bound kinase found that the kinase is sensitive to thiol reagents(13, 52) , effects probably due to changes in the oxidation-reduction state of the lipoate of L2 domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Although there is a small increase in alkylation of cysteines of the K1 subunit following treatment of E2Xkinase-E3 with NADH, this was not rapidly reversed by excess NAD which opposes kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	316	 ()Thus, a mediator role for changes in the thiol-disulfide status of the kinase is not indicated.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Furthermore, our finding that free dihydrolipoamide and to a greater extent acetylated dihydrolipoamide directly stimulated kinase activity in the absence of a lipoyl domain source, eliminating the prospect that stimulation results from removal of an inhibitory effect by the oxidized form of lipoate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	318	 9, we conclude that kinase activity is enhanced through direct positive allosteric interactions of the reduced or the acetylated form of an L2 lipoate and we further suggest that L2 specificity derives from the L2 domain engaged in binding the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	319	Figure 9: Model of proposed steps in kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	320	 The proportion of L2 domains of the E core having oxidized, reduced, or acetylated lipoates responds to changes in the NADH:NAD ratio and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio via the rapid and reversible reactions catalyzed by E3 and E2, respectively.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Our model proposes that a change from the kinase binding to one or two L2 containing only oxidized lipoate (nonstimulated K state) to interacting with an L2 containing a reduced or an acetylated lipoate results in the modified lipoates allosterically inducing conformational changes that generate the progressively more active K* or K** states, respectively.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	322	Consistent with stimulation occurring at low ratios of acetyl-CoA to CoA, half-maximal and near-maximal stimulation of kinase associated with the intact bovine kidney PDC are achieved with only 7-10 and 22-26 acetyl groups incorporated, respectively, per PDC(15, 16, 17) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	323	 With the recent knowledge that there are 3 lipoyl domains, two on E2 and one on the E3-binding protein giving a total of at least 126 lipoates per E2, ()it seems likely that no more than 12 and possibly as few as 7 acetyl groups are incorporated per PDC into the kinase-binding L2 domain for near-maximal stimulation, and as few as 3 and no more than 6 are incorporated for half-maximal stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	324	 ()This constitutes a highly responsive regulatory mechanism in which the kinase must preferentially interact with acetylated L2 and suggests that full stimulation may result from only one subunit of a kinase dimer interacting with a reductively acetylated L2 domain.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Consistent with this prospect, half-maximal stimulation occurred with free L2 when only 20% of the L2 are acetylated.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Although a much higher portion was found than estimated (above) for the intact complex, very different conditions are operative at the outer surface of the complex where lipoyl domains are concentrated at 1 mM, making the localized L2 level at least 50-fold higher than the highest level of free L2 used in the present work.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Interaction of the kinase with acetylated-L2 would be aided by steady state turnover in the overall PDC reaction rapidly changing the location of acetyl groups within the multienzyme cluster.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Kinase shuffling between L2 domains may also contribute, but this is needed, regardless, since acetylation by acetyl-CoA requires an unhindered lipoate(50, 51) , and the kinase must interact after L2 acetylation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	329	 We conclude that increased reductive-acetylation is very effective in activating kinase due to this preferred interaction of acetylated L2 altering the structure of the kinase and thereby increasing kinase activity (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	330	In being stimulated, kinase kinetic properties must fundamentally change since stimulation occurs over a wide range of rates (e.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	331	 even with a peptide substrate that is slowly phosphorylated) and in the absence of kinase movement on the surface of the E2 core.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Previous studies demonstrated that stimulation of the kinase requires physiological levels of potassium salts(7, 14, 53) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Increasing K from low (0-10 mM) to higher levels (90-120 mM) leads to a marked inhibition of kinase activity and a gain in the capacity for NADH and acetyl-CoA stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Another property of the kinase that changes with increasing K ion is that ADP inhibition markedly increases(55) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	335	 A potential mechanism is that interaction of the kinase with an L2 domain containing an acetyl-dihydrolipoate leads to a conformational change in the kinase that speeds up ADP dissociation, which is probably the rate-limiting step in the kinase reaction at elevated (physiological) K levels.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	336	 Consistent with that prospect are the observation that acetylation causes a greater stimulation of ADP-inhibited kinase (13) and the evidence that kinase-ADP is a prominent reaction intermediate, since pyruvate effectively inhibits by binding to the kinase-ADP in the absence of free ADP(56) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	337	 For this mechanism to be correct, it must operate in conjunction with the slow rate of phosphorylation of peptide substrate, a particularly useful system for testing this mechanism.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Further studies will be needed to define the structural changes that attenuate the kinase through changes in L2's lipoyl group and to determine how the K1 and K2 subunits of the kinase vary in their regulatory control.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	339	In conclusion, our results strongly support E3-catalyzed reduction and E2-catalyzed acetylation of lipoyl moiety of the kinase binding inner (L2) domain of E2 mediating a marked enhancement in kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	340	 The effectiveness in intact PDC of acetylating a low proportion of L2 domains in enhancing the phosphorylation of many bound E1 by a single tightly bound kinase molecule is probably accomplished by inter-L2 domain movement of the kinase combined with a stronger interaction of the kinase with acetylated L2 domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Several studies on kinase function and regulation are consistent with a change in a K-requiring process ultimately occurring in kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	342	 A candidate mechanism involves counteracting K-strengthened ADP binding to the kinase to speed up slow dissociation of this product from the active site of the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	343	*This work was supported in part by National Institutes of Health Grant DK18320, by a grant from the Kansas Affiliate of the American Heart Association, and by the Agriculture Experiment Station (contribution 95-476-J) (to T.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	344	), and by a grant from The Wellcome Trust (to J.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	345	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	346	 This article must therefore by hereby marked ``advertisement'' in accordance with 18 U.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	348	 To whom correspondence should be addressed: Dept.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	349	 of Biochemistry, Willard Hall, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	350	: 913-532-6121; Fax: 913-532-7278.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	351	()The abbreviations used are: PDC, pyruvate dehydrogenase complex; E1, pyruvate dehydrogenase component; E1a, active, nonphosphorylated form of E1; E2, dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase component; E2 or L1, NH-terminal lipoyl domain of E2; E2 or L2, interior lipoyl domain of E2; E2, E1 binding domain; E2, oligomer forming, transacetylase catalyzing COOH-terminal domain of E2; PDK1 or just K1, major (in bovine kidney) catalytic subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase kinase, formerly designated by K; PDK2 or K2, minor catalytic subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase kinase, formerly designated K; E3, dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase; E3BP or X, E3-binding protein or protein X; TPP, thiamin pyrophosphate; PAGE, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis; PMSF, phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride; MOPS, 4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	352	()The E1 fraction was free of E2 based on SDS-PAGE separation, silver staining, and Western blot analysis using monoclonal antibodies that were specific for the L2 domain of E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Silver staining of a 2- microg sample of E1 demonstrated a band that migrated at the position of the K1 subunit of the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	354	 However, because of comigration with the subunit of E1 with the K2 subunit of the kinase, we were unable to determine whether this kinase subunit was also present in this preparation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	355	 A very low level of E3 was also present in the E1 preparation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	356	()The E3 component uses the lipoyl domain-attached lipoate much more effectively than the free lipoate in the cyclic E3 assay; accordingly there is little interference by lipoates released by lipoamidase from lipoyl domains (J.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Roche, manuscript in preparation).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	358	()The binding to E1 of TPP (37) or of thiaminthiazalone pyrophosphate, an analog of the transition state intermediate, hydroxyethylidene-TPP(14) , inhibits phosphorylation of E1 by the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	359	 To evaluate the effect of the hydroxyethylidene-TPP intermediate on kinase activity, Cary (39) tested the effect of addition of TPP to PDC in the presence of low pyruvate plus a level of acetyl-CoA and NADH that give a high acetylation of lipoyl moieties (and high stimulation of the kinase).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Addition of 50  microM TPP reduced kinase activity by 60% due to formation of hydroxyethylidene-TPP which, due to the short reaction time (40 s) and low pyruvate used (50  microM) used, was minimally converted to acetoin and acetolactate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	361	 This inhibition by this tightly bound intermediate is similar to that by a saturating level of TPP binding to E1 (37) and indicates stimulation of kinase activity does not result from relieving the kinase of inhibition by E1-bound TPP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	362	()This level of acetylation requires some biacetylation of lipoates.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	363	 This tends to occur under conditions in which acetyl-CoA lipoyl domains of the complex, particularly when the CoA removal approach is used to prevent deacetylation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	364	 As acetylation is increased from a level expected to give primarily monoacetylated lipoates (some reduced and some biacetylated) to a level expected to give a much higher proportion of biacetylated lipoates, there is a concomitant decrease in the number of sites that can be alkylated (by N-[C]ethylmaleimide) supporting formation of biacetyl-lipoates (S.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	365	(54) have presented evidence that there are 12 protein X (E3BP) in yeast PDC using an area densiometric analysis approach.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Using a less accurate densiometric approach, Jilka et al.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	367	(42) determined that there are only 6 E3BP in mammalian PDC but that should be reinvestigated.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	368	()Even at fairly low levels of acetylation, both E2 and E3BP are acetylated(42) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Furthermore, analysis by autoradiography of the acetylation of elastase-generated polypeptides of L1 and L2, that were identified on blots by L1- and L2-specific monoclonal antibodies(27) , demonstrated that both lipoyl domains of E2 are acetylated well with low levels of acetylation (S.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	370	 There appeared to be a somewhat higher acetylation of L2 but the complex distribution of L1- and L2-derived polypeptides made that judgment uncertain.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	371	We are thankful to Jason Baker for preparing lipoyl domain constructs and for helping with figure preparation and to Connie Schmidt for helping in the preparation of this manuscript.
