0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	420	 187, 121-131 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Mattevi, A.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	421	 (1992) Science 255, 1544-1550 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Mattevi, A.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	422	 (1993) Biochemistry 32, 3887-3901 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Pettit, F.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	423	 79, 3945-3948 [Abstract] Robertson, J.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	424	 265, 16814-16820 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Maeng, C-Y.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	425	 (1994) Biochemistry 33, 13801-13807 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Roche, T.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	426	 59, 1341-1348 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Pratt, M.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	427	 254, 7191-7196 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve]  1996 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	0	The cytoplasmic tail of herpes simplex virus envelope glycoprotein D binds to the tegument protein VP22 and to capsids Jung Hee I.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Harley, Aparna Mukhopadhyay and Duncan W.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	2	Department of Developmental and Molecular Biology, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, NY 10461, USA.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Herpes simplex virus (HSV) capsids assemble, mature and package their viral genome in the nucleoplasm.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	4	 They then exit the nucleus into the cytoplasm, where they acquire their final tegument and envelope.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The molecular mechanism of cytoplasmic envelopment is unclear, but evidence suggests that the viral glycoprotein tails play an important role in the recruitment of tegument and capsids at the final envelopment site.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	6	 However, due to redundancy in protein to protein interactions among the viral glycoproteins, genetic analysis of the role of individual glycoproteins in assembly has been difficult.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	7	 To overcome this problem, a glutathione S-transferase fusion protein-binding assay was used in this study to test the interaction between the cytoplasmic tail of one specific viral glycoprotein, gD, and tegument proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The study demonstrated that the 38 kDa tegument protein VP22 bound specifically to the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	9	 This association was dependent on arginine and lysine residues at positions 5 and 6 in the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In addition, HSV-1 capsids bound the gD tail and exhibited a similar sequence dependence.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	11	 It is concluded that VP22 may serve as a linker protein, mediating the interaction of the HSV capsid with gD.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	12	Present address: Pfizer Global Research and Development, Groton Laboratories, Eastern Point Road, Groton, CT 06430, USA.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	13	   INTRODUCTION Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a complex DNA virus.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The viral genome is packaged within an icosahedral capsid surrounded by an amorphous layer of proteins termed the tegument.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This in turn is contained within a lipid envelope bearing numerous virally encoded glycoproteins (Roizman  and  Pellett, 2001).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	16	It is generally agreed that HSV capsids acquire their final tegument and envelope in the cytoplasm.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	17	 However, the molecular mechanism of HSV-1 envelopment in the cytoplasm is poorly characterized.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	18	 During infection, viral membrane glycoproteins are expressed and traffic via cytoplasmic organelles to the cell surface.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Several lines of evidence suggest that the cytosolic domains of these glycoproteins may provide a platform for tegument assembly and recruitment of capsids followed by envelopment (Mettenleiter, 2002).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In a recent study, a double mutant of pseudorabies virus (PrV) lacking viral glycoproteins gM and gE (or gM and the cytoplasmic tail of gE) showed a failure in envelopment, instead accumulating cytoplasmic nucleocapsids immersed in a dense layer of tegument (Brack et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Following single deletion of either glycoprotein, the production of infectious virions was not affected, suggesting that the cytoplasmic tails of gE and gM act in a redundant fashion during assembly, most likely interacting with the tegument proteins and, indirectly, with the surface of nucleocapsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In HSV-1, simultaneous deletion of the same two glycoproteins did not dramatically affect production of infectious virions (Browne et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 2004), although simultaneous deletion of gD and gE resulted in a striking defect in particle assembly (Farnsworth et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	24	 This apparent redundancy makes analysis of specific glycoprotein to tegument interactions difficult to perform in vivo.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	25	 To overcome this obstacle, we developed a glutathione S-transferase (GST) fusion protein-binding assay to investigate the interaction between envelope glycoprotein tails and tegument partners in vitro.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	26	 This approach has previously been used to demonstrate the interaction between the cytoplasmic tail of glycoprotein H (gH) and the tegument component VP16 (Gross et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In the current study, we focused on analysing the tail of the glycoprotein D (gD) because it is a highly abundant component of the envelope (Spear  and  Roizman, 1972) with a short cytoplasmic tail of 30 amino acid residues that can easily be manipulated in mutagenesis studies.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Moreover, it has been shown to play a key, albeit redundant, role in assembly (Farnsworth et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Additionally, Pomeranz  and  Blaho (1999) reported that gD co-localizes with at least one tegument protein, VP22, during infection.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	30	We prepared GST fusion proteins that contained the cytoplasmic tail of gD or mutants thereof at their carboxy terminus.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Following binding of the GST fusion proteins to glutathione to Sepharose beads and incubation with HSV-infected cell extracts, these fusion proteins were tested for their ability to interact with tegument proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Here we report that the cytoplasmic tail of gD bound to the tegument protein VP22 in a manner that was independent of other viral polypeptides.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Additionally, our results indicated that VP22 may be one of the tegument components that mediate the interaction between the cytoplasmic tail of gD and the HSV capsid.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	34	   METHODS Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Construction of a GST to gD-expressing vector.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The predicted cytoplasmic tail of HSV-1 gD, encoded by the 3' end of the US6 gene, was amplified by PCR from genomic DNA using the oligonucleotides 5'-GCGAATTCTACACCGCCGCACTCGGAAAG-3' (upstream primer) and 5'-GGGAAGCTTAACTAGTTCACTAGTAAAACAAGGGCTG-3' (downstream primer).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The PCR product encoded the entire carboxyl-terminal tail of gD with two stop codons, flanked by EcoRI and HindIII restriction sites.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Digestion with these two restriction enzymes, followed by ligation to EcoRI/HindIII-digested pGEX-KG plasmid (Guan  and  Dixon, 1991), resulted in an in-frame fusion of GST with the gD cytoplasmic tail ORF.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	38	 This construct will be referred to as gDc.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	39	 A truncation mutant expressing only the first 17 amino acids of the cytoplasmic tail of gD, termed T17, was constructed using complementary oligonucleotides 5'-AATTCTACACCGCCGCACTCGGAAAGCCCCAAAGCGCATACGCCTCCCCCACATCCGGTGATGAA-3' and 5'-AGCTTTCATCACCGGATGTGGGGGAGGCGTATGCGCTTTGGGGCTTTCCGAGTGCGGCGGTGTAGAATT-3'.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	40	 To anneal these oligonucleotides, 5  microg of top and bottom strands was mixed in TE (10 mM Tris, 1 mM EDTA) and placed in a 95  degrees C water bath.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	41	 This was then allowed to cool slowly to room temperature to produce a dsDNA fragment with EcoRI- and HindIII-terminal ends.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The dsDNA fragment was ligated in frame into pGEX-KG.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Generation of alanine mutants of T17 was conducted in the same manner using annealed complementary oligonucleotides, except that, where appropriate, codons were mutated to encode alanine.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The oligonucleotides were annealed in the same manner as described above and ligated in frame to the GST gene in pGEX-KG.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	45	 gDR5K6, gDK9R10, gDR and gDK mutants were generated using the upstream primers 5'-GCGAATTCACCGCCGCACTGCTGCT3', 5'-GCGAATTCACCGCCGCACTCGGAAAGCCCCAGCTGCT-3', 5'-GCGAATTCACCGCCGCACTGCTAAA-3' and 5'-GCGAATTCACCGCCGCACTCGGGCT-3', respectively, with a common downstream primer, 5'-GCAGCTTCACTAGTAAAACA-3'.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The gDc plasmid expressing the full-length gD cytoplasmic tail was used as the DNA template.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	47	Expression of GST fusion proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Appropriate expression plasmids were transformed into Escherichia coli strain BL21 (Stratagene).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Overnight stationary-phase cultures were used to inoculate fresh medium the following day to an OD600 of 0 2 and cultures were grown on a shaker to an OD600 of 0 9.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	50	 IPTG was added to the cells to a concentration of 1 mM to induce expression of the fusion protein.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	51	 After 3 h, cells were collected by centrifugation at 8000 r.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	52	 for 10 min at 4  degrees C in a JA20 rotor, the medium was discarded and the pellet was frozen at  to 20  degrees C overnight.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The following day, the pellet was thawed and resuspended in lysis buffer (0 05 % Tween 20, 50 mM EDTA, 1 mM PMSF, 5  microg aprotinin ml to 1, 5  microg leupeptin ml to 1 and 1 mg lysozyme ml to 1 in PBS) and sonicated using a probe sonicator six times for 10 s each, with 30 s intervals on ice.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Debris and unbroken cells were pelleted at 10 000 r.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	55	 for 10 min at 4  degrees C in a JA20 rotor.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Supernatants were subjected to SDS-PAGE and stained with Coomassie blue to visualize the fusion proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	57	Preparation of HSV-1-infected cell extracts.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Confluent monolayers of COS cells were infected with HSV-1 strain SC16 at an m.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	59	 of 10 in DMEM with 10 % fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1 % penicillin/streptomycin (PS).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	60	 After 1 h, fresh medium was added and the incubation proceeded for an additional 18 h at 37  degrees C.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Cells were collected and a post-nuclear supernatant (PNS) was prepared as previously described (Harley et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Briefly, cells were washed twice with cold homogenization buffer (0 25 M sucrose, 2 mM MgCl2, 10 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 6), scraped, pelleted at 1000 g for 5 min at 4  degrees C and resuspended in 1 ml homogenization buffer containing 5  microg leupeptin ml to 1, 5  microg aprotinin ml to 1 and 1 mM PMSF.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Cells were broken by passing through a 25 gauge 5/8 inch needle eight times and then spun at 2000 g for 10 min at 4  degrees C to remove unbroken cells and nuclei.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The PNS was adjusted to 150 mM NaCl, 0 5 % NP-40, 50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 6, incubated for 1 h on ice to solubilize tegument proteins and centrifuged at 53 000 r.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The supernatant (S100) was aliquotted and frozen at  to 70  degrees C.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	66	Production of radiolabelled VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	67	 A VP22/myc to His-encoding plasmid (Invitrogen) and Redivue [35S]methionine were added to the TNT Rabbit Reticulocyte Lysate in vitro transcription/translation system (Promega) following the manufacturer's protocol.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The resulting in vitro-translated VP22 was mixed with PBS containing 5  microg leupeptin ml to 1 and 5  microg antipain ml to 1 and incubated with GST fusion protein-coated glutathione to Sepharose beads as described below.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Material bound to the beads was subjected to SDS-PAGE and the gel treated with 30 % methanol, 10 % acetic acid for 30 min, En3Hance (NEN Life Sciences Products) for 1 h and 1 % glycerol for 30 min.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The gel was then dried using a Bio-Rad gel drier and exposed to film for 1 to 2 days.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	71	Preparation of [3H]thymidine-labelled capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Prior to infection, confluent monolayers of COS cells were overlaid with DMEM containing 1 % dialysed FBS and 1 % PS for 2 h and then infected with HSV-1 strain SC16 at an m.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	73	 After 1 h, fresh medium with [3H]thymidine (NEN) was added to a final concentration of 25  microCi ml to 1 and incubated for 18 h.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Cells were harvested as above, and a PNS was prepared and adjusted to a final concentration of 2 5 mM magnesium acetate, 50 mM potassium acetate, 150 mM NaCl, 0 5 % Triton X-100 and 5 mM DTT and incubated on ice for 1 h.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The treatment removed the membranes and solubilized some of the tegument associated with the cytoplasmic virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Following incubation, debris was removed by a clearing spin at 1500 g.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The treated PNS was used to test for binding of capsids to fusion proteins bound to glutathione to Sepharose beads.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The protein concentration of the PNS was determined using a BCA assay (Pierce) with BSA as a protein standard.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Glutathione to Sepharose beads were dispensed into a microcentrifuge tube and washed three times with cold PBS.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	80	 BSA (100  microl of a 10 mg ml to 1 solution), an equivalent amount of GST fusion protein-containing bacterial extract and PBS to a total volume of 1 ml were added to the washed beads and incubated at 4  degrees C for 1 h on a rotator.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The beads were then washed twice with wash buffer 1 (50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 6, 150 mM NaCl, 0 5 % Triton X-100) and then with wash buffer 2 (50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 6, 1 3 M NaCl, 0 5 % Triton X-100) and again with wash buffer 1.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Infected-cell cytosol (S100), in vitro-translated VP22 or cell extracts containing [3H]thymidine-labelled capsids was then added to the GST fusion protein-bound beads, incubated at 37  degrees C for 1 h and then washed six times with wash buffer 1.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	83	 For detection of bound tegument proteins, the beads were resuspended in 500  microl 50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 6.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	84	 SDS-PAGE sample buffer was added and the mixture was heated to 95  degrees C for 5 min, subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotted using appropriate antibodies.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	85	Measurement of packaged viral DNA.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	86	 A TCA precipitation assay to measure DNA packaging was carried out as previously described (Church et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Briefly, after performing the GST in vitro-binding assay with [3H]thymidine-labelled capsid-containing extracts, beads were incubated with 2 mM MgCl2 and 280 U DNase I (type II; Sigma) ml to 1 for 90 min at 37  degrees C.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	88	 EDTA and SDS were added to final concentrations of 10 mM and 0 3 %, respectively, and incubation continued for an additional 15 min.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The treated material was then spotted on to individual GF/C Whatman filter papers and allowed to dry.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Each filter was subjected to one 4  degrees C wash and two consecutive 65  degrees C washes in TP buffer (5 % TCA, 20 mM sodium pyrophosphate) before rinsing in 70 % ethanol and drying.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The level of TCA-precipitable radioactivity was determined by liquid scintillation counting.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	92	Electron microscopy analysis of bead-associated capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	93	 GST or GST fusion proteins were bound to glutathione to Sepharose beads and incubated with HSV capsid-containing extracts and the beads were washed, pelleted and fixed in 2 5 % glutaraldehyde in SC (100 mM sodium cacodylate, pH 7 43) at room temperature for 45 min.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The pellet was then rinsed in SC, post-fixed in 1 % osmium tetroxide in SC followed by 1 % uranyl acetate, dehydrated through a graded series of ethanols and embedded in LX112 resin (LADD Research Industries).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Ultrathin sections were cut on a Reichert Ultracut E, stained with uranyl acetate followed by lead citrate and viewed on a JEOL 1200EX transmission electron microscope at 80 kV.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	96	Co-immunoprecipitation of endogenous gD and VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	97	 COS cells were infected with HSV-1 strain PAAr5 (Jones et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	98	 At 15 h post-infection, cells were collected and resuspended in lysis buffer [50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 6, 150 mM NaCl, 0 5 % NP-40, 0 5 mM EDTA, 0 5 mM PMSF, 2 mM DTT, 200  microg protease inhibitor cocktail tablets (Roche Diagnostics) ml to 1] and incubated on ice for 30 min.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The resulting lysate was cleared by centrifugation for 20 min at 15 000 g and pre-cleared by incubation with Protein G to agarose beads (Sigma) for 20 min at 37  degrees C.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	100	 After pelleting the beads, the supernatants were collected and mixed with fresh Protein G beads with either anti-gD (Virusys) or anti-HA (Roche Diagnostics) monoclonal antibody (mAb).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	101	 After a 15 min incubation at 37  degrees C, beads were washed four times with a wash buffer and once in PBS.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Bound material was then subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotted using anti-VP22 antibody.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	103	   RESULTS Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Generation of a GST to gD tail fusion protein to test for interaction with tegument proteins A PCR-amplified DNA fragment encoding the gD cytoplasmic tail was cloned in frame to the coding sequence of GST using the vector pGEX-KG (Guan  and  Dixon, 1991) (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	104	 coli (strain BL21) was transformed with pGEX-KG or gDc, treated with IPTG to induce expression and cell extracts were subjected to SDS-PAGE.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	105	 1(b), Coomassie blue staining shows the fusion protein of the predicted size of approximately 30 kDa as the most abundant protein in the gel.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	106	View larger version (54K):    Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Construction and expression of the GST to gD fusion protein.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	108	 (a) Schematic diagram of the fusion protein-expressing region of pGEX-KG.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Ptac is an IPTG-inducible promoter with the arrow indicating the direction of transcription.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The GST ORF is indicated by a filled box, followed by a polyglycine flexible hinge (GGGGG).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The gD cytoplasmic tail was cloned between the EcoRI and HindIII sites.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The protein sequence of the gD tail is shown followed by two stop codons.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	113	 coli BL21 cells, expression of the fusion proteins was induced with IPTG and cell extracts were subjected to 10 % SDS-PAGE.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Coomassie blue staining readily showed GST and the fusion protein as the most abundant proteins in the cell extract (arrows).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The positions and sizes (kDa) of standard molecular mass markers are indicated on the left.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	116	 (c) Equivalent amounts of GST-, gDc- or gHc-expressing bacterial extracts were added to the in vitro GST-binding assay and incubated with the S100 fraction from HSV-infected cells.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Bound (B) and unbound (U) polypeptides were resolved by SDS-PAGE, transferred to a PVDF membrane and probed with various antibodies as indicated on the left (-Tub.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Input indicates the total amount of S100 fraction added to each binding reaction.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	119	  Binding of the tegument protein VP22 to the gD fusion protein To prepare a source of tegument polypeptides for the binding assay, we followed the methodology previously described for isolating HSV-1-containing organelles and putative assembly intermediates from the cytoplasm of HSV-1-infected cells (Harley et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	120	 PNS from HSV-infected COS cells was first treated with NP-40 and NaCl to solubilize the viral structural proteins, as we have previously found many tegument polypeptides to be insoluble in the PNS, perhaps due to their incorporation into assembling virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The detergent-solubilized extract was then incubated with glutathione to Sepharose beads to which had previously been bound equivalent amounts of GST, gDc or gHc, a fusion protein of the viral gH tail with GST that has been well characterized by our laboratory (Gross et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Bound and unbound material was then resolved by SDS-PAGE, Western blotted and analysed by probing with various antibodies.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	123	 1(c) shows binding of the tegument protein VP22 to the GST to gD fusion protein.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	124	 VP22 remained mostly in the unbound fraction when incubated with GST alone, suggesting that the binding was tail specific.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	125	 To test the specificity of binding further, we also examined the association of other abundant cellular and viral proteins with the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The cellular protein -tubulin and the abundant capsid scaffold proteins Pra and ICP35 failed to bind to the gD and gH tails, indicating that the glycoprotein tails do not bind these cellular and viral proteins non-specifically: VP22 bound to the gD tail but not to the gH tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	127	 We also observed that gD bound the tegument protein VP16 in a manner similar to gH.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	128	 This was consistent with a previous study by Zhu  and  Coutney (1994), which demonstrated that VP16 could be cross-linked to both gD and gH in purified virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	129	Binding of VP22 to the gD tail is independent of other viral proteins The interaction between VP22 and gD may be direct or mediated by other viral proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	130	 To examine this question, we used a rabbit reticulocyte lysate in vitro transcription/translation system to generate 35S-labelled VP22 and added it to our in vitro GST-binding assay.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Autoradiography showed that in vitro-translated VP22 (running at a molecular mass of 45 kDa) bound to the gD tail (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Since the rabbit reticulocyte lysate contained only the in vitro-translated VP22 and no other viral proteins, we could conclude that VP22 binding did not require any other viral polypeptides.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Although we could not discount the possibility that a cellular polypeptide in the reticulocyte lysate mediated the gD to VP22 interaction, no host protein with the abundance of VP22 has ever been described in the HSV particle.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	134	View larger version (42K):    Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	135	 VP22 binds to the gD tail in the absence of other viral proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	136	 35S-labelled VP22 was generated using a rabbit reticulocyte lysate in vitro transcription/translation system.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	137	 gDc- or GST-coated glutathione to Sepharose beads were incubated with radiolabelled VP22 in duplicate and subjected to SDS-PAGE, fixed and exposed to film for 1 to 2 days.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Input corresponds to the amount of in vitro-translated product included in the binding reaction.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	139	  Smaller fragments of VP22 that might have been the result of either early termination of protein synthesis or partial degradation were also found in the bound lane of gDc.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	140	 We assumed that the smallest fragment (23 kDa; Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	141	 2) of the in vitro-translated VP22 contained the region required for binding to the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	142	Alanine-scanning mutagenesis of the gD cytoplasmic tail To simplify the identification of amino acids within the gD cytoplasmic tail that play an important role in VP22 binding, we generated a truncation mutant of the tail that retained only the most amino-terminal 17 residues (named T17) (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	143	 When the GST to T17 fusion protein was tested for its ability to bind VP22 present in cytosolic extracts prepared from HSV-infected cells, it was found to bind VP22 in a similar manner to the full-length gD tail (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Next, to identify residues that might be critical for binding VP22, we carried out alanine-scanning mutagenesis.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Clusters of amino acids were mutated simultaneously to alanine and named according to the amino acid residues that were mutated (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	146	 These mutants, along with gDc and GST, were expressed and incubated with infected-cell extracts and the relative amounts of VP22 binding were detected by Western blotting.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	147	 3(c) shows that mutations in the arginine and lysine residues at positions 5/6 or 9/10 diminished the binding of VP22, indicating that these amino acid residues are important.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Although the HRR mutant showed a slightly decreased binding of VP22, this level of binding was variable, and most commonly the HRR mutant bound VP22 at a level similar to the wild-type gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Next, we examined the role of the key lysine and arginine residues in the context of the full-length gD tail (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Similar to the truncated mutant, mutation of R5/K6 showed a dramatic decrease in binding of VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Individual mutation of these residues had a less dramatic effect, indicating that these amino acid residues both contribute to VP22 binding but may play a somewhat redundant role.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	152	View larger version (52K):    Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Alanine-scanning mutagenesis of the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	154	 (a) Amino acid sequence of the gD tail and its corresponding mutants.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	155	 (b) T17 fusion protein containing the first 17 amino acid residues of the gD tail binds VP22 (S100) at an equivalent level to the full-length gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Binding of the gD tail to VP22 in the bound (B) and unbound (U) fractions is shown.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	157	 (c) Clusters of basic residues of T17 were changed to alanines as indicated in (a).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The residues that were mutated to alanines are indicated above each lane.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	159	 When these fusion proteins were examined for their ability to bind VP22, the R5K6 and K9R10 mutants showed diminished binding in comparison with the others.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	160	 (d) The full-length gD tail containing substitutions of arginine and lysine residues at positions 5/6 and 9/10 to alanine showed diminished binding of VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Individual mutations containing alanine substitutions at either the lysine 5 or the arginine 6 residue showed some binding to VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The Western blots in (c) and (d) also revealed the quantity of GST fusion protein in each binding reaction, since the anti-VP22 antiserum is cross-reactive with GST.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	163	  Co-immunoprecipitation of endogenous gD and VP22 So far, the gD to VP22 interaction was demonstrated using an in vitro GST-binding assay.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	164	 In order to confirm this protein to protein interaction in vivo, a co-immunoprecipitation experiment was performed using infected-cell lysate prepared from COS cells infected with the wild-type HSV-1 strain PAAr5.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Infected-cell lysates were incubated with protein G to agarose beads containing either an anti-gD or anti-HA mAb as described in Methods.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The immunoprecipitated materials were then subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotted for VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The amount of VP22 in the total-cell lysate is shown in Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	168	 VP22 was present when immunoprecipitation was carried out with the anti-gD mAb (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	169	 4, lane 2), but not when the anti-HA mAb was used (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Therefore, gD can indeed be co-immunoprecipitated with VP22, indicating that these two proteins interact in vivo.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	171	View larger version (8K):    Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Co-immunoprecipitation of VP22 and gD.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Infected-cell lysate was prepared and incubated with either anti-gD (lane 2) or anti-HA (lane 3) mAb.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Immunoprecipitated material was then subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotted with anti-VP22 antibody.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Lane 1 contained total-cell lysate.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	176	  Binding of capsids to the gD tail in the presence of tegument proteins To examine the interaction of the glycoprotein tail and capsids, we prepared cell extracts containing capsids in which the viral genome was labelled with [3H]thymidine, as described in Methods.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The packaged, radiolabelled viral genome enabled us to monitor the presence of HSV capsids by scintillation counting.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	178	 It should be noted that, since this was a relatively crude extract, tegument polypeptides such as vhs, VP22 and VP16 were also present, as determined by Western blotting (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	179	 This extract was then incubated with glutathione to Sepharose beads pre-coated with equivalent amounts of GST, gDc or gHc as previously described.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	180	 After washing, the beads were incubated with DNase I under conditions previously shown to destroy any DNA that has not been packaged within the icosahedral capsid (Church et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	181	, 1998; Dasgupta  and  Wilson, 1999; Harley et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Any surviving full-length, previously packaged DNA was then collected by TCA precipitation and subjected to scintillation counting.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	183	 5(b), only low levels of protected, encapsidated DNA became bound to beads coated with GST or gHc.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In contrast, much higher levels of binding were apparent when capsids were incubated with bead-bound gDc.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	185	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Binding of HSV-1 capsids to the cytosolic tail of gD.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	187	 (a) Capsids were prepared from detergent-solubilized HSV-infected cell PNS, as described in Methods.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The capsid preparation was resolved by 12 % SDS-PAGE, transferred to a nitrocellulose filter and probed with antibodies specific to the capsid subunit VP23 or the tegument polypeptides vhs, VP22 or VP16, as indicated.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The positions and sizes (kDa) of standard molecular mass markers are indicated on the left.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	190	 (b) Equivalent amounts of GST or the gDc or gHc fusion protein were bound to glutathione to Sepharose beads and incubated with a crude preparation of [3H]thymidine-labelled capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	191	 After washing, beads were incubated with DNase I to digest any DNA not protected within a capsid.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	192	 EDTA (10 mM) was then added to inactivate the DNase plus 0 3 % SDS to release the capsids from the beads and disrupt them.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Released viral DNA was collected by TCA precipitation and subjected to scintillation counting.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	194	 of precipitated 3H-labelled DNA.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Plotted values represent the mean plus or minus SD for triplicate samples.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	196	 (c) Increasing amounts of crude capsid preparation were incubated with glutathione to Sepharose beads bound to either GST (filled circles) or the gDc fusion protein (open squares).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Following incubation, samples were treated with DNase I, followed by EDTA and SDS, then TCA precipitated and subjected to scintillation counting as in (b).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	198	  If the capsids are binding to a specific site on the gD tail then, for any constant amount of gDc fusion protein bound to the beads, capsid binding should be saturable.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	199	 5(c) shows the result of an experiment in which increasing amounts of radiolabelled capsid-containing extract were incubated with GST- or gDc-coated glutathione to Sepharose beads and scored for capsid binding as described above.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Under these conditions, binding of capsids to the gD tail appeared to be saturable at between 500 and 750  microg cytosolic protein (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In contrast, binding to GST was at a much lower level and increased linearly in relation to the quantity of extract added, consistent with the lack of a saturable binding site.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	202	 This indicated that capsids were binding specifically to the gD tail, most likely indirectly, via tegument proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	203	Visualization of HSV-1 capsids bound to gDc-coated glutathione to Sepharose beads Although rapid and convenient, monitoring the c.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	204	 of labelled packaged viral DNA is an indirect method of testing for the presence of capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	205	 As a direct test of gD tail to capsid interaction, GST- or gDc-coated glutathione to Sepharose beads were incubated with the capsid preparation, fixed and then processed for ultrastructural analysis.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	206	 6 shows representative images of capsids bound to gDc-coated beads.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	207	 For gDc-coated beads, it was relatively easy to identify icosahedral capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Capsids were never found within beads, but always at the perimeter, suggesting they were not non-specifically trapped within the glutathione to Sepharose matrix.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	209	View larger version (159K):    Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Visualization of bead-bound capsids by electron microscopy.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Capsid-containing cell extracts were incubated with bead-bound gDc.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	212	 After washing, the mixture was fixed in glutaraldehyde and processed for thin-section electron microscopy.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	213	 (a to c) Representative bead perimeters.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Bound capsids are indicated by arrows.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	215	 (d) Sevenfold magnification of the capsid indicated in (b).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	216	  In this study we did not attempt to discriminate between B and C capsids, since they are believed to have similar surface compositions (Newcomb et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	217	, 1996) and both B and C capsids are capable of becoming enveloped (Baines et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Interestingly, all capsids scored had some internal structure, either a DNA core or a scaffold, suggesting that under these conditions very few A capsids were present (data not shown).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Table 1 shows quantification of the number of capsids bound to the GST- or gDc-coated beads.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Quantification of bead-bound capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	221	  Capsid binding to the gD tail is dependent on the same arginine and lysine residues that are important for binding VP22 The capsid preparation was known to contain tegument polypeptides such as vhs, VP16 and VP22 (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	222	 To test the possibility that VP22 might play a role in capsid to gD tail interactions, we made use of the GST to gDR5K6 fusion protein that had previously been shown to have diminished ability to bind VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Beads previously bound to either GST, gDc or gDR5K6 were incubated with cell extract containing capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	224	 of capsids bound to the gDR5K6 fusion protein were similar to background levels.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	225	 This correlative result was consistent with the possibility that VP22 plays an essential role in attachment of capsids to the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	226	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Mutation of arginine and lysine residues essential for VP22 binding abolishes binding to capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Equivalent amounts of GST, gDc and gDR5K6 were added to the GST in vitro-binding reaction and incubated with a crude capsid preparation, as in Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The level of capsid binding seen for the mutant gDR5K6 was similar to the background binding seen for the negative control of GST.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	230	     DISCUSSION Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   The cytoplasmic tails of HSV-1 glycoproteins have been shown to interact with various tegument proteins (Brack et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	231	, 2003; Zhu  and  Courtney, 1994), which may facilitate capsid recruitment to the site of envelopment.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	232	 So far, dissecting the molecular mechanism of assembly using a genetic approach has been complicated by redundancy among the viral glycoproteins: deletion of a single glycoprotein does not generally lead to apparent defects in cytoplasmic envelopment; instead, multiple simultaneous deletions are necessary.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	233	 In this study we took a biochemical approach towards analysing protein to protein interactions that might be important during virus assembly.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	234	We generated a fusion protein between GST and the cytoplasmic tail of gD in order to test its interaction with HSV-1 tegument proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Our results showed that the gD tail specifically bound the tegument protein VP22 but did not interact with the abundant cellular protein -tubulin nor with the capsid scaffold proteins ICP35 and Pra.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Furthermore, co-immunoprecipitation experiments confirmed that the interaction between gD and VP22 could be detected in infected cells.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Additionally, alanine-scanning mutagenesis of the gD tail identified two amino acid residues, arginine and lysine (from the amino-terminal end of the tail) at positions 5 and 6, respectively, that were critical for VP22 binding.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	238	Since VP22 and VP16 form a complex (Elliott et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	239	, 1995) and we observed VP16 binding to the gD tail, we were interested to test whether VP22 bound the gD tail directly or via VP16 or other viral proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Therefore, we synthesized 35S-labelled VP22 using a rabbit reticulocyte lysate in vitro transcription/translation system and tested its ability to bind the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	241	 We found that in vitro-translated VP22 did bind specifically to the gD tail, showing that this binding was independent of other viral polypeptides.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	242	Under our conditions we also observed capsid binding to the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	243	 This binding was saturable, unlike the low level of binding seen with GST alone.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	244	 We speculated that capsid binding to the gD tail was mediated by tegument components present in the crude capsid preparation.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Our results showed that the gD mutant tail gDR5K6 that failed to bind VP22 also failed to bind capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	246	 This suggested that VP22 was mediating capsid to tail interactions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	247	 However, it is also possible that other tegument proteins mediate binding of capsids to the gD tail, utilizing the same residues as VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Although VP16 is present on these capsids (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	249	 5a) and can bind to the gH tail (Gross et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	250	, 2003), it appeared unable to tether capsids to the gH tail (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Additionally, we observed that VP16 was capable of binding to the gD mutant tail gDR5K6, which does not bind capsids (data not shown).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	252	 This also suggested that VP16 was not involved in capsid to tail interactions under these conditions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	253	The association between VP22 and gD may be one of many interactions between glycoprotein tails and tegument proteins that facilitate the budding of capsids into organelles and the incorporation of tegument/glycoproteins into nascent virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	254	 In HSV-1, deletion of the cytoplasmic tail of gD had relatively little effect on normal virus production (Feenstra et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	255	 However, simultaneous deletion of gD and gE showed elimination of cytoplasmic envelopment and accumulation of large numbers of unenveloped nucleocapsids within a dense layer of tegument in the cytoplasm (Farnsworth et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	256	, 2003), indicating that gD and gE may share overlapping roles in cytoplasmic envelopment.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Our data suggest that at least one of these roles may be in VP22 recruitment and predict that the cytoplasmic tail of gE may also bind VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Interestingly, Farnsworth et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	259	 (2003) reported that the cytoplasmic tail of gE, when fused to GST, was indeed able to bind VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Thus, gD and gE may act in a redundant manner to incorporate VP22 into the newly forming virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Alternatively, it could be argued that VP22 serves to gather gD and gE to the sites of capsid to envelope interaction.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	262	Our findings regarding HSV-1 are somewhat similar to data reported for the alphaherpesvirus PrV.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	263	 gE and gM have been shown to interact with the UL49 protein, a homologue of HSV-1 VP22 (Fuchs et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	264	, 2002), and, following simultaneous deletion of these two glycoproteins, the UL49 product does not become incorporated into the PrV particle (Fuchs et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	265	 However, in the absence of the UL49 protein, gE and gM are incorporated into virions, implying that they may interact redundantly with other tegument proteins for this purpose.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	266	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   This work was supported by National Institutes of Health grant AI38265 to D.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	267	 and by NIH training grant T32 AI07506 to J.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	268	 We thank Jim Smiley for the HSV-1 strain PAAr5 and the Analytical Imaging Facility of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine for help with electron microscopy.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	269	 We thank both Dr John Blaho and Dr Richard J.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Courtney for providing anti-VP22 anti-sera.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	271	   REFERENCES Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Baines, J.
