0.15918402.15728575.html.plaintext.txt	347	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS  All ASBMB Journals   Molecular and Cellular Proteomics   Journal of Lipid Research   Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Education  Copyright   2005 by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	0	Neural cell recognition molecule L1: relating biological complexity to human disease mutations Sue Kenwrick+, Alex Watkins and Elena De Angelis.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	1	Wellcome Trust Centre for the Study of Molecular Mechanisms of Disease and Department of Medicine, University of Cambridge, Addenbrooke s Hospital, Cambridge CB2 2XY, UK.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received 5 February 2000; Accepted 11 February 2000.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	4	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	5	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	6	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   Human single gene disorders that affect the nervous system provide a host of natural mutations that can be deployed in the quest to understand its development and function.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	7	 A paradigm for this approach is the study of disorders caused by mutations in the gene for the neural cell recognition molecule L1.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	8	 L1 is the founder member of a subfamily of cell adhesion molecules that are primarily expressed in the nervous system, and to date it is the only one to be associated with a hereditary disease.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In this review we will summarize how the analysis of pathological mutations in L1 is complementing the study of mouse models and in vitro analysis of L1 function.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	10	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	11	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	12	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	13	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   L1 is one member of a subfamily of four mammalian cell surface glycoproteins that are related by structure and sequence (Fig.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	14	 They belong to the large class of immunoglobulin superfamily cell adhesion molecules (CAMs) that can mediate cell to cell adhesion through Ca2+-independent homo- or heterophilic binding at the cell surface (1,2).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Each member of the L1 subfamily contains six Ig-like domains linked to five fibronectin type III (FNIII) domains on the extracellular surface, a single-pass transmembrane domain and a short, but highly conserved, cytoplasmic tail.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	16	 L1 or L1-like molecules with this structure have been identified in many species including rodent, fish, fruit fly and nematode.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In each case they have proven to be important components of the ligand to receptor network of guidance forces that influence axonal growth and guidance (for reviews see refs 3 to 5).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	18	 For this reason L1 is more aptly called a neural recognition molecule rather than adhesion molecule.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	19	View larger version (30K):    Figure 1.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The vertebrate L1 subfamily comprises four structurally related molecules each containing six domains with structural similarity to the constant domains of immunoglobulins (Ig) and four or five domains similar to the type III repeats found in fibronectins (Fn).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	21	 NrCAM and Neurofascin (ankyrin binding glycoprotein/ABGP in rat) are known to have numerous isoforms dictated by alternative splicing, whereas L1 has only two isoforms: a neural isoform that includes the sequences encoded by mini exons 2 and 27 and a peripheral form that lacks these residues.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Neural L1 therefore contains five additional amino acids prior to the first Ig domain and a four-residue insertion in the cytoplasmic domain.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	23	 NgCAM is thought to be the chicken homologue of L1 although the sequence is not as highly conserved as that of other L1 subfamily members.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	24	 However, functional studies using human or rodent L1 have usually corroborated findings conducted with the chick protein.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In this review NgCAM and L1 are considered functionally equivalent.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	26	  In mammals, L1 is expressed throughout the nervous system on subsets of developing and differentiated neurons as well as on Schwann cells of the peripheral nervous system.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	27	 On differentiated neurons L1 is found at regions of contact between neighbouring axons and on the growth cones, the structures at the leading tip of axons that are responsible for sensing extracellular growth and guidance cues.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This distribution supports the suggestion from in vitro studies that L1 adhesive inter actions may mediate axon bundling (fasciculation) (6,7) and that L1 acts as a growth cone receptor for signals that induce the extension of processes (neurites) from neurons in culture (8).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Neurite outgrowth is likened to axon growth and is taken as evidence that L1 may be involved in axon growth during development.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	30	 L1 is also involved in interactions between Schwann cells of the peripheral nervous system and axons (9,10), in neuronal cell migration (11), synaptogenesis, myelination, neuronal cell survival (12) and even long-term potentiation (13).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Although primarily expressed in the nervous system L1 is also found at other specialized sites including a subclass of leukocytes, intestinal crypt cells and kidney tubule epithelia (14 to 16, and reviewed in ref.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	32	 As the human disorder involving L1 is essentially neurological we will focus here on its role in the nervous system.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	33	   MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT DEVELOPMENT OF THE NERVOUS SYSTEM IN MAN AND MOUSE TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	34	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	35	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	36	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   Mutations in the L1 gene are responsible for an X-linked recessive neurological disorder that has been described as X-linked hydrocephalus, MASA syndrome or spastic paraplegia type I (SPG1).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The varying nomenclature is a reflection of extremely variable presentation both within and between families (reviewed in refs 18 to 20).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The most consistent features in affected boys are degrees of lower limb spasticity, mental retardation, hydrocephalus and flexion deformity of the thumbs.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Those that develop hydrocephalus (water on the brain) in utero or soon after birth have a lower life expectancy and many die neonatally.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The excess of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and increased size of cerebral ventricles may partly result from stenosis of a thin channel called the aqueduct of Sylvius through which CSF circulates, although inadequate cell migration or loss of neurons may also contribute to the increase in cavity size.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Perhaps the most striking pathological observation is hypoplasia or absence of two long axonal tracts, the cortico spinal tract (CST) and the corpus callosum.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The former is involved in the control of voluntary motor function and its disruption provides an explanation for the spasticity observed in the patients.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The corpus callosum is the large bundle of nerve fibres that connects the two cerebral hemispheres and its underdevelopment may contribute to the mental retardation or epilepsy observed in patients with abnormal L1.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Other frequent malformations include underdevelopment of the anterior vermis of the cerebellum and fused thalami (21) which may indicate abnormal neuronal proliferation, migration or survival.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	45	The L1 protein in mice is very similar in sequence to human L1 and its targeted disruption in  knockout  mice produces interesting phenotypic similarities.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	46	 As in the human condition, the central nervous system of these mice is largely intact with major malformation limited to hypoplasia of the CST, corpus callosum and cerebellar vermis and a degree of ventricular enlargement (22).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	47	 L1 disruption in mice also produces a cognitive defect that may relate to the  mental retardation  of the human condition (23).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	48	 However, the real value of the mouse models is that a more detailed analysis of nervous system malformations and the mechanism underlying them is possible.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	49	 For example, abnormalities of the hippocampus and the morphology of individual neurons have been noted in L1 knockout mice (24).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Furthermore, in vivo confirmation of the involvement of L1 in Schwann cell function follows from the observation that L1-deficient mice have reduced interaction between Schwann cells and the axons of unmyelinated sensory nerves.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The resulting degeneration of sensory axons leads to impaired sensory function (10).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	52	 This observation will un- doubtedly lead to an assessment of sensory function in human subjects with L1 mutations.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	53	The mechanism by which L1 mutation disrupts the development of the CST in knockout lines involves failure in axonal pathfinding at a time when these axons are required to grow across the midline (25).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Presumably, L1 is required as an attractive or repulsive cue, substrate or neuronal receptor at this point in axon guidance.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The underdeveloped CST observed in mouse and man could result from degeneration of neurons that do not synapse with the correct targets.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	56	 In keeping with the extreme interfamilial as well as intrafamilial variability seen for the condition in man, some aspects of the knockout phenotype in mouse vary markedly on different genetic backgrounds (24), indicating the epistatic influence of other genes on the  penetrance  of the L1 mutation.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	57	Overall, the phenotypes observed in mouse and man show that L1 function is clearly pivotal for generation of certain axonal tracts and important for correct cortical and cerebellar morphology.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	58	   HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	59	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	60	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	61	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   It is apparent that L1 participates in a variety of different cellular responses both within and outside the nervous system.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	62	 This flexibility of function is probably related to a multiplicity of binding partners, potential signalling routes and post-translational modifications.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	63	Cell surface ligands A bewildering array of molecules have been found to bind to the extracellular domains (ECDs) of L1.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	64	 These include L1 itself, other members of the Ig superfamily, integrins, extracellular matrix proteins such as laminin and a variety of proteoglycans (reviewed in refs 17,26,27) (Fig.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Where and when these different interactions are relevant is now the challenging question.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	66	 L1 acting as ligand and receptor, will promote both cell adhesion and neurite outgrowth from explanted neurons, indicating that this interaction may be relevant to both fasciculation and axon growth.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Furthermore, cerebellar neurons from L1 knockout mice will no longer extend processes on purified L1 (22).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	68	 However, heterophilic ligands for L1 may also influence L1 activity.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In several cases this influence is exerted in the plane of the neuronal membrane (in cis).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	70	 For example, L1 binds in cis to TAG-1 a member of another subfamily of Ig CAMs (28) and this interaction may even be required for L1 to L1 mediated neurite outgrowth from specific neurons (29,30).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	71	 DM-GRASP, another cell surface adhesion molecule, may also cooperate with L1 to promote neurite outgrowth (31).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Cis interaction with NCAM has been shown to enhance the ability of L1 to bind homophilically (32) and the small cell surface glyco protein nectadrin (CD24) may also be recruited to this complex (33).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	73	View larger version (27K):    Figure 2.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The complexity of L1 interaction.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	75	 L1 is shown interacting homophilically at the neuronal cell surface with L1 present on another surface, e.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	76	 another cell membrane or extracellular matrix.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	77	 This interaction is known initiate neurite outgrowth through activation of a fibroblast growth factor receptors (FGFR) and a local increase in intracellular calcium within the neuronal growth cone (at least in some in vitro systems).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	78	 L1 is likely to be part of a complex that involves cis and trans interactions at the cell surface.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Some of these may modulate L1 binding or activity.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The biological consequences of L1 interaction with its many potential heterophilic ligands are largely unknown, although interaction with neurocan may have a negative effect on adhesion or axon growth.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The cytoplasmic domain interacts with the cytoskeleton and is subject to phosphorylation by a variety of kinases.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Ankyrin is mobilized to sites of L1 to L1 binding through direct attachment to L1 and this has an  inside-out  effect of stabilizing homophilic interaction.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Thin arrows represent binding potential, thick arrows a biological effect.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	84	 F11 and F3, and axonin-1 and TAG-1, are homologous chick and mammalian proteins, respectively.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	85	  Not all of L1 s potential interactions result in a positive effect on adhesion or axon growth.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	86	 For example, L1 binds with strong affinity to neurocan, a neural, extracellular matrix chondroitin sulfate proteoglycan that has an inhibitory effect on both neuronal adhesion and neurite outgrowth (34).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	87	Signalling Influences on cell behaviour imply that L1 ligand binding must be linked to intracellular signalling pathways.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	88	 So how does a cell surface glycoprotein with no self-contained catalytic domains engage a signalling pathway? One obvious way is by binding to molecules that can themselves elicit signal trans duction.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	89	 At least one mechanism through which L1 to L1 recognition can stimulate axonal growth is by activating the tyrosine kinase-linked receptors for fibroblast growth factors (FGFRs).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The downstream signalling cascade involved has been worked out in considerable detail and culminates in transient influx of calcium through L- and N-type channels at localized sites in the growth cone (35,36).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Growth cone morphology and behaviour are known to be sensitive to waves of calcium with increased concentration generally slowing neuritic growth (37,38).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	92	 How focal domains of calcium conversely promote growth cone advance is not understood, although one possibility is through the action of Ca2+-dependent modifiers of the actin cytoskeleton.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	93	Dimerization with TAG-1 offers yet another mechanism through which L1 may influence intracellular events as the chick homologue of TAG-1 (axonin-1) is associated, through an unknown linker, with non-receptor tyrosine kinase (39).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Components of the MAPK (mitogen-activated protein kinase) signalling pathway (40), tyrosine kinase src and pertussis toxin sensitive G proteins have also been implicated in L1 mediated responses (41,42).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	95	   INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	96	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	97	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	98	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   The 100 or so amino acid stretch of the cytoplasmic domain is the most conserved region between L1-like molecules in all species and its functional importance is highlighted by the finding that deletions or even single amino acid changes in this region can cause neurological disease in man.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Members of the L1 subfamily share an amino acid sequence that has high affinity for ankyrin, a linker protein of the spectrin-based cytoskeleton that underlies the plasma membrane (43,44).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Ankyrins are multi-domain proteins that can bind both cytoskeletal and integral membrane components and two forms (ankyrinB and ankyrinG) are abundant in the nervous system (45).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Mobilization of ankyrin to sites of cell contact is observed on homophilic binding of L1 or on formation of a TAG-1 to L1 complex (28).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Thus CAM adhesion is translated into mobilization of cytoskeletal components and potentially of other integral membrane proteins.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The ability of L1-like molecules to bind ankyrin is regulated by phosphorylation of a highly conserved tyrosine residue within the L1 cytoplasmic motif FIGQY (46).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Interestingly, deletion, mutation or phosphorylation of this motif has an inside-out effect on the ability of L1-like CAMs to bind homophilically (46), suggesting that ankyrin recruitment may have a role in stabilization of intercellular contacts that involve L1.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	105	 A role for ankyrin in L1 function is supported by the remarkable overlap between the phenotype of ankyrinB to / to  mice, L1-deficient mice and human subjects with L1 mutations (47).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The cytoplasmic domain can also associate with actin stress fibres (48).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	107	The cytoplasmic domain also houses a tyrosine-based sorting motif, YRSL (or more generally Yxx, where is an amino acid with a bulky hydrophobic side chain), that is required for the correct trafficking of L1 along axons to the growth cone as well as for L1 endocytosis (49,50, and see below).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The YRSL motif binds to the adaptor complex AP-2 in a pathway of internalization via clathrin-coated pits.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	109	L1 modification L1 is subject to glycosylation and phosphorylation, both of which may affect its function.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Modulation of L1 function by NCAM, for example, occurs through recognition of L1 carbohydrate (32).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	111	 In addition to tyrosine phosphorylation of the ankyrin-binding domain, serine phosphorylation by specific kinases occurs at several sites (40,51 to 53).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Interestingly, these sites are next to known binding domains for either cytoskeletal components or the AP-2 complex (Fig.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	113	 3A), suggesting that serine phosphorylation may influence cytoplasmic inter actions, L1 mobility and internalization.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Indeed, phosphorylation by ERK2 is found to be dependent on L1 endocytosis in vitro (40).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	115	 ERK2 and p90rsk are components of the MAPK pathway, a signalling cascade that can also be activated by FGFRs.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The possibility of cooperation between these pathways in modulating L1 action is intriguing.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	117	View larger version (51K):    Figure 3.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	118	 (A) Cytoplasmic domain interactions and mutations.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	119	 L1 has a highly conserved cytoplasmic domain that contains binding and phosphorylation sites (right).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	120	 These are shown relative to pathological mutations (left) with missense mutations boxed in yellow.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The YRSL motif of L1 is required for correct targeting to the growth cone.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	122	 It interacts with the AP-2 adapter complex facilitating endocytosis via clathrin-coated pits.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	123	 This may control the ability of L1 to respond rapidly to changes in environment.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	124	 This motif is partly encoded by an alternatively-spliced exon 27 (RSLE).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The rapid formation and disassociation of stable adhesion complexes of L1 with itself and other heterophilic ligands probably requires specific interaction with two components of the cytoskeleton: actin and ankyrin.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	126	 This may be regulated by phosphorylation of serine and tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic domain.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Phosphorylation of Y1229 reduces binding to ankyrin and this residue is mutated in one family.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	128	 (B) Distribution of missense mutations relative to extracellular domain function.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The sites of missense mutations (left) are shown relative to L1 domains involved in ligand binding and proteolytic cleavage (right).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Each line represents the results of a different study (referenced in parentheses) with solid lines covering regions definitely involved in binding.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The debate about which domains are required for homophilic binding continues.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Analysis of L1 fragments expressed in E.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	133	coli highlights 14 amino acids in Ig domain 2 as a key homophilic binding site (70).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Studies based on analysis of pathological missense mutations support the finding that Ig domain 2 is required for homophilic binding but indicate that the integrity of several other domains is also required (69).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Studies on NgCAM, the chicken homologue of L1, highlight Ig domains 2 to 4 as having a key role in homophilic binding (7).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Interactions of mutant L1 with F11 and axonin-1 indicate that the integrity of a number of domains are required (69) although the effects of individual mutations are distinct from their effects on L1 to L1 interaction.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Domain-deletion studies using NgCAM and axonin-1 suggest the involvement of at least Ig domains 2 to 4 and Fn domain 3 (7).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	138	 A site for integrin binding of 5ss1 or vss3 has been localized to two RGD motifs in the sixth Ig domain (71,72).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Neurocan, which inhibits neurite outgrowth, can bind Ig domain 1 but other domains may also be involved (72).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	140	  It has been known for some time that in addition to full-length 200 kDa protein, fragments of L1 polypeptide can be found in tissue extracts, but it has been a matter of debate whether L1 is specifically cleaved.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Recently, however, a matrix metalloprotease (TACE) and plasmin have been shown to release L1 from the cell surface through cleavage at specific sites (54,55) (Fig.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	142	 This raises the interesting possibility that as well as acting as a cell surface receptor, L1 may be released in a soluble form that could act as a ligand at some distance from its source.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Along with regulated endocytosis this may modulate the spatial availability of L1 in response to intra- or extracellular signals.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Such regulation may be very important, for example, at the growth cone where polarity of L1-mediated effects may influence axonal turning.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	145	L1 expression Further modification of L1 activity and localization is afforded by the use of specific splice variants.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The L1 gene comprises 29 exons of which 28 are coding (56,57).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Studies on its transcriptional regulation have revealed that its neural expression is at least partly determined by a neuron restrictive silencing element (NRSE) contained within the second intron and a homeobox- and paired domain-containing region (HPD) in the first intron (57,58).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Neural expression is also associated with inclusion of two mini exons (exons 2 and 27) that are excluded from the non-neural transcript (59,60).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Exon 27 (encoding RSLE) has a neuron-specific function as it contributes to the YRSL motif that is required for targeting to the growth cone.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	150	 As this sequence is lacking outside the nervous system AP-2-mediated endocytosis of L1 is presumably also restricted to neural tissue.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The function of exon 2 is unknown although preliminary results indicate that it may modulate homophilic and heterophilic ligand binding (E.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	152	   MUTATIONS IN L1: INFERENCES FOR L1 FUNCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	153	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	154	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	155	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   Since our first description of an L1 mutation (61), 91 different mutations have been identified in  > 100 families (62, and references therein).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Most forms of mutation have been reported and they are distributed across all domains (38 missense, 10 nonsense, 21 frameshift, 17 splicing, 5 intragenic deletion and 1 intragenic duplication).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Most of the nonsense and frameshift mutations would eliminate cell surface expression of L1 through truncation prior to the transmembrane domain.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Although the mutations are heterogeneous, attempts to relate position and type of disruption to phenotype are confounded by intrafamilial variability in presentation.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Nevertheless, mutations of the cytoplasmic domain are less likely to cause life-threatening hydrocephalus than those disrupting the extra cellular surface, indicating some qualitative difference in the effect of these two broad classes of mutation (63).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	160	 As homophilic binding may be preserved in the absence of the cytoplasmic domain (64,65) the relative longevity of patients with cytoplasmic mutations may be due to preservation of some of L1 s  adhesive  functions.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	161	   CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	162	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	163	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	164	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   Five mutations truncate the cytoplasmic domain at various points along its length and these can be related to known sites of L1 binding, modification or intracellular trafficking (Fig.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Whereas some delete additional functional sites, all eliminate at least part of the conserved ankyrin-binding domain as well as the tyrosine residue at position 1229 that is involved in moderating ankyrin binding for the L1 subfamily (46,66).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Mutation of Y1229 to histidine in one family confirms the importance of controlled ankyrin binding for L1 function in the nervous system.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	167	 No mutations have been found to date that mutate serines phosphorylated by p90rsk (S1152), casein kinase II (S1181) or ERK2 (S1204 and S1248).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	168	 However, mutation of an additional serine at 1194 implicates this residue as a potential substrate for modification.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Clearly mutations that delete the RSLE will also disrupt trafficking of L1 in differentiated neurons, only allowing transport of protein to the cell soma.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	170	   MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE ECDS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	171	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	172	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	173	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   The most interesting mutations to consider with respect to gene function are the missense mutations and for L1 these represent the largest single class.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The majority are distributed across 10 of 11 of the ECDs (Fig.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Outline structures for the ECDs based on the crystallographic resolution of related proteins allow predictions to be made concerning the structural outcome of many of these changes (67).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Over half of the mutations that can be mapped onto these structures are found to affect residues that are key to the structural integrity of individual domains (Table 1).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	177	 A smaller proportion affect residues that are not part of the core structure and are more likely to affect surface properties of L1 than domain integrity.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Additional insight comes from the structural resolution of hemolin, an insect protein composed of four Ig domains with similarity to the first four domains of L1.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In hemolin these domains are folded into a horseshoe structure through interaction between Ig domains 1 and 4 and between domains 2 and 3 (68).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Interestingly, 50% of the human mutations affected Ig domains 1 to 4 lie in the contact regions that are required for this four-domain conglomerate.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Missense mutations in L1 and their effect on domain structure and ligand binding   Missense mutations can theoretically have a number of consequences for L1 production and function.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Firstly, they may alter the folding or intracellular trafficking of L1.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	183	 A mutation of the signal peptide (W9S), for example, has predictably been found to affect cell surface expression (69).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Secondly, mutations that put a cysteine on the surface of the molecule, such as Y194C and Y1070C, could be affecting protein function or mobility by promoting inappropriate intermolecular disulfides either during folding or on the cell surface.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Thirdly, and most intriguingly, some of these mutations may affect ligand binding and therefore offer the potential for mutation-based structure to function studies.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Through analysing 12 mutations we have shown that missense changes in the ECDs have variable effects on binding of L1 to itself or to the related CAMs TAG-1/axonin-1 and F3/F11 (69) (Table 1).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Whereas many mutations affect more than one binding activity, several have no influence or affect homo- or heterophilic binding selectively.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	188	 As the latter are usually surface changes they may highlight key binding sites for specific ligands.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	189	 For example, E309K is a surface mutation that does not affect homophilic binding but severely compromises binding to axonin-1 and F11.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Interestingly, mutations affect TAG-1/axonin-1 and F3/F11 binding in a similar way indicating that these two structurally related ligands interact with L1 in a very similar fashion.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	191	 These studies indicate, for the first time, that pathogenesis may result from different effects on L1 ligand binding.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	192	 That several domains are required for correct homo- or heterophilic binding of L1 is also apparent.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	193	 This is in contrast to results of a previous study using isolated domains, which suggested that only Ig domain 2 was required for homophilic interaction (70).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	194	 This difference may be reconciled if Ig domain 2 contains an essential binding site but interaction requires considerable antiparallel overlap of L1 monomers.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Figure 3B also shows the distribution of missense mutations alongside known binding regions for several L1 ligands (7,69 to 72).
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	196	 It is clear that domains of interaction overlap considerably and that human mutations may also be affecting binding to integrins or proteo glycans.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Further studies on the effects of L1 mutations both on ligand binding and on intracellular processing will allow a much better understanding of disease pathology and the functional requirements of L1 domains, and will influence the design of animal models that test the relevance of disrupting specific aspects of L1 interaction and mobility.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	198	   SUMMARY TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	199	 HOW DOES L1 FUNCTION? INTERACTIONS OF THE CYTOPLASMIC.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	200	 CYTOPLASMIC DOMAIN MISSENSE MUTATIONS AFFECTING THE.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	201	 SUMMARY REFERENCES   L1 is part of a dynamic complex of interacting molecules, associated signal transduction pathways and cytoskeletal connections.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	202	 How these different pathways cross-talk to influence neurite outgrowth, stabilize cell adhesion or affect neuronal migration is unclear although some general principles do emerge.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Firstly, L1 is not merely an intercellular glue but a receptor capable of transducing signals to the inside of the cell as well as responding to signals from the inside.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Secondly, it has an intimate and plastic relationship with the cytoskeleton.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Thirdly, L1 activity is mediated by a number of different binding partners, both in trans and in cis, as well as post-translational modification and cleavage.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Mutation of L1 in man and mouse results in developmental defects that are consistent with a role for L1 in axonal pathfinding as well as cell migration.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Assessment of the effects of disease-causing mutations on L1 function together with analysis of animal models is proving a valuable tool in relating L1 function to in vivo activity.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	208	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   We would like to thank the Wellcome Trust and the EC for their support.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	209	   FOOTNOTES   + To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Tel: +44 1223 762616; Fax: +44 1223 331206; Email: sjk12@mole.
0.16214354.10767310.html.plaintext.txt	211	   REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MUTATIONS IN L1 AFFECT.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	0	ET-1 receptor gene expression and distribution in L1 and L2 cells from hypertensive sheep pulmonary artery Elena V.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Balyakina1, Daohong Chen2, Mayme L.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Lawrence2, Suzanne Manning2, Richard E.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Shappell2, and Barbara Meyrick1,2.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	4	Departments of 2 Pathology and 1 Medicine and Center for Lung Research, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, Tennessee 37232-2650.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	5	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	6	We examined gene and surface expression and activity of the endothelin (ET)-1 receptors (ETA and ETB) in subendothelial (L1) and inner medial (L2) cells from the main pulmonary artery of sheep with continuous air embolization (CAE)-induced chronic pulmonary hypertension (CPH).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	7	 According to quantitative real-time RT-PCR, basal gene expression of both receptors was significantly higher in L2 than L1 cells, and hypertensive L2 cells showed significantly higher gene expression of ETB than controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Expression of both genes in hypertensive L1 cells was similar to controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Fluorescence-activated cell sorter analysis confirmed the increased distribution of ETB in hypertensive L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Although only the ETA receptors in control L2 cells showed significant binding of [125I]-labeled ET-1 at 1 h, both receptors bound ET-1 to hypertensive cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Exposure to exogenous ET-1 for 18 h revealed that only the L2 cells internalized ET-1, and internalization by hypertensive L2 cells was significantly reduced when compared with controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Treatment with ETA (BQ-610) and ETB (BQ-788) receptor antagonists demonstrated that both receptors contributed to internalization of ET-1 in control L2 cells, whereas in hypertensive cells only when both receptor antagonists were used in combination was significant suppression of ET-1 internalization found.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	13	 We conclude that in sheep receiving CAE, alterations in ETB receptors in cells of the L2 layer may contribute to the maintenance of CPH via alterations in their expression, distribution, and activity.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	14	ETA receptor; ETB receptor; smooth muscle cells; pulmonary hypertension; endothelin.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	15	    INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	16	SINCE ITS DISCOVERY 12 YEARS AGO, endothelin (ET) has been shown to contribute to a wide variety of physiological and pathophysiological processes in various systems (22).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The ET family of 21 amino acid peptides exists in three distinct isoforms: ET-1, ET-2, and ET-3.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	18	 It is an extremely potent vasoconstrictor resulting in slowly developing and sustained contraction.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Although the endothelial cell was originally described as the source of ET-1, it is now known that several other cell types, including pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cells, synthesize this peptide (33, 36).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	20	The biological effects of ET-1 are mediated by two distinct ET receptor subtypes, ETA and ETB (1, 35).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The affinity of the ETA receptor for ET-1 has been shown to be ~100 times that for ET-3 (ET-1  >  ET-2  >  ET-3), whereas the affinity of the ETB receptor is equipotent for all three isoforms of ET (34).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Early reports indicated that the ETA receptor on smooth muscle was responsible for the vasoconstrictor effect of ET-1, whereas the ETB receptor on endothelial cells modulated ET-1-induced vasodilation.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	23	 However, recent pharmacological studies suggest that there are two classes of ETB with cell specific effects, ETB1 on endothelial cells mediating vasodilation and ETB2 on smooth muscle cells mediating vasoconstriction (9).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The ETB receptor also functions as a "clearance receptor" and is particularly important in the lung, where 50% of ET-1 is retained (22, 29).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	25	ET-1 has been linked to the development of chronic pulmonary hypertension (CPH).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Increased expression of the peptide has been demonstrated in endothelial cells of pulmonary arteries from patients with idiopathic and secondary forms of pulmonary hypertension (15), and arterial-to-venous ratios of ET-1 protein were found to be elevated above the normal range in patients with pulmonary hypertension (40).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Several studies have linked increased expression of ET-1 to the development of hypoxia-induced CPH in rats (5, 24), and use of ET-1 receptor antagonists has been shown both to inhibit progression of the disease and to promote recovery (4, 10, 43).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	28	Although these studies support a central role for ET-1 in the pathogenesis of CPH, the picture is likely more complicated than first suspected, in that prepro-ET-1 (ppET-1) mRNA is decreased in the monocrotaline model of CPH, and in addition, we recently reported regional variability in ppET-1 gene expression in the pulmonary artery of normal sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Furthermore, we found in a model of CPH, sheep receiving continuous air embolization (CAE) into the main pulmonary artery, that ppET-1 gene expression in the main pulmonary artery and peripheral lung gradually decreased with the onset of pulmonary hypertension while the midregion artery (9th-10th generation) showed a gradual increase (42).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	30	At least four cell types have been identified in the bovine main pulmonary artery: subendothelial L1 cells, inner medial L2 cells, and outer medial L3S and L3R cells (12, 13).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	31	 We recently showed that L1 cells (a cell with characteristics of both endothelial and smooth muscle cells) cultured from control sheep produce strikingly more ET-1 than L2 cells (mature smooth muscle cells) under basal conditions, but when exposed to exogenous ET-1, only the L2 cells internalize exogenous ET-1 (41).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The present study examines whether ETA and ETB gene and surface expression is altered in L1 and L2 cells from control and hypertensive sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	33	 This study also examines whether ET-1 receptor distribution and activity are altered in L1 and L2 cells cultured from hypertensive sheep induced by 12 days of CAE.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	34	    METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The protocol for delivery of CAE into the sheep pulmonary artery has been described previously, and the physiological and structural changes for this model of CPH have been reported in detail (16, 32).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Briefly, a left thoracotomy was performed on yearling mixed-breed sheep under general anesthesia, and pulmonary artery and left atrial catheters were inserted.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	37	 A jugular venous introducer and carotid artery catheter were placed through a neck incision.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	38	 After a recovery period of 3-5 days, a Swan-Ganz catheter was positioned in the pulmonary artery through the jugular vein introducer.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Baseline measurements of pulmonary arterial pressure (Ppa), cardiac output (CO), and left atrial pressure (Pla) were made, and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) was calculated using the formula: PVR = (Ppa  Pla)/CO.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	40	 After baseline measurements, the sheep received CAE (n = 3) into the pulmonary artery by way of the proximal port (lying in the right heart) of the Swan-Ganz catheter over a 12-day period.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The rate of air embolization administered was sufficient to cause an increase in PVR that was ~2.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Physiological measurements were performed each day, and the rate of air flow was adjusted as necessary to maintain the elevation in PVR.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Surgically prepared animals not receiving air but maintained for the same time period served as controls (n = 3).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	44	 At the end of the experiment, the animals were killed with an overdose of sodium barbiturate (pentobarbital sodium 325 mg   ml1   5 kg1 body wt, Euthanazia-5 solution; Henry Schein, Port Washington, NY), and the lungs were removed.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The main pulmonary artery was dissected from a point 1 cm from its exit from the right ventricle to its point of entry into the right and left lungs, and a section was taken for routine light microscopy and for 1- microm sections of epoxy-embedded tissue.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Cells were isolated from the subendothelial (L1) and inner medial (L2) layers of the main pulmonary artery from control and hypertensive sheep as previously described (41, 42).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Briefly, the artery was opened, and the endothelial layer was removed by gentle scraping; the subendothelial L1 cells were isolated from pulmonary artery segments by deep scraping.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The inner media L2 cells were isolated either by a modified explant technique or by enzymatic dissociation.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Using phase contrast microscopy, we identified L1 and L2 cell colonies by their morphology, trypsinized them in "cloning rings" and transferred them into culture dishes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Both cells types were seeded and cultured in RPMI-1640 containing 100 U/ml penicillin, 100  microg/ml streptomycin, 40  microg/ml gentamicin, 2 mmol/l L-glutamine (GIBCO-BRL, Grand Island, NY), and 15% heat-inactivated calf serum (Atlanta Biologicals, Norcross, GA).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Confluent cells (passages 3-6) were used for all experiments; higher passage numbers have been associated with a substantial increase in ETB receptor density (27).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Cell lines cultured from each of three different control and three different hypertensive animals were used for each assay.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	53	 All experiments were carried out in RPMI-1640 containing 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Experiments were initiated after overnight incubation of the cells in that medium.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	55	 For real-time RT-PCR analysis of ETA and ETB gene expression, cells were harvested 90 min after addition of 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	56	 For dose-response studies of ET-1 internalization, intracellular levels of ET-1 were measured after 18-h exposure to exogenous ET-1 at concentrations from 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Experiments with ETA (BQ-610) and ETB (BQ-788) antagonists included a 2-h preincubation period before addition of exogenous ET-1 (10 nM) for 18 h.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The dose of each antagonist used in these experiments was based on dose-response curves.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The concentrations of BQ-610 tested were from 1 to 100  microM, and those for BQ-788 were from 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The dose chosen was the dose that gave a 50% reduction in uptake of exogenous ET-1 by control L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	61	 For ET-1 binding assays, cells in two P150 dishes were pretreated with either BQ-610 or BQ-788 for 2 h before isolation of cell membranes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Untreated L1 and L2 cells and cells treated with each antagonist alone served as controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	63	Quantitative real-time RT-PCR for ETA and ETB.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Total RNA was isolated with RNA STAT-60 reagent (TEL-TEST "B", Friendswood, TX).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	65	 mRNA copy numbers of ETA and ETB in L1 and L2 cultured cells from control and hypertensive sheep were determined by real-time quantitative RT-PCR using a Lightcycler fluorescence temperature rapid-air cycler (Roche Molecular Biochemicals, Indianapolis, IN) with cDNA (ETA) or RNA (ETB) standard curves and the double-stranded DNA binding fluorescent probe SYBR green (38).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Amplifications were done in glass capillary tubes with a 20- microl reaction of 200 ng for L2 and L1 total RNA samples, 6 mM magnesium chloride, 2.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	67	0  microl 1 x  SYBR green RNA master-mix (Roche Molecular Biochemicals), 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	68	4  microl RT enzyme (Roche Molecular Biochemicals), and 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	69	The cDNA template for ETA standard curves was derived by reverse transcription of total RNA from control L2 cells (17).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Total RNA from L2 cells was used as a template for standard curves for the RT-PCR assay for ETB.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Copy number for ETA and ETB standard templates was assigned based on the concentration of the total cDNA or RNA and the known number of base pairs (bp) in the full-length cDNAs or RNA of ETA and ETB, respectively.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The primers for ETA (based on the human sequence) were: 5' AGC TTC CTG GTT ACC ACT CAT CAA 3' (forward) and 5' TCA ACA TCT CAC AAG TCA TGA G 3' (reverse), which give a 714-bp product (corresponding to nucleotides 136-850) (45).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	73	Primers for ETB were derived from a newly generated sheep cDNA sequence, because our first attempts at real-time RT-PCR using primers generated from the human ETB cDNA sequence revealed several nonspecific products.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Briefly, RT-PCR amplimers for sheep ETB were cloned into pGEM-T Easy Vector System (Promega, Madison, WI) and transformed into DH5a-competent cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Positive colonies were selected by color screening, and the plasmid DNA was isolated using a QIAprep Spin Miniprep Kit (QIAGEN).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Digestion of the plasmid DNA with EcoRI gave inserts of the expected size (701 bp).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Comparison of the sequence of these clones with the human sequence demonstrated 89-90% homology.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	78	 New ETB primers were designed to amplify a 297-bp fragment from this sequence using DNA-STAR software.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The utilized ETB primers were: 5'-TTT GGC CAC TTC CCG TCT CTG TTT 3' (forward) and 5' ATT TGG GTG GTC TCC GTG GTT CTG 3' (reverse).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	80	The one-step real-time RT-PCR reactions consisted of the following steps: reverse transcription at 55 degrees C for 15 min, denaturation at 95 degrees C for 1 min, amplification for 55 cycles, and melting curve analysis from 95 to 65 degrees C at a rate of 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	81	1 degrees C/s under continuous fluorescence monitoring.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The amplification program for ETA consisted of heating at 20 degrees C/s to 95 degrees C, cooling at 20 degrees C/s to 57 degrees C, annealing at 57 degrees C for 5 s, heating at 20 degrees C/s to 72 degrees C, elongation at 72 degrees C for 29 s, and heating at 5 degrees C/s to 86 degrees C for fluorescence acquisition.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The amplification program for ETB consisted of heating at 20 degrees C/s to 95 degrees C, cooling at 20 degrees C/s to 55 degrees C, annealing at 55 degrees C for 5 s, heating at 20 degrees C/s to 72 degrees C, elongation at 72 degrees C for 14 s, and heating at 5 degrees C/s to 79 degrees C for fluorescence acquisition.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The specificity of the amplimer in each reaction was confirmed by melting curve analysis, with initial gel confirmation that this large peak corresponded to the expected amplimer (representative melting curve analysis for ETB shown in Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The contribution to fluorescence signal of any nonspecific products and/or primer dimers was eliminated by increasing the temperature to 2 degrees C below the melting temperature of the specific product, which eliminated any other minor cDNAs (which have lower melting temperatures) (38).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Copy numbers of mRNA were calculated from serially diluted standard curves generated from cDNA or RNA templates (17, 38).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Serial dilutions (1:10) over a range of three orders of magnitude were used to generate the standard curves.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The serially diluted standards were simultaneously amplified with the unknown samples to generate a linear standard curve by the fit-points method of analysis with five points.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Standard curves for both ETA and ETB consistently had correlation coefficients of 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	90	00 (representative sample for ETB is shown in Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Control samples run in triplicate had a variance of ~10%.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	92	 All biological samples fell on the standard curves, and copy numbers of the unknown samples were calculated with the Lightcycler software (version 3).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	93	 ETA and ETB values were normalized to the copy numbers of the housekeeping gene glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (G3PDH) and multiplied by 100 (%) to correct any variation in amount of RNA utilized per assay.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	94	 All samples for an individual receptor subtype were analyzed in the same assay, eliminating any contribution of interassay variability.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	95	ET-1 ligand-receptor maximal binding assay.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Control and hypertensive L2 cells were pretreated with BQ-610 and BQ-788 alone and together for 2 h before isolation of crude cell membrane fractions (CMF) as previously described (42).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Maximal ET-1 receptor binding (Bmax) was examined by mixing 20  microg of CMF protein with 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	98	1  microCi of [125I]-labeled ET-1 (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) at 37 degrees C for 1 h.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The reaction was performed in a total volume of 200  microl in 50 mM Tris buffer.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Controls for nonspecific binding were carried out in parallel using 20  microg of CMF protein mixed with 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	101	5  microM unlabeled ET-1 plus 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The reaction was terminated by passing the reaction mix through a Glass Fiber C-grade filter paper (Whatman, Maidstone, England) and washing it in PBS.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The bound radioactive disintegrations on the filter paper were then counted on an autoradiocounter for [125I].
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The counts were correlated to saturation curves using Ligand software, and the Bmax of ET-1 receptors was calculated for each experimental group.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	105	Assessment of ETA and ETB by flow cytometry.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Confluent monolayers of L1 and L2 cells in P100 dishes were treated with a modified cell dissociation buffer (Life Technologies, Rockville, MD) containing 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	107	5% EDTA disodium salt, 6% glycerol, and 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	108	06 M sodium citrate for 15 min at room temperature.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The dissociated cells were centrifuged at 800 rpm for 10 min at 4 degrees C, and the pellet was resuspended in 1 ml of cold 1% BSA in PBS.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	110	 A further 1 ml of cold PBS-1% BSA was added, and the cell suspensions were divided into two microcentrifuge tubes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The samples were washed twice by centrifugation for 15 s at 4 degrees C, and each cell pellet was resuspended in 100  microl of cold PBS-1% BSA.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Sheep ETA and ETB receptor antibodies (Oxford Biomedical Research, Oxford, MI) were added to each sample to give a final concentration of 1  microg/106 cells, and the samples were incubated at 4 degrees C for 1 h.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The cells were then washed twice in cold PBS-1% BSA; rabbit F(ab')2 anti-sheep IgG (heavy + light)-FITC (Southern Biotechnology Associates, Birmingham, AL) was added to a final concentration of 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	114	5 mg/ml, and the samples were incubated in the dark at 4 degrees C for 30 min.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The samples were washed twice in cold PBS-1% BSA and fixed in 1% paraformaldehyde in PBS (Electron Microscopy Sciences, Fort Washington, PA) at 4 degrees C for 10 min in the dark.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The samples were then put into a light-protected tube, placed on ice, and submitted for fluorescence-activated cell sorter (FACS) analysis.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Controls included untreated cells and cells that were treated with the secondary antibody alone (background controls).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	118	Flow cytometric measurements were performed at a Becton-Dickinson FACStar+ instrument, equipped with a single 5-W argon-ion water-cooled laser tuned to 488 nm (blue green) and three fluorescence detectors.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The data were analyzed using Cell Quest software (Becton-Dickinson, San Jose, CA).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Each sample was measured in duplicate.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	121	 All cells were included in the analysis (3).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Specific fluorescence (Fsp) was calculated by subtracting the mean fluorescence of all the cells in each sample reacted with the secondary antibody alone (Fbkgd) from that obtained with the specific antibodies (Ftot).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Percent specific signal (%Fsp) was also calculated using the formula: %Fsp = Fsp/(Ftot  x  100) (20).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	124	ET-1 extraction and measurement of intracellular ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Intracellular levels of mature ET-1 were determined in homogenates from both L1 and L2 cells as described previously (42).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Briefly, at the end of the experiment, cells were washed three times in serum-free medium and trypsinized, and cell number was counted using a hemocytometer.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	127	 After centrifugation at 1,000 rpm for 10 min, the cell pellets were homogenized in 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	128	1% Triton X-100 with a Teflon glass pestle.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The homogenates were centrifuged at 3,000 rpm for 15 min, and the supernatants were collected for solid-phase extraction.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The cell supernatants were acidified by 2 M HCl and loaded in Sep-Pak C18 cartridges, which were prewashed with 100% methanol, acetonitrile-5 mmol/l trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), and distilled H2O with 5 mmol/l TFA.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Each cartridge was then washed in distilled H2O with 5 mmol/l TFA and eluted with 2 ml of 80% methanol containing 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The samples were divided into two tubes and dried under vacuum.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Levels of ET-1 were determined in 100- microl aliquots of L1 and L2 homogenates using a commercially available ET-1 ELISA system (Biotrak ELISA System; Amersham International).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The ELISA was performed according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The assay is sensitive to values of  > 1 fmol and cross-reacts with 100% of ET-1 and ET-2 (ET-2 is not generally found in the walls of the pulmonary vasculature) but not with ET-3 ( < 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Each sample was run in duplicate.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Results were expressed as femtomoles of ET-1 per 106 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Values are presented as means  plus or minus  SE.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Data from control and hypertensive L1 and L2 cells were compared using the Student's t-test.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Dose-response curves, ET-1 binding, and ET-1 internalization studies were analyzed by ANOVA followed by the Duncan multiple-comparison test.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	141	05 was considered statistically significant.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Analysis was performed using the Number Cruncher Statistical System (version 6.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	143	    RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	144	In previous studies we have documented that 12 days of CAE causes the development of sustained pulmonary hypertension that is characterized by a doubling of PVR (32).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The sheep utilized in the present study showed a similar significant increase in PVR after 12 days of CAE (controls, 2.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The control animals exhibited no increase in PVR over a 12-day period.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	147	Morphology of L1 and L2 cells in control and hypertensive sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Light microscopy revealed that 12 days of CAE resulted in a striking increase in the thickness of both the L1 and L2 layers of the main pulmonary artery (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Marked hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the L1 and L2 cells were apparent as was an increase in extracellular ground substance.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	150	View larger version (87K):    Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	151	   Light micrographs showing subendothelial (L1) and inner medial (L2) layers of control (A) and hypertensive (B) sheep pulmonary artery.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Section (1  microm) stained with toluidine blue.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	153	As shown previously, L1 and L2 cells cultured from the main pulmonary artery of control sheep showed cell-specific differences in morphology.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	154	 By phase-contrast microscopy, L2 cells exhibited the characteristic spindle shape and "hill-and-valley" formation of mature smooth muscle, whereas the L1 cells were initially rhomboidal and later formed a multilayer of rhomboidal and large stellate cells (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	155	 L1 cells cultured from the hypertensive sheep maintained a shape and size similar to control cells (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	156	 2D), whereas the hypertensive L2 cells were larger and more rounded than control cells (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	157	 2B), and the typical hill-and-valley formation was less pronounced.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	158	View larger version (183K):    Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	159	   Phase contrast micrographs of L1 and L2 cells isolated from control and hypertensive sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	160	 A: control L2 cells exhibit the characteristic spindle shape and hill-and-valley formation of mature smooth muscle cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	161	 B: hypertensive L2 cells are larger, more rounded, and the hill-and-valley formation is less pronounced that in controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	162	 C: control L1 cells show a rhomboidal shape.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	163	ETA and ETB receptor gene expression in control and hypertensive L1 and L2 cells.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	168	08  x  1012, respectively) (P  <  0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Similar findings were demonstrated when these data were related to G3PDH (Fig.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	192	ETA and ETB expression by FACS analysis on control and hypertensive L1 and L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	193	 FACS analysis of control and hypertensive L1 and L2 cells, when expressed as Fsp, revealed no significant difference between the ETA and ETB receptors save for a modest trend to an increase in ETB expression in the hypertensive L2 cells compared with the controls (Fig.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	196	 However, when the data were expressed as percent-specific fluorescence, a modest but significant increase in ETB was apparent for the hypertensive L2 cells compared with controls (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	197	 5B), confirming the real-time RT-PCR data.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In hypertensive cells, treatment with the ETA and ETB inhibitors alone or in combination led to a significant reduction in Bmax below their baseline value (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	209	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	210	   Effect of ETA and ETB receptor antagonists (BQ-610 and BQ-788, respectively) on maximal binding (Bmax) of ET-1 in control (open bars) and hypertensive (hatched bars) L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Data are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE, *P  <  0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	212	Internalization of ET-1 by L1 and L2 cells from control and hypertensive sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Exposure of L2 cells from control animals to various concentrations of ET-1 resulted in a dose-dependent increase in intracellular ET-1 with a 50% effective dose (ED50) of 2 nM (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	214	 L2 cells from hypertensive sheep also showed a dose-dependent increase in intracellular ET-1, but the level of uptake was 10-fold less than that seen for control cells (ANOVA P  <  0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	215	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
