0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	221	ET-1 receptor antagonists and ET-1 internalization by L2 cells from control and hypertensive sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Because only L2 cells responded to exogenous ET-1, experiments with ETA and ETB receptors antagonists were performed only on those cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Pretreatment of control L2 cells with various concentrations of either the ETA antagonist BQ-610 or the ETB antagonist BQ-788 revealed that the IC50 for BQ-610 in our system was 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	224	 8) and that for BQ-788 was 25  microM (data not shown).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The concentration of each receptor antagonist giving the IC50 was chosen for further experiments.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	226	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	227	   Dose-responses curve for the ETA antagonist BQ-610 in control L2 cells demonstrating its effectiveness against internalization of exogenous ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Cells were treated with BQ-610 for 2 h, washed, and then exposed to 10 nM ET-1 for 18 h.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Uptake is shown as intracellular levels of ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	230	Basal levels of intracellular ET-1 in control and hypertensive L2 cells were not altered by exposure to either BQ-610 or BQ-788 (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Exposure of control L2 cells to exogenous ET-1 resulted in a significant increase in intracellular ET-1 (P  <  0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	232	 9A); pretreatment with either BQ-610 or BQ-788 significantly suppressed the increase in intracellular ET-1 by 18 and 25%, respectively.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Simultaneous exposure to both antagonists caused an additive inhibitory effect (~40%), although the level of intracellular ET-1 remained significantly elevated above basal levels (P  <  0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	234	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	235	   Effect of the ETA and ETB receptor antagonists BQ-610 and BQ-788 alone and in combination on uptake of exogenous ET-1 (10 nM) in L2 cells from control sheep (A) and hypertensive sheep (B).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Cells were pretreated with antagonists for 2 h, washed, and then exposed to ET-1 for 18 h (hatched bars).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Controls (open bars) did not receive ET-1 treatment.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Data are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE, n = 6, except for the experiments with both antagonists where n = 3.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	239	Basal levels of intracellular ET-1 in the hypertensive L2 cells were similar to those in control cells (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	240	 9B), although uptake by hypertensive cells was ~50% less than by control cells (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Unlike the response of the control cells, pretreatment of the hypertensive L2 cells with either BQ-610 of BQ-788 failed to inhibit the ET-1-stimulated increase in intracellular ET-1 (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Simultaneous exposure to both antagonists, however, caused significant and striking inhibition of the ET-1-stimulated increase in intracellular ET-1 such that the level of intracellular ET-1 returned to basal values.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	243	    DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	244	In a previous study, our group identified differences in the ET-1 system in L1 and L2 cells from control sheep (41).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	245	 L1 cells, like endothelial cells, were found to synthesize and release ET-1, whereas L2 cells had less synthetic capacity for ET-1 but, rather, had the propensity to internalize exogenous ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The present study extends these findings and examines ETA and ETB gene and surface expression, Bmax sites, and activity as assessed by ET-1 internalization by L1 and L2 cells from the main pulmonary artery of control sheep and those with sustained pulmonary hypertension induced by CAE.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The present in vitro study documents that the hypertensive L2 cells, as seen in vivo, maintain their hypertrophic appearance, whereas the L1 cells from the thickened subendothelial layer revert to an appearance similar to controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	248	 In addition, we show that L2 cells from control and hypertensive animals exhibit significantly higher basal expression of both the ETA and ETB genes than L1 cells and that ETB gene and surface expression in hypertensive L2 cells was significantly increased compared with controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The present findings also confirm that L2, but not L1, cells from control sheep internalize exogenous ET-1 in a dose-dependent manner and further demonstrate that L2 cells from hypertensive sheep internalize less ET-1 than controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	250	 In addition, we found that in control cells, the ETA receptors were mainly responsible for binding ET-1 to the L2 cells, but after 18 h of exposure to ET-1, both receptors played a role in internalization.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Using ETA and ETB receptor antagonists, our study also demonstrates that in hypertensive cells, both receptors bound radiolabeled ET-1; internalization of ET-1, however, was inhibited only when the ETA and ETB antagonists were used in combination.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	252	Function of ETA and ETB receptors.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	253	 In humans, ETA and ETB are encoded by distinct genes located on chromosomes 4 and 13, respectively (32).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	254	 In pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cells, the ETA receptor is linked to vasoconstriction as well as hypertrophy and smooth muscle proliferation, whereas the ETB receptor is linked to clearance of ET-1 from the circulation as well as both vasoconstriction and vasodilation (22, 36, 39).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Studies in the pulmonary vasculature suggest that the actions of ET-1 are mediated by at least three receptors: one ETA receptor and two ETB receptor subtypes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Pharmacological studies in several species indicate that the endothelial ETB receptor (designated ETB1) mediates vasodilatation, whereas the ETB2 receptor expressed in smooth muscle acts as vasoconstrictor (5, 7, 9).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	257	ETA and ETB receptors are G protein-coupled receptors that undergo agonist-stimulated desensitization or inactivation (26).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Desensitization is thought to prevent both overstimulation and damage to activated cells as well as saturation by weak stimuli.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Phosphorylation has been identified as the major mechanism for rapid desensitization for many G protein-coupled receptors.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	260	 In humans, ETA receptors have been shown to have a prolonged period of desensitization occurring within 5 min of exposure to ET-1; sensitization is restored between 80 and 120 min (8).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	261	 This prolonged desensitization period seems to be unique to the ETA receptor and may explain, at least in part, the prolonged contraction of smooth muscle cells in response to ET-1 (6).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	262	 The ETB receptors, on the other hand, are rapidly deactivated (via phosphorylation and dehydration) and lose  > 80% of their initial activity within 5 min of agonist stimulation.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This rapid deactivation of ETB has been linked to the short-term vasodilatory effect of ET-1 (7).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The present study shows that both ETA and ETB receptors bind and are responsible for internalization of exogenous ET-1; however, our data in hypertensive cells suggest that both receptors types have become desensitized.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	265	ETA and ETB receptors in L1 and L2 cells from control sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Both ETA and ETB receptors have been identified in pulmonary and systemic vascular smooth muscle cells, e.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	267	, rat aorta (30), human internal mammary artery and vein, porcine coronary arteries (37), and rat and human pulmonary artery (28).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	268	 In humans, ETA receptors were found in both resistance and conduit arteries, and in the main pulmonary artery, ETA receptors predominated (90%) (5).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Tracheal smooth muscle from rats and mice, however, exhibited approximately equal numbers of the two receptor subtypes (18), whereas ETB receptors were 50% more numerous than ETA in rat pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells (23).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Thus the distribution and density of ET-1 receptors on various smooth muscle types may vary between species and location (5, 31).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	271	The present study demonstrates that L1 and L2 cells from control sheep express both the ETA and ETB genes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The significantly lower expression of both genes in L1 cells compared with L2 cells substantiates our previous suggestion that the L1 cell contributes little to the maintenance of vascular tone in the main pulmonary artery.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The paucity of ET-1 receptors in L1 cells also corroborates our finding that these cells fail to internalize exogenous ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	274	Our binding studies confirm the notion that activity of the ETA receptors predominates in L2 cells from the main pulmonary artery of control sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	275	 With long-term exposure, however, it seems that both receptors participate equally in the internalization process.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	276	 This difference is likely to reflect the effects of long- and short-term exposure, the ETB receptor becoming more active when exposure to ET-1 is prolonged perhaps as a result of an increase in the requirement for internalization, and degradation of ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Previous studies in isolated, perfused rat lungs (29) have also shown that both receptors play a role in clearance of ET-1 (14).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	278	ETA and ETB receptors in hypertensive L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Alterations in ET-1 receptors have been demonstrated in several models of CPH.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	280	 For example, increased ETA gene expression was demonstrated in rat lungs and increased ETB gene expression in the rat main pulmonary artery after exposure to hypoxia for 48 h (25).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	281	 After 14 days of hypoxia, increased expression of both ETA and ETB was found in the distal pulmonary arteries of rats, ETA expression occurring mainly in the media and ETB in the intima; no change in expression of either receptor was found in the large muscular pulmonary arteries (39).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	282	 In contrast to the hypoxic models, in monocrotaline-induced CPH, ETB receptor mRNA was shown to be decreased in the lung (46).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	283	The present study demonstrates a selective and significant increase in ETB gene and surface expression in and receptor binding by the hypertensive L2 cells compared with controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Further confirmation of the increase in ETB receptors on hypertensive L2 cells is shown by our finding of an increase in early internalization of ET-1 by ETB.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Similar increases in ETB gene expression have been reported in the pulmonary arteries of patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (44).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The ETB signaling pathway has been linked to the regulation of ppET-1 gene expression in rat mesangial cells (19).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The present study confirms this notion since, in a previous study, we showed that ppET-1 gene expression in the main pulmonary artery was decreased in hypertensive sheep compared with controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	288	Although our studies demonstrate that, in the short term, internalization and clearance of ET-1 by ETB in the hypertensive cells may be increased, our studies with the ETA and ETB receptor antagonists suggest that, in the longer term, this scenario does not occur.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Rather, our data demonstrate that ET-1-stimulated internalization of exogenous ET-1 is decreased in hypertensive L2 cells compared with controls and that the sensitivity of the individual ET-1 receptors is lost.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	290	 It is only when the ETA and ETB antagonists are added simultaneously that suppression of ET-1 uptake occurs.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Similar findings have been demonstrated in isolated perfused lungs from rats with hypoxic CPH (23).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	292	 One possible explanation for the failure of each antagonist alone to inhibit ET-1 uptake is that the concentration of antagonists used in the study was not sufficient to inhibit ETA and ETB receptors in hypertensive L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	293	 This would seem unlikely, because both antagonists failed to exert an inhibitory effect.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Another possibility is that phosphorylation of the receptor/ligand complex and/or receptor recycling are altered in the hypertensive cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	295	 This notion requires further study.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	296	Another possible explanation is that concurrent treatment with the ETA and ETB antagonists involves simultaneous activation and heterodimerization of the two receptors (26).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Recent studies suggest that ET-1 binds simultaneously to both an ETA and ETB receptor (2, 11).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	298	 This heterodimerization between two fully functional G protein-coupled receptors is suggested to result in a new receptor/ligand binding complex with functional properties different from those of either receptor alone (21).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Thus it is possible that when the individual ETA and ETB receptors of hypertensive L2 cells are desensitized to exogenous ET-1, their simultaneous stimulation results in heterodimerization of ETA and ETB receptors and internalization of ET-1 by a different pathway.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	300	 This new pathway would seem to be extremely effective, since intracellular levels of ET-1 in the hypertensive L2 cells returned almost to basal values.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Further studies are needed to elucidate this possible explanation.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	302	In summary, we have shown that gene and surface expression and activity of the ETB, but not the ETA, receptors in L1 and L2 cells from control and hypertensive sheep are different.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Control and hypertensive L2 cells exhibit significantly higher steady-state basal expression of both the ETA and ETB genes than L1 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	304	 In agreement with this finding, we found that only the L2 cells internalize exogenous ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	305	 In the short term, the ETA receptors are mainly responsible for binding of ET-1, but with longer exposure, both receptors contribute to internalization.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	306	 In hypertensive L2 cells, we showed that ETB gene and surface expression and Bmax by this receptor were significantly elevated above baseline.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Uptake of exogenous ET-1 by these cells, however, was less pronounced than in control cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Furthermore, we found that only concurrent treatment with both ETA and ETB antagonists suppressed ET-1 uptake in the hypertensive cells, suggesting an alteration in their structure.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	309	 We conclude that changes in gene and surface expression and activity of the ETB receptors in L2 cells from hypertensive sheep may contribute to the development and maintenance of CPH through an altered sensitivity to locally produced ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Guohuan Fan, Department of Cell Biology at Vanderbilt University, for help in ET-1 receptor binding data processing.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	311	This work was supported by National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Grant HL-48536.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	417	   Sakurai, T, Yanagisawa M, Takuwa Y, Miyazaki H, Kimura S, Goto K, and Masaki T.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	418	 Cloning of a cDNA encoding a non-isopeptide-selective subtype of the endothelin receptor.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	419	 Role of endothelin-1 in hypertension.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	420	 Hypertension 34: 876-881, 1999[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	421	   Seo, B, Oemar BS, Siebenmann R, Segesser L, and Luscher TF.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	452	00 Copyright   2002 the American Physiological Society.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	0	Mutation of Interfacial Residues Disrupts Subunit Folding and Particle Assembly of Physalis mottle tymovirus* Mahadevaiah Umashankar, Mathur R.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the  Department of Biochemistry and the   Molecular Biophysics Unit, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, August 6, 2002, and in revised form, December 6, 2002.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	4	Virus-like particles (VLPs) serve as excellent model systems to identify the pathways of virus assembly.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	5	 To gain insights into the assembly mechanisms of the Physalis mottle tymovirus (PhMV), six interfacial residues, identified based on the crystal structure of the native and recombinant capsids, were targeted for mutagenesis.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, I123A, and S145A mutants of the PhMV recombinant coat protein (rCP) expressed in Escherichia coli were soluble.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, except for the S145A mutant, which assembled into VLPs similar to that of wild type rCP capsids, all the other mutants failed to assemble into VLPs.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Furthermore, the purified Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A rCP mutants existed essentially as partially folded monomers as revealed by sucrose density gradient analysis, circular dichroism, fluorescence, thermal, and urea denaturation studies.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The rCP mutants locked into such conformations probably lack the structural signals/features that would allow them to assemble into capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Thus, the mutation of residues involved in inter-subunit interactions in PhMV disrupts both subunit folding and particle assembly.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	11	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	12	Physalis mottle tymovirus (PhMV)1 is a small spherical plant virus consisting of a single-stranded, plus-sense RNA genome with a size of 6.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The RNA genome is encapsidated in a protein shell comprising 180 chemically identical coat protein (CP) subunits (20,000 Da) arranged in icosahedral symmetry.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Depending on the bonding interactions, the subunits are designated as A, B, and C (2).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The A-type subunits form pentamers at the 5-fold, and the B and C subunits form hexamers at the 3-fold icosahedral axes.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The protein subunits are held by strong protein-protein interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	17	Purified preparations of tymoviruses, including PhMV, consist of empty capsids (top component) in addition to the full capsids (bottom component) containing complete genomic RNA.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	18	 An interesting feature of tymoviruses is that empty capsids are also formed in vitro when the intact virus is subjected to a freeze-thaw cycle or when exposed to high temperatures, alkaline pH, or denaturants (3-6).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The presence of empty shells in vivo and in vitro suggests that the information required for error-free assembly is contained within the primary structure of protein subunits in these viruses.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	20	 It is difficult to isolate an assembly-competent PhMV CP subunit under non-denaturing conditions from isolated viral capsids that can be used for deciphering the assembly pathway.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Hence, the CP gene of PhMV and a number of its deletion mutants were cloned and expressed in Escherichia coli.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Interestingly, the bacterially expressed rCP could self-assemble into stable virus-like particles (VLPs) (7).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Furthermore, the deletion of 30 amino acid residues or the addition of 41 amino acid residues at the N terminus of rCP did not affect the assembly into T = 3 capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Several site-specific mutants were also studied.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	25	 One of the mutations, His-69 to Ala, led to the formation of a 19.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	26	4 S subassembly intermediate (8).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Recently, the crystal structures of native and recombinant capsids of PhMV have been elucidated (9, 10).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	28	 To gain further insights into the assembly mechanism of this virus, a careful analysis of these crystal structures was made in the present study to identify residues involved only in inter-subunit interactions, and these residues were targeted for mutagenesis.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Gln-37, Tyr-67, Arg-68, Asp-83, Ile-123 and Ser-145 were mutated to Glu, Ala, Gln, Ala, Ala, and Ala respectively, with a view to examine whether such mutations could lead to the formation of assembly intermediates or monomers.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The mutant rCPs were expressed in E.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The mutants were characterized by sucrose density gradient analysis, electron microscopy, high pressure liquid chromatography, circular dichroism (CD), and fluorescence spectroscopy.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Our results imply that Gln-37, Tyr-67, Arg-68, Asp-83, and Ile-123 are not only important for assembly but also crucial for the proper folding of the subunits, whereas the interactions with Ser-145 are not important either for folding or assembly.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	33	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	34	Materials-- [-32P]dATP was obtained from PerkinElmer Life Sciences.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Restriction endonucleases and the SequenaseTM Version 2 DNA sequencing kit were obtained from Amersham Biosciences.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Deep Vent DNA polymerase, DpnI, and Ni-NTA agarose were obtained from New England Biolabs and Qiagen, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Ampicillin, isopropyl-1-thio--D-galactopyranoside, Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250, and ultra-pure urea were obtained from USB.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Diaminobenzidine, bromphenol blue, and EDTA were obtained from Sigma.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The oligonucleotide primers and conjugated double antibodies were purchased from Bangalore Genei Pvt.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	40	 All other chemicals were of analytical grade.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	41	Primers-- The following primers were used to obtain rCP mutants by the PCR-based approach (-S, sense; -AS, antisense): Q37E-S, 5'-TCCCTTTTGAGTTTGAAG-3'; Q37E-AS, 5'-CTTCAAACTCAAAAGGGA-3'; Y67A-S, 5'-CGCCCCCGCCCGACATGC-3'; Y67A-AS, 5'-GCATGTCGGGCGGGGGCG-3'; R68Q-S, 5'-CCCCTACCAACATGCTCAG-3'; R68Q-AS, 5'-CTGAGCATGTTGGTAGGGG-3'; D83A-S, 5'-TCCAACTGCTCTTGCTGTC-3'; D83A-AS, 5'-GACAGCAAGAGCAGTTGGA-3'; I123A-S, 5'-CGGCGCCGCCTCAGCCGCC-3'; I123A-AS, 5'-GGCGGCTGAGGCGGCGCCG-3'; S145A-S, 5'-TTGAAAGACGCCGTGACCTAC-3'; and S145A-AS, 5'-GTAGGTCACGGCGTCTTTCAA-3'.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	42	Site-directed Mutagenesis-- The rCP mutants were constructed by the PCR-based method using corresponding sets of mutant primers (11).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	43	 CP gene in pRSET-B vector) was used as the template for PCR amplification with the sense and antisense primers with 2.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	44	5 units of Deep Vent DNA polymerase under optimal conditions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The PCR-amplified mixtures were treated with DpnI (10 units) at 37  degrees C for 1 h to digest the methylated template DNA and then transformed into E.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The plasmid DNA isolated from the colonies was sequenced by Sanger's dideoxy chain termination method with a SequenaseTM Version 2.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	47	0 DNA sequencing kit to confirm the presence of the mutations.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	48	Overexpression and Purification of Wild Type and Mutant rCPs-- The wild type and mutant constructs were transformed into the BL21 (DE3) pLys S strain.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	49	 500 ml of Terrific broth containing 50  microg/ml ampicillin was inoculated with 1% of the preculture.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	50	 After 4 h of growth, the cells were induced with 0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	51	3 mM isopropyl-1-thio--D-galactopyranoside for 4 h.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The virus-like particles formed (if any) were purified by using a procedure similar to that used for purification of the virus (6).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Briefly, the cell pellet obtained after the induction was resuspended in 50 mM sodium citrate buffer (pH 5.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	54	5), sonicated, and the supernatant was subjected to 10% polyethylene glycol precipitation.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The precipitate was resuspended in 50 mM citrate buffer (pH 5.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	56	5) and subjected to high speed pelleting.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The pellet was dissolved in citrate buffer and layered onto 10-40% sucrose gradient and centrifuged at 26,000 rpm in an SW28 rotor for 3 h.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The light scattering zone was collected with a Pasteur pipette, diluted, and subjected to ultra centrifugation for 3 h at 26,000 rpm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The pellet obtained was resuspended in 50 mM sodium citrate buffer (pH 5.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	60	The mutant rCPs that failed to assemble were purified by Ni-NTA affinity chromatography.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The cell pellet after the induction was resuspended in 100 mM Tris HCl buffer (pH 6.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	62	8) containing 300 mM NaCl and 5% glycerol.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The sample was frozen at 20  degrees C overnight, thawed at room temperature, and sonicated for 30 min.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The sample was then centrifuged at 27,000  x  g for 15 min to remove the insoluble debris.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The soluble fraction was mixed with 2 ml of Ni-NTA resin pre-equilibrated with the same buffer and allowed to rotate in an end-to-end rocker for ~2 h.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The protein resin complex was washed extensively with 100 mM Tris-HCl (pH 6.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	67	8) containing 300 mM NaCl, 60 mM imidazole, and 5% glycerol.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The protein was eluted with 100 mM Tris-HCl (pH 6.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	69	8) containing 300 mM NaCl, 250 mM imidazole, and 5% glycerol.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The purity of the mutant rCPs thus obtained was checked by 12% SDS-PAGE (12).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	71	Western Blot Analysis-- The mutant rCPs were separated on SDS 12% acrylamide gel and transferred onto nitrocellulose membranes (13).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The Western blot analysis was carried out using a monoclonal antibody (PA3B2) specific for CP as the primary antibody and goat antimouse IgG conjugated to horseradish peroxidase as the secondary antibody as described earlier (14).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The blot was developed using diamino benzidine in the presence of hydrogen peroxide in 0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	74	05 M sodium citrate buffer (pH 4.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	75	8) containing trace amounts of cobalt chloride.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	76	Gel Filtration Analysis-- The wild type and mutant rCPs were analyzed on a Bio-Sil 400 gel filtration column using the Shimdzu LC6A system.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The column was equilibrated with the Tris-HCl buffer (pH 6.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	78	8) containing 300 mM NaCl and 5% glycerol.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The column was calibrated with standard molecular weight markers supplied by Bio-Rad.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	80	Circular Dichroism-- CD spectra of protein samples (0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	81	8) containing 200 mM NaCl and 5% glycerol were recorded on a Jasco-715 spectropolarimeter (Japan Spectroscopic Co.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	82	, Tokyo, Japan) at room temperature (25  degrees C).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	83	Thermal stability of the rCP and its mutants was assessed using CD by following the changes in the secondary structure as a function of temperature.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The CD measurements were carried out in a Jasco-810 spectropolarimeter (Japan Spectroscopic Co.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	85	, Tokyo, Japan) using a bandwidth of 1 nm and a response time of 1 s in a cuvette with a 0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	86	3 mg/ml in 100 mM, Tris-HCl (pH 6.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	87	8) containing 200 mM NaCl and 5% glycerol) were heated from 25-95  degrees C at the rate of 1  degrees C/min.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The thermal unfolding was monitored at 222 nm, and the ellipticity observed was used to calculate molar ellipticity ([]) as seen in Equation 1, (Eq.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	89	 1) where  is measured ellipticity, Mr is protein molecular weight, c is the concentration of the protein in milligrams per milliliter, and l is the path length in centimeters.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	90	Fluorescence-- Fluorescence measurements were recorded on a SPEX FluoroMax-3 Spectrofluorimeter in a 1-ml cuvette with a path length of 1 cm at 25  degrees C.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	91	 For measuring the intrinsic fluorescence, the protein was excited at 280 nm, and the emission spectrum was recorded between 300 and 400 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In the case of urea-induced unfolding experiments, the fluorescence intensities were recorded at 324 nm, where the difference between partially folded (untreated) and 8 M urea treated proteins was maximum.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The readings were converted to relative fluorescence and plotted against urea concentration.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	94	 In all the experiments the protein concentration was 0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	95	8) containing 200 mM NaCl and 5% glycerol at room temperature (25  degrees C).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	96	8-Anilino-1-naphthalenesulfonate (ANS) Binding-- ANS binding was monitored by measuring the fluorescence intensities between 440 and 540 nm after excitation at 370 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In the case of urea unfolding, the proteins (0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	98	2 mg/ml) were incubated at various concentrations of urea for 2 h at 25  degrees C.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	99	 ANS was added to the protein samples to a final concentration of 10  microM.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The samples were excited at 370 nm, and ANS binding was monitored by measuring the fluorescence emission at 470 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The readings were converted to relative fluorescence and plotted against urea concentration.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	102	Fluorescence Quenching by Acrylamide and Potassium Iodide-- Fluorescence measurements of rCP and its mutants in the presence of increasing concentrations of acrylamide/iodide (0-0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	103	5M) were recorded on a SPEX FluoroMax-3 Spectrofluorimeter in a 1-ml cuvette with a path length of 1 cm at 25  degrees C.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The fluorescence intensity was recorded at 324 nm after excitation at 280 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The fractional quenching (F0/F) was plotted against acrylamide/iodide concentration (Stern-Volmer plot), where F0 and F represent the fluorescence in the absence and presence of acrylamide/iodide, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	106	 In all experiments, the protein concentration was 0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	107	8) containing 200 mM NaCl and 5% glycerol at room temperature (25  degrees C).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	108	Light Scattering Measurements of Urea Unfolded rCP-- Purified rCP capsids were incubated with 0-8 M urea at room temperature for 4-5 h.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The absorbance was recorded at 325 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	110	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	111	Expression and Characterization of Site-specific Mutants of rCP-- The site-specific mutants Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, I123A, and S145A were generated by the PCR-based sense and antisense primer method (11).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The mutant clones were sequenced by Sanger's dideoxy chain termination method to confirm the presence of the desired mutation (15).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The mutants were overexpressed in E.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	114	 All of the mutants were expressed to high levels (25-30% of the total proteins) and were partially soluble.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Approximately 60% of I123A and S145A were present in the soluble fraction.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The solubility of the other mutant rCPs varied depending on the expression level in different batches.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	117	 On average, ~10-15% of the expressed protein was present in a soluble fraction (data not shown).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The mutant proteins present in the soluble fractions were purified by the procedure similar to that used for the purification of wild type rCP capsids (6).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	119	 coli has 41 additional amino acid residues (including six histidines) at the N terminus and, as shown earlier (8), it assembled into capsids that sedimented as a single peak when subjected to sucrose density gradient centrifugation (fractions 12-16; Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The S145A mutant rCP co-sedimented with rCP capsids (Fig 1b).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	121	 However, none of the other mutant proteins exhibited peaks corresponding to assembled particles (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Furthermore, no assembled particles were seen when these mutant proteins were viewed under the electron microscope, whereas particles of 30 nm were observed for the mutant S145A capsids (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The mutant rCPs that failed to assemble into T = 3 capsids could not be purified by the procedures used for the purification of rCP capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Hence, these mutant proteins were purified by Ni-NTA chromatography, making use of the histidine tag at the N terminus.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The purified proteins were analyzed by 12% SDS-polyacrylamide gel and were authenticated by Western blot analysis (data not shown).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The yields of the purified proteins were 10-15 mg/liter for Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, and D83A rCPs, whereas it was slightly higher (20-25 mg/liter) for the I123A rCP.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	127	 These purified proteins were also observed under an electron microscope, which further confirmed that these mutant rCPs failed to assemble into virus-like particles.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	128	 These purified mutants rCPs were retained in the loading wells when run on 1% agarose gel and 8% native polyacrylamide gels (data not shown), suggesting that these may represent proteins that are folding defective.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	129	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	130	   Sucrose gradient analysis of the recombinant capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	131	 a, rCP and its mutants were layered onto a 10-40% sucrose gradient and centrifuged at 26,000 rpm for 3 h using an SW 28 rotor.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	132	 1-ml fractions were collected from the bottom of the tubes, and the absorbance at 280 nm was measured.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	133	 rCP, Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A and I123A rCPs are shown as , , , , , and , respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	134	 b, sucrose gradient analysis of rCP and S145A capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	135	 rCP and S145A capsids mutants were layered onto a 10-40% sucrose gradient and centrifuged at 26,000 rpm for 2.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	136	 1-ml fractions were collected from the bottom of the tubes, and the absorbance at 280 nm was measured.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	137	 rCP and S145A rCP are shown as  and , respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The inset shows the electron micrograph of S145A capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	139	Oligomeric Status of rCP Mutant Proteins-- Purified rCP capsids and the mutant rCPs were loaded onto a Bio-Sil 400 gel filtration column.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The column was calibrated with standard protein molecular weight markers.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The rCP capsids eluted immediately after the void volume as expected.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	142	 However, the I123A mutant rCP behaved abnormally and eluted after vitamin B12 (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	143	 2 were confirmed to be I123A mutant rCP by Western blot analysis (data not shown).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, and D83A mutant rCPs also behaved in a similar manner.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	145	 S145A rCP capsids co-eluted with rCP capsids (data not shown).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Therefore, it is likely that Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A rCP mutants exist as partially folded monomers that bind to the column and are eluted later in the run.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	147	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	148	   Size-exclusion chromatography of the rCP mutant.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	149	 The I123A mutant (upper panel) was run on a Bio-SIL 400 column calibrated previously with molecular mass markers (bottom panel).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Peaks a, b, c, d, and e correspond to thyroblobulin (670 kDa), IgG (150 kDa), ovalbumin (44 kDa), myoglobin (17 kDa), and vitamin B12 (1.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The top panel shows the elution profile of I123A.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The peaks 1, 2, and 3 obtained were authenticated by Western analysis.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Similar gel filtration profiles were obtained for the Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A mutants (data not shown).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	154	rCP Mutants (Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A) Exist in a Partially Folded State-- Far UV CD was used to examine the secondary structural features of the mutant rCPs that failed to assemble into capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The far UV CD spectra of these mutants showed troughs in the 208-225 nm range, suggesting that all of them had a considerable amount of secondary structure (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Furthermore, the fluorescence emission spectra of these mutants showed an emission maxima at 332-336 nm and was similar to that observed with the rCP capsids (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	157	 This indicated that the aromatic residues, especially the single tryptophan residue, was inaccessible to the solvent.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Upon incubation with 8 M urea, the emission maximum shifted to 350-356 nm, suggesting that the tryptophan side chain was exposed to the solvent (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The fluorescence intensity was measured at 324 nm, at which the maximum difference in intensity was observed between the native (0 M urea) and 8 M urea unfolded proteins.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The fluorescence intensities at various concentrations of urea were calculated as a percent of the fluorescence intensity at 0 M urea.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	161	 A discrete unfolding transition was found between 3 to 5 M urea in the case of rCP capsids (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	162	 5b), whereas no such transition was observed with the mutants rCPs (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	163	 This observation corroborates earlier studies in which the rCP capsids were found to be stable up to 4 M urea at room temperature (7).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Interestingly, the urea-induced denaturation of the rCP capsids, as measured by fluorescence, overlapped with the changes in light scattering as monitored by absorbance at 325 nm (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	165	 This indicated that disassembly and denaturation could be concerted events in this virus.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The lack of a discrete unfolding transition in the case of rCP mutants as monitored by fluorescence reflects conformational flexibility of these mutant proteins.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Furthermore, the absorbance at 325 nm for the mutant rCPs (0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	168	005), suggesting that the spectral changes observed are not due to aggregation.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	169	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	170	   Far UV CD spectra of purified rCP and its mutants.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	171	 CD measurements were made using Jasco Spectropolarimeter.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The spectra were recorded between 200 and 280 nm at room temperature (25  degrees C).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	173	 rCP, Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A mutant rCPs are shown as solid (), long dashed ( ), medium dashed (- - -), short dashed (- - -), dotted (   ), and dash-dot-dash ( ) lines, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	174	View larger version (15K):    Fig.

0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	180	 rCP, Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A and I123A rCP mutants are shown as solid (), long dashed ( ), medium dashed (- - -), short dashed (- - -), dotted (   ), and dash-dot-dash ( ) lines, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	181	View larger version (10K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	182	   Urea denaturation studies of rCP and its mutants.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	183	 a, purified rCP mutants were treated with 0-8 M urea for 2 h at 25  degrees C.

0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Fluorescence at 0 M urea concentration was taken as 100%, and the relative fluorescence calculated was expressed as a function of urea concentration.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A mutant rCPs are shown as , , , , and , respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	187	 b, urea denaturation of rCP capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Purified rCP capsids were treated with 0-8 M urea, and the fluorescence was monitored as described above in panel a.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Fluorescence emission of the tryptophan at 324 nm (closed circles and left axis) and light scattering measurements at 325 nm (open circles and right axis) are indicated.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	190	The accessibility of tryptophan residues in the mutant rCPs was further assessed by quenching experiments with acrylamide and potassium iodide.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Stern-Volmer plots for the wild type and mutant rCPs (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	192	 6a) showed a similar slope for Y67A, R68Q, and I123A mutant proteins, suggesting that the tryptophan in these proteins are protected from the quencher to a similar extent.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The tryptophan in Q37E and D83A mutant rCPs, however, seemed to be more accessible.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Similarly, when potassium iodide was used as a quencher, subtle differences in the accessibility of tryptophan in the mutants could be observed.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Although rCP, I123A, and D83A had similar slopes, Q37E, Y67A, and R68Q showed increased slopes (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	196	View larger version (10K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	197	   Stern-Volmer plot of tryptophan fluorescence quenching by acrylamide.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	198	 a, purified rCP capsids and rCP mutants were treated with 0-0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The proteins were excited at 280 nm, and the emission was recorded at 324 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Fractional quenching F0/F is plotted as a function of acrylamide concentration, where F0 and F represent the fluorescence in the absence and presence of acrylamide, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	201	 rCP capsids, Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A mutant rCPs are shown as , , , , , and , respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	202	 b, Stern-Volmer plot of tryptophan fluorescence quenching by iodide.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Purified rCP capsids and rCP mutants were treated with 0-0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The proteins were excited at 280 nm, and emission was recorded at 324 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Fractional quenching F0/F is plotted as a function of acrylamide concentration, where F0 and F represent the fluorescence in the absence and presence of iodide, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	206	 rCP capsids, Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A mutant rCPs are shown as , , , , , and , respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	207	Furthermore, the rCP mutants strongly bound ANS, suggesting the presence of exposed hydrophobic pockets (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	208	 ANS binding to rCP capsids was less when compared with ANS binding to the rCP mutants (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	209	 This is understandable, as the capsids are held by strong hydrophobic interactions and, hence, hydrophobic surfaces are unavailable for ANS to bind.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The urea-induced unfolding of the rCP capsids and mutant rCPs was also monitored by measuring ANS fluorescence.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	211	 As in other globular proteins, there was an initial increase (up to 3 M urea), followed by a decrease in ANS binding (up to 5 M urea) in the case of wild type rCP capsids (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The unfolding transition observed here is in agreement with the results of urea-induced denaturation as monitored by intrinsic fluorescence (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	213	 In contrast, the mutant rCPs showed only a continuous decrease in ANS fluorescence, suggesting that they were already in a partially unfolded state (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	214	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	215	   Fluorescence emission spectra of rCP capsids and rCP mutants in the presence of ANS.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	216	 a, ANS was added to the purified mutants (0.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	217	2 mg/ml) from a stock solution of 1 mM to a final concentration of 10  microM.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The excitation wavelength was 370 nm, and fluorescence emissions were measured between 440 and 540 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	219	 rCP, Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A mutant rCPs are shown as solid (), dotted (   ), short dashed (- - -), dash-dot-dot (  ), medium dashed (- - -), and dash-dot-dash ( ) lines, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	220	 b, ANS binding to rCP capsids and rCP mutants in the presence of urea.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The mutant proteins were incubated in 0-8 M urea at 25  degrees C for 2-3h.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	222	 ANS was added to a final concentration of 10  microM.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The samples were excited at 370 nm, and the fluorescence emission was monitored at 470 nm.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The readings were converted to relative fluorescence and plotted against urea concentration.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	225	 rCP, Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A mutant rCPs are shown as , , , , , and , respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	226	Thermal Stability of Mutant rCPs-- The partially folded nature of the mutant rCPs was further assessed by monitoring the effect of temperature on the molar ellipticity at 222 nm of the wild type and the mutant rCPs.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The wild type rCP and S145A capsids exhibited a Tm of 88 and 83  degrees C, respectively (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Q37E, Y67A, and R68Q mutant rCPs did not show a discrete transition, whereas the D83A and I123A mutant rCPs showed a broad transition between 50 and 70  degrees C (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	229	 These results further emphasize the conformational flexibility in these mutant rCPs.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	230	View larger version (12K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	231	   Thermal denaturation of rCP capsids and its mutants.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	232	 a, Tm of wild type rCP (line 1) and S145A rCP mutant (line 2) are shown.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Wild type rCP has a Tm of 88  degrees C, whereas that of the S145A mutant rCP was found to be 83  degrees C.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	234	 b, thermal denaturation of rCP mutants.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The thermal scans of the Q37E (line 1), Y67A (line 2), R68Q (line 3), D83A (line 4), and I123A (line 5) rCP mutants are indicated.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	236	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	237	We have resorted to the molecular biology approach to decipher the roles of specific amino acids in the formation of capsids of PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Earlier studies by site-directed mutagenesis have shown the presence of a 19.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	239	4 S intermediate in the assembly/disassembly pathway (8).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	240	 In this study, we have carried out a structure-based mutagenesis of six residues, namely Gln-37, Tyr-67, Arg-68, Asp-83, Ile-123, and Ser-145, which are predominantly involved in inter-subunit interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Except for S145A, all of the other mutant rCPs failed to assemble into T = 3 capsids, although they were found to be soluble (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Furthermore, these mutant proteins are partially folded, as evidenced by the following: (i) gel filtration elution behavior (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	243	 2); (ii) the presence of secondary structure as shown by far UV CD (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	244	 3); (iii) the lack of a sharp transition in thermal denaturation as shown by CD (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	245	 8); (iv) persistent high levels of innate fluorescence due to the single tryptophan present in the protein (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	246	 4); (v) lack of discrete unfolding transition upon denaturation with urea (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	247	 5); (vi) accessibility of tryptophan residue in the mutants as measured by fluorescence quenching with acrylamide and potassium iodide (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	248	 6); (vii) enhanced fluorescence of ANS in the presence of mutant proteins (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	249	 7); and (viii) the lack of a sharp structural transition in ANS binding experiments in the presence of urea (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Thus, the mutation of residues involved in extensive inter-subunit interactions affect both the subunit folding and particle assembly of PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	251	 A detailed analysis of the position of the residues mutated and the probable consequence of the mutation on the folding and assembly is presented below.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	252	Gln-37 is conserved in all of the tymoviruses and is present at hydrogen-bonding distance to the conserved glycines 113 and 114 and leucine 109, respectively, at the A-A5 interface (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Gln-37 also interacts with Gly-113 and Leu-109 at B5-C interface and with Asn-188 at C-C2 contacts (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	254	 This residue does not seem to interact with any of the residues within the subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The mutation of Gln-37 to Glu should therefore have disrupted only the inter-subunit interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Replacement of Gln with Glu in the structure using the molecular modeling software program "O" showed that there are no short contacts and also that all the interactions of Gln-37 can be retained by Glu.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	257	 However, it introduces a negative charge in the dense interface of subunits.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The results presented here demonstrate that the mutation of Gln-37, which is involved in multiple inter-subunit interactions, also affects the proper folding of the subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Probably, the negative charge introduced somehow interferes in the folding.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	260	View larger version (51K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	261	   Coat protein subunits of PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	262	 a, ribbon diagram of the A, B, and C subunits of the PhMV coat protein in the assymetric unit showing the mutations.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	263	 The A, B, and C subunits are colored green, red, and cyan respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The residues selected for mutation are indicated.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	265	 b, diagram illustrating the convention used to designate subunits on the T = 3 capsid of PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	266	 The A subunits form pentamers at the 5-fold axis, whereas the B and C subunits form hexamers at the 3-fold icosahedral axes.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	267	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	268	   Interfacial interactions of PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	269	 a, interactions of Gln-37 (Q37) with residues from the neighboring subunits.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Hydrogen bonding interactions of Gln-37 with other residues at the A-A5, B5-C, and C-C2 contacts.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The A, B, and C subunits are colored in green, blue, and red, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	272	 b, interaction of Asp-83 (D83I) with Arg-159 (R159) from the neighboring subunits.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Asp-83 (D83) is involved in salt linkage with Arg (R159) at the A-A5 and B5-C contacts.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The A, B, and C subunits are colored in green, blue, and red, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	275	 c, hydrophobic interaction of Ile-123 (I123) with itself from the neighboring subunit at the A-A5 contact.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	276	 d, interaction of Ser-145 (S145) with residues from the neighboring subunits.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Interactions of Ser-145 with other residues at A-B, B-C, and C-A contacts are shown.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The A, B, and C subunits are colored in green, blue, and red, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	279	Arg-68, another conserved residue in all tymoviruses, is at hydrogen-bonding distance with Asp-136, Ser-137, and Val-138 at the A-B interface and is involved in a salt bridge with Asp-150 at the B-C interface (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	280	 This residue does not have any obvious intra-subunit interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The replacement of Arg with Gln can be done without short contact within the same subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	282	 However, its mutation to Gln led to the partially folded and assembly-incompetent protein.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	283	 These results further support the observation that the mutation of residues involved in multiple inter-subunit interactions disrupts subunit folding and particle assembly.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Even here, the uncompensated negative charge might interfere in the folding of the protein.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	285	Asp-83 and Ile-123, although not conserved among all tymoviruses, are involved in extensive interactions with residues from the other subunits (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The mutation of these two residues to alanine also led to the partially folded proteins that were assembly-incompetent.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	287	Tyr-67 is also conserved across the tymovirus group.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	288	 It is involved not only in inter-subunit interactions at C-C2 and B5-A, but also in intra-subunit hydrogen-bonding interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Its mutation to alanine disrupts the hydrogen-bonding interaction at the quasi-2-fold axis.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	290	 This creates a cavity in the vicinity of residues Leu-34, Leu-63, Leu-180, and Ile-32.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	291	 This may have a destabilizing effect on the same subunit, which could hinder proper folding of the subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Hence, its mutation to Ala led to the misfolding of the subunits and the consequent arrest of assembly.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	293	Interestingly, the tertiary structure of the partially folded mutant proteins is similar to that of the rCP capsids (Figs.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The single tryptophan residue, Trp-96, is located inside the -barrel, and its mutation led to soluble aggregates defective in folding and assembly (8).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Furthermore, this Trp is not an interfacial residue.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Therefore, it is possible that the partially folded mutant rCPs and the wild type rCP have similar accessibility to this tryptophan.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	297	In contrast to the Q37E, Y67A, R68Q, D83A, and I123A mutant rCPs, the S145A mutant assembled into capsids that were indistinguishable from wild type rCP capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	298	 An analysis of the intact PhMV capsid structure shows that Ser-145 has hydrogen-bonding interactions with Thr-149 and Asp-150 in the A-B interface, Ser-19 and Thr-149 at the A-C interface, and Asp-150 and Asn-139 at the B-C interface (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	299	 These interactions are presumably less important or are compensated by other interactions in the mutant rCP and thus do not affect the folding or assembly.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Earlier studies on D144N, N1881, and N188A mutant rCPs have shown that they do assemble into capsids, although these residues occur at the inter-subunit interfaces (8).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Thus, none of the mutant proteins studied thus far has resulted in a fully folded and assembly-competent monomeric subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	302	 It is, however, possible that the mutant rCPs are not correctly folded when synthesized in vivo and hence are assembly incompetent.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	303	 To examine this, the wild type rCP capsids were incubated with 8 M urea for 4 h at room temperature and subjected to stepwise dialysis or immediate dilution (20-fold) to remove the denaturant.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	304	 However, it was not possible to obtain assembled particles from such refolding mixtures.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Invariably, the removal of denaturant led to the complete precipitation of the protein.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Because it was not possible to refold and assemble the wild type rCP, similar experiments with mutant rCPs were not attempted.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	307	 In vivo studies on the related turnip yellow mosaic virus has shown that the coat protein synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum accumulates in the cytoplasm overlying clustered vesicles in the chloroplast (17).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	308	 These become inserted into the outer chloroplast membrane with the hydrophobic sides that are normally buried in the complete virus particle within the lipid bilayer.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	309	 It is suggested that the nascent RNA strand emerges through the vesicle neck and that virus assembly takes place in the vesicular membrane (17).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Thus, the partially folded CP attached to the membrane, upon interaction with RNA, could further fold and assemble into mature capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	311	 In the absence of RNA, these proteins might self-assemble to form empty capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The results presented in this communication clearly demonstrate that the mutation of residues crucial for interfacial interactions disrupts subunit folding and assembly in the PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Furthermore, these mutants are partially folded and are probably locked in conformations that lack the signals/features that would allow them to assemble into T = 3 capsids.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	314	 The unfolding transition, as monitored by fluorescence, overlapped with the changes in the light scattering when wild type rCP capsids were denatured with urea, suggesting that disassembly and unfolding are also concerted (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Thus, there is a close connection between folding and assembly in PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	316	 In the flock house virus also, the disassembly and unfolding of the mature capsids was shown to be concerted (18).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Viral structural proteins, such as the herpes simplex virus triplex forming protein (VP23), when expressed in E.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	318	 coli, are shown to exist predominantly in a molten globule state (19).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	319	 The P22 coat protein has also been shown to be quite flexible in solution (20).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Thus, concerted coat protein folding and capsid assembly may be a general phenomenon in viruses stabilized predominantly by inter-subunit interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Sridevi Annapurna Singh, and Mrs.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Radha for help in carrying out thermal denaturation studies.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Eaazhisai for help in some of the experiments.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	324	* This work was supported by the Departments of Science and Technology and Biotechnology, New Delhi, India.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	325	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	326	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	328	  To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	329	: 91-80-3601561 or 91-80-3942310; Fax: 91-80-3600814 or 91-80-3600683; E-mail: bchss@biochem.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	330	Published, JBC Papers in Press, December 10, 2002, DOI 10.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	331	The abbreviations used are: PhMV, Physalis mottle tymovirus; CP, coat protein; rCP, recombinant coat protein; CD, circular dichroism; Ni-NTA, nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid; ANS, 8-anilino-1-naphthalenesulfonate; Tm, melting temperature.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	332	    REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES 1.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	333	 143, 1489-1500[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 2.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	334	 (1975) The Chemical Basis of Virus Structure, Dissociation, and Assembly , Vol.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	335	 39 , North-Holland Publishing Co.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	336	 272, 541-552[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 8.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	337	 289, 905-918[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 9.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	338	 289, 919-934[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 10.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	339	 307, 1035-1047[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 11.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	340	 (1994) Gene 151, 119-123[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 12.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	341	 (1970) Nature 227, 680-685[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 13.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	342	 (1993) Virology 193, 959-966[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 15.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	343	 189, 113-130[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 17.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	344	 (1991) Plant Virology , 3rd Ed.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	345	 231-239, Academic Press, New York 18.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	346	 275, 16037-16043[Abstract/Free Full Text] 19.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	347	 72, 10066-10072[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	348	Copyright   2003 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	0	Structural Requirements within the Lipoyl Domain for the Ca2+-dependent Binding and Activation of Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Phosphatase Isoform 1 or Its Catalytic Subunit* Ali Turkan, Xiaoming Gong, Tao Peng, and Thomas E.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Biochemistry, Kansas State University, Manhattan, Kansas 66506.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, August 31, 2001, and in revised form, January 4, 2002.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	4	The inner lipoyl domain (L2) of the dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2) 60-mer forms a Ca2+-dependent complex with the pyruvate dehydrogenase phosphatase 1 (PDP1) or its catalytic subunit, PDP1c, in facilitating large enhancements of the activities of PDP1 (10-fold) or PDP1c (6-fold).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	5	 L2 binding to PDP1 or PDP1c requires the lipoyl-lysine prosthetic group and specificity residues that distinguish L2 from the other lipoyl domains (L1 in E2 and L3 in the E3-binding component).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The L2-surface structure contributing to binding was mapped by comparing the capacities of well folded mutant or lipoyl analog-substituted L2 domains to interfere with E2 activation by competitively binding to PDP1 or PDP1c.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Our results reveal the critical importance of a regional set of residues near the lipoyl group and of the octanoyl but not the dithiolane ring structure of the lipoyl group.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	8	 At the other end of the lipoyl domain, substitution of Glu182 by alanine or glutamine removed L2 binding to PDP1 or PDP1c, and these substitutions for the neighboring Glu179 also greatly hindered complex formation (E179A  >  E179Q).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Among 11 substitutions in L2 at sites of major surface residue differences between the L1 and L2 domains, only the conversion of Val-Gln181 located between the critical Glu179 and Glu182 to the aligned Ser-Leu sequence of the L1 domain greatly reduced L2 binding.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Certain modified L2 altered E2 activation of PDP1 differently than PDP1c, supporting significant impact of the regulatory PDP1r subunit on PDP1 binding to L2.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Our results indicate hydrophobic binding via the extended aliphatic structure of the lipoyl group and required adjacent L2 structure anchor PDP1 by acting in concert with an acidic cluster at the other end of the domain.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	12	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	13	The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC)1 catalyzes the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and reduction of NAD+ via the sequential action of the pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1), dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2), and dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3) components.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Mammalian PDC is organized around a central framework formed by assembly of 60 E2 subunits.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	15	 E2 consists of four independently folded domains connected to each other by mobile linker regions 20-30 amino acids in length (1-4).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Association of 20 trimer units of E2's C-terminal domain produces a central cavity in the shape of a dodecahedron.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	17	 At its surface, this assembled inner core is connected by the first linker region to a 5-kDa domain that binds the E1 component (5, 6); 20-30 E1 tetramers (22) are anchored per E2 60-mer (7).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Then, set off by two more linker regions in the E2 structure, are two ~10-kDa lipoyl domains: an interior one, L2, and an NH2-terminal one, L1.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	19	 An E3-binding protein (E3BP) has a multidomain structure similar to E2 consisting of three linker region-connected globular domains (8, 9).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The C-terminal domain of E3BP binds E2's inner domain followed with intervening linker regions first by the domain that binds E3 and then by a single lipoyl domain (designated L3) at the N terminus (5, 8-10, 12-14).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	21	Mammalian PDC is tightly regulated by a phosphorylation-dephosphorylation cycle, which determines the proportion of active (nonphosphorylated) E1 (2-4, 15).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	22	 PDC inactivation of E1 is carried out by pyruvate dehydrogenase kinase (PDK) and reactivation by pyruvate dehydrogenase phosphatase (PDP).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	23	 PDC is regulated by at least four PDK isoforms and by two PDP isoforms, which are variably expressed in different tissues (16-20).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In Ca2+-sensitive tissues, the pyruvate dehydrogenase phosphatase 1 (PDP1) is the dominant phosphatase isoform (20).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	25	 PDP1 catalyzes a Mg2+-requiring, Ca2+-stimulated dephosphorylation and activation of E1 (15, 21, 22).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	26	 PDP1 activity is enhanced manyfold when the phosphorylated E1 and PDP1 are bound by the E2 60-mer (23, 24).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Indeed, Ca2+ stimulation requires E2 because PDP1 binds to E2 via an interaction that requires Ca2+ (23) at micromolar levels (22).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The magnitude of this enhancement (typically 7-16-fold) primarily depends on the level of free phosphorylated E1 in the absence of E2 because kinetically it results in a near saturated activity in the presence of E2 being compared with an activity that varies greatly with the level of phosphorylated E1.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Thus, there is a major decrease in the apparent Km of PDP1 for phosphorylated E1 upon concentrating PDP1 along with phosphorylated E1 at the surface of the E2 core (23).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Ca2+ also causes an ~2-fold decrease in the Km of PDP1 for Mg2+ (25).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	31	PDP1 is composed of two subunits (26, 27).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Its catalytic subunit (PDP1c, mass = 52.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	33	6 kDa) is in the phosphatase 2C class but shares only ~20% sequence identity with rat cytosolic  and  isoforms of phosphatase 2C (28).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The other subunit (PDP1r, mass = 96 kDa) serves a regulatory role by elevating the concentration of Mg2+ required for efficient PDP1c catalysis (29).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The PDP1r subunit is a flavoprotein with a bound FAD; the sequence of PDP1r is distantly related to the mitochondrial flavoprotein, dimethylglycine dehydrogenase (30), which functions in choline degradation.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Spermine and, to a lesser degree, other polyamines reduce the Km of PDP1 for Mg2+ (31), probably by binding to PDP1r to reverse the effect of this subunit in elevating the Mg2+ responsiveness (29).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The PDP2 isoform has an even higher Km for Mg2+, which is reduced from  > 15 mM to 3 mM by direct interaction of spermine with recombinantly produced PDP2 that consists just of a catalytic subunit.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Rat PDP2 shares 55% sequence identity with rat PDP1c, but PDP2 is not activated by Ca2+ (20).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	39	 A similar diminution in the concentration dependence of PDP activity for Mg2+ is produced by insulin and sustained in permeabilized mitochondria prepared from insulin-treated adipose tissue (32).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	40	 This probably involves a change in the activity of PDP2, which is located in adipose tissue (20).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	41	The L2 domain of E2 selectively binds PDP1 by an association that specifically engages L2's lipoyl prosthetic group (33, 34).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	42	 PDP1 does not interact productively with the L1 domain of E2 (33, 34) or with the lipoyl domain of E3BP (reported herein).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	43	 PDP1c, alone, undergoes Ca2+-dependent binding and activation (28) via an association with the L2 domain (Ref.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Using gel-anchored GST-L2, Ca2+-aided binding has been used to selectively purify PDP1 (33) and PDP1c (35).
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Ca2+ does not bind to either PDP1c or the L2, alone; binding requires the combination of the catalytic subunit and the free lipoyl domain.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	46	2 This suggests either a bridging role of Ca2+ between L2 and PDP1c or a stepwise interaction in which Ca2+ stabilizes the complex by binding at a site induced by a precursory (weaker) interaction between PDP1c and the L2 domain.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	47	To understand and compare the lipoyl-domain specific, Ca2+-dependent binding of the L2 domain to PDP1 and PDP1c, we have mapped the effects of changes in the L2 structure both by site-specific changes in surface amino acid residues and by substitution of analogs of the lipoyl prosthetic group.
