0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	401	 316, 926-940[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 41.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	402	 (1998) Gastroenterology 115, 139-146[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 42.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	403	 (1996) in Keto Acid Dehydrogenase Complexes (Patel, M.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	404	 131-138, Birkhauser Verlag Press, Basel 43.
0.25463712.11842080.html.plaintext.txt	405	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	0	Human papillomavirus 16 virus-like particles use heparan sulfates to bind dendritic cells and colocalize with langerin in Langerhans cells Latifa Bousarghin1,, Pascale Hubert1, Elisabeth Franzen1, Nathalie Jacobs1,2, Jacques Boniver1 and Philippe Delvenne1.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 University Hospital of Liege, Department of Pathology, Tour de Pathologie B35, B-4000 Liege, Belgium 2 Department of Virology, Faculty of Medicine, Imperial College London, St Mary's Campus, Norfolk Place, London W2 1PG, UK.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	2	Correspondence Latifa Bousarghin bousarghin{at}univ-tours.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Langerhans cells (LC), the immature dendritic cells (DC) that reside in epithelial tissues are among the first immune cells to encounter human papillomavirus (HPV) and are not activated by HPV virus-like particles (VLPs) in contrast to DC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The notion that the differences in response to HPV VLPs between LC and DC are associated with different types of cell binding and intracellular trafficking has been addressed.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Inhibition experiments with heparin and sodium chlorate showed that heparan sulfates are necessary for HPV 16 VLPs to bind to DC but not to LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Electron microscopy analysis demonstrated a colocalization of HPV 16 VLPs and langerin, which is expressed only by LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	7	 This colocalization was observed on the cell surface but also in cytoplasmic vesicles.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	8	 As anti-langerin antibodies, HPV 16 VLPs were associated with a faster entry kinetics in LC, as reflected by the fact that VLPs were observed near the nuclear membrane of LC within 10 min whereas more than 60 min were needed in DC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, no difference between LC and DC was observed for the endocytosis pathway.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	10	 HPV 16 VLPs entered in both DC and LC by a clathrin-dependent-pathway and were then localized in large cytoplasmic vesicles resembling endosomes.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	11	Present address: Laboratoire de Virologie Moleculaire, INSERM U618, Faculte de Pharmacie, 31 Avenue Monge, 37000 Tours, France.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	12	   INTRODUCTION Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Cervical cancer, the second most frequent cause of death by cancer amongst females worldwide, is associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and represents one of the best examples of a human cancer preceded by a well characterized preneoplastic period (Richart  and  Barron, 1967; Richart, 1987).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Despite the evidence that specific types of HPV are strongly implicated as causative agents in the aetiology of cervical cancer and its precursors, designated squamous intraepithelial lesions (SILs), HPV alone is not sufficient for cancer development (Chen et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The role of the intrinsic immunity in controlling HPV infection and the subsequent development of SILs is shown indirectly by the increased frequency of HPV-associated lesions in patients with depressed cell-mediated immunity (Petry et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Initiation and progression of HPV-associated cancer of the uterine cervix have been shown to be related with functional alterations of Langerhans cells (LC) within the cervical epithelium (Giannini et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	16	 LC are immature dendritic cells (DC) of myeloid origin resident in squamous epithelia, including skin and genital mucosa.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The normal function of LC is to survey cell surfaces for pathogens, capture antigens by micropinocytosis or mannose receptor-mediated uptake, process captured proteins into immunogenic peptides, emigrate from tissue to lymph nodes and present peptides in the context of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules to T cells, thereby initiating antigen-specific immune responses.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	18	 LC are the only cells that constitutively express MHC class II molecules, CD1a (Fithian et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 1981) and langerin (CD207) (Valladeau et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In addition, LC differ ultrastructurally from other DC through the presence of a unique pentalamellar cytoplasmic organelle, the Birbeck granule.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	21	Because of their role in initiating antiviral immune response, DC and LC represent an ideal target for immune evasion by viruses.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Several viruses interfere with DC function, especially measles virus (Grosjean et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 1997), vaccinia virus (Drillien et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	24	, 1999) and dengue virus (Tassaneetrithep et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The study of the interactions between HPV and DC or LC has been complicated by the fact that native infectious HPV virions cannot be isolated in large enough quantities either in vitro or in vivo.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	26	 However, HPV to DC or HPV to LC interactions may be studied by using HPV virus-like particles (VLPs) that morphologically mimic native virions (Lenz et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	27	 HPV VLPs are non-enveloped icosahedral particles, composed of the L1 major capsid protein, which form via self-assembly in the nucleus after high level expression of L1 in eukaryotic cells (Kirnbauer et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	28	 (2002) reported that DC and LC are able to bind and internalize HPV VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	29	 However, in contrast to DC, LC incubated with VLPs do not upregulate activation markers, do not initiate immune response and do not migrate in vivo out of skin explants (Fausch et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	30	In this study, we showed that HPV 16 VLPs bind similarly to DC and LC but use different types of cell binding and intracellular trafficking.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Heparan sulfates are necessary for VLPs to bind to DC but not to LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Electron microscopy analysis demonstrated a colocalization of HPV 16 VLPs and langerin in LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	33	 However, no difference between LC and DC was observed for the endocytosis pathway.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	34	   METHODS Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Production and purification of HPV 16 VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	35	 HPV 16 VLPs were expressed in Sf9 cells infected with a recombinant baculovirus encoding the HPV 16 L1 protein and incubated at 27  degrees C for 72 h (Touze et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Cells were harvested by centrifugation, resuspended in PBS containing 0 5 % NP40 and allowed to stand at 4  degrees C for 30 min.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Cell lysates were then centrifuged at 14 000 g for 15 min at 4  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The nuclear fraction was further resuspended in PBS and sonicated.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	39	 This fraction was then loaded on the top of a preformed CsCl gradient and centrifuged at equilibrium in a Beckman SW28 rotor (24 h, 27 000 r.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	40	 L1 positive fractions were pooled in PBS and centrifuged (3 h, 28 000 r.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	41	 VLPs were resuspended in 0 15 M NaCl.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	42	Carboxy-fluorescein diacetate succinimyl ester (CFDA-SE) labelling of HPV 16 VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Purified HPV 16 VLPs were diluted in PBS (pH 8 5) to 0.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	44	 CFDA-SE (Molecular Probes) was then added to a final concentration of 100  microM (Drobni et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Succinimyl ester group reacts with primary amines on the VLPs and forms stable conjugates.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Inside cells, acetate on the CFDA-SE is cleaved off by intracellular esterases and yields highly fluorescent particles.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	47	 After incubation for 2 h at room temperature, reactions were subjected to centrifugation in a sucrose density gradient using 30 and 70 % to separate VLPs from free CFDA-SE.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Fractions (1 ml) were collected, L1 positive fractions were pooled in PBS and sedimented by ultracentrifugation.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The pellet was resuspended in 0 15 M NaCl.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	50	To characterize the integrity of CFDA-SE-labelled VLP, VLPs were tested by ELISA with the H16.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	51	V5 monoclonal antibody (mAb) (Christensen et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Plates were coated with the VLP at different dilutions, stored overnight at 4  degrees C, washed four times with PBS and blocked with 1 % fetal calf serum (FCS).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The mAb was diluted at 1 : 5000 in PBS-FCS and allowed to bind to HPV VLP for 1 h at room temperature.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	54	 After four stringent washes, the bound primary antibody was probed with the relevant streptavidin-labelled secondary antibody and the absorbances on the ELISA plate were read at 450 nm.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	55	Generation of human DC and LC DC culture.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were isolated from heparinized leukocyte enriched buffy coats of healthy adult donors by Lymphoprep (Lucron Bioproduct) density-gradient centrifugation applying 400 g at room temperature.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	57	 After two washes, PBMCs were plated on tissue culture dishes at a density of 1x107 cells ml to 1 in RPMI 1640 without serum and incubated for 24 h at 37  degrees C to select adherent cells.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Non-adherent cells were washed away with RPMI 1640 and remaining adherent cells were cultured for 6 days in medium containing 800 U granulocyte to macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF; Amoytop Biotech) ml to 1 and 20 U interleukin (IL) 4 (Biosource) ml to 1.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Routinely, about 70 % of DC displayed a CD1a+ phenotype as assessed by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	60	 CD34+ cells (1x105), isolated from cord blood mononuclear cells using the MACS Direct CD34 Progenitor Cell Isolation kit (Miltenyi Biotec), were seeded in T25 flasks (Sarstedt) in 10 ml RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10 % FCS, antibiotics and 50  microM mercaptoethanol (all from Gibco-BRL).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Cultures were supplemented with previously optimized concentrations of the following human molecules: 20 ng stem cell factor ml to 1, 10 U thrombopoietin ml to 1, 25 ng Flt3 ligand ml to 1, 200 U GM-CSF ml to 1, 50 U tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-, ml to 1 100 U IL4 ml to 1 and 5 ng transforming growth factor (TGF)- ml to 1.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	62	 All these agents were purchased from PeproTech, except for GM-CSF and IL4, which were obtained from Amoytop Biotech and Biosource, respectively.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The cells were cultured at 37  degrees C in a humidified atmosphere and in the presence of 5 % CO2.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	64	 At day 7, the cellular density was adjusted to 2x104 per cm2 and the cells were fed, at days 7 and 14, with GM-CSF, IL4, TNF- and TGF-.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	65	 At day 18, cells were collected from cultures by vigorous pipetting to prepare single-cell populations.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	66	 To detect cell-associated VLPs, DC and LC were collected, respectively, on day 6 and 18 and transferred to new 24-well plates at a density of 2x105 cells ml to 1.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	67	 DC or LC were exposed to CFDA-SE-labelled VLPs or VLPs alone (10  microg ml to 1) in RPMI 1640 medium for 1 h at 37  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Unbound labelled VLPs were removed by extensive washing with PBS.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	69	 RPMI 1640 medium was then replaced with RPMI 1640 containing 10 % FCS and cells were incubated at 37  degrees C for 6 h.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Flow cytometry measured the fluorescence of DC and LC, resulting from the uptake of labelled VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The relative fluorescent intensity was measured using FACSVantage SE and by Cellquest software (Becton Dickinson).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Typically, 20 000 events were collected for each experiment.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	73	Transmission electron microscopy.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	74	 DC and LC were incubated with VLPs as described above for different lengths of time.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Cells were centrifuged at room temperature and prepared for electron microscopy.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	76	 They were fixed at room temperature in 4 % glutaraldehyde (Laborimpex), post-fixed in 1 % osmium tetroxide (Laborimpex) for 1 h at 4  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Cells were then dehydrated in graded (70, 90, 100 %) ethanol solutions (VWR International).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Fixed cells were embedded in Epon (Serva) and propylene oxide (Laborimpex), and hardened at 60  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Ultrathin sections were stained with uranyl acetate (Fluka) and lead citrate (Leica).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	80	 These sections were examined using a transmission electron microscope LEO 906E (60 kV) (Zeiss).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	81	 DC and LC were incubated with HPV 16 VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	82	 After two washes with PBS, specimens were incubated for 1 h at 4  degrees C with anti-langerin antibody (Beckman).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Other sections were incubated with an unrelated antibody (anti-CD3 mAb) and with anti-6 integrin antibody (Sigma).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Fixed antibodies were revealed with anti-mouse IgG coupled to 20 nm colloidal gold particles (Tebu-bio).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Cells were washed, fixed and treated as above for electron microscopy analysis.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	86	 DC and LC were incubated with cell trafficking inhibitors at the following concentrations: 25  microM chlorpromazine (Sigma), which induces the misassembly of clathrin-coated pits at the plasma membrane by preventing clathrin recycling, 2  microM cytochalasin D (Sigma), which causes the disruption of actin filaments and actin polymerization inhibition, 25  microM nystatin and 5  microg filipin ml to 1 (Sigma), which inhibit the caveolae pathway.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	87	 For the blocking of mannose-type receptors, LC were also preincubated with mannan from Saccharomyces cerevisiae 5 mg ml to 1 (Sigma).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Labelled VLPs were incubated with DC and LC in the presence of inhibitors for 1 h.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Washed cells were then incubated in culture medium for 6 h.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Fluorescence of DC and LC, resulting from the uptake of CFDA-SE-labelled VLPs, was measured by flow cytometry as described earlier.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	91	Analysis of VLP to heparan sulfate interactions.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Heparan sulfate expression in LC and DC was detected by anti-syndecan-1 and anti-syndecan-4 mAb (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) followed by goat anti-mouse phycoerythrin (PE) antibody and analysed by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	93	Labelled VLPs were incubated with heparin (heparin leo; Leo Pharma) at 37  degrees C for 1 h before adsorption to DC and LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	94	 These cells were then washed with PBS and incubated with appropriate medium for 6 h at 37  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Internalization efficiency was assessed by detecting cell fluorescence by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	96	To examine the role of heparan sulfates in cell binding, DC and LC were also incubated with heparinase II (1 U ml to 1; Sigma), which cleaves -N-acetyl-D-glucosaminidic linkage, in medium containing 20 mM Tris/HCl, 50 mM NaCl, 4 mM CaCl2, 0 01 % BSA, pH 6 8.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	97	 After incubation for 1 h at 37  degrees C and one wash with PBS, DC and LC were incubated with labelled VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	98	To reduce the sulfation of heparan sulfate on the cell surface, DC and LC were cultured for 48 h in the presence of sodium chlorate (100  microM) as described previously (Bousarghin et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Sodium chlorate acts as a competitive inhibitor for sulfate recognition by ATP sulfurylase, the first enzyme in the sulfate assimilation pathway (Farley et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Pretreated cells were incubated with labelled VLPs and fluorescence was measured by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	101	   RESULTS Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Binding and uptake of labelled VLPs by DC and LC To investigate the interactions between viral particles and antigen-presenting cells, we studied the binding of HPV 16 VLPs to DC and LC generated in vitro.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In vitro generated LC exhibited morphological (Birbeck granules) and immunohistochemical features of LC as observed by FACS analysis and surface phenotype [CD1a+, CD207+(langerin), E-cadherin+ and CCR6+] (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The proportion of cells expressing CD207 (langerin) in the entire population was 57 plus or minus 9 % (n=8).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	104	 DC generated from adherent PBMC in the presence of GM-CSF and IL4 also presented classical phenotypical markers of DC (CD1a+, HLA-DR+, CD80+) (data not shown).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	105	 By electron microscopy, HPV 16 VLPs were shown to bind to both DC and LC (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	106	 HPV 16 VLPs internalization by DC and LC was studied by using CFDA-SE/VLPs and flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	107	 In order to investigate the integrity of VLP after CFDA-SE-labelling, an ELISA with the H16.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	108	V5 mAb specific for conformational epitopes (Christensen et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	109	 This antibody reacted similarly with VLP alone or with CFDA-SE/VLP, suggesting that the labelling of VLP with CFDA-SE does not induce VLP epitope conformation changes (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	110	 To determine a suitable incubation time to study VLPs cell-internalization, a kinetics curve for CFDA-SE fluorescence was studied.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Mean fluorescence increased with time of incubation and after 6 h, 80 % of cells were fluorescent.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	112	 To exclude the possibility that the detected fluorescence is caused by non-bound CFDA-SE dye co-migrating with the labelled VLPs, DC and LC were incubated with the fraction of control gradient loaded with CFDA-SE alone.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	113	 No fluorescence was detected in DC and LC when incubated with this control gradient fraction (data not shown).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Phenotypical analysis of LC generated in vitro.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	116	 CD34+ cells cultivated for 18 days in the presence of TNF-, GM-CSF, IL4 and TGF-1, after amplification with stem cell factor, thrombopoietin and Flt3 ligand, display the surface phenotype of LC, with a high expression of CD1a, CD207, E-cadherin and CCR6.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The values correspond to % of CD207+, E-cadherin and CCR6 cells in the entire population.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	118	 One representative result is shown out of eight experiments.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	119	  View larger version (35K):    Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Binding and uptake of HPV 16 VLPs in DC and LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	121	 (a) HPV 16 VLPs binding in DC and LC at 4  degrees C (BG, Birbeck granules).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	122	 (b) ELISA immunodetection of CFDA-SE/VLP with H16.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	123	 (c) Entry kinetics of CFDA-SE-labelled HPV 16 VLPs in DC and LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Cells were incubated with labelled VLPs at 4  degrees C for 1 h, washed and incubated at 37  degrees C for different lengths of time.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	125	 They were then trypsinized and incubated for 6 h at 37  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Fluorescence was detected by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	127	  To study the cell entry kinetics, DC and LC were first incubated with labelled VLPs at 4  degrees C, washed and then incubated at 37  degrees C for 5, 10, 30, 60 min and 6 h (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	128	 After a trypsin treatment to remove uninternalized VLPs and washings, cells were incubated at 37  degrees C for 6 h.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Trypsin treatment reduced binding of VLPs as observed by Evander et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	130	 When cells were incubated for 5 min with labelled VLPs, 69 plus or minus 7 % of LC were fluorescent compared with 27 plus or minus 1 % for DC (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	131	 This difference was also observed after 1 h of incubation (fluorescence in 84 plus or minus 2 % of LC and 35 plus or minus 2 % of DC), suggesting that VLP entry in DC is slower than in LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	132	 With increased incubation times, differences between the two cell populations decreased and at 6 h of incubation 84 plus or minus 12 % of DC and 94 plus or minus 1 % of LC were fluorescent.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The faster VLPs entry in LC compared with DC was confirmed by electron microscopy (see Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	134	 VLPs were observed in LC cytoplasm after only 5 min of incubation (see Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	135	 In contrast, a slower kinetic of VLPs entry in DC was observed since VLPs were detected in the cytoplasm after only 20 min of incubation (see Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	136	 In LC, VLPs were found near the nuclear membrane after an incubation time of 10 min (see Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	137	 6c), whereas more than 1 h was needed for VLPs to reach the nucleus in DC (data not shown).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	138	View larger version (74K):    Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Clathrin-dependent pathway of HPV 16 VLPs into LC (a to c) and into DC (d to f): binding and coated pits formation (a, d); clathrin vesicle formation (e); clathrin vesicle fusion (b, f); VLPs near nuclear membrane (c); demonstration of HPV 16 VLPs (0 2  microg ml to 1) in coated vesicles (g) and clathrin vesicles (h) of LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	140	  HPV 16 VLPs use heparan sulfates to bind to DC Since the difference observed in entry kinetics between DC and LC could be explained by the use of different types of cell binding, we investigated if heparan sulfates are used by VLPs to enter into DC or LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	141	 We first examined the ability of heparin to block binding and cell entry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Labelled HPV 16 VLPs were preincubated with heparin for 1 h at 37  degrees C and their capacity to enter into DC or LC was investigated by cell fluorescence (Table 1).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	143	 In the presence of heparin, fluorescence was inhibited by 76 plus or minus 5 % in DC whereas no inhibition (12 plus or minus 2 %) was observed with LC (Table 1).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	144	 To determine if this difference was not due to the origin of cells used to induce the differentiation of DC and LC, we also generated DC with CD34+ cells and showed that the entry of VLPs was inhibited in the presence of heparin (51 plus or minus 13 % of inhibition), suggesting that heparan sulfates are receptors for DC but not for LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	145	 We also investigated the heparan sulfates expression by immunostaining with anti-human syndecan-1 and syndecan-4 antibodies.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The results showed that DC and LC express similar levels of syndecan-4 whereas syndecan-1 was poorly expressed (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Effect of heparin and sodium chlorate on labelled HPV 16 VLPs entry in DC generated from either PBMCs or CD34+ cells and LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	148	Results are expressed as mean percentages of cell fluorescence inhibition ( plus or minus standard deviation).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	149	  View larger version (31K):    Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Heparan sulfate expression in DC and LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	151	 DC and LC were stained with anti-human syndecan-1 and syndecan-4 and analysed by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	152	  The role of proteoglycans in the binding of HPV 16 VLPs to DC and LC was also assessed by inhibiting their sulfation with sodium chlorate.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	153	 For this purpose, LC and DC were grown in the presence of sodium chlorate for 48 h before the addition of labelled VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	154	 As shown in Table 1, HPV 16 VLPs entry was reduced by 71 plus or minus 5 % in DC treated with 100  microM sodium chlorate compared with untreated cells.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	155	 In contrast, only a 13 plus or minus 2 % inhibition was detected in LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	156	 To confirm the role of heparan sulfate in the DC entry of VLPs, DC were incubated with heparinase II, which induced a 51 % infection inhibition in DC whereas LC were not affected (data not shown).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	157	Langerin is colocalized with HPV 16 VLPs Since VLPs did not enter in LC by heparan sulfates and VLPs entry was faster in LC, we investigated if VLPs use the same method as langerin (CD207), an endocytic receptor in LC, to enter quickly into LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Electron microscopy analysis showed that after an incubation at 37  degrees C for 5 min, anti-langerin mAb were present in LC in coated pits (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	159	 4a) or in small vesicles with clathrin morphology (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	160	 A proportion of langerin was also localized intracellularly in large multivesicular compartments (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Electron microscopy also showed that VLPs and langerin are colocalized (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	162	 We observed a colocalization at the cell surface (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	163	 4e), but also in coated pits (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	164	 4f), which lead to the formation of vesicles with clathrin morphology (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Langerin and VLPs were found inside large cytoplasmic vesicles in LC (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	166	 4h), whereas no langerin was detected in DC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	167	 To exclude potential artefacts due to a high level of VLP (10  microg ml to 1), we used VLP at a lower concentration (0 2  microg ml to 1) and showed, by electron microscopy, that langerin and VLP also colocalize in these conditions (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	168	View larger version (70K):    Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Colocalization of HPV 16 VLPs and langerin in LC by immunogold electron microscopy.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	170	 LC were incubated with anti-langerin alone (a to d) or with anti-langerin and HPV 16 VLPs (e to h).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Langerin is detected by a secondary antibody associated with gold particles (20 nm), which were found at the cell surface (a, e), in clathrin vesicles (b, c, f, g) and in large vesicles resembling endosome (d, h).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Colocalization of VLP (0 2  microg ml to 1) and langerin (i, j) in LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	173	  As a negative control, we preincubated LC with an antibody not specific for LC such as anti-CD3 mAb.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	174	 In the presence of anti-CD3 mAb, no gold particles were detected (data not shown).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	175	 We have also tested the ability of anti-6 integrin mAb to interact with the HPV 16 VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The results revealed a low expression of integrin on LC and the absence of colocalization with HPV16 VLPs (data not shown).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	177	To determine the specificity of VLP/LC-binding, cells were preincubated with 5 mg mannan ml to 1 before adding labelled VLP.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	178	 In the presence of mannan, a 40 % inhibition of fluorescence was observed for LC (see Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	179	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Cells were pretreated with chlorpromazine (a), cytochalasin D (b), nystatin (c), filipin (d) and mannan (e).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	181	 After 1 h of incubation, CFDA-SE-labelled VLPs were added.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Cells were then washed with PBS and incubated with culture medium for 6 h before detecting fluorescence by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Solid black line, LC+PBS; solid grey line, LC+CFDA-SE/VLP; dashed line, LC+CFDASE/VLP+drug.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	184	  HPV 16 VLPs endocytosis in DC and LC Since VLP could be internalized by different pathways (Selinka et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	185	, 2003), we examined the role of clathrin-coated-pit-mediated endocytosis in the entry of HPV 16 VLPs in LC and DC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	186	 These cells were preincubated with chlorpromazine, which inhibits clathrin-mediated endocytosis.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	187	 A 70 % inhibition in HPV 16 VLPs endocytosis was observed in both DC and LC populations after chlorpromazine treatment (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	188	 We also tested the effect of cytochalasin D, a potent inhibitor of actin-dependent cellular processes.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	189	 In the presence of this drug, VLP fluorescence was shown to decrease (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	190	 LC and DC were also treated with nystatin and filipin, which inhibit caveolae-mediated endocytosis and no inhibition was observed with these drugs (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	191	 To visually analyse the uptake of HPV VLPs into DC and LC, transmission electron microscopy analysis was also performed.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	192	 In the presence of HPV 16 VLPs, DC and LC plasma membranes were rich in coated pits where VLPs accumulated (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	193	 These coated pits budded off to yield coated vesicles with clathrin morphology confirming that HPV enter by endocytosis through clathrin-coated pits in both DC (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	194	 VLPs were contained in cytoplasmic coated vesicles (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	195	 6b), which enlarged with time by fusion of different coated vesicles (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	196	 The HPV 16 VLPs remained clustered in large vesicles resembling endosome (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	197	 At this step, most vesicles were smooth rather than coated.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In LC, vesicles containing VLPs were located near the nucleus after an incubation of 10 min (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	199	 6c), whereas more time was needed for DC (data not shown).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	200	When using VLP at low concentration (0 2  microg ml to 1), they were also observed in coated pits and cytoplasmic vesicles of LC with a clathrin morphology (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	201	   DISCUSSION Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   HPV 16 VLP-based vaccine formulations have been shown to induce strong humoral and cell-mediated immunity and to confer protection against HPV 16-related SILs (Koutsky et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	202	 These data suggest that vaccine antigens are efficiently presented to the immune system and may be correlated to the ability of HPV VLPs to activate DC (Rudolf et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	203	 (2002) demonstrated that SILs are deficient in presenting antigens to T cells suggesting that the function of LC is incapacitated in the HPV-transformed epithelium.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In agreement with these observations, Fausch et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	205	 (2002) demonstrated that LC in the presence of HPV 16 VLPs are unable to activate T cells.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	206	The purpose of the present report was to investigate further the interactions between HPV 16 VLPs and DC or LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	207	 We showed that these antigen-presenting cells differentially interact with HPV 16 VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Although DC and LC are able to bind and internalize HPV 16 VLPs, difference in entry kinetics was observed between both cell types with a faster entry of HPV 16 VLPs into LC compared with DC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	209	 As a correlation between entry kinetics and cell receptors has been previously shown with other viruses (Narayan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	210	, 2003), we looked for potential different types of HPV 16 VLPs binding to DC and LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The most described epithelial receptors for HPV are heparan sulfates and integrin (Evander et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Our inhibition experiments with heparin or sodium chlorate confirm that DC use heparan sulfates to bind HPV 16 VLPs in contrast to LC in agreement with the data of Yan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	213	 (2004) showing that HPV 6b L1 VLPs uptake by DC is inhibited in the presence of heparin.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Other pathogens such as Chlamydia trachomatis also use heparan sulfates to enter DC (Matyszak et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	215	 (2002) suggested that heparan sulfates moiety detected on DC may also play an immunoregulatory role.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	216	 In fact, heparan sulfates and their degradation products have been reported to deliver costimulatory signals to T cells and maturation signals to DC (Wrenshall et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	217	, 1991; Kodaira  and  Platt, 2000; Johnson et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	218	 This may explain why HPV VLPs initiate DC (but not LC) maturation and activation.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	219	HPV 6b genotype has been shown to interact with epithelial cells by 6 integrin (Evander et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	220	 However, this receptor is poorly expressed in DC and LC and probably not implicated in the differences of HPV 16 VLPs uptake between both cell types.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	221	 (2004) also reported that 6 integrin is not responsible for the initiation of binding of HPV 6b L1 VLPs by LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	222	LC express several receptors that facilitate antigen recognition and uptake, including Fc receptors, DEC205 multilectin and langerin.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Langerin is exclusively expressed by LC (Valladeau et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	224	, 1999) and is localized not only on the cell surface, but also intracellularly in close association with Birbeck granules.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	225	 This molecule functions as an endocytic receptor (Valladeau et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Upon binding to the cell surface, anti-langerin antibodies are rapidly internalized and delivered to Birbeck granules (Valladeau et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Electron microscopy analysis showed that HPV 16 VLPs colocalize with anti-langerin antibodies.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Indeed they were detected together in coated pits and in large cytoplasmic vesicles.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	229	 These data are in agreement with recent studies showing that the processing pathway of HPV 6b L1 VLPs in LC is associated with langerin+ compartments (Yan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	230	, 2004) and that other viruses, such as HIV, also use langerin and lectin or mannose to enter into LC and DC, respectively (Turville et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Our electron microscopy analysis showed a colocalization of HPV 16 VLPs and langerin in large cytoplasmic vesicles resembling to endosome, which may be related to the observation that langerin is associated with the CD1a recycling compartment (McDermott et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	232	 HPV 6 VLPs were also shown to be colocalized with CD1a+ endosome (Yan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	233	, 2004), but the loading mechanism was not determined.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	234	 When mannan, which was shown to be able to inhibit HIV entry in LC, was used a 40 % inhibition of VLP entry was observed suggesting that other proteins are also involved in the VLP binding to LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	235	 It will be interesting to determine the direct effects of langerin in VLP binding by further experiments and if other lectins are also involved in the uptake of VLPs by LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	236	As the cell surface binding of HPV 16 VLPs differed in DC and LC, we wondered if their internalization was also different as suggested by Fausch et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	237	 (2003) showed that DC use a clathrin-mediated endocytosis whereas LC use a different pathway, which is not associated with clathrin or caveolae.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	238	 (2004) show that HPV 6 VLP enter in LC by a caveolae-dependent pathway.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Entry pathways can be inhibited at different stages by specific inhibitors, such as chlorpromazine, cytochalasin D, nystatin and filipin.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	240	 When using these drugs, HPV 16 VLP entry was only inhibited in the presence of chlorpromazine and cytochalasin D whereas no inhibition was observed with the caveolae inhibitors, nystatin and filipin.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	241	 These results suggest that VLP enter in DC and LC by a clathrin-mediated pathway and are in agreement with the direct demonstration of HPV 16 VLPs in coated pits and cytoplasmic vesicles with a clathrin morphology in LC and DC preparations processed for electron microscopy.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The differences between these studies might be related to the different methods used to analyse HPV VLPs internalization although we cannot exclude different endocytosis pathways according to the origin of cells used to generate LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	243	 In agreement with this hypothesis, the LC used in this study poorly expressed syndecan-1 in contrast to the LC generated by Yan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	244	The fact that HPV 16 VLPs use different types of cell binding to DC and LC might have important functional consequences.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	245	 It has been shown that the maturation of DC and LC depends not only on receptors involved in the uptake of pathogens but also on receptors directly acting on DC activation (Niedergang et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Moreover, a cooperation between these two types of receptors has been shown to be important for the diversity of DC or LC responses and to determine the outcome of the immune response (Gantner et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	247	 As receptors implicated in DC maturation activate nuclear factor kappa B and mitogen-activated protein kinase pathways (Janeway  and  Medzhitov, 2002), it will be interesting to characterize the cytoplasmic factors implicated in DC or LC maturation in the presence of VLPs and to determine if heparan sulfates are able to interact with these factors.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	248	Future research addressing the recognition of HPV VLP by DC and LC will provide insight on how these cell surface receptors regulate antigen-presenting functions and may contribute to the development of novel strategies that specifically prevent or treat HPV infections and associated (pre)neoplasic lesions.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	249	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   This work was supported by the Belgian Fund for Scientific Research (FNRS), the Leon Fredericq Foundation, the  Centre Anticancereux  Pres l'Universite de Liege, the Centre de Recherche InterUniversitaire en Vaccinologie (Convention 3073 with GlaxoSmithKline Biologicals and the Walloon Region) and the IAP (InterUniversity Attraction Pole) network P5/31.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	250	 is a senior research associate of the FNRS.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Christensen for kindly providing anti-L1 monoclonal antibodies (H16.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	252	V5) and Antoine Touze and Pierre Coursaget for their generous donation of HPV 16 recombinant baculovirus and for critical discussion of the manuscript.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	253	 We also thank Renee Gathy, Patrick Roncarati, Josiane Renson and Ludivine Herman for their help.
