0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Despite differences between dendritic cells and Langerhans cells in the mechanism of papillomavirus-like particle antigen uptake, both cells cross-prime T cells.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	317	Received 27 August 2004; accepted 8 February 2005.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	318	 This Article Abstract Full Text (PDF) Alert me when this article is cited Alert me if a correction is posted Citation Map Services Email this article to a friend Similar articles in this journal Similar articles in PubMed Alert me to new issues of the journal Download to citation manager Google Scholar Articles by Bousarghin, L.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Articles citing this Article PubMed PubMed Citation Articles by Bousarghin, L.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Agricola Articles by Bousarghin, L.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	321	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS INT J SYST EVOL MICROBIOL MICROBIOLOGY J GEN VIROL J MED MICROBIOL ALL SGM JOURNALS.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	0	Transcriptional interference perturbs the binding of Sp1 to the HIV-1 promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Greger, Francesca Demarchi1, Mauro Giacca1, Nick J.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	2	Sir William Dunn School of Pathology, University of Oxford, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3RE, UK and 1International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology, AREA, Science Park, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received October 24, 1997; Revised and Accepted January 8, 1998.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	4	Transcriptional interference between adjacent genes has been demonstrated in a variety of biological systems.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	5	 To study this process in RNA polymerase II (pol II) transcribed genes we have analysed the effect of transcription on tandem HIV-1 promoters integrated into the genome of HeLa cells.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We show that transcriptional activation at the upstream promoter reduces transcription from the downstream promoter, as compared with basal transcription conditions (in the absence of an activator).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Furthermore, insertion of a strong transcriptional termination element between the two promoters alleviates this transcriptional interference, resulting in elevated levels of transcription from the downstream promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Actual protein interactions with the downstream (occluded) promoter were analysed by in vivo footprinting.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Binding of Sp1 transcription factors to the occluded promoter was reduced, when compared with the footprint pattern of the promoter protected by the terminator.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	10	 This suggests that promoter occlusion is due to disruption of certain transcription factors and that it can be blocked by an intervening transcriptional terminator.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Chromatin mapping with DNase I indicates that a factor binds to the termination element under both basal and induced conditions.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	12	Termination of transcription may be defined as arrest of the elongating polymerase followed by release of the transcription complex and nascent RNA from the DNA template.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	13	 It is known that in eukaryotes functional poly(A) signals are required for efficient transcriptional termination by RNA polymerase II (pol II), since mutations which disrupt polyadenylation also result in the loss of termination (1-3).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Furthermore, the strength of the poly(A) signal correlates with termination efficiency, since a stronger processing signal is more effective in directing termination (4).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Actual termination sites remain ill defined and in most cases studied so far transcription continues well beyond the poly(A) site (5) until a downstream element is encountered which forces the elongating polymerase to pause or arrest (6,7).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Pause sites can take various forms, such as DNA-bound protein complexes or intrinsic DNA sequence elements, either of which are capable of causing poly(A) site-dependent termination of transcription (6,8-11).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	17	It has been reported that inefficient transcriptional termination can cause interference with DNA replication and with transcription of an adjacent, downstream gene, leading to impairment of these central cellular processes (12-16).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	18	 This emphasizes the need for an efficient termination process in some cases.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Transcriptional interference (promoter occlusion) has been observed in various eukaryotic systems, including genes transcribed by pol I and II, in prokaryotic operons and in certain viruses (12).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In vitro experiments in the pol I system have suggested a mechanism for promoter occlusion where transcription through the promoter may cause displacement of a bound transcription factor.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Interference is prevented by terminator elements which reside upstream of each pol I promoter (17,18).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In contrast to the less complex pol I promoter, transcription by pol II depends on multiple protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions in the promoter and enhancer regions, which form stable initiation complexes (19).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	23	In the present work we have studied tandem pol II promoters, derived from the HIV-1 long terminal repeat (LTR), stably integrated into the chromosome.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	24	 We investigated the importance of an intervening transcriptional terminator in this context and furthermore have also investigated DNA-protein interactions on the downstream promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Analysis of cytoplasmic RNA revealed that upon transactivation with the viral Tat protein transcription from the downstream promoter is reduced (as compared with already high basal transcriptional conditions).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A transcriptional terminator placed between the two LTR promoters allowed increased transcription from both promoters upon transactivation by Tat.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Actual DNA-protein interactions on the downstream promoter were analysed by DMS in vivo footprinting.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	28	 While we consistently observed footprints when the promoter was preceded by the terminator, these were reduced when the protective intervening terminator was absent, suggesting reduced binding of transcription factors to the occluded promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The footprint pattern changed mainly across the binding sites for transcription factor Sp1.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Furthermore, DNase I footprinting in vivo indicated binding of a protein to the 5[prime]-end of the pause site, corresponding to the position where the termination factor MAZ has been shown to bind in vitro (11).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	31	 This binding activity is stable under induced conditions.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Taken together, our results demonstrate that a pol II termination element located between strong pol II promoters plays a critical role in preventing transcriptional interference in a chromosomal context.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	33	 We suggest that transcriptional interference may result in destabilization of specific transcription factors on the occluded promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Schematic diagram of the two constructs (CI and CII) used in this study.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Both contain two minimal HIV-1 LTR promoters in tandem (L1 and L2).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	36	 CII contains a termination element placed between the LTR promoters [the SpA poly(A) site followed by the C2 pause site], allowing termination of L1 transcripts upstream of the L2 promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	37	 L1 transcripts derived from the CI construct have to read through the L2 promoter to use the HIV poly(A) site (HpA).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The transcriptional start sites are indicated by arrows, transcripts initiated at L1 are indicated by dashed lines and the major upstream promoter elements are shown as boxes (NF-[kappa]B in black, SP1 white).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	39	 MATERIALS AND METHODS Plasmid constructs.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	40	The interference constructs (L1[alpha]L2[alpha] and L1[alpha]-SPAC-L2[alpha]) have been previously described (20).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	41	 For stable transfection into HeLa cells a 2404 bp SfiI-BamHI fragment, containing the SV40 early promoter driving the neo gene, was inserted between SfiI and EagI sites of these constructs to generate CI and CII.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	42	The Tat gene (derived from a Tat expression plasmid; 21) was cloned into pBabe hygro, a plasmid containing the hygromycin resistance gene driven by the SV40 early promoter (22).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	43	HeLa cells were transfected by the calcium phosphate precipitation technique with 5  microg plasmid.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The medium was changed 12 h after transfection and selective medium [MEM (Gibco), containing 400  microg/ml G418 (Gibco), 300  microg/ml hygromycin (Boehringer Mannheim), 10% fetal bovine calf serum] added 48 h after transfection.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Single colonies were picked and expanded; cell pools consisted of ~100 individual colonies.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Cells were maintained in medium containing 200  microg/ml G418.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Tat-expressing HeLa cells were established by transfecting CI and CII clonally derived cell lines with a Tat-expressing plasmid and propagated in the same selective medium containing additionally 200  microg/ml hygromycin.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	48	RNA extraction and RNase protections were carried out as described previously (20).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Riboprobe L is complementary to the PvuII-SmaI region of L2 (Figs 2 and 3; 20).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Riboprobe S, for the internal standard, was constructed by inserting a restriction fragment (AvaI-HindIII from CI) spanning the neo gene into AvaI/HindIII-cut pGEM-3 (Promega).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The plasmid was linearized with NcoI for in vitro transcription.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Riboprobes were purified on 5% sequencing gels and 5  x  105 c.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	53	 probe were hybridized with 10  microg cytoplasmic RNA.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Gels were scanned in a phosphorimager and quantified using appropriate software (Molecular Dynamics).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	55	HeLa cells (106) grown in 10 cm dishes were incubated with DMS (1  microl/ml; Aldrich) for 5 min.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	56	 DNA extraction and linker-mediated PCR reactions were performed as described in Current Protocols (1996).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	57	 All primers were purified on 20% sequencing gels.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	58	HeLa cells (up to 2  x  106) were trypsinized, washed in PBS, then in physiological buffer (23), before being taken up in 200  microl physiological buffer (+1% NP-40) and treated with 175 U DNase I (Boehringer Mannheim) for 5 min at 4 degrees C.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	59	 After DNase I treatment 5 ml lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8, 20 mM EDTA, 1% SDS) were added and the DNA phenol extracted and analysed by linker-mediated PCR (24).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	60	It has previously been shown that a strong transcriptional termination signal can block interference between two HIV-1 LTR promoters on plasmids transiently transfected into HeLa cells (20).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	61	 To study promoter interference in a chromosomal context we stably integrated these tandem promoter constructs into HeLa cells.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Two constructs (CI and CII; Fig.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	63	 1) were transfected, one containing an intervening termination signal [SPAC, consisting of the strong poly(A) site SPA and the downstream C2 pause element] between the two LTRs (CII; 25) and the other without this intervening termination signal (CI).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Individual cell clones containing the CI and CII transgenes respectively were expanded and maintained in selective (G418-containing) medium.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Since the HIV-1 promoter is inducible by the viral transactivator Tat, we were able to detect transcriptional interference by enhancing transcription with Tat.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	66	 This was achieved by stably transfecting these clonally derived CI and CII cells lines with a Tat-expressing vector, allowing a direct comparison of basal and Tat trans-activated transcription of one particular clone.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Tat expression was monitored at the RNA level by S1 nuclease mapping of the Tat transcript (data not shown).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	68	 In the experiments described below we analysed individual clones derived from these stable transfections which were checked for their integrity and copy number by Southern blotting (data not shown).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Clones containing single copy integrants were employed.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Furthermore, to obtain position-independent values we also analysed complex cell pools consisiting of >100 positive clones.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Trans-activation by Tat leads to reduced transcription from the L2 promoter in CI cell lines.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	72	 RNase protection assay of cytoplasmic RNA from HeLa cells stably transfected with CI.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Lanes 1 and 2, undigested riboprobes S and L; lanes 3, 5 and 7, three different CI clones under basal transcription conditions; lanes 4, 6 and 8, the same clones transactivated by Tat.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The gel was quantified in a phosphorimager.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Bars represent RNA levels from the L1 and L2 promoters under basal (-Tat) and trans-activated conditions (+Tat) and were normalized to the neo control.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Also shown are values for a complex CI cell pool (note the lower scale).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The diagram at the bottom shows the origin of the protected RNA species.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The tandem promoters L1 and L2 (white boxes) driving the [alpha]2-globin reporter fragments (grey bars) and the SV40 promoter (which is driving the neo gene) are shown, as are the HIV-1 poly(A) site at +80 (relative to the start site at +1; empty triangles), the [alpha]2-globin poly(A) site (grey triangle) and the LTR-specific antisense riboprobe (L) which protects transcripts initiated at both LTR promoters simultaneously.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The intervening terminator (SPAC) allows increased transcription from L2 promoters in the presence of Tat.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	80	 RNase protection assay of cytoplasmic RNA from HeLa cells stably transfected with CII.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Lanes 1 and 3, two different CII clones under trans-activated conditions (+Tat); lanes 2 and 4, the same clones under basal conditions (-Tat); lanes 5 and 6, undigested riboprobes L and S.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Trans-activation allows an increase in transcription from both promoters, L1 and L2, in the presence of the terminator.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Values were normalized to the internal neo standard.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Also shown are values for a complex CII cell pool.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Diagram as in Figure 2, except that the intervening terminator, SPAC, containing the synthetic poly(A) site is shown (filled triangle).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	86	It should be noted that the CI and CII constructs both contain an adjacent SV40 promoter-enhancer element which is used to drive expression of the neo gene.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Consequently, the HIV LTR promoters are significantly active in the absence of Tat, presumably due to the proximity of the SV40 enhancer (26,27).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Even so, the presence of Tat further activated the LTR promoters and allowed detection of transcriptional interference effects between the adjacent LTR promoters.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	89	Transcriptional activity from the two promoters (L1 and L2) was assessed by RNase protection assays (Figs 2 and 3).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Cytoplasmic RNA, extracted from various individual clones and pools, was analysed using a mixture of two riboprobes: probe L, an LTR-specific riboprobe which recognizes both LTR transcripts simultaneously and distinguishes between L1 read-through and L2 initiating transcripts (derived as a PvuII-SmaI fragment from L2); probe S hybridizes to transcripts initiated at the SV40 promoter (which drives transcription of the neo gene contained within the transfected plasmid).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Probe S was included as an internal control in each assay which allowed direct comparison of a single clone under basal and trans-activated conditions, when normalized to the internal standard.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	92	Transcriptional interference occurs between stably integrated tandem HIV-1 LTR promoters.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	93	As shown in Figure 2, RNase protection analysis of transcripts derived from three CI clones yields two major products of 134 and 230 nt, corresponding to transcripts initiating on the L1 and L2 promoters respectively.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Figure 2 also shows quantitative analysis of this data as well as comparable data for a CI pool.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	95	 These results demonstrate a relatively small change in L1 and L2 promoter activity following trans-activation by Tat, presumably due to their already high basal levels.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Using the SV40 RNA as an internal standard (which is not responsive to Tat), a direct assessment of the change in LTR promoter activity under induced conditions was determined.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Under basal conditions (-Tat) the L2/L1 ratio was calculated as ~3 (varying from 2.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	98	5 between the three clonal and pool RNAs, taking the number of labeled residues into account).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	99	 However, in the presence of Tat, while the activity of L1 increased, L2 activity actually decreased (relative to basal transcription conditions), indicating that the trans-activated upstream promoter may be reducing transcription from the downstream promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The LTR fragment comprising L2 contains an additional 20 bp from the LTR at its 3[prime]-end, which might explain the consistently higher L2 promoter activity.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	101	 As mentioned above, using these chromosomally integrated constructs transcription from the HIV-1 promoters is rather high, even in the absence of Tat.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In contrast, transcription from the same constructs (lacking the SV40 driven neo gene) could hardly be detected without Tat in transient expression assays (20).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The most likely explanation for this difference is the presence of the SV40 regulatory region containing the enhancer (380 bp from SfiI to PvuII), which has been shown to influence expression from the HIV-1 and human globin gene promoters (28).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The proximity of this potent enhancer could affect basal transcription rates, thereby leading to the relatively muted Tat enhancement (27,28).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	105	 However, since these tandem promoters are differently affected by Tat, we infer that the activated L1 promoter (+Tat) reduces transcription from the downstream L2 promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	106	Additional minor bands visible in Figure 2 derive from L1 transcripts reading into the L2 region of the construct.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	107	 In particular, the L1 transcript is polyadenylated at the downstream L2 HIV poly(A) site (HpA; Fig.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	108	 1), giving rise to a 116 nt 3[prime] doublet.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	109	 A small fraction of transcripts read through this poly(A) site, generating bands of ~150 and 248 nt.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The 248 nt species arises from read-through of Hp(A) in L2 to the 5[prime] splice site of the [alpha]-globin reporter gene.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The origin of the 150 nt species may derive from a cryptic splice site.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Both of these L1 species, as well as the major 134 nt fragment, increase upon trans-activation.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The constant band of ~200 nt does not change upon trans-activation and derives from incompletely digested riboprobe.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Overall the 3[prime]-end products of transcription initiated at the L1 promoter are clearly present at much lower levels than the 134 nt 5[prime] product using probe L.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Presumably a significant fraction of L1 transcripts is spliced out in the L2 region.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Identification of these various minor L1-derived bands was confirmed by S1 nuclease mapping (data not shown).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	117	An intervening transcriptional terminator alleviates interference and restores L2 promoter activity upon Tat transactivation.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	118	To examine the role of a strong transcriptional termination element placed between two pol II promoters in a chromosomal context, cytoplasmic RNA extracted from clones and pools stably transfected with the CII construct was analysed by RNase protection (Fig.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	119	 CII contains a strong synthetic poly(A) site (SPA) followed by the C2 transcriptional pause site (11,25,29) between the two LTR promoters.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	120	 As mentioned above, transcriptional termination signals have previously been shown to relieve interference in transient transfection assays (30).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Since promoters may be regulated differently when part of higher order chromatin we wished to examine the role of this termination element between the LTR promoters in stable integrants.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	122	 As shown in Figure 3, no read-in transcripts were detected from the L1 promoter, suggesting 100% SPA use.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Secondly, whereas trans-activaton led to a relative decrease of L2 in CI clones, we consistently observed an increase for both promoters, L1 and L2, in CII when transcription was enhanced by Tat.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	124	 These results suggest that transcription from the downstream promoter, upon trans-activation, can only increase when preceded by the termination element.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	125	The data presented in Figures 2 and 3 indicate that interference occurs between stably integrated tandem LTR promoter constructs which was detected upon transcriptional enhancement by Tat.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Inhibition of the downstream promoter can be overcome by the presence of the intervening termination signal.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	127	In vivo footprinting indicates reduced binding of transcription factors to the occluded L2 promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	128	Promoter occlusion by the incoming polymerase complex may be caused by impeding transcription factor access to the promoter or alternatively by actual displacement of factors already bound to the promoter (17).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	129	 We therefore analysed actual DNA-protein interactions on the downstream L2 promoter by in vivo footprinting (31).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	130	 It should be noted that neither restricted access nor displacement of factors is likely to be an `all-or-nothing effect' and its resolution in vivo is therefore limited.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Footprinting was carried out using dimethylsulfate (DMS) as the modifying agent.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	132	 DMS methylates freely accessible guanosine residues of DNA in living cells, unless they are protected by DNA-bound factors.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Cells derived from both lines (CI and CII) were incubated with DMS for 5 min (qualitatively similar results were obtained with 2 and 10 min incubations), genomic DNA was purified, cleaved with piperidine and analysed by linker-mediated PCR on 6% sequencing gels.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	134	 As a control phenol-extracted chromosomal DNA was treated with DMS in vitro and analysed in parallel.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	135	 DMS in vivo footprinting across the L2 promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Footprinting was performed on the coding strand of various clones and pools.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The promoter region from -15 (relative to the start site at +1) to the distal NF-[kappa]B sites is shown.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The left half of the figure (CI) shows the reduced footprints across the upstream elements (indicated on the left side) of CI integrants.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Lanes 1 and 2, DNA from a CI cell pool; lanes 3-6, DNA from two CI clones (+Tat and -Tat); lane 7, in vitro-treated control DNA (co), the right half showing footprints over the upstream elements; lanes 8 and 9, DNA from a CII cell pool; lanes 10 and 11, DNA from a CII clone.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Three G residues are indicated at the right side (filled arrowheads, -47, -60 and -79 relative to the start site at +1).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	141	A typical analysis is shown in Figure 4, where panel CII represents samples from a CII clone and pool.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Binding sites for transcription factor Sp1 are clearly visible as compared with the control (co, lane 7).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	143	 As expected, these sites are engaged in protein interactions on an active HIV-1 promoter (32).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	144	 In detail, the CII profiles compared with the control DNA (lane 7) indicate a partial protection of G residues in Sp1 sites 1 and 2, in particular at positions -54 and -55 with respect to the transcriptional start site, a hypersensitive site between the proximal Sp1 sites 1 and 2, at position -60, strong protections in Sp1 site 3 and a hypersensitive site at -79.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The distal Sp1 site 3 is known to have the highest affinity for Sp1 in vitro (33).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Whereas these footprints are clearly apparent in CII clones (and pools), they are significantly reduced in CI clones (and pools) lacking the intervening terminator.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The clearest differences are seen over the distal, high affinity Sp1 site 3, where all G residues are less protected in CI integrants.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Also, the G residues at -54 and -55 are markedly less protected in the CI clones (G residues in SP1 site 1 are also slightly less protected).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	149	 A reduction in hypersensity over the NF-[kappa]B sites was also noted (mainly in CI clones), although with less consistency.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Overall these results indicate that protein interactions on the downstream promoter, especially over the Sp1 sites, in CI clones are reduced when compared with those on the corresponding promoter preceded by the terminator.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	151	 We also observed minor differences in the protein interactions in CI clones when trans-activated by Tat as compared with basal conditions.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In particular, the two NF-[kappa]B sites and position -79 evident in c1/1 and c1/2, which are less hypersensitive in the presence of Tat, indicate perturbed protein interactions under trans-activated conditions.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	153	Taken together, the genomic footprinting data presented in Figure 4 reveal reduced binding of Sp1 (and to a lesser extent NF-[kappa]B) to the downstream promoter in the absence of an upstream terminator, indicating an effect of interference on protein interactions at the promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Since Sp1 activates transcription synergistically (34) and both proteins, Sp1 and NF-[kappa]B, are known to contact components of the basal transcription factor TFIID (35), displacement of these factors would explain reduced transcription from an occluded promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	155	A factor binds to the C2 pause site in vivo.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	156	The C2 pause element originates from the 420 bp intergenic region of the human complement genes C2 and factor B, located in the MHC class III region.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	157	 A region of 156 bp downstream of the C2 poly(A) site, which contains a protein binding site towards its 5[prime]-end, has been implicated in pol II termination (Fig.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The zinc finger protein MAZ (Myc-associated zinc finger protein), which was originally identified as a factor that binds to the c-myc P2 promoter (36), correlated with the termination efficiency of the pause sites in various assays (29).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	159	 DNase I in vivo footprinting of the C2 pause site.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The 5[prime]-end of the C2 pause site, containing the MAZ binding site, is shown.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	161	 All samples (lanes 1-5) were probed with the same set of primers.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Lane 1, G ladder (CII DNA treated with DMS and piperidine as a marker); lanes 2 and 3, DNA from a CII clone (+Tat and -Tat); lane 4, DNA from a CII pool (+Tat); lane 5, naked DNA treated with DNase I.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The white box on the left hand side corresponds to the in vitro MAZ binding site.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Arrowheads show protected (empty) and hypersensitive sites (filled) with the degree being indicated by size of the arrowhead.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The diagram at the bottom shows the position of the pause site and the MAZ binding site.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	166	To see whether a protein binds to the MAZ site in our integrated construct in vivo we analysed the chromatin structure of this region by DNase I in vivo footprinting.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Footprinting was carried out in isolated nuclei, which were taken up in physiological buffer (23) and partially digested with DNase I (24).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The cleavage pattern of the non-coding strand was analysed by linker-mediated PCR and compared with naked DNA, partially digested in vitro (no specific primers could be designed to analyse the coding strand).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Figure 5 shows a hypersensitive site at the 5[prime]-border of the protein binding site, slight protection in the centre (compare lane 2 and 5), a strongly protected residue towards the 3[prime]-end and a hypersensitive site at the 3[prime]-border.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The in vivo footprinting pattern is in agreement with previous in vitro footprinting data, where a 27 bp region at the same position was protected from DNase I using HeLa cell extract (29).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The data also indicated that the pattern did not change upon Tat induction (Fig.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	172	 5, lanes 2 and 3), suggesting stable binding of the protein to this site under basal and induced conditions.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The same pattern was obtained when analysing DNA from a cell pool in the presence of Tat (lane 4).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	174	 These results indicate that a protein binds to the C2 pause site in vivo and that binding is not abolished by Tat-actived transcription from upstream.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	175	 It would therefore seem likely that the binding of this factor to the terminator sequence is not disrupted by transcriptional interference.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	176	Transcriptional interference between adjacent transcription units has been observed in various systems.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Initially experiments in Escherichia coli showed that transcription from the strong prophage [lambda] promoter Pl inhibits the adjacent gal promoter (12).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Interference between promoters has also been detected on plasmids transiently transfected into mammalian cells (30).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In vitro experiments in pol I systems led to the suggestion of a possible mechanism for this phenomenon.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Template competition experiments in the mouse pol I system indicated actual displacement of transcription factor D by the incoming polymerase, which allowed transcription of competitor templates by the displaced factor (17).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	181	 A similar observation was made on the pol I promoter in the lower eukaryote Acanthamoeba, where a single initiation factor (TIF, the Acanthamoeba analogue of mouse factor D) is required for pre-initiation complex assembly and polymerase recruitment to the promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	182	 In vitro footprinting analysis revealed displacement of TIF from a dimeric pol I promoter construct by pol I passage through the promoter (18).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	183	Earlier work has emphasized a role for transcriptional termination elements to relieve interference between transcription units on plasmids transiently transfected into mammalian cells.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	184	 To examine the importance of terminators between transcription units in the genome we used HIV-1 LTR driven reporter constructs stably integrated into HeLa cells.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Since the HIV promoter is trans-activated by Tat we could directly compare individual clones under basal and trans-activated conditions and the effect of a trans-activated promoter on the downstream transcription unit.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	186	 As mentioned above, the high basic transcription rates of the transgenes were ascribed to the proximity of the SV40 regulatory region with its strong enhancer.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Therefore, the relative increase in transcription in the presence of Tat in this system was not drastic (27).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Nevertheless, upon trans-activation, while transcription from the upstream promoter L1 increased up to 5-fold, transcription from the downstream L2 promoter increased only when preceded by the terminator.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Mapping the 3[prime]-end of the upstream L1 transcript revealed its extension into the L2 promoter in CI (-terminator) cell lines, whereas in CII lines it was processed at the intervening terminator.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The same terminator consisting of the strong synthetic poly(A) site SPA linked to the C2 pause site (SPAC) has been shown to prevent promoter interference between the MLV LTR promoter and the keratin 10 gene in a recent study (22).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Stable cell lines transfected with an MLV expression vector containing the whole keratin 10 gene downstream of the MLV promoter followed by a hygromycin B resistance gene were selected and tested for keratin expression by western blotting.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	192	 No keratin 10 was detected in these clones unless SPAC was positioned between the MLV and keratin promoters.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Eighteen of 22 hygromycin B-resistant clones synthesized keratin 10 when SPAC was present (22).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	194	Since interference might be caused by disruption of transcription factor binding to the promoter by an upstream elongation-competent polymerase complex, we mapped DNA-protein interactions on the L2 promoter in vivo.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Comparison of occluded versus protected L2 promoter by DMS in vivo footprinting revealed reduced footprints at the occluded promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Differences in the protein binding pattern in CI and CII were mainly evident across the three Sp1 binding sites and to a lesser degree at the tandem NF-[kappa]B binding sites.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Reduction in Sp1 binding was consistent in several experiments and ~3-fold, whereas changes at the NF-[kappa]B sites varied.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Since Sp1 activates transcription synergistically (34) and partly by interacting with TAF 110, a component of the basal transcription factor TFIID (37), loss of Sp1 would be expected to result in a reduction in transcriptional activity.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Interestingly, Sp1 sites were shown to have no effect on transcriptional termination (10), whereas a bound CAAT box binding protein was effective in termination.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	200	 It seems possible that, depending on the nature of the DNA-protein interaction, binding of some factors is disrupted by transcription, whereas others remain stably bound.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The ability of DNA-bound proteins to impede polymerase elongation has previously been demonstrated (38).
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	202	DNase I in vivo footprinting across the C2 pause site of the terminator indicated binding of a factor to the 5[prime]-part of the of the pause element.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	203	 This binding pattern did not change after Tat trans-activation, suggesting a stable contact despite increased transcription from upstream.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	204	 This region of the pause site, in particular the sequence G5AG5 has been shown to bind the zinc finger protein MAZ in vitro, which has been implicated in termination in various assays.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Insertion of the C2 pause site between two poly(A) sites greatly increased use of the weak upstream site, probably by pausing the polymerase.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Binding of this factor to the pause site might be necessary to halt the polymerase (Fig.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The role of MAZ in the termination process is currently being investigated in vitro.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Model for interference between stably integrated HIV-1 promoters.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Shown are the L2 promoter regions of both the CI and CII constructs.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Sp1 transcription factors (filled grey circles) are displaced by the incoming polymerase (pol II) in CI.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	211	 In CII the polymerase is stalled at the terminator, possibly by MAZ (black oval) bound to the pause site of the terminator, allowing stable binding of Sp1 to the downstream promoter.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	212	Our data suggest that transcriptional termination elements play an important role in regulation of gene expression, to allow individual expression of adjacent transcription units.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	213	 The absence of a terminator can lead to reduction or impairment of adjacent gene expression, probably resulting from a disruption of DNA-bound regulatory proteins by a processive polymerase complex.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	214	 We are currently testing our model for transcriptional interference (Fig.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	215	 6) in yeast, where transcription units are densely packed and therefore efficient transcriptional termination of more significance.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	216	Murphy for critical reading of the manuscript and S.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	217	Grange for providing us with the DNase I footprinting protocol.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	218	 was supported by the Oesterreichisches Bundesministerium fuer Wissenschaft und Forschung.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	219	 This work was supported by a Wellcome Trust Programme Grant no.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	220	 (1992) New Biologist, 4, 369-381.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	221	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Tel: +44 1865 275566; Fax: +44 1865 275556; Email: nicholas.
