0.15876892.9469840.html.plaintext.txt	224	uk' + u + '@' + d + ''//--> Last modification: 19 Feb 1998 Copyright  Oxford University Press, 1998.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	0	  The Rockefeller University Press, 0021-9525/2001/8/741 $5.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 The Journal of Cell Biology, Volume 154, Number 4, August 20, 2001 741-752 Article.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	2	A conserved -herpesvirus protein necessary for axonal localization of viral membrane proteins M.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	3	Department of Molecular Biology, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	4	Address correspondence to Lynn W.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Enquist, 314 Schultz Laboratory, Department of Molecular Biology, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	6	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Pseudorabies virus, an -herpesvirus, is capable of infecting the nervous system and spreading between synaptically connected neurons in diverse hosts.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	7	 At least three viral membrane proteins (gE, gI, and Us9) are necessary for the spread of infection from presynaptic to postsynaptic neurons (anterograde spread) in infected rodents.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	8	 To understand how these proteins effect anterograde spread between neurons, we analyzed the subcellular localization of viral proteins after infection of cultured rat sympathetic neurons with wild-type or mutant viruses.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	9	 After Us9-null mutant infections but not gE-null mutant infections, only a subset of the viral structural proteins had entered axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Surprisingly, capsid and tegument proteins but not viral membrane proteins were detected in axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The spread of Us9 missense mutants in the rodent nervous system correlated with the amount of viral membrane proteins localized to axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	12	 We conclude that the Us9 membrane protein controls axonal localization of diverse viral membrane proteins but not that of capsid or tegument proteins.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The data support a model where virion subassemblies but not complete virions are transported in the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Our results provide new insight into the process of virion assembly and exit from neurons that leads to directional spread of herpesviruses in the nervous system.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	15	Key Words: axonal transport; virus assembly; membrane proteins; herpesvirus; pseudorabies virus.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	16	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   -Herpesviruses are unique parasites of the vertebrate peripheral nervous system (PNS)*.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	17	 After primary infection at an epithelial surface, virus invades the termini of sensory and autonomic neurons innervating the infected tissue.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Subsequently, virion components are transported through axons to the cell bodies of these neurons, usually a substantial distance from the termini.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Movement of virion components from the axon terminal to the cell body is thought to occur via microtubule-based motors such as dynein moving material in a plus-to-minus direction (Enquist et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Within a week of invading the cell bodies of PNS ganglionic neurons, production of infectious virus ceases, and a quiescent or latent state is established.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Months or years later, the latent infection can be reactivated, and new virions are produced in PNS ganglionic neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The virions then travel via axons to the periphery and infect the epithelia, producing infectious virus that can spread to other hosts.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Long distance movement of newly replicated virions from the cell body to distant axon terminals is not well understood but has been suggested to occur using microtubule-based motors such as the kinesins that move cargo in the minus-to-plus direction (Enquist et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	24	, 1998; Sodeik, 2000; Smith et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The movement of virions in PNS axons toward the cell body after primary infection or away from the neuronal cell body via PNS axons after replication implies that -herpesviruses may encode gene products capable of regulating directional axonal transport.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	26	Evidence of viral proteins capable of affecting direction of virus movement in living animals came from studies of circuit-specific transneuronal infection by pseudorabies virus (PRV; a broad host range -herpesvirus).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The proteins gE, gI, and Us9 are all universally conserved in known neurotropic -herpesvirus genomes.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	28	 gE and gI are type I transmembrane proteins that typically form a heterodimer, whereas Us9 is a type II tail-anchored membrane protein.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Several groups discovered that -herpesvirus gE, gI, or Us9 mutants were able to replicate in primary neurons but were incapable of spreading to secondary postsynaptic neurons (Card et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	30	 For example, after infection of the rat eye wild-type PRV replicates in retinal neurons and spreads via the optic nerve to secondary neurons in all visual nuclei in the central nervous system (for review see Enquist et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	31	 By contrast, gE, gI, or Us9-null mutants replicate well in retinal neurons but do not spread to second-order neurons in the superior colliculus in the midbrain (Whealy et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	32	 This defect is significant, since >90% of the retinal ganglion cells in the rat retina are in synaptic contact with neurons in the superior colliculus (Linden and Perry, 1983).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Similar defects in the spread of gE and gI mutant viruses from presynaptic to postsynaptic neurons (often called anterograde spread) have also been reported after nasal infection of swine (the natural host of PRV) (Kritas et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Although PRV gE, gI, and Us9 proteins are required for efficient spread from presynaptic to postsynaptic neurons through most neural circuits tested, these three proteins are not required for spread from postsynaptic to presynaptic neurons (often called retrograde spread) (Whealy et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	35	All available evidence suggests that the defect in anterograde transsynaptic spread exhibited by gE, gI, and Us9 mutants occurs within the primary presynaptic infected neuron (Husak et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	36	 One hypothesis is that in gE, gI, or Us9 mutant infections virions assembled in the cell body fail to be transported into axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	37	 An alternative suggestion is that in mutant infections assembled virions enter axons but can not be released from axon terminals.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	38	 In this report, we tested these hypotheses by examining the localization of virion structural proteins after wild-type or mutant infection of cultured neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	39	 If the first hypothesis is true, virion structural proteins should not be found in axons after mutant infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	40	 If the second hypothesis is true, structural proteins should be found in axons for both mutant and wild-type infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Our work revealed that neither hypothesis is correct and suggested a unique function for the Us9 protein.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Although the presence or absence of gE had no obvious effect on localization of virion structural proteins to axons of infected neurons, after Us9-null mutant infections only a subset of the viral structural proteins had entered axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Surprisingly, capsid and tegument proteins but not viral membrane proteins were detected in axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	44	We have previously used alanine substitution mutagenesis to define Us9 residues essential for in vivo anterograde spread of PRV in the rat visual system (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	45	 This work indicated that two adjacent tyrosines (Y49Y50) in an acidic motif (residues 46 to 56) were absolutely essential for Us9 function (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	46	 In addition, we found that two serines (S51S53) in the acidic domain were phosphorylated, and alanine substitutions of these residues affected the rate of Us9-dependent in vivo anterograde spread.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Finally, alanine substitution mutagenesis of two adjacent leucine residues (L30L31) that function as an endocytosis motif (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	48	, 2000b) are dispensable for anterograde spread in vivo.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	49	 We infected cultured PNS neurons with these mutant viruses to determine if the Us9-dependent localization of viral membrane proteins correlated with their ability to promote anterograde spread of infection in vivo.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	50	 We found that tyrosines 48 and 50 but not serines 51 and 53 were absolutely required for Us9-mediated membrane protein localization in axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Leucines 30 and 31 were completely dispensable for the axonal localization of viral membrane proteins just as they are for anterograde spread in vivo.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	52	View larger version (32K):    Figure 1.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	53	 (A) The amino acid sequence of PRV Us9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Amino acids that have been substituted with alanine are bolded.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The acidic region of Us9 is underlined with a solid line, and the predicted transmembrane domain is underlined with a dashed line.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	56	 (B) The PRV Us9 missense mutants and their amino acid changes.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	57	  These results provide new insight into the process of virion assembly and exit from neurons that leads to directional spread of herpesviruses in the nervous system.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	58	 We suggest that a single viral protein (Us9) is responsible for the localization of most if not all viral membrane proteins to the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	59	 If membrane proteins are not localized to axons and transported to axon terminals, viral infection cannot spread to synaptically connected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	60	 An important finding was that Us9 is not required for localization of the capsid or tegument proteins to the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	61	 An interpretation of our observations is that mature virions are not assembled in the cell body and subsequently transported in axons to the axon terminal.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Rather, components of mature virions are transported separately in axons to terminals where infection of postsynaptic cells occurs.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	63	   Results Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Determining the subcellular distribution of gB, an essential virion envelope protein in infected superior cervical ganglia neurons Predictions from previous work were that gE and Us9 mutants would be defective either in the transport of intracellular virions into axons or that mutant virions could not exit from axon terminals (Husak et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Accordingly, we determined the localization of viral structural components in neurons infected with wild-type or mutant viruses.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Initially, we examined the subcellular distribution of the viral glycoprotein gB in neurons that were infected with wild-type, gE-null, and Us9-null viruses.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	66	 gB is an abundant viral membrane protein that is required for virus entry and cell-to-cell spread in all cells (Rauh and Mettenleiter, 1991).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The kinetics of expression and the cellular localization of gB were indistinguishable in the cell body of neurons infected with all three viruses (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	68	 In neurons infected with the wild-type and gE-null mutants, puncta of gB immunoreactivity appeared in the axons at 11 h after infection (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	69	 At 16 h after infection, gB puncta could be found throughout the extent of axons of neurons infected with either virus (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	70	 However, in Us9-null infections very little gB could be detected in the axons of infected neurons even at the latest times after infection (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Occasionally, puncta of gB immunoreactivity appeared in axons after Us9-null mutant infection but only in the proximal portion of the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	72	 These experiments provided the first direct evidence that Us9 and gE may have different functions in infected neurons leading to transsynaptic spread.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	73	View larger version (82K):    Figure 2.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The axonal localization of the essential viral membrane protein gB requires Us9 but not gE.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Less than 10% of the neurons in a culture were infected for 12 h with the wild-type (A and D), the gE-null mutant (B and E), or the Us9-null mutant (C and F) and then were fixed and permeabilized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Infected neurons were labeled with antibodies that recognize gB.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	77	 A to C have image planes at the level of the cell bodies, whereas D to F have image planes at the substrate so that axons can be visualized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Arrows point to axons of infected neurons, and N indicates the nucleus of infected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	79	  Us9 is required for axonal localization of two other viral membrane proteins We next determined whether gC and gE, two abundant but nonessential virion membrane proteins, localize to axons in the absence of Us9 (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The results were similar to those for gB described above: the amount of gC and gE and the distance the membrane proteins had traveled in the axon were dramatically reduced during Us9-null mutant infections compared with wild-type infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Thus, three diverse virion membrane proteins (gB, gC, and gE) required Us9 protein to localize to and fill axons, even though no obvious defect in the expression or localization of these glycoproteins within the cell body was apparent by confocal microscopy.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	82	View larger version (77K):    Figure 3.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The axonal localization of viral membrane proteins requires Us9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	84	 (A) Neurons were infected with the wild-type (a, b, and c) and the Us9-null virus PRV160 (d, e, and f) such that every neuron was infected for 16 h and then were fixed and permeabilized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Infected neurons were labeled with antibodies that recognize gB (a and d), gC (b and e), and gE (c and f).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Arrows point to axons that are labeled with viral membrane proteins in the wild-type infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	87	 (B) The same experiment as above but at lower magnification.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Bars: (A) 25  microm; (B) 150  microm.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	89	  Viral membrane proteins traffic through the secretory system during Us9-null infections The absence of viral membrane proteins in axons during Us9-null infections may reflect aberrant trafficking of viral membrane proteins through the secretory system.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Accordingly, we examined the kinetics of cell surface expression of a viral membrane protein during infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	91	 If Us9-null infections lead to retention of viral membrane proteins in the secretory system, viral membrane proteins should not be found on the surface of the infected cell.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Neurons were infected with the wild-type or the Us9-null virus for varying lengths of time, and the cell surface localization of gE was examined.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	93	 gE appeared on the neuronal surface after infection with either virus (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The kinetics of surface expression were similar for both viruses: detectable levels of gE appeared 7 h after infection (during experiments where all neurons in a culture were infected).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Despite similar kinetics, gE initially surfaced on the axons of neurons infected with the wild-type virus, but little to no gE was detected on the surface of axons infected with the Us9-null virus (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	96	 By 9 h after infection, markedly different surface-staining patterns were evident: gE covered the surface of neurons during the wild-type infection, both on the cell body and the axon (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	97	 During Us9-null infections, little to no detectable staining appeared on the axons (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	98	 4 A, c and d), despite significant staining on the surface of the cell body.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	99	 These results demonstrate that gE is able to traffic through the secretory system to the cell body surface during Us9-null mutant infections yet is not targeted to the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	100	View larger version (62K):    Figure 4.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Analysis of the neuronal secretory system during PRV infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	102	 (A) Cell surface gE during wild-type or Us9-null infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Neurons were infected such that every neuron was infected for 9 h with the wild-type (a and b) or Us9-null virus (c and d).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Antibodies that recognize gE were placed directly in the culture medium for 5 min, and then unbound antibodies were removed and the infected neurons were fixed.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	105	 (B) The steady-state localization of the synaptic vesicle marker SV2.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Neurons were mock infected (a) or infected with the wild-type virus (b) or the Us9-null virus (c) such that every neuron was infected for 16 h, and then the neurons were fixed and permeabilized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	107	 An antibody that recognizes SV2 was then used in indirect immunofluorescence experiments.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	108	 (C) The subcellular localization of a cellular protein (NgCAM) expressed during PRV infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	109	 A replication- defective virus expressing the cellular protein NgCAM was used to infect cultured neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	110	 After 1 h, the medium was removed, and cultures were mock infected (a to c) or infected with the wild-type (d to f) or Us9-null virus (g to i).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	111	 a to c show NgCAM localization in the absence of PRV infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	112	 NgCAM appears on the surface of the cell body (a), in vesicles within the axon (b; note that this is an image of a large fasiculation, and therefore many axons are present within the bundle), and on the surface of the axon (c).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	113	 NgCAM labeled the surface of neurons infected with wild-type virus (d) and Us9-null virus (g).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The expression of gE during the wild-type (e) and Us9-null (h) infections demonstrates that they are infected with PRV.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Merged images of the wild-type infection (f) and Us9-null infection (i) are shown with NgCAM in green and gE in red.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Bars: (A, a and b, B, and C) 25  microm; (A, c and d) 150  microm.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	117	  Targeting of cellular proteins is not disrupted during Us9-null infections We examined the possibility that axonal targeting of cellular proteins was disrupted during Us9-null mutant infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	118	 We first assessed the steady-state localization of the synaptic vesicle marker SV2.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Neurons were infected with the wild-type, Us9-null, or were mock infected for 16 h and then were fixed.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Antibodies that recognized SV2 were used in indirect immunofluorescence experiments, and the levels of staining were compared.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	121	 SV2 staining appeared along the length of the axon in the control sample (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	122	 No notable difference in staining was found for either the wild-type (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	123	 4 B, b) or the Us9-null infections (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	124	 4 B, c) compared with the control.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	125	Although this evidence is consistent with the hypothesis that cellular proteins are targeted normally during Us9-null mutant infections, it only examined the steady-state localization of a cellular protein during infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	126	 To assess the fate of de novo to translated protein, we expressed a cellular protein that normally localizes to the axon (NgCAM) from a replication-defective herpes simplex virus during PRV infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The defective virus was first used to infect neurons, and 1 h later either the wild-type or Us9-null virus was used to superinfect cultured neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Because NgCAM is a chicken protein, only protein expressed from the defective virus is detectable with an antibody against the chicken protein (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	129	 After 16 h of PRV infection, antibodies against NgCAM were used to determine targeting of the cellular protein to the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	130	 4 C shows the expression of NgCAM after 18 h of infection with the replication-defective virus.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Staining is found predominantly on the cell surface (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	132	 4 C, a and c) but also in vesicles within the axon (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The intensity of expression was drastically reduced during infection with PRV, but many neurons expressed NgCAM adequately.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	134	 NgCAM was found on the surface of axons and cell bodies of neurons infected with either wild-type (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	135	 4 C, d) or Us9-null mutant (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Taken together, these two experiments indicate that axonal targeting of cellular proteins is not markedly disrupted during infection with either the wild-type or the Us9-null virus.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	137	Critical domains defined for Us9 function in vivo are also required for localization of viral membrane proteins into axons Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	138	 (2000b) used alanine substitution mutagenesis to define residues of Us9 required to promote anterograde viral spread in the rat visual system (see Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	139	 1 for the details of these mutant viruses).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	140	 These Us9 mutants (PRV 166, 172, and 173) differ in the rate and extent of anterograde spread in vivo.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	141	 We infected cultured superior cervical ganglia (SCG) neurons with these viruses to determine if the axonal localization of viral membrane proteins correlated with anterograde spread in vivo.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	142	 PRV166 (L30L31 to AA) spreads through the rat visual system like a wild-type virus (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	143	 4, A to C, shows the results of SCG infection with PRV166.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	144	 All viral membrane proteins examined (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	145	 5 A, gB; B, gC; and C, gE) localized to the axons of infected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	146	 These infections were similar to the wild-type infections (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	147	 PRV173 (S51S53 to AA) is defective in rate but ultimately approximates wild-type extent of anterograde spread of infection in the rat visual system (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Infection of cultured neurons with PRV173 led to an intermediate phenotype: all viral membrane proteins examined did localize to the axon (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	149	 5, G to I), but the extent was reduced compared with the wild-type infection (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	150	 5, G to I, compared with A to C).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	151	 PRV172 (Y49Y50 to AA) has the Us9-null phenotype (restricted anterograde spread) after infection of the rat visual system (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Infections of cultured neurons with this mutant were identical to Us9-null virus infections; viral membrane proteins were not found in axons, and only scattered vesicles were found near the cell body (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	153	 These data demonstrate that Us9-mediated membrane protein localization in axons correlates well with the anterograde spread of infection in the rat visual system.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	154	View larger version (95K):    Figure 5.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Axonal localization of viral membrane proteins promoted by Us9 missense mutants correlates with degree of anterograde spread in the rodent nervous system.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Neurons were infected with PRV166 (L30L31 to AA) (A to C), PRV 172 (Y49Y50 to AA) (D to F), and PRV173 (S51S53 to AA) (G to I) such that every neuron was infected for 16 h and then were fixed and permeabilized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	157	 I for a more detailed description of the Us9 mutant viruses.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Infected neurons were labeled with antibodies that recognize gB (A, D, and G), gC (B, E, and H), and gE (C, F, and I).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	159	  Us9 is not found on all vesicles within the axon We examined the colocalization of Us9 and other viral membrane proteins during wild-type infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Us9 was observed on vesicles close to the cell body of an infected neuron (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	161	 6 , A to C, gB; D to F, gC; and G to I, gE) but often did not colocalize with viral membrane proteins containing vesicles in the distal axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	162	View larger version (111K):    Figure 6.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Colocalization of Us9 with other viral membrane proteins within the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Neurons were infected with the wild-type virus such that every neuron was infected for 6 h, and then antibodies to Us9 (A, D, and G) and gB (B), gC (E), or gE (H) were added.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The merged images are shown in C, F, and I with Us9 in green and the corresponding membrane protein in red.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	166	  Us9 is not required for tegument protein localization One hypothesis consistent with the results presented so far is that Us9 but not gE protein is required to transport mature (fully assembled) virions into axons of infected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	167	 If true, we predicted that other nonmembrane structural components of the virus (that is, the capsid and the tegument) would also require Us9 for localization in axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	168	 To test this prediction, we followed the localization of these virion components over time in cultured neurons infected with wild-type or Us9-null mutants.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	169	We first focused on the localization of tegument proteins in infected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The tegument is the collection of proteins just below the virus envelope and outside the capsid of a herpes virion (Roizman and Furlong, 1974).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Early in the infection for the wild-type and Us9 mutants (4 to 8 h after infection), the tegument proteins VP22 and UL25 localized most strongly to the nucleus but also were observed throughout the cell body (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Tegument proteins could not be detected in axons during these early stages of the infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	173	 However, 8 h after infection immunoreactivity for tegument proteins in the nucleus decreased with a concomitant increase in antibody staining of infected axons during wild-type and Us9-null infections (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Both VP22 and UL25 also localized to axons during infections with Us9 missense mutants PRV 166, 172, and 173 (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	175	 We conclude that Us9 is not required to localize the tegument proteins VP22 and UL25 to axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Thus, the original hypothesis that Us9 is required for localization of fully assembled virions to the axon is not likely to be correct.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	177	View larger version (91K):    Figure 7.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The axonal localization of the tegument proteins UL25 and VP22 does not require Us9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Less than 10% of the neurons in the cultures were infected for 8 h with the wild-type (A) or the Us9-null virus (C) and then were fixed and permeabilized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Antibodies that recognize UL25 (A and C) revealed the subcellular localization of this tegument protein in infected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	181	 In a second series of experiments,  < 10% of the neurons in the cultures were infected for 12 h with the wild-type (B) or the Us9-null virus (D) and then were fixed and permeabilized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The neurons were labeled with antibodies that recognize VP22 (B and D).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	183	  Us9 is not required for localization of capsid proteins to axons The PRV capsid is an icosahedral structure that contains and delivers the viral genome to the nucleus of an infected cell.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Early in the infection (4 to 8 h after infection), an antibody to the major capsid protein, VP5, stained the nucleus intensely with weaker staining of the cytoplasm.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	185	 This observation is consistent with the initial synthesis of VP5 in the cytoplasm and subsequent transport to the nucleus where it assembles into capsids.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Despite the significant localization of VP5 in the nucleus and cell body, VP5 was not detected in axons at this time (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Approximately 8 h after infection, VP5 immunoreactivity was detected in the axons of neurons infected with the wild-type and Us9 mutants (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Wild-type levels of VP5 immunoreactivity was also found in axons of neurons infected with the Us9 missense mutants (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	189	View larger version (68K):    Figure 8.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The axonal localization of two capsid proteins does not require Us9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	191	 (A) Less than 10% of the neurons were infected for 12 h with the wild-type (a) or the Us9-null virus (b) and then were fixed and permeabilized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	192	 An antibody that recognizes the major capsid protein VP5 was used to label capsids in the infected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	193	 (B) Viruses that express a GFP capsid fusion (GFP to VP26) from the wild-type and Us9-null viral genomes were used to infect all neurons in the culture for 17 h and then were fixed and permeabilized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Antibodies that recognize GFP-labeled capsids in the infected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	195	 gE localization in the same fields is shown (c compared with d) and required Us9 to localize to axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Bars: (A) 25  microm; (B) 150  microm.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	197	  To confirm these findings, we constructed viruses that express green fluorescent protein (GFP) fused to another capsid protein, VP26, in both wild-type and Us9-null virus genomes.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The capsids produced by these viruses are predicted to contain 900 copies of the GFP to VP26 fusion protein (Desai and Person, 1998; Smith et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	199	 After infection, neurons were fixed, and antibodies recognizing GFP revealed the subcellular localization of VP26 and assembled capsids.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Again, we observed strong immunoreactivity in the nucleus and a weaker signal throughout the cell body at early times after infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	201	 No GFP to VP26 was detected in the axons at these times (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	202	 However, 8 h after infection immunoreactivity in the nucleus decreased, and GFP to VP26 was found in the axons of neurons in the presence or absence of Us9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	203	 6 B shows an experiment 17 h after infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	204	 GFP to VP26, presumably in assembled capsids, localized to the cell body and axons of infected neurons for the wild-type (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	205	 8 B, a) and Us9-null virus (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	206	 As a control, we also examined simultaneously the localization of membrane protein gE in these infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	207	 3), the axonal localization of gE requires expression of Us9 (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In Us9-null mutant infections, gE protein is confined mainly to the cell body and is not found in axons (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	209	 By contrast, capsids in the same infected cell, as deduced by GFP to VP26 staining, are found abundantly in axons in the presence or absence of Us9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Evidence that GFP to VP26 in axons is in assembled capsids is described in Smith et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	211	 These experiments demonstrate that Us9 is required for axonal localization of viral membrane proteins but not capsids.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Taken together with data from the previous section, the results are not consistent with the hypothesis that enveloped virions are transported in axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	213	Us9 is not involved in attachment, entry, or replication of PRV in SCG neurons Us9-null mutants grow normally with no obvious defects in attachment, entry, or replication in nonneuronal cells (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	214	 We observed that the Us9-null mutant produced infectious virus at essentially the same rate and to the same extent as wild-type virus in SCG neurons (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Wild-type and Us9-null mutant viruses produced relatively few infectious particles per neuron compared with infection of nonneuronal cell lines such as PK15 cells.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The quantity of infectious virus released into the medium was also low compared with nonneuronal cell lines.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	217	 We note that measurement of released virus is likely to be an underestimate as virus can bind avidly to the poly-lysine substrate required for neuronal growth (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Since there are no differences in rate and extent of infectious virus production among wild-type and Us9-null viruses, we conclude that Us9 does not affect viral attachment, entry, or replication in SCG neurons during the duration of our experiments.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Therefore, the Us9-null phenotype is not due to a replication defect.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	220	View larger version (17K):    Figure 9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Us9 is not involved in viral attachment, entry, or replication in SCG neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Neurons were infected with the wild-type and the Us9-null virus such that every neuron was infected, and the amount of infectious virus (plaque forming units) produced at 1, 8, 16, and 24 h after infection was determined.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Each sample was performed in triplicate for both viruses, and only the data for the cell-associated virus is shown in the graph.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	224	     Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Directional spread of -herpesviruses into and out of the PNS is a fundamental aspect of the viral life cycle.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Upon primary infection of a natural host, virus travels from the peripheral epithelia to neuronal cell bodies of the PNS where it usually establishes a latent infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	226	 During reactivation, the virus travels back to the periphery most likely in the same neuron that had been infected some time before.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Movement of virion components to and from the cell body of PNS neurons requires that viral proteins enter axons and move substantial distances (Tomishima et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Because access to the axon is restricted to a subset of neuronal proteins, typically those involved in synapse formation and function, it is likely that -herpesviruses have evolved mechanisms to interact with the axonal targeting and transport machinery to ensure the transport of viral proteins into axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	229	 We have demonstrated previously that Us9 is involved in spread of virus from presynaptic to postsynaptic neurons (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Here, we provide a simple explanation of this phenotype and demonstrate that Us9 is required for the localization of most if not all viral membrane proteins to the axon of infected neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	231	We were surprised to find that Us9 was not required to localize nonmembrane structural components of the virion (for example, capsid and tegument proteins) to the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	232	 This finding has important implications for herpesvirus assembly and addresses a long-standing problem of how and where the large and complex herpes virion is assembled in infected PNS neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	233	 A widely held idea is that completely assembled virions accumulate in the cell body and these nascent enveloped virions are transported in vesicles out of the cell body into axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Then, by microtubule-based motors the vesicles carry the enveloped virions to the axon terminals where they exit to infect the postsynaptic cell (Lycke et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	235	 In another model first suggested by Penfold et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	236	 (1994) for herpes simplex virus type 1, complete virions are not assembled in the cell body but rather are assembled at or near the axon terminal.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	237	 These workers observed capsids in axons separate from envelope proteins and never observed fully assembled enveloped virions in axons of cultured human PNS neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	238	 (1994) proposed that capsids destined for axon terminals were not enveloped in the cell body but rather acquired their envelope at or near the axon terminal such that mature enveloped virions are released into the cleft between neuron and epithelial cell.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Our data are consistent with this proposal.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Moreover, we extend this model and suggest that Us9 protein is required for axonal localization of virion envelope subassemblies but not tegument or capsid proteins.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	241	We and others have found that the -herpesvirus genes gE, gI, and Us9 are necessary for the anterograde spread of infection in vivo (Card et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	242	 One limitation of these in vivo experiments is the technical difficulty of examining the cell biology of the infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	243	 These previous experiments have only looked at the replication of virus within first- or second-order neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Consequently, it was not possible to determine why the second-order neurons were not infected.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Here, we report that Us9 is responsible for localizing viral membrane proteins to the axons of infected neurons, yet the gE and gI proteins are not needed for this function.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	246	 One idea is that gE and gI accumulate at nerve terminals to promote the spread of infection from pre- to postsynaptic neurons (Dingwell et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	247	, 2000a; Tirabassi and Enquist, 2000).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	248	The mechanism by which Us9 enables viral envelope proteins to enter axons is under study.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	249	 We tested three ideas initially.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	250	 First, does Us9 "open" the axon to any membrane protein, or does it discriminate among host and viral proteins? To test this idea, we determined the localization of well-known somatodendritic and axonal marker proteins during infection and found that even late in the infection (for example, 20 h) all marker proteins remained in their proper compartments (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Second, in the absence of Us9 are all membrane proteins, including host membrane proteins, blocked from entering axons in infected cells? We performed two sets of experiments to address this question.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The first experiments examined the steady-state localization of a synaptic vesicle protein in uninfected cultures and during wild-type or Us9-null mutant infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	253	 No difference could be found between the uninfected and the wild-type or Us9-null infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	254	 We also demonstrated that an axonal protein (NgCAM) translated during PRV infection was capable of trafficking into axons infected with either the wild-type or the Us9-null virus.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Finally, we tested the idea that viral membrane proteins were unable to progress through the secretory system in Us9-null infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	256	 We found that gE reaches the cell surface during Us9-null infections with kinetics that are similar (if not identical) to wild-type infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Together, these data argue that the secretory pathway is functional in Us9-null infections, and the trafficking of cellular proteins into the axon is normal in Us9-null infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	258	 It appears that Us9 specifically promotes the axonal delivery of viral membrane proteins.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	259	 (2000b) identified L30L31 and an acidic domain (amino acids 46 to 56) as important residues for retrieval and TGN localization of Us9 from the plasma membrane in nonneuronal cells.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	260	 In addition, these authors found that amino acids Y49Y50 in the acidic motif were essential for Us9 to promote transneuronal spread of infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	261	 By contrast, the phosphorylated S51S53 residues affected rate of viral spread, whereas the dileucine motif had no role in viral spread in the rat visual system (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Experiments in this report extend our understanding of these phenotypes.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Infection by PRV172 (Y49Y50 to AA), which has a Us9-null phenotype in vivo, also had a null phenotype after infection of cultured neurons: all viral membrane proteins tested were markedly reduced in axons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	264	 PRV173, an Us9 alanine substitution mutant with a partial loss-of-function phenotype in anterograde spread in animals also had an intermediate phenotype in cultured neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Finally, PRV166, which has no phenotype in vivo, is indistinguishable from wild-type infection of cultured neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	266	 We can now surmise for the first time why Us9-null mutants are defective in directional transneuronal spread: membrane proteins such as gB that are absolutely required for transneuronal spread (Babic et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	267	, 1993) do not enter axons in the absence of Us9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	268	How does Us9 promote localization of viral membrane proteins to axons? Us9 has no obvious homology to any protein or nucleic acid sequences in GenBank that might provide insight into how it functions.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	269	 However, the motifs identified by alanine substitution mutations discussed above suggest that Us9 may participate in recruiting cytoplasmic coat proteins, allowing the formation of vesicles destined for different subcellular locations (for review see Kirchhausen et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	270	, 1997; Schmid, 1997; Lewin and Mellman, 1998).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The deletion of a 10 amino acid highly conserved acidic motif (residues 46 to 56) region of Us9 blocks retrieval of Us9 from the plasma membrane to a compartment in or near the TGN, implicating this region in the recruitment of the adaptor protein AP-2 necessary for clathrin-dependent endocytosis.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	272	 This deletion mutation also removes two serines that are likely to be phosphorylated (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The cell adhesion molecule L1, the endoprotease furin, the mannose-6-phosphate receptor, and many other viral proteins have a YXX motif near an acidic cluster that contains serine residues capable of being phosphorylated by casein kinase I and II.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The trafficking of these proteins is regulated by casein kinase II phosphorylation and the tyrosine-based sorting signal (Trowbridge et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	275	The Y49Y50 motif and acidic domain are conserved throughout the known Us9 homologues in all -herpesviruses (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	276	 This YY motif is different from the YXX motif that classically has been shown to mediate interactions with adaptor proteins (Bonifacino and Dell'Angelica, 1999).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Nevertheless, given the phenotypes of the YY to AA mutants we suggest that the two tyrosines critical for Us9 function interact with particular cytoplasmic adaptor proteins necessary for the movement of vesicles between compartments of the cell.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	278	 There is a precedent for herpesviruses usurping adaptor-mediated targeting during infection: the PRV membrane protein gE has been shown to direct vesicles containing virions to the basolateral domain of polarized epithelial cells, and this sorting is dependent on the adaptor complex AP-1 (Johnson et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	279	 10) where viral membrane proteins achieve a steady-state localization in the trans-Golgi network or a post-Golgi compartment in the cell body.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Once in this compartment, viral membrane proteins are selectively incorporated into vesicles destined for the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	281	 In the simplest case, the presence of Us9 in the compartment recruits a neuron-specific adaptor complex that binds to Us9 via the dityrosine motif (for example, some forms of AP-3 are possible candidates) (Pevsner et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	282	, 1994), leading to the formation of transport vesicles carrying Us9 and other viral membrane proteins "coated" with the axonal adaptors.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Therefore, in the absence of Us9 vesicles, containing viral membrane proteins would not be directed to the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The cytoplasmic tails of other viral membrane proteins could still bind to other adaptor complexes, allowing vesiculation and transport to the cell surface or movement to compartments other than the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	285	 In this model, only one molecule in a transport vesicle need carry the cis-acting axonal sorting signal.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Such a "piggyback" model of axonal targeting of neuronal proteins has been proposed recently (Roos and Kelly, 2000).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Other proteins within the vesicle gain access to the axon simply by being in the same vesicle as the protein with the sorting signal.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	288	 We propose that Us9 represents such an axon-specific sorting molecule and that other viral membrane proteins are merely "cargo.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	289	" However, our observation that not all of the vesicles within the axon contain Us9 is noteworthy.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Perhaps only vesicles moving into the axon contain Us9, whereas the non-Us9 to containing vesicles enriched in the distal axon represent viral membrane proteins that have accumulated within an organelle (for example, an endosome).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Alternatively, Us9 may function in the cell body of the neuron to alter the trafficking patterns of viral membrane proteins.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	292	 We are in the process of testing these ideas.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	293	View larger version (24K):    Figure 10.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	294	 A model for Us9-dependent axonal sorting of viral membrane proteins.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Us9 is depicted as a white rectangle, and other viral membrane proteins are black "lollipops.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	296	" The adaptor complex AP-1 is shown as a hexagon, and AP-3 is shown as a star.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	297	 (A) The targeting of viral membrane proteins to the axon requires Us9.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	298	 A tyrosine-based cytoplasmic sorting signal in Us9 interacts with AP-3, allowing the formation of axonal transport vesicles coated with this adaptor complex.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Other viral membrane proteins are passive "cargo" that are targeted to the axon due to an association with Us9, not a cis-acting peptide sequence.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	300	 The cytoplasmic tails of other viral membrane proteins can still interact with other adaptor complexes in wild-type infections, allowing transport vesicles to traffic to other regions of the neuron in addition to the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	301	 (B) Without Us9, no axonal-sorting signal is present on the cytoplasmic tails of viral membrane proteins.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Vesicles still form but are no longer targeted to the axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The cytoplasmic tails of other viral membrane proteins still interact with other adaptor complexes, allowing transport vesicles to traffic to other regions of the neuron.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	304	  In summary, we find that virion assembly is intimately associated with directional spread of infection between neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	305	 It had been assumed that complete virus particles were assembled in the cell body and then moved into axons for long distance travel to axon terminals.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Our results support an alternative model proposed by Penfold et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	307	 (1994), whereby structural components of the virus are moved separately into the axons of infected neurons for later assembly.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Our genetic data indicate that the loss of a single gene, Us9, leads to a wholesale change in the subcellular localization in PNS neurons of all viral membrane proteins examined yet does not change the localization of capsid and tegument proteins.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Since viruses must subvert host processes during their replication, understanding how Us9 changes the polarity of viral membrane proteins during infection should reveal conserved neuronal proteins involved in axonal targeting and transport and may provide insight into the general mechanism of directional axonal transport.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Cell biologists have long relied on selected viral proteins to facilitate an understanding of intracellular trafficking and polarized protein delivery.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	311	 -Herpesviruses have evolved mechanisms to parasitize and coexist with neurons of a broad range of hosts, and they may offer new tools to probe the cellular and molecular mechanisms of polarized protein traffic in neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	312	   Materials and methods Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Virus strains and cells The Porcine kidney cell line PK15 and all viruses were grown and maintained as described previously (Whealy et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	313	 The laboratory strain of PRV used as the wildtype and parent for all virus constructions was PRV-Becker (Card et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	314	 The isogenic mutants PRV 160 (Us9-null), PRV 166 (L30L31 to AA), PRV 172 (Y49Y50 to AA), and PRV 173 (S51S53 to AA) have been described (see Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	315	 1 for amino acid sequence of Us9 and location of the alanine substitution mutations) (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	316	 PRV 91 (gE-null) has been described (Whealy et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	317	 PRV 160R is a revertant of PRV 160 that restores all tested wild-type virus phenotypes (Brideau et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	318	 In this study, PRV 160R and PRV-Becker were also indistinguishable.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	319	 PRV-GS443 was constructed by G.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	320	, 2001) and expresses a hybrid protein comprising the GFP fused to the capsid protein VP26.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	321	 PRV 368 carries both the Us9-null mutation from PRV 160 and the GFP to UL35 hybrid gene from PRV-GS443 replacing the UL35 gene.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	322	 It was constructed by recombination between PRV 160 and PRV-GS443.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	323	 The replication-defective herpes simplex virus vector that expresses the axonal chicken protein NgCAM was a gift from G.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Banker and has been described previously (Jareb and Banker, 1998).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	325	Antibodies The polyclonal rabbit antiserum recognizing gE (Rb 501) and the polyclonal goat antisera recognizing gB (Ab284) and gC (Ab282) have been described (Whealy et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	326	, 1993; Tirabassi and Enquist, 2000).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The monoclonal antibody IN-13 recognizing the major capsid protein VP5 was a gift from H.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Rziha (Federal Research Centre for Virus Diseases of Animals, Tubingen, Germany).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	329	 The monoclonal antibody recognizing VP22 was a gift from T.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Mettenleiter (Federal Research Centre for Virus Diseases of Animals, Insel Riems, Germany).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	331	 The polyclonal mouse antiserum recognizing the tegument protein UL25 was a gift from A.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Flamand (Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Gif-sur Yvette, France).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	333	 The monoclonal antibody recognizing GFP was purchased from Molecular Probes.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	334	 The monoclonal antibody 8D9 recognizing the chick adhesion molecule NgCAM was a gift from G.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Banker (Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, OR).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	336	Neuronal culture Rat sympathetic neurons from the SCG of rat embryos (15 to 16 d gestation) were dissociated according to the methods of DiCicco-Bloom et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	337	 35-mm plastic dishes (353001; Falcon) were coated with 100  microg/ml poly-D-lysine (P-6407; Sigma-Aldrich) in tissue culture grade water (W-3500; Sigma-Aldrich).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Approximately 80,000 neurons per dish were plated.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Cultures were maintained in 50% Ham's F-12 medium (11765-054; GIBCO BRL) and 50% DME (11965-084; GIBCO BRL) supplemented with 10 mg/ml BSA (A-2153; Sigma-Aldrich), 10  microg/ml insulin (I-6634; Sigma-Aldrich), 100  microg/ml transferrin (616397; Calbiochem), 100  microM putrescine (P-7505; Sigma-Aldrich), 20 nM progesterone (P-6149; Sigma-Aldrich), 30 nM selenium (S-5261; Sigma-Aldrich), 2 mM glutamine (15039-027; GIBCO BRL), 6 mg/ml glucose (4912; Mallinckrodt), 50  microg/ml penicillin and 50  microg/ml streptomycin (15140-122; GIBCO BRL), and 100 ng/ml NGF 2.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Culture medium was replaced three times per week and was equilibrated for 1 h in a 37 degrees C 5% CO2 incubator before use.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Cytosine-ss-D-arabino-furanoside (C-6645; Sigma-Aldrich) was added to 2  microM from days 2 to 3 and 5 to 6 to eliminate dividing cells.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	342	 Experimental protocols were approved by the Animal Welfare Committee at Princeton University and were consistent with the regulations of the American Association for Accredition of Laboratory Animal Care and those in the Animal Welfare Act (public law 99-198).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	343	Expression of cellular proteins during PRV infection Neurons were cultured in 35-mm plastic dishes for at least 3 wk as described above.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	344	 30  microl of replication-defective herpes simplex virus vectors were added directly to the neuronal culture medium for 1 h (Jareb and Banker, 1998).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	345	 After this incubation, this medium was removed, and medium containing PRV-Becker (wild-type) or PRV 160 (Us9-null virus) was placed on the neurons at a concentration of virus that permits infection of all neurons in a culture (see below).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	346	 After 1 h, the PRV-containing medium was removed, and the original medium containing the replication-defective virus was placed back on the neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	347	 16 h after PRV infection, the neurons were fixed, and NgCAM expressed from the viral vector was visualized using an antibody that recognizes only the chicken protein (NgCAM) and not the rat orthologue.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	348	Indirect immunofluorescence microscopy Neurons were cultured in 35-mm plastic dishes for 3 wk as described above.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	349	 At this time, the axonal network was extensive.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	350	 Two concentrations of virus inoculum were used: a low multiplicity of infection such that 10% of the cells were infected and a high multiplicity of infection such that almost all neurons were infected.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	351	 We found that the majority of the input virions bound directly to the tissue culture dish and never came into contact with the cultured neurons (unpublished data).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Therefore, precise calculations of the multiplicity of infection are difficult.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	353	 After 1 h, the inoculum was removed by aspiration and replaced with the original culture medium that had been incubated at 37 degrees C.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	354	 At various times after infection, neurons were rinsed with PBS, fixed with 3.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	355	2% paraformaldehyde, and then rinsed three times with PBS.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	356	 The neurons were permeabilized for 3 min in PBS containing 3% BSA and 0.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	357	 In all subsequent manipulations, PBS containing 3% BSA and 0.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	358	5% saponin is included in the solutions.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Fixed cells were then incubated with the appropriate primary antibody for 1 h in a humidified chamber at 37 degrees C.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	360	 The dishes were rinsed three times with PBS/BSA/saponin and incubated with Alexa 488 to  or Alexa 568 to conjugated secondary antibodies (Molecular Probes) for 1 h in a humidified chamber at 37 degrees C.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	361	 Finally, the dishes were rinsed three times with PBS/BSA/saponin and once with distilled water.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	362	 A drop of Vectashield mounting medium (H 1000; Vector Laboratories) was placed in the floor of the dish, and then a coverslip was placed on the Vectashield and sealed with nail polish.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	363	Experiments examining the cell surface localization of proteins were performed as follows: after infection, antibodies were diluted in a small volume of neuron culture medium (600  microl per 35-mm dish), and this was placed on the infected neurons for 5 min at 37 degrees C, and then the neurons were rinsed once with PBS and fixed for 10 min in 3.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	364	 After fixation, the neurons were rinsed with PBS three times and were incubated in 3% BSA in PBS overnight.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Secondary antibodies were diluted in 3% BSA in PBS and were incubated with the fixed neurons for 1 h.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Finally, the neurons were processed as described above.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	367	Low multiplicity infections were useful as the large number of uninfected neurons provided internal controls for nonspecific antibody binding.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Low multiplicity infections also enabled us to locate and follow the long axons from single infected cell bodies.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	369	 High multiplicity infections confirmed that phenotypes were uniform throughout all neurons in the culture.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	370	 Unless otherwise indicated, all times after infection are based on low multiplicity infections.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	371	Single optical sections were captured using a Nikon Optiphot-2 microscope equipped with a Bio-Rad Laboratories MRC600 scan head.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Images were processed with Adobe Photoshop  (version 4.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	373	Determining polarity of cultured neurons: targeting and retention of control cytoskeletal components to cell bodies and axons Many types of neurons can not sort their proteins to axonal or dendritic compartments until at least 2 wk of growth in vitro (Caceres et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	374	 Rat sympathetic neurons derived from the SCG are reported to sort endogenous proteins to axonal and somatodendritic compartments after 3 wk in vitro (Bruckenstein and Higgins, 1988).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	375	 The polarity of cultured neurons used in this report was determined by analysis of three control proteins: (a) the axonal markers tau-1 (Boehringer) and SMI-31 (Sternberger-Meyer Immunochemicals), and (b) the cell body/dendrite markers MAP2 (Boehringer) and SMI-32 (Sternberger-Meyer Immunochemicals).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	376	 The antibody SMI-31 recognizes the phosphoforms of the M and H neurofilament, whereas the antibody SMI-32 reacts with the nonphosphoforms of the M and H neurofilament (Sternberger and Sternberger, 1983).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Since neuronal cell bodies are raised as much as 20  microm from the floor of the tissue culture dish where the axons grow, two different image planes are shown in Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	378	 11, D to K : the top panels (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	379	 11, D to G) show an image plane at the center of the cell bodies (above the substratum), whereas the bottom panels (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	380	 11, H to K) have the image plane at the substratum where the neurites can be visualized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	381	View larger version (124K):    Figure 11.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Characterization of cultured SCG neurons.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Phase to contrast images of neurons after 3 h (A), 5 d (B), or 21 d (C) in culture.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	384	 The establishment of cell polarity of SCG neurons after 21 d in culture is demonstrated in D to K.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	385	 After fixing and permeabilizing, the neurons were labeled with antibodies that recognized the axonal markers tau-1 (D and H) and phospho-M and H neurofilament (E and I) or the somatodendritic markers MAP2 (F and J) and nonphospho-M and H neurofilament (G and K).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Two confocal images of each field are shown: D to G have image planes at the level of the cell bodies, whereas H to K show the same neuron at the level of the substratum so that axons can be visualized.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	387	  The axonal marker tau-1 was found in nearly all neurites examined in the cultures.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	388	 Faint immunoreactivity was found within cell bodies of neurons (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	389	 11 D), but most of the staining was confined to the neurites (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	390	 Similar neurite localization was seen with the second axonal marker, SMI-31 (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	391	 The cell body/dendrite marker MAP2 (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	392	 11, F and J) localized mainly to the cell body.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Some immunoreactivity was also found in a proximal-to-distal gradient within the neurites with the strongest immunoreactivity in the proximal axon.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	394	 The same was true for the second cell body/dendrite marker SMI-32 (Fig.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	395	 However, the extent of proximal axon staining with SMI-32 was not as pronounced as the MAP2 staining pattern.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	396	 These data are consistent with previously published studies on the polarity of this culture system (Peng et al.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	397	, 1986; Bruckenstein and Higgins, 1988).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	398	Kinetics of infectious PRV production in SCG neurons The embryonic ganglia from a pregnant rat were pooled and dissociated, and the SCG neurons resulting from that preparation were plated into a 24-well dish (2,500 neurons per well).
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	399	 We determined empirically that 250,000 plaque-forming units (as determined on PK15 cells) were required in each well to infect all neurons in the culture.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	400	 Added virus was incubated with neurons for 1 h to facilitate attachment of virus to cells.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	401	 The inoculum was then removed and fresh medium added.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	402	 The supernatant and neurons were collected at 1, 8, 16, and 24 h after infection.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Each time after infection was assayed in triplicate, and the quantitation of infectious virus in each sample was determined on PK15 cells.
0.16384977.11502759.html.plaintext.txt	404	   Footnotes   * Abbreviations used in this paper: GFP, green fluorescent protein; NgCAM, neural glycoprotein cell adhesion molecule; PNS, peripheral nervous system; PRV, pseudorabies virus; SCG, superior cervical ganglia.
