0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	363	 226, 1063 to 1069[Abstract] Prince, S.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	364	 268, 412 to 423[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve].
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	0	Overlapping reading frames in closely related human papillomaviruses result in modular rates of selection within E2 Apurva Narechania1, Masanori Terai1 and Robert D.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Department of Microbiology and Immunology, The Albert Einstein Cancer Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461, USA 2 Department of Pediatrics, The Albert Einstein Cancer Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461, USA 3 Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health, The Albert Einstein Cancer Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461, USA 4 Department of Epidemiology and Population Health, The Albert Einstein Cancer Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461, USA.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	2	   ABSTRACT Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   A core group of four open reading frames (ORFs) is present in all known papillomaviruses (PVs): the E1 and E2 replication/transcription proteins and the L1 and L2 structural proteins.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Because they are involved in processes that are essential to PV propagation, the sequences of these proteins are well-conserved.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	4	 However, sequencing of novel subtypes for human papillomaviruses (HPV) 54 (AE9) and 82 (AE2/IS39), coupled to analysis of four other closely related genital HPV pairs, indicated that E2 has a higher dN/dS ratio than E1, L1 or L2.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The elevated ratio is not homogeneous across the length of the ORF, but instead varies with respect to E2's three domains.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The E2 hinge region is of particular interest, because its hypervariability (dN/dS > 1) differs markedly from the two domains that it joins: the transcription-activation domain and the DNA-binding domain.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Deciphering whether the hinge region's high rate of non-synonymous change is the result of positive Darwinian selection or relaxed constraint depends on the evolutionary behaviour of E4, an ORF that overlaps E2.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The E2 hinge region is contained within E4 and non-synonymous changes in the hinge are associated with a disproportionate amount of synonymous change in E4, a case of simultaneous positive and purifying selection in overlapping reading frames.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Modular rates of selection among E2 domains are a likely consequence of the presence of an embedded E4.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	10	 E4 appears to be positioned in a part of the HPV genome that can tolerate non-synonymous change and purifying selection of E4 may be indicative of its functional importance.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	11	The GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ accession numbers for the sequences reported in this work are AF436129 (HPV54A) and AF293961 (HPV82A).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	12	   INTRODUCTION Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) include a group of closed-circular, double-stranded DNA viruses established as the aetiological agents of cervical neoplasia and invasive cervical cancer (Bosch  and  de Sanjose, 2003; Munoz et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Over 100 putative HPVs have been described, more than 90 of which have been cloned and officially designated (de Villiers et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Despite an array of types, the development of cervical carcinoma is restricted to a subset of high-risk viruses, of which HPV16 and HPV18 together account for nearly two-thirds of observed cases (Munoz et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Classification of HPV types into categories, such as  cancer-causing  and  non-cancer-causing  or cutaneous and mucosal, is based on both epidemiological and phylogenetic studies (Chan et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	16	, 1995; Pfister  and  Fuchs, 1994; Van Ranst et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Most oncogenic types share a common ancestor and most common ancestors radiate within an ecological niche, such as the skin or mucosa.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	18	The typical HPV genome contains six open reading frames (ORFs) encoding the structural proteins (L1 and L2), proteins that mediate the viral life cycle (E1 and E2) and proteins that regulate host-cell DNA replication and transformation (E6 and E7) (Knipe et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	19	 E6 and E7 bind the cell-cycle regulators p53 and pRb, respectively.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Among highly cancerous types, these oncogenes degrade p53 and pRb, resulting in host-cell immortalization and proliferation (reviewed by Fehrmann  and  Laimins, 2003).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Some papillomaviruses (PVs) also encode the E4 and E5 genes, whose roles, although largely unknown, seem to involve functions in the later phases of the viral life cycle (Longworth  and  Laimins, 2004; Peh et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The E5 ORF is situated between E2 and L2 in typical PV genomes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In most cases, E5 does not overlap with any of its neighbours; however, the E4 ORF is contained completely within E2.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	24	A great deal of effort has been spent studying the evolutionary implications of overlapping reading frames in viruses (Hein  and  Stovlbaek, 1995; Krakauer, 2000; Miyata  and  Yasunaga, 1978).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	25	 A fundamental question is how natural selection operates on two protein sequences encoded by the same stretch of DNA.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We address this question in the context of HPV E2 and E4, highlighting rates of synonymous and non-synonymous substitution in overlapping reading frames.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	27	 To this end, we utilized two recently cloned and sequenced viral isolates, HPV AE2/IS39 and HPV AE9.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Although initially thought to be novel types (10 % variance in L1 nucleotide sequences) based on sequence analysis of the MY09/MY11 region of the L1 ORF, upon analysis of their complete genomes, HPV AE2/IS39 and HPV AE9 were found to be subtypes (2 to 10 % variance in L1 sequences) of HPV82 and HPV54, respectively.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In this report, we examine rates of evolution of each ORF by using dN/dS ratios across these subtype pairs and other closely related mucosal types.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Closely related genomes allow examination of evolutionary change prior to saturation of genetic changes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	31	 We focus specifically on the modular rates of selection exhibited by E2 and a possible explanation for this modularity, in the overlapping ORF, E4.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	32	   METHODS Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   A cervicovaginal sample containing HPV AE2/IS39 (HPV82 subtype) originated from a white, 22-year-old female with persistent stage 1 cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, and a sample containing HPV AE9 (HPV54 subtype) was obtained from a white, 19-year-old female with normal cervical cytology.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	33	 HPV AE2/IS39- and HPV AE9-containing samples were originally detected by MY09/MY11 PCR and dot-blot analyses, as described previously (Tachezy et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	34	, 1994; Terai  and  Burk, 2002).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	35	To clone the potentially novel genomes, PCR primers were designed by alignment of closely related HPV genomes using the sequences of the partial L1 region amplified by MY09/MY11 primers.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Additional primers were used to amplify the entire genome in fragments by using overlapping PCR amplification, as described previously (Terai  and  Burk, 2002).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	37	 PCR products were separated by agarose-gel electrophoresis, stained with ethidium bromide and visualized under UV illumination.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	38	 After confirmation of appropriate product sizes, each PCR product was purified (Qiagen gel-extraction kit) and ligated into the pGEM-T Easy vector (Promega) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Initially, SP6 and T7 primers flanking each HPV DNA insert were used to determine the nucleotide sequence.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Additional primers were designed by sequence walking.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Sequencing was performed in the Albert Einstein Cancer Center DNA-sequencing facility.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Overlapping fragments were assembled manually and several additional primers were used to clarify sequence ambiguities.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The primer sequences used are available from the authors on request.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	44	Pairwise sequence alignments were performed by using CLUSTAL W (Thompson et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	45	, 1994) with a gap cost of 10 0 and the IUB weight matrix.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Multiple sequence alignments, providing prototype and subtype phylogenetic context, were generated in the same way.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Calculation of overall, ORF-wide non-synonymous and synonymous changes and rates of non-synonymous and synonymous change were done by using SNAP (Synonymous/Non-synonymous Analysis Program) (Korber, 2002; Nei  and  Gojobori, 1986) and K-Estimator was used to perform sliding-window analysis of dN/dS (Comeron, 1999).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	48	Phylogenetic trees were constructed in PAUP (version 4.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	49	10) (Swofford, 1998) from multiple sequence alignments of the E6, E7, E1, E2, L2 and L1 concatenated ORFs, using both distance (neighbour-joining) and parsimony methods.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Alignment gaps were coded as missing before distance and parsimony trees were reconstructed by using equal-weighted characters and 100 bootstrap replicates.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	51	 To ensure adequate searches in the tree space, 100 random-addition heuristic searches and TBR (tree bisection and reconnection) swapping were employed.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	52	HPVs used in this study and their GenBank accession numbers are as follows: HPV7 (NC_001595), HPV11 (NC_001525), HPV27 (NC_001584), HPV40 (NC_001589), HPV44 (NC_001689), HPV54 (NC_001676), HPV55 (NC_001692), HPV82 (NC_002172), HPV13 (NC_001349), HPV26 (NC_001583), HPV30 (NC_001585), HPV32 (NC_001586), HPV42 (NC_001534), HPV51 (NC_001533), HPV53 (NC_001593), HPV56 (NC_001594), HPV66 (NC_001695), HPV69 (NC_002171), HPV74 (NC_004501), HPV91 (NC_004085), HPV54A (AF436129) and HPV82A (AF293961).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	53	   RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   The genomes of HPV AE2/IS39 (abbreviated as HPV82A) and HPV AE9 (abbreviated as HPV54A) were each amplified and cloned as three overlapping PCR fragments.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	54	 For HPV82A, these fragments measured 3 8, 3 9 and 0 5 kb, and for HPV54A, 4 3, 3 6 and 0 5 kb.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The complete genome sequences are available from GenBank under the accession numbers AF436129 (HPV54A) and AF293961 (HPV82A).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	56	The genomes of HPV54A and HPV82A share a high level of similarity with their prototypes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	57	 A comparison of whole genomes reveals 93 5 % nucleic acid similarity between HPV54 and HPV54A, and 89 8 % similarity between HPV82 and HPV82A.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The currently accepted criterion for HPV classification relies on comparison of L1 nucleotide ORFs.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The L1 ORF in the HPV54 pair diverges by 4 6 %, whilst the HPV82 pair diverges by 7 7 %, placing both isolates within the subtype range.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	60	As expected, subtype and prototype genome lengths are also comparable.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	61	 HPV82 and HPV82A are 7871 and 7904 bp, respectively, whilst HPV54 and HPV54A are 7759 and 7717 bp in length.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Each pair contains the anticipated PV ORFs, including the E6 and E7 proteins, the replication proteins (E1 and E2) and components of the viral capsid (L1 and L2).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The only major difference in genomic architecture across the two pairs is HPV54's lack of an E5 homologue.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	64	 HPV82 contains an unambiguous E5 ORF, but lacks a proximal start codon, whereas the corresponding genomic region in HPV54 is as variable as some sections of its upstream regulatory region.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Lack of evidence for E5 in HPV54 reinforces its status as a unique outlier, rooting members of the -PV species clades 1, 8 and 10 (Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	66	 1), all of which contain an intact E5 ORF.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The identification of an HPV54 subtype implies that this ancient part of the tree still appears to be evolving.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	68	 In their greater phylogenetic context, HPV82A and HPV54A sort into species groups 5 and 13, respectively.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	69	 This evolutionary relationship held in phylogenies constructed from either the concatenated ORFs or L1 nucleotide sequences alone (data not shown) (Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	70	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Phylogenetic trees constructed by using maximum-parsimony and distance methods resulted in identical topologies.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Representative cladograms of (a) HPV82 and its taxonomic context and (b) HPV54 and its taxonomic context are shown.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Both trees were based on the alignment of the nucleotide sequences of compiled ORFs (E6, E7, E1, E2, L2 and L1) of the indicated PV genomes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Bootstrap values for the parsimony calculation are provided at all nodes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Numbers to the right indicate the taxonomic species group of the -PVs (de Villiers et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	76	  The distribution of polymorphisms across each ORF within HPV54 and HPV82 is shown in Table 1, accompanied by four closely related genital HPV pairs.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The subtypes HPV44 and HPV55 and the sister taxa HPV6 and HPV11, HPV7 and HPV40, and HPV2 and HPV27 were chosen because they all exhibit whole-genome divergence of  < 15 %.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	78	 These closely related pairs allow unambiguous alignment and are less likely to be subject to saturation of genetic variation.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	79	 To examine the possibility of directional selection, we calculated the ratio of non-synonymous substitutions per non-synonymous site (dN) to synonymous substitutions per synonymous site (dS).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	80	 A dN/dS ratio equal to 1 indicates neutrality, a ratio  < 1 indicates purifying selection and a ratio  > 1 indicates positive Darwinian selection (Yang, 1998).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Overall, the small ratios of non-synonymous to synonymous changes and dN/dS values indicate that E1, L1 and L2 are under strong purifying selection, forming a functional core essential to the viral life cycle.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Previously, we had also included E2 in this group because of its presence in all known PVs and its role in viral-genome replication (Narechania et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	83	 However, in the current analysis, a remarkably consistent pattern of elevated non-synonymous E2 variation was observed, a pattern more in line with the values seen for the E6/E7 ORFs than the stable core E1, L1 and L2 ORFs.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The median E2 dN/dS value (0 31) was significantly different from that of the E1/L1/L2 group (0 09) (Mann to Whitney P < 0 0004) (Siegel, 1956).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	85	All values were calculated with SNAP as described by Korber (2000).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	86	  Much of E2's variation is attributable to the hinge region connecting the transcription activation domain (TAD) to the DNA-binding domain (DBD) (Table 2; Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	87	 In all cases except for the HPV54 pair, the hinge region did not manifest the purifying selection that constrains the rest of the E2 ORF (dN/dS median, 1 11).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	88	 HPV16 variant genomes also showed elevated dN/dS ratios in the E2 hinge region (Z.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The TAD and DBD regions display intermediate median dN/dS values (0 18), lower than that for the hinge, but significantly higher than that observed for E1, L1 or L2 (Mann to Whitney P < 0 002).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	90	 This pattern holds in all cases except for the HPV54 pair.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Aside from a low hinge dN/dS and a high TAD dN/dS, the HPV54 pair also exhibits relatively high E1 and L1 dN/dS ratios, again highlighting its status as a unique outlier of species clades 1, 8 and 10.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Although relatively elevated E2 dN/dS values are a trend that is consistent across all analysed pairs, there are many functional protein motifs that are conserved across all types.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	93	 For example, the -1 recognition helix in the E2 DBD is well-conserved across all types used in the current study, as are the cognate DBD sites (ACCgNNNNcGGT) in the long control region (reviewed by Hegde, 2002).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	94	All values were calculated with SNAP as described by Korber (2000).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	95	  View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Distributions of nucleotide and amino acid changes within the E2 ORF.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	97	 (a) HPV54 and HPV54A; (b) HPV82 and HPV82A.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Positions of the three functional domains of E2 (TAD, the hinge and DBD) are delimited along the horizontal axis in white, black and grey, respectively.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	99	 These positions were derived by alignment to HPV18 E2 (Hegde, 2002).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Vertical lines above the horizontal axis indicate non-synonymous changes (i.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	101	 amino acid changes), whereas those below the axis correspond to synonymous changes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The height of the vertical lines both above and below the horizontal axis represents the number of non-synonymous and synonymous changes per codon, respectively.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	103	  The most compelling observations in the current analysis were the high overall dN/dS ratio of E2 and the concentration of non-synonymous changes in the hinge region of this ORF.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	104	 E2 is unique in the PV genome in that it is the only ORF that completely contains another (in this case, E4).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Moreover, E4 frames the hinge region completely in all pairs analysed (for two examples, see Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	106	 In each sliding-window analysis, except for HPV54 where little time has apparently passed since subtype divergence, non-synonymous changes dominate the E2 reading frame, whereas E4 favours synonymous changes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	107	 This observation is at odds with the prevailing notion concerning overlapping genes  to  that severe evolutionary constraint should operate on nucleotide sequences encoding two layers of protein in the dense genetic environment of viruses (Mizokami et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	108	, 1997; Pavesi, 2000; Pavesi et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	109	 For overlapping genes, codon changes at the third position in one reading frame are unusual, because they result in changes in the second position of the +1 reading frame.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	110	 However, what we see here is a pattern of E4 purifying selection superimposed on the E2 hinge, the one domain that can physically accommodate high levels of non-synonymous change.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The relaxed constraint observed for the hinge is therefore attributable to both its role as a flexible connector between the functionally conserved TAD and DBD domains and the existence of the overlapping E4 reading frame.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	112	 In PVs with no evidence of an E4 ORF, we might expect this phenomenon to disappear.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	113	 However, to our knowledge, all PVs contain an E4-like ORF except for the two avian PVs that have been characterized to date: Psittacus erithacus papillomavirus (PePV) and Fringilla coelebs papillomavirus (FPV) (Terai et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	114	 An alignment of PePV and FPV E2 ORFs yielded only 52 % identity.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	115	 At this level of divergence, saturation becomes a problem and a satisfactory dN/dS analysis could not be performed.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	116	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Sliding-window traces of rates of synonymous (dS, dashed line) and non-synonymous (dN, solid line) change in the overlapping E2 hinge and E4 reading frames.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The analysis employed a 100 nt window sliding 10 positions at a time, registering the dN and dS values at the centre position (i.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	119	 in a 100 nt window, the centre position would be 50 5 bp).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Lines below the horizontal axis delimit the position of the E2 hinge within a particular trace.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Plots shown include pairwise alignments between HPV44 and HPV55 in the E2 reading frame (top left) and the E4 reading frame (bottom left), and alignments between HPV2 and HPV27 in the E2 (top right) and E4 (bottom right) reading frames.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	122	  Despite the claim that constraint should be the rule in overlapping reading frames, more recent reports indicate that some viral genomes demonstrate simultaneous positive and purifying selection.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Simian immunodeficiency virus (Hughes et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	124	, 2001), potato leafroll virus (Guyader  and  Ducray, 2002) and Sendai virus (Fujii et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	125	, 2001) all show increased non-synonymous change in one ORF with concurrent dominance of synonymous change in an overlapping reading frame.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	126	 We suggest that the modularity displayed in the E2 dN/dS profile is a probable consequence of the presence of the E4 overlapping reading frame, and that the E2 hinge is the ideal genomic position in which to fix an overlapping gene.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	127	 As E4 is subject to purifying selection relative to the E2 hinge in all tested cases and there is evidence of an E4 ORF in all mammalian PVs, this ORF may have greater functional importance than thought previously.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	128	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   This work was supported in part by a grant from the National Cancer Institute, National Institutes of Health to R.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	129	   REFERENCES Top ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Bosch, F.
