0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Likelihood ratio tests for detecting positive selection and application to primate lysozyme evolution.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	180	Received 5 November 2004; accepted 8 February 2005.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	0	Specificity Determinants for the Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Component Reaction Mapped with Mutated and Prosthetic Group Modified Lipoyl Domains* Xiaoming Gong, Tao Peng, Alexander Yakhnin, Michal Zolkiewski, Janet Quinn  , Stephen J.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	1	From  Department of Biochemistry, Kansas State University, Manhattan, Kansas 66506 and the   Department of Biochemistry and Genetics, The Medical School, University of Newcastle, Newcastle Upon Tyne NE2 4HH, United Kingdom.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	3	Efficient catalysis in the second step of the pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) component reaction requires a lipoyl group to be attached to a lipoyl domain that displays appropriately positioned specificity residues.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	4	 As substrates, the human dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase provides an N-terminal (L1) and an inner (L2) lipoyl domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We evaluated the specificity requirements for the E1 reaction with 27 mutant L2 (including four substitutions for the lipoylated lysine, Lys173), with three analogs substituted for the lipoyl group on Lys173, and with selected L1 mutants.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Besides Lys173 mutants, only E170Q mutation prevented lipoylation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Based on analysis of the structural stability of mutants by differential scanning calorimetry, alanine substitutions of residues with aromatic side chains in terminal regions outside the folded portion of the L2 domain significantly decreased the stability of mutant L2, suggesting specific interactions of these terminal regions with the folded domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	8	 E1 reaction rates were markedly reduced by the following substitutions in the L2 domain (equivalent site-L1): L140A, S141A (S14A-L1), T143A, E162A, D172N, and E179A (E52A-L1).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	9	 These mutants gave diverse changes in kinetic parameters.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	10	 These residues are spread over  > 24 A on one side of the L2 structure, supporting extensive contact between E1 and L2 domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Alignment of over 40 lipoyl domain sequences supports Ser141, Thr143, and Glu179 serving as specificity residues for use by E1 from eukaryotic sources.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Extensive interactions of the lipoyl-lysine prosthetic group within the active site are supported by the limited inhibition of E1 acetylation of native L2 by L2 domains altered either by mutation of Lys173 or enzymatic addition of lipoate analogs to Lys173.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Thus, efficient use by mammalian E1 of cognate lipoyl domains derives from unique surface residues with critical interactions contributed by the universal lipoyl-lysine prosthetic group, key specificity residues, and some conserved residues, particularly Asp172 adjacent to Lys173.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	14	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	15	The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC)1 oxidatively decarboxylates pyruvate with the production of acetyl-CoA and NADH.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The PDC reaction results from the sequential catalysis by the pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1), the dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2), and the dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3) components.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In the intermediate steps, the lipoyl groups on mobile lipoyl domains of the E2 are reductively acetylated by E1, de-acetylated by E2, and re-oxidized by E3.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Thus, lipoyl domains play a vital role in connecting the sequential series of reaction catalyzed by these three components.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In mammalian PDC, two lipoyl domains, L1 and L2, and an E1-binding domain are provided in the outer structure of the E2 (1, 2).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	20	 These flexibly held domains surround a pentagonal dodecahedron shaped inner core formed by association of 60 C-terminal catalytic domains of E2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The capacity of lipoyl domains to rapidly move between active sites is provided by highly flexible inter-domain linker segments which are located between the globular domains of E2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In mammalian PDC-E2 these linker regions are 20 to 30 amino acids in length and are high in alanine and proline residues; prolines introduce stiffness in these interdomain segments (3).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Mammalian PDC has a third lipoyl domain on an E3-binding protein (E3BP) which has a similar segmented structure (1).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	24	In the first step of the E1 reaction, the bound thiamin diphosphate (TPP) forms an adduct with pyruvate which is rapidly decarboxylated to generate 2-(1-hydroxyethylidene)-TPP (HE-TPP) (4).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In the second step, reductive acetylation of a lipoyl group is achieved by linking the oxidation of the hydroxyethylidene group to the reduction of the disulfide in the dithiolane ring of the lipoyl group.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	26	 By either a concerted or sequential mechanism, the acetyl group is introduced onto the thiol formed at the 8-position of the lipoyl group.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The E1 reaction proceeds with high efficiency only with a lipoyl domain substrate.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Known model reactions, coupled or not coupled to artificial electron acceptors, proceed slowly and free lipoate, lipoamide, or lipoyl-lysine are particularly poor acceptors (3).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	29	2 Consistent with the standard two-step mechanism described above, Liu et al.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	30	2 have established by steady state kinetic analyses that rapid E1 catalysis, using natural lipoyl domain substrates, proceeds by a ping-pong reaction sequence.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	31	Thus, the lipoyl domain makes critical contributions to rapid E1 catalysis.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Furthermore, a set of specificity residues in the lipoyl domain structure is required to allow an E1 source to use its cognate lipoyl domains and not use lipoyl domains from other complexes.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In the case of mammalian PDC, this specific molecular recognition by the E1 component must exclude using the lipoyl domains provided by other mitochondrial systems: the -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, the branched chain -keto acid dehydrogenase complex, and the glycine cleavage enzyme.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In marked contrast, the lipoyl domains of all of these multienzyme systems are substrates for a common E3 component which catalyzes the reversible conversion of each of their reduced lipoyl groups to the disulfide form coupled to the reduction of NAD+ (1, 5, 6).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	35	Studies using bacterial PDC E1 and various lipoyl domain sources have delineated structural features of the lipoyl domains that contribute to specific recognition (7, 8).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The first loop in the lipoyl domain structures, which is located adjacent to the lipoyl prosthetic group, was shown to contribute to reaction specificity (8-10).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	37	 These studies have focused on residues fairly close to the lipoyl group and have provided limited insights into the relative importance of interactions of the prosthetic group and the lipoyl domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Despite the high specificity of an E1 for its cognate lipoyl domain, only weak interactions between E1 and its lipoyl domain substrate have been detected (11).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	39	2 Indeed, dissociation constants for E1-lipoyl domain interactions appear to be much higher than the Km of E1 for lipoyl domain substrates.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	40	 A weak interaction is probably a desirable feature for sustaining high efficiency since the flexibly held lipoyl domains are concentrated in mammalian PDC at  > 1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	41	0 mM (12, 13) next to E1 and should, therefore, efficiently ferry lipoyl groups into the active site of E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	42	The recent crystal structure of the Pseudomonas putida branched chain -keto acid dehydrogenase, also an 22 tetramer, show that the active site is a long funnel requiring the full reach of the lipoyl lysine prosthetic group (14).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Consistent with specificity determining interactions being provided by specific interactions between E1 and the cognate lipoyl domains of a particular complex, it was predicted that the lipoyl domain would need to be positioned close to the surface of the E1 for the reaction to proceed.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Similar requirements for the lipoyl-lysine cofactor to use its length in reaching into deep active sites also formed at subunit interfaces in the E2 (15, 16) and E3 (17) oligomers indicate the extended length of this cofactor is needed to directly support the three catalytic reactions and that the connecting linker regions provide the capacity for movement of the lipoyl domains between active sites (14, 18).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	45	We have used two approaches to evaluate the structural features of the lipoyl domain of human PDC-E2 that contribute to the specificity and efficiency of the reductive acetylation reaction catalyzed by mammalian E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	46	 First, we have compared the capacity of mutated human E2 lipoyl domains to serve as substrates in the E1 reaction to determine key specificity residues and other residues important for catalysis.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Mutation of putative specificity residues in the L2 domain was guided by the three-dimensional structure of this domain determined by NMR spectroscopy (19).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Second, to evaluate the contribution of the lipoyl prosthetic group to interactions with E1, we have evaluated the competitive inhibition versus the native domain of lipoyl domains modified at the lysyl-lipoyl prosthetic group either by replacing the lysine with other amino acids or by substituting nonreactive lipoyl analogs onto the lysine side chain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Our studies support extensive interactions between E1 and both the lipoyl domain and the lipoyl-lysine prosthetic group.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	50	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	51	Materials-- Bovine kidney E1 was prepared as described previously from the purified kidney PDC (20, 21).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	52	 As will be described in detail elsewhere,3 human E1 was prepared by restructuring the preparation of Korotchkina et al.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	53	 (22) so that His-tag could be removed by treatment with Precision Protease and changing the purification procedure to eliminate a contaminant.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The sodium salt of [2-14C]pyruvate purchased from NEN Life Science Products Inc.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	55	 was quantified by measuring the extent of NADH formed (pyruvate limiting) using the overall PDC reaction and liquid scintillation counting and further analyzed by separation on AMINEX ion exclusion HPX87H column (Bio-Rad) with isocratic elution using 5 mM H2SO4 with continuous monitoring radioactivity using a PACKARD TRACE 7140.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	56	 [2-14C]Pyruvate preparations gave a single peak; different preparations had specific radioactivities of 20.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Oligonucleotides were purchased from Oligos Etc.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	58	 or synthesized on an Applied Biosystems 381A DNA synthesizer.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Pfu polymerase was from Stratagene.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	60	Preparation and Evaluation of Lipoyl Domain Constructs-- Expression conditions (23, 24) were compared and modified as described under "Results.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	61	" Optimal expression of GST-lipoyl domain constructs was obtained with the host Escherichia coli BL21 grown at 37  degrees C to 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	62	9 absorbance at 600 nm followed by induction with 1 mM isopropyl-1-thio--D-galactopyranoside and expression at 22-24  degrees C for 6 h.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Prior to preparation of mutated L1(1-128)4 and L2(120-233) structures, silent mutations were introduced flanking the lipoyl domains to produce restriction sites and the corresponding changes were introduced into the coding sequence for native E2 so mutated lipoyl domains could be substituted to produce modified E2 oligomers (25).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	64	3 All mutations introduced into the pGEX-2T plasmids to produce single amino acid substitutions in GST-L1(1-128) or GST-L2(120-233) were introduced using offset oligonucleotide primers containing the appropriate base change(s) and a design which allowed replication only of the parental strands.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Replication was performed using Pfu polymerase through 10 (one base change) or 12 (two-base change) replication cycles.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	66	 This was followed by digestion of the methylated parent strands with DpnI endonuclease (target sequence 5'-GmATC-3').
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Mutations in L2(128-229) were introduced using the Altered Sites mutagenesis kit (Promega Corp.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	68	); some properties were previously described (26).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	69	 All mutations were confirmed by dideoxy sequencing.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	70	 In the L2(120-233) alanine was substituted for Tyr129, Leu140, Ser141, Thr143, Thr145, Val156, Lys173 (site of lipoylation), Glu179, Leu190, Asp197, Phe217, and Thr220.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The basic residues Lys188 and Arg196 were substituted with glutamine, and selected acidic residues in the extended C-terminal tail were converted to their corresponding amides (e.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The site of lipoylation, Lys173, was also mutated to Met or Leu with L2(120-233) and to Gln using the L2(128-229) structure.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Neighboring the lipoylation site, the L2(128-229) mutations included: E170Q, D172N, and A174S.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The positions of mutated amino acids in the L2 structure are shown in Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	75	 L1(1-128) was mutated by alanine substitution at Ser14, Lys46 (site of lipoylation), Glu52, and Asp70 which correspond to Ser141, Lys173, Glu179, and Asp197 in the L2 domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Lipoyl domain sequences, obtained from GenBank were aligned by the Genetics Corporation Group Pileup program, Wisconsin Package version 9.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	77	Native and mutated lipoyl domains, purified as described previously (23), were evaluated by native gel electrophoresis, which readily detects the degree of lipoylation (23, 24, 26).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The effective use of the lipoyl group is further tested by the use of lipoyl domains as substrates in the E3 reaction, as described previously (23).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Compact mobility in native gel electrophoresis requires well folded domains.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	80	 As reported here, changes to forms that tend to aggregate are also detected by native gel electrophoresis.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	81	 In some cases, masses were also evaluated by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization mass spectrometry using a Lasermat 2000.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	82	Melting transitions for the cooperative unfolding of domains were determined by DSC using MicroCal VP-DSC (27) and a scanning rate of 1  degrees C/min unless otherwise indicated.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	83	7-2 mg/ml) were dialyzed into 20 mM potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	84	0); scans of buffer alone were subtracted from those for the lipoyl domains.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	85	 After the first scan of a sample, the solution was cooled and re-scanned to test the reversiblity of unfolding.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Tm values reported are the transition mid-point temperatures.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	87	 For estimation of H values, base line corrections were made using a smooth transition between the pre- and post-melting transition baselines.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Protein concentrations were determined by measurements of absorbance at 280 nm standardized based on amino acid composition.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	89	 For wild type L2s, this gives a predicted 280 = 9650 M1 cm1; both constructs of wild type L2 share all aromatic residues and therefore have the same molar extinction coefficient.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	90	 On a per mg basis, this 280 translates for L2(120-233) to 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	91	74 A280/mg/ml cm and for L2(128-229) to 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Protein concentrations obtained with the BCA method using bovine serum albumin as a standard (23) generally gave protein values 55-65% as high as the values determined by 280 nm absorbance for domains exhaustively dialyzed into 20 mM phosphate buffer.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	93	Circular dichroism (CD) spectra were obtained for all lipoyl domain structures using a quartz cell with a 1-mm light path in 20 mM potassium phosphate (pH 7.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	94	0) maintained by water jacketed holder at 20  degrees C using a Jasco J720 spectrometer by averaging at least 16 scans each accumulated at 50 nm/min.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Spectra from 300 to 180 nm were collected at 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Protein concentrations were based on 280 nm absorbance.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The instrument was calibrated with using D-10-camphorsulfonic acid as a standard.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	98	E1 Activity Assays-- The rate of acetylation of lipoyl domain constructs was measured by minor modification of procedure of Liu et al.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	99	2 E1 was diluted in 50 mM potassium phosphate (pH 7.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	100	5 mg/ml bovine serum albumin and 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In duplicate or triplicate, the lipoyl domain construct was equilibrated at 30  degrees C in small conical tubes in 20  microl followed by addition of 5  microl of E1 (6-15 ng) and then, after 60 s, 5  microl of [2-14C]pyruvate to initiate the reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In some assays, this volume was reduced to 15  microl final volume with E1 and pyruvate added in 2 or 3  microl.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	103	 In all assays the final reaction mixture contained 50 mM potassium phosphate (final pH 7.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	104	5 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, and the indicated levels of pyruvate and lipoyl domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	105	 After 40-s reactions were terminated by spotting two-thirds of the reaction mixture to P81 filter paper discs pretreated with 1 M acetic acid.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Discs were then washed with 5-6 changes 1 M acetic acid (10 ml/disc) with at least a 1-h period for each wash followed by 5-min treatments with ethanol and then ethyl ether.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Radioactivity retained in the discs was counted to measure the level of acetylation of lipoyl domain substrates.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Kinetic data were analyzed by least square analysis in double reciprocal plots (1/v versus 1/S) and by Cricket graph version 1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	109	Lipoate Substitution-- 8-Thioloctanoate was synthesized by reacting 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	110	65 M 8-bromooctanoic acid with thiol-urea (1:1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	111	1) in dry ethanol by refluxing for 8 h.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This was followed by addition of 3 ml of 5 N NaOH per 10-ml reaction mixture to bring pH  > 7.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	113	 After being stirred at 0  degrees C for 1 h, the reaction mixture was clear and HCl was added to acidify the solution to pH 3.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The product was extracted three times with 10 ml of CHCl3.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The combined CHCl3 fraction was washed three times with water and then dried over MgSO4.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The solution was filtered and the solvent removed by vacuum evaporation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	117	 This 8-thioloctanoic acid was adequate for some studies but, for some studies, the product was further purified on silica gel column (to remove small amounts of disulfide and ethanol esterified forms of the product).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	118	Nonlipoylated L2 was isolated from a preparation of purified L2, made from cells grown without lipoate supplementation, by separation from lipoylated L2 using a 5-ml Econo-Pac Methyl HIC cartridge (Bio-Rad) using a linear decreasing salt gradient starting at 2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	119	4 M (NH4)2SO4 in 100 mM potassium phosphate (pH 7.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	120	0) and developed versus 100 mM potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The nonlipoylated L2 elutes first, well separated from the lipoylated L2; salt was then removed by dialysis versus 20 mM potassium phosphate (pH 7.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	122	 8-Thioloctanoate, octanoate, or heptanoate at 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	123	5 mM were ligated onto L2 using E.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	124	 coli lipoyl-protein ligase (28) in the presence of 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Native gel electrophoresis was used to follow the ligation reaction since each modified domain changed to a more mobile L2 as described previously for addition of lipoate (23, 34, 26).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Modified L2 were then dialyzed to remove ATP.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	127	     RESULTS AND DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	128	Mutation Sites in Lipoyl Domains-- Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	129	 1 shows a ribbon diagram and space filled views of two sides of the -barrel structure of the L2 (19) with labeling of the amino acids that were substituted.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Panel A shows the location of the loop (arrow) containing Lys173 to which the lipoyl group is attached and the location of the specificity loop (*); panel B is in approximately the same orientation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	131	 This side of the folded domain includes a high proportion of acidic residues with those on the upper side located away from basic residues and those on the lower side generally located near basic residues.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The opposing side of the folded domain has a hydrophobic face (yellow residues, Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	133	 1, panel C) centered around Leu190, has only one acidic residue (Asp197), and prominent basic residues.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Besides prominent hydrophilic groups, substitutions were made at hydrophobic side chains that are well exposed to solvent at the surface of the folded portion of the L2 domain (Leu140, Val156, and Leu190) and in terminal regions (e.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	135	 At the lipoylated end of the molecule, alanine substitutions were made for solvent exposed residues in the specificity loop (L140A, S141A, and T143A) and around the lipoyl domain next to and just interior to Lys173 (T145A, E170Q, D172Q, A174S, R196Q, and D197A).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	136	 To the rear of the folded domain, substitutions of well exposed hydrophilic residues included Q134A, E162A, E179A, Q181A, and K188Q.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Substitutions were also made for residues with a potential for functional importance in the N-terminal (Y129A) and C-terminal (D213N, F217A, D219N, Y220A, R221Q, and E224Q) regions.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	138	View larger version (50K):    Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	139	   Ribbon diagram and space-filled presentations of the human L2 domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	140	 These models are based on the structure of Howard et al.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	141	 (19), but the extra amino acids on the N terminus, which are not part of the L2 structure are removed.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The ribbon diagram (panel A) shows L2 is a the flattened -barrel structure made up of two antiparallel  sheet regions.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The position of Lys173 is marked with an arrow and the specificity loop (loop 1) with a star.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Panel B shows a space filled model positioned in a similar orientation to the ribbon diagram in Panel A and panel C shows the opposing side of the lipoyl domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The positions of all mutated amino acids and the location of the specificity loop in the L2 structure are indicated.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Residues are numbered according to their sequence in mature E2 which is 123 higher than the numbering used in Ref.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Each asterisk in panels B and C indicates a residue that is a different amino acid in the aligned sequence of the L1 domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Colors used: Asp is red; Glu is orange; Lys and Arg are blue except Lys, which is magenta; Gln and Asn are burgundy; Ser and Thr are green; Pro, Met, and Gly are white; Leu, Ile, and Val are yellow; and Phe and Tyr are gray.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Ala residues are white in panel A but are yellow in panel B.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Cys and Trp do not have significant exposure at the surface of L2 and were left white.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	151	Corresponding to Ser141, Glu179, Asp197 in L2, Ser14, Glu52, and Asp70 were substituted in L1 based on these residues being seldom found in the aligned sequences of bacterial PDC lipoyl domains or domains of other -keto acid dehydrogenase complexes.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Thus, there seemed to be a high likelihood of these being specificity residues.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Beyond the pursuit of the full range of E1 interactions, these L2 mutants are also being used to determine the basis for the specific interactions of certain kinase and phosphatase isoforms of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex with the L2 domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	154	5 Indeed, Tyr129, Gln134, Thr145, Gln181, and Val156 would not be expected to be major specificity residues for E1 function since these residues differ in L1, a good E1 substrate2; however, these residues may contribute to specificities of different regulatory enzymes.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The testing of all mutants for E1 use is important, since effective use in the E1 reaction constitutes strong evidence that a mutant domain retains near native folding to allow correct presentation of the residues that interact with E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	156	Lipoyl Domain Properties-- Besides substitutions for the Lys that undergoes lipoylation (Lys46 and Lys173 in L1 and L2, respectively), only the substitution E170Q prevented lipoylation of L2 by the bacterial lipoyl-protein ligase.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Besides not being used in the E1 and E3 reactions, the lack of lipoylation was confirmed by the mass determined by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-MS.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The E170Q-L2 is well folded (below).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	159	 (29) demonstrated the importance of Glu residues in the corresponding position (3 residues to the N-terminal side of the lipoylation site) for the lipoylation of various lipoyl domain sources by the mammalian lipoyl-AMP:N-lysine lipoyl transferase.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	160	 coli lipoyl-protein ligase and mammalian enzyme apparently share a need for this residue.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	161	With many mutated L1 or L2, native gel electrophoresis detected small portions of nonlipoylated domain (upper band) with the level being  < 1 to 5% for expression at 23-25  degrees C and 3 to 30% when expression is at 37  degrees C for wild type or mutant L1 or L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Like the wild type construct (lane 1, upper panel, Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	163	 2), mutant L2(120-233) structures expressed at 37  degrees C (lanes 2 and 6, upper panel) generally contained low levels of nonlipoylated domain although the level of this upper band rose to as high as 30% with the T145A mutant and with all L2(128-229) constructs (lane 8, wild type).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Expression at 23-25  degrees C greatly reduced or eliminated the nonlipoylated constructs (lanes 3-5 and 10 in upper panel and lanes 1-4 in the lower panel) even in the case of the T145A construct (lane 5) or A174S (lane 4) and D172N (not shown) which are L2(128-229) structures mutated at the sites adjacent to the lipoylated Lys173.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The latter finding is consistent with mutations of the Bacillus stearothermophilus PDC-E2 lipoyl domain in which Met and other residues were introduced on either side of the lipoylated lysine without affecting the relative extent of lipoylation (30).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	166	 However, the wild type form of this bacterial domain was only partially lipoylated (~30%) in E.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Lipoylation is probably limited by the high expression of this small domain and hindered because it contains a glutamate at the position aligned with Glu170 for which glutamine substitution prevented lipoylation of L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	168	 coli pyruvate and -ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complexes have a glutamate at this position (31, 32).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The successful removal of nonlipoylated domain by chromatography on a small HIC column was established by native gel electrophoresis, e.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	170	 2 for L2(128-229), upper panel, lane 9, prepared from the mixture in lane 8 of lipoylated and nonlipoylated domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	171	 For introduction of lipoate analogs (lanes 6-8, lower panel), nonlipoylated L2(120-233) was prepared by HIC, lower panel, lane 5, from an L2 preparation containing ~80% nonlipoylated L2 that was made by expressing cells in media not supplemented with lipoate at 37  degrees C.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	172	View larger version (54K):    Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	173	   Characterization of lipoyl domain preparations by native gel electrophoresis.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Native gel electrophoresis and staining with Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250 were conducted on the indicated L2 constructs under conditions previously described (28) except that 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	175	1% Pluronic F-68 was included in all buffers used to produce the gel shown in lanes 10-12 of the upper panel.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	176	 L2 structures in lanes 1-3, 5, and 8 (upper panel) and lane 5 (lower panel) were expressed at 37  degrees C and those in lanes 4, 5, 7, and 10-12 in the upper panel and lanes 1-4 in the lower panel were expressed at 23-24  degrees C.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	177	 HIC chromatography was used to prepare the lipoylated L2(128-229), lane 8, from the preparation in lane 9 and to separate nonlipoylated L2(120-233) shown in lane 5 (lower panel) from lipoylated L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	178	 This nonlipoylated L2 was, in turn, used to prepare the octanoyl-L2 (oct.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	179	), 8-thiol-octanoyl-L2 (8-SH-oct.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	180	) by lipoyl-protein ligase reaction (32).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Protein amounts loaded were 2  microg for lanes 1-6, lane 10 of the upper panel and all lanes in the lower panel, 6  microg for lanes 7 and 8, 8  microg for lane 9, and 1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	182	L190A and F217A were well lipoylated based on the masses determined by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-MS, but native gel electrophoresis (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	183	 2) revealed a tendency to aggregate.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Primarily dimer was observed with L190A (lane 11) and a combination of dimer and monomer with F217A (lane 12).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Leu190 is exposed in the center of hydrophobic face in L2, Phe217 is located in the unfolded C-terminal region (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	186	 It would appear that Leu190 and Phe217 must participate in interactions that prevent aggregation elicited by the individual alanine substitutions.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Consistent with this, deletion of the C-terminal regions of L1 or L2 also led to aggregation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	188	 An interaction of the C-terminal lobe with the surface of L2 was not detected in NMR studies (19) suggesting that any interaction is either weak or condition-dependent.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	189	 An interesting prospect is that the hydrophobic face centered around Leu190 interacts with the hydrophobic residues in the C terminus.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	190	 With the large number of charged residues in the C terminus and next to the hydrophobic face, such a reversible positioning of the C-terminal lobe against the folded domain might also be aided by favorable electrostatic interactions.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	191	The above finding of high lipoylation of mutated domains constitutes strong evidence that lipoylated domains were folded into the appropriate -barrel structure since the E.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	192	 coli lipoyl-protein ligase requires a folded lipoyl domain with the lipoylated Lys residue located at the tip of a sharp -turn onto which lipoate is added (28, 30).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Additionally domains were tested for their effectiveness as substrates in the E3 reaction (cyclic activity measured) (23).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	194	2 All mutant lipoyl domains that were lipoylated functioned as effective substrates in the E3 reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Using 10  microM levels of lipoyl domains, rates within  plus or minus 15% of 26.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	196	7  micromol/min/mg E3 were observed with each of these L2 mutants.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	197	 This rate is about 5 times faster than the rate with 10  microM lipoamide, but a lipoylated peptide substrate (L2 domain residues 163-177) was also used at a higher rate.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	198	Mutant lipoyl domains had CD patterns similar to those found with native L1 and L2 structures2 with a positive peak at 227 nm and a deep trough at 198-200 nm (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The trough depth is decreased with L2(128-229) structures in comparison to L2(120-233) structures,2 supporting a major contribution of the terminal regions to this feature of the CD spectra.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Some variation is observed in the spectra of mutant lipoyl domains.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	201	 However, CD spectra do not give good insight into the presence of the expected -barrel fold because the spectra are not typical for a domain containing primarily antiparallel -structure but are dominated by the contributions of terminal regions, particularly the large C-terminal lobe.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	202	2 This is in marked contrast to B.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	203	 stearothermophilus PDC-E2 lipoyl domain (30, 33) which gave a typical CD pattern for a structure dominated by antiparallel -structure.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Similar spectra are found with the K173A mutant and native L2 indicating that the absence of a lipoyl group does not greatly change the CD pattern; this was also found with a nonlipoylated Lys173.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	205	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	206	   Circular dichroism pattern for native and mutated L2(120-233).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	207	 CD spectra were collected as described under "Experimental Procedures" on L2 domains with the indicated L2(120-233) construct added to a 1-mm cuvette at 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	208	To further establish that the lipoyl domains form stably folded structures, differential scanning calorimetry studies were conducted.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Table I (data columns 1 and 2) summarizes Tm and H values determined from these scans; Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	210	 4 shows representative Cp profiles for these highly cooperative melting transitions.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	211	 All but two transitions were nearly symmetric and Tm values were unchanged when multiple cycles of heating-cooling were performed which is consistent with unfolding transitions representing a two-state, reversible equilibrium process.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Tm values were reproduced with considerable accuracy (repeat determinations were invariably within  plus or minus  0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Although Tm values were unchanged in repeated melting cycles, the area of second and third scans were typically reduced 4-10%.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The most likely cause is lack of refolding due to aggregation of unfolded domain prior to or during the lowering of the temperature.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The combination of base line corrections and small deviations in protein determinations limit the accuracy of H estimates such that two constructs can be considered to have significantly different H values only when the difference is  > 5 kcal/mol.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	216	                              View this table:    Table I Tm and H values for the thermal unfolding of various L2 domain structures and comparison of E1 activity using wild type and various mutant L2 domains at 20 and 50  microM Values were determined by differential scanning calorimetry as determined under "Experimental Procedures.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	217	" E1 activity assays were conducted in 15- microl reaction mixtures using 8 ng of E1 and 40 s reaction time.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Data from several experiments are combined and normalized with the rates with the wild type L2 (range for rates at 50  microM wild type L2 was 5.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	219	7  micromol/min/mg E1) assigned a value of 100% for each lipoyl domain concentration.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The average ratio of rates using wild type L2 at 20  microM to rates at 50  microM L2 in different experiments was 0.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Other conditions were as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	222	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	223	   Thermal unfolding of L2 domains measured by differential scanning calorimetry.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	224	 A comparison is made of the thermal melting profiles that occur over a range of 13  degrees C centered around the wild type L2(120-233) domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The 22 mutant L2 that fell within this range all had similarly shaped profiles for thermal unfolding which appear to involve a entropy-based Boltzman distribution.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	226	Twenty-three mutants had Tm values within  plus or minus 4  degrees C of native L2 (Table I).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	227	 NMR studies indicate the specificity loop is somewhat flexible and the side chains tend to extend outward from the folded structure (19).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Substitution of alanine mutation for each of the exposed side chains in this loop (Leu140, Ser141, and Thr143) lowered Tm with the Leu140 mutation causing a 11  degrees C decrease.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	229	 In each case H values were also significantly reduced and the apparent S (S = H/Tm, where S is the entropy difference between the unfolded and the folded domain and Tm is in K) values were therefore also reduced relative to native L2 with the largest S decrease (36%) occurring with S141A mutation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	230	 One possibility is that alanine substitution enhances the flexibility of the specificity loop leading to a smaller gain in entropy upon unfolding S141A-L2 while also reducing specific interactions that contribute to stability of the folded domain which also reduces the H difference.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	231	 This suggests that significant organization is contributed by the specificity loop in the native structure even though this region is somewhat flexible (19).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	232	Marked decreases in Tm were also observed with L190A and F217A L2 mutants.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	233	 This is consistent with loss of a stabilizing interaction involving the C-terminal lobe which results in the tendency of these mutant L2 to aggregate, as described above.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	234	 With L190A and F217A a second transition was observed after the main cooperative melting transition.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The area of this second (but not the first) transition was greatly reduced by increasing the scan rate from 1  degrees C/min to 1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	236	 That is consistent with the second phase arising from aggregation of the unfolded domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Besides F217A substitution, the D213N (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	238	 5) and Y220A mutations in the C-terminal lobe caused significant reductions in Tms.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The combination of a reduced Tm with maintenance of high H indicates a S gain with the D213N-L2 mutation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	240	 This suggests that the C-terminal lobe has reduced flexibility upon converting Asp to Asn and a larger gain in entropy upon unfolding this structure.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Given the large number of C-terminal residues separating Asp219 from the folded domain, it is surprising that this mutation reduces the H value estimated from melting transitions.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Since the D219N mutation lowered the H by about 20  plus or minus  6 kcal/mol without significantly affecting Tm, this indicates S is significantly decreased, suggesting a decrease in the organization within the C-terminal lobe due to this mutation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Asp219 likely forms an electrostatic interaction that reduces the flexibility of the C-terminal lobe in the native domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Smaller decreases in H were estimated for other substitutions in C-terminal residues (Y220A and R221A) suggesting Tyr220 and Arg221 contribute to structure within this lobe.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	245	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	246	   Comparison of E1 reaction rates using wild type and mutant L1 domains.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Lipoyl domains were added at the indicated concentrations.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Other conditions were as described in Table II and under "Experimental Procedures.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	249	Similarly, mutation of the N-terminal Tyr129, mounted off the folded domain by two intervening Pro residues, reduced the Tm to 63.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	250	6  degrees C; this outcome suggests Tyr129 interacts to stabilize the folded domain, possibly through a H-bond.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Conversion of Glu162 to alanine produced a domain with a significantly increased Tm value (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Tm values were also increased by the E179A and K173Q substitutions.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Removal of a charge repulsion between Glu162 and Glu179 (with concomitant gain in flexibility of the remaining acidic residue) and favorable H-bonding by a Gln173 side chain are likely sources of increased stability of these mutant L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	254	Overall the DSC results support all mutant L2 being cooperatively folded.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Differences in stability of a few mutants seem to reflect changes in the interaction at the surface of L2 with this being most pronounced in the case of F217A and L190A mutant L2 domains.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Both these structures are well lipoylated and, as described below, both were used as substrates in the E1 reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	257	 As noted above, E1 will only reductively acetylate folded lipoyl domain structures (10).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	258	Mapping of Specificity Residues in the Lipoyl Domains in E1 Catalysis-- Table I (data columns 3 and 4) compares use of wild type and all lipoylated-mutant L2 by bovine E1 using 20 and 50  microM L2 construct; these concentrations are below and just above the Km of E1 for wild type L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The L2 mutants L140A, S141A, T143A, E162A, D172N, and E179A were reductively acetylated by E1 at greatly reduced rates.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Much smaller rate reductions were observed with the A174S, L190A, and F217A mutants.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The reduced rates with L190A and F217A may, in part, be due to their tendency to aggregate.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	262	 In comparison to wild type L2, very small decreases or no change in E1 activity were observed with the Y129A, T145A, V156A, K188Q, R196Q, D197A, D213N, D219N, Y220A, R221Q, and E224Q mutant L2 domains.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This indicates that these residues do not directly contribute to the interaction of L2 with E1 and that these mutations do not greatly alter the L2 structure in regions required for E1 binding.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	264	The D172N mutant gave the greatest reduction in E1 activity; whereas the A174S mutation on the other side of the lipoylated K173 was used at a rate that was only modestly reduced (Table I).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	265	 The effects of substitutions for the corresponding Asp and Ala residues preceding and following, respectively, the lipoylated Lys of the B.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	266	 stearothermophilus PDC-E2 lipoyl domain have been characterized (30).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The D42A mutation had a smaller effect on the rate of the bacterial E1 reaction than our D172N substitution had on the mammalian E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	268	 It would appear that Asp172 plays a more important role in the reaction catalyzed by mammalian E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Introduction of a charged residue (Glu) for Ala44 greatly reduced the activity of B.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	270	 stearothermophilus E1 while substitution of Met had even less effect than the corresponding A174S substitution had in reducing the activity of bovine E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The substantial effects of the Leu140, Ser141, and Thr143 mutations add further support to studies on bacterial domains (8-10) which indicated that the loop formed following the first run of N-terminal -structure (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	272	 1) is a key specificity loop for the E1 reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The size and sequence of this loop region varies for different lipoyl domain sources.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	274	Substitution of alanine in the L1 domain at the Ser14 (aligns with Ser141 in L2) and the Glu52 position (aligns with Glu179 in L2) gave similar decreases in E1 activity as the corresponding substitutions in L2 (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	275	 As in the case of D197A mutation in L2, the corresponding D70A mutation in L1 did not affect E1 activity.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	276	Most of our kinetic studies were performed with bovine E1 prior to our developing human E1 preparations with nearly equivalent specific activities in reconstituted PDC assays.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Human E1 use of lipoyl domain substrates and characterization of human E1, E2-E3BP (native and mutant forms) along with use of human E3 are described elsewhere.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	278	2,5 Human E1, while having a similar activity in reconstitution assays as bovine E1 with human E2-E3BP3 and a similar Km for free lipoyl domain substrates, nevertheless has a lower kcat using free L1 or L2 as substrates in the E1 reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	279	5-fold lower Vm(app) than bovine E1 using free L2 domain substrates and 120  microM pyruvate.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	280	 All mutant L2 constructs which greatly reduced catalysis by bovine E1 also reduced the activity of human E1 with similar relative changes in activity at 20 and 50  microM to those shown in Table I.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Because of the discrepancy between the nearly equivalent activities human E1 and bovine E1 in reconstituted PDC assays (using either human E2-E3BP or bovine E2-E3BP and human E3 or porcine E3) but the lower activities in utilizing free lipoyl domain substrates by human E1, further studies are being conducted to evaluate whether improved assay conditions will elevate the activity of human E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Nevertheless, our results support a common set of key residues in the lipoyl domain substrates that are required for efficient reductive acetylation by bovine and human E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	283	Changes in Kinetic Parameters with Key Residues-- Mutations at the sites that greatly reduced E1 activity produced folded domains that underwent highly cooperative melting transitions.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Thus, the substantial effects of these mutations favor the direct involvement of these residues in interactions with the E1 component.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Apparent Km and Vmax values were obtained for all mutant L2 domains that greatly lowered E1 activity (Table II).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The apparent Km of bovine E1 (pyruvate fixed at 120  microM) is 35  microM L2; its true Km, determined from a full steady state study in which the pyruvate level was also varied, is 49  plus or minus  6  microM L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	287	2 The changes in E1 kinetic parameters were very different with different mutants.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The L140A mutation actually gave a reduced Km in conjunction with decreasing the Vmax so that the kcat:Km ratio in the E1 reaction was not significantly changed (Table II).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	289	 In native L2, Leu140 may aid E1 catalysis by favoring dissociation of the reductively acetylated lipoyl domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	290	 With S141A, the Km of E1 for this L2 mutant was increased along with a decrease in the maximal velocity to produce overall a 26.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	291	8-fold change in the catalytic efficiency of the E1 reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Thus, it seems likely that Ser141 contributes to specific binding of the lipoyl domain by E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	293	 With the T143A mutant, the kcat for the E1 reaction was markedly decreased while there was little change in the apparent Km for this mutant (Table II) suggesting that Thr143 contributes to E1 specificity by enhancing the rate of acetylation of the native substrate.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	294	                              View this table:    Table II Variation in kinetic parameters of E1 with mutant lipoyl domains that had markedly supported markedly reduced activities in Table I Pyruvate was fixed at 120  microM; initial velocities were measured in duplicate at six or more lipoyl domain concentrations.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	295	 The kinetic parameters were estimated from double reciprocal plots of 1/v versus l/lipoyl domain concentration.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	296	The E179A mutation caused a marked reduction in E1 catalysis (Table I) as a result of an ~5-fold increase in Km and ~2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	297	5-fold decrease in kcat (Table II).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	298	 The change in apparent Km with the E52A mutant was not nearly as large as with Glu179 (data not shown).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	299	 This distinction suggests that E1 interacts somewhat differently with the L1 domain than it interacts with the L2 domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Glu162 is located behind Glu179 (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Alanine substitution at this position primarily reduced Vm while also modestly elevating the Km of E1 for this substrate (Table II).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	302	 The strong effects of mutations at Glu179 and Glu162 indicate that the E1 interaction extends well beyond the specificity loop (below).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	303	 However, E1 activity was not significantly affected by substitutions for Thr145, Arg196, or Asp197 which are located almost directly opposite from Thr143 and Ser141, respectively at the lipoylated end of L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Asp197 is the only acidic residue on this side of the folded domain (panel C, Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	305	 1) and was selected as a potential specificity residue based on sequence alignments.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Substitutions of the corresponding amides for the three acidic residues in the C-terminal tail (Asp213, Asp219, and Glu214) also failed to significantly affect the E1 reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	307	The marked decrease in activity due to the D172N mutation was a consequence of the largest increase among the L2 mutants in the apparent Km of E1 and some reduction in Vmax (Table II).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	308	 The catalytic efficiency (kcat/Km) was decreased about 75-fold.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Replacing the acid side chain with the corresponding amide did not affect E3 catalysis, alter lipoylation, change parameters in scanning calorimetry from those for native L2 (Table II), or greatly change the CD spectra (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	310	 It would therefore seem likely that the presentation of the adjacent lipoyl group is probably not substantially modified by the D172N mutation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Thus, this residue, which is found in virtually all lipoyl domains, makes an important contribution to catalysis by mammalian E1.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	312	Key Specificity Residues and Lipoyl Domain Alignment-- Residues that have a particularly important role in providing the high specificity of mammalian PDC-E1s for their cognate lipoyl domain substrates would not be expected to be found in the aligned positions in bacterial PDC lipoyl domain sequences or in lipoyl domains of the E2 components of various sources (including mammalian) of the -ketoglutarate and branched chain -keto acid dehydrogenase complexes.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Leu140 or a similar amino acid (particularly Ile) is commonly found in the aligned position in a wide range of -keto acid dehydrogenase complexes.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	314	 However, Ser141, Thr143, or Glu179 are not found even once in the aligned positions in 19 known sequences of bacterial PDC lipoyl domains and only one instance of a Ser residue is found aligned with Ser141 in the sequences of non-PDC lipoyl domains.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	315	 These residues are present not only in the aligned position in the L1 domain of mammalian E2 but also in most of the known lipoyl domain sequences of other eukaryotic PDC-E2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	316	 In the lipoyl domain of the human E3BP component, Glu179 is conservatively substituted by Asp50.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	317	 This residue in the E3BP lipoyl domain is preceded by a leucine which is a substantial change from the phenylalanine located in the aligned position of L1 and L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Further studies will be needed to evaluate the importance of Glu occupying this position in L1 and L2 and an Asp residue occupying this position in E3BP.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	319	Competitive Inhibition by Lipoyl Domains Modified at the Site of Lipoylation-- Graham and Perham (11) observed a weak interaction of E.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	320	 coli PDC-E1 with its cognate lipoyl domain despite high specificity for this substrate.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Using GST-H1 L2, this laboratory has only been able to detect weak binding to L2 by E1 containing transition state analogs of HE-TPP and even under turnover conditions in which the inner domain of E2 and E3 supported slow catalysis in the overall reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	322	2 A potential explanation for the capacity of E1 to be highly selective for a lipoyl domain substrate while a weak affinity is that binding energy from the required protein-protein interactions between E1 and its lipoyl domain is used to move the lipoyl group into the active site.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	323	 This would predict that the L2 mutant K173A would be a good competitive inhibitor.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Alternatively, the long lysyl-octanoyl chain or specific interactions of the dithiolane ring of the lipoyl group may make an important contribution to specific binding or catalysis.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	325	 To evaluate this, L2 was modified at the site of lipoylation either by substitution of the amino acids alanine, methionine, leucine, or glutamine for Lys173 or by introduction of the lipoyl substitutes: octanoate, 8-thioloctanoate, or heptanoate into nonlipoylated L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Although 8-thioloctanoyl-L2 was an efficient substrate for the transacetylation reaction catalyzed by the E2 component,3 it was not used by E1 at a significant rate ( < 2 nmol/min/mg E1).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Using a driven NADH regenerating system (-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex reaction) to convert and maintain lipoyl groups via the E3 reaction in the reduced form, rates of acetylation by E1 of reduced lipoyl groups using pyruvate at least 100-fold faster than the above rate obtained using the 8-thioloctanoyl-L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	328	6 In both cases, O2 presumably serves as the electron acceptor for the required oxidation of the HE-TPP to acetyl-TPP (4).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Assuming that very low levels of oxidized lipoyl groups were not contributing to the higher rates with the dihydrolipoyl-containing substrate,6 this finding suggests that the presence of a thiol in the 6-position is important for the reductive acetylation reaction to proceed even though acetylation is at the 8-position (4).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	330	 6 (left panel), the substitution of Leu or Gln for Lys173 yielded L2 that were inhibitory at a 1:1 ratio versus native L2, whereas Ala- and Met-substituted L2 gave much less inhibition.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Introduction of heptanoate gave weak inhibition and 8-thioloctanoate gave stronger inhibition (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	332	 However, octanoyl-L2 was a very weak inhibitor.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	333	 It is possible that substitutions like Leu or Gln for Lys173 or heptanoate for lipoate produce L2 that can interact with E1 in artificial ways that do not mimic the prosthetic group on the native domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	334	 However, the substantial inhibition by 8-thioloctanoyl-L2 probably involves specific interactions of the thiol group since octanoyl-L2 is a much weaker inhibitor.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	335	 The poor inhibition due to substitutions like K173A and octanoyl-L2 supports the lipoyl lysine group interacting via its specific structure.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	336	 Specifically the dithiolane ring of lipoate may contribute to binding by forming favorable interactions and increasing the probability of a cofactor conformation that accommodates the active site.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	337	 In combination, the results with Lys173 substitutions and lipoate substitutions support significant interactions with E1 occur throughout the lipoyl-lysine prosthetic group and do not support lipoate being forced into the active site.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	338	 This is consistent with the active site channel of the P.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	339	 putida branched chain E1 being lined with hydrophobic groups which could interact favorably with the mostly aliphatic lipoyl-lysine prosthectic group (14).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	340	View larger version (40K):    Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	341	   Inhibition of E1 activity by L2 structures modified within the site of lipoylation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	342	 L2 was modified either by substitution of Lys173 (left panel) or ligation onto Lys173 or lipoate analogs (right panel) by lipoyl-protein ligase as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	343	" The E1 assays were conducted with both the modified (nonsubstrate) L2 structures and wild type L2 included at levels indicated in the insets.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	344	L2 Structure and Relation to the E1 Reaction-- We have prepared a versatile set of mutant lipoyl domains that are well folded.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	345	 All of the mutant domains, that had major effects on E1 activity, were well behaved in native gel electrophoresis and, with the exception of L140A-L2 mutant, unfolded with Tm values in excess of 64  degrees C.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	346	 We would emphasize that D170Q-L2, which was not lipoylated gave near wild type values in DSC and CD studies indicating it had a near native structure.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Thus, our studies further support the concept that lipoylation requires both proper folding and the presentation of essential residues.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Since the lipoyl domains used to test E1 function were well lipoylated, that further supports their retaining a well folded structure that properly presented the tight turn bearing Lys173 for the lipoylation reaction.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	349	The specificity loop 1 (Leu140, Ser141, and Thr143), the conserved Asp172 and, anterior to those residues, Glu179 and Glu162 are located on one side of the L2 domain (panel B, Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	350	 1) in a region abundant in acidic residues (10 on the folded part of the domain).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Glu179 is located in a long -strand leading away from Lys173; its -C is 16 A from Ser141 and the -C of these amino acids are separated by 19 A and 11 A, respectively, from the -C of Lys173.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Glu162 is located an additional 6 A behind Glu179.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	353	 These acidic residues are well separated from basic residues; this is in contrast to the acidic residues that line the bottom edge of the panel B structure.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Electrostatic interactions of Glu162 and Glu179 with basic residues at the surface of E1 are predicted to contribute to the E1-L2 complex.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Thus, E1 interacts over a substantial region with the surface of the lipoyl domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	356	 The opposite side of the lipoyl domain has a hydrophobic face (Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	357	 1, panel C) with Leu190 in the center and prominent residues, Arg196, Asp197, and Thr145, which were not important for E1 catalysis.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	358	 Apparently, there is very limited interaction of E1 with this side of the lipoyl domain structure although mutation of Val156 and Leu190 reduced activity.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	359	The mutants developed here have been used to establish specificity residues for specific kinase and phosphatase isoforms.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	360	5 Those studies have revealed an overlapping pattern in supporting of the function of the regulatory enzymes and E1 but also established the involvement of many distinct residues and large differences in the relative importance of overlapping residues.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	361	 This further indicates that these established mutations do not propagate extended changes in the structure of the lipoyl domain to thereby interfere with normal lipoyl domain roles.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Now that this initial mapping has been achieved, further substitutions at the key specificity sites should greatly add to our understanding of the roles and relative importance of these key specificity residues in the L2 domain for E1 function.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	363	Based on the capacity of lipoylated L2 to compete very effectively versus analogs lacking structural features of the lipoyl-lysine prosthetic group, structural requirements for the interaction of the lipoyl prosthetic group include distinct structural features, probably including active site complementarity favoring binding of the dithiolane ring of the lipoate prosthetic group.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	364	 The stronger inhibition in substituting a Gln rather than Ala or Met for Lys173, probably results from Gln participating in H-bonding with E1 which cannot be formed by the Met and Ala side chains.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	365	 However, the alternative explanation that the Gln participates in a relatively stable internal H-bond within the lipoyl domain that enhances binding to E1 cannot be eliminated.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Since extensive interactions between E1 and L2 are supported and yet, to date, the binding of the lipoyl domains to E1 appear to be weak (Kd well above Km values (11)),2 this suggests that intrinsic interaction energy is used to facilitate catalysis.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	367	 That is consistent with the high specificity for cognate lipoyl domains of an E1 source of an -keto acid dehydrogenase complex and with the extraordinarily slow use of free lipoamide as a substrate (3).
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Thus, it seems likely that productive E1-lipoyl domain interactions facilitate structural changes within E1 that aid catalytic turnover such as facilitating a slight repositioning of the HE-TPP intermediate formed after decarboxylation to aid efficient reductive acetylation.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	369	Overall, we conclude that in the second step of the ping-pong reaction catalyzed by mammalian E1 reaction, the specificity for reductive acetylation of its cognate lipoyl domain is governed by unique surface residues spread primarily along the upper edge of the folded L2 structure shown in Fig.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	370	 Additional critical interactions of the universal lipoyl-lysine prosthetic group and preceding Asp residue (Asp172 in L2) contribute to catalysis.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Although E1 function was not affected by mutations in terminal regions, substitutions, particularly in the C-terminal lobe, were shown by DSC studies to contribute to the ordered structure of L2.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Further structural studies will be required to determine the how this lobe is structured and the degree to which it interacts with the  barrel structure within the domain.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	373	We thank Xiaohua Yan and Jason C.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	374	 Baker for help in preparing PDC and E1 and Shane Kasten for help in preparing wild type and mutant lipoyl domains.

0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	389	 Roche (unpublished data) using the bilipoyl domain fragment derived from bovine E2 as a substrate.
0.21141487.10788482.html.plaintext.txt	390	 Reaction of a re-neutralized, acid quenched sample with 5,5'-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoate) supported full reduction of the lipoyl domain substrate; however, the complete absence of oxidized lipoyl groups is uncertain because the presence of NADH with no NAD+ tends to cause E3 to be converted to the four electron reduced state which allows oxygen to react at the E3 active site to form H2O2 which, in turn, may serve to oxidize small portion of the dihydrolipoyl groups.
