0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	0	Characterization of Cyclin L2, a Novel Cyclin with an Arginine/Serine-rich Domain PHOSPHORYLATION BY DYRK1A AND COLOCALIZATION WITH SPLICING FACTORS* Katrin de Graaf, Paul Hekerman, Oliver Spelten, Andreas Herrmann, Len C.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Packman , Konrad Bussow||, Gerhard Muller-Newen, and Walter Becker**.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Institut fur Pharmakologie und Toxikologie, Medizinische Fakultat der RWTH Aachen, Wendlingweg 2, 52074 Aachen, Germany, Institut fur Biochemie, Medizinische Fakultat der RWTH Aachen, Pauwelstrasse 30, 52074 Aachen, Germany, the  Department of Biochemistry, University of Cambridge, 80 Tennis Court Road, Cambridge CB2 1GA, United Kingdom, and ||Max-Planck-Institut fur Molekulare Genetik, Heubnerweg 6, 14059 Berlin, Germany.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, October 1, 2003 , and in revised form, November 14, 2003.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   A novel method employing filter arrays of a cDNA expression library for the identification of substrates for protein kinases was developed.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	5	 With this technique, we identified a new member of the cyclin family, cyclin L2, as a substrate of the nuclear protein kinase DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Cyclin L2 contains an N-terminal cyclin domain and a C-terminal arginine/serine-rich domain (RS domain), which is a hallmark of many proteins involved in pre-mRNA processing.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The gene for cyclin L2 encodes the full-length cyclin L2, which is predominantly expressed in testis, as well as a truncated splicing variant (cyclin L2S) that lacks the RS domain and is ubiquitously expressed in human tissues.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Full-length cyclin L2, but not cyclin L2S, was associated with the cyclin-dependent kinase PITSLRE.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Cyclin L2 interacted with splicing factor 2 in vitro and was co-localized with the splicing factor SC35 in the nuclear speckle compartment.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Photobleaching experiments showed that a fusion protein of green fluorescent protein and cyclin L2 in nuclear speckles rapidly exchanged with unbleached molecules in the nucleus, similar to other RS domain-containing proteins.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In striking contrast, the closely related green fluorescent protein-cyclin L1 was immobile in the speckle compartment.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	12	 DYRK1A interacted with cyclin L2 in pull-down assays, and overexpression of DYRK1A stimulated phosphorylation of cyclin L2 in COS-7 cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These data characterize cyclin L2 as a highly mobile component of nuclear speckles and suggest that DYRK1A may regulate splicing by phosphorylation of cyclin L2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	14	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   DYRK1A (dual specificity tyrosine phosphorylation-regulated kinase 1A) is a nuclear protein kinase that appears to play an important role in brain development (for a review, see Ref.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The first evidence for a role of DYRK1A in neurogenesis came from its similarity with the Drosophila orthologue, the minibrain kinase (2).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Mutant flies with a reduced expression of minibrain show a significant reduction of neurons in distinct areas of the brain, correlated with specific behavioral defects (2).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In addition, the human DYRK1A gene is located on chromosome 21 in the "Down syndrome critical region" (3 to 5).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Consistent with a potential involvement of the DYRK1A gene in the pathogenesis of mental retardation in Down syndrome, overexpression of DYRK1A in transgenic mice causes learning deficits and neurodevelopmental alterations (5, 6).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Furthermore, mice heterozygous for a targeted deletion of the Dyrk1a gene (Dyrk1a+/- mice) develop abnormal brain morphology (7).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In early embryonal development, DYRK1A is expressed in neural progenitor cells during the transition from proliferating to neurogenic divisions (8).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Altogether, these findings suggest a relevant function of DYRK1A during neuronal development, related to proliferation and/or differentiation.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	22	In recent years, several transcription factors have been identified as substrates of DYRK1A (for a review, see Ref.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Particularly, overexpression of DYRK1A has been shown to modulate the transactivation potential of FKHR (forkhead in rhabdomyosarcoma) (10, 11), cAMP-response element-binding protein (12), and GLI1 (13).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Cytoplasmic proteins like eukaryotic initiation factor 2B, tau (14), and dynamin (15) have also been reported to be phosphorylated by DYRK1A, but these proteins might equally well be targets of the cytoplasmic kinases DYRK2 or DYRK3.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	25	 However, although DYRK1A contains a canonical nuclear localization signal and is indeed predominantly targeted to the nucleus (16, 17), a significant fraction of the kinase is also present in the cytoplasm (18).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Within the nucleus, DYRK1A is localized in "nuclear speckles," which represent the splicing factor compartment (17, 19).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The precise function of DYRK1A in the nucleus is still largely unknown, and it is an open question whether any of the known substrates of DYRK1A is a key mediator of its functions on cell differentiation and proliferation.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We have therefore performed a more extensive search for interacting proteins and substrates to address this problem.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	29	Several methods have been employed to identify novel substrates of protein kinases.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Routine interaction screens like the yeast two-hybrid system, phage display, and phage expression library screening, yield in many cases substrates of kinases (20 to 23).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Other approaches are based on the specificity of substrate recognition by kinases and aim to identify substrate proteins by searching data bases with experimentally determined or predicted consensus phosphorylation sequences (24, 25).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	32	 More direct strategies include the phosphorylation screening of phage expression libraries (26) or of cell lysates (27), and the identification of phosphoproteins by functional proteomics and mass spectrometry (28).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	33	Here we have employed a new method which allowed us to screen in parallel for interaction partners and substrates of the kinase DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In this approach, we used an arrayed protein expression library (29, 30) both for interaction screening by overlaying with the radiolabeled recombinant kinase (31), and for a substrate screen by solid phase phosphorylation (26).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The use of the filter array allowed us to directly identify positive clones without the need of further rounds of purification.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Several DYRK1A-interacting and/or phosphorylated proteins were identified by this approach, and one protein was found in both screens.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	37	 This protein turned out to be a novel member of the cyclin family and was designated cyclin L2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	38	Here we characterize cyclin L2 as a novel substrate of DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Furthermore, we describe the alternative transcripts generated from the cyclin L2 gene and show that full-length cyclin L2, but not the truncated splicing variant cyclin L2S, is co-localized with the splicing factor SC35 in nuclear speckles.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Using photobleaching techniques, we demonstrate that cyclin L2 and the closely related isoform, cyclin L1, differ strikingly with regard to their intranuclear mobility.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	41	   EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Production of the Filter Array The construction of the cDNA expression library and the production of high density filter arrays have been described previously (29).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Human fetal brain cDNA was directionally cloned into the pQE-30NST vector (GenBankTM accession number AF074376 [GenBank] ) for isopropyl-1-thio--D-galactopyranoside-inducible expression of His6-tagged fusion proteins.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The filter array (22 x 22 cm) used in the present study contained a library of 37,830 double-spotted plasmid clones (library number 800; RZPD, Berlin, Germany) that were enriched for putative expression clones as described earlier (29).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The colonies were lysed by alkali treatment (0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	45	5 M NaCl, 10 min), and the filter was neutralized for 2 x 5 min in 1 M Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Bacterial debris was carefully wiped off in TBS1 supplemented with 0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	47	1% (v/v) Tween 20 (TBS contains 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	48	5 M NaCl), and then the filter was washed twice for 10 min in TBS with 0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	49	1% (v/v) Tween 20 and once for 10 min in TBS.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	50	Probe Labeling for Overlay Assays The probe for the interaction screen, GST-DYRK1A-C-K188R, was expressed from the pGEX-2TK vector (GenBankTM accession number U13851 [GenBank] ), which allows labeling of the fusion protein on a vector-encoded phosphorylation site by cAMP-dependent protein kinase.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The C-terminally truncated mutant of DYRK1A was used as a probe in order to avoid potential nonspecific binding of the repeat structures in the C-terminal domain of DYRK1A (32).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The kinase-negative point mutant (K188R) of DYRK1A should exhibit enhanced enzyme-substrate interactions.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	53	 For labeling, 20 to 25  microg of GST-DYRK1A-C-K188R bound to glutathione S-Sepharose beads (Amersham Biosciences) were incubated in a volume of 110  microl with 10 units of cAMP-dependent protein kinase (New England Biolabs) in 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	54	5, 10 mM MgCl2, 6 mg/ml dithiothreitol for 30 min at 4  degrees C in the presence of 45  microCi of [-32P]ATP (3000 Ci/mmol).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The reaction was stopped by adding 10 mM EDTA to a final concentration of 2 mM.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The Sepharose beads were then washed seven times with 500  microl of ice-cold PBST (137 mM NaCl, 2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	57	5% (w/v) Triton X-100) in order to remove free [-32P]ATP.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The labeled protein was then eluted for 10 min on ice in 500  microl of glutathione elution buffer (10 mM reduced glutathione in 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The typical yield of this reaction was about 15  microCi of incorporated 32P in the eluted protein.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	60	Interaction Screening by DYRK1A Overlay In order to allow refolding of denatured proteins (33), the filter array or nitrocellulose membranes with electroblotted proteins were first incubated for 1 h at room temperature in 6 M guanidinium HCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	61	3, 50 mM dithiothreitol, 2 mM EDTA and then rinsed with TBS, followed by an overnight incubation at 4  degrees C in 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	62	 To reduce false positive signals due to binding of GST, the membrane was blocked by incubation in interaction buffer (0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	63	5% BSA, 75 mM KCl, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	64	5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	65	05% Nonidet P-40) containing 1  microg/ microl GST for 1 h at room temperature.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The membrane was then incubated with 6 x 104 cpm/ml of 32P-labeled GST-DYRK1A-C-K188R in interaction buffer for 18 h at 4  degrees C.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	67	 After washing three times for 10 min each at room temperature with interaction buffer, the membrane was dried and subjected to autoradiography.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	68	Substrate Screening by Solid Phase Phosphorylation The filter with the expression array or polyvinylidene fluoride membranes with electroblotted proteins were preincubated in kinase buffer (25 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	69	5 mM dithiothreitol, 5 mM MgCl2, 5 mM MnCl2), 100 mM NaCl, 3% BSA containing 3  microM cold ATP for 1 h at room temperature to mask proteins with autophosphorylating and/or ATP-binding activities (26).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The solid phase phosphorylation was done by incubation with 0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	71	2 units/ml GST-DYRK1A-C in kinase buffer containing 3  microM [-32P]ATP (5  microCi/ml) for 45 min at room temperature.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	72	 This construct has been shown to have the same substrate specificity but higher activity than the full-length kinase when produced in Escherichia coli (34).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	73	 One unit of protein kinase activity was that amount that catalyzed the phosphorylation of 1 nmol of DYRKtide, the standard synthetic peptide substrate (34), in 1 min in kinase buffer containing 100  microM ATP and 200  microM DYRKtide.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	74	 After phosphorylation, the membrane was washed twice with 30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	75	4, once with 30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	76	05% Nonidet P-40, twice with 30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	77	4, without Nonidet P-40, once with 1 M HCl, and again twice with 30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	78	4, each washing step for 10 min.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The membrane was air-dried and exposed to x-ray film.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	80	Bacterial Expression The plasmids for bacterial expression of GSTDYRK1A-C (34), GST-DYRK1A-C-K188R, GST-DYRK1A-CN (35), and GST-DYRK2 (17) have been described previously.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	81	 GSTDYRK1A-NT contains amino acids 1 to 177 of the N terminus of DYRK1A; GST-DYRK1Acat contains amino acids 133 to 499 of DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Plasmids from the human fetal brain expression library that encode His6-tagged fusion proteins (Table I) were obtained from the RZPD Deutsches Ressourcenzentrum fur Genomforschung (Berlin, Germany) (for cloning and vector information see, on the World Wide Web, www.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The expression plasmids for GST-SF2/ASF and GST-hTRA21 were kindly provided by Stefan Stamm (Erlangen, Germany) (36).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The bacterial expression plasmid coding for GST-CycL2 was constructed by cloning the cDNA from clone N16596 (corresponding to amino acids 270 to 520 of cyclin L2) into pGEX-2TK.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	85	View this table:    TABLE I Identification of DYRK1A-interacting proteins and substrates of DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	86	  GST- and His-tagged fusion proteins were expressed in E.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	87	 coli and affinity-purified using glutathione-Sepharose 4B (Amersham Biosciences) or nickel-charged nitrilotriacetic acid-agarose beads (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Proteins were eluted from the beads under native conditions (reduced glutathione or imidazole).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	89	 His6-tagged cyclin L2 expressed from the pQE-30NST vector (RZPD clone N16596) was purified from inclusion bodies as described previously (37).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The purified protein was refolded by gel filtration through a Sephadex G25 column (NAPTM-5 column, Amersham Biosciences) with 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	91	4, 100 mM NaCl as equilibration and elution buffer.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	92	 For kinase assays, imidazole was removed from His6-tagged fusion protein by ultrafiltration using Centricon concentrators (Amicon, Beverly, MA).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	93	Mammalian Expression The expression clone for GFP-DYRK1A has been described (17).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	94	 GFP-CLK3 was constructed by cloning the insert of pGEX-CLK3 (38) into pEGFP-C1 (Clontech) and expresses C-terminal to the GFP tag amino acids 33 to 490 of rat CLK3.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	95	 GFP constructs of cyclin L2 were cloned in pEGFP-C1 and comprise the indicated amino acids C-terminal of GFP (numbered as in Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	96	 3A): GFP-CycL2, amino acids 1 to 520; GFP-CycL2-N, amino acids 223 to 520; GFP-CycL2S, amino acids 1 to 220 of cyclin L2 plus 6 specific amino acids as indicated in Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	97	 GFP-CycL1 contains the full open reading frame of human cyclin L1 (amino acids 1 to 526; GenBankTM accession number AF180920 [GenBank] ).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	98	 A plasmid for expression of untagged cyclin L2 was generated by deletion of GFP from GFP-CycL2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	99	View larger version (37K):    FIG.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Structure of the CCNL2 gene and gene products.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	101	 A, amino acid sequence of cyclin L2 and cyclin L2S.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The sequence of cyclin L2 was deduced from an uncharacterized data base entry (AY037150 [GenBank] ).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Cyclin L2S consists of amino acids 1 to 220 of cyclin L2 and 6 additional amino acids (italics).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The cyclin domain is boxed, and the RS domain is underlined.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The amino acids of the antigenic peptide used for antibody production are highlighted by boldface type.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	106	 B, structural comparison of cyclin L2, cyclin L2S, and cyclin L1.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	108	 C, structural organization of the human CCNL2 gene and derived transcripts.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Exons are shown as filled boxes, and the alternatively spliced exon 6a is shaded.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Three differentially spliced transcripts (T1, T2, and T3) identified in this work and by searching of the public expressed sequence tag data bases are shown.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	115	  In Vitro Kinase Assays For in vitro-kinase assays (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	116	 2), amounts of substrates were adjusted to 750 ng of myelin basic protein (Sigma) according to the intensities of the Coomassie Blue-stained bands on SDS-PAGE.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Substrates were incubated for 15 min at 30  degrees C with 0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	118	5 units/ml GST-DYRK1A-C in kinase buffer supplemented with 100  microM [-32P]ATP (66.
