0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	566	 143, 297-307[Abstract/Free Full Text] Higgins, D.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	567	 266, 383-402[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve].
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	0	Implication of the product of the bovine herpesvirus type 1 UL25 gene in capsid assembly Nathalie Desloges and Claire Simard.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	1	Institut National de la Recherche Scientifique, Centre INRS-Institut Armand-Frappier, 531 Bd des Prairies, Laval, Quebec, Canada H7V 1B7.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	2	Correspondence Nathalie Desloges desloges{at}uni-wh.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT Top ABSTRACT MAIN TEXT REFERENCES   The UL25 ORF of bovine herpesvirus type 1 (BHV-1) was demonstrated recently to represent a gene encoding a 63 kDa viral protein.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	4	 To investigate the role of this gene in virus replication, a BHV-1 UL25 deletion mutant was constructed.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Although the UL25 mutant synthesizes late viral proteins and viral DNA, it fails to produce virus progeny in cells that do not express the UL25 gene, demonstrating that the UL25 protein is essential for the replicative cycle of BHV-1.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Moreover, Southern blotting analyses of HindIII-digested DNA from infected non-complementing cells probed with the leftward terminal fragment of the BHV-1 linear genome revealed that the cleavage of the viral DNA produced is not impaired.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, the packaging of this cleaved DNA is compromised severely, since only few full C capsids were observed in infected non-complementing cells by transmission electron microscopy.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	8	Present address: University of Witten/Herdecke, Institute of Microbiology and Virology, Stockumer Str.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	9	   MAIN TEXT Top ABSTRACT MAIN TEXT REFERENCES   Similar to herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), bovine herpesvirus type 1 (BHV-1) is a member of the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Infection of host cells by these two viruses is similar, beginning with the entry of the nucleocapsid into the cytoplasm and translocation of the viral DNA into the nucleus.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	11	 After expression of viral proteins, assembly and release of new virions occurs (Roizman  and  Sears, 1996).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	12	During the replication process, cleavage and packaging of viral DNA are tightly linked functions at least requiring the following seven genes in HSV-1: UL6, UL15, UL17, UL25, UL28, UL32 and UL33 (Poon  and  Roizman, 1993; Taus et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1990; Lamberti  and  Weller, 1996, 1998; al-Kobaisi et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Viruses mutated in one of these genes synthesize near-wild-type levels of viral DNA but fail to cleave and package concatemeric DNA into capsids, resulting in an accumulation of B (intermediate) capsids in infected cells, with the exception of the UL25 mutant, which was shown to cleave newly synthesized viral DNA (McNab et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Moreover, in contrast to the latter study where no packaging of matur DNA was observed, Stow (2001) reported that a significant amount of DNA synthesized by the UL25 mutant was packaged stably into capsids.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	16	To propagate a BHV-1 deletion mutant with a potentially lethal mutation in the UL25 gene to study the function of this gene, it was necessary to develop a complementing cell line expressing the UL25 protein in trans.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	17	 For this purpose, RK13 cells (rabbit kidney cells, ATCC CCL-377) were stably transfected with 2  microg ScaI-linearized pRetroTET-OFF/UL25, encoding the complete UL25 ORF under the control of a tetracycline-regulated promoter (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	18	 A selected cell line grown in the absence of doxycycline, a tetracycline derivative compound (Gossen et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 1995), expressed a 63 kDa protein that reacted specifically with the UL25 antiserum (results not shown; Desloges et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	20	 This polypeptide represents the full-length product of UL25, since its size correlated with that of the protein observed in BHV-1-infected cells (Desloges et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	21	 This cell line, named RK13/UL25+, was used subsequently as a complementing host cell for the construction of a UL25 deletion mutant.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	22	View larger version (33K):    Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The linear genome of BHV-1 is represented at the top with its unique long segment (UL) and its unique short segment (US), the latter being flanked by internal and external inverted repeats (IR and TR, respectively).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The HindIII restriction map of the two possible isomers is shown below.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The UL25 ORF is located within fragment A at positions 6060262398 (in the leftward orientation).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The 4299 bp ApaI to BamHI fragment, representing the region 58917 to 63216 of the viral genome and shown in an expanded view, was subcloned from pKS/Ahd carrying the HindIII fragment A (Simard et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	27	, 1990) to generate pKS/BHV58-63kApa-Bam.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This recombinant plasmid was used as illustrated to create the recombinant eukaryotic expression vector pRetroTET-OFF/UL25 for the development of a cell line inducibly expressing UL25.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The strategy used to generate the recombinant pKS/58-63kUL25/-gal+ plasmid used to create BHV-1UL25 is shown on the right.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The -Gal gene cassette is flanked by the promoter of the gene encoding the BHV-1 gB glycoprotein (pgB) and a consensus polyadenylation signal (pA).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The illustrations below the vertical arrows are not drawn to scale.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	32	  The UL25-encoding sequence is located at positions 6239860602 of the BHV-1 genome.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	33	 To genetically engineer a BHV-1 UL25 deletion mutant, we constructed the plasmid pKS/58-63kUL25/-gal+ from pKS/BHV58-63kApa-Bam, by replacing the SalI fragment encoding aa 86 to 393 of the UL25 protein by a -Gal reporter gene cassette (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In this way, the deletion introduced into UL25 should not alter the expression of neighbouring genes.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The plasmid pKS/58-63kUL25/-gal+ was linearized and used with BHV-1 viral DNA to co-transfect RK13/UL25+ cells grown in the absence of doxycycline (on-state) by the calcium phosphate precipitation method, as described previously (Desloges  and  Simard, 2003).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Regenerated progeny viruses were then plated on RK13/UL25+ cells and tested for their ability to form blue plaques in the presence of the chromogenic compound X-Gal.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	37	 A -Gal-positive mutant virus, designated BHV-1UL25, was plaque-purified five times on RK13/UL25+ cells before virus production.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	38	The known, complete sequence of the wild-type BHV-1 genome allowed us to determine the restriction profiles that were expected for the mutated genome.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	39	 We compared the HindIII restriction profiles of mutant versus BHV-1 DNA-purified, infected cell lysates.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	40	 No divergence between the patterns observed and that expected for the mutant genome was noted (results not shown).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	41	 These findings demonstrate that the -Gal reporter gene cassette interrupts, as intended, the UL25-encoding sequence of the virus mutant.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	42	To verify that the engineered mutant was indeed incapable of expressing the UL25 gene product, we performed Western blotting analyses of protein extracts from RK13 cells infected for different periods of time with either BHV-1 or BHV-1UL25.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	43	 2(A), extracts infected with BHV-1 revealed the presence of an abundant 63 kDa protein, which was detected specifically with the UL25 antiserum, accumulating in cells from 12 to 18 h post-infection (p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	44	 In contrast, the UL25 antiserum detected no protein in extracts from BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells, thus demonstrating that the virus mutant was incapable of expressing the UL25 protein in RK13 cells (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	45	 This protein was absent in lysates prepared in the presence of phosphonoacetic acid (PAA), a DNA synthesis inhibitor, confirming further our previous findings that BHV-1 UL25 belongs to viral genes of the 2 class, since its expression is dependent strictly on viral DNA synthesis (Desloges et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	46	View larger version (12K):    Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Expression of viral proteins and replication kinetics in infected cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	48	 (A, C) RK13 cells were infected with either BHV-1UL25 or BHV-1 at an m.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	49	 of 2 for 0, 6, 12 and 18 h in the presence (+) or absence (-) of PAA.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Protein cell lysates were fractionated on SDS-PAGE, electrotransferred onto a PVDF membrane and then reacted with the BHV-1-specific UL25 antiserum (A) or with a monospecific antiserum directed against the product of the BHV-1 UL48 gene (C).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Sizes in kDa of standards are indicated.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	52	 (B) RK13 cells (closed symbols) and complementing RK13/UL25+ cells (open symbols) were infected synchronously at an m.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	53	 of 5 with either BHV-1 (squares) or BHV-1UL25 (circles).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Cultures were harvested at the indicated times p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	55	 and the mean yield of virus per cell generated in either BHV-1- or BHV-1UL25-infected samples was determined by plaque assays on RK13 and RK13/UL25+ cells, respectively.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	56	  To investigate the consequence of the UL25 defect on the replicative cycle of BHV-1, virus production was examined by establishing one-step growth curves of both BHV-1UL25 and BHV-1 in non-complementing RK13 as well as in complementing RK13/UL25+ cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Cells were infected synchronously with one or the other virus at an m.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	58	 of 5 and then harvested at different times p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	59	, after which the total number of virus particles present either extracellularly or intracellularly in each sample was determined by titration assays, as described previously (Desloges  and  Simard, 2003).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	60	 BHV-1 was capable of replicating efficiently in both RK13 and RK13/UL25+ cells, reaching similar maximal virus yields at 21 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	61	 In contrast, BHV-1UL25 could only replicate in RK13/UL25+ cells, as no progeny was produced in RK13 cells (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	62	 These results demonstrate that the UL25 gene product is necessary for virus replication in non-complementing cells, as was observed also with an HSV-1 UL25 deletion mutant (Ali et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	63	 In addition, the virus yield obtained with BHV-1UL25 on RK13/UL25+ cells was similar to that of BHV-1 virus yield recovered from either cell line, indicating that the RK13/UL25+ cell line was capable of fully complementing the UL25 defect of the mutant virus.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	64	 These results demonstrate that the amount of the UL25 protein within the complementary cell line is sufficient to allow replication of BHV-1UL25 to BHV-1 levels, indicating that no mutations in other essential genes had been introduced during the recombination event giving rise to the mutant.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	65	To identify the step at which the UL25 deletion mutant replication aborts in RK13 cells, we examined whether the mutation compromised the expression of late viral genes products.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	66	 For this purpose, the expression of the BHV-1 gene trans-inducing factor protein encoded by the UL48 gene, a late gene (Misra et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	67	, protein lysates were prepared from BHV-1UL25- and BHV-1-infected RK13 cells and analysed by immunoblot for the presence of the UL48 gene product using a BHV-1-specific UL48 antiserum directed against an Escherichia coli-expressed T7 tag to UL48 fusion protein.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The antiserum detected a 50 kDa protein in lysates collected at 18 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	69	 from both BHV-1UL25- and BHV-1-infected RK13 cells (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Moreover, the production of the UL48 gene product was abrogated by PAA treatment (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	71	 2C, +PAA), confirming further that UL48 is a 2 gene.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Thus, these results demonstrate that the UL25 defect does not impair the expression of viral genes of the 2 class or, consequently, the expression of genes of the earlier classes (, 1, 2 and 1).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	73	 These results also demonstrate indirectly that the mutation does not compromise viral DNA synthesis, since genes whose expression is dependent strictly on viral DNA synthesis (such as UL48) are expressed efficiently.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	74	To obtain direct evidence that the UL25 defect does not compromise viral DNA synthesis in RK13 cells, Southern blotting analysis of HindIII digests of total cell DNA isolated from BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 and RK13/UL25+ cells was performed.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The HindIII fragment N, representing the leftward terminal region of the BHV-1 linear viral genome, was used as probe (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Probe N hybridized to a major 2 4 kbp and two minor non-well-resolved 14 and 15 kbp fragments present in DNA from BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells obtained at 12 and 24 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In contrast, no hybridization signal was observed at 0 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	78	 3A, lane 1), demonstrating that the bands observed represented newly synthesized viral DNA.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The DNA profile observed at 24 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	80	 3A, lane 3) was very similar to that observed in BHV-1UL25-infected RK13/UL25+ cells (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The 2 4 kbp bands common to the two profiles co-migrated with the KpnI to HindIII insert of the recombinant plasmid pKS/Nhd, which harbours the complete HindIII fragment N (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	82	 3A, lane 5), demonstrating that these bands represented the leftward terminal 2 4 kbp HindIII fragment N of the BHV-1 linear genome.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The sizes of the other two bands correlated to those expected for head-to-tail HindIII genomic fragments (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	84	 1, N to F and N to H head-to-tail fragments are in the range of 14 and 15 kbp, respectively), indicating the presence within infected cell lysates of viral DNA, which was in the form of either immature DNA concatemers or of circular unit-length genomes, or both.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Interestingly, the levels of the 2 4 kbp fragment observed were similar in the two cell lines.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	86	 These findings indicate that DNA replication of BHV-1UL25 is as effective in RK13 cells as in complementing RK13/UL25+ cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Moreover, the much higher abundance of terminal versus head-to-tail HindIII fragments indicate that mutant viral DNA synthesized in infected cells is processed efficiently into linear unit-length genomes.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	88	View larger version (56K):    Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Synthesis, processing and packaging of BHV-1UL25 DNA.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	90	 (A) Total DNA extracts from RK13 and RK13/UL25+ cell lysates infected with BHV-1UL25 for different times p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	91	 were purified, digested with HindIII and then analysed by Southern blotting.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The blot was hybridized with a DIG-labelled probe representing the leftward HindIII terminal fragment N of the BHV-1 linear viral genome (see Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Lane 5 contains a HindIII digest of purified BHV-1 DNA.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The blot was reacted with a chemiluminescent substrate and then exposed to X-ray films for 16 h.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Sizes in kbp of standards are indicated.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	96	 (B) BHV-1-infected RK13 cells (upper left panel), BHV-1UL25-infected RK13/UL25+ cells (upper right panel) and BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells (lower panels) were fixed at 18 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Thin sections were prepared for electron microscopy analysis.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In the lower left panel, the arrowhead points to an empty A capsid, whereas the tailed arrow points to an intermediate B capsid.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	99	 In the lower right panel, the arrow points to a full C capsid.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Magnification, x70 000; bars, 100 nm.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	101	  To determine whether mutant viral DNA is packaged into capsids, thin sections of BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 and RK13/UL25+ cells as well as BHV-1-infected RK13 cells, collected at 18 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	102	, were examined by transmission electron microscopy to assess the presence of full (C), intermediate (B) and empty (A) capsids, as described previously (Desloges  and  Simard, 2003).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Significant numbers of all three capsid types were found on sections from both BHV-1-infected RK13 cells (A capsids, 35 7 %; B capsids, 16 7 %; C capsids, 47 6 %) and BHV-1UL25-infected RK13/UL25+ cells (A capsids, 29 6 %; B capsids, 51 7 %; C capsids, 18 7 %).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Each of these infected cell samples (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	105	 3B, upper left and right panels, respectively) presented several C capsids surrounded by a bilayer envelope.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	106	 In contrast, most of the capsids in BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells were of types A and B (40 0 and 57 2 %, respectively), as illustrated in Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	107	 3(B, lower left panel), showing an accumulation of both capsid types in infected cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The generation of empty A capsids devoid of both DNA and internal structure is believed to result from an abortive packaging event.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Abortive packaging has been observed also in mutants of the dsDNA bacteriophage P22, which presents similarities to alphaherpesviruses concerning the DNA packaging and capsid assembly process.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	110	 In Salmonella cells infected with mutants of phage P22 defective in genes 4, 10 and 26, it was shown that the procapsids are assembled and that viral concatemeric DNA is packaged but that the newly filled capsids are unstable and lose their DNA (Strauss  and  King, 1984).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The phenotype observed in bacterial cells infected with these mutants is an accumulation of empty A capsids, similar to those observed in BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	112	However, careful examination of these infected cells revealed the presence of few electron-dense cored C capsids (2 8 %).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	113	 3(B, lower right panel), in which a complete enveloped C capsid is shown in the extracellular compartment of BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	114	 It was reported previously that the HSV-1 UL25 mutant (KUL25NS) does not package matur DNA (McNab et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Recently, Stow (2001) detected successfully low levels of KUL25NS DNA being packaged and retained into capsids.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The latter findings are corroborated in the present study by the observation of few full C capsids in electron micrographs of thin sections of BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, it appears that these enveloped C capsids were either non-infectious or their number was too low for cytopathogenesis, as no virus was detected in one-step growth curve analyses.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Also, it could be that UL25 mutant genomes are packaged efficiently into capsids but are released subsequently and then degraded rapidly, as suggested by Stow (2001).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	119	In summary, we describe the engineering and characterization of a UL25 deletion mutant of BHV-1.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Our results show that the mutant is not impaired in its ability to synthesize viral proteins and to replicate and cleave viral DNA into unit-length genomes.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Moreover, the mutant is still able to encapsidate viral DNA, albeit at very low levels.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Further studies will be required to elucidate more precisely the role played by UL25 in the encapsidation process and especially in the stabilization of the packaged DNA into the capsid.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	123	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   The authors wish to thank N.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Gagnon for her excellent technical assistance, R.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Alain for his appreciated help in electron microscopy experiments and L.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Bello for kindly providing the -Gal cassette.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	127	 This work was funded by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) and by the Conseil des Recherches en Peche et en Agroalimentaire du Quebec (CORPAQ).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	128	 was supported by NSERC, by the Fonds pour la Formation de Chercheurs et l'Aide a la Recherche (FCAR) and by the Fondation Armand-Frappier.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	0	Tripartite Hemolysin BL from Bacillus cereus HEMOLYTIC ANALYSIS OF COMPONENT INTERACTIONS AND A MODEL FOR ITS CHARACTERISTIC PARADOXICAL ZONE PHENOMENON*.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	1	(Received for publication, June 25, 1996, and in revised form, October 11, 1996).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Food Research Institute, Department of Food Microbiology and Toxicology, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin 53706 ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION FOOTNOTES Acknowledgments REFERENCES.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	3	Hemolysin BL (HBL) is a unique membrane-lytic toxin from Bacillus cereus composed of three distinct proteins, designated B, L1, and L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	4	 HBL produces a paradoxical zone phenomenon in gel diffusion assays in sheep blood agar.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Lysis does not begin immediately adjacent to the source of diffusion; rather, it begins several millimeters away.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Cells near the source and at intersections of lysis zones remain intact longer.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Here, we developed a spectrophotometric hemolysis assay system that measures the activities of the individual HBL components and used it to analyze the mechanisms of hemolysis and the paradoxical zone phenomenon.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The B component was rate-limiting, and erythrocytes were slowly primed by B at an optimal concentration of about 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	9	3 nM to rapid lytic action by the combination of the L components (L1+2).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	10	 All of the individual components bound to cells independently, and membrane-associated HBL components were neutralized by specific antibodies, suggesting that lysis was caused by formation of a membrane attack complex on the cell surface.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Osmotic protection experiments indicate a colloid osmotic lysis mechanism.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Concentrations of the B component above 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	13	3 nM caused inhibition of L1-mediated lysis, and L1 inhibited the priming reaction of B over a similar concentration range.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	14	 From analyses of spectrophotometric and diffusion assays we constructed a basic model for the interactions between HBL components and for the paradoxical zone phenomenon in blood agar.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In the latter, areas of slow lysis near diffusion sources are caused primarily by the accumulation of inhibitory levels of L1 reached before cells are primed by B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	16	Bacillus cereus secretes hemolysin BL (HBL),1 a membrane-lytic system composed of three antigenically distinct proteins thought to contribute to diarrheal food poisoning (1) and necrotizing infections such as endophthalmitis (2).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Separately, the HBL components are nontoxic, but when combined they exhibit a variety of toxic activities including hemolysis, cytotoxicity, vascular permeability, dermonecrosis, enterotoxicity, and ocular toxicity (1, 2, 3, 4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	18	 When HBL diffuses from a bacterial colony or a well in blood agar, it produces an unusual discontinuous hemolysis pattern (5), called a paradoxical zone phenomenon (6).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Lysis begins away from the well or colony, followed by slow lysis nearer the source (5).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	20	 A similar zone phenomenon is seen in spectrophotometric assays in which there is decreased hemolysis at HBL concentrations above a maximally effective dose (4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	21	HBL is the first known three-component bacterial toxin.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The components are designated B, L1, and L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	23	2 kDa, and their pI values are 5.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	24	33 (4), as determined electrophoretically.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The genes for all three components have been cloned, and the sequences have been determined (7, 8).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The amino acid sequences predicted from the nucleotide sequences are in complete agreement with published N-terminal amino acid sequences determined chemically (4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	27	 All of the proteins appear unique and exhibit no significant similarity with other known proteins.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The three genes are immediately adjacent to one another, apparently in an operon (8).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Methods for purification of relatively large quantities of pure HBL components were developed only recently (4); therefore, little is known about the mode of action of HBL at the molecular level.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	30	Here we present a novel hemolysis assay system that has provided significant insight into the mechanism and interactions of HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	31	 These assays are based on a fundamental difference between the activities of the B and L components and allow analysis of the activities of the individual HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	32	 When sheep erythrocytes were treated with B they did not lyse, but they slowly became primed to lysis by the combination of the two L components (L1+2).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The discrete proportion of cells primed at a given time could be used as a measure of the activity of B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The priming reaction, which took less than 1 h at 42  degrees C could be nearly stopped by reducing the temperature to 22  degrees C or below, creating a quasistable population of B-primed red blood cells (RBC-B).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The addition of L1+2 to RBC-B at 22  degrees C caused rapid lysis of cells that was over 3000 times faster than the priming rate at that temperature.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Consequently, numerous samples of the L components could be analyzed against an RBC-B preparation with little change in the primed cells.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	37	All three HBL components bound to erythrocytes independently of the others.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Complete neutralization of membrane-bound L components by specific antibodies suggest that HBL causes hemolysis via the interaction of at least the L components in a "membrane attack complex" and not by enzymatic degradation of the membrane.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Osmotic protection experiments indicated that lysis was by a colloid osmotic mechanism through transmembrane pores.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	40	Analysis also indicated that concentrations of B above 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	41	3 nM caused inhibition of the lysis of RBC-B by L1 in the presence of L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Conversely, excess L1 inhibited the priming reaction of B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The data suggest that B and L1 each inhibit the other above a threshold concentration relative to the concentration of a membrane component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The L2 component was required for lysis, but it exhibited little or no interference with the other components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	45	From these observations we propose a model for the paradoxical zone phenomenon seen in gel diffusion assays.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Hemolysis is slow near the HBL source because excess (and therefore inhibitory) concentrations of B and L1 accumulate before cells can be primed by B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The initial location of lysis occurs at a point at which the diffusion rate has decreased enough so that the rate of priming by B exceeds the rate at which excess components accumulate.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	48	Erythrocytes, HBL Components, and Antibodies.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	49	Except for the osmotic protection experiments described below, all protein and red blood cell (RBC) preparations were in Tris-buffered saline (TBS), pH 7.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	50	4, containing 50 mM Tris-Cl and 150 mM NaCl.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Pure HBL components were purified as described previously (4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The concentrations of the components in stock solutions were determined by absorbance at 280 nm through a 1-cm light path using extinction coefficients of 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	53	83 for B, L1, and L2, respectively (1).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Sheep RBCs were washed in TBS by centrifugation until the supernatant was colorless and then held on ice until use the same day.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Neutralization experiments were carried out with IgG fractions of specific polyclonal antisera described previously (1).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The IgG fractions were purified with a fast protein liquid chromatography system, using a Protein G-Superose column as per the instructions of the manufacturer (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	57	 When tested in double immunodiffusion and dot blot assays, the titers of the antibodies to components B and L2 were roughly equal and were 2-4 times higher than those of the antibodies to L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The antibodies were highly specific for their respective antigens and exhibited no cross-reactivity to the other HBL components in double immunodiffusion assays or on Western blots.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	59	Osmotic protection experiments were performed essentially as described by Moayeri and Welch (9).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	60	 All samples had final compositions of 2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	61	75 nM concentrations of each HBL component in 25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	62	4, containing isotonic concentrations of NaCl (154 mM) or carbohydrates (270 mM each) of different sizes.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Carbohydrates used were ribose, fucose, glucose, maltose, and maltotriose, with respective molecular weights of 150.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Assuming that the dimensions of these carbohydrates are the same as those reported (9) for carbohydrates of identical molecular weights, their molecular diameters are 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Hemolysis was initiated by the addition of 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	66	9 ml of preparations containing HBL and the respective carbohydrates or controls.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The samples were held at 37  degrees C for 75 min and then centrifuged.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Hemolysis was determined by the absorbance of the supernatants at 540 nm.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Percentage of hemolysis was calculated by comparing the absorbances of the samples with positive (100% lysis by saponin) and negative controls containing NaCl and no HBL (6).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	70	 All samples were prepared in triplicate.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	71	Spectrophotometric Determination of the Activities of the B and L Components of HBL.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	72	 1 depicts the main steps and reactions in the assay of the HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Standard RBC suspensions, consisting of 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	74	3  x  107 cells ml1 were prepared by diluting washed cells into TBS such that the optical density (OD) at 630 nm through a 1-cm path length was 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Below this value, the OD630 was directly proportional to the number of intact cells present.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Naive standardized RBCs were primed to the lytic action of the L components by treatment with the B component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Cells in the B-primed state are referred to as RBC-B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The priming reaction (reaction 1 in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	79	 1) was conducted for desired times or until all RBCs were primed (100% RBC-B), at 42  degrees C with 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	80	3 nM B, unless otherwise indicated.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	81	 After priming, the cells were cooled to 22  degrees C, and lysis was initiated in 1-ml cuvettes by the addition of 7  microl of the L component stock (100 times the desired final concentration) to 693  microl of RBC-B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	82	 1) was measured continually by the decrease of the OD630 over time.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The activity of the B component was measured as the proportion of cells primed (%RBC-B; Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	84	 This proportion was evident as a distinct terminal plateau in the lysis curve, and proportion of primed cells was estimated as illustrated in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	85	 For some samples with low hemolytic activity, the terminal plateau was approached gradually over a long assay period.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In these cases the plateau was measured at the point at which the OD630 did not change for at least 12 s.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Spectrophotometric determination of the activities of the B and L components of HBL.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	88	 A, a representation of steps comprising the spectrophotometric hemolysis assay for individual HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In reaction 1 standardized RBC (1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	90	3  x  107 RBC ml1) are treated with 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	91	 During this treatment, RBC do not lyse; rather, they slowly become primed to the lytic action of the combined L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The priming reaction is "stopped" by cooling the cells to 22  degrees C or below, and primed cells (RBC-B) are distributed to cuvettes.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The addition of the combination of the two L components (L1+2) produces reaction 2, the rapid lysis of RBC-B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	94	  , the absorbance of primed RBC is generally lower than the starting OD value due to slight dilution with sample and a small amount of spontaneous lysis, but OD does not differ from that of untreated control cells.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	95	 B, the graph is a time trace of the lysis of B-primed cells upon the addition of L1+2, illustrating reaction 2 from panel A.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Cells underwent priming (reaction 1) at 37  degrees C for 60, 100, and 145 min as indicated above each curve.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	97	 After cooling, lysis was initiated by the simultaneous addition of 2 nM of each of the two L components at t = 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The decrease over time in OD630 in each curve is due to hemolysis of RBC-B by L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The difference between the starting OD value and the plateau on each curve reflects the discrete proportion of erythrocytes that are primed (%RBC-B) at a given time.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The values for the maximum hemolysis velocity (OD630 min1) are shown beside each curve.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Velocity varies directly with the concentration of L1+2 for a given RBC-B preparation and is used as a measure of L activity.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	102	 C, priming reaction of B at 42, 37, and 22  degrees C.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Cells underwent reaction 1 at 42, 37, or 22  degrees C for the times indicated on the x axis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	104	 %RBC-B was calculated from the terminal plateaus of lysis curves in reaction 2 of the HBL assay.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	105	 *, values corresponding to the lysis curves shown in B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	106	 [View Larger Version of this Image (32K GIF file)].
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	107	Stabilization of RBC-B and Comparison of Lytic Samples.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	108	With the standard concentrations of B and RBC, the priming rate at 42  degrees C was about 4.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	109	7% RBC-B min1, and at 22  degrees C the rate was only about 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	110	04% RBC-B min1 (2 to 3% h1) (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	111	 1C), and priming was not detectable at 0  degrees C.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Practically, this means that the priming reaction can be nearly stopped at 22  degrees C.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Since the L components cause rapid lysis of RBC-B at 22  degrees C, multiple samples tested sequentially on temperature-stabilized RBC-B can be compared under the assumption that the cells are identically primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	114	The gel diffusion assay was performed, and the blood agar gel was prepared as described previously (5).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Each well (3-mm diameter) received 4 pmol (about 150 ng) of the appropriate HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The gel was photographed after 8 h at 24  degrees C.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	117	Osmotic Protection from Lysis by HBL.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	118	It is generally thought that pore-forming hemolysins cause lysis by a colloid osmotic mechanism.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	119	 When pores form in the membrane, external solutes that are smaller than the pores enter the cell, creating an osmotic gradient.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	120	 This in turn produces a net flow of water into the cell, which swells and lyses from excess osmotic pressure.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Osmotic protection experiments are the standard methods for detecting colloid osmotic lysis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Theoretically, if pores of defined size are produced, and the diameters of the external solutes are larger than the diameters of the pores, those solutes cannot enter the cell.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	123	 This prevents the production of an osmotic gradient, thereby protecting cells from lysis (9).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	124	Hemolysis due to HBL decreased in the presence of isotonic concentrations of carbohydrates of increasing size as shown in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	125	 These results indicate that HBL lyses cells by a colloid-osmotic mechanism and suggest that, under these conditions, functional pores of 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	126	 This pore size should only be considered a rough estimate, because calculated values vary greatly with assay conditions (9).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Osmotic protection of sheep erythrocytes from HBL by carbohydrates of increasing size.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Sheep erythrocytes were suspended in isosmotic concentrations of NaCl or carbohydrates of increasing sizes as indicated and treated with 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The percentage of cells lysed was determined after 75 min at 37  degrees C.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Additional experimental details are provided under "Experimental Procedures.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	131	" [View Larger Version of this Image (20K GIF file)].
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	132	The Slow Priming Reaction of the B Component Versus the Rapid Lytic Reaction of L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	133	RBC did not lyse when treated with isolated B, but became primed to the lytic action of the combined L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	134	 1B depicts three lysis curves generated by the simultaneous addition of both L components (L1+2) to RBC that had been treated at 37  degrees C for the times indicated above each curve.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The difference between the starting OD and that of the terminal plateau following the lysis phase in each curve, measures the discrete proportion of cells primed by B to lytic action by L1+2 (%RBC-B).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	136	 This value at 42, 37, and 22  degrees C (by 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	137	3 nM B) is plotted versus time in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Note that the time scale is in hours for the priming reaction (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	139	 1C) and in seconds for the lysis reaction of primed cells by L1+2 (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The priming reaction of B at 47, 37, and 22  degrees C was, respectively, 1, 2, and 3 orders of magnitude lower than the lysis velocity of 100% RBC-B caused by comparable concentrations of L1+2 at 22  degrees C.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	141	 This slow priming rate of B corresponds to the slow hemolysis reaction that occurs in the presence all three HBL components (4), which required more than 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	142	5 h for complete lysis at 37  degrees C.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	143	 This shows that the priming reaction of the B component is the rate-limiting step of HBL hemolysis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	144	Independent Binding of L Components to RBC and Neutralization of Membrane-bound L Components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	145	Naive RBC were treated at 22  degrees C for 20 min with 5, 10, or 50 nM L1 or 5 nM L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The cells were washed twice by centrifugation with cold TBS such that the free L concentration was reduced by a factor of at least 5  x  105.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Washed cells were then diluted to an OD630 of 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The washed L-treated RBC and naive RBC, were then primed at 42  degrees C with B for 1 h, as described above.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Lysis was initiated by the addition of the appropriate L component (5 nM) as indicated in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Independent binding to RBC of the L1 and L2 components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Standardized naive RBC were pretreated with either L1 (top) or L2 (bottom) at the concentrations indicated beside each curve.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The L-treated cells were washed and then primed with B for 1 h.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Lysis of primed cells was initiated at t = 0 by the addition of 5 nM L2 to the L1-treated cells (top) or 5 nM L1 to the L2-treated cells (bottom).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The control samples were naive RBCs that were not pretreated with L1 or L2 but were primed with B for 1 h.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Each L component was added to a separate control sample at t = 0, and then lysis was initiated after 300 s by the addition of the complementary L component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	156	 [View Larger Version of this Image (31K GIF file)].
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	157	Cells that were pretreated with either L component and then primed with B lysed upon the addition of the complementary L component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Control RBC-B without pretreatment with an L component did not lyse upon the addition of either L component, but lysed rapidly upon the subsequent addition of the complementary L component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Pretreatment with L1 was less effective than with L2, possibly due to a lower affinity of L1 for RBC.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	160	Neutralization of Membrane-associated HBL Components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	161	In the experiment depicted in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	162	 3, specific neutralizing antibodies to L1 and L2 were added at t = 0 to RBC-B-L1 (5 nM L1) and RBC-B-L2 (5 nM L2), respectively.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Each antibody completely inhibited lysis by the complementary L component for at least 1 h.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	164	When specific antibodies to the B component were mixed with B prior to the addition to naive RBC, the priming reaction was completely inhibited.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	165	 However, when those antibodies were added after the priming reaction (i.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	166	 added to 100% RBC-B) there was only partial inhibition of lysis of by L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The simultaneous addition of L1+2 and the B-specific antibodies to RBC-B resulted in about 30% inhibition of lysis velocity (see point at t = 0 in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Pretreatment of RBC-B with the antibodies increased inhibition of lysis in a time-dependent manner (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Inhibition also increased with increasing antibody dose (data not shown).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	170	 As a control, the L1+2 preparation was treated with the anti-B antibody prior to the addition to RBC-B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	171	 There was no significant effect on inhibition of lysis although the concentration of antibody exposed to L1+2 was 100 times that exposed to RBC-B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	172	 This indicates that the inhibitory effect of the antibody was due to interaction with B on the surface of RBC-B and not due to an interaction with the L1+2 preparation.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	173	 These results demonstrate a detectable difference between B in the unprimed versus the primed state.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Inhibition of L-induced lysis of RBC-B by antibodies specific for component B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Hemolysis of 100% RBC-B was initiated by the addition of L1+2 in the presence or absence of specific antibodies to the B component of HBL.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The antibodies were preincubated with either the RBC-B cells or with the L1+2 preparation to distinguish whether inhibition was specific for B or due to cross-reaction with L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The x axis indicates the time that the RBC-B or L1+2 was preincubated with the antibodies.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	178	 At t = 0 on the x axis the antibodies, L1+2, and RBC-B were all mixed simultaneously.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Circles, RBC-B were incubated with antibodies before the addition of L1+2 for the times indicated on the x axis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Squares, L1+2 was incubated with antibodies before the addition to RBC-B for the times indicated on the x axis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The inhibitory activity of the antibodies is expressed on the y axis as the percentage by which the maximum lysis velocity was decreased compared with simultaneously run control samples containing no antibody (% inhibition).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	182	 [View Larger Version of this Image (21K GIF file)].
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	183	Inhibition of Hemolysis by Excess Component B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	184	We previously found that, when equal concentrations of all three HBL components were simultaneously varied, hemolysis exhibited a paradoxical zone phenomenon (4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Hemolysis was higher within a certain low concentration range than at higher concentrations.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The effect of the concentration of the B component on the priming rate of B and the lysis velocity of L1+2 is illustrated in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The extent of priming and the L-induced lysis velocity were both maximal around 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	188	 When the time course of priming at 37  degrees C was followed, the maximum priming rate at the inflection point of the sigmoidal priming curve was 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	189	5 nM B, supporting the idea that there is an antagonistic effect of excess B on itself (not shown).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	190	5 nM B, the priming rate increased slightly, but lysis velocity was further inhibited.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Inhibition of L1-induced lysis by excess component B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	192	 A, effect of the concentration of B on the priming reaction of B and the lysis velocity of L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Erythrocytes were primed at 37  degrees C for 60 min with the B concentrations indicated on the x axis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Lysis was initiated by the addition of 5 nM L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The percentage of primed cells (%RBC-B) and lysis velocity were measured as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	196	" B, inhibition of hemolysis of RBC-B by Bi.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Bi (5 nM) was added to primed erythrocytes prior to, simultaneously with, or following L1+2 (2 nM).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The labels for each curve indicate the time (min) at which Bi was added relative to t = 0 on the x axis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Inset, plot of percentage of inhibition of velocity versus the time of the addition of Bi.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	200	 C, inhibition of L1 and not L2 by Bi.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Lysis curves A and B were generated by the addition of L components to 100% RBC-B at 0 s and 180 s (closed arrow) in the order indicated beside each curve.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	202	 When excess B was added at 0 s, inhibition of both A and B occurred.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	203	 However, when Bi was added at 180 s, inhibition occurred for B and not for A.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	204	 , the percentage of inhibition of the lysis velocity of curve A (L1 at 0 s; L2 at 180 s) that occurred when Bi was added between 0 and 180 s.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	205	 For each symbol, the abscissa corresponds to the time at which Bi was added, and the ordinate corresponds to the percentage of inhibition for that sample.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Open arrow, the point at which RBC-B were completely lysed by the addition at t = 0 s of the combination of both L components (2 nM).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	207	 [View Larger Version of this Image (22K GIF file)].
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	208	The inhibitory effect of excess B on L1+2 was observed even when B was added to previously primed erythrocytes (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Erythrocytes were completely primed (100% RBC-B) and stabilized, and then excess B (an inhibitory concentration, Bi) was added prior to, simultaneously with, or following L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The addition of Bi simultaneously with L1+2 resulted in nearly 60% inhibition of the lysis velocity.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Inhibition did not increase if B was preincubated with RBC-B, and inhibition decreased drastically when B was added after L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	212	 This indicates that under these conditions, B did not alter the cell surface, but it did interfere either with the binding or an intermediate step of one or both L components, and B did not interfere with lysis once binding or an intermediate step occurred.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	213	The sequential addition of L1, L2, and Bi to RBC-B in various permutations indicated that Bi inhibits L1 and not L2 (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	214	 When either L component was added to RBC-B, the cells did not lyse until the second L was added (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	215	 When Bi was added at t = 0, lysis was inhibited regardless of the order of addition of the L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	216	 But when Bi was added with an L component at t = 180 s, inhibition only occurred when L1 was added at that time (curve B), suggesting that B interferes with L1 and not L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	217	 With respect to curve A (L1 at 0 s, L2 at 180 s), Bi inhibited lysis when added at 0 s but not when added at 180 s.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The kinetics of the loss of inhibitory activity of Bi is graphically illustrated by the closed circle scatter plot in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	219	 When L1 was added first (at t = 0), less inhibition occurred the later Bi was added until no inhibition occurred at 180 s.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	220	RBC were primed by B in the presence of increasing concentrations of either L1 or L2, and the extent of priming was measured by the addition of the complementary L component (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	221	 L1 drastically inhibited the priming reaction above ~1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The inhibition dose response was very similar to the inhibition of L1 by B in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The priming reaction of B could be inhibited by adding an excess concentration of L1 at any time before 100% RBC-B occurred (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The L2 component did not significantly inhibit the priming reaction in the concentration range tested, just as Bi did not inhibit L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Inhibition of component B by excess L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	226	 A, effect of the concentrations of L1 and L2 on the priming reaction of B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	227	 RBCs were primed at 42  degrees C with 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	228	3 mM B in the presence of either L1 or L2 at the concentrations indicated on the x axis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The extent of priming was measured after 1 h by the addition of the complementary L component (5 nM) to lyse susceptible cells as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	230	" Inset, inhibition of the B component by the addition of L1 (5 nM) at any time during priming.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Excess L1 was either not added (circles) or added at 5 (squares) or 15 min (triangles) as indicated by the arrows.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The extent of priming (%RBC-B) was determined at the times indicated on the x axis by the addition of L2 to RBC-B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	233	 B, inhibition of hemolysis in a gel diffusion assay by excess L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Lack of lysis was observed within the intersections of HBL hemolysis zones.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The diffusion assay was performed, and the blood agar gel was prepared as described previously (10).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Each well (3-mm diameter) received 4 pmol (~150 ng) of the respective HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Wells labeled H received all three HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The remaining wells received components B, L1, and L2 as indicated.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The gel was photographed after 8 h at 24  degrees C.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	240	 [View Larger Version of this Image (46K GIF file)].
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	241	An implication of the above observations is that, in blood agar, the inhibition of lysis near the HBL diffusion source and at the intersections of lysis zones (10) is a function of the mutual inhibitory activity between B and L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	242	 To test this idea, the separated components were added to wells adjacent to wells containing all three components (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Consistent with the above observations, the L1 component inhibited lysis in the adjacent zone, and the L2 component had no apparent effect on the adjacent pattern.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Lysis was enhanced adjacent to the B component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	245	 This superficially contradicts the observation that excess B inhibits lysis by L1, but it is consistent with the overall kinetics of the system, as discussed below.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	246	Among the greater than 300 described bacterial toxins, there are several that require two different, individually soluble, proteins for toxic activity (11) but none that require three components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	247	 These binary toxins include staphylococcal -hemolysin and the related leukocidins (12, 13); anthrax toxin (14); Clostridium botulinum C2 and the related toxins of Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium spiroforme, and Clostridium difficile (15); and Bacillus sphaericus binary toxin (16).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	248	 For all of these (except possibly the B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	249	 sphaericus toxin), the components exhibit a compulsory cell-binding order.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Also the protective antigen of anthrax toxin, which acts as a docking protein, must be cleaved by a cellular protease before the complementary proteins will bind.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The observations presented here allowed us to address related questions about the mechanism of HBL and helped answer three basic questions.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Does HBL cause lysis enzymatically or by formation of a membrane attack complex? Do the HBL components act randomly or in a compulsory order? What is the basis for the paradoxical zone phenomenon exhibited by HBL?.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	253	Hemolysins are thought to lyse cells by two general mechanisms (17).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	254	 First, the cell surface may be enzymatically altered to an extent that causes membrane degeneration.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	255	 This usually involves phospholipases, and there are numerous examples of hemolysis that require two enzymes acting in a compulsory order (18).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	256	 In some systems a phospholipase acts on the cell, which is subsequently lysed by a nonphospholipase enzyme or nonenzymatic protein.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	257	 In the second hemolysis mechanism, lysin molecules insert into the membrane and form functional transmembrane pores (19), or "leaky patches" (20).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Such lesions are generally composed of oligomers of one protein or multiple proteins.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Complement is an example of a lytic system that produces lesions composed of more than one different protein.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Complement lesions are called membrane attack complexes (MACs) to account for their multicomponent composition (21).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Hemolysins may also exhibit detergent-like activity and "solubilize" membranes, but this mechanism may not occur for hemolytic proteins (17).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	262	 3 demonstrates that both L components bound to erythrocyte membranes independently of any other HBL component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	263	 After priming of L1- or L2-treated and washed cells by B, the addition of antibodies specific to either membrane-bound L component completely neutralized hemolysis by the complementary L component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	264	 This indicates that the L components remained associated with the membranes after washing and that each needed to be present for a competent lytic lesion to be formed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	265	 It also strongly suggests that a competent lesion is only formed when L1 and L2 physically interact on the cell surface, which, by definition, describes a MAC.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	266	 If the L components were simple enzymes that caused lysis by independently damaging membranes, then antibodies to an L component would not reverse the membrane damage and protect cells from lysis by the other HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	267	 It appears, therefore, that HBL ultimately causes lysis by forming a lesion analogous to a complement MAC that has a minimum structure consisting of an L1-L2 heterodimer.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Osmotic protection of erythrocytes treated with HBL (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	269	 2) suggests that the putative MAC results in formation of transmembrane pores but does not indicate whether the pores are protein-lined or simply perturbations of the phospholipid bilayer surrounding the HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	270	Antibodies specific for the B component also interfered with the ability of the L components to lyse B-primed cells (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	271	 4), suggesting that L components interact with B to form an integral three-component heteromeric membrane lesion.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	272	 However, although the anti-B antibodies completely neutralized the autonomous priming reaction of B, they could only partially inhibit lysis once cells were primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	273	 If HBL lysis does involve a three-component MAC, there are several possibilities as to what might occur during the priming reaction that decreases the ability of the anti-B antibodies to neutralize lysis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	274	 During priming, the B component may insert into the membrane, possibly forming oligomers.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	275	 This would allow antibodies to bind only to exposed portions of B and not to portions sequestered within the membrane.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Any conformational changes experienced by B might also decrease the avidity of antibodies prepared to its native conformation.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	277	 It is also possible that B is altered by a membrane component, such as occurs in the proteolytic processing of the protective antigen component of anthrax toxin (14).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Antibodies prepared to native B may bind poorly to the processed version.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	279	The inability of anti-B antibodies to completely neutralize lysis of RBC-B by L1+2 might also be diagnostic of an enzymatic mechanism for B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	280	 A situation can be envisioned in which B binds to a membrane and converts a substrate to a product that is subsequently recognized by the L components, leading to lysis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	281	 If the product was to accumulate in a pool in the immediate vicinity of the membrane-bound B, partial inhibition might occur if B-associated antibody sterically prevented access of L components to the product.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Such a mechanism seems rather unlikely, but it cannot be ruled out with present observations.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	283	The next question addressed by our data is whether the HBL components act in an ordered or random manner.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	284	 1 and 3 that all three HBL components bind to erythrocytes independently (i.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	285	 However, as pointed out by Ponder in 1948 (6), hemolysis is a relatively complex multistep process.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Pore assembly models for staphylococcal -toxin and for streptolysin O provide examples of such a multistep process (22).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	287	 -Toxin monomers bind to membranes, diffuse laterally into a prepore complex on the membrane surface, and subsequently insert and form pores.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	288	 SLO also binds as monomers and then undergoes a rate-limiting nucleation process involving formation of dimers on the membrane surface, followed by dimer insertion, and then rapid accumulation of monomers around the dimer nucleus to form the functional lesion.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The complexity of these processes demonstrates that simple association of toxin components with erythrocytes does not provide a picture of the overall hemolysis mechanism.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	290	Our evidence suggests that HBL components form pores after they form a complex.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The L1 and L2 components rapidly contribute to the complex in a manner that does not appear to depend on the sequence of their addition.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	292	 However, the B component clearly must undergo an autonomous, rate-limiting reaction before a functional lesion can be formed with the L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Therefore, although all of the components bind independently to the cell, final lesion formation appears to follow a specific order with respect to the B and L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	294	 It is possible that the appearance of an ordered reaction is an artifact of the kinetics of the individual components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	295	 All of the components might undergo analogous independent priming reactions, with the reaction of B being extremely slow relative to the reactions of the L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	296	 However, our data suggest that the priming process followed by B is fundamentally different from those followed by the L components, because antibodies could completely protect cells when reacted with either membrane-associated L component, but not when reacted with B-primed cells.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	297	The cause of the paradoxical zone phenomenon of HBL is the third major mechanistic question addressed by these data.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	298	 5 and 6 indicate that B and L1 are mutually inhibitory above a threshold concentration and that this antagonism is responsible for the paradoxical hemolysis behavior seen in gel diffusion and suspension assays.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	299	In a dose-response curve for the priming reaction of B (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	300	 5A), the lysis velocity (reaction 2 in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	301	 1A) of L1+2 decreased with increasing concentrations of B even when most cells were primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	302	 5B shows that lysis velocity could be inhibited even if Bi was added after cells were completely primed (100% RBC-B).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The inhibition of lysis did not increase if RBC-B were pretreated with Bi (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	304	 5B, inset), indicating that inhibition was not due to an enzymatic action of Bi on the cells.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Inhibition decreased, however, if Bi was added after L1 (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	306	 5, B and C), indicating that Bi interferes with the incorporation of L1 into the lesion and not with the function of a preformed lesion.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	307	The kinetics of the inhibition of L1 by B in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Inhibition decreased linearly with time (r = 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	309	 This suggests a first order process for the incorporation of L1 into lesions, which is in distinct contrast to the complex shape of hemolysis curves.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	310	 This type of measurement was possible only because of the special situation in which B does not appear to interfere with lysis once L1 has been incorporated into a lesion.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	311	 6 shows that, above a threshold concentration, L1 also inhibited the priming reaction of B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The dose-response of L1-mediated inhibition of the priming reaction was nearly identical to that for inhibition of L1 by excess B (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	313	 In addition, excess L1 inhibited hemolysis caused by HBL placed in adjacent wells in blood agar (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	314	The hemolysis data presented here provide an explanation for the paradoxical zone phenomenon of HBL and the lysis patterns seen in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	315	 HBL hemolysis in blood agar is discontinuous and begins away from a well containing the components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	316	 However, diffusing molecules create a continuous concentration gradient, and the components must therefore reach a concentration that promotes hemolysis at every point between the well edge and the zone in which lysis begins; this is the paradox, and we propose the following model to explain it.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	317	 A cell will not lyse unless it has been primed by B, and maximal priming occurs only at permissive concentrations of B and L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	318	 When membrane-bound B or L1 exceeds a critical ratio versus a membrane constituent, the other component is inhibited from forming a functional lesion (or perhaps produces an inefficient lesion).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Priming by B is slow and, since L1 can inhibit B at any time during the reaction (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	320	 6A, insert), priming is inhibited near a well when L1 diffuses rapidly enough to accumulate to inhibitory levels before cells are primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Hemolysis only begins in a zone in which the B concentration is high enough to prime cells, but the diffusion rate of L1 is too low for it to reach an inhibitory concentration before the cells are primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Inhibition at the intersections of zones is due to accumulation of excess L1 before cells are primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	323	 It is unlikely that inhibition is caused by an excess ratio of B to L1 or vice versa, because a paradoxical zone phenomenon occurs in suspension assays simply by increasing the concentration of all three components at a constant ratio of each to the others (4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	324	The influence on hemolysis patterns of the inhibitory effect of L1 is seen in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Just as lysis is inhibited at the intersections of HBL hemolysis zones, lysis was also inhibited at the intersection of an HBL hemolysis zone and an L1 diffusion zone.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	326	 6A, L2 had no appreciable effect on an adjacent hemolysis pattern.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The enhanced lysis between wells containing either HBL or B only seems contradictory in light of the observation that excess B inhibits lysis by L1, but it is consistent with the mechanism of HBL.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	328	 The B component primes cells independently of the other components (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	329	 1, B and C), and once primed, cells are rapidly lysed by any concentration of L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	330	 The lysis within the B diffusion zone occurred simply because cells were primed by B in the absence of inhibitory concentrations of L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	331	 The priming reaction of B is over 1000 times slower than the lytic action of L1 at room temperature.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Therefore, even in the presence of excess B, the lysis rate of RBC-B will not be noticeably slower than the rate at which cells are primed by B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	333	 On the other hand, any inhibition by L1 of the priming reaction of B should be profoundly evident.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	334	 This seems to be born out in the lysis patterns in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	335	Our hemolysis data provide some insights into the mechanism of HBL, which appears to involve novel modes of interactions between proteins and membranes.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	336	 The three proteins that comprise HBL are collectively called a toxin because of an early simplifying assumption that they represent a single functional unit to the bacterium that produces them.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	337	 This work supports that assumption.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	338	 New findings show that the genes for all three components are arranged immediately adjacent to one another, probably in an operon (8), lending additional weight to the idea that the three proteins comprise a functional unit.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	339	 HBL is unlike any previously described cytolytic toxin, from its complex composition to the unique hemolytic phenomena that it causes.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Further study of this toxin promises to add a new perspective to perceptions about the mechanisms and utility of cytolytic toxins.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	341	*   This work was supported by the National Research Initiative Competitive Grants Program of the U.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	342	 Department of Agriculture Grant 93-37201-9194 and by the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, University of Wisconsin.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	343	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	344	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	346	    To whom correspondence should be addressed: Food Research Inst.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	347	 of Food Microbiology and Toxicology, University of Wisconsin, 1925 Willow Dr.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	348	: 608-263-1177; Fax: 608-263-1114; E-mail: dbeecher{at}facstaff.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	349	 1    The abbreviations used are: HBL, hemolysin BL; L1+2, a combination of HBL components L1 and L2; RBC, red blood cells; RBC-B, erythrocyte(s) primed by the B component of HBL to the lytic action of the combination of the two L components; Bi, inhibitory concentration of B; TBS, Tris-buffered saline; MAC, membrane attack complex.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	368	 63, 4121-4129 [Abstract] Leppla, S.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	369	 (1991) in Sourcebook of Bacterial Protein Toxins (Alouf, J.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	370	 277-302, Academic Press, London Rappuoli, R.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	371	 (1991) in Sourcebook of Bacterial Protein Toxins (Alouf, J.
