0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	373	 (1991) in Sourcebook of Bacterial Protein Toxins (Alouf, J.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	374	 101-115, Academic Press, London Fehrenbach, F.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	375	 (1991) in Sourcebook of Bacterial Protein Toxins (Alouf, J.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	376	 187-213, Academic Press, London Bhakdi, S.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Today 12, 318-320 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Esser, A.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Today 12, 316-318 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Esser, A.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	379	 (1994) Toxicology 87, 229-247 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Bhakdi, S.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	380	 165, 71-79 [CrossRef]  1997 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	0	Structure of L-A Virus: A Specialized Compartment for the Transcription and Replication of Double-stranded RNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	1	* Laboratory of Structural Biology, National Institute of Arthritis, Musculoskeletal, and Skin Diseases;  Computational Bioscience and Engineering Laboratory, Division of Computer Research and Technology;   Laboratory of Biochemistry and Genetics, National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892; and   Department of Biology, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973 Abstract Materials and Methods Results Discussion Footnotes Acknowledgements Abbreviations used in this paper References.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	2	The genomes of double-stranded (ds)RNA viruses are never exposed to the cytoplasm but are confined to and replicated from a specialized protein-bound compartmentthe viral capsid.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	3	 We have used cryoelectron microscopy and three-dimensional image reconstruction to study this compartment in the case of L-A, a yeast virus whose capsid consists of 60 asymmetric dimers of Gag protein (76 kD).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	4	 At 16-A resolution, we distinguish multiple domains in the elongated Gag subunits, whose nonequivalent packing is reflected in subtly different morphologies of the two protomers.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Small holes, 10-15 A across, perforate the capsid wall, which functions as a molecular sieve, allowing the exit of transcripts and the influx of metabolites, while retaining dsRNA and excluding degradative enzymes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Scanning transmission electron microscope measurements of mass-per-unit length suggest that L-A RNA is an A-form duplex, and that RNA filaments emanating from disrupted virions often consist of two or more closely associated duplexes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Nuclease protection experiments confirm that the genome is entirely sequestered inside full capsids, but it is packed relatively loosely; in L-A, the center-to-center spacing between duplexes is 40-45 A, compared with 25-30 A in other double-stranded viruses.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The looser packing of L-A RNA allows for maneuverability in the crowded capsid interior, in which the genome (in both replication and transcription) must be translocated sequentially past the polymerase immobilized on the inner capsid wall.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	9	IN eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells alike, the medium in which genetic information is stored is double-stranded (ds)1 DNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	10	 From this repository, genes are copied in the same medium (replication) or into different media (transcription and translation).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Viruses, more limited but less constrained genetic entities than cells, exhibit greater diversity in their replication cycles.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	12	 All four alternative media, single-stranded (ss)RNA, ssDNA, dsDNA, and dsRNA, are used by different virus families to encode their genomes (for review see Roizman and Palese, 1996).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Whereas dsDNA and ssRNA molecules are abundant cellular components, dsRNA and ssDNA molecules are not.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In these circumstances, one might expect viruses of the latter kinds to have developed special strategies for interfacing with the metabolic resources of their host cells.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	15	One such strategy that is widespread if not universal among dsRNA viruses is their use of capsids as specialized cytoplasmic compartments that genomes are confined to, and are replicated and expressed from (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Such capsids are selectively porous protein shells that the genome and replicase reside within, nucleotides infuse into, and nascent strands (positive sense) are extruded from.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	17	The present study addresses the capsid structure and the organization of encapsidated RNA in the L-A virus of yeast, an excellent model system because of its relative simplicity and well-known molecular biology.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	18	6-kbp, single-segment molecule that encodes a major capsid protein (Gag; 680 residues, 76 kD) and a minor capsid protein.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The latter molecule is a fusion of Gag with Pol, the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (Pol; 868 residues, 100 kD) (Fujimura and Wickner, 1988a; Icho and Wickner, 1989) that is generated by ribosomal frameshifting (Dinman et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The L-A capsid is a spherical particle, ~430 A in diam, composed of 120 copies of Gag (Esteban and Wickner, 1986; Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	21	, 1994), of which approximately two carry the Pol moiety (Dinman and Wickner, 1992; Ribas, J.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Its surface lattice has the unusual property of being composed of 60 asymmetric dimers (Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 1994), configured as an otherwise conventional icosahedron of triangulation class T = 1 (Caspar and Klug, 1962).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Interestingly, 120-subunit capsids have been detected in several other dsRNA viruses, including bacteriophage 6 (Mindich and Bamford, 1988), reovirus (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	25	, 1993), orbivirus (Burroughs et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	26	, 1995), aquareovirus (Shaw et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	27	, 1996), and rotavirus (Estes, 1996), but thus far, in no other kind of virus.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	28	Motivated by the expanding generality of this unusual capsid stoichiometry and architecture and the prospect of gaining insight into the features that commend it as a compartment for the sequestration and replication of dsRNA, we have pursued further cryoelectron microscopic studies of the L-A capsid, extending the resolution to 16 A.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Using these data, we have also examined the structural organization of the viral genome, both in the encapsidated state and as released from virions.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Complementary information was obtained by using dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) (Wall and Hainfeld, 1986; Thomas et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	31	, 1994) to measure the mass per unit length of L-A chromosomes extruding directly from capsids, and after isolation.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	32	Materials and Methods Virus Particle Preparation.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	33	L-A virus was extracted from stationary phase cells of Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain TF229 [MATa His(3,4) Leu2 ski2-2 L-A-HN] grown in 1 liter of rich medium, and purified by CsCl equilibrium gradient centrifugation as described (Fujimura and Wickner, 1988b), except that 12.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	34	5 ml CsCl gradients were run at 157,000 g (44,000 rpm in a Beckman NVT65 rotor; Beckman Instruments, Inc.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	35	, Fullerton, CA) for 15 h at 4 degrees C.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The virus-containing fractions were dialyzed against buffer A (50 mM Tris HCl, 150 mM NaCl, 5 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, pH 7.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	37	8) for 6 h, and stored at ~20 mg/ml at 4 degrees C.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	38	 All samples were used within 7 d of purification, as L-A virions tend to lose their dsRNA upon protracted storage.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	39	Virions to be examined by cryoelectron microscopy were dialyzed against buffer A for 8-12 h to remove CsCl.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	40	 They were then diluted in buffer A until (when examined by negative staining) a uniform, dense but not continuous, distribution of particles was observed.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	41	 5- microl drops of virus at this concentration (typically, 2-5 mg/ml) were applied to holey carbon films on 400 mesh copper grids, and observed by cryoelectron microscopy, essentially as described (Booy et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Micrographs were recorded under minimal exposure conditions at nominal magnifications of  x 36,000 or  x 46,000 (~8 e/A2) on Kodak SO-163 films, using an electron microscope (EM400RT; Philips Technologies, Eindhoven, The Netherlands) equipped with modified Gatan anticontaminator blades and a Gatan 626 cryoholder (Gatan, Warrendale, PA).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In some experiments, bacteriophage T4 was mixed with L-A, and the 40.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	44	5-A axial spacing of its tail-sheath (Moody and Makowski, 1981) was used as an internal magnification standard.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Micrographs were assessed for resolution and stigmation by optical diffraction of large areas, and their defocus values estimated from the positions of the first zero of the contrast transfer function (CTF).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	46	 For the micrographs chosen for analysis, the first zero was in the range of (15 A)1-(27 A)1 (Table I).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Underfocus values () were calculated according to  = 1/k2 , where  is the wavelength of the 100 keV electrons (0.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	48	037 A), and k is the spatial frequency of the first zero (Lepault and Leonard, 1985).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Spectra calculated from powder patterns of genome-revealing difference images of L-A virions.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The positions and spread of the peaks in these spectra give statistically representative estimates of the predominant spacings between RNA filaments packed in L-A virus capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Because the shape of a spectrum depends on the defocus of the micrographs from which it was calculated, this analysis was repeated for micrographs covering a range of defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	52	 In each case, difference images were calculated as shown in Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	53	 4, their diffraction patterns calculated and azimuthally averaged, and the powder pattern obtained by summing over many such particles.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The various spectra are indexed according to the serial numbers of the micrographs used.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The closest-to-focus spectrum is at top, and the furthest-from-focus one is at bottom (Table I).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Each spectrum shows a broad peak in the range of (47 A)1 to (31 A)1 (gray vertical band).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Also shown is the control spectrum calculated from empty particles in micrograph #7261.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	58	 It shows a much weaker peak in the same frequency range indicative of the defocus value at which this micrograph was recorded, and confirms that the strong peak in the full particle spectrum reflects scattering from the viral RNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	59	 For reference, a line is shown at (26 A)1, the average interduplex spacing for many other dsDNA and dsRNA viruses.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	60	 [View Larger Version of this Image (29K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Computer-filtered images of encapsidated L-A genomes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Typical full and empty particles are shown in a and e, respectively.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	63	 b and f show the same particles after low pass filtering at (28 A)1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	64	 c and g were obtained by reprojecting the corresponding density maps in the appropriate viewing orientations, and reproduce the micrographs well, particularly in terms of peripheral detail.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	65	 d and h are "difference images" calculated by subtracting c from a after nullifying the internal density of the "full" map, and g from b, respectively.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	66	 d reveals the encapsidated genome.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The control h simply represents background noise, and confirms that the shell is cleanly removed in this procedure.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The two particles shown are from the highest defocus micrograph analyzed (2- microm defocus; first CTF zero at [27 A]1).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	69	 i-l show two more examples each of exposed genomes from four micrographs with different defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Their first CTF zeros at spacings of 15.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	71	 In each case, the density map used to calculate the shell contribution to the virion image was calculated from the micrograph in question.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	72	 These images illustrate the variable appearance of encapsidated genomes, and demonstrate that this variability does not arise from differences in defocus.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	73	 [View Larger Version of this Image (182K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	74	Micrographs were digitized on a Perkin Elmer 1010MG microdensitometer (Norwalk, CT) at 12- microm intervals ( x 36,000 negatives) or 16- microm intervals ( x 46,000 negatives), corresponding to 3.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	75	 General image processing operations were carried out using the PIC Software system (Trus et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	76	, 1996), running on Alpha workstations (Digital Equipment Co.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Particles were extracted and preprocessed using the automated procedure of Conway et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Particle orientations were determined by means of the Polar Fourier Transform algorithm, an iterative, model-based procedure (Baker and Cheng, 1996).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	79	 As a starting model, we used our earlier 26A resolution three-dimensional (3-D) map of empty L-A particles (Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In all micrographs analyzed, reconstructions of empty and full particles were calculated separately, using Fourier-Bessel techniques (Crowther, 1971; Fuller, 1987; Baker et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Complete icosahedral (532) symmetry was imposed on the final density map.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The contour level imposed for surface rendering was based on 100% of expected volume, assuming a protein density of 1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Resolution of the three-dimensional maps was estimated in terms of a Fourier shell correlation procedure (Saxton and Baumeister, 1982; Conway et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	84	, 1993), and was, in each case, very close to the first zero of the CTF.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Data quality was also assessed by eigenvalue spectra (Fuller et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	86	To obtain a distribution of particle orientations that uniformly cover the asymmetric unit (Baker et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	87	, 1989), data from three micrographs were combined.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	88	 All three micrographs were well stigmated and had first zeros at ~(15 A)1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Three independent reconstructions were first calculated and mutually scaled to the same magnification and density by matching their spherically averaged radial density profiles (Booy et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	90	 A composite reconstruction including  > 80 particles (Table I) was then calculated, the orientation and alignment parameters of each particle refined, and a final map calculated.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The resolution was 16 A by the above criterion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	92	To visualize the internal contents of full particles, we first calculated reconstructions from micrographs recorded at several different defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The contribution of the capsid shell to each such image was obtained by reprojecting the three-dimensional map in the corresponding orientation, after setting the internal densities to background (solvent) level.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Finally, the projected capsid shell was subtracted from the raw image (Baker et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	95	, 1991), thus providing an unobstructed view of the encapsidated dsRNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	96	 As a control, the same procedure was applied to images of empty particles.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Diffraction patterns were calculated for all difference images in each data set.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	98	 These were then added together with equal weighting (combining empty and full particles separately), and azimuthally averaged to obtain the respective one-dimensional powder patterns.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	99	Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	100	STEM was performed at the Brookhaven Biotechnology Resource (Upton, NY) (Wall, 1979; Wall and Hainfeld, 1986).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Full particles, purified as described above and stored briefly at a concentration of ~20 mg/ml, were diluted 40-fold in buffer A, and a 5- microl drop was applied to a thin carbon film.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The grid was washed 10 times with 100 mM ammonium acetate, pH 6.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	103	5, frozen, and then dried (Wall, 1979).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	104	 To visualize isolated dsRNA, material purified by phenol extraction (Wickner, 1994) at 2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	105	4 mg/ml in diethyl pyrocarbonate-treated water was diluted 100 times with 100 mM ammonium acetate and applied to a polylysine-coated carbon film, washed with 20 mM ammonium acetate, and freeze-dried.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) at 50-100  microg/ml was included in all preparations as an internal mass standard.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Digital micrographs (512  x  512 pixels) were recorded using sampling steps of 20 or 10 A/pixel.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Mass determinations were carried out as described (Newcomb et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	109	RNase protection assays were performed with three different samples: dsRNA purified from full viral particles; freshly prepared full particles; and viral particles disrupted by dilution to low ionic strength (25 mM NaCl) and incubated for 45 min at room temperature.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	110	 RNase III has an exclusive specificity for dsRNA (Crouch, 1974), and under our conditions, is active only in the presence of 10 mM MgCl2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The reaction mixture (25  microl), containing 0.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	112	5  microg dsRNA and ~1  microg of RNase III in 50 mM Tris HCl, pH 7.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	113	1 mM DTT, and 0 or 10 mM of MgCl2, was incubated for 45 min at 37 degrees C.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The resulting products were phenol extracted, ethanol precipitated, separated on a 1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	115	5% agarose gel, and then detected by ethidium bromide staining.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	116	Results Cryoelectron Microscopy of Full and Empty Capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	117	Fields of purified L-A particles are shown in Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	118	 1, in micrographs recorded at several different defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	119	 As expected, the image contrast increases with defocus; however, L-A exhibits no conspicuous surface relief, even at quite high defocus (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Empty particles are clearly distinguished from full ones, and almost all capsids appear intact (see below).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	121	 We observed a small percentage of a distinctive polymorphic variant, the "dimeric" capsid (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	122	 1 d, large arrowhead), it seems to be a fusion of two capsids, both lacking one icosahedral cap.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Whether they arise from pairing of two partially dissociated capsids or are simply aberrant assembly products is not known.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Filamentous material, presumably RNA released from virions, is usually visible (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Some full particles exhibit "swirl" patterns of curved striations (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	126	 1 c, large arrowhead), we attribute this to the encapsidated RNA as they were never seen on empty capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The spacing between these striations is 35-40 A.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	128	 More often, full particles present punctate, nonsymmetric, motifs.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Cryoelectron micrographs of purified L-A virions at different defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	130	 One of the full particles exhibits a ringlike "swirl" pattern (c, large arrowhead).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	131	 (d) At ~2  microm underfocus; a "dimeric" capsid is shown (large arrowhead).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Filamentous material, presumably RNA, is observed in all four micrographs (small arrowheads).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	133	 [View Larger Version of this Image (129K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	134	In this typical experiment, full and empty particles were observed in a ratio of ~3:2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Since the sample was collected as a compact band about one-third of the way up the CsCl gradient, it originally contained only full particles.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	136	 We infer that the empty particles were generated either during dialysis (see Materials and Methods) or grid preparation.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	137	Three-dimensional Structures of Full and Empty Capsids at 16 A Resolution.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	138	The presence of both kinds of particles in the same micrographs allowed us to calculate reconstructions that may be compared directly, without concern about extraneous factors such as differences in defocus, ice thickness, radiation damage, etc.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The resolution achieved was 16 A in both cases.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The outer diameter and average thickness of the capsid shell were measured from spherically averaged radial density profiles (not shown) of maps whose magnification was carefully calibrated, as 430 and 46 A, respectively.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	141	 However, the reconstructions reveal local variations in shell thickness, which is maximally, ~54 A (compare with Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Three-dimensional density maps of L-A capsids at 16 A resolution.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	143	 (a) Stereo views of the outer (upper panels) and inner (lower panels) surfaces of the full capsid, viewed along a fivefold axis of symmetry.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The internal contents were computationally removed to expose the inner surface.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	145	 (b) Transverse central sections taken from the maps of empty (left) and full (right) capsids, viewed along a twofold axis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Darker shades represent higher densities (corresponding to protein and/or RNA).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Black arrowheads, fivefold symmetry axes; black lollipops, threefold axes; and white arrowheads, twofold axes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The two shells are virtually identical.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In the full capsid (right), the closest contacts between the inner surface of the protein shell and the underlying RNA appear to take place around the lateral twofolds.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The white rings just inside and outside the shell represent interference fringes arising from phase contrast.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Since the holes in the capsid wall are too small to admit an A-form duplex (see Discussion), it seems likely that the empty capsids lost their RNA through a hole created by the dislodging of one or a few Gag subunits.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	152	 With the averaging that takes place in calculating a density map, such a loss would not significantly affect the average density at that lattice site, and thus may be reconciled with the essentially identical structures visualized for full and empty capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	153	 [View Larger Version of this Image (121K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	154	The molecular topography of the capsid is shown in stereo in Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	155	 2 a, as viewed along a fivefold axis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The structure shown was calculated from images of full capsids and its internal contents were erased computationally to expose the inner surface (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The placement of subunits on this surface lattice is indexed in Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The penton is constructed of an inner ring of five elongated subunits (A-subunits), surrounded by an outer ring of five similar, partially intercalated, B-subunits.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The nonequivalent bonding environments of the A- and B-subunits are reflected in their subtly different morphologies (see below).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Structural organization of the two nonequivalent Gag monomers in the L-A capsid.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	161	 (a) Spherical sections through the density map of the L-A capsid, as viewed along a twofold axis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	162	 These sections correspond to radii of 214, 207, 201, 194, 188, 181, 175, and 168 A, respectively (left to right, and top to bottom).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Here, white tones correspond to high density, denoting protein and/or RNA (i.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	164	, the contrast has been reversed relative to Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	165	 (b) Schematic diagram showing arrangement of Gag subunits in the L-A surface lattice, as viewed along a fivefold axis (compare with Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The A-subunits are green, and the B-subunits orange.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	167	 (c) Diagram showing three pentons (each a Gag decamer) clustered around a threefold axis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Five- and twofold axes are also marked.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	169	 (d) The outer crests of both subunits may be subdivided into three domains: B1, B2, B3, and A1, A2, A3, respectively.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Two possible modes of association of neighboring A- and B-subunits into dimers are shown in the lower part of the panel.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The one on the left appears to have more extensive intersubunit contacts and therefore may be favored.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	172	 (e) Closeup views down a twofold axis from outside (left) and inside (right).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	173	 A- and B-subunits are marked in both cases (A and B, respectively).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	174	 On the left panel, the largest of the five kinds of holes that traverse the capsid wall are marked (arrows).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	175	 On the right panel, the Y-shaped motifs seen on the subunits' undersides are apparent.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	176	 For one A-subunit, this motif is tinged with green and for a B-subunit, with orange.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	177	 [View Larger Version of this Image (80K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	178	The empty capsid has an essentially identical structure, particularly on the outer surface (data not shown).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	179	 On the inner surface, the match between full and empty capsids is less perfect, but such differences are slight.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Of these, the most prominent are thin arms of density near the twofold axes on the full capsid (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	181	 2 b, right, white arrows) that connect the protein to the underlying genome-associated density.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	182	 These features imply that there is likely to be close contact between the RNA and the capsid wall at these sites, but (by comparison) not elsewhere.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	183	Unlike the impression given at 26-A resolution (Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	184	, 1994), the capsid wall is seen to be quite porous, perforated with many small holes (Figs.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	185	 There are five classes of holes: those at the fivefold axes (area = ~107 A2); those surrounding the fivefold axes (~165 A2); those on the threefold axes (~118 A2); relatively large Y-shaped holes surrounding the threefold axes (~244 A2); and oblong holes between the A- and B-subunits (~110 A2).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	186	In these maps, the capsids' interiors are icosahedrally symmetric; although there is no reason to suppose that the material in these regions actually conforms to this symmetry, which was imposed by the reconstruction procedure.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In the empty capsid, internal density is (as expected) at the same level as the solvent outside.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In the full capsid map, the internal density gives the impression of three concentric shells 35-40 A apart (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	189	 We do not interpret this to mean that the viral RNA is strictly confined to three spherical shells.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Rather, because the micrographs contain a strong signal at these spacings, arising from the distances between nearest-neighbor RNA filaments, the icosahedral density map calculated from them also contains strong features at the same spacings.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The density of these shells diminishes progressively towards the center, which is probably a valid indication that proportionately more RNA resides at higher radii.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	192	Structures and Interactions of the Nonequivalent A- and B-Subunits.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	193	The A- and B-subunits are very similar in morphology.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	194	 On the outer capsid surface, each subunit is shaped like a boomerang and subdivides into three domains, called A1, A2, A3, and B1, B2, B3, respectively (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	195	 On the inner surface, the two kinds of subunit are less alike, although both present a Y-shaped motif (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	196	 This motif is clearly visible in the spherical sections at inner radii shown in Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	197	 3 a (especially bottom row, third from left).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In the middle of the capsid wall is a hollow cavity (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	199	 2 b) that separates the inner and outer surface domains.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Within a given penton (Gag decamer), neighboring A- and B-subunits can be aligned by a rotation of ~15 degrees  (see Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	201	 3 e, left), whence we conclude that they are oriented in parallel.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	202	 3 e, right) supports this conclusion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	203	The internal features of the Gag subunits are conveniently viewed in spherical sections through the density map (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The protomer should be a Gag dimer.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	205	 In principle, there are three possible pairings of neighboring A- and B-subunits.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The pairing in which subunits interact across the twofold axis (A3 to B3) involves only a small contact surface.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Consequently, we favor the two more compact arrangements (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	208	 3 d, bottom), in which there are more extensive interactions to stabilize the dimer.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	209	From the spherical sections (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	210	 3 a), we can discern likely boundaries between subunits, and the pattern of interactions that consolidates the surface lattice.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	211	 A-subunits cluster around the fivefold axis via A1-A1 interactions.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The corresponding region of the B-subunit (B1) makes contacts with A1 and A2, further out from the fivefold axis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Three B3 domains meet around the threefold axis, whereas across the twofold axis, the contacts are head- to-head between A3 and B3.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Interactions between twofold and threefold axes take place deep in the lattice, from radii at ~184 to 197 A (whereas the protein shell extends from radii 171 to 217 A) via arclike densities (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	215	The thin arms of density linking the capsid with the underlying RNA (see above) are also visualized in the Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	216	 3 a (bottom, far right) for the twofold axes, and they extend from A-subunits.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	217	Packing of dsRNA Inside the L-A Capsid.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	218	The protein shell, accounting for ~73% of the virion mass, tends to dominate images of full particles, in which it is coprojected with the RNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	219	 To obtain unimpeded views of encapsidated genomes, we erased the shell contributions from virion images, computationally (Booy et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The resulting difference images show punctate motifs and/ or swirls; some examples are shown in Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	221	 To estimate the interstrand spacings, we measured the positions of diffraction peaks in powder patterns calculated from many such images (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Because phase-contrast imaging accentuates particular spatial frequencies, depending on the defocus, this analysis was performed for micrographs that cover a range of defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	223	 All of these patterns exhibited broad peaks extending from ~(31 A)1 to ~(47 A)1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The position of the peak varied slightly with defocus but was invariably between (36 A)1 and (40 A)1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	225	 As a control, the same procedure was applied to empty capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	226	 5, dashes) has a small peak in this range, this probably reflects noise amplified by the phase-contrast at this defocus value.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	227	 It is, however, much weaker than the corresponding peak of the full particle powder pattern, confirming that this peak primarily reflects scattering from the RNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	228	Resistance of Encapsidated RNA to RNase Digestion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	229	The interstrand spacings measured above are considerably larger than the values obtained for other dsDNA and dsRNA viruses (Lepault et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Accordingly, one might wonder whether their RNA is partly extruded, with a concomitant loosening up of the portion remaining inside the capsid.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The presence of empty capsids and free RNA in electron micrographs is consistent with such a hypothesis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	232	 To test it, we conducted accessibility experiments with RNase III, a nuclease specific for dsRNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The genomes of freshly prepared virions proved entirely resistant to the enzyme (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	234	 6); whereas in a positive control, isolated L-A RNA was extensively digested (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	235	 When virions were preincubated in a low salt buffer, (known to destabilize them) (Esteban and Wickner, 1986), their RNA partially degraded (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	236	 These results imply that the dsRNA is entirely sequestered inside freshly prepared virions.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	237	 This conclusion is consistent with earlier STEM mass measurements that yielded masses for full L-A virions consistent with their containing whole genomes (Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	238	 RNA is gradually lost on storage, but release from any given particle, once started, appears to proceed quite rapidly.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The conclusion that the L-A genome is indeed packed more loosely than in other viruses is supported by calculations of packing density (see Discussion).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	240	 RNase III accessibility for L-A dsRNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Purified RNA (lanes 1-3), dsRNA in intact full particles (lanes 4-6), and dsRNA from disrupted full particles (lanes 7 and 8) were treated with RNase III as described in Material and Methods, in the absence (lanes 2, 5, and 7) or presence (lanes 3, 6, and 8) of 10 mM MgCl2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Lanes 1 and 4 are controls for purified dsRNA and dsRNA from intact full particles without RNase III treatment, respectively.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	243	 On the left, molecular weight markers.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	244	 After RNase treatment, RNA was separated in a 1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	245	5% agarose gel and detected by ethidium bromide staining.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The digestion products are diffusely spread out in lane 8, whereas in the other lanes the genome band is either present at the appropriate position or absent, having been digested to small fragments.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	247	 [View Larger Version of this Image (85K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	248	We used dark-field electron microscopy to measure the mass-per-unit length of L-A chromosomes, both after purification (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	249	 7 a) and as released from, but still connected to, disrupted capsids (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The data obtained for purified RNA molecules observe a quasi-Gaussian distribution with a mean of 2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	251	 For RNA filaments emanating from capsids, the distribution (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	252	 7 b) is broader, displaced to higher values, and is suggestive of multiple components.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The lower values (~30-40% of the data) match those obtained for purified molecules.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The other measurements are higher and appear to represent structures in which two or more duplexes associate laterally to form multistranded filaments.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	255	 We think it unlikely that their higher density reflects coating of the RNA with protein since these preparations contain no protein other than Gag in detectable amounts.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	256	 When a similar experiment was carried out with particles that had been stored for a few days at 4 degrees C (L-A virions gradually lose their dsRNA upon storage, see above), most of the measurements matched those obtained for purified molecules.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	257	 STEM dark-field images of unstained L-A RNA molecules.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	258	 (a) Freeze-dried preparation of purified dsRNA, with a few tobacco mosaic virions (the rodlike particles), included as internal mass standards.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	259	 At right is a histogram of mass-per-unit length measurements made from these micrographs (n = 53).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	260	 (b) Purified L-A virions, with some free RNA; at right, the histogram of mass-per-unit length data (n = 275).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	261	 These measurements were restricted to RNA segments visibly connected to capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	262	 The arrows indicate densities corresponding to integral numbers of strands per filament, assuming 2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	263	8 kD/nm for an A-form RNA duplex (Results).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Black arrows mark even numbers of strands, i.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	265	 The precision of the measurements is insufficient to resolve the distribution into a set of well-defined peaks.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	266	 In principle, these densities could be biased to higher values by residual salt deposits, as a consequence of insufficient grid washing.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	267	 However, in this case, one would expect greater variability in the data, and the standard deviation of the measurements made on TMV particles to be considerably higher.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	268	 In fact, the SDs were very similar, at 3.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	269	81% for the TMV in the experiments with purified RNA molecules, and 4.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	270	48% for those on capsid-connected RNA filaments.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	271	 [View Larger Version of this Image (86K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	272	The replication cycles of all known dsRNA viruses follow the same pattern (Roizman and Palese, 1996).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	273	 First, dsRNA is transcribed by a polymerase resident within the virion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Next, (+) strand transcripts are extruded to serve as (a) mRNA for the synthesis of viral proteins, (b) the species that becomes encapsidated in progeny virions, and (c) used as the template for synthesis of complementary () strands in replication.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Both transcription and replication take place inside the nucleocapsid, which is the complete virion for fungal dsRNA viruses or an inner core for higher eukaryotic viruses like those of the Reoviridae family (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	276	, 1993]; rotavirus [Mansell and Patton, 1990; Labbe et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	277	, 1991]; and orbivirus [Huismans et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	278	 This model also applies to the prokaryotic dsRNA virus, bacteriophage 6 (Mindich and Bamford, 1988).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	279	 What features do these various transcription-cum-replication chambers have in common?.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	280	As noted in the Introduction, stoichiometry data indicate that many dsRNA virus capsids contain 120 copies of at least one protein.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	281	 So far, no other kind of virus capsid has this stoichiometry, which corresponds to the "forbidden" T-number of two (Caspar and Klug, 1962).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	282	 It is of interest to know whether this commonality extends to more detailed aspects of capsid architecture.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Here, fewer data are available, but we note a definite morphological similarity between L-A capsid and the core of Bluetongue virus (Hewat et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	284	, 1992); this virus is also composed of 120 subunits (Burroughs et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Aquareovirus cores also show 120 morphological subunits on their surface (Shaw et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Although reovirus cores are more complex than the L-A capsid, the presence of Y-shaped domains on their inner surface (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Birnaviruses, whose genomes consist of two segments of dsRNA, seem to be an exception since they are single-shelled T=13 particles with no internal core (Bottcher et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	288	Capsid Structure and Control of Assembly.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	289	Our current three-dimensional map at 16-A resolution depicts the 76-kD Gag monomer as an elongated molecule with multiple domains coiled around a central cavity.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	290	 The structural differences seen between the nonequivalent A- and B-subunits are minor, but their bonding environments are entirely different (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	291	 As shown by expression studies (Fujimura et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	292	, 1992), Gag can selfassemble into correctly sized capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	293	 This reaction should be controlled by some switching event that specifies the A and B conformations (Johnson, 1996).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	294	 This switch may operate at the level of dimer formation, yielding protomers of which 60 equivalent copies would then self-assemble into a conventional T = 1 icosahedron.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	295	 The plausibility of this model is supported indirectly by observations in other systems (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	296	, the human growth hormone receptor [de Vos et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	297	, 1992]), which attest that an asymmetric homodimer can be a stable state of assembly.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Alternatively, A-subunits might associate into homo-pentamers, with the switch accompanying the accretion of B-subunits to convert them into decamers capable of forming the capsid pentons.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	299	 The fact that Gag-Pol appears to nucleate assembly of L-A in vivo (Fujimura and Wickner, 1988b), and there are only 1-2 copies of this protein per capsid, argues against the pentamer-based model.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	300	Mass-per-unit-length Measurements Suggest that L-A dsRNA Is A-form.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	301	Our STEM data on the mass-per-unit length of purified L-A dsRNA yield a mean value of 2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Acknowledging the spread in these data, they suggest an A-type duplex2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	303	81 A rise per base pair (Arnott et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	304	, 1972) and 682 D/ bpand are less consistent with a B-form duplex2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	305	 It has been previously demonstrated by spectroscopy that packaged 6 dsRNA has an A-form structure (Bamford et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	306	 However, x-ray diffraction studies of crystallized reovirus dsRNA (for review see Nibert et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	307	, 1996) were indicative of a double helix with 10 or 11 bp per turn and a 3-A pitch, this corresponds to a structure intermediate between A-form (2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	308	81-A rise per bp) and B-form (3.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	309	The L-A Capsid as a Molecular Sieve.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	310	One striking feature revealed by our capsid model is its porosity; the capsid wall is perforated by many small holes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	311	 While their sizes may be revised somewhat when higher resolution data become available, current estimates suggest a strategically useful property.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	312	 None of these holes is large enough to pass an A-form duplex (~23-A diam), but the largest holes (triangular, average distance from apex to base ~15 A; Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	313	 3 e) should readily allow passage of an ssRNA molecule.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Thus the capsid appears to be configured to function as a molecular sieve: duplex RNA is retained inside, but transcripts may exit.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	315	 It would be expedient for freshly synthesized transcript to be fed directly into an exit port (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	316	 8), as this would forestall formation of secondary structure that might impede export.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Since there are only one to two copies of Pol per capsid, presumably no more than two transcripts per capsid are being exported at any one time.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	318	 However, the other holes should facilitate the infusion of nucleotides, of which a steady supply is required to sustain synthesis during transcription or replication.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	319	 A further filtering property is that the holes are presumably small enough to exclude potentially degradative enzymes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Hypothetical model of a transcriptionally active L-A virion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	321	 The polymerase (Pol) is covalently attached to a Gag subunit, which we assume to be integrated into the icosahedral surface lattice, thus immobilizing Pol (Icho and Wickner, 1989).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Pol (and the COOH terminus of Gag) are assumed to reside on the inner surface of the shell, to facilitate access to the substrate dsRNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	323	 The shape assigned to Pol in this diagram is arbitrary.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	324	 In this scenario, it is necessary for the genome to be propelled sequentially past Pol as transcription proceeds.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Transcripts are hypothesized to be extruded directly through the largest holes in the capsid shell (Discussion).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	326	 [View Larger Version of this Image (159K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	327	Unusually Low Density of dsRNA Packing in L-A.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	328	In projection, encapsidated L-A genomes exhibit punctate and/or swirl motifs (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Presumably, these two classes of motifs represent distinct views, although it is not clear that the genome is packed in the same way in each particle.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	330	 We infer that the genomes are loosely coiled, with variable spacing between adjacent filaments.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	331	 5) have average Bragg spacings of 36-40 A, corresponding to a center-to-center spacing of 41-46 A between filaments.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	332	 The L-A motifs differ from those of dsDNA viruses such as phages T4 and  (Lepault et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	333	, 1992) and herpes simplex virus (Booy et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	334	, 1991), and other dsRNA viruses such as reovirus (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	335	, 1993); these are relatively highly ordered and tightly packed, with center-to-center spacings of 25-30 A.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	336	 In part, the larger spacing in L-A reflects the fact that A-form duplexes are wider than B-form duplexes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	337	 However, the average interduplex spacing may be calculated independently from the volume available (average internal capsid diam = 348 A) and genome length (1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Assuming quasi-hexagonal close packing to a uniform density, a spacing of ~40 A is obtained.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	339	 There is some flexibility in this figure, arising from the center being less populated with RNA, the packing not being perfectly crystalline, and possibly also from some local compaction into multistranded filaments (see below).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Nevertheless, this figure is in good agreement with the spacings measured directly from the powder patterns (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Its consistency supports our inferences that (a) the dsRNA genome is fully internalized, and (b) its packing is much looser than in other double-stranded viruses.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	342	RNA extending from capsids often has a uniform mass-per-unit length that is significantly higher than for a single A-form duplex (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	343	 7), and appears to represent some sort of higher order filament formed by two or more duplexes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	344	 We have not observed these thicker filaments in preparations of isolated dsRNA, and see no obvious way in which they might arise as an artifact of specimen preparation.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	345	 It may be that within the confines of the capsid, i.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	346	, under conditions of high packing density, some piecewise condensation of duplexes into higher order filaments takes place.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	347	, at much lower density, the RNA gradually relaxes to single duplexes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	348	Headful Replication and the Churning Model of Transcription.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	349	L-A is also a helper virus for other dsRNA segments in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Wickner, 1996a).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	350	 These satellite viruses (M1, M2, etc.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	351	) and deletion mutants of L-A itself (such as X) contain more dsRNA segments than L-A, but approximately the same number of base pairs per particle.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	352	 This occurs by "headful replication," whereby one viral (+) strand is packaged, and replicates inside the particle until it is full.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Subsequently synthesized (+) strands are extruded from the particle (Esteban and Wickner, 1986; Fujimura et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	354	 As noted above, much more room remains available in the packaged L-A capsid than in other double-stranded viruses.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	355	 We can think of two explanations.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	356	 In one, the Gag gene has evolved recently to provide a more capacious capsid, but the genome as a whole has not yet evolved to fully exploit this opportunity for expansion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	357	 The fact that the multisegmented satellites do not package RNA more densely than L-A appears to argue against this hypothesis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	358	In the second explanation, we speculate that the maximum viable packing density may be dictated by a requirement for long range mobility of the dsRNA in this transcriptionally active particle.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	359	 The polymerase is thought to reside on the inner surface, anchored by integration of its Gag moiety into the surface lattice (Wickner, 1996a,b).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	360	 8), large tracts of dsRNA must be propelled sequentially past this fixed point.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	361	 In so doing, the organization of the entire packaged genome must undergo constant revision, or "churning" motion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	362	 (In contrast, the tightly compressed genomes of dsDNA phages are thought to be in a static vegetative state.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	363	) RNA polymerases are known to be powerful translocases, capable of generating forces in the range of 14 piconewtons (Yin et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	364	 The ability of L-A Pol to function in replication and transcription depends on its being capable of overcoming the frictional drag imposed by the packaged genome.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	365	 We infer that this resistance increases with higher packing density, whence the observed packing density may represent the highest level of frictional resistance against which the enzyme can function effectively.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	366	 This idea is testable by generating insertions in the L-A genome.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	367	Is a similar mechanism operative in other dsRNA viruses? The consideration that dsRNA appears to be packed more densely in the cores of both reovirus (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	368	, 1993) and rotavirus (Prasad et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	369	, 1996) than in L-A might suggest otherwise.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	370	 However, these systems, in which transcriptionally active particles have been visualized (Yeager, M.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	371	, 1997), are considerably more complex; more proteins and many more RNA segments are involved, and precisely calibrated spacings for their packaged genomes have yet to be reported.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Transcription of reovirions is thought to require "activation" by proteases, and concomitant conformational changes (Powell et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	373	, 1993), which, we conjecture, may rearrange the core structure, so as to facilitate motion of the dsRNA during transcription.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	374	 Nevertheless, the same overall requirements apply.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	375	 It will be fascinating to learn more about possible solutions to this problem, and the properties of protein shells that are not only closed containers but also active metabolic compartments.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	376	Received for publication 5 March 1997 and in revised form 30 June 1997.
