0.2730276.16135518.html.plaintext.txt	369	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS  All ASBMB Journals   Molecular and Cellular Proteomics   Journal of Lipid Research   Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Education  Copyright   2005 by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	0	Tripartite haemolysin BL: isolation and characterization of two distinct homologous sets of components from a single Bacillus cereus isolate Douglas J.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	1	Food Research Institute, Department of Food Microbiology and Toxicology, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1925 Willow Drive, Madison WI 53706, USA1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	2	Author for correspondence: Douglas J.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Tel: +1 608 263 6939 Fax: +1 608 263 1114.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Haemolysin BL (HBL), a three-component enterotoxic/necrotizing/vascular permeability toxin, is a likely virulence factor of Bacillus cereus diarrhoeal food poisoning and necrotic infections.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	5	 This paper describes the isolation of two distinct homologous sets of all three HBL components from a single B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The proteins of one set (designated HBL, consisting of B, L1 and L2), were about 87 to 100% identical in N-terminal amino acid sequences to their respective prototype components from strain F837/76, and the proteins of the homologous set (HBLa, consisting of Ba, L1a and L2a) were all about 62 to 65% identical.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Only the latter homologues differed immunochemically and physicochemically from the prototypes.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	8	 HBL and HBLa exhibited similar haemolytic and vascular permeability potencies, and the homologues could be interchanged freely.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	9	 There were no notable differences in activity between the L component homologues.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	10	 However, components B and Ba were significantly different.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Both were secreted as monomers, but unlike B, Ba was isolated as a relatively inactive complex that could be reactivated with urea.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	12	 When Ba was substituted for B in gel-diffusion assays the distinct discontinuous haemolysis pattern typical of the presence of B did not occur.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In suspension assays, excess B inhibited the haemolysis of B-primed cells by L1 (as previously described), but not that of Ba-primed cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Excess Ba had the opposite effect and enhanced lysis of Ba-primed cells, but not that of B-primed cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	15	 These differences reveal details about how the toxin components interact on target cell membranes.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The authors  observations indicate that HBL represents a new family of multicomponent toxins that was generated by a process of gene and operon duplication that occurred either intracellularly or by horizontal transfer, and raise the possibility of the existence of other related toxins in the genetically diverse B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	17	Keywords: Bacillus cereus, hemolysin BL, enterotoxin, gene duplication, discontinuous hemolysis.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	18	Abbreviations: BCA, bicinchoninic acid; HA, hydroxyapatite; HBL, haemolysin BL; TBS, Tris-buffered saline.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	19	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Bacillus cereus is a ubiquitous soil-borne bacterium that, under appropriate circumstances, causes diarrhoeal and emetic food poisoning and a variety of typically necrotic non-gastrointestinal infections (Drobniewski, 1993 ; Kramer  and  Gilbert, 1989 ; Turnbull, 1986 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Among the many potential virulence factors of B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	21	 cereus is haemolysin BL (HBL), a unique and potent three-component pore-forming toxin (Beecher  and  Macmillan, 1991 ; Beecher  and  Wong, 1994c ; Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The toxic activities so far identified for HBL include haemolysis, vascular permeability and necrosis in rabbit skin (Beecher  and  Macmillan, 1991 ; Beecher  and  Wong, 1994c ), fluid accumulation in rabbit ileal loops (Beecher et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 1995b ), toxicity to a number of transformed cell lines (Beecher, 1990 ), in vitro degradation of explanted rabbit retinal tissue, and in vivo ocular necrosis and inflammation in rabbits (Beecher et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	24	 HBL is secreted by 45% of over 200 B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	25	 mycoides isolates tested in our laboratory (Beecher  and  Wong, 1994b ; Schoeni  and  Wong, 1999 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A distinctive feature of HBL is an unusual discontinuous haemolysis pattern produced in blood agar (Beecher  and  Macmillan, 1991 ; Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	27	 When HBL diffuses from a bacterial colony or a well in blood agar, lysis begins away from the well or colony, followed by slow lysis nearer the source.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	28	 cereus strain F837/76, the three HBL components are encoded in an operon by tandemly arranged genes in the order hblC, hblD and hblA, which respectively encode components designated L2, L1 and B (Heinrichs et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Immediately downstream from hblA is an open reading frame, hblB, which is about 85% identical to hblA in the first 158 predicted amino acids.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The hblB gene product has not yet been isolated.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	31	Many isolates in our Bacillus collection produce more than one antigen reactive to antibodies against individual HBL components (Schoeni  and  Wong, 1999 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	32	 For example, on Western blots of denaturing electrophoresis gels B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	33	 cereus MGBC 145 produces two bands reactive with antibodies to HBL components B and L1, and one band reactive with antibodies to component L2.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	34	 This strain is used in studies of experimental endophthalmitis in our laboratory and in others (Beecher et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Because the production of multiple toxin homologues might confound efforts to characterize the molecular basis of B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	36	 cereus virulence in intraocular infections, we decided to characterize the antigens responsible for producing multiple bands on Western blots.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	37	 We isolated and characterized two distinct homologous variants of each HBL component from a single B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	38	 cereus strain, demonstrating that the variant antigens are distinct gene products.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The activities of the variants were essentially the same as the prototype components, the homologues were interchangeable, and the requirement for three components to produce activity was maintained.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	40	 A homologue of one component possessed several important differences in the details of its activity that elucidate some of its interactions with other components on erythrocyte membranes.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	41	   METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Bacterial isolates.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	42	 cereus strain MGBC 145 was used as the source of HBL homologues.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	43	 This strain was isolated from the infected eye of a patient with post-traumatic endophthalmitis (Beecher et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	44	 cereus strain F837/76, an isolate from an infected prostate, was used as the source of prototype HBL components in the present study.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	45	 This isolate was originally chosen as the source of HBL because it is exceptionally toxigenic (Beecher  and  Macmillan, 1990 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	46	Production of crude haemolysin BL.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	47	 cereus isolates were grown at 32  degrees C for 5 h in 3 litres of casein/glucose/yeast extract broth with shaking at 200 r.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The culture supernatants were each concentrated by ammonium sulfate precipitation to 50 ml.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The concentrates were used as sources of crude HBL.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The culture medium, growth conditions and concentration procedure are described in detail elsewhere (Beecher  and  Wong, 1994c ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Details (columns, flow rates, elution gradients, etc.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	52	) of purification steps involving anion-exchange (Whatman DE-52 and Pharmacia Mono-Q) and hydroxyapatite (HA) chromatography were as previously described (Beecher  and  Wong, 1994c ) with the following exceptions.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The pH 5 9 Bistris anion-exchange equilibration buffer was 20 mM instead of 25 mM, and the HA was Macro-Prep ceramic HA (20  microm beads, Bio-Rad) instead of BioGel HTP.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Salt concentrations of fractions were estimated assuming that the gradients were linear and began eluting one column volume after they were started.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Column volumes were estimated empirically by changes in the apparent absorbance of eluate after abrupt changes in salt concentration.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	56	Three additional chromatographic steps were used.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	57	 First, rather than dialysis, buffer exchange of the concentrated culture supernatant was by gel-filtration chromatography on a 2 6x78 cm column of medium-grade Sephadex G-25 (Pharmacia) equilibrated with 20 mM Bistris/HCl, pH 5 9, and eluted at a flow rate of 7 5 ml min-1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Second, for final isolation of the L1a component (see below for nomenclature), fractions from the pH 5 9 Mono-Q column were dialysed against 25 mM Tris/HCl, pH 7 4, and applied to the Mono-Q column equilibrated with the same buffer.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Proteins were eluted with a linear gradient of NaCl from 0 to 0 5 M over 50 ml at a flow rate of 1 ml min-1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Third, for isolation of the L2a the nonbound DE-52 fraction containing L2a was applied to a 1 ml (0 5x5 cm) HA column (as compared to the 1 6x8 cm column usually used) equilibrated with 10 mM NaCl and eluted at 1 ml min-1 with a linear gradient of sodium phosphate from 0 to 0 3 M over 30 ml and collected into 1 ml fractions.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Concentrations of purified proteins were routinely determined by measuring A280 using previously estimated absorption coefficients (1 mg ml-1) of 1 3, 1 8 and 0 8 for B, L1 and L2 (from strain F837/76) respectively.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Initial experiments suggested that the absorption coefficients of B and Ba may differ significantly.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Thus, when homologue doses were to be compared, concentrations were measured using a bicinchoninic acid assay (Pierce Chemical Co.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	64	) in which components from strain F837/76 were used as concentration standards for their respective homologues.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The BCA assay measures primarily peptide bonds rather than aromatic amino acid residues, thus decreasing protein-to-protein variation.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	66	Assay for HBL components and sphingomyelinase.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	67	 HBL components and sphingomyelinase were identified in chromatography fractions immunochemically with dot blots.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The different B and L1 homologues were distinguished from one another by their different apparent molecular masses on Western blots.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The L2 homologues were identical in size, but could be distinguished by their widely different chromatographic behaviour.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The antibodies and procedures used for the immunoassays were described previously (Beecher et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	71	Electrophoresis and protein blotting.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	72	 PAGE was performed using precast ReadyGels (Bio-Rad) composed of polyacrylamide with a Tris/glycine buffer system, using Mini Protean II dual-slab electrophoresis cells (Bio-Rad).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	73	 SDS gels (Laemmli, 1970 ) were composed of 12% polyacrylamide, and native gels (Davis, 1964 ; Ornstein, 1964 ) were composed of 4 to 15% acrylamide gradients.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The minigels were stained with Coomassie brilliant blue R-250 (0 1%, w/v) or silver (Nesterenko et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	75	, 1994 ), or were used for protein blotting.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The Pharmacia LMW Marker Kit was used for size standards (phosphorylase b, bovine serum albumin, ovalbumin, carbonic anhydrase and lactalbumin).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	77	Proteins resolved in SDS and native PAGE gels were transferred to PVDF membranes (Millipore) in a Mini Trans-Blot electrophoretic transfer cell (Bio-Rad) at 100 V, constant voltage, for 1 h or 1 25 h, respectively.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Isoelectric points were determined on a PhastSystem (Pharmacia) using Pharmacia IEF standards and Phastgel IEF gels with pH ranges of 3 to 9 and 4 to 6 5.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	79	 All gels were run at 2000 V, 2 mA, 3 5 W for 75 V h prior to loading samples and at 200 V, 2 mA, 3 5 W for 15 V h during sample loading.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Proteins were focused at 2000 V, 5 mA, 3 5 W for 510 V h (pH 3 to 9 gels) or 410 V h (pH 4 to 6 5 gels).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Purified proteins were prepared for N-terminal sequence analysis as described by Matsudaira (1990) .
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Electroblotted proteins were sent to the Protein/Nucleic Acid Shared Facility at the Cancer Center of the Medical College of Wisconsin for N-terminal sequence analysis by Edman degradation.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	83	Haemolysis assays: gel diffusion.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	84	 For all haemolysis assays (diffusion and turbidimetric), defibrinated sheep blood (Crane Laboratories) was washed in 50 mM Tris/HCl, 150 mM NaCl, pH 7 4 (TBS) prior to use.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Gel-diffusion assays for haemolysin BL were as described previously (Beecher, 1990 ; Beecher  and  Wong, 1994c ) except that 0 3 U ml-1 of B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	86	 cereus phosphatidylcholine-preferring phospholipase C (Boehrenger-Mannheim) was added to the gels.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	87	 This enzyme enhances and preserves the discontinuous haemolysis pattern of HBL by an as-yet unknown mechanism (Beecher  and  Wong, 1996 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	88	 All gel-diffusion assays were at 22 to 25  degrees C.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	89	Haemolysis assays: turbidimetric.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Haemolysis was also measured with turbidimetric assays (Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ) modified to a microtitre plate format.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Washed sheep erythrocytes were diluted into TBS such that 200  microl in a well of a 96-well microtitre plate had an OD620 of 0 7.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	92	 At this OD620 there were approximately 6 1x107 sheep erythrocytes ml-1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Cell suspensions were warmed to the assay temperature prior to addition to the assay plate.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Lysis was measured as the decrease in OD620 over time using a temperature-controlled SpectraFluor spectrophotometer/microplate reader (Tecan).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Haemolysis rates were calculated as the maximum rate of change during the assay period in OD620 min-1x1000 (mOD620 min-1) using DeltaSoft 3, a microplate analysis software package for the Macintosh (Biometallics Inc.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Assay samples consisted either of individual HBL components, combinations of components, or control samples.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Samples were either first mixed and diluted, then transferred to empty microtitre wells for the assay, or diluted and then added separately to the empty assay wells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Premixed samples were added to assay wells in volumes from 5 to 20  microl (usually 10  microl), but always in the same volume for a given assay.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Samples added separately were generally in 5  microl.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Sample volumes were all made identical with TBS when necessary.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Immediately prior to the start of the assay, 200  microl of naive erythrocytes (cells that have not been treated with any HBL component) warmed to the assay temperature were added to wells containing the samples and lysis was monitored as described above.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	102	Priming of erythrocytes by B components.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The priming activity of the HBL B component was described in detail by Beecher  and  Wong (1997) .
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Erythrocytes treated with the B component do not lyse, but slowly become sensitized to the rapid lytic action of the combined L1 and L2 components.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The priming reaction nearly stops at or below 25  degrees C, whereas the L components rapidly (1 to 5 min) lyse primed cells, but not unprimed cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Here, B or Ba was added to erythrocytes at 42  degrees C, then cooled to 25  degrees C for the lysis reaction.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The extent of priming was quantitated by adding 5 nM L1+2 to B-treated erythrocytes at 25  degrees C and measuring the percentage of cells that lysed in less than 5 min.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	108	Quantitation of L component activity.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	109	 To determine the activity of the L components the rate of the rapid lysis of B-primed erythrocytes was measured (Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Sheep erythrocytes were treated with B homologues at 42  degrees C until 100% of the cells were primed.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Primed cells were then added to wells containing the desired amount of L components and lysis was measured as described above and expressed as mOD620 min-1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Some samples of component Ba were treated with 8 M urea to dissociate complexes and then tested for haemolysis and priming activity.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	113	 When these samples were to be compared with non-urea-treated components, the same final concentration of urea was added to the erythrocytes separately from the components.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	114	 During the priming reaction, if present, the urea concentration was 0 11 M.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	115	 When 25 nM excess B or Ba was tested, if urea was present, the final concentration was 0 4 M.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	116	 None of the urea concentrations used had an effect on the lysis rate of L1+2 components or the priming rate of B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Urea at 4 M in wells of gel-diffusion assays had no effect on activity of binary combinations of components (i.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	118	 there was no lysis), and had the effects on ternary combinations shown in Results.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Vascular permeability activity was assayed as described by Glatz et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Briefly, 50  microl samples were injected intradermally in the shaved backs of rabbits, and after 3 h, Evans blue dye was injected into the marginal ear vein.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Samples possessing vascular permeability activity produced areas of oedema and bluing in proportion to the concentration of the toxin.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	122	 High toxin concentrations also produced areas of necrosis.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Female New Zealand White rabbits of 3 to 4 kg (Covance Research Products) were used for all assays.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	124	 All activities are reported as means of duplicate or triplicate samples.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Prototype HBL components isolated from strain F837/76 are referred to as B(F) L1(F) and L2(F) or else the strain from which they were purified is stated.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Among the proteins isolated from strain MGBC 145, the homologues exhibiting the closest relationship to the prototypes from F837/76 (i.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	127	 87 to 100% identity in the N-terminal sequences) are designated B, L1 and L2.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The more distantly related homologues (i.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	129	 62 to 65% identity in the N-terminal sequences) are designated with a subscript  a , i.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Component Ba was isolated as a complex.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Under the assumption that the complex is a dimer, Ba in complex form is sometimes referred to as 2Ba and the urea-treated monomer as Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Combinations of the L components are similarly indicated by L1+2(F), L1+2 and L1a+2a.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Other combinations are specifically identified, e.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Combinations, such as HBL or L1+2, were composed of equimolar concentrations of each component unless otherwise specified.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	135	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Isolation of HBL homologues The following description applies to the isolation of components from B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	136	 For comparisons with the components from MGBC 145, the prototype HBL components were also isolated from B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	137	 cereus F837/76 (data not shown).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	138	DE-52 anion-exchange chromatography.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The desalted fraction from the G-25 column was applied directly to the DE-52 column and eluted with a linear gradient of NaCl as described in Methods and by Beecher  and  Wong (1994c) .
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The elution characteristics of the B, L1 and L2 components from MGBC 145 were essentially identical to those from F837/76, while elution of the  a  components varied to different extents.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The following list indicates what fractions were pooled to isolate each component and the calculated concentration range of NaCl comprised by the fractions.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	142	 L2a, nonbound fraction (isocratic elution); L1a and L2, fractions 23 to 26 (0 10 to 0 13 mM NaCl); L1, (some L2) fractions 27 to 32 (0 13 to 0 17 mM NaCl); B, fractions 33 to 38 (0 17 to 0 21 mM NaCl); Ba, fractions 39 to 46 (0 21 to 0 26 mM NaCl).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Except for L2a, the fraction pools listed above were each applied to the 1 6x8 cm HA column and eluted with identical gradients of phosphate buffer.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	144	 L2a was applied to a smaller HA column as described in Methods.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Upon elution from HA, the proteins are nearly pure, so that comparison of their A280 elution profiles becomes informative.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	146	 1(a) compares the elution profiles of each component from HA relative to the phosphate eluent concentration.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Only the elution profiles of L2 and L2a were exceptionally different from one another.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	148	 At this point, L2a was essentially pure, and no further separations were performed.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Also of interest, L1a and sphingomyelinase behaved identically on HA.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	150	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Chromatographic elution profiles of HBL and HBLa components.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	152	 (a) Elution profiles from HA columns.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The top four profiles are from the 16 ml HA column and the bottom profile is from the 1 ml HA column (details in Methods).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	154	 (b) Elution profiles from Mono-Q (anion-exchange) columns.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	155	 All Mono-Q columns were run at pH 5 9 except for one depicted in the inset, which was run at pH 7 4.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Proteins were eluted with linear salt gradients and flow rates as described in Methods.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Labels adjacent to peaks identify the major proteins in those peaks.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The L1a/S peaks contained both L1a and sphingomyelinase (S).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Inset, separation of L1a from sphingomyelinase on the Mono-Q column at pH 7 4.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The L1a and S peaks are labelled and eluted at 110 and 140 mM, respectively.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The first peak contained no proteins larger than 10 kDa.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The x- and y-axes do not apply to this profile, which is included only to illustrate the effectiveness of separation at pH 7 4.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	163	  Mono-Q anion-exchange chromatography.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Except for L2a, the fractions containing the respective HBL component homologues were pooled and applied to a Mono-Q column.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	165	 1(b) compares the Mono-Q elution profiles for each component.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	166	 All of the homologous component pairs behaved differently on this column (essentially reflecting their behaviour on DE-52).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Note that both peaks that eluted from the column depicted in the top panel in Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	168	 1(b) represent the B component.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The later peak represents intact B, and the early peak represents B with its first two N-terminal residues (Ser-Glu) cleaved by endogenous protease (unpublished observations).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Also note that, as on HA, L1a and sphingomyelinase behaved identically on the Mono-Q column at pH 5 9, but could be easily separated at pH 7 4 (inset, Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Under these conditions, the L1a peak occurred at 110 mM NaCl, and the sphingomyelinase peak was at 140 mM NaCl.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	172	Physicochemical comparison of components Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	173	 2 shows the purified HBL homologues from strains F837/76 and MGBC 145 on SDS-PAGE.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Table 1 compares their N-terminal sequences and their estimated molecular masses and isoelectric points.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Also shown for comparison is the predicted N-terminal sequence from the hblB open reading frame immediately downstream from the B gene (hblA).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	176	View larger version (83K):    Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	177	 SDS-PAGE gel of purified HBL and HBLa components.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Lanes 3 to 5, 7 to 9 and 11 to 13 contain 1  microg of each purified component as labelled at the top of the gel.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Components with a dot above them were isolated from B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	180	 All other components were from B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Lanes 1, 2, 6, 10, 14 and 15 contained low-molecular-mass protein standards (s).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The gel was run and stained as described in Methods.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	183	 N-terminal sequence alignments and characteristics of HBL and HBLa components.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	184	  Between aligned residues, B, L1 and L2 were 92, 100 and 87% identical to their respective prototype components from F837/76.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Ba, L1a and L2a were respectively 60, 65 and 63% identical to B, L1 and L2.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Interestingly, L2a was more similar to L2(F) over 36 residues (67% identical) than to L2 (63% identical).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Ba was 67% identical to the hblB predicted amino acid sequence from F837/76.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	188	 It is doubtful that these identities reflect the overall identities between the respective sequences; for example, B(F) and the predicted hblB amino acid sequence are approximately 85% identical over 158 residues, but only 60% identical over 43 aligned N-terminal residues.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	189	Isolation of Ba as a complex We recently found, in experiments unrelated to this study, that treatment of the B component from strain F837/76 at 65  degrees C converts it to stable but relatively inactive complexes, primarily dimers (analysis to be presented elsewhere).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The complexes can be identified as slowly migrating bands on native PAGE gels and can be dissociated to the monomer with 8 M urea, which also restores activity.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	191	 3(a) shows that, in our preparation, Ba was a complex that can be dissociated with urea.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Unlike B, which forms mixtures of increasingly larger complexes over time, Ba was present primarily as a single complexed species that migrated at the same rate as the initial complex formed by B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The other proteins purified in this study were all monomers, because their migration distances on native PAGE were not affected by 6 to 8 M urea (not shown).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	194	View larger version (95K):    Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Production of Ba as a monomer and isolation as a dimer.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Lanes 1 to 5, native PAGE of components B and Ba in complex and monomer forms.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Each lane was loaded with 0 25  microg protein and the gel was stained with silver.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Lane 1 (B65), component B treated at 65  degrees C, 10 min, to form complexes.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Lane 2 (B), untreated component B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Lane 3 (Ba), untreated component Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Lane 5 (BaU), component Ba added to gel in the presence of 6 M urea.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Note: 8 M urea eliminates upper band (not shown).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Lanes 6 and 7, Western blot probed with polyclonal antiserum to B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Lane 6 (F), 20  microl culture supernatant from B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	205	 cereus F837/76 (HBL prototype strain).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Lane 7 (M), 20  microl culture supernatant from B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	207	 cereus MGBC 145 (HBLa-producing strain).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	208	  Fresh culture supernatants were run on a native PAGE gel and analysed by Western blotting to determine whether Ba is secreted as a dimer.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	209	 3(b) compares supernatants from strains MGBC 145 and F837/76 (which produces only B).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	210	 No complex was detected in either supernatant.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Both supernatants did exhibit one slow-moving band, which did not correspond to the complexes.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The identities of these bands are unknown.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	213	Haemolysis by HBL and HBLa components: similarities Activity of component combinations.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	214	 In turbidimetric haemolysis assays, sheep erythrocytes were treated with all possible binary and ternary combinations of the prototype-like and  a  components from MGBC 145.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	215	 None of the binary combinations was lytic.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Among the 20 possible three-component combinations, all eight of those possessing B, L1 and L2 homologues were lytic.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	217	 None of the 12 combinations that possessed redundant homologues (e.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Thus, the three-component requirement for HBL activity was maintained, and homologous components could be interchanged freely.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	219	 During the priming reaction, which occurs independently of the L components, naive erythrocytes gradually become sensitive to rapid lytic action by the L components (Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	220	 This slow priming occurred here for both B and Ba from MGBC 145.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	221	 B at 5 nM completely primed erythrocytes at 40  degrees C in 1 h, whereas 10 nM Ba monomer (urea-treated) required 1 25 h to prime all of the cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Untreated Ba complex also primed erythrocytes.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	223	 However, its activity has not yet been characterized thoroughly because we had only limited quantities, and the monomer appears to be the natural form (Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	224	Rapid lytic activities of all L components.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	225	 We tested all combinations of L and La components for their abilities to lyse B- and Ba-primed cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	226	 For all combinations possessing L1 and L2 homologues (e.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	227	) lysis by 0 5 to 10 nM of the L components was rapid and complete (data not shown).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	228	 L1a appeared to be about half as potent as L1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	229	 However, minor concentration inaccuracies cannot yet be ruled out.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	230	 There were no apparent differences in activities between L2 and L2a.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	231	Haemolysis by HBL and HBLa components: differences Haemolysis in blood agar.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	232	 When B was present the discontinuous haemolysis pattern typical of HBL occurred for all L component combinations (i.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	233	 L1+2, L1+2a, L1a+2 and L1a+2a).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	234	 This suggests that the L1 and L1a components interact in similar ways with the B component to produce the pattern (L2 neither inhibits B or L1, nor is it inhibited by them and thus does not contribute to the discontinuous pattern: Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	235	 However, when Ba replaced B, the discontinuous pattern did not occur for any L combination, i.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	236	 lysis was continuous from the well edge to the edge of the lysis zone.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	237	 4 shows the effect of varying the concentration of L1 on the haemolysis pattern in the presence of B or Ba (L1a produced the same effects in blood agar; not shown).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The discontinuous pattern occurred at all L1 concentrations in the presence of B, but lysis occurred more quickly near the well at lower L1 concentrations, which appear nearly continuous in the figure.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	239	 A discontinuous pattern was not evident at any time around the wells containing Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	240	View larger version (79K):    Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Effect of urea and L1 concentration on the haemolysis pattern in sheep blood produced by B and Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Wells in rows received 100 ng of either B or Ba in the presence or absence of 8 M urea as indicated on the left.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Wells in columns received L1 at the concentrations indicated at the bottom.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	244	 All four horizontal strips were on the same blood agar gel.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The image was recorded after 6 h at 25  degrees C.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	246	 4 also indicates that 8 M urea significantly enhanced the activity of Ba, but quantitation of the enhancement was not possible because of the inhibitory effects of excess L1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The relative potencies of B and Ba in blood agar were estimated by placing serial dilutions of each in wells surrounding a central well containing 100 ng L1+2.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	248	 In this method B primes cells surrounding the well without the inhibitory effect of excess L1 (Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The lowest amounts of B, Ba and Ba+8 M urea exhibiting lytic activity were 0 3, 4 and 1 25 ng per well respectively.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	250	Inhibition of L1 components by B and Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Just as excess L1 inhibits the priming reaction of B to produce discontinuous haemolysis on blood agar, it also inhibits priming in erythrocyte suspensions (Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Likewise, the addition of excess B to previously primed erythrocytes inhibits the lysis rate of L1 (Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	253	 We examined the abilities of excess B and Ba components to inhibit the lysis of B- and Ba-primed cells by L1 (preliminary experiments indicated that there were no discernible differences between L1 and L1a components; therefore only results using L1 are shown).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The results are shown in Table 2.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Effect of excess B, Ba or 2Ba on erythrocyte lysis by components L1+2.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	256	  Sheep erythrocytes were primed at 42  degrees C with 5 nM B or 10 nM Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The primed erythrocytes were lysed with 5 nM L1+2 in the presence or absence of 25 nM B or Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The Ba was added either in 8 M urea to test the monomer, or only in buffer to test the complex (2Ba).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Final urea concentrations in samples and controls are described in Methods.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	260	There were striking differences between the effects of excess B and excess Ba on the lysis rate produced by L1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	261	 As expected, excess B inhibited the lysis of B-primed cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	262	 However, excess Ba actually enhanced haemolysis of Ba-primed cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Neither excess B nor excess Ba significantly affected the lysis rate of cells primed by the other protein.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Complexed Ba (2Ba in Table 2) did not significantly affect lysis of cells primed by either B or Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	265	Most proteins unfold in 8 M urea, and it was possible that the enhanced activity of urea-treated Ba was due to the unfolding and refolding of Ba rather than dissolution of the complex per se.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	266	 When B, which was already in monomer form, was first dissolved in 8 M urea, its inhibition of lysis differed by less than 10 % compared to untreated B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	267	 This suggests that urea had little effect on the monomer.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	268	Vascular permeability activity of HBL and HBLa The ability of the HBL and HBLa components to cause vascular permeability and necrosis in rabbit skin was tested using combinations that appeared likely to be active based on their haemolytic characteristics.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Samples containing 0 5 to 1 5  microg of single components and binary combinations produced no reaction.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	270	 There were no clear differences between samples containing 0 5  microg of each component of HBL from F837/76, or HBL and HBLa from MGBC 145, which produced respectively 20 plus or minus 1 6, 21 plus or minus 1 2 and 20 plus or minus 2 0 mm of bluing and 3 7 plus or minus 2 5, 4 4 plus or minus 3 7 and 4 0 plus or minus 1 2 mm of necrosis (means plus or minus SD, n=3).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Similar reactions were obtained when Ba was mixed with L1+2 and when B(F) was mixed with L1a+2a.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	272	 When B and Ba concentrations were varied with constant L1+2, necrosis occurred with 0 5  microg of B and Ba, but not with 0 25 and 0 125  microg.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The only difference appeared in the bluing response between 0 125  microg of B and 0 125  microg of Ba, which produced 23 plus or minus 0 5 and 9 plus or minus 2 6 mm zones respectively.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	274	Ba was not treated with urea prior to vascular permeability testing to avoid any complications that high concentrations of urea might produce.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	275	 This component will be further characterized when conditions are developed to produce significant concentrations of Ba monomer in physiological salt concentrations.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	276	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   We have noted that numerous B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	277	 cereus strains produce multiple bands on Western blots probed with antibodies specific for components of HBL.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The presence of multiple toxin homlogues might complicate attempts to understand virulence mechanisms.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Therefore, we tried to determine whether the different bands seen on Western blots represent distinct gene products.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Using antibodies to track the chromatographic behaviour of the different forms of the HBL components, we isolated two distinct homologues of each component from the medically important B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Both sets of homologues, HBL and HBLa, were haemolytic, dermonecrotic, and caused vascular permeability in rabbit skin with similar potencies.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Overall, there were no discernible differences in activity between the L homologues, but there were significant differences in activity between B and Ba.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	283	The homologous components differed from one another in size, net charge and chromatographic behaviour.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	284	 L1 and L1a behaved most similarly, and L1a coeluted with sphingomyelinase from HA and from anion-exchangers at pH 5 9.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	285	 However, it could be separated from sphingomyelinase at pH 7 4.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	286	 L2 and L2a were essentially identical in size, but because they differed in pI by a full pH unit, they were readily separated by ion-exchange chromatography, and the exceptionally late elution of L2a from HA made it easy to isolate in as few as two chromatographic steps.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	287	 It was isolated as a complex, which may explain its incongruous chromatographic elution.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Its apparent pI was 6 0 (Table 1), and one would expect that it would elute earlier from anion-exchange columns than B (pI 5 3).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Instead, it eluted later, at 1 3 times the elution volume of B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	290	 The heat-generated complexes of B (upper bands, Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	291	 3a, lane B65) behave in the same way (data to be published elsewhere).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	292	 It appears, however, that Ba is naturally produced as a monomer, which is how it appeared in fresh B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	293	 cereus culture supernatant (Fig.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	294	 We are investigating the factors that result in complex formation during purification.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	295	All of the  a  components were 62 to 65% identical to their respective homologues over 30 to 43 residues.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Similar identity (60%) in strain F837/76 between the N-termini of B and the predicted hblB sequence rises to approximately 85% over the first 158 residues (Heinrichs et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	297	, 1993 ), suggesting that the HBLa components may prove to be more closely related to HBL components than indicated by the N-termini.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	298	 The high sequence similarity among the  a  homologues suggests that the three genes may have been either simultaneously duplicated or simultaneously transferred horizontally, and this would have been facilitated by their tandem arrangement in an operon (Ryan et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	299	 We have also determined that the four hbl genes in strain F837/76 all arose via duplication of a single gene (Beecher, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Note that HBL has been mapped to a portion of the B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	301	 cereus chromosome that exhibits exceptional variability compared with other regions, and that this variable region is sometimes located on large extrachromosomal DNA fragments that appear to be stable, but might also prove to be large mobile plasmids (Carlson et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	302	, 1996a , b ; Carlson  and  Kolsto, 1994 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	303	 This raises fundamental questions about the extent and role of gene duplication and horizontal transfer in the evolution of B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	304	In addition to HBL and HBLa, we have found (data not shown) that strain MGBC 145 expresses another homologous three-component toxin designated nonhaemolytic enterotoxin (NHE) by Lund  and  Granum (1996) .
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Data from several studies suggest that, among strains that express either HBL or NHE, 80% of them express both (Buchanan  and  Schultz, 1994 ; Day et al.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	306	, 1994 ; Rusul  and  Yaacob, 1995 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	307	 These data are based on detection of the L2 protein of HBL, or the NHEA protein, by two commercial kits (Beecher  and  Wong, 1994a ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	308	Our observations highlight practical problems both for the diagnosis of toxigenic strains and for the identification of B.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	309	 cereus virulence factors, particularly since there may be additional unidentified HBL homologues.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Since the discontinuous haemolysis pattern typical of HBL appears to be produced only in the presence of the prototype B component, discontinuous lysis around colonies or culture supernatants (Beecher  and  Wong, 1994b ) now appears to be of limited diagnostic value.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	311	 For maximum value, other methods should detect all relevant toxin components or component combinations.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	312	 However, not all of these components and combinations are completely defined.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	313	 In attempts to identify virulence factors, possible contributions from multiple, potentially interacting, multicomponent toxins must be kept in mind.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	314	Although numerous physical phenomena have been documented for HBL, little is known about how the components interact at the molecular level beyond the fact that the they bind to cells independently and must physically interact to form pores.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	315	 It is also clear that there is a change in the physical state of B between its initial association with the membrane (Bm) and its primed state (B').
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	316	 This change may involve conformational changes, oligomerization, membrane insertion, or all three.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	317	 The experiment represented in Table 2 provides some insight into such additional interactions as discussed below.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	318	We previously found that the lysis of B-primed erythrocytes by L1+2 was inhibited by excess B added simultaneously with the L components, and that it is L1 that is inhibited, not L2 (Beecher  and  Wong, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Table 2 shows that excess B and Ba have different effects, and that the specific effect depends on which was used to prime the cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	320	 A significant effect occurred only when the protein added in excess was the same as that used to prime cells.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	321	 This indicates that the excess Bm must physically interact with B' (likewise for excess and Ba'), and that B and Ba are sufficiently unrelated that they do not interact with one another.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	322	The excess B may inhibit lysis simply by obstructing L1 from contact with B', or by producing inefficient lytic complexes composed of Bm, B' and L1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Enhancement of lysis by Ba was unexpected, and the mechanism by which this occurs is unclear.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	324	 It might occur either if enhances the incorporation of L1 into the lesion, or if  to Ba' to L1 complexes are more efficient than Ba' to L1 complexes.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	325	There is a structural basis for suggesting that L1 binds more efficiently to  to Ba' complexes.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	326	 B and L1 from strain F837/76 appear to be distant homologues, and the most significant structural difference between them is that B is missing 40 residues of a 60-residue apparent transmembrane segment present in L1 (Beecher, 1997 ).
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The observed size difference of approximately 4 4 kDa between B and Ba (Table 1) equates with a difference of approximately 40 residues.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	328	 In essence, Ba may act as a hybrid between B and L1 by virtue of retaining the full transmembrane segment that is characteristic of L1.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	329	While our observations emphasize practical difficulties for diagnosis and identification of virulence factors, they also provide promising opportunities for structure to function analysis of the HBL family of toxins.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	330	 The structural and functional differences between B and Ba are significant and may provide insight into the mechanism of HBL toxicity as well as an explanation for the unique haemolytic phenomena of this toxin.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	331	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   This work was supported by grant 96-35201-3765 from the National Research Initiative Competitive Grants Program of the US Department of Agriculture, and by the College of Agricultural and Life Sciences, University of Wisconsin-Madison.

0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	377	Int J Food Microbiol 53, 159-167.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	378	 In Pharmacology of Bacterial Toxins, pp.
0.1914435.10846215.html.plaintext.txt	379	Received 24 August 1999; revised 7 December 1999; accepted 16 March 2000.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	0	Focal Adhesion Kinase Plays a Pivotal Role in Herpes Simplex Virus Entry* Natalia Cheshenko, Wen Liu, Lisa M.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Departments of Pediatrics and  Microbiology, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, New York, New York 10029.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, March 31, 2005 , and in revised form, June 29, 2005.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Development of strategies to prevent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection requires knowledge of cellular pathways harnessed by the virus for invasion.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	4	 This study demonstrates that HSV induces rapid phosphorylation of focal adhesion kinase (FAK) in several human target cells and that phosphorylation is important for entry post-binding.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Nuclear transport of the viral tegument protein VP16, transport of viral capsids to the nuclear pore, and downstream events (including expression of immediate-early genes and viral plaque formation) were substantially reduced in cells transfected with dominant-negative mutants of FAK or small interfering RNA designed to inhibit FAK expression.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	6	 These observations were substantiated using mouse embryonic fibroblast cells derived from embryonic FAK-deficient mice.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Infection was reduced by  > 90% in knockout cells relative to control cells and was further reduced if the knockout cells were transfected with small interfering RNA targeting proline-rich tyrosine kinase-2, which was also phosphorylated in response to HSV.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The knockout cells were permissive for viral binding, and virus triggered an intracellular calcium response, but nuclear transport was inhibited.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Together, these results support a novel model for invasion that implicates FAK phosphorylation as important for delivery of viral capsids to the nuclear pore.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	10	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Herpes simplex virus (HSV)1 type 2 is a major global health problem, the leading cause of genital herpes and neonatal herpes encephalitis, and a major cofactor for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Novel strategies to prevent HSV-2 and other sexually transmitted infections are urgently needed.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Development of new approaches requires an understanding of the molecular and cellular events critical for the establishment of infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Previous work demonstrates that HSV entry is a complex process requiring the following steps: (i) binding to heparan sulfate receptors; (ii) engagement of glycoprotein D coreceptors; (iii) penetration, which, for human epithelial cells, is mediated primarily by fusion of the viral envelope with the cell membrane; (iv) transport of the viral tegument protein VP16 (trans-inducing factor (TIF)) to the nucleus; and (v) transport of viral capsids to the nuclear pore with release of viral DNA into the nucleoplasm (1, 2).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Glycoprotein B plays the major role in mediating binding of HSV-2 to heparan sulfate receptors, whereas glycoprotein C plays a more dominant role in mediating binding of HSV-1 (3, 4).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	15	 For both serotypes, glycoproteins B, D, and H-L are required for penetration, but their precise role and the cellular pathways important for viral invasion have not been fully elucidated.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The observations that heparan sulfate is the major attachment receptor for HSV and that heparan sulfate moieties also interact with gp120 of HIV fostered the development of sulfated or sulfonated polymers as candidate topical microbicides to prevent viral transmission.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	17	 These compounds prevent genital herpes in the mouse and simian immunodeficiency virus in the macaque and are currently being evaluated in Phase II/III clinical trials (5, 6).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	18	 However, competitive antagonists of viral binding are not likely to be sufficient to fully protect against sexual transmission.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Experience with systemic therapy indicates that combination therapies that target more than one step in the viral life cycle are optimal.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Thus, elucidating the cellular pathways required for viral entry may provide novel targets for microbicide development.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	21	We reported previously that both serotypes of HSV trigger inositol triphosphate-mediated release of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Ca2+ stores and that Ca2+ signaling plays a critical role in viral entry (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Pharmacological inhibition of ER Ca2+ release or chelation of intracellular Ca2+ reduces nuclear transport of the viral tegument protein VP16, a surrogate marker for capsid transport, and the downstream events in the viral life cycle, including expression of viral immediate-early genes and viral plaque formation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Activation of Ca2+ signaling is associated with triggering of phosphorylation signaling pathways.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Specifically, we observed previously that HSV-1 and HSV-2 trigger the phosphorylation of focal adhesion kinase (FAK) within 5-10 min following exposure of Vero (monkey kidney) or CaSki (human cervical epithelial) cells to virus.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	25	 FAK phosphorylation appears to occur downstream of release of ER Ca2+ stores, as treatment of cells with 2-aminoethoxydiphenyl borate, an inositol triphosphate receptor antagonist that prevents release of ER Ca2+, or chelation of intracellular Ca2+ blocks the virus-induced phosphorylation of FAK.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Activation of both pathways (Ca2+ and FAK phosphorylation) requires exposure to entry-competent virus, as HSV-1 deleted in the glycoproteins essential for penetration (glycoproteins B, D, and H-L) fails to induce Ca2+ release or to trigger FAK phosphorylation, whereas Ca2+ release and phosphorylation are preserved following exposure to the repaired viruses and to inactivated virus, which retain the ability to penetrate cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	27	 These findings led to the proposal of a new paradigm for HSV entry in which HSV triggers inositol triphosphate-mediated release of ER Ca2+ stores, which may facilitate fusion of the viral envelope and cell membrane, allowing delivery of capsids to the cytoplasm (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In response to activation of the Ca2+ pathways, we hypothesize that FAK and related signaling pathways are activated, which may promote transport of the viral capsids to the nuclear pores.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	29	 This study was designed to test this hypothesis and to evaluate whether HSV exploits FAK signaling pathways to promote its nuclear transport.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	30	 We used complementary molecular techniques, including dominant-negative variants, small interfering RNA (siRNA), and knockout cells, to explore the role played by FAK in HSV invasion.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	31	 We tested the hypothesis with both serotypes using human and murine cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Our findings indicate that FAK phosphorylation plays a central role in promoting transport of viral capsids.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	33	View larger version (71K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	34	 HSV induces phosphorylation of FAK in multiple human target cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Cells were mock-infected or infected with HSV-2(G) (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	36	 At the indicated times post-infection (minutes), cell lysates were prepared, and proteins were separated, transferred by Western blotting, and incubated with anti-phospho-Tyr397 FAK antibody (FAK[pY397]).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Blots were then stripped and reprobed with mAb to total FAK.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The blots are representative of results obtained from three independent experiments.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	39	     MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Cells and Viruses CaSki (human cervical epithelial), CaCo-2 (human colonic epithelial), and SK-N-SH (human neuroblastoma) cells were obtained from American Type Culture Collection and passaged in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Immortalized human endocervical and ectocervical cells were a generous gift from R.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Mouse embryonic fibroblast (MEF) cells derived from embryonic FAK-deficient mice (FAK-/-) and control MEF cells (FAK+/+) were originally described by Ilic et al.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	42	 (9) and were a generous gift from I.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Gelman (Mount Sinai School of Medicine).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The FAK+/+ cells were derived from the same age embryos (day 8).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Cells were cultured overnight in serum-free medium to minimize background tyrosine phosphorylation due to growth factors in serum.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Roizman, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL) and vesicular stomatitis virus-Indiana (provided by P.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Palese, Mount Sinai School of Medicine) were grown on Vero cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	48	 HSV-1 containing a green fluorescent protein (GFP)-VP26 fusion protein (designated K26GFP) was a generous gift from P.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Desai (The Johns Hopkins University) (10).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Heat-inactivated virus was prepared by heating to 56  degrees C for 30 min.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	51	Purification and Quantification of Viruses For binding and Ca2+ studies, dextran-purified viruses were used as described previously (4, 11).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Titers of the purified virus were determined by plaque assays.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Relative viral particle numbers were determined by comparing the amounts of glycoprotein D by optical densitometry after Western blotting with anti-glycoprotein D monoclonal antibody (mAb) 1103 (Rumbaugh-Goodwin Institute, Plantation, FL) as described previously (3, 12).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	54	Reagents EGTA and ionomycin were purchased from Calbiochem and diluted in Me2SO or phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) following the manufacturer's instructions.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Fura-2 acetoxymethyl ester was purchased from Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Heparin and cycloheximide were purchased from Sigma.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	57	Plasmids and Transfections pKH3-FAK carrying the gene for wild-type FAK and pKH3-Y397 carrying the FAK gene with a Y397F mutation were gifts from J.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Guan (Cornell University, Ithaca, NY).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	59	 All transfections were done with Effectene transfection reagent (Qiagen Inc.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	60	) following the manufacturer's protocol.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	61	 CaSki, FAK+/+, and FAK-/- cells were grown in 12-well plates and transfected with siRNA for FAK and Pyk2 and with control nonspecific siRNA using siRNA/ siABTM assay kits (Upstate%20Biotechnology">Upstate Biotechnology Inc.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	62	) at a concentration of 100 pmol/well.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	63	 24 h post-transfection, the cells were infected with virus and analyzed for expression of phosphorylated FAK/FAK and phosphorylated Pyk2/Pyk2 by preparing cell lysates and performing Western blotting as detailed below.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	64	Measurement of [Ca2+]i Cells were loaded with 25 mM fura-2 acetoxymethyl ester prepared in PBS for 30-60 min, rinsed with PBS for 30 min at 37  degrees C, and then exposed sequentially to PBS buffer or HSV diluted in PBS at 37  degrees C.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The viral inoculum was equivalent to a multiplicity of infection (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	66	) equal to 1-5 plaque-forming units (pfu)/cell.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Using a Nikon Eclipse TE300 inverted epifluorescence microscope linked to a cooled Pentamax CCD camera (Princeton Instruments) interfaced with a digital imaging system (MetaFluor, Molecular Devices, Downingtown, PA), [Ca2+]i was measured in individually identified fura-2-loaded cells visualized using a Nikon S Fluor x40 objective (numerical aperture of 0.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Cells were alternately excited at 340 and 380 nm, and the images were digitized for subsequent analysis.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Images were acquired every 2-10 s.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	70	 An intracellular calibration was performed at the conclusion of each experiment as described previously (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	71	 8-15 cells were monitored for each experiment.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	72	Plaque Assays Briefly, cells in 6-well dishes were exposed to virus for 2 h at 37  degrees C; the inoculum was removed; and cells were washed three times with PBS.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The cells were then overlaid with medium containing 0.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	74	 For HSV-1(KOS) and HSV-2(G), plaques were counted by immunoassay (black plaque) (4).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	75	 For vesicular stomatitis virus, cells were overlaid with 1% methylcellulose, fixed after 24 h with methanol, and stained with Giemsa stain.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Unless indicated otherwise, the m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	77	 was selected to yield 200-500 pfu/well (e.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	78	Viral Binding and VP16 Time Course Assays To examine which steps in HSV infection are blocked in transfected or knockout cells, viral binding and VP16 transport to the nucleus were compared.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For binding studies, cells were exposed to serial 2-fold dilutions of purified HSV-2(G) for 5 h at 4  degrees C.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Unbound virus was removed by washing, and cell-bound virus was analyzed by preparing Western blots of cell lysates and probing with anti-glycoprotein D mAb 1103.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	81	 To examine transport of VP16 to the nucleus, synchronized infection assays were conducted as described previously (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Cells were precooled and exposed to HSV at 4  degrees C for 2 h at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	83	1, 1, or 10 pfu/cell to allow binding.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Unbound virus was removed, and the cells were washed three times with PBS and then transferred to 37  degrees C for 15 min to allow penetration.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Unpenetrated virus was inactivated by washing the cell monolayer with a low pH citrate buffer adjusted to pH 3.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	86	0 for 2 min and then by washing three times with PBS.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The cells were overlaid with fresh medium, and nuclear extracts were prepared 1 h after citrate treatment.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The nuclear proteins were separated on a 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gel, transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) using a Trans-Blot system (Bio-Rad), and blocked overnight in 5% milk-containing Tris-buffered saline.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Membranes were incubated with mouse anti-VP16 antibody (1:500 dilution; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	90	), diluted in 5% milk-containing Tris-buffered saline for 2 h, and rinsed extensively with 50 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The membranes were then incubated with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG (1:1000 dilution; Calbiochem) in 5% milk-containing PBS for 2 h.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	92	 After rinsing, the membranes were developed using Immuno-Star-AP chemiluminescent kit (Bio-Rad).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Blots were scanned and analyzed using the GelDoc 2000 system.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (27K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	95	 FAK-/- cells exhibit reduced susceptibility to HSV infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	96	 A, FAK+/+ and FAK-/- cells were infected with HSV-2(G) (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	97	 At the indicated times post-infection, cell lysates were prepared, and proteins were separated, transferred by Western blotting, and incubated with anti-phospho-Tyr397 FAK antibody (FAK[pY397]).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Blots were then stripped and reprobed with mAb to total FAK and with antibody to -actin.

0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	100	 B, to compare susceptibility to HSV infection, the cells were exposed to serial dilutions of HSV-1(KOS) (VP26-GFP), HSV-2(G), or vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV).

0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	105	 of 1 pfu/cell for the indicated times (5-120 min).

0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	108	 44-624G, BIOSOURCE, Camarillo, CA), or with a 1:500 dilution of rabbit anti-phospho-Tyr402 Pyk2, which recognizes the tyrosine autophosphorylation site at position 402 (catalog no.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The membranes were then stripped and reincubated with a 1:1000 dilution of mouse anti-FAK mAb (catalog no.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	110	 F15020 [GenBank] , Transduction Laboratories), which recognizes total FAK, or with a 1:500 dilution of rabbit anti-Pyk2 antibody, which recognizes total Pyk2 (catalog no.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	111	 07-437, Upstate%20Biotechnology">Upstate Biotechnology Inc.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	112	View larger version (41K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	113	 FAK is required for steps post-binding.
