0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	124	  Confocal Microscopy CaSki, FAK+/+, and FAK-/- cells were grown on glass coverslips in 12-well plates and, if indicated, transfected with siRNA as described above and then infected 24 h post-transfection with K26GFP at the indicated m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	125	 At the indicated times post-infection, the infected cell monolayers were washed three times with PBS.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	126	 To label plasma membranes, the cells were stained for 30 min with EZ-Link sulfosuccinimidobiotin reagent (1:1000 dilution; Pierce), which reacts with primary amines on cell-surface proteins prior to fixation (13), and the biotinylated cells were reacted with Alexa Fluor 647-conjugated streptavidin antibody (1:1000 dilution; Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Microtubules were labeled with anti--tubulin mAb (1:200 dilution; catalog no.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	128	) and Alexa Fluor 647-conjugated goat anti-mouse secondary antibody (1:200 dilution; Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Nuclei were detected by staining with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole nucleic acid stain (Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Images were examined using a Zeiss LSM 510 Meta confocal microscope fitted with x100 objective.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Image analysis and subcellular co-localization were generated and analyzed using the LSM confocal software package.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Quantification of amounts of cell-associated GFP was performed with NIH Image densitometric software.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	133	 In addition, to determine the fraction of cells expressing nuclear GFP 8 h post-infection, 100 cells were analyzed and counted.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	134	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   We previously showed that HSV induces FAK phosphorylation in CaSki or Vero cells and that phosphorylation requires fusion-competent virus (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	135	 This study was expanded to include multiple cell types known to be susceptible to HSV-2.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Cells were serum-starved overnight and exposed to HSV-2 or mock-infected.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	137	 At the indicated times post-infection, cell lysates were prepared and examined for expression of total and phosphorylated FAKs by Western blotting.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	138	 HSV-2 induced an increase in phosphorylated FAK within 5 min in CaSki cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Similar results were obtained with immortalized human ectocervical cells (Ecto1E6/E7), colonic cells (CaCo-2), neuronal cells (SH-N-SK), and macrophages (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	140	View larger version (34K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Transfection of CaSki cells with FAK-specific siRNA or with the dominant-negative variant Y397F reduces susceptibility to HSV.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	142	 A, CaSki cells were transfected with FAK-specific or control siRNA and then, 24 h later, mock-infected or infected with HSV-2(G) (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	143	 5 min post-infection, cell lysates were prepared, and proteins were separated, transferred by Western blotting, and incubated with anti-phospho-Tyr397 FAK antibody (FAK[pY397]).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Blots were then stripped and reprobed with mAb to total FAK and with antibody to -actin as a control.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	145	 B, alternatively, CaSki cells were mock-transfected or transfected with empty vector, wild-type FAK, or the Y397F variant and, 24 h later, infected with HSV-2 (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Cell lysates were prepared 5 min post-infection and analyzed for total and phosphorylated FAKs by immunoblotting.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	147	 C, to assess the impact of the transfections on susceptibility to HSV, cells were transfected and, 24 h later, infected with 150 pfu of HSV-2(G)/ well.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Plaques were counted after immunostaining 48 h post-infection, and the results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	149	 of three independent experiments.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	150	  To determine whether phosphorylated FAK contributes to HSV infection, we used several different strategies.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	151	 First, we exposed MEF cells derived from embryonic FAK-deficient mice (FAK-/-) (9) and control MEF cells (FAK+/+) to HSV-2 and examined FAK response and susceptibility to infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	152	 HSV-2 induced an 3-fold increase in the level of phosphorylated FAK as a percentage of total FAK compared with mock-infected cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	153	 2A, left panel); the response persisted for 1 h.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	154	 In contrast, no FAK or phosphorylated FAK was detected in FAK-/- cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Moreover, FAK-/- cells showed reduced susceptibility to infection by either serotype (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Viral titers were reduced by 93 and 96% in FAK-/- cells relative to FAK+/+ cells for HSV-1 and HSV-2, respectively.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Notably, no reduction in susceptibility to vesicular stomatitis virus was observed for FAK-/- cells relative to FAK+/+ cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Susceptibility to HSV infection was partially restored if cells were transfected with the wild-type FAK gene (data not shown).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	159	To more carefully explore which steps in viral infection are impaired in FAK-/- cells, we compared viral binding and nuclear transport of the viral tegument protein VP16 in FAK-/- and FAK+/+ cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The results demonstrate that there was no reduction in binding of virus to cells in FAK-/- cells relative to FAK+/+ cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	161	 However, nuclear transport of VP16 1 h after citrate treatment was substantially reduced in FAK-/- cells compared with FAK+/+ cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The blots were scanned, and optical densitometry corrected for differences in loading.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	163	 of 10 pfu/cell, there was an 93% reduction in the relative amounts of VP16 detected in the nuclei of FAK-/- cells compared with FAK+/+ cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The amount of nuclear VP16 detected was comparable with that observed if FAK+/+ cells were infected with 10-fold less virus (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	165	 To ensure that nuclear VP16 reflects transported and not newly synthesized protein, experiments were also conducted in the presence of cycloheximide, an inhibitor of protein synthesis (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Comparable amounts of nuclear VP16 were detected 1 h after citrate treatment in FAK+/+ cells independent of cycloheximide treatment and accounted for 73% of total cell-associated VP16.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	167	 As anticipated, a substantial reduction in viral ICP4 expression was also observed in FAK-/- cells compared with FAK+/+ cells, consistent with impaired delivery of viral DNA to the cell nucleus and thus viral gene expression (data not shown).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Taken together, these results suggest that, in the absence of FAK, viral invasion is blocked at a step post-binding, leading to reduced nuclear transport of VP16 and inhibition of downstream events, including expression of immediate-early gene products and plaque formation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	169	Because the embryonic knockout cells are murine and because our goal is to identify the signaling pathways required for HSV infection of human target cells, we adopted a complementary strategy to assess the role of FAK and its phosphorylation in human cervical epithelial cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	170	 CaSki cells were transfected with siRNA specific for FAK, a dominant-negative variant of FAK (Y397F) in which the major autophosphorylation site has been mutated (a gift from J.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Guan) (14), or appropriate controls, and the impact on HSV infection was examined.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Transfection with FAK sequence-specific siRNA (but not control nonspecific siRNA) reduced FAK protein expression by 85% (based on optical densitometry scanning of blots) and prevented HSV-induced FAK phosphorylation (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Similarly, a substantial reduction (70%) in virus-triggered phosphorylated FAK was also observed in CaSki cells transfected with Y397F compared with cells transfected with wild-type FAK (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Transfection with the FAK-specific siRNA or the Y397F FAK variant also reduced HSV-2 infection (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	175	 4C), supporting the results obtained for FAK-/- cells showing that FAK and its phosphorylation play important roles in HSV infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	176	View larger version (111K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Delivery of viral capsids to the cytoplasm and newly synthesized GFP are readily detected by confocal microscopy following infection of cells with HSV-1(KOS) (GFP-VP26) (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	178	 A, CaSki cells were infected at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	179	1 (upper panels), 1 (middle panels), or 10 (lower panels) pfu/cell and, at the indicated times post-infection, fixed and stained as described under "Materials and Methods.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	180	" Red, plasma membrane; blue, 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole staining delineating nuclei; green, viral capsid GFP fusion protein.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	181	 B, cells were infected in the absence (upper panels) or presence (lower panels) of cycloheximide (Cyclohex; 10  microg/ml).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The results are representative of three independent experiments.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	183	  To determine whether FAK inactivation prevents viral capsid transport, confocal microscopy studies were conducted.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	184	 For these studies, we took advantage of the viral variant, K26GFP, an HSV-1 that expresses a GFP-VP26 fusion protein; VP26 is a major viral capsid protein.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	185	 K26GFP grows comparably to wild-type virus in cell culture (10), and infection of FAK-/- cells was impaired to a similar extent for K26GFP compared with HSV-2(G) (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	186	 for confocal experiments, CaSki cells were first infected with K26GFP at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	187	1, 1, or 10 pfu/cell; at the indicated times post-infection, fixed and stained with EZ-Link sulfosuccinimidobiotin to detect cellular plasma membranes and with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole to detect nuclei; and viewed by confocal microscopy.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Viral GFP was detected in the cytoplasm of most of the cells infected with 10 pfu/cell as early as 1 h post-infection and in some cells infected with 1 pfu/cell (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	189	1 pfu/cell, GFP was not visible.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Notably, 4 h post-infection, newly synthesized GFP appeared to accumulate in the nucleus in cells infected with 1 or 10 pfu/cell.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	191	 To confirm that the observed nuclear GFP reflects newly synthesized protein, experiments were conducted in the presence or absence of cycloheximide (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Cycloheximide had no effect on delivery of viral capsids to the cytoplasm and its transport to the nuclear pore at 1 and 2 h post-infection, but blocked synthesis of GFP at 4 and 8 h post-infection (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	193	Next, to explore the role played by FAK in HSV entry, CaSki cells were transfected with nonspecific siRNA (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	194	 6A, upper panels) or FAK-specific siRNA (middle panels), infected with K26GFP (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	195	 = 10 pfu/cell), and then fixed and stained 1, 2, 4, and 8 h post-infection as described above.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Viral GFP was detected at the plasma membrane and in the cytoplasm of CaSki cells as early as 1 h post-infection independent of transfection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	197	 However, transport of viral capsids to the nuclear pore and newly synthesized GFP were rarely detected in cells transfected with FAK-specific siRNA 4 and 8 h post-infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Parallel experiments were conducted with MEF cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	199	 As reported previously (15), knockout of FAK alters the morphology of fibroblast cells with loss of typical elongated morphology.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Intracellular GFP-VP26 was detected 1 h post-infection in both FAK+/+ and FAK-/- cells, but newly synthesized GFP was observed only in FAK+/+ cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The relative amounts of intracellular and nuclear GFPs at 1 and 8 h post-infection, respectively, were determined by scanning 100 cells using NIH Image densitometric software (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	202	 No measurable reduction in intracellular GFP was detected 1 h post-infection in the absence of FAK (FAK-/- cells or CaSki cells transfected with FAK-specific siRNA), suggesting no impediment to viral entry.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	203	 In contrast, a substantial reduction in newly synthesized GFP was detected, consistent with a block at the level of capsid transport to the nuclear pore.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	204	To further explore the role of FAK in capsid transport, confocal experiments were modified; and instead of staining the plasma membrane, microtubules were immunostained using anti--tubulin mAb.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	205	 In CaSki and FAK+/+ cells, viral capsids were readily detected associated with microtubule structures 1 and 2 h post-infection (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	206	 7, upper and middle panels, respectively).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In contrast, no GFP was detected in microtubules in FAK-/- cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Taken together, these results indicate that, in the absence of FAK, there is a restriction to capsid transport, leading to a reduction in the delivery of viral DNA to the nucleus and subsequent viral gene expression.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	209	View larger version (74K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Transport of capsids to the nuclear pore and subsequent synthesis of new viral proteins are impaired in the absence of FAK.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	211	 A, CaSki cells were transfected with nonspecific (NS; upper panels), FAK-specific (middle panels), or Pyk2-specific (lower panels) siRNA and, 24 h later, infected with HSV-1(KOS) (GFP-VP26) at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	212	 of 10 pfu/cell for the indicated times, fixed, and stained as described under "Materials and Methods.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	213	" B, confocal microscopy studies were also conducted following infection of FAK+/+ (upper panels) and FAK-/- (lower panels) cells with HSV-1(KOS) (GFP-VP26) at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	214	 C, for each experiment, the relative amount of intracellular GFP and nuclear GFP detected 1 and 8 h post-infection, respectively, was compared by collecting data from 100 cells from different fields using NIH Image densitometric software.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The results are expressed as the intensity/cell in relative units.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	216	 siNS, nonspecific siRNA; siFAK, FAK-specific siRNA; siPyk2, Pyk2-specific siRNA.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	217	  Our previous study suggested that phosphorylation of FAK is triggered downstream of Ca2+ signaling because pharmacological agents that block the release of ER Ca2+ or chelation of intracellular Ca2+ prevent virus-induced phosphorylation of FAK (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	218	 These observations suggest that Ca2+ signaling should be preserved in FAK-/- cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	219	 To test this directly, we examined the virus-induced Ca2+ signaling response by excitation ratio fluorometry of cells loaded with the Ca2+ indicator fura-2.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	220	 FAK+/+ and FAK-/- cells were exposed sequentially to PBS or HSV-2(G) at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	221	 A rapid increase in the superfusate flow rate of PBS alone, simulating the conditions elicited by the addition of virus to the bathing medium, had no effect on resting [Ca2+]i.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The resting [Ca2+]i of FAK+/+ and FAK-/- cells were comparable (100 nM) (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Exposure of both FAK+/+ and FAK-/- cells to HSV resulted in a significant rapid increase in [Ca2+]i, which peaked within 1 min and returned to the base line within 3 min (p  <  0.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	224	001, analysis of variance) (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	225	 8), although the mean change in peak [Ca2+]i was greater for FAK+/+ cells compared with FAK-/- cells (181.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	226	1 versus 70  plus or minus  45 nM, respectively; mean  plus or minus  S.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	227	, n = 20 cells), possibly reflecting a reduction in virus-induced Ca2+ signaling in the absence of FAK or perturbations of other signal transduction pathways in the knockout cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The ability of HSV to induce a significant Ca2+ response in FAK-/- cells supports the notion that FAK phosphorylation occurs downstream of virus-induced release of ER Ca2+.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	229	View larger version (114K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Viral capsid-incorporated GFP co-localizes with microtubules following infection of CaSki or FAK+/+ cells, but not FAK-/- cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Cells were infected with HSV-1(KOS) (GFP-VP26) at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	232	 of 50 pfu/cell and, at the indicated times post-infection, fixed and stained.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Microtubules were labeled with anti--tubulin antibody (red), and nuclei were stained with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (blue).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The results are representative of those obtained in three independent experiments.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	235	  Pyk2 is a non-receptor tyrosine kinase related to FAK; is activated by various extracellular signals, including an increase in [Ca2+]i; and is overexpressed in embryonic FAK-/- cells (15, 16).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	236	 We hypothesized that HSV may also trigger phosphorylation of Pyk2, which could contribute to signaling pathways required for capsid transport.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	237	 CaSki, FAK+/+, and FAK-/- cells were serum-starved and then exposed to HSV-2(G) at 1 pfu/cell or mock-infected.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Cell lysates were prepared at different times post-infection and analyzed for phosphorylated and total Pyk2 proteins.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	239	 HSV-2 triggered Pyk2 phosphorylation within 5 min following inoculation of cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The response was substantially greater in FAK-/- cells, presumably reflecting the increase in total Pyk2 in these cells and the absence of any FAK (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The observation that Pyk2 phosphorylation occurs in the absence of FAK suggests that Pyk2 is phosphorylated independent of FAK phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	242	 To further address the independence of Pyk2 and FAK phosphorylation, we again took advantage of siRNA strategy.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	243	 CaSki cells were transfected with control nonspecific siRNA or with Pyk2- or FAK-specific siRNA and then mock-infected or infected with HSV-2(G).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Transfection with Pyk2-specific siRNA led to an 70% reduction in Pyk2 expression and virus-induced Pyk2 phosphorylation (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In contrast, virus-induced Pyk2 phosphorylation was preserved in cells transfected with FAK-specific siRNA (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	246	 9B, middle panels), and virus-induced FAK phosphorylation was preserved in cells transfected with Pyk2-specific siRNA (lower panels, which show results with FAK+/+ cells; similar results were obtained with CaSki cells).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	247	To evaluate whether Pyk2 phosphorylation contributes to HSV infection, plaque assays were conducted in cells transfected with siRNA specific for FAK or Pyk2 alone and in combination.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Compared with cells transfected with control nonspecific siRNA, HSV-2 infection was inhibited by 74  plus or minus  6, 60  plus or minus  5, and 94  plus or minus  7% in CaSki cells transfected with siRNA for FAK, Pyk2, or both, respectively (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Consistent with the low level of Pyk2 phosphorylation observed in FAK+/+ cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	250	 9A), transfection of these cells with Pyk2-specific siRNA had little inhibitory effect (22%), whereas transfection with FAK-specific siRNA reduced viral infection by 71%.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	251	 In contrast, transfection of FAK-/- cells with Pyk2-specific siRNA further reduced viral infection by  > 99%.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	252	 To directly evaluate whether Pyk2 phosphorylation also contributes to nuclear transport, CaSki cells were transfected with nonspecific or Pyk2-specific siRNA, and the effects on viral binding and VP16 transport to the nucleus were evaluated.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Transfection with Pyk2-specific siRNA had no effect on viral binding (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	254	 10B), but had a modest inhibitory effect on nuclear transport of VP16 (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Optical densitometry scanning of the gels demonstrated an 40% reduction in nuclear VP16 following Pyk2-specific siRNA transfection, consistent with the modest inhibition of viral plaque formation (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Similarly, transfection with Pyk2-specific siRNA also had a moderate effect on delivery of GFP to the nuclear pore as detected by confocal microscopy (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Together, these results suggest that HSV induces phosphorylation of Pyk2 independent of phosphorylation of FAK and that, although FAK plays the predominant role, activation of both kinases contributes to viral infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	258	View larger version (10K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Effect of exposure of cells to HSV-2 on [Ca2+]i.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	260	 FAK+/+ (A) and FAK-/- (B) cells were loaded with the Ca2+ indicator dye fura-2 and exposed to HSV-2 (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	261	0), and changes in [Ca2+]i were monitored.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Shown are representative recordings from two cells showing [Ca2+] before and after exposure to virus.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	263	 The base-line and peak [Ca2+] achieved in response to HSV-2 are shown (n = 20 cells) (C).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The asterisk indicates that the peak change in [Ca2+]i compared with the base line for both cell types was significant (p  <  0.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	265	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   The dependence of viruses on host cell machinery for transcription, translation, and genome replication is well established.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	266	 However, viruses presumably also must harness host cell pathways for entry and egress (16).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The results obtained in this study demonstrate for the first time that HSV triggers phosphorylation of the cellular kinases FAK and Pyk2 to promote successful invasion.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	268	 HSV independently induces phosphorylation of FAK and Pyk2, and disruption of these pathways impedes delivery of the tegument protein VP16 to the nucleus and delivery of capsids to the nuclear pore, leading to a reduction in downstream events (viral gene expression and plaque formation).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	269	View larger version (46K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	270	 HSV induces Pyk2 phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	271	 A, CaSki, FAK+/+, and FAK-/- cells were serum-starved overnight and then challenged with HSV-2(G) (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	272	 At the indicated times post-infection, cell lysates were prepared and analyzed by Western blotting for phosphorylated and total Pyk2 proteins.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	273	 B, additionally, CaSki cells were transfected with control, Pyk2-specific, or FAK-specific siRNA and, 24 h later, mock-infected or infected with HSV-2(G).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	274	 5 min post-infection, cell lysates were prepared and analyzed for the indicated tyrosine-phosphorylated protein (Pyk2 phosphorylated at Tyr402 (Pyk2[pY402])), FAK, and Pyk2.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The results are representative of three independent experiments.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	276	  Several studies suggest that HSV uses microtubule-based transport to delivery viral capsids to the nuclear pore, where viral DNA is released into the nucleus (1, 17-19).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Immunofluorescence studies demonstrate that HSV-1 capsids co-localize with dynein and dynactin.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Microtubule-depolymerizing agents, such as nocodazole, block HSV infection in culture and in animal models (1).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Moreover, nuclear transport of capsids is reduced by dynein inhibitors (19).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Precisely how HSV (or other viruses) engages and regulates the microtubule complexes is not known.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	281	 It has been suggested that cellular kinases triggered by viral infection or perhaps encoded by viruses themselves may play this regulatory role.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The results obtained in this study support this notion and suggest that cellular FAK and the related tyrosine kinase Pyk2 are activated by HSV to promote transport along microtubules.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	283	View larger version (37K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Pyk2 also contributes to HSV infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	285	 A, CaSki, FAK+/+, and FAK-/- cells were transfected with FAK-specific siRNA, Pyk2-specific siRNA, or both siRNAs and then, 24 h later, challenged with serial dilutions of HSV-2(G).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Plaques were counted 48 h post-infection, and viral titer (plaque-forming units/ml) were determined.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	288	 of two independent experiments conducted in duplicate.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	289	 B, CaSki cells were transfected with nonspecific (NS) or Pyk2-specific (siPyk2) siRNA and then, 24 h later, exposed to serial dilutions of purified HSV-2(G) at the m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	290	 indicated for 5 h at 4  degrees C.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The input and cell-bound viral particles were detected by analyzing Western blots of cell lysates for glycoprotein D (gD).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Blots were also probed with mAb to -actin to control for cell lysate loading.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	293	 C, transfected cells (Cell) were exposed to HSV-2(G) (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	294	 = 10 pfu/cell) in a synchronized infection assay; and 1 h post-entry, nuclear extracts (Nucl) were prepared and analyzed for the presence of the viral tegument protein VP16 by Western blotting.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	295	  FAK was originally identified as a tyrosine kinase localized to focal adhesions, which are multiprotein structures that link the extracellular matrix to the actin cytoskeleton through integrin receptors.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	296	 More recent studies indicate that FAK also participates in the regulation of microtubule function.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	297	 For example, integrin-mediated activation of FAK is required for microtubule stabilization in mouse fibroblasts (20).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Additionally, FAK phosphorylation at Ser732 is important for microtubule organization, nuclear movement, and neuronal migration (21).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	299	 The latter study suggests that FAK phosphorylation regulates microtubule-based nuclear translocation and neuronal migration.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Pyk2 (also called FAK2) belongs to the same family of non-receptor tyrosine kinases as does FAK.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	301	 In contrast to FAK, which is expressed ubiquitously, Pyk2 expression is more restricted, but is found in hematopoietic, neuronal, and epithelial cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Pyk2 shares substantial homology with FAK and interacts with intracellular signaling molecules to activate a variety of cellular pathways, including regulation of microtubules (15).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Notably, increases in intracellular Ca2+ levels are associated with Pyk2 phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	304	 We found that HSV also induces Pyk2 phosphorylation independent of FAK.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Pyk2 phosphorylation was most evident in FAK-/- fibroblasts, which are known to overexpress Pyk2 (15), and also contributed to viral infection post-binding.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Thus, the observation that HSV capsid nuclear transport occurs via microtubules and the association of FAK and Pyk2 with microtubule regulation suggest that HSV triggers these cellular kinases to harness the microtubule machinery for its nuclear transport.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	307	Several viruses activate FAK or related signaling pathways, but the precise role played by these pathways in viral invasion or pathogenicity has not been delineated previously.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	308	 FAK is activated by integrin binding and aggregation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Thus, viruses that bind integrin receptors, such as adenovirus and human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), trigger FAK phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Adenovirus induces tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK within 15 min following infection of human corneal fibroblasts, but its role in viral pathogenicity is not known (22).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	311	 HHV-8 glycoprotein B, which possesses an RGD motif, binds to integrin receptors on target cells and triggers rapid phosphorylation of FAK and related signaling pathways.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The finding that HHV-8 infection of FAK-null cells is substantially reduced suggests that FAK may also be required for HHV-8 entry, but this has not yet been experimentally demonstrated (23-25).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Additionally, binding of HIV gp120 to T cells also triggers tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK (26), which may promote apoptosis (27), but has not yet been demonstrated to play any role in HIV entry or nuclear transport.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	314	It is not clear yet how HSV activates the FAK cell signaling pathway.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Although glycoprotein B is highly conserved among herpesviruses, only HHV-8 glycoprotein B possesses the RGD motif and interacts with integrin molecules as a receptor (28).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Recent studies demonstrate that HSV-1 glycoprotein H binds to v3 integrins; however; the functional significance of this interaction is unclear (29).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	317	 A recombinant virus with the RGD motif in glycoprotein H mutated to RGE shows no impairment in entry or infectivity in vitro (30) and also induces FAK phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	318	The results from our study suggest that FAK phosphorylation occurs downstream of Ca2+ signaling and is triggered either directly by the increase in [Ca2+]i or in response to Ca2+-dependent viral penetration.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	319	 This notion is supported by the findings that HSV induces an increase in [Ca2+]i in FAK-/- cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	320	 9) and that treatment of cells with pharmacological agents that block release of ER Ca2+ stores or chelation of intracellular Ca2+ prevents the virus-induced phosphorylation of FAK (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	321	 In contrast to what has been observed for HHV-8 glycoprotein B or HIV gp120, no single HSV glycoprotein-cell interaction appears to be sufficient to activate the requisite cell signaling pathways.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Our studies with deletion viruses indicate that penetration-competent virus is required to induce signaling.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	323	 This follows from the observations that HSV-1 deleted in glycoprotein L or glycoprotein D, both of which bind but do not penetrate, fails to induce the signaling responses, whereas heat-inactivated virus induces phosphorylated FAK (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Possibly, one of the HSV envelope glycoproteins interacts with a cell-surface receptor to trigger the signaling cascade, but the interaction is dependent on the other glycoproteins being present in the viral envelope.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	325	 This could occur if, for example, the other glycoproteins induce a conformational change in and/or recruit the requisite glycoprotein(s) to a specific site at the membrane.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	326	Defining precisely how HSV triggers the signaling pathways is critical, as the viral proteins involved are excellent candidate targets for antiviral therapies.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Although targeting critical cellular pathways such as FAK phosphorylation will undoubtedly have pleiotropic and potentially deleterious effects as suggested by the reduction in magnitude of virus-induced Ca2+ transients in FAK-/- cells and the observed changes in morphology of FAK knockout cells (15), targeting the viral proteins that activate the requisite signaling pathways should lead to the development of novel specific antiviral therapies.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	328	 The results from this study provide an important piece to the puzzle and suggest that blockade of HSV-triggered phosphorylation of FAK and, to a lesser extent, Pyk2 will prevent nuclear transport, a critical step in the establishment of HSV infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	329	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported in part by National Institutes of Health Grants AI061679 and HD43733 (to B.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	330	) and Grants DK38470 and DK64104 (to L.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	331	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	332	 This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	334	Supported by a Polycystic Kidney Research Foundation fellowship grant and a Revson Foundation fellowship.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	335	|| To whom correspondence should be addressed: Pediatric Infectious Diseases, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, One Gustave L.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	336	: 212-241-5272; Fax: 212-426-4813; E-mail: betsy.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	337	1 The abbreviations used are: HSV, herpes simplex virus; HIV, human immunodeficiency virus; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; FAK, focal adhesion kinase; siRNA, small interfering RNA; MEF, mouse embryonic fibroblast; GFP, green fluorescent protein; mAb, monoclonal antibody; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	338	, multiplicity of infection; pfu, plaque-forming units; HHV-8, human herpesvirus 8.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	339	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Prashant Desai for the generous gift of the K26GFP virus and Robert F.

0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	0	Differential regulation of L1 and L2 ss-lactamase expression in Stenotrophomonas maltophilia.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	1	Bristol Centre for Antimicrobial Research and Evaluation, Department of Pathology and Microbiology, School of Medical Sciences, University of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1TD, UK.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	2	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References   It has been reported that Stenotrophomonas maltophilia L1 and L2 ss-lactamase expression is coordinated.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	3	 maltophilia mutants where (i) L1 is constitutively hyper-expressed and L2 is inducible; (ii) L2 is hyper-expressed and L1 is inducible; and (iii) L1 and L2 are constitutively hyper-expressed.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The frequency of isolating type 1 and 2 mutants is c.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	5	 10-7, indicating that promoter mutations are probably not involved and providing strong evidence that L1 and L2 expression is not, after all, coordinated.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The frequency of isolating type 3 mutants is c.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	7	 10-9, however, implying that there is a significant overlap between the regulatory mechanisms.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	8	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References   In a recent survey of British medical microbiologists, Stenotrophomonas maltophilia was voted one of the most important emergent multidrug-resistant pathogens.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	9	1 As well as causing bacteraemias, S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	10	 maltophilia has been reported to be responsible for many different organ-specific infections and is an important cause of respiratory tract colonization in young adults with cystic fibrosis.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	11	 maltophilia isolates are resistant to many clinically useful antibiotics, with ss-lactam resistance being mediated through two ss-lactamases, L1 and L2, whose expression is induced when cells are exposed to ss-lactam antibiotics.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	12	2,3 Little is known about the mechanism(s) used to regulate L1 and L2 expression, so the experiments presented in this report were designed to investigate the regulation of L1 and L2 expression in S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	13	 maltophilia by isolating mutants in which L1 and L2 expression were altered.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	14	   Materials and methods Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References   Bacterial strains and materials.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	15	 maltophilia isolates used in this study have been described previously.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	16	3 They are divided into groups A, B and C according to 16S rRNA gene sequence.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Group A strains are K279a, H33b, J530b and J675Ib; group B strains are N531 and P567II; and group C strains are J675a, J675b, O132II and O133.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	18	3 All the materials used in this study have been described elsewhere.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	19	Induction, preparation of crude cell extracts and ss-lactamase assay.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	20	Induction of ss-lactamase activity was attempted where appropriate, crude cell extracts were made, ss-lactamase assays were carried out and specific ss-lactamase activity was calculated using the methods described previously.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	21	4 One unit of ss-lactamase activity was defined as that required to hydrolyse 1 micromole of substrate per minute at 25 degrees C.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	22	Isolation of total RNA and RT to PCR analysis.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	23	Isolation of RNA and RT to PCR were carried out as described previously.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	24	5 The RT to PCR primers used were  L1-MID  (forward) 5'-CTGGCCGTCGCTCTTCCG-3' and (reverse) 5'-TCCAGGCGGTGCTGCCC-3' and  L2-MID  (forward) 5'-CGATGATCACCAGCGACA-3' and (reverse) 5'-CGGTTACCTCATCCGATC-3'.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Although these primers were designed from the L1c and L2b gene sequences located in S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	26	 maltophilia group A isolates, they are known to amplify equivalent regions from the L1 and L2 isoforms carried by group B and C S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	27	Selection of ss-lactamase hyper-producing mutants.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	28	Etest MIC determinations were carried out on IsoSensitest agar with an inoculum of 0.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Following incubation at 37 degrees C for 24 h, colonies that grew within the zone of clearing were selected.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	30	   Results Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References   Using crude cell extracts from uninduced or cefoxitin-induced group A, B and C S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	31	 maltophilia isolates (see Materials and methods), the activities of L1 and L2 ss-lactamases were determined with meropenem as a specific L1 substrate and ceftazidime as an L2 substrate (Figure 1a).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In the latter case, EDTA (100 mM) was added to inhibit L1, which also hydrolyses ceftazidime.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	33	6 RT to PCR analysis was used to determine L1 and L2 transcript levels in similarly incubated cells (Figure 1b).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The data reveal that L2 is expressed at higher levels following induction of group A strains, but very little L2 expression was detected in group B or C strains, even following induction.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The same level of L1 induction was seen in group A and B strains, but there was no detectable L1 expression in group C strains (Figure 1).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	36	View larger version (41K):    Figure 1.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	37	 maltophilia L1 and L2 transcription.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	38	 maltophilia isolates from group A, B and C strains are represented in the figure by isolates K279a, N531 and J675a, respectively.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	39	 (a) Crude extracts from cefoxitin-induced (labelled  A In ,  B In  or  C In ) or uninduced (labelled  A ,  B  or  C ) cultures were prepared as described in Materials and methods.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	40	 ss-Lactamase activities in the extracts were measured against meropenem (white bar) or ceftazidime in the presence of 100 mM EDTA (black bar).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	41	 (b) From the same cultures used in (a), total RNA was prepared and assayed for the abundance of L1 and L2 transcripts by RT to PCR (see Materials and methods).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The figure represents an ethidium bromide-stained 1.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	43	2% w/v agarose gel under UV illumination following resolution of the L1 mid and L2 mid PCR amplicons.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	44	 maltophilia K279a (group A) has inducible L1 and L2 ss-lactamases (Figure 1).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	45	 K279a mutants that display high-level resistance to meropenem, ceftazidime or ampicillin were isolated (see Materials and methods).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Of 50 hyper-resistant mutants examined, eight showed increased levels of ss-lactamase expression.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Three classes of ss-lactamase hyper-producing mutants were isolated, denoted K279a M1, K279a M2 and K279a M3.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Using crude cell extracts of uninduced K279a M1, K279a M2 and K279a M3, the activities of L1 and L2 ss-lactamases (Figure 2a) and the levels of L1 and L2 transcripts (Figure 2b) were determined.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Compared with K279a, K279a M1 has increased expression of L1 but not L2; K279a M2 has increased expression of L2 but not L1; and K279a M3 has increased expression of both L1 and L2 (Figure 2).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The ss-lactamases that are not over-expressed in uninduced K279a M1 or K279a M2 are inducible upon cefoxitin challenge (data not shown).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	51	View larger version (49K):    Figure 2.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	52	 maltophilia isolate K279a was used to produce the mutants denoted M1, M2 and M3 as described in the text.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	53	 (a) Crude extracts from uninduced cultures of the parent strain or from the three mutants were prepared as described in Materials and methods.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	54	 ss-Lactamase activities in the extracts were measured using meropenem (white bar) or ceftazidime in the presence of 100 mM EDTA (black bar).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	55	 (b) The same cultures were used to prepare total RNA, which was assayed for the abundance of L1 and L2 transcripts by RT to PCR (see Materials and methods).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The figure represents an ethidium bromide-stained 1.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	57	2% w/v agarose gel under UV illumination following resolution of the L1 mid and L2 mid PCR amplicons.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	58	     Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References   Both sets of data indicate that expression of the L1 and L2 genes in S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	59	 maltophilia is differential, a conclusion that contrasts with those of previous studies.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	60	2 It is clear from several reports that challenging S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	61	 maltophilia isolates with ss-lactams induces L1 and L2 expression simultaneously.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	62	 From this, it has been concluded that the same mechanism is used to control the expression of both enzymes.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	63	 maltophilia mutant where L1 was constitutively repressed and L2 remained inducible; Bonfiglio et al.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	64	8 found a clinical isolate with identical properties; and we have found clinical isolates where L2 is repressed and L1 is inducible (Figure 1).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Promoter mutations could explain all of these findings, however, uncoupling one gene in each case from the induction machinery.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	66	We also report the isolation of S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	67	 maltophilia K279a mutants where either L1 or L2 is constitutively hyper-expressed and the partner enzyme remains inducible (Figure 2).
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Again, promoter mutations could explain this, but the frequency at which differentially hyper-expressing mutations arise argues against this theory.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Promoter mutations that lead to over-expression of ss-lactamases are rare events.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	70	 For example, the promoter mutation frequency resulting in ampC over-expression in Escherichia coli is c.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	71	9 Although the Etest method used here does not allow determination of accurate mutation frequencies, the frequency to L1 over-expression is c.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	72	 10-7 and that to L2 over-expression is similar.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Hence, mutation to L1 or L2 over-expression is about two orders of magnitude greater than that for ampC over-expression in E.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	74	 coli due to a promoter mutation.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	75	9 A similar high mutation frequency (c.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	76	 10-7) leading to ss-lactamase over-expression of ampC in Citrobacter freundii and Enterobacter cloacae is primarily a reflection of non-specific loss-of-function mutations in ampD.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	77	10 Hence, we think it likely that non-specific mutations are the cause of ss-lactamase hyper-production in the S.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	78	 maltophilia mutants isolated, and not promoter mutations.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Whereas the predicted frequency of isolating L1 and L2 double over-expressing mutants would be 10-14 (10-7 for L2 multiplied by 10-7 for L1), if both systems were entirely independent, the observed frequency is c.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	80	 This frequency indicates that some single-site mutations result in over-expression of both genes, implying that there is a common component(s) to control of L1 and L2 gene expression.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	81	   Acknowledgements Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References   This work was funded by grants from the British Society for Antimicrobial Chemotherapy (to M.
0.18210748.11815585.html.plaintext.txt	82	 was in receipt of a Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council CASE studentship in collaboration with GlaxoSmithKline pharmaceuticals.

0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	0	Chimeric papillomavirus-like particles expressing a foreign epitope on capsid surface loops Katharina Slupetzky1, Saeed Shafti-Keramat1, Petra Lenzb,1, Sabine Brandt2, Andreas Grassauer2, Margit Sara3 and Reinhard Kirnbauer1.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	1	Laboratory of Viral Oncology, Division of Immunology, Allergy and Infectious Diseases (DIAID)1, and Division of General Dermatology, Department of Dermatology2, University of Vienna Medical School, Wahringer Gurtel 18 to 20, A-1090 Vienna, Austria Center for Ultrastructure Research and Ludwig Boltzmann Institute for Molecular Nanotechnology, University of Agricultural Sciences, Gregor Mendel Strasse 33, A-1180 Vienna, Austria3.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	2	Author for correspondence: Reinhard Kirnbauer.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	3	   Abstract Top Abstract Main text References   Neutralization capsid epitopes are important determinants for antibody-mediated immune protection against papillomavirus (PV) infection and induced disease.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Chimeric L1 major capsid proteins of the human PV type 16 (HPV-16) and the bovine PV type 1 (BPV-1) with a foreign peptide incorporated into several capsid surface loops self-assembled into pentamers or virus-like particles (VLP).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Binding patterns of neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (MAb) and immunization of mice confirmed (i) that regions around aa 282 to 286 and 351 to 355 contribute to neutralization epitopes and identified the latter region as an immunodominant site and (ii) that placing a foreign peptide in the context of an assembled structure markedly enhanced its immunogenicity.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Pentamers disassembled from wild-type HPV-16 and BPV-1 VLPs displayed some of the neutralization epitopes that were detected on fully assembled VLPs, but were deficient for binding a subset of neutralizing MAb that inhibit cell attachment.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	7	   Main text Top Abstract Main text References   Papillomavirus (PV) infections are widespread in animals and humans, causing mostly benign epithelial proliferations, papillomas or warts, of the skin and mucous membranes (Howley, 1991 ; Lowy et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Infection with oncogenic types, most often human PV type 16 (HPV-16), has been aetiologically associated with the development of anogenital malignancies, in particular cervical cancer (zur Hausen, 1994 ).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	9	 PVs are nonenveloped 8 kb double-stranded DNA viruses with a T=7 icosahedral symmetry and a diameter of approximately 55 nm (Baker et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The capsid consists of 60 hexavalent and 12 pentavalent capsomers, with each capsomer being a pentamer composed of 5 L1 major capsid proteins.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The second viral structural protein, the minor capsid protein L2, is required for genome encapsidation and the generation of infectious virions (Day et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Despite the development of in vitro and in vivo methods, there is still no efficient tissue culture system or laboratory animal to easily propagate HPV, which has hampered immunological and structural studies of the virion (Kreider et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	13	In recent years progress has been achieved towards development of a prophylactic HPV vaccine to prevent genital HPV infection and associated benign and dysplastic lesions (Kirnbauer, 1996 ; Schiller  and  Okun, 1996 ).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Capsid protein(s) L1 alone, or L1 plus L2, expressed in eukaryotic cells self-assembles into virus-like particles (VLP) which are morphologically and antigenically similar to native virions, but lack potentially oncogenic DNA.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Immunization with L1 or L1/L2 VLP generated sera containing neutralizing antibodies that conferred type-specific and long-lasting protection in several animal models (Bell et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	16	, 1992 , 1993 , 1996 ; Rose et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Neutralizing antibodies are thus considered the major protective component in prophylactic PV vaccination.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	18	Because neutralization PV epitopes are non-linear and conformation-dependent, their amino acid composition and surface localization are incompletely characterized.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Monoclonal antibody (MAb) binding and immunization studies have tentatively mapped neutralization epitopes of the low-risk HPV-11 along a 20 aa stretch of L1 (residues 120 to 140), immunodominant sites at aa 131 to 132 and 346 to 349 (Ludmerer et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	20	, 1997 , 2000 ), and have implicated L1 residues 50, 266 and 282 in HPV-16 neutralization epitopes (Roden et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	21	 To further explore these epitopes and the potential of VLP as an immunogenic vaccine carrier, we engineered the 8 aa B-cell epitope LELDKWAS (Leu-Glu-Leu-Asp-Lys-Trp-Ala-Ser) from the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) gp41 envelope glycoprotein into the L1 protein of HPV-16 and bovine PV type 1 (BPV-1) using inverse touch-down PCR (Ochman et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Oligonucleotides encoding the epitope were cloned into several hypervariable regions of the L1 ORF of the HPV-16 baculovirus transfer vector 114K-L1-pSynwtVI- (Kirnbauer et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 1993 ) and BPV-1 L1-pEVmod (Kirnbauer et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	24	 These regions are likely to encode surface structures in the assembled capsid (Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	25	 For HPV-16 L1, recombinant baculovirus expression vectors were generated with the peptide inserted between amino acid residues 286/287, 281/287 (replacing aa 282 to 286) or fused to the C terminus as a control (Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We also designed BPV-1 L1 chimeras that incorporate the peptide in three different hypervariable regions, between amino acid residues 133/134, 282/286 (replacing aa 283 to 285) or 351/355 (replacing aa 352 to 354) (Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Recombinant proteins were immunoblotted using MAb Camvir-1 (Pharmingen) and AU-1 (BAbCO), directed against linear epitopes of HPV-16 L1 and BPV-1 L1, or MAb 2F5, which recognizes the LELDKWAS epitope (AIDS Research and Reference Reagent Program, NIAID, NIH, USA) (Muster et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Following purification of high molecular mass complexes on density gradients, HPV-16 and BPV-1 L1 chimeric proteins were analysed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Micrographs demonstrated pentamers and full-size or smaller VLP, indicating that peptide insertion did not prevent L1 self-assembly into higher-ordered structures (data not shown).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Further evidence for assembly of chimeric BPV-1 L1 proteins was obtained by analytical centrifugation on 20 to 40% sucrose density gradients demonstrating a migration pattern which corresponded to both wild-type (wt) L1 VLP (bottom of gradient) as well as disassembled wt L1 pentamers (top of gradient) that were run in parallel (data not shown).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	31	 These results supported the presence of both VLP and pentamers in chimeric L1 preparations as observed by TEM.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	32	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Construction of chimeric HPV-16 (A to C) and BPV-1 (D to F) L1 to LELDKWAS baculovirus expression vectors.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	34	 HPV-16 capsid surface loops DE, FG, HI (dotted lines) and amino acid numbering are indicated (Chen et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The LELDKWAS peptide (indicated by a bold line) was engineered into the L1 ORF between the indicated amino acid residues, encoding the following deduced chimeric L1 epitope sequences with the added amino acids in brackets: A, TANL(ELDKW)ASSN; B, KGSG(LELDKW)ASSN; C, KKRKL(ELDKWAS); D, DATL(ELDKWA)SVHF; E, RKVT(LELDKWAS)TQTT; and F, TPLT(LELDKWA)SSKF (oligonucleotide primer sequences are available on request).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Loops and inserts are not drawn to scale.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	37	 N, C, amino- and carboxy-terminus.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	38	  We next examined if amino acid deletion and/or peptide insertion at a hypervariable region of HPV-16 L1 would interrupt neutralizing MAb-binding to conformation-dependent epitopes by ELISA (Roden et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Two classes of MAb that neutralize HPV-16 virions have been described, MAbs E70 and V5, which inhibit virus to cell binding (referred to here as class A), and U4, which does not inhibit binding (class B) (Roden et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	40	 By ELISA, both classes of MAb bound the HPV-16 C-terminal fusion protein similar to wt VLP (Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	41	 There was a complete loss of binding for class A antibodies E70 and V5 to chimeras A 286/287 and B 281/287.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	42	 In contrast, binding of the class B MAb U4 to chimeras A 286/287 and B 281/287 was similar to that of wt VLP.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	43	 These results confirm and extend our previous observation that amino acids around 282 are part of the E70 epitope and also contribute to the V5 epitope (Roden et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	44	View larger version (33K):    Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	45	 (a) Binding of HPV-16-neutralizing MAb to wt HPV-16 L1 VLP and chimeric HPV-16 L1 proteins A, B, C or disassembled wt capsomers by ELISA.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	46	 MAbs E70 and V5 inhibit haemagglutination (class A); U4 does not inhibit haemagglutination (class B).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	47	 (b) Binding of BPV-neutralizing MAb to wt BPV L1 VLP and chimeric BPV-1 L1 proteins D, E, F or disassembled wt capsomers by ELISA.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Neutralizing MAbs #6 and #9 inhibit haemagglutination (class A); 5B6 does not inhibit haemagglutination (class B).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	49	  It has been shown that HPV-11 capsomers contain conformational epitopes found on intact VLP (Rose et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	50	 To examine whether VLP are required for MAb binding or whether HPV-16 L1 pentamers are sufficient to display the epitopes, wt HPV-16 L1 capsids were disassembled into pentamers and the absence of VLP was verified by TEM and sucrose gradient (data not shown).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	51	 By ELISA, MAbs V5 and U4 bound wt L1 pentamers with kinetics similar to wt VLP, whereas absorbance values for MAb E70 were significantly reduced.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	52	 These results indicated that the E70 epitope is partially sensitive to VLP disassembly (Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	53	 2a), and HPV-16 L1 pentamers appear sufficient for the display of the MAb V5 (class A) and U4 (class B) epitopes.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	54	 As shown previously for low-risk HPV-11, we demonstrate for the first time that high-risk HPV-16 L1 capsomers display at least a subset of the neutralization epitopes found on full-size VLP.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	55	As with HPV, two classes of MAb that neutralize BPV virions have been described, those represented by MAbs #6 and #9 (both of class A), and MAb 5B6 (class B) (Roden et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	56	 When BPV-1 chimeric L1 proteins or pentamers disassembled from wt L1 VLP under reducing conditions (3% 2-mercaptoethanol/150 mM NaCl) (McCarthy et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	57	, 1998 ) were analysed by ELISA (Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	58	 2b), binding of MAb #6 (class A) to wt L1 VLP, the chimeric BPV-1 L1 proteins D 133/134, E 282/286 and wt L1 pentamers was observed.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Data for MAb #6 binding to chimera F 351/355 were inconclusive as absorbance values did not decline across 3 logs of antibody dilution.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	60	 These results indicate that wt pentamers appear sufficient for the display of the #6 epitope and that the determinants were not contained within the targeted L1 regions of chimeras D 133/134 and E 282/286.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Antibody #9 (class A) recognized VLP of wt L1 and chimera D 133/134, but no binding was seen with chimeras E 282/286 and F 351/355.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	62	 This finding raises the possibility that peptide insertion at aa 282/286 and 351/355 had either directly targeted the respective BPV neutralization epitope or indirectly affected the quaternary structure of the particles.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	63	 In addition, wt pentamers did not react, indicating that MAb #9 requires assembly into VLP for binding.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The above findings add to published results indicating that residues 282 to 286 and 351 to 355 form part of the neutralization epitopes (Ludmerer et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Reactivity of MAb 5B6 (class B) was specifically absent for construct F 351/355, indicating that peptide targeting to aa 351/355 interrupted the 5B6 epitope.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	66	 This interpretation is consistent with the observation that aa 346 of the analogous region of HPV-11 L1 is critical for binding of a neutralizing MAb (Ludmerer et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	67	, 1996 ), although an indirect effect on quaternary structure remains possible.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Interestingly, in high resolution reconstructions, MAb 5B6 binds monovalently or divalently to (neighbouring) hexavalent capsomers just above intercapsomer cross-bridges (Trus et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Taken together these data suggest that aa 351 to 355 contribute to the 5B6 epitope at a virion surface location close to the interpentamer connections.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	70	 In addition, pentamers appear sufficient for the display of this neutralization epitope.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Our results also identify the existence of two sub-classes of neutralizing antibodies within those antibodies that interfere with binding of particles to cell surface (class A).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	72	 One sub-class (MAb #6) can bind both to intact VLPs and to pentamers/capsomers, while the other sub-class (MAb #9) requires the higher-ordered structure of VLP for binding.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The BPV pentamer results are similar to those for the HPV-16 pentamers, which were deficient for E70 binding but bound V5 similarly to intact VLPs.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	74	To examine the effect of peptide insertion on the immunogenicity of BPV-1 L1 proteins, three mice each were injected with native or denatured protein preparations and boosted twice in 2-week intervals.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Two weeks after the last immunization, pooled sera were analysed for antibodies against the LELDKWAS peptide and for BPV-neutralizing activity using an in vitro focus-forming assay (Dvoretzky et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Sera raised against native preparations of chimeras D 133/134, E 282/286 and wt VLP neutralized BPV virions with a titre of 1000, 100 and 10000 respectively.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	77	 This indicated that these chimeric proteins retain PV-neutralization epitopes, although the potency to induce neutralization activity was lower than that of wt VLP.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	78	 These results suggest the feasibility of inserting epitopes of choice into immunogenic regions of L1, e.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	79	 to generate HPV vaccines with a broad-spectrum protection.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In contrast, sera raised against chimera F 351/355 were non-neutralizing, suggesting that peptide insertion at residues 351/355 had disrupted a major immunogenic determinant(s).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	81	To evaluate the potential of assembled chimeric BPV-1 L1 proteins to induce antibodies against the inserted epitope, sera were analysed by ELISA using alkaline phosphatase (AP) to LELDKWAS as the antigen (Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Antisera raised against chimera E 282/286 showed insignificant binding to the LELDKWAS peptide, whereas sera raised against chimera F 351/355 showed reactivity comparable to that obtained with MAb 2F5.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Thus insertion of a foreign peptide at 351/355 (chimera F) generated a protein that efficiently induced anti-peptide antibodies, while binding of MAb 5B6 and the capacity to induce BPV-neutralizing antisera were completely abrogated.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	84	 This change of function provides additional evidence that amino acids around 351/355 contribute to an immunodominant neutralization surface structure.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Sera raised against chimera D 133/134 also demonstrated significant binding, implicating residues 133/134 as part of another immunogenic region.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Remarkably, denatured proteins did not induce immunoreactivity against the peptide, although sera contained antibodies to linear L1 epitopes.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	87	 This indicated that placing a foreign peptide in the context of an assembled structure markedly enhanced its immunogenicity, whereas the peptide appeared subdominant when presented as denatured (linear) chimeric L1 to LELDKWAS protein.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	88	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Reactivity of immune sera in the LELDKWAS epitope ELISA.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Three BALB/c mice each were injected subcutaneously with 50  microg (estimated by SDS to PAGE) of native or heat/SDS-denatured protein in complete Freund s adjuvant followed by two boosts in incomplete Freund s adjuvant at 2-week intervals.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Two weeks after the last immunization, serum samples were collected, pooled and heat-inactivated.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Twofold serial dilutions of immune sera raised against native or denatured chimeric L1 proteins D, E or F, or dilutions of MAb 2F5 (1 ng/ml) were reacted against the LELDKWAS peptide fused to the C terminus of AP, expressed in and affinity-purified from E.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	93	 coli and attached to ELISA plates.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	94	  The sera neither reacted to AP to scF control protein nor neutralized macrophage (BAL) and T-cell tropic (IIIb) HIV-1 laboratory strains by in vitro assays, whereas MAb 2F5 directed against this epitope was neutralizing (data not shown).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	95	 It is likely that in the context of chimeric VLP the epitope did not present in its native conformation as detected on infectious HIV virions.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Alternatively, it is possible that the antibody concentration in the sera was too low to score in the assay.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	97	This observation represents an important extension to previous results generating autoantibodies against a self-antigen (Chackerian et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	98	, 1999 ), supporting the potential of a virus structure as a vaccine carrier (Zinkernagel  and  Hengartner, 1997 ).
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	99	Our results corroborate the functional relevance of the crystal structure of an HPV-16 L1 assembled into small T=1 particles (Chen et al.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	100	, 2000 ), demonstrating that highly variable positions exposed on the pentamer surface can tolerate insertion of heterologous amino acids without losing the salient structural characteristics of L1.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	101	 By L1 sequence comparison, we had grafted the epitope into three distinct surface loops that connect strands of the -jelly roll of the L1 monomer, i.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	102	 the DE loop (comprised of HPV-16 aa 111 to 151), the FG loop (aa 257 to 298) and the HI loop (aa 349 to 359) (Fig.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Insertion resulted in either a loss or change of function for immunogenic capsid regions (Figs 2 and 3), supporting the role of surface loops as virion neutralization determinants.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	104	The identification of neutralization, immunogenic and mutation-permissive capsid regions may be relevant for HPV vaccine design and allows a rational approach for the insertion of epitopes of choice.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The display of foreign peptides in the context of an immunogenic self-assembled L1 oligomer can induce a vigorous humoral immune response and may thus become a more general procedure to overcome the low immunogenicity of free peptide antigens.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	106	 This may become an attractive strategy to generate a cross-protective vaccine against multiple HPV types or other, e.
0.33479095.11602792.html.plaintext.txt	107	 sexually transmitted, diseases.
