0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	387	 277, 35314-35322[Abstract/Free Full Text] Mori, T.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	388	 (2002) Neoplasia 4, 268-274[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Zhao, L.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	389	 1, 195-206[Abstract/Free Full Text] Redon, R.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	390	 62, 6211-6217[Abstract/Free Full Text] Kasof, G.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	391	 19, 4390-4404[Abstract/Free Full Text] Basu, A.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	0	Three-Dimensional Structure of Human Follicle-Stimulating Hormone Kristin M.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	1	) Union College Schenectady, New York 12308 Division of Molecular Medicine (K.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	2	) Wadsworth Center Albany, New York 12201-0509.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS AND DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The crystal structure of a ssThr26Ala mutant of human follicle-stimulating hormone (hFSH) has been determined to 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The hFSH mutant was expressed in baculovirus-infected Hi5 insect cells and purified by affinity chromatography, using a sshFSH-specific monoclonal antibody.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The ssThr26Ala mutation results in elimination of the ssAsn24 glycosylation site, yielding protein more suitable for crystallization without affecting the receptor binding and signal transduction activity of the glycohormone.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The crystal structure has two independent hFSH molecules in the asymmetric unit and a solvent content of about 80%.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The - and sssubunits of hFSH have similar folds, consisting of central cystine-knot motifs from which three ss-hairpins extend.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The two subunits associate very tightly in a head-to-tail arrangement, forming an elongated, slightly curved structure, similar to that of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The hFSH heterodimers differ only in the conformations of the amino and carboxy termini and the second loop of the ss-subunit (L2ss).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Detailed comparison of the structures of hFSH and hCG reveals several differences in the ss-subunits that may be important with respect to receptor binding specificity or signal transduction.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These differences include conformational changes and/or differential distributions of polar or charged residues in loops L3ss (hFSH residues 62 to 73), the cystine noose, or determinant loop (residues 87 to 94), and the carboxy-terminal loop (residues 94 to 104).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	12	 An additional interesting feature of the hFSH structure is an extensive hydrophobic patch in the area formed by loops L1, L3, and ssL2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Glycosylation at Asn52 is well known to be required for full signal transduction activity and heterodimer stability.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The structure reveals an intersubunit hydrogen bonding interaction between this carbohydrate and ssTyr58, an indication of a mechanism by which the carbohydrate may stabilize the heterodimer.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	15	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS AND DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   FSH is a member of the family of pituitary glycoprotein hormones (GPH) that play key roles in human fertility.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The GPH, which also include CG, LH, and TSH, are heterodimers, each consisting of a common -subunit (92 amino acids) and a unique ss-subunit (111 amino acids in FSH) (1, 2, 3, 4).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	17	 FSH acts by binding to G protein-coupled receptors that signal, in part, through the protein kinase A pathway (5, 6).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	18	 FSH enables ovarian folliculogenesis to the antral follicle stage and is essential for Sertoli cell proliferation and maintenance of sperm quality in the testis.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The amino acids in GPH that have been identified as critical for receptor binding are striking in similarity, yet they are not the residues essential for signal transduction (7).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Identification of GPH residues that are key to signal transduction could provide for the development of molecular mimetics or antagonists of GPH action, with clinical applications in fertility management (8) and treatment of thyroid disorders (9).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	21	Glycosylation of the GPH has been shown to be important in circulatory persistence and clearance, and in bioactivity (10, 11, 12, 13, 14).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Each subunit contains two glycosylation sites: at Asn52 and Asn78 in the - subunit and at conserved sites in the ss-subunit, Asn7 and Asn24 in human FSH (hFSH).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	23	 ss-Subunit glycosylation has been reported to affect disulfide bond formation and rate of secretion, with site 2 having a greater effect than site 1, especially on secretion (15).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Glycosylation at Asn78 appears to be important for thermal stability (16).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Deglycosylation of hFSH and hCG at Asn52 has long been accepted to impair signal transduction while allowing full binding activity, suggesting that receptor binding and signal transduction are two separate functions involving different residues and that the carbohydrate is key to signal transduction.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Recent evidence suggests that deglycosylation at Asn52 causes hCG to be metastable, and dissociation of the subunits occurs at 37 C (17).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In that study, disulfide bonds engineered between the subunits could overcome the effect of deglycosylation on signal transduction.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Although such studies have not been performed for hFSH, they obscure previous results with deglycosylated GPH and demonstrate that the carbohydrate at Asn52 is not essential for full signal transduction if the subunit association is otherwise stabilized.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	29	 It remains unclear whether the carbohydrate, or the lack of it, affects the structure of all GPH, or whether the formation of intersubunit disulfide bonds stabilizes hCG in a conformation that is signal transduction competent.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	30	Previous structural studies of GPH heteroolimers are limited to two independent reports of the crystal structure of human CG (hCG), partially deglycosylated by hydrogen fluoride treatment (3, 4), and a recent report of a low resolution structure of the ternary complex of fully glycosylated hCG with two Fv fragments (18).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	31	 With the goal of determining the structure of fully active, glycosylated hFSH, we achieved high-level expression of hFSH in Hi5 insect cells and established a method for purification that produces biologically active hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	32	 As part of studies of the glycosylation of hFSH, it was observed that glycosylation at Asn24 of the ss-subunit is detectable in only about half of the molecules (7).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	33	 To reduce glycoform heterogeneity, in anticipation that this would facilitate crystallization, glycosylation at ssAsn24 was eliminated by site- directed mutagenesis, converting Thr26 to Ala.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	34	 This isoform of hFSH was fully active and yielded crystals suitable for x-ray diffraction.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Here, we report the structure of ssT26A-hFSH and compare it to that of hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	36	   RESULTS AND DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS AND DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Characterization of Recombinant hFSH-ssT26A Amino acid sequencing of purified, Hi5 insect cell-expressed, hFSH-ssT26A revealed N termini of -APDVQDCPEC and ss-CELTNITIAI, indicating that the -subunit signal peptide was cleaved as in mammalian cells but that the ss-subunit lacked the two amino-terminal residues (Asn, Ser).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Purified hFSH-ssT26A was similar in activity to hFSH expressed in insect cells, was stable during a 16-h incubation period at room temperature, and bound receptor, effectively competing with labeled pituitary hFSH for binding to hFSH receptors expressed in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	38	 As expected, the biological activity of hFSH-ssT26A was indistinguishable from wild-type hFSH, showing dose-response-related stimulation of progesterone production (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	39	 1C) in Y1 cells stably transfected with hFSHR.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	40	View larger version (21K):    Figure 1.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Characterization of the in Vitro Bioactivity of ssT26A hFSH and Wild-Type (Wt) hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	42	The data are representative of experiments repeated at least twice.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Error bars represent sample error.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	44	 A, Competition of recombinant wild-type hFSH (iFSH) and ssT26A hFSH with 125I-hFSH (pituitary) for hFSH receptors expressed in CHO cells.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	45	 B, Progesterone production induced by wild-type hFSH or ssT26A hFSH, measured in an in vitro bioassay.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	46	 C, cAMP production induced by treatment with either wild-type hFSH or ssT26A hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	47	  Crystallization The first hFSH crystals were obtained for glycohormone that was extracted from human pituitary glands, purified as previously described (19) and desialylated by neuraminidase treatment.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	48	4 M (NH4)2SO4 in phosphate buffer at pH 7.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	49	5 mm in all three dimensions, but required about 6 months to grow to full size and diffracted inconsistently, with some crystals diffracting to 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	50	8 A resolution but most diffracting to less than 5.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Next, crystals of insect cell-expressed wild-type hFSH were grown, initially starting by cross-seeding with crystals of the pituitary hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	52	 These crystals were more consistent in quality, all diffracting to about 4.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	53	0 A resolution, but still required several months to grow.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The crystals of the ssT26A mutant were grown by macroseeding methods under similar conditions, and initial crystals were obtained by cross-seeding with the recombinant wild-type hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The final crystallization conditions were similar to those of the initial pituitary protein conditions, except that the crystals grew most consistently at pH 9.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Crystals grew to full size in less than 1 month and all were of similar diffraction quality.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	57	Structure Determination The crystals belong to space group P41212 with cell parameters, a = 128.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Structure determination revealed the presence of two hFSH molecules in the asymmetric unit, with a solvent content of about 80%.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The structure was determined by multiple isomorphous replacement with anomalous scattering, using four heavy atom derivatives, followed by solvent flattening.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Continuous electron density for more than 95% of the main chain was observed in the initial 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The model was refined to an R value of 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	62	7% of the total data set) for all data from 30 to 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The final model contains residues 5 to 90 and ss3 to ss109 in hFSH molecule 1 (hFSH1) and residues 5 to 90 and ss3 to ss108 in hFSH molecule 2 (hFSH2) in addition to 14 sugar residues and 2 sulfate ions.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	64	 No attempt was made to include other solvent molecules because of the relatively low resolution of the structure and the uncertainty of the location of the disordered protein and carbohydrate moieties.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Thermal parameter refinement was performed in a blocked mode, with main chain atoms and side chain atoms of each residue represented as separate blocks.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The thermal parameters are high, due to a combination of the high solvent content and the high flexibility of the molecule, with an average for all protein atoms of 58 A2 and ranging from 28 A2 for residues in the core of the molecule to 100 A2 in some loops.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Figure 2 shows the initial experimental electron density maps of a representative loop, residues ss87 to 94.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The atomic coordinates and structure factors have been deposited with the Protein Data Bank, RCSB, entry number 1FL7.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	69	View larger version (44K):    Figure 2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Electron Density of a Representative Loop in hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	71	The model for residues ss87 to 94 is shown in black sticks with the disulfide between ss87-ss94 in a thicker line, and the 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	72	5 A experimental electron density map is displayed at a 1.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The refined average temperature factors for the residues included in the figure were 70A for the main chain atoms and 85A for the side chain atoms.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Figures 2 and 4 were created using the program Setor (46 ).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	75	  Overall Structure As expected, hFSH (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	76	 3) belongs to the family of cystine-knot growth factors (20, 21) and the overall fold is identical to that of hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Both the - and ss- subunits have similar topologies, in which the cystine knot is the central motif.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	78	 In this motif, a disulfide bond between Cys 10 (ss3) and 60 (ss51) passes through a ring defined by disulfide bonds from Cys 28 to 82 and from Cys 32 to 84.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Three ss-hairpins extend from the cystine knot, two of which end in tight ss-turns at one end of the molecule (loops L1 and L3), while the other one forms a longer, more open loop (L2) at the opposite end.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The L2 loop of the -subunit (L2) includes the only helical segment in the molecule, a 1.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	81	5-turn -helix that runs nearly perpendicular to the ss-strands.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The ss-hairpins are stabilized by, and associate through, disulfide bridges.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The disulfide bond pairings of hFSH, 7 to 31, 10 to 60, 28 to 82, 32 to 84, 59 to 87 and ss3 to 51, ss17 to 66, ss20 to 104, ss28 to 82, ss32 to 84, and ss87 to 94, are identical to those of hCG and contradict earlier biochemical assignments (22, 23).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The two subunits are aligned head to tail and are slightly wound around each other so that ssL2, L1, and L3 form one end of the elongated, curved heterodimer and L2, ssL1, and ssL3 form the other.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The two subunits are intimately associated via intermolecular contacts that bury 32% of the total solvent-accessible surface of the monomers.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	86	 A loop at the C terminus of the ss-subunit, residues ss84 to 104, wraps around ss-strands 2 and 3 of the -subunit, resulting in the -subunit being surrounded on both sides by the ss-subunit.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Consequently, this loop has been referred to as the "seat belt" loop in hCG (3).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	88	View larger version (38K):    Figure 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Cartoon Illustrating the Overall Fold of hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	90	The fold is typical of the cystine-knot growth factors in which both the -subunit (light gray ribbon) and the ss-subunit (dark gray ribbon) have similar topologies.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The carbohydrate and the disulfide bonds in both subunits are represented by ball-and-stick models.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The N and C termini of each subunit, the N-glycosylated Asn residues (ss7 = Asn7 from the sssubunit), and the loops discussed in the text are labeled.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Figures 3, 6, 7, and 8 were drawn with Molscript (47 ).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	94	  Insect cell-expressed glycoproteins are glycosylated by short high-mannose type, N-linked oligosaccharides, typically consisting of the core (Man)4-(GlcNAc)2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In both ssT26A hFSH molecules, interpretable electron density is observed for the two GlcNAcs at site 52 and ss7 and for two GlcNAcs and one Man at site 78.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Although some additional density is observed at all three sites in both hFSH molecules, disorder prevents modeling of the remaining oligosaccharide.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	97	Crystal Packing The two molecules in the asymmetric unit sit close together with their concave surfaces associated in clasped hands-like fashion (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Residues in loops L2, L3, ssL2, and the carboxy terminus of the - subunit of hFSH2 contact the carboxy-termini of both hFSH1 subunits as well as the hFSH1 seatbelt.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	99	 In total, the interactions render approximately 10% of the surface of the heterodimer solvent inaccessible.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Intermolecular contacts with symmetry-related molecules are limited to the loops at the ends of the molecules.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	101	 This packing arrangement results in an open crystal lattice with channels of about 70 A in diameter.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	102	 All carbohydrate chains extend into this open channel, as would be expected because the crystals are ultimately derived from the initial crystals produced from the more extensively glycosylated pituitary protein.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The average temperature factor of hFSH2, 49 A2, is significantly lower than that of hFSH1, 59A2, possibly due to the slightly larger number of crystal contacts in which hFSH2 is involved.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	104	View larger version (46K):    Figure 4.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Stereodiagram Showing the Crystal Packing of hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	106	Shown are all 16 hFSH heterodimers that have their center of mass within the unit cell.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The two dimers in the asymmetric unit associate tightly with their concave surfaces overlapping, while contacts with symmetry-related molecules are mostly limited to the ends of the molecules.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	108	  Comparison of the Two Molecules in the Asymmetric Unit The conformations of the two hFSH heterodimers in the asymmetric unit are similar, with a root mean square deviation (r.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	109	9 A for all 180 -carbon atoms (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Although the subunits associate in identical fashion in both heterodimers, there is a small difference in the angle between the subunits, which results in an r.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	111	6 A between the ss-subunits when the -subunits are superimposed.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This suggests that there is some flexibility in the association of subunits.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	113	 As expected, the core region of the protein, the cystine knot motifs, and the surrounding ss-strands have the same conformation in both molecules, and all of the major differences occur in the loops and at the amino and carboxy termini (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The C-terminal end of the -helix in loop 2 of the -subunit is less helical in hFSH2, resulting in a shift in the position of the -carbon of residue 48 by 2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	115	 ssL2 differs most, with its carboxy-terminal end shifted by about 5.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	116	 This shift appears to be correlated with a major difference in the conformation of the carboxy terminus of the -subunit, which lies in the middle of loop ssL2 in hFSH2 but is positioned away from the molecule in hFSH1.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The final large difference is in L3, which differs by about 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	118	7 A in the position of residue 72.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	119	 While these conformational differences between the two independent observations of the hFSH structure are indicative of the flexibility of the hFSH heterodimer, they are small compared with the differences between hFSH and hCG in many of the same loops.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	120	View larger version (32K):    Figure 5.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Difference Mapping of the hFSH and hCG Structures.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	122	A, Diagram showing the variation in temperature factor with residue number for the two hFSH molecules in the asymmetric unit: hFSH1 (thin lines) and hFSH2 (thick lines).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The average temperature factor for hFSH1 is higher than that for hFSH2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	124	 B, Diagram showing the -carbon atom r.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	125	 for the least-squares superposition of the two hFSH molecules (thin lines) and of hFSH2 with hCG (thick lines).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	126	 In the -subunit, both superpositions show that the largest deviations are seen around residue 72 (loop L3).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The largest deviations between hFSH and hCG are observed in the ss-subunit loops ssL1 around residue 25, ssL2 around residue 50, ssL3 around residue 80, and at the ss-carboxy terminus.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Large deviations are also observed in loop ssL2 in the comparison of hFSH1 and hFSH2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	129	 This suggests that ssL2 is quite flexible and can adopt a variety of conformations, while the changes in the other three regions of the protein may be important for receptor discrimination.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	130	 C, Alignment of the sequences of the ss-subunits of hFSH (top) and hCG (bottom) with the important loops labeled.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The cystine residues involved in the cystine knot are highlighted with filled diamonds of different shades according to their disulfide pairings.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The N-glycosylated asparagines are identified by an italicized N.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Major sequence differences can be found in ssL2, ssL3, the cystine noose, and at the ss-carboxy terminus.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The carboxy terminus of hCG sequence is truncated at residue 111 for clarity.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The hCG sequence numbering is indicated in parentheses.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	136	  View larger version (29K):    Figure 6.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Comparison of the Molecular Conformations of hFSH and hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	138	A, Superposition of hFSH2 (, green; ss, light blue) and hFSH1 (, yellow; ss, dark blue) shown in two perpendicular views and produced by least-squares fitting of the -carbon atoms.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	139	 B, Similar figure of the superposition of hFSH2 (, green; ss, light blue) and hCG (, orange; ss, magenta).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	140	  Comparison with hCG For the comparisons of the conformations of hFSH and hCG, the hCG coordinates with PDB code 1HCN (4) have been used because this structure was determined at somewhat higher resolution than the 1HRP structure (3).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	141	 However, the two structures were of the same crystal form and have an r.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	142	7 A, with maximum main chain differences of approximately 1 A in some of the loops.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	143	 In the absence of any systematic differences between the two structures, the conformational analysis presented here is relevant to both structures.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	144	hFSH and hCG have identical folds, but significant differences occur in the amino and carboxy termini and several loops (Figs.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	145	 As expected, the -subunits, with r.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	146	9 A for the least-squares fit of hCG with hFSH1 and hFSH2, respectively, are more similar than the ss-subunits, with r.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The largest differences in the ss-subunits occur in the three loops ssL1, ssL2, and ssL3, the cystine noose, and the ss-subunit carboxy-terminal loop (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	148	 ssL1 and ssL3, together with L2 and the C terminus of the ss-subunit, form one end of the heterodimer, extending beyond the area where the two subunits interact (Figs.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Comparison of the structures reveals large differences in the conformations of hFSH and hCG in this area, but no differences in the two independent molecules of hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The amino acid sequences of hFSH and hCG differ greatly in ssL3, with only 4 identical residues in the 13-residue span between hFSH residues ss64 and ss76.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In addition the loop includes three prolines in hCG but only one in hFSH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Consequently, the conformation of ssL3 of hFSH is a more curved ss-hairpin than hCG, resulting in a shift toward the concave surface of the heterodimer and nearer to the area of the ss- subunit carboxy terminus (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The distances between corresponding residues in the loop are as large as 6.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The amino acid sequences in ssL1 for hFSH and hCG are quite similar (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	155	 5C) and the conformation of the loop itself is also similar.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	156	 However, this loop moves by as much as 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	157	9 A) toward the concave side of the molecule in hFSH in concert with ssL3, because the two loops are tied together by the disulfide bridge, ssCys17-ssCys66.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	158	 These conformational changes are also correlated with conformational changes in L2 and the C terminus of the ss-subunit, which are discussed below.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	159	View larger version (19K):    Figure 7.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Overlap of Selected Areas of hFSH2 (, green; ss, blue) and hCG (, orange; ss, magenta).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The conformation adopted by ssL3 is different in the two hormones due to significant sequence differences.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Although the overall sequence and conformation of ssL1 is similar in hFSH and hCG, the tethering of ssL1 to ssL3 by a disulfide bridge results in a concerted movement of the two loops.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Sequence variation with respect to charged residues in this area results in a negatively charged patch on one side of the cystine noose in hFSH and several positively charged residues in hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	164	 This loop may be important for receptor discrimination.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	165	 c, The solvent-exposed hydrophobic patch in the area of L1, L3, and ssL2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The size and shape of the patch differs in hFSH and hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The unusually large hydrophobic surface area suggests importance for stabilizing intersubunit interaction and possibly for receptor binding.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	168	  The conformation of hCG loop ssL2 is quite different from either one of the conformations seen for hFSH (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	169	 6B), but the two hFSH molecules differ at this locus as much in conformation from each other as they differ from hCG (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	170	 While the difference between hFSH and hCG in part must result from differences in the sequences in this loop, including a variation in the presence of proline residues (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	171	 5C), overall this result suggests that the loop is highly flexible in the GPH.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The cystine noose, or determinant loop, is a short loop between two disulfide-linked cysteines, ss87 and ss94 in hFSH (ss93-ss100 in hCG) (24) located toward the center of the concave surface of the molecule, adjacent to L2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Residues in the cystine noose play a role in determining the specificity of hCG receptor (25) and FSH receptor (26) binding.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The main chain conformation of the loop is very similar in hFSH and hCG, although the entire loop is shifted by about 3 A at its tip (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	175	 This shift is part of the global conformational change at this end of the molecule, also including ssL1, ssL3, and L2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	176	 More important than the conformational differences between the cystine nooses are their strikingly different surface charge characteristics.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	177	 There are three negatively charged residues, Asp 88, Asp 90, and Asp 93, and no positively charged residues in hFSH, while hCG has two positively charged residues (Arg 94 and Arg 95) and one negatively charged residue (Asp 99).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The conserved aspartic acid residues near the C terminus of the cystine noose, Asp 93 in hFSH and Asp 99 in hCG, have similar conformations in the two hormones.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The structure is consistent with the biochemical data since this residue has been shown to be essential for both hFSH activity (7, 27) and hCG activity.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The three aspartic acid residues in hFSH create a negatively charged patch on one side of the cystine noose.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	181	 In contrast, the positively charged arginines in hCG are not arranged to form a charged patch; rather the side chains are directed to opposite sides of the loop (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	182	 These observations are consistent with biochemical data, showing that while neither hFSH Asp 88 nor Asp 90 is essential for hFSH binding to receptor (27), both play a role in discriminating between the hFSH and hCG/LH receptors (26).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	183	 5C) shows that the cystine noose and ssL3 are the only two areas where there is a significant charge differential between hFSH and hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The only other possibly significant area is in ssL2, but the change in this case is from a generally charged surface in hFSH to a generally uncharged surface in hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The carboxy terminus of the hFSH ss-subunit, residues 95 to 108, adopts a different conformation than in hCG, with maximum distances between equivalent residues of 7.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	186	 5B and 6B) at hFSH residue ss99.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Specifically, the loop spanning residues 95 to 103 in hFSH makes a tighter turn than the equivalent loop from 101 to 109 in hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Both hFSH molecules have identical conformations in this area, despite the fact that this loop in hFSH1 is involved in more intermolecular contacts than in hFSH2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Therefore, differences between hFSH and hCG are caused by divergent sequences in this area (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Biochemical data indicate that the ss-subunit carboxy terminus plays a role in hFSH receptor binding, because alanine substitution of the three residues Arg97-Gly98-Leu99 (27), as well as replacement of the hFSH residues 95 to 100 with the corresponding residues of human LH (hLH) (26), diminishes hFSH receptor binding.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	191	 However, swapping hLH residues for hFSH residues at this locus does not allow for LH receptor binding by the hFSH-LH chimera (26).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The biochemical data are consistent with the structure, in that these residues clearly adopt a different conformation, allowing for differential recognition by the appropriate receptor.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	193	 However, the changes in this region alone are not sufficient to change the receptor specificity of the hormone.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Comparison of the structures of hFSH and hCG indicate that glycosylation has no global effect on the glycohormone conformations.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Although the conformation of the insect cell-expressed, and fully active, hFSH differs significantly from that of more extensively deglycosylated, HF-treated hCG in several loops, none of these differences can be directly correlated with differences in the glycosylation.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	196	 The structure of hFSH reveals one likely mechanism by which the oligosaccharide contributes to heterodimer stability (17).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The nitrogen atom of the acetamido group of the Asn-proximal GlcNAc at Asn52 forms a hydrogen bond with the hydroxyl group of ssTyr58, thereby adding an additional intersubunit contact.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In hCG, the equivalent residue is Phe64, incapable of forming a similar hydrogen bond, but able to make a hydrophobic interaction with the hydrophobic side of the sugar ring.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	199	 (3) report contacts between the Asn52 carbohydrate and residues ssTyr59, ssVal62, ssPhe64, ssAla83, and ssThr97.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	200	 While the single additional hydrogen bond observed in the hFSH structure may not be adequate to explain the higher stability of the glycosylated heterodimer, it is quite possible that sugar groups not fully defined in the electron density map make additional contacts.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	201	 A propeller-shaped triad of aromatic residues, Phe17, Phe74, and ssTyr39, together with Pro16, Phe18, and Met71, forms a solvent-exposed hydrophobic patch at the end of the hFSH heterodimer composed of loops L1, L3, and ssL2 (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	202	 This region includes only three charged residues (Lys75, ssLys40, and ssAsp41), all of which are directed away from the hydrophobic patch.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	203	 In hCG, ssLeu45 replaces hFSH ssTyr 39 and the patch is smaller because of a difference in the conformation of the ssL2 loop.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	204	 This area may play a major role in receptor binding.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Although the relevance of the L1 loop in hFSH (residues 14 to 27) has not been evaluated by mutagenesis studies, epitope mapping with monoclonal antibodies revealed a discontinuous immunoneutralizing epitope comprised of residues 11 to 27 and 61 to 92 (29, 30).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Mutational analysis of Phe74 revealed only a modest decrease in hFSH binding to receptor.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In contrast to the importance of L1 and L3, alanine scanning mutagenesis has shown that ssL2 (residues 33 to 53) is not essential for hFSH binding to receptor (31).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Rather, ssL2 appears to be important in stabilizing the heterodimer association (32).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The -subunit carboxy terminus has been implicated in receptor binding in hCG (33, 34, 35), hFSH (36), and TSH (37).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Clearly, this region is very flexible in hFSH because it adopts different conformations in hFSH1 and hFSH2 and electron density is lacking for the last two residues, 91 to 92.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	211	 This makes it difficult to draw conclusions about how this region is involved in receptor binding.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The only clear difference between hFSH and hCG is the formation of a hydrogen bond between the side chain NH of Arg95 from the cystine noose of hCG with the carbonyl oxygen of 89, constraining the conformational flexibility of hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	213	 This bond is not possible in the hFSH structure, because the hFSH -carboxy terminus is not as close to the cystine noose.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	214	 This difference in conformation is interesting in the context of receptor interaction, as the residues in the carboxy terminus of the -subunit are essential for hFSH and hCG binding (34, 35, 36).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	215	Conclusion The overall structures of hFSH and hCG are similar, but several intriguing differences are observed in specific loops, especially in the ss-subunit.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The largest difference is at one end of the molecule where ssL1 and ssL3 move together toward the concave side of the molecule in hFSH compared with hCG.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	217	 In addition, the ssL3 loop has a very different conformation as a result of major differences in the amino acid sequence.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Currently, no biological data are available regarding the importance of these loops in receptor binding or signal transduction.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The three other areas with different conformations, the ss carboxy-terminal loop, the cystine noose, and the hydrophobic patch area between loops L1, L3, and ssL2 also have different surface characteristics.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	220	 In addition, several residues in these areas have been shown, by scanning alanine mutagenesis or epitope mapping, to play a role in receptor binding (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Interestingly, the ss-carboxy-terminal loop, the cystine noose, and the ssL1 and ssL3 loops are located on the concave side of the heterodimer (Fig.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	222	 8), resulting in a face that is very different in the two gonadotropins.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	223	 These differences are therefore very likely to be important for discrimination between hFSH and hCG by their respective receptors.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	224	View larger version (29K):    Figure 8.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Ribbon Image of the Structure of hFSH Highlighting Areas of Interest.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	226	Magenta, areas with known biological importance and structural differences with hCG; blue, areas of biological significance but no defined conformational difference with hCG; and, yellow: areas of conformational differences between hFSH and hCG, without known biological relevance.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Residues known to be important for hFSH-receptor binding are shown: Lys51 of L2, Ser85, Thr86, Tyr88, and Tyr89 of the carboxy terminus of the -subunit (blue) and Asp93 (red) on the ss-carboxy terminal loop.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The residues forming the exposed hydrophobic patch are shown in green.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	229	 All areas of interest, except the hydrophobic patch, are located at the concave surface of the molecule.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	230	     MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS AND DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Preparation of hFSH Isoform ssT26A Site-directed mutagenesis experiments, aimed at elimination of hFSHss glycosylation site 2, were performed as previously described for other hFSH mutants (36).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The oligonucleotide used to create the mutation was 5'-A-AGC-ATC-AAC-ACC- GCT-TGG-TGT-GCT-GGC-3'.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	232	Production of Recombinant hFSH Production of recombinant hFSH in insect cells was carried out using procedures as previously described (26, 31).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Each production run consisted of about 30 roller bottles, seeded with 1 x 108 Hi5 cells and kept at 27 C for 48 h.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	234	 At that time, virus was added directly to each flask [1.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	235	0 MOI (multiplicity of infection) of hFSHssT26A virus and 3.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	236	5 MOI of hFSH virus] and flasks were rotated for an additional 4 to 5 days.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Next, media were collected by centrifugation in 1-liter bottles (2,500 x g, 10 min).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The clarified media were pooled and made 1.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	239	0 mM with phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Typically, recombinant hFSH-ssT26A was expressed at levels of 2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	241	7 mg/liter (n = 9) as determined by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) (32).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Media (typically 4 liters) were then concentrated at 4 C utilizing an Amicon (Waltham, MA) radial flow cartridge (10,000 mwc), to a volume of about 200 ml, and then frozen until processed.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	243	 The concentrate was thawed, clarified by centrifugation (16,000 x g, 30 min) and then applied to the affinity column without further processing.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	244	Preparation of the Affinity Support An affinity column was prepared using monoclonal antibody (mAb) 46.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	245	 This antibody binds to both the monomeric ss-subunit of native hFSH, and the heterodimeric hormone, but has no measurable cross-reactivity with the -subunit or with hLH (19, 38).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	246	B7 was expanded as ascites tumors in mice (Animal Welfare Committee Approval was obtained for these studies).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	247	B7 ascitic fluid were diluted 1:3 with PBS and subjected to ammonium sulfate precipitation as follows.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Saturated ammonium sulfate (pH 7.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	249	2) was added to the diluted ascitic fluid in a ratio of 4.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	250	5 volumes of ammonium sulfate solution to 5.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The mixture was stirred (4 C, 30 min), and the antibody precipitate was collected by centrifugation (5, 858 x g, 15 min).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Each precipitate was dissolved in PBS and reprecipitated twice as before.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Wet pellets were dissolved and dialyzed against 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Dialyzed samples were clarified by centrifugation, the pH and conductivity were adjusted to the buffer values, and the sample was applied to a 1.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	255	9 x 18 cm diethylaminoethyl (DEAE) Sephacel column.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Antibody was eluted with a gradient of 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The procedure used for coupling of the DEAE Sephacel-purified antibody (100 mg) to CNBr-activated Sepharose was exactly as described by the manufacturer (Pharmacia Biotech, Piscataway, NJ).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	258	Purification of hFSH ssT26A Concentrates of conditioned media, collected from cells producing hFSH ssT26A, were applied directly to the affinity support.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The sample buffer and column buffer were 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	260	1 M potassium phosphate, made 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The absorbance (275 nm) of the fractions was determined during the procedure.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	262	 After a decrease of absorbance to baseline, elution buffer (0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	263	5 M NaCl) was pumped through the column.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Fractions were collected into tubes containing 2.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	265	0 M Tris base and mixed to neutralize each fraction.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	266	Biological Characterization of hFSH-ssT26A Heterodimer Recombinant hFSH-ssT26A was compared with wild-type hFSH in a RRA using CHO cells, stably expressing hFSH receptors (36, 39).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Signal transduction induced by hFSH-ssT26A was determined by measuring progesterone (36) or cAMP (38) production by Y1 cells that stably express hFSH receptors (39).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	268	Protein Crystallization Crystals of ssT26A hFSH were grown by macroseeding into drops containing 3  microl protein (9 mg/ml in 10 mM Tris, pH 7) and 1  microl reservoir solution.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	269	 The reservoir solution was 100 mM glycine, pH 9.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	270	Data Collection and Structure Determination The crystals were transferred to a solution consisting of the crystallization buffer enriched with 25% wt/vol sucrose before flash cooling in liquid nitrogen.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The crystals were highly sensitive to the addition of heavy atom compounds.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Crystals tolerated soaking in heavy atom solutions for no more than about 10 h, with some heavy atom compounds, especially platinum and mercury compounds resulting in significant degradation of the diffraction quality after as little as 2 h.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Data were collected at Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (SSRL) Beamline B9.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	274	1, processed with MOSFLM (40), and then scaled and merged with SCALA (40) (Table 1).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Initial MIRAS phases were calculated using SOLVE (41) (Table 1).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	276	 The correct space group and enantiomer were determining by examining the figure-of-merit (FOM) for both space groups with each hand.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	277	 This clearly indicated that P41212 was the correct space group, FOM 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	278	43, and that the positive hand was correct.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	279	 All four derivatives had relatively weak phasing power due to low occupancy, and the sites of the platinum and osmium derivatives were similar.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	280	 However, solvent flattening [CCP4 program DM (40)] greatly improved the quality of the phases because of the very high solvent content of the crystals (80%).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	281	 MIRAS phasing in program SOLVE resulted in an overall FOM of 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	282	 After solvent flattening, the electron density clearly showed two molecules in the asymmetric unit.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	283	  Structure Refinement An initial model was built into the MIRAS/solvent-flattened electron density map.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Rounds of simulated annealing refinement using the torsion angle dynamics option in the CNS (42) were followed by phase combination in SIGMAA (40) before rebuilding in O (43) during early stages of refinement.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Once the majority of the sequence had been placed in the model, composite omit maps in CNS were used for rebuilding in an effort to reduce model bias.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The quality of the model was monitored throughout with PROCHECK (44).
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Grouped temperature factor refinement, where the main chain atoms of each residue formed one group and the side chain atoms formed a second group, was used in later stages of refinement.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Thermal parameters that exceeded 100 A2 were reset to this value during the refinement.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Experiments were done using NCS constraints and restraints to tether the two molecules in the asymmetric unit, but in all cases this caused Rfree to increase.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	290	 The final hFSH structure has an R value of 25.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The model contains 2,992 protein atoms, 14 carbohydrate residues, and 2 sulfate ions.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	292	3% of residues in the most favored regions of the Ramachandran plot, and only three residues (0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	293	9%) from the loops in disallowed regions.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	294	 values from ideality for the protein are as follows: bonds, 0.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	295	Structure Comparisons/Surface Area Calculations Protein structures were compared using LSQMAN (45), and values quoted in the text are the results of comparing regions of the structure after the entire structure was superimposed by least-squares fitting of the -carbon atoms only.
0.15123306.11222739.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Solvent-accessible surface area was calculated using CNS with a 1.

0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Institut fur Biotechnologie, Martin-Luther-Universitat Halle-Wittenberg, Kurt-Mothes-Str.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	3	 3, 06120 Halle and 2 ACGT Progenomics AG, Weinbergweg 22, 06120 Halle, Saale, Germany.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	4	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion References   The development of novel delivery systems for therapeutic substances includes targeting of the carriers to a specific site or tissue within the body of the recipient.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	5	 This can be accomplished by appropriate receptor-binding domains and requires linking of these domains to the carrier.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We have used recombinantly expressed polyomavirus-like particles as a model system and inserted the sequence of a WW domain into different surface loops of the viral capsid protein VP1.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In one variant, the WW domain maintained its highly selective binding properties of proline-rich ligands and showed an increased affinity but also an accelerated association/dissociation equilibrium compared to the isolated WW domain, thus allowing a short-term coupling of external ligands onto the surface of the virus-like particles.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	8	Keywords: cellular targeting/drug delivery/polyomavirus VP1/protein design/WW domain.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	9	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion References   In recent years, there have been intense efforts to generate targetable, injectable vectors for gene and drug delivery based on a variety of viral and non-viral systems (Anderson, 1998).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	10	 It is envisaged that the ideal targeted vector would be administered by intravenous infusion or injection, and then concentrates in the tissues and organs harboring the targeted cells (Peng and Russel, 1999).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Strategies to achieve a cell-type specific targeting often use direct genetic modification of the coat proteins with receptor-binding domains or sequences, e.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	12	 the insertion of integrin-binding RGD sequences into an adenoviral capsid (Wickham et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Another approach is the use of soluble bifunctional crosslinkers that bind both to the vector and to a cell-surface receptor (Douglas et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	14	 A combined approach is to display an immunoglobulin-binding domain of protein A on the vector as a genetic fusion to the coat protein, and then use a monoclonal antibody to crosslink the vector with the targeted cell (Ohno and Meruelo, 1997; Ohno et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Here, we investigate a more general strategy using a genetic fusion of a viral capsid protein with a WW domain, in order to bind any recombinantly produced polyproline-tagged protein which can be, for example, an antibody or a receptor-binding domain.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	16	Surface loops of viral capsid proteins often show a high sequence variability due to the influence of the immune system in viral life-cycles which makes these loops susceptible to the insertion of foreign sequences (Stirk and Thornton, 1994).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Recombinantly expressed polyomavirus-like particles were used as a model for a viral protein shell.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The outer capsid protein VP1 of murine polyomavirus can be expressed from recombinant Escherichia coli (Leavitt et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	19	 It is a pentameric protein which forms virus-like particles in vitro consisting of 72 pentamers (Salunke et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The in vitro assembly process was studied in great detail and is thought to involve a pre-existing equilibrium between free capsomeres and capsids which is completely shifted to capsids upon oxidation of a single disulfide bridge (Schmidt et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The crystal structures of the capsid and of truncated pentameric VP1 have been reported (Stehle et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	22	, 1994; Stehle and Harrison, 1996, 1997).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Polyomavirus VP1 gained attention for the in vitro packaging of plasmid DNA and oligonucleotides for the development of non-viral gene transfer vectors (Forstova et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	24	In order to specifically bind proline-rich ligands onto the outer surface of VP1 capsids, the sequence of a WW domain was genetically fused into ss-turns of VP1.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	25	 WW domains are the smallest protein domains known so far and were first discovered in the Yes-kinase associated protein (YAP) of Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Bork and Sudol, 1994; Sudol et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	26	 They were named after two conserved tryptophan residues which are essential for the maintenance of the native fold and for ligand binding (Koepf et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Until now, WW domains were found in several proteins of different species where they contribute to signal transduction processes or to protein to protein interactions in general.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In analogy to SH3 domains, WW domains bind proline-rich peptide sequences which differ in their consensus sequences (Pawson and Scott, 1997).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	29	 WW domains can either be subdivided into four classes according to their binding specificity (Bedford et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	30	, 2000) or into three subclasses according to sequence similarity (Macias et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The NMR structures of WW domains representing all three sequence subtypes have been reported, including the YAP WW domain in complex with a proline-rich peptide (Macias et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	32	, 1996) and the FBP28 and YJQ8 WW domains (Macias et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The WW domain contains a three-stranded antiparallel ss-sheet; the proline-rich peptide is mostly bound by hydrophobic interactions.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In this study the first of two WW domains of the mouse formin-binding protein 11 (FBP11) was used which binds PPLP-motifs (Chan et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The affinity of this WW domain to its ligand is the highest reported so far for WW domains.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Its equilibrium dissociation constant KD is 21 nM (Bedford et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	37	   Materials and methods Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion References   Protein modeling.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	38	The structure of VP1-WW150 was modeled using the program Modeller 4 (Sali and Blundell, 1993) based on the published structures of VP1 at 1.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	39	65 A (Stehle and Harrison, 1996, 1997).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The inserted FBP11 WW domain was modeled using the NMR structure of the YAP WW domain (Macias et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Figures were generated by MolScript (Kraulis, 1991) and Raster3D (Merritt and Bacon, 1997).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	42	Cloning and vector construction.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	43	The first FBP11 WW domain was genetically fused into the VP1 sequence as shown in Figure 2 using the oligonucleotides FBP11-WWa-5' (5'-ATACTCTTCA GGCAGCGGCT GGACAGAACA TAAATCACCT GATGG-3'), FBP11-WWa-3' (5'-ATACTCTTCT ACCACTACCA TCATCCGGCT TTTCCCAGGT AGACTG-3'), VP1-150-WWaC (5'-ATACTCTTCA GGTAGCGGCG TAAACACAAA AGGAATTTCC ACTCCAG-3'), VP1-150-WWaN (5'-ATACTCTTCA GCCGCTGCCT GTATCTGTCG GTTTGTTGAA CCCATG-3'), VP1-292-WWaC (5'-ATACTCTTCA GGTAGCGGCG TTACAAGAAA CTATGATGTC CATCAC-3'), VP1-292-WWaN (5'-ATACTCTTCA GCCGCTGCCC CAGCCCATTA TATCTACGCT CGAG-3'), VP1-Nde I-5' (5'-TATACATATG GCCCCCAAAA GAAAAAGC-3') and VP1-Sma I-3' (5'-ATATCCCGGG AGGAAATACA GTCTTTGTTT TTCC-3').
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The resulting final PCR product was cloned via introduced NdeI and SmaI restriction sites into the plasmid pET21-Int which contained a T7lac-promoter for high level expression in E.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	45	coli, and a C-terminal fusion with an intein and a chitin-binding domain for affinity chromatography (Schmidt et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	46	View larger version (55K):    Fig.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Cloning of the fusion constructs VP1-WW150 and VP1-WW292.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The strategy avoids changes in the original sequences and involves the ligation and reamplification of three separate fragments that were generated by PCR.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The recognition sequence of the endonuclease Eam1 104 I is printed in bold letters.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	50	  Protein expression and purification.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	51	All proteins were expressed from recombinant E.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	52	coli as C-terminal fusion proteins with modified intein and chitin-binding domains and were purified as described before (Chong et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	53	In vitro assembly and size-exclusion chromatography.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	54	Particles were assembled in vitro according to Salunke et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	55	 For the binding onto virus-like particles the proline-rich ligands were added after completion of the assembly process.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The capsid assembly was quantitatively analyzed by size-exclusion chromatography using 14 ml TSKgel 5000/6000PWXL columns (Tosoh Biosep, Stuttgart, Germany) as described before (Schmidt et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	57	In order to determine the affinity of the VP1-WW fusion proteins to polyproline sequences, surface plasmon resonance was measured using a Biacore X (Biacore AB, Uppsala, Sweden) and a CM5 sensorchip which was coated with PPLP peptide (sequence: CSGP6PPLP) following the manufacturer's protocol.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The protein concentrations were varied between 5 and 50 nM.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	59	 For the screening of different buffers and additives the protein solution was diluted in the buffer which was also used for the measurement.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Kinetic parameters were calculated with the BIAevaluation software using a simple Langmuir binding model.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	61	Circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	62	Far-UV CD spectra of VP1 variants were measured from 195 to 260 nm in 0.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The proteins (concentration: 0.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	64	0 mg/ml) were dialyzed against a buffer containing 10 mM HEPES, 100 mM NaCl, pH 7.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The secondary structure contents of the proteins were calculated with the program CDNN (Bohm et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	66	, 1992) from the buffer-corrected spectra.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	67	For electron microscopy studies, an EM 912 instrument (Zeiss) was used with a magnification factor of 63 000.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Staining of the specimen was performed with uranyl acetate on bacitracin-incubated (0.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	69	1 mg/ml, 1 min) copper to carbon-grids according to standard protocols.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	70	   Results Top Abstract Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion References   Protein design and model building.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	71	Two variants of the fusion protein were designed for the presentation of the WW domain on the surface of polyomavirus-like particles.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The first incorporates the WW domain in the DE loop at position 150 in the VP1 sequence and the second in the HI loop at position 292.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Both loops are well accessible from the outer surface and are flexible according to the temperature factors determined from crystallographic data (Stehle and Harrison, 1996).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	74	 These positions are also distant from the CD loop and C-terminal sequences which are required for the formation of virus-like particles.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Therefore, insertions at these positions should not inhibit the formation of virus-like particles.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	76	 A sequence alignment did not reveal any conservation in those regions between polyomavirus strains from different species (data not shown).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The WW domain insert was flanked by spacers of five amino acids consisting of serine/glycine repeats to allow maximal flexibility and solubility.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The overall size of the inserted sequence was 38 amino acids.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	79	 A model of the VP1-WW150 structure is presented in Figure 1.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	80	View larger version (35K):    Fig.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Model structure of VP1-WW150: (a) monomeric subunit and (b) pentameric capsomere.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The WW domain is represented in purple and the serine/glycine-linker in blue.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The WW domain folds towards the central hole of the capsomere and does not interfere with the pentameric structure.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	84	  Cloning and protein expression.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	85	For the genetic fusion of the WW domain into the VP1 sequence, PCR products with overhangs containing the serine/glycine linker sequences and recognition sites for the type IIs restriction endonuclease Eam1 104 I were generated (Figure 2).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Eam1 104 I cleaves outside its recognition sequence and therefore allows ligation of fragments without the introduction of suitable restriction sites.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	87	The expression of both proteins as C-terminal fusions with intein and chitin-binding domains allowed a single-step purification (Chong et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	88	, 2000) and yielded approximately 6 mg of purified protein per liter of culture medium.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	89	CD analysis reveals increased ss-sheet contents.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	90	Far-UV CD spectra were recorded and compared with the authentic VP1 in order to verify the native fold of the VP1-WW fusion proteins (Figure 3).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The spectra of VP1 and VP1-WW292 had similar shapes, whereas the VP1-WW150 spectrum had a significantly increased negative ellipticity difference () below 207 nm, indicating a higher portion of ss-sheet secondary structure.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Secondary structure deconvolution of the spectra revealed an increase of antiparallel ss-sheets in VP1-WW150 and VP1-WW292, which was, however, significantly higher for VP1-WW150.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The difference spectra of VP1-WW150/VP1-WW292 minus VP1 should represent the spectrum of the single WW domain (Figure 3).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The difference CD spectrum of VP1-WW150 had a maximum at 225 nm and an intense negative ellipticity at 198 nm.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	95	 This spectrum corresponds to a typical WW domain spectrum that is shifted approximately 5 nm towards shorter wavelengths (Macias et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	96	, 2000), indicating that the WW domain obtains its native fold in the fusion protein VP1-WW150.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In contrast, the difference spectrum of VP1-WW292 showed a much smaller amplitude, suggesting that the WW domain is not or only partially folded in this construct.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	98	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	99	 (a) CD spectra of pentameric VP1, VP1-WW150 and VP1-WW292.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	100	 (b) Deconvolution with the program CDNN (Bohm et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	101	, 1992) indicates an increased secondary structure content of antiparallel ss-sheet in the fusion constructs.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	102	 (c) Difference spectra of VP1-WW150/VP1-WW292 minus VP1, representing the spectra of the WW domains in the fusion proteins as described in the literature.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	103	 (d) Thermal denaturation experiments demonstrate that the thermal stability of VP1-WW150 is 6 degrees C lower than that of VP1 (51 degrees C).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	104	 VP1-WW292 starts to aggregate at 40 degrees C.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	105	  Ellipticity changes during thermal denaturation yielded a Tm of 51 degrees C for the VP1 capsomer (Figure 3).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The thermal transition midpoint for VP1-WW150 was lowered by 6 degrees C to 45 degrees C.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	107	 This value corresponds well to the typical midpoint transition temperature determined for a prototype WW domain (44 degrees C; Macias et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The denaturation of VP1-WW292 did not have a sigmoidal shape and began to decrease already at 40 degrees C and increased again beyond 60 degrees C, probably due to aggregation followed by sedimentation of the protein that may be caused by large unfolded regions in the protein.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The starting aggregation at 40 degrees C was therefore set to be the starting point of thermal denaturation of VP1-WW292.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	110	VP1-WW150 specifically binds proline-rich ligands.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	111	For an analysis of the binding properties of the inserted WW domains, a proline-rich peptide with the sequence +H3N-CSGP6PPLP-COOminus; was immobilized via its N-terminal cysteine residue on the surface of a sensorchip for surface plasmon resonance measurements.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This peptide contains the PPLP consensus motif that makes it an ideal ligand for binding of the FBP11 WW domain used in this study (Bedford et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The sensorchip was tested with a linear construct of the WW domain as an N-terminal fusion with glutathione-S-transferase (GST-WW).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	114	 For this protein, the equilibrium dissociation constant KD was determined to be 18 nM (Table I), in good agreement with the value of 21 nM published earlier (Bedford et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Kinetic parameters of the binding reaction of the WW domain to a proline-rich peptide using a Langmuir binding model   The kinetic parameters of the interaction of the WW domains within the VP1 sequence with the peptide were determined with serial dilutions of the fusion proteins under different buffer conditions.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	116	 VP1 without a WW domain did not interact with the sensorchip surface or with the immobilized peptide (data not shown).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The protein VP1-WW292 did not bind to the ligand under any condition tested so far, indicating that the WW domain in this construct did not obtain a native fold or had a dramatically lowered affinity which, therefore, could not be measured using surface plasmon resonance.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	118	However, VP1-WW150 showed a high affinity for the ligand (Figure 4).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Using the same conditions as for GST-WW, the equilibrium dissociation constant KD of VP1-WW150 was increased to 7.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	120	7  plus or minus  5 nM (Table I).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	121	 VP1-WW150 exhibited a high affinity for the proline-rich ligand in the range of KD = 4 to 15 nM under all buffer conditions tested.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	122	 In order to mimic a cell culture or physiological system, the measurement was carried out in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and in Dulbecco's modified Eagle cell culture medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The serum proteins did not compete with the binding sites on the VP1 surface and their presence did not inhibit the specific binding of VP1-WW150 to its PPLP-ligand, a prerequisite for therapeutic applications.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Although the equilibrium constants were similar for the inserted and the linear WW domain, the interaction of the inserted WW domain is accompanied by an accelerated exchange of the ligands (Table I).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Association and dissociation reactions (represented by the association/dissociation rate constants ka and kd in Table I) of VP1-WW150 were approximately 10 times faster than the respective values of GST-WW.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	126	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Surface plasmon resonance with an immobilized PPLP ligand.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Analysis with WW domain concentrations of 20, 15, 10 and 5 nM, respectively, in a buffer containing 20 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, 200 mM NaCl, pH 7.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	129	2 of (a) cysteine free VP1-WW150 and (b) VP1-WW150 containing cysteines 19 and 114.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	130	  Altered in vitro assembly properties of VP1-WW fusion proteins.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	131	An essential function of VP1 is its ability to form virus-like particles in vitro.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	132	 For easier handling, the VP1-WW fusion proteins used so far did not contain cysteine residues and were therefore unable to form an intrapentameric disulfide bridge which is needed for a complete capsid assembly.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	133	 However, upon addition of Ca2+ ions an equilibrium with 55% reduced capsids and 45% free capsomeres should be reached which is an early step during the assembly process (Schmidt et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	134	 However, removal of EDTA and the addition of Ca2+ resulted in a loss of 90% of the protein due to significant aggregation of VP1-WW150; this indicated a strong decrease of the solubility of the reduced capsid species which resulted in precipitation until the protein concentration fell below a critical limit.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	135	 This was not due to aggregation via the WW domain in the presence of Ca2+ since the solubility of similar concentrations of the GST-WW protein did not decrease upon addition of CaCl2 (data not shown).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Also, in contrast to VP1-WW150, the protein VP1-WW292 did not aggregate and remained in solution.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	137	The in vitro assembly can be quantitatively analyzed by size-exclusion chromatography (Schmidt et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Analysis of the assembly of the VP1-WW proteins revealed that VP1-WW150 that still remained in solution assembled to only 15% (Figure 5).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	139	 VP1-WW292 did not form capsids at all and represents the first described variant of VP1 which is totally blocked in capsid formation, although the C-terminal domain for the interaction of capsomeres is present (Figure 5).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	140	 These results demonstrate that large inserts, like the 38 amino acids containing the WW domain, into the viral capsid protein had long-distance effects on parts of the protein which are essential for capsid formation.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	141	View larger version (73K):    Fig.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In vitro assembly of VP1-WW fusion proteins.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	143	 (a) Size-exclusion chromatography (TSKgel 5000PWXL) demonstrates that only VP1-WW150, which contains cysteines 19 and 114, forms quantitatively virus-like particles.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Elution volumes of capsids (6 to 8 ml) and free capsomeres (10 to 11 ml) are marked.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	145	 (b) Electron microscopy shows an homogeneous population of disulfide-stabilized VP1-WW150 capsids.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	146	  An intrapentameric disulfide bridge between cysteines 19 and 114 of neighboring monomers is needed for a complete capsid assembly of the wild-type protein (Stehle et al.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In order to improve the inefficient cysteine-free in vitro assembly and to test whether oxidized, disulfide-linked VP1-WW150 capsids are also prone to aggregation, cysteines 19 and 114 were reintroduced into VP1-WW150.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The disulfide bridge forming variant of VP1-WW150 had no differences in the binding properties of proline-rich ligands (Figure 4; Table I) and did not aggregate upon initiation of in vitro assembly by dialysis.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Size-exclusion chromatography demonstrated that the assembly efficiency of the modified protein was improved to  > 95%, similar to the wild-type protein.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Electron micrographs also showed an homogeneous population of virus-like particles consisting of VP-WW150 (Figure 5).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	151	 This single intrapentameric disulfide bridge could therefore completely restore the assembly properties of the wild-type protein.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	152	VP1-WW150 capsids can bind external ligands in solution.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	153	In order to test the ability of polyomavirus-like particles to bind external ligands in solution, as would be necessary for therapeutic applications, completely assembled disulfide stabilized capsids of VP1-WW150 were mixed with an equal molar amount of green fluorescent protein (GFP) that was tagged with a PPLP motif at its C-terminus.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The formation of the complex consisting of capsids and GFP was analyzed by size-exclusion chromatography (Figure 6).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	155	 GFP could be detected by its specific absorbance at 490 nm while detecting the protein absorbance at 280 nm for both capsids and GFP in parallel.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Absorbance at 490 nm at the elution volume of the capsids represented GFP bound to the particle's surfaces.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Control experiments with VP1 wild-type capsids showed no co-elution of GFP with the capsids (data not shown).
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Integration of the peak areas and calculation of the molar ratio of capsids and GFP, respectively, indicated that 25  plus or minus  5 molecules of GFP were bound to the capsid surface, demonstrating the general applicability of our approach.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The binding ratio was probably limited by the rapid dissociation reaction of the inserted WW domain.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	160	View larger version (31K):    Fig.
0.15323845.11739895.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Coupling of polyproline-tagged GFP onto the surface of virus-like particles.
